title: Outside the Law (Hors-la-loi)
review1: It's a big, bold film defined by a reserved passion, a stately style and strong performances from its three leads.
review2: It's a ham-handed "issue" movie that preaches to the converted, but the mid-century threads look cool and those Coppola moments remain effective all these years later.
review3: Think The Godfather II as told through France vs. Algeria tensions, and you have the essence of Rachid Bouchareb's vivid combo crime saga, action movie and historical drama.
review4: "Outside the Law" is an epic film about Algeria's fight for liberation from France, with three outstanding performances and a grand, sweeping feel.
review5: A gripping French-Algerian coproduction that makes Algeria's epic struggle for independence from France look like a gangster movie.

title: The Music Never Stopped
review1: A wounded and hopeful take on generation gaps and the wider, nearly unbridgeable chasms created by neurological disaster.
review2: A medley of "Memento," "The King's Speech" and "Hair," "The Music Never Stopped" is sentimental pop packaged as a profound rock opera.
review3: The sentiments are real without succumbing to exaggerated sentimentality, thanks in large part to that big lovable lug, J.K. Simmons.
review4: Kohlberg is determined to manipulate your emotions; he succeeds.
review5: It's sentimental, yet so honest and eccentric that it rises above schmaltz.

title: Cold Weather
review1: The result is pretty entertaining, though most of that entertainment derives from Katz's skillful exploitation of gumshoe formula.
review2: Katz's characters are beautifully observed, the autumnal photography of downtown Portland is lovely, and the tension is expertly maintained...
review3: This is a slacker detective story, emphasis on the slack, and if you can downshift into its loping rhythms, it's pretty wonderful.
review4: Katz is a triple threat, his editing every bit as important as his writing and directing for his movies' sense of place, shifting tonalities, and emotional vibrations.
review5: 'Cold Weather' is an engaging and inventive act of genre-tweaking with no bells and whistles attached, and it represents a huge leap forward for an increasingly promising filmmaker.

title: The Perfect Game
review1: Notable only for being a catalog of just about every kid-pic cliche' ever committed to film.
review2: Director William Dear is not one to miss a sentimental beat.
review3: [From] the second minute of the movie I knew every single thing that was going to happen and there was not a single surprise.
review4: It's an unabashedly corny but occasionally stirring dramedy based on the true-life story of scrappy young baseball players from Mexico.
review5: So overwhelmed by its own based-on-actual-events tale that it can't find the tone to tell it effectively.

title: Blossoms in the Dust
review1: Result is a sentimentally sugary flavor which also extends over the romantic portions of the film. There is no comedy relief.
review2: Pretty Technicolor, but the tearjerking is shameless.
review3: With lovely Greer Garson playing the leading role, the spirit of the story is maintained on a level generally above its frequent insipid spots.
review4: It was a noble deed and a noble effort to make a biography about a woman who was virtually unknown outside Texas, but the picture was long, overly teary, and didn't excite too many people at the box office, although it did make money.
review5: Littered with stilted melodrama, wooden dialogue, and over-the-top courtroom showdowns.

title: Dear Lemon Lima
review1: If 'Napoleon Dynamite' had had a bigger heart it may have turned out like this sweet and smart comedy about high school misfits.
review2: The filmmaker knows how to gently skew reality just enough to offset the excess cuteness.
review3: It's more appealing than anything Hollywood has recently offered the 8- to 13-year-old female demographic.
review4: There's almost nowhere for such a plot to go that audiences haven't seen countless times before.
review5: A spoonful of sugar, to say nothing of bright pastel colors and friendly bunny rabbits, helps the medicine go down in the sometimes ungainly but often winning prep school comedy Dear Lemon Lima.

title: Meek's Cutoff
review1: Imagine a collaboration between John Ford and Wallace Stevens and you might get a sense of what Kelly Reichardt pulls off here: a sincere re-creation of the pioneer experience, brought to life through careful, often unexpected detail.
review2: Greatly enhanced by the performances of Michelle Williams and Bruce Greenwood, director Kelly Reichardt's film quietly becomes engrossing - it almost sneaks up on you.
review3: I was hypnotized from the opening sequence.
review4: Meek's Cutoff is a thoughtful, and intimate narrative that is beautifully shot and has outstanding direction.
review5: Reichardt's film is - to put it simply - a masterpiece.

title: Dream Home
review1: For all the film's bleak ironies, Lai-sheung's brutal asphyxiation of a pregnant woman, who aborts her child while dying, destroys any residual empathy.
review2: A surprisingly high-end slasher exploit, but there's a big batch of interesting ideas tucked inside this flick.
review3: The carnage is excruciating and sometimes funny, and the quiet rage of Ho's heroine is almost comprehensible. But the flashback format is clumsy and confusing, and the violence veers toward the misogynistic.
review4: We're billboarding this bloodbath because it's stylish, jaw-droppingly funny and features a knockout performance by Ho, who brings to mind the young Deneuve of "Repulsion."
review5: Horror fans will be elated with what could be the bravest slasher effort of the last couple years.

title: The Last Godfather
review1: "The Last Godfather" is more harmlessly amiable than outright awful, though it might still be best to just forget about it.
review2: although not offensively bad, there is little to recommend this knockabout comedy.

title: Clash
review1: A dazzling Vietnamese martial arts movie with a soul, a stylish, gorgeously photographed film in which action sequences are punctuated by serene vistas of natural beauty.
review2: an impressive all-out actioner that fans of films such as Jason Statham's Transporter trilogy will adore.

title: Super
review1: If I hadn't foolishly gone and saw Sucker Punch a couple weeks ago, this would be the worst film of the year.
review2: Gunn's movie is an ingeniously nasty concoction that feeds the cult of superhero fandom back into itself.
review3: Great dark humor and enjoyable performances make this one a winner. Surprisingly, the animated sequences also work quite well.
review4: The graphic violence spatters along for an hour and a half until we reach that point when writer-director James Gunn says, "That's all I've got" and basically gives up.
review5: [Not] an easily digestible movie but this is ... the point - in a world where everything isn't as cut and dry as 'good versus evil', rationality is increasingly rare.

title: The Conspirator
review1: Robert Redford teams with The American Film Company for The Conspirator, a project better left to the History Channel than the big screen.
review2: Wonderfully cast and carefully shot, there's barely a hint of a great filmmaker working with a fraction of his normal budget in this period piece...
review3: If nothing else, this is certain to have a long life playing in middle school history classes for decades to come.
review4: The Conspirator deserves a lot more praise than it got on initial release: yes it is slow in parts and even provocatively tentative, but it is intricately crafted, a wonderful example of precision and attention to detail.
review5: full review at Movies for the Masses

title: Jane Eyre
review1: Screenwriter Moira Buffini sticks pretty closely to the novel, and director Cary Fukunaga conjures a drab tone that nicely sets off the characters' violent but rigidly controlled passions.
review2: Duttiful, for the most part adequate and, as far as I can see, it has no compelling reason to exist
review3: A rather anemic version of Charlotte Bronte's classic novel, Focus Film and BBC's Jane Eyre favors atmosphere over strong narrative.
review4: Pretty as a postcard -- a postcard of a dark grey, gloomy, windswept moor
review5: Thanks to this beautifully crafted treatment, newcomers and veterans will learn something about the past and more than likely a few things (wanted or not) about themselves.

title: Something Borrowed
review1: From its empty soul to its poorly framed shots ready for pan-and-scan conversion, Something Borrowed seems primed to play on Saturday afternoons on E!, sandwiched between reruns of Keeping Up with the Kardashians...
review2: Chemistry-free casting (Ginnifer Goodwin and John Krasinski) and a flawed premise, not the recipe for a great romance
review3: The work of the lead trio keeps the movie from ever becoming something blue.
review4: No romantic drama has ever been so misguided and eager for you to root against its characters. This tacky, morally abhorrent film is unbearable.
review5: While Something Borrowed obviously wants to explore themes of competitiveness and betrayal in female friendships, it seems to feel compelled to hit pre-programmed chick flick beats at regular intervals.

title: The Grace Card
review1: As stiff as it is sincere.
review2: Movie goers likely will look over The Grace Card's entertainment value to focus on this simple prescription for how to gracefully love your neighbor.
review3: Blessed with fine performances, credible dialogue and slick production values that belie a reportedly paltry budget, The Grace Card ranks among the better religious-themed indies released in recent years.
review4: It's OK to put out a movie with a message. But rendering even potentially dramatic stories so inoffensive that they bear no relation to reality makes for middling drama.
review5: Despite its lapse into melodrama, this faith-based drama is surprisingly effective.

title: Meet Monica Velour
review1: Pretty good performance, awfully lame movie.
review2: Had first-time director Keith Bearden been as devoted to keeping Meet Monica Velour on track as he did to coming up with punderful porn flick names, he could have had a satisfying dark comedy on his hands.
review3: The role of a former star of the ''golden age'' of porn sounds perfect for Kim Cattrall, and she handles it nicely - at least, in the rare moments when this indie comedy isn't terminally contrived.
review4: You really come away wishing Cattrall could take this character to a more serious film. Who better to show the flip side of beauty?
review5: Better than its premise would suggest, the film works to the degree that it does thanks to the well-drawn characterizations and the frequent doses of sly, subtle humor.

title: The Bang Bang Club
review1: A queasy mix of high-toned intentions and commercial compromises.
review2: Silver cut his teeth in documentaries and it shows in the skilled on-the-ground style of the camerawork. But visuals are only half the story and the plot doesn't keep up.
review3: "The Bang Bang Club" divulges little insight into what keeps this dangerous brotherhood banging away around the world.
review4: This is one of those relatively rare movies that gets better and smarter as it goes along...
review5: Seldom does "The Bang Bang Club" show much interest in the big picture of South Africa.

title: Road To Nowhere
review1: The final scene offers clarity, at least, if not a satisfying payoff.
review2: "The Road to Nowhere" plays like an exercise in frustrating audiences.
review3: Ultimately, the film gets too clever and confusing for its own good, while the slow pacing zaps momentum from the story (and the story within the story).
review4: A rabbit hole of enigmatic characters and swampy motives...Shot by shot, the film has a burnished, beautiful sheen.
review5: "Road to Nowhere" is a beautifully made, glorious mess.

title: I Will Follow
review1: There's smooth-jazz polish to the emotions, even the unpleasant ones, in "I Will Follow."
review2: I Will Follow, Ava DuVernay's triumphant feature debut, is a life-affirming portrait of a woman, Maye (Salli Richardson-Whitfield), juggling all kinds of loss.
review3: This touching if insular drama about a woman grieving over the recent death of her aunt is well acted and incisively observed, although it's ultimately too low-key to have much dramatic impact.
review4: Shows a certain amount of promise but often falls prey to easy emotional beats and an overall sentimentality when it should push for moments less obvious, more rare, true and insightful.
review5: As a director, DuVernay handles her actors with care, though visually the picture sometimes betrays its shoestring budget.

title: The High Cost of Living
review1: So artistically well-intentioned and earnest in its ambitions that you can almost forgive the banality of its every scene.
review2: Movies often make too much of that truism, but surprisingly committed performances from actors like these can still make it feel like something meaningful.
review3: Ridiculously implausible yet still predictable.
review4: Chow and her actors are so gifted that this fragile situation escapes contrivance to become a poignant, romantic and deftly nuanced revelation of character and emotions.
review5: An already iffy premise is badly served by a film that is tonally jarring.

title: The Beaver
review1: It's a bummer of a movie -- dark and at cross-purposes with both itself and any image do-over [Gibson] might be seeking.
review2: It doesn't quite work, but it does provide something of a cinematic exorcism for the public's increasingly conflicted relationship with Gibson.
review3: Thinks it's a whimsical tale of a man finding himself, but Gibson thinks it's the tale of a man losing his mind.
review4: Jodie Foster's The Beaver had its moments, but the overall premise just didn't fly. I just couldn't buy the idea of the talking puppet.
review5: Mel Gibson's last hurrah

title: Poetry
review1: True to the title, writer-director Lee Chang-dong is principally concerned with rendering emotions that seem inexpressible.
review2: Those with an eye for reading between the lines can find layers of meaning.
review3: A deceptively gentle tale with a tender ache at its center, as well as a performance from Yun Jung-hee that lingers long in the memory.
review4: Anyone who starts a film going to poetry classes is eventually going to come up with a poem. The one Mija finally delivers will rip your heart to shreds.
review5: Writer and director Chang-dong Lee's film is moving without ever stooping to melodrama; Yun is the main reason why.

title: Blitz
review1: It's hard to know how seriously anyone besides Statham is taking this - but that only adds to its absurd, cock-eyed charm.
review2: prospathei na prosferei skhnothetikh poikilia s' ena senario poy para toys grhgoroys rythmoys toy, paramenei kommataki monotono ki epanalhptiko, omws tis sepies toy tis exeis ksanadei kai ta plana toy prodidoyn amhxania
review3: As conventional as you can get without needing an epilogue that says "...next week on Blitz."
review4: America, where Statham does the majority of his work these days, seems to appreciate his particular talents. On this evidence, he might want to stick to Hollywood.
review5: ...Lester is no Don Siegel and Statham, though credibly formidable, lacks the conscience that made Harry Callahan human...

title: Trollhunter
review1: The film is shot with handheld cameras in the standard mockumentary style, but the content is often hilarious, especially when the trolls show up.
review2: A leisurely, shambling, deadpan movie about a man who finds trolls and kills them. That's enough.
review3: Not nearly as much fun as it might have been, neither consistently funny nor remotely scary.
review4: Trollhunter adopts the form of a found footage documentary, which translates as lots of banal conversations, abundant shots of the Scandinavian countryside, and competent but shaky handheld camerawork.
review5: TrollHunter is both creepy and funny, a clever combination for this sly monster movie.

title: Neds
review1: The casting is good throughout, but McCarron makes the movie.
review2: A stringent street psychodrama in which brutality is an infection and every male is a carrier.
review3: First-timer McCarron is never less than convincing as a baby-faced brute who can elicit a stranger's sympathy as easily as he can inflict devastating comeuppance.
review4: There's a sense of inevitability about things, certainly, but it seems less written in the stars than unhappily scratched onto the kerb with a flicknife by John himself.
review5: ... Despite its bold efforts to the contrary, it ultimately becomes a dehumanising experience and apology for self-ruination.

title: Cold Fish
review1: A deliciously warped wallow in misogyny, depravity and dead-eyed manipulation, "Cold Fish" charts the twisted alliance of two tropical-fish salesmen with baleful glee.
review2: Cold Fish is wild, head-turning, stomach-churning stuff, and it makes a bracing addition to the overstuffed canon of serial-killer cinema.
review4: Smart, devious, audacious filmmaking from a man who's quickly becoming a master at this sort of stuff.
review5: Overlong? A tad. Still, at two-and-a-half hours it's 90 minutes shy of its predecessor Love Exposure. Insane fun? Absolutely. Darkly funny and deliriously absurd in all of its bloody glory, I found it impossible to look away.

title: Win Win
review1: The rare, humanist beauty of Win Win is that none of its characters is a caricature, none of its plot twists a blatant play for tears or laughs, none of its appeal based on some mythical lowest common denominator.
review2: In a still young movie year, Win Win is already on the mat as one of the best.
review3: Tom McCarthy doesn't make great movies, but he makes movies about people I enjoy spending time with.
review4: WIN WIN makes Tom McCarthy three-for-three. Grabbing the affection from the audience is what he wants, and dear reader, he can't lose.
review5: McCarthy understands the thrill of incontrovertible victory and our primal lust for it.

title: Tracker
review1: A relative lack of action, pared with simplistic message-movie sentiments, that hampers what in any other case is a solid movie.
review2: Ultimately, the drama's more satisfying than exciting, but it's a solid entertainment nonetheless.
review3: What would Ray Winstone sound like if he did a South African accent? Answer: Exactly the same as he would if he was doing a London, Italian or Kathmandu accent. Like either a homicidal tuba or Muttley with a hangover.
review4: With Winstone in the lead you won't expect it to have the action power of Seraphim Falls, which starred Pierce Brosnan and Liam Neeson in 2006, but prepare to be surprised.
review5: There are echoes of classics like Hell In The Pacific in Tracker and the seesawing relationship between the two men is entertainingly handled, if repetitive, until some welcome 11th-hour twists in the plot.

title: Secret Sunshine
review1: There is a natural tendency to appreciate movies that are neat and concise. "Secret Sunshine" makes a striking argument for the antithesis.
review2: The cinematic equivalent of prose that is clear, elegant and lyrical.
review3: Buried in the year-end rush but one of the year's best films.
review4: Secret Sunshine is a frequently beautiful film with a cold, dark heart.
review5: A secular hymn to the small triumphs and cavernous tragedies of the everyday, and to our awesome ability to cope.

title: Sympathy for Delicious
review1: You can't make this stuff up. Or maybe you can, but you shouldn't.
review2: Mark Ruffalo is one of the best actors of his generation, and I'd like to be able to say that, with his directorial debut, Sympathy for Delicious, he's one of its best filmmakers, too. Alas, this semiexpressionist fantasia is a botch.
review3: While, as director, Ruffalo is a little too fond of hand-held shots, he keeps all the performances simmering and moves the story ahead in simple, straightforward steps.
review4: Interesting but never compelling...
review5: As it builds, kind of epically, to a thoughtful conclusion, "Sympathy" appreciates the places we find after defeating our demons.

title: X: Night of Vengeance
review3: X most certainly won't be for everyone, but I found myself enjoying every second of its slick, bordering on camp, nature. It's one of the most alive and confident genre titles to come out of this country in quite some time.
review4: The seedy pic is long on raunchiness and short on credibility.
review5: The ensuing chase doesn't entirely hang together, with some twists more plausible than others, but the setting's scuzzy, febrile atmosphere adds to the tension and the two leads hold their own.

title: Nola
review1: Needs to be put out of its misery -- and yours.
review2: So laughably preposterous that it's thoroughly entertaining.
review3: A dubious script that detonates into a full-blown disaster midway through.
review4: Has everything you want from a good bad movie: overheated drama, overripe performances, arch characters and fruity dialogue.
review5: Pits a substantial actor like Mary McDonnell, playing a New York madam, against a bogus story that crossbreeds noirish affectations and romantic comedy into an unpalatable mush that suggests strawberry ice cream slathered with beer.

title: Roadkill
review1: An improvement over most of the "Maneater Series" entries. Relatively speaking.

title: Madea's Big Happy Family
review1: Like most of Perry's movies, this one oscillates wildly and shamelessly between raunch and pathos, leaving plenty of room for the performers to work. The lively ensemble includes a scene-stealing Cassi Davis as pothead Aunt Bam.
review2: Epitomizing the shrill franchise's schizophrenic tonal shifts, Madea metes out Christian life lessons with one hand -- and righteously bitch-slaps with the other.
review3: The title is meant to be ironic. Too bad irony is in such short supply in Tyler Perry's Madea's Big Happy Family. Sadly, subtlety is also missing.
review4: If Perry gets on your wavelength, you can forgive him too. He's only the host at a home-cooked banquet of wild emotions.
review5: "Madea's Big Happy Family'' nonsensically knots the spiritual and the salacious, asking gossipy questions then giving pulpit answers so that the movie is wonderfully, woefully absurd.

title: In A Better World
review1: True, the resolutions on offer seem conventionally pat, yet the tough questions stay with you in an absorbing drama which pushes the viewer's buttons with effective intelligence.
review2: Although this being a film by Susanne Bier, there is unfortunately a good measure of unneeded melodrama stirred in to trivialize the very important thematic concerns.
review3: There's little flash or surprise in Bier's latest well-shot film, but plenty of substance.
review4: A most deserving Oscar winner and a film that could provoke discussion anywhere it is shown, anywhere people of any age are being bullied
review5: Film defies conventional expectations about biblical notions of retribution, even as it initially prepares you to accept them. A truly complex work of art.

title: Skateland
review1: A film with some engaging performances and a swell soundtrack whose biggest problem is that it wants to be "Dazed and Confused" when it grows up.
review2: Like so many other films set in the Reagan era, Anthony Burns' directorial debut fails to acknowledge the lingering and pervasive angst that shaped anyone growing up in the late Cold War.
review3: Indifferently acted, written and directed, the oft soporific "Skateland" is beautifully photographed and boasts a greatest-hits soundtrack, as well as some spot-on art direction.
review4: Though noticeably lacking in originality, Anthony Burns' low-key directorial debut skates by on the charms of its hazy wistfulness and a likable cast.
review5: Anthony Burns's sweetly nostalgic re-creation of small-town Texas in the early 1980s.

title: The 5th Quarter
review1: The film is poorly written and directed at the most basic levels.
review2: This real-life football story fumbles the ball at every decisive juncture.
review3: It scores points for being that rare "faith based film" to show a little edge.
review4: Football tearjerker might be too intense for younger viewers.
review5: A well-acted drama that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally as well as intellectually. It will make you stand up and cheer.

title: The Arbor
review1: Numerous celluloid experiments have fudged reality and fiction lately, but few are as formally inventive or socially revelatory as The Arbor.
review2: For the morbidly curious, it's mesmerizing. But it's also a singularly watchable story for the strange, and strangely fitting, way in which it's told.
review3: [An] exquisitely crafted docudrama.
review4: Barnard's boldest move is to unveil the irresponsible chaos of the playwright's private life, and to make us wonder if the art was worth the suffering, after all.
review5: Brings the Dunbar story to life through a technique known as "verbatim theater," in which actors lip-synch testimony from the real people they're portraying.

title: Everything Must Go
review1: A gratifying story with a quietly powerful performance from funnyman Will Ferrell.
review2: Has a similar problem to its protagonist: It just sort of sits there.
review3: Good performances by Ferrell and Wallace and fantastic cinematography make Everything Must Go an enjoyable watch.
review4: The best movie Will Ferrell ever made
review5: Gentle understatement that stealthily but surely gets under the skin and touches the heart.

title: Merantau
review1: In dire need of a tighter edit and a few smiles, Merantau is a bizarrely lethargic picture, great with violence, but a complete chore to sit through between the punches.

title: Reach for Me
review1: Places a solid cast of smallscreen names in service of well-intentioned but formulaically second-rate material. Next stop, cable.

title: X-Men: First Class
review1: For reasons arising from the way the X-Men film franchise has developed, this is the first Marvel movie set in the period when the characters were created, and thus able to embrace the Rat Pack cool that was part of their original charm.
review2: That First Class also offers up a decent narrative about the importance of self-love, family bonding and friendship gives it extra dimension -- even if the overall dramatic range only goes X to Z.
review3: X-Men: First Class manages the neat trick of staying true to the superhero legend while also creating something fresh and exciting. This class graduates with top marks.
review4: In truth, the film is a very conventional summer potboiler repackaged in reasonably pretty, moderately crisp wrapping paper. In short, not quite groovy enough.
review5: In some glorious zone between Mad Men and Thunderbirds comes this X-Men prequel, as kinetic as it is character-driven, and full of ridiculous retro pleasures.

title: The Putt Putt Syndrome
review1: After watching the leaden comedy "The Putt Putt Syndrome," you actually might understand less about marriage than you did going in.

title: All Night Long
review1: ... the elegance of the camerawork, the machinations of the plot and the fun of seeing these musicians performing onscreen keeps the film involving.

title: Sapphire
review1: This is Important Cinema with Socially Relevant Themes and, while surely daring in its day, comes off as insufferably patronizing and sanctimonious at times.

title: The Singing Nun
review1: Debbie Reynolds, then in her second and last popularity phase, plays the titular role in this unbearably cloying, poorly scripted musical melodrama, trying to cash in on the success of The Sound of Music.

title: Nostalgia for the Light
review1: A truly eye-opening experience.
review2: A nearly unbearable examination of good and bad in the human heart.
review3: Guzmán offers a poetic narrative that celebrates the searches and insists on the moral obligation to remember Chile's not-too-distant past.
review4: Moving and poetic, with beautiful composition and strong direction, Nostalgia For The Light has an authentic sense of gravitas.
review5: The vast expanse of the world's driest place - captured here in all its arid intensity - makes for a fascinating and eerie backdrop.

title: Incendies
review1: A strong film based on a weak story.
review2: Although "Incendies" shows very little violence, the burden of knowing what's taking place off-screen is just as difficult for the audience to stomach.
review3: Rewarding, but ridiculously stingy in handing out simple details -- relationships, geographical settings, etc. -- vital to our grasp of what's going on.
review4: Watching Incendies is a long, hard, and emotionally draining experience but one that richly rewards the time and effort invested.
review5: Every time the film begins to feel more like a history lesson than a drama, it explodes into action.

title: The Four Times (Le Quattro Volte)
review1: The God's-eye view becomes mesmerizing when we stop insisting that the film flatter us and just enjoy a quiet ride on the cycle.
review2: I drifted pleasantly in its depths.
review3: Le Quattro Volte may sound like art-house tedium, but in fact it's a movie of grave beauty, serene pace and surprising humor.
review4: Give Le Quattro Volte the patience it deserves, and you will be captivated by its stately rhythms, transfixed by its strange imagery, and moved by its sudden dramas. Don't, and you'll be bored to tears.
review5: If Dante hadn't already made classic use of the title, Michelangelo Frammartino's Le Quattro Volte could instead have been called The Divine Comedy.

title: Thor
review1: Let's hope Branagh was well-compensated, at least. To quote his favorite author: No profit grows where is no pleasure taken.
review2: Thor is on much safer ground here on Earth. The tone is immediately different: more relaxed; comic, not cosmic.
review3: Thor is a really good popcorn flick -- just a little too bloated in places to hit the mark as well as it could have.
review4: The mildly amusing midsection plays like a Viking take on Crocodile Dundee.
review5: Strikes a mighty blow to the summer blockbuster season and will charge up audiences just like the first 'Iron Man.'

title: Hesher
review1: Happily, Hesher never lays things out too clearly. Just as you never know where he came from, it's hard to grasp where he's going, or even what he's doing in the moment. But you know he fits somewhere. And that's satisfaction enough.
review2: Gordon-Levitt is a sly and inventive actor, and it can be genuinely fun to watch him having so much fun. But this character wears out his welcome fast.
review3: Rather than a character rooted in some sort of reality -- social, satirical, psychological, take your pick -- Hesher is an abstract notion animated by false energy.
review4: Bad role models sometimes make the most interesting movie characters.
review5: Unlike many films that hope to be called black comedy, it does not skimp on either the black or the comedy.

title: True Legend
review1: Diverting but unmemorable martial arts feature unlikely to become a classic.
review2: Somewhere between masterful and messy, Yuen Woo-ping offers lots of kinetic kicks, but his CGI work deserves a kick in the pants.
review3: A silly and yet often enjoyable action film, the movie isn't so much a winking homage to those late-'70s Hong Kong exports as another entry...
review4: Fans don't go to martial-arts movies for the story. They want action -- and Yuen doesn't disappoint.
review5: Fans who've been waiting 15 years for the director of "Drunken Master" to helm a new movie definitely won't be disappointed.

title: The River Murders
review1: ...a disappointingly uneven endeavor that can't quite get the job done...

title: We Are The Night
review1: A love triangle with fangs but no bite, the German import "We Are the Night" is mostly infatuated with its own stylish excesses.
review2: Stylishly reinvents juvenile pulp with flashy pyrotechnics.
review3: Gansel compensates for the story's lack of emotional heft with rousing chase scenes and impressive, near-poetic CGI set pieces, and works in a sly suggestion that vampirism is the ultimate expression of consumerist indulgence.
review4: an odd - and therefore interesting - blend of genetic elitism, feminist emancipation and rave-culture hedonism, where oldworld bloodlines leave a trail imprinted in the postmodern age - all wrapped in a slickly stylish audiovisual package.
review5: It's stylishly constructed and a better feminist vampire yarn than Twilight, but still problematic in itself.

title: Setup
review1: "overall, awkward is the best word to describe this disjointed and strained film."

title: Go for It!
review1: An unpretentious rite-of-passage drama whose merits belie the banality of its title.
review2: Go For It! never manages to conjure an iota of the joyful exuberance that enlivens even the most formulaic dance films.
review3: Go for It! brings nothing new to the coming-of-age dance film.
review4: Earnest and sympathetic but unsophisticated.

title: Circo
review1: Circo takes you to the edge of human experience on a path none of this summer's superhero daredevils would ever consider taking.
review2: "Circo" is an amazing feat.
review3: It says as much about human nature as it shows about struggling entertainers.
review4: Sort of a modern-day version of "Toby Tyler," only without a frisky, mischievous Mr. Stubbs as comic relief.
review5: "Circo'' offers a fascinating mix of backstage drama and family dynamics.

title: Bride Flight
review1: Smug and unconvincing, this 2008 period drama from the Netherlands is the sort of movie that defines an era solely by its prejudices, on the implicit assumption that we'll applaud the central characters for their modern attitudes.
review2: This very pretty melodrama is a rather ordinary entry.
review3: Aside from its period New Zealand setting, there is little to distinguish Bride Flight from something you might watch briefly on Lifetime, then change the channel.
review4: The events in the plot are the stuff of soap opera, but the movie treats it seriously, and the acting is convincing enough that we forgive the story and begin to care about the characters.
review5: Lovely scenery and historical context elevate the sentimental story lines above the soap opera domain.

title: Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara
review1: It largely succeeds due to its charismatic, handsome leads and a cracking 'Spanglish' soundtrack.
review2: Dogged by clunky humor and too much travelogue in the early running, helmer Zoya Akhtar's sophomore feature improves markedly halfway through by toning down the tomfoolery and getting to grips with the trio's emotional frailties.
review3: Slick it may be. But tourist board employees representing the various Spanish cities flattered in the movie are not the only ones who will come out grinning.
review4: [A] hugely enjoyable and amusing romp.
review5: This is defiantly old-fashioned, high-value entertainment with a glamorous, talented cast. You used to see this sort of thing all the time from Hollywood.

title: The Lost Future
review1: Something you'd catch on the TV one night when you're in the mood for television no matter what is showing . . .

title: Cherry
review1: An attempted mashup of "Gilmore Girls" and "The Graduate," "Cherry" fails to be either raunchy or sweet.
review2: Cherry cribs from The Graduate, Educating Rita, Good Will Hunting and Legally Blonde, but never comes close to being as funny or as touching as those movies at their best.
review3: As ungainly and unkempt as its teen protagonist.
review4: A sparkling coming-of-ager about a 17-year-old virgin who imperfectly juggles academic challenges and off-campus liaisons, somehow emerging able to walk on water.
review5: The movie stirs up a thoroughly relatable swirl of youthful tentativeness, raging hormones, and the thrill and angst that come with new independence - all the things running through a good kid's head at 17.

title: Where The Road Meets The Sun
review1: "Where the Road Meets the Sun" is earnest but inorganic, trying hard but uninvolving, with little to actually say about the big, mixed-up intersection of crazy and unbelievable that is Los Angeles at its best.
review2: This movie serves best as a tutorial on what happens when the genre is botched: It fails to deliver a single story worth caring about.
review4: A sprawling, somewhat self-consciously multi-ethnic drama of struggling immigrants that, despite some relaxed performances, repeatedly identifies plausibility as an enemy, and never locates a truly compelling through-line.

title: The Stool Pigeon (Sin yan)
review3: By the time we get to the centerpiece bloody climax, too much air has gone out of the film for it to be revived.

title: Viva Riva!
review1: A slick, exciting, well-made crime thriller, dripping with atmosphere.
review2: It feels so raw and urgent and real.
review3: Pulsing with polyglot music and outlaw vigor, "Viva Riva!" is a raucous reply to the new world order.
review4: Patsha Bay plays the macho title character, but the film belongs to sultry Manie Malone as the dancehall diva he aims to steal from the top mob boss. She makes even the act of applying lipstick spark with erotic electricity.
review5: "Viva Riva!" has its cake and eats it, too. Shoots it to pieces, actually.

title: Good Neighbors
review1: Working from a 1982 novel set in Quebec City, director-writer Jacob Tierney provides enough thrills and surprises, even a little satire, to keep viewers' attention.
review2: Swerving from bland to brutal, endearingly coy to shockingly explicit, the Canadian import "Good Neighbors" finds pitch-black comedy among white-bread lives.
review3: There's enough creepy tension and nefarious deeds afoot to make for a really suspenseful short film, but even at just 96 minutes, Good Neighbors outstays its welcome.
review4: An agreeably sick little movie about a serial killer, a bunch of cats and the uneasy tenants of a Montreal apartment complex.
review5: Good Neighbors is a darkly comedic thriller with echoes of Shallow Grave and an undercurrent of repressed Canadian rage, and though it comes to an anticlimactic end, it manages a lot with a slow build of unease.

title: Angel of Evil
review1: What is missing is any sort of psychological insight. Just what made Renato run? You won't find out here.
review2: To borrow Robert Evans's famous quotation about "The Godfather," you can smell the spaghetti, but less sauce might have helped.
review3: Gangster clichés fly like submachine gun bullets in the Italian crime biopic "Angel of Evil," a restless and hollow rundown of '70s criminal Renato Vallanzasca.
review4: As a tale of squabbling gangsters and prison intrigues, "Angel of Evil" is ordinary.
review5: You can all but feel the checklist being marked off, and the viewer is never really drawn into the world or made to care what's happening.

title: The Ledge
review1: Chapman coaxes good performances from his cast, especially Wilson, who makes Joe's immense conflicts a matter of empathy as much as abhorrence. But Chapman doesn't have the filmmaking skills to conceal the talky, formulaic narrative.
review2: Gavin recalls his experiences while standing atop a building ready to jump; we're meant to be on edge ourselves, but the only real mystery is why Tyler took such an unrewarding role in the first place.
review3: A film that's ultimately sabotaged by its own heavy-handed screenplay.
review4: Unlike its talky hero, the credibility of this preposterous drama immediately plunges into the abyss.
review5: Can't wait until Thanksgiving dinner to witness a pointless conversation between a pompous fundamentalist Christian and a sneering atheist? Then The Ledge is the movie for you.

title: Trainwreck: My Life as an Idiot
review1: Tod Harrison Williams directs with a sense of humour that never takes cheap shots but isn't overtly reverential to the author, and the playful tone helps make the film entertaining as well as offbeat.

title: Phase 7
review1: Gore enthusiasts will find the body count acceptable, others may find the splatter a bit crude.
review2: An entertaining variation on a well-worn theme.
review3: No matter how hard the musical score labors to convince us otherwise, it's not scary.
review4: Phase 7 distinguishes itself by its suffocating setting, its low-affect tone, and its cast of flaky characters.
review5: Phase 7 is slick, smart horror.

title: 17 Miracles
review1: Falls victim to uneven pacing and odd structure.
review2: While the film won't likely convert the masses at large (and really doesn't aim to) it has the power to promote the faith of many a believer.

title: The Heart Specialist
review1: A ploddingly paced and tonally dissonant mix of broadly played sitcom-style humor and shameless heartstring-yanking.
review2: Amateurish doctors-in-training comedy/drama too blatantly reveals its television inspirations.
review3: Dr. Dennis Cooper must have knocked off this script while watching "Scrubs" re-runs in the break room. This is "Scrubs" told totally from a black doctor's point of view.

title: Submarine
review1: Although the movie is, by design, largely non-specific about its period (late 1980s would be a good guess), Jordana's casual profanity impresses. In American comedies, swears are studded like peppercorns or chocolate chips.
review2: SUBMARINE is a story about growing up all while not wanting to get older. It's what HAROLD & MAUDE would have been if they had met in high school.
review3: Submarine is a remarkably assured debut filled with dry humor, inventive visual wit and great performances.
review4: The movie's conception of the tender agonies and embarrassments of would-be teenage lovers is hobbled by punchline cuts and predictable musical montages (carefree dashes, setting off bottle rockets, etc.).
review5: That rare teen comedy where the kids aren't gorgeous, the hero isn't heroic and the object of desire has a lot of reasons why she isn't necessarily desirable.

title: Fast Five
review1: Fast Five is grindingly mechanical -- and not just because of all the emphasis on car repairs and retooling.
review2: ...achieves the sort of zen chaos that defines the Die Hard films
review3: Hard-core fans of the series with enjoy it but others should steer away from this over-the-top action flick.
review4: Forty minutes of this movie are big dumb fun. The other 85 forget the fun part.
review5: Has really transformed this series from camp action cinema to exciting heist cinema.

title: Amazing Grace and Chuck
review1: Puerile.
review2: The film's style is as doggedly ordinary as its story is preposterous.
review3: As amazingly bad as it is audacious, film will live forever in the hearts of connoisseurs of Hollywood's most memorably outrageous moments.
review4: Intermittently entertaining and embarrassing.
review5: Ultimately Mike Newell manages to make the film into something worthwhile.

title: Lucky
review1: Nearly every step the movie makes feels completely random, with no payoff.
review2: Thank your lucky stars I had to see Gil Cates Jr.'s darkly comic misfire early enough to warn you against wasting your own time and money.
review3: Mr. Hanks performs with customary blankness and a woeful lack of chemistry with his hardworking co-star.
review4: Nothing is bleaker than failed black comedy, which this is.
review5: The concept, perilously high, is further overloaded by performances that are perilously broad, particularly from Graynor and an ill-used Ann-Margret as Ben's mother.

title: The Sylvian Experiments
review1: Those occasional flashes of fright don't add up to a satisfying or cohesive whole.

title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier)
review1: Functions swimmingly as an ambiguous study of wrongly diverted passions.
review2: An engrossing subplot tracks the older man's chaste devotion to the young man's wife, which Tavernier parallels with his love of Christ; unfortunately the routine love triangle takes up most of the screen time.
review3: Swords cross, blood spurts and bosoms heave in The Princess of Montpensier, French director Bertrand Tavernier's thoroughly ravishing drama.
review4: There is more than a trace of ennui in a story that gallops at times and plods along at others.
review5: How can the 16th-century heroine of a movie based on a 17th-century novella feel like such a 21st-century woman - without seeming at all anachronistic? That's the wonder of Bertrand Tavernier's "The Princess of Montpensier.''

title: Lunopolis
review1: Utterly drenched in the convoluted lore that exists within the world of UFO-cultists, fringe-science theorists and anti-establishment agitators, Matthew J Avant's time-traveller-themed mock-umentary is seriously wacky but undeniably compelling.

title: Leap Year
review1: Nothing about Leap Year plays out exactly like you expect, and Rowe prefers to send you home with enigmatic questions instead of clear-cut answers.
review2: "Leap Year" might be too much for some audiences, but it is a potent and surprising work.
review3: It's a gripping, mysterious use of no-budget cinema at its finest, and an intimate character study with surprising emotional power.
review4: To Rowe's credit, this isn't just a movie about sex. It's a compassionate study of human loneliness.
review5: A haunting portrait of loneliness in its starkest state.

title: Beautiful Boy
review1: In Beautiful Boy, the themes are vast but the picture is small, and the ensuing emptiness is what the characters are meant to feel -- not us.
review2: An excruciating drama about a couple caught in the aftermath of a pivotal moment involving their college-age son.
review3: At a certain point lofty objectivity is just a refusal to engage, and no raw camera work can disguise it.
review4: Most of "Beautiful Boy" is unrelentingly bleak and depressing, but there are smatterings of understatement and grace.
review5: This feels like a movie that won a high school current-events contest: Take a tragedy, make a movie.

title: The Tree of Life
review1: Frankly, it may require multiple viewings before someone can definitively arrive at a conclusion.
review2: Malick's reach exceeds his grasp. But man, that is one hell of a reach.
review3: Go ahead and take away my credibility badge...The film is one of the most emotionally affecting and profound experiences of my life, regardless of how recent it is.
review4: You'd be hard pressed to find an examination of human existence as profound and spiritual as Terrence Malick's mind-blowing trip through the cosmos.
review5: The lack of story or purpose is annoying and at times, the film is too experimental. Topping things off is an abrupt and unsatisfying ending which doesn't leave us with good feelings towards the film.

title: Master Harold...and the Boys
review1: This film version never quite clicks because of a lack of ensemble chemistry with its three main stars.

title: Mr. Nice
review1: Though the film takes a while to cast its spell, writer-director-cinematographer Bernard Rose's close observation of Marks and those around him becomes increasingly involving and allows Rose to comment on the widespread failure of the war on drugs.
review2: The writer-director tells the story with verve and small-budget ingenuity.
review3: Ifans looks 20 years too old for the part, and the problem with the movie is it seems so desperate to be made that it barely cares that he spends half of his time miscast.
review4: [Ifans] captures the character's charisma and cool, and it's fun to ride shotgun with him. But the script isn't pointed enough to drill beneath the surface.
review5: Effortlessly captures the looks, attitudes and the various mentalities of the period from the late 1960s and early 1970s, through the transition from the hippie era into the Studio 54 days, followed by the Just-Say-No retrenchment of the 1980s.

title: Strangers (Zarim)
review1: A warm love story despite its harsh background war story.

title: The Shock Doctrine
review1: This movie, clearly assembled in haste, throws surprisingly poor archival footage into the mix with a Klein lecture, scant original interviews and a narration from on high that will brook no dissent.
review2: In a lucid way clears up how America is now in the midst of a severe financial crisis through questionable free market policies.
review3: The worst that comes out of the documentary's final moments is the sense that Winterbottom and Whitecross ultimately don't know what their film is supposed to be about.
review4: Pure capitalism unmasked
review5: A movie that describes the scorched earth policy associated with free market fundamentalism, continuing with the current occupant of the White House.

title: A Better Life
review1: The film's beautiful simplicity is carried massively on the work of Demián Bichir, instantly and surely one of the best performances seen in 2011.
review2: Well-acted, but quite over-hyped -- a melodramatic Mexican-American version of "Bicycle Thieves."
review3: A Better Life is a half-step removed from the Hallmark Hall of Fame.
review4: A Better Life's sense of place and eye for detail are strong, but the too-smooth style and rushed dramatics are at odds with the hardscrabble existence on display.
review5: [A] gentle, honest, heartfelt film, but [it] does not have much to offer beyond an earnest respect for a segment of American society that is too often derided...

title: The One
review1: Thought piece about identity? Soap opera romance? Light dramedy? Tragedy? "The One" doesn't find its footing in any of these genres; they just plod around one another uncomfortably.

title: The Robber
review1: Here is a well-made movie with insufficient interest in its hero.
review2: "The Robber" is artfully done but emotionally remote.
review3: The film boasts several turbocharged chase-and-escape sequences, alongside understated character analysis.
review4: The Robber is powerful stuff.
review5: "The Robber" is one of the most abstemious thrillers in recent memory.

title: The Last Circus
review1: Basque director Álex de la Iglesia's exotic, surreal, hilarious, bloody and utterly explosive grand opus.
review2: From the far-too-teeming brain of Spanish writer/director Alex de la Iglesia, The Last Circus is a bizarre, surreal, grotesque, fascinating, demanding, disappointing and ultimately exhausting political allegory that plays like a waking nightmare.
review3: For those with a taste for the subversive and outrageous, run, don't walk.
review4: You're left with the vague recollection of an interesting movie you were watching before you got kidnapped and subjected to over an hour of torture porn starring a fat, sadistic clown.
review5: If you like your baroque sex and violence with a side dish of heavy-duty symbolism ... put "The Last Circus" on your must-see list right now.

title: All She Can
review1: The movie bucks Hollywood norms without quite knowing what to put in their place.
review2: The film veers into morality play and, finally, inspirational uplift.
review4: Approaches the coming-of-age story of the Chicana girl unwilling to reproduce "her" culture without putting up a fight developing some unconventional threads.

title: The History of Mr. Polly
review1: Parts of the movie are engaging, parts lightly amusing, parts awkward, and parts a little dull.

title: Baarìa
review1: The picture does have its plodding moments - but there's enough left over for the rest of us to have a reasonably good time.
review2: It's a shame Tornatore's movie, impressive statement though it is, never musters the emotional potency that would make it really special.
review4: I'm all for bloated, confusing, directorial vanity projects like Synecdoche New York and 8 1/2. But Synecdoche New York and 8 1/2 this ain't.
review5: Baaria is like a pleasant package holiday: alfresco dinners, strolls through lemon orchards.

title: The Countess
review1: Wacky tale of a woman who killed virgins for their blood to keep her skin wrinkle-free might get some traction in Central Europe, where it is set, but won't make it past the Europudding label elsewhere.
review2: A bizarre tale of a vampiric countess performed with stilted, faux-Shakespearean dialogue

title: Night Watch
review1: Lucille Fletcher's Night Watch isn't the first average stage play to be turned into a better than average film. Astute direction and an improved cast more than help.
review2: Tired, old-fashioned thriller.
review3: Elizabeth Taylor, and about time, has got herself a good picture and a whodunit at that
review4: Filled with red herrings and featuring a bloody "twist" ending, Night Watch fails to create much of an atmosphere.
review5: Less than satisfactory thriller.

title: Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale
review1: Rare Exports also twists the season's staples with a morbidly merry, tongue-in-cheek sense of humor.
review2: For anyone who can look a little askance at the monster that contemporary Christmas has become, this artfully made Finnish tale is -- I kid you not -- a real treat.
review3: The end gets a little silly, but the building tension of the first two acts allows for some deliciously creepy moments and a true feeling of dread: the sense of something very old, and very hungry, shuffling toward you in the Yuletide dark.
review4: [A] deliciously loopy oddball of a film.
review5: A James Bond movie, fairy tale and potentially a full blown horror story rolled into one, if you enjoyed the original Swedish vampire thriller Let The Right One In, you'll find much to admire here.

title: Good Day for It
review1: Not agile enough to make the idea of a contemporary small-town western really work, Stagliano instead simply cranks out a rather bland programmer doomed for the anonymity of a video store shelf or VOD queue.

title: Eating Out: Drama Camp
review2: The "Eating Out" series isn't known for comedic or sexual subtlety, but what "Drama Camp" lacks in restraint it makes up for with good humor and hot guys.
review3: No drama queen, their subjects or pretenders will be disappointed with this frothy adventure where, when everything works out for the better, the possibilities are endless.

title: Shaolin
review1: An ambitious, almost epic drama that devotes as much time to introspection as it does to combat.
review2: "Shaolin" fits in the more somber kung-fu tradition. But it also finds room for the genre's comic strain.
review3: The epic feel to this Hong Kong action-drama helps balance a lack of hand-to-hand combat scenes.
review4: More action, less talk should be the order of the day, but it isn't.
review5: Shaolin features a half-dozen impressive action set pieces, including an elaborate carriage chase and a battle inside the cages where Cao imprisons his workers.

title: Father of Invention
review1: For all its eagerness to please, you'd think Father of Invention could come up with at least one sister of independence.
review2: Highly predictable...
review3: Like Graham and Madsen, Spacey too often gets lost in smaller projects that aren't worthy of his talents. He, and his costars, deserve a more inventive movie than this one.
review4: The screenplay, by Mr. Cooper and Jonathan D. Krane, is so sketchy that it feels like a hastily executed first draft.
review5: The film promises a nasty little satire for a while but finally goes soft and self-pitying.

title: A Little Help
review1: The next chapter in Laura's story might be something worth rooting for, but here's hoping she has a different writer penning her lines.
review2: A Little Help doesn't dazzle, and you can pick at its parts, but Fischer's performance gives the movie a sense of romantic weariness that lingers. Life is a series of disasters to be weathered, no matter how cute you are.
review3: The film suffers from an uncertain tone, playing serious situations for laughs while supplying Laura with a drinking habit and a hair-trigger temper that come across as problems rather than endearing foibles.
review4: This is one of the smarter, more honest scripts to be filmed in quite some time. And Jenna Fischer gives one of the smarter, more honest - and vulnerable, and tough - performances by an actress on the big screen in an even longer stretch.
review5: It's not that Jenna Fischer is miscast in "A Little Help.'' It's that she's mis-everything else: misused, misdirected, misanthropic.

title: City of Life and Death
review1: It is not an easy film, and perhaps a touch too relentless, but it is a great reminder of how bloody, mad and awful this world can be.
review2: Lu Chuan makes this feature film soar by telling the story both through the eyes of the Japanese occupiers and the defenseless Chinese civilians in the ancient capital. It makes the savagery all the more senseless.
review3: Exquisitely shot in black and white, with a rare attention to detail and dramatic complexity, "City of Life and Death" is a timelessly great film that commands our collective attention.
review4: In almost any form, the story of the Nanking atrocities can leave you profoundly shaken. But Lu Chuan's version may be the most compassionate and emotionally satisfying treatment to date.
review5: Here, in bloodless miniature, is the true obscenity of war.

title: Judas Kiss
review1: Undone by half-baked characters and inconsistencies, keeping focus off the key elements of heartache Tepnapa and Pedraza hope will be strong enough to define the viewing experience.

title: Edie & Thea: A Very Long Engagement
review1: While gay issues from Stonewall to same-sex marriage are worked into the mix, the success of the film stems from its makers creating a beautifully personal family atmosphere that welcomes everyone on both sides of the lens.
review2: Edie and Thea are the elderly lesbian aunts you never had.

title: Water for Elephants
review1: Supporting characters are too hastily sketched in, serving only to further the unsmooth course of true love.
review2: This movie doesn't have half the imagination of even the most subpar circus and, all told, I think it even has fewer elephants.
review3: The leads lack chemistry and the movie has a very cookie-cutter love story that was far too predictable.
review4: Whatever romance Gruen summoned forth from this rough and tumble world of show people living by their own laws in a traveling, self-contained world of poverty and cruelty, director Francis Lawrence has hacked and ground it off.
review5: "Water for Elephants" is a surprisingly good film that once again shows that first impressions aren't everything.

title: "Crazy, Stupid, Love."
review1: A slickly polished, perhaps too carefully-structured romantic comedy that benefits immeasurably from Gosling's brand of anarchy.
review2: This well-cast comedy easily stands high above many of the romantic comedies we've seen in recent years.
review3: This is a movie with a bigger heart than a brain. As frustrating as it can be, still, there are worse offenses.
review4: Crazy, Stupid, Love has several humorous spots and is filled with good performances from the entire cast.
review5: Steve Carell, with Ryan Gosling as his wing man? Go figure.

title: Forged
review1: While only 77 minutes long, the movie doesn't feel rushed; nicely paced, it merely shows that Mr. Wedig is sure of his material.
review3: Wedig and Perez are telling a small story with big emotions ... They can't be accused of hewing to the tried-and-true in the homestretch. The open-ended ending is as uncompromising as it is gutsy.

title: "Faith, Fraud And Minimum Wage"
review1: An often interminable piece of work...

title: Trespass
review1: As terrible movies go, it's not unentertaining - once you surrender to its trashmeister idiocy.
review2: It's sloppy and obvious, with curves so un-serpentine they might as well be straightaways
review3: Don't spend thirteen bucks on Trespass unless you're running from the cops and you need a place to hide, wait for it to hit VOD.
review4: It's so routine that it's as if Joel Schumacher showed his final cut to producer Avi Lerner and said, "Avi, look, I put together a thing!" "You mean you finished the movie?" "No, it's not a movie, it's a thing.
review5: ektos apo trypes, aythairesies, kai amhxanes prospatheies sygkalypshs dolofonikwn nekrwn xronwn, pasxei thlibera sto basiko dramatiko ths aksona

title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan
review1: An ever-so-tasteful, watered-down and unnecessarily-improved-upon adaptation of Lisa See's bestselling 2005 novel of the same name.
review2: Snow Flower and the Secret Fan is a delicate, if sometimes disturbing, portrait of the enduring relationships that bond women together, out in theaters now.
review3: Despite the unevenness, the sincerity of the work shines through.
review4: It's a well shot film with beautiful cinematography, though it does feel a bit too constrained at times. But as beautiful as it was, the story and characters failed to grab me
review5: Were it not for the slow pacing and the obviousness of message, Snow Flower and the Secret Fan would have been successful.

title: The Rich Are Always with Us
Juarez
review3: A dull epic directed without inspiration by William Dieterle.
review4: Warner Brothers spectacle of highest order with Muni never better.

title: No Blade of Grass
review1: Cornel Wilde's grim, fatalistic end-of-the-world thriller... is a forgotten dystopian classic of its time.

title: An Invisible Sign
review1: Agrelo clumsily attempts to play jaunty larkiness against somber situations.
review2: Alba certainly tries her best at portraying not just a beauty but also a beautiful mind, yet very few things add up despite director Marilyn Agrelo's efforts.
review3: Cuter than a basket of puppies licking a litter of kittens, "An Invisible Sign" is an excruciatingly whimsical collision of adult themes and kid-friendly aesthetic.
review4: What's the sign for boredom?
review5: Offhandedly charming, if a bit labored in its eccentricity.

title: PT 109
review1: Mild drama is best in long opening showing restoration of PT boat.
review2: Much of the film hits the familiar notes of the classic platoon film with a stiff reverence... It also delivers a personable portrait of an inspiring leader.
review3: JFK as most remember him. Fine performance by Robertson.
review4: Rapidly produced hero drama (JFK's WWII exploits) has its moments.

title: The Carey Treatment (A Case of Murder) (Emergency Ward)
review2: The Carey Treatment ... belongs to its period more than to all time, but its ineffaceable qualities prove that [Blake] Edwards could never be reduced to quack or hack.
review3: Shallow character study murder mystery, that seems like a made for TV film.

title: Video Girl
review1: A showcase for the dimensions of Meagan Good's talent too often neglected by her higher profile projects.

title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll
review1: Those who go looking for tragic relevance in Scott Rosenbaum's debut indie won't find much to grasp onto.
review2: You'd be better off renting "Eddie and the Cruisers" (1983) than slogging through this latest, far more dire recycling of the same rock clichés.
review3: Some grace notes and riffs ring true, but mainly it plays like a familiar tune on a broken record.
review4: Unconvincing rock-biz melodrama feels even thinner when invoking legendary musicians.
review5: An exhausted pileup of rock-movie clichés, "The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll" presents artistic self-destruction with the solemnity of a movie that has invented a spanking-new genre.

title: The Human Resources Manager
review1: If director Eran Riklis's intention is to show the blossoming humanity, so to speak, of a human resources manager, the transformation is much too subtle to work.
review2: Even with incidents involving drunken locals, an underground bunker and a decommissioned tank, the film doesn't build the comic momentum of good intentions hurtling downhill in a strange land.
review3: A cross-cultural shaggy-dog story along the lines of Bill Forsyth's "Local Hero."
review4: Yehoshua and Riklis are sometimes better at setting things up than following through, but the result suggests a novelistic density.
review5: Ivanir's acting is the key - he portrays the transition without sentimentalizing his character.

title: Twelve Thirty
review1: Lipsky tries to use dialogue to cover up weaknesses in other areas - such as why these people behave the way they do. Some of the movie is inviting, some of it off-putting.
review2: It doesn't work but I doubt you'll regret seeing it.
review3: Reiners and Gummer have respective moments where their talents shine, but there's not enough here to keep any but the most masochistic even moderately interested.
review4: This sort of emotional-chaos-in-suburbia (it all takes place in Iowa) has been done well, of course, and at times it is here. But Lipsky's overly arch and tangential dialogue has too many curlicues, and everyone's emotions seem just this side of affected.
review5: For all the promising fodder, the talky, acrid "Twelve Thirty" feels soulless, an emotion-free zone that deals its darkness in a shockingly flip manner.

title: A Better Tomorrow
review3: Woo took the old-time story of two brothers, one a cop and another a counterfeiter, and raised the stakes on it.
review4: More melodramatic and operatic than any of Woo's subsequent films.
review5: While it doesn't rely on style quite as much as [Woo's] later films, it has a complex plot, hundreds of flying bullets and buckets of flowing blood.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Part I
review1: Made on the cheap with no-name stars, this is no better than a stilted anachronistic curiosity, a low-rent version of the eighties' prime-time soap Dallas, with the industrial concerns and sexual mores of 1950s, all, somehow, set in 2016.
review2: A talky bore that spends too much time in wood-panelled offices and at chatter-heavy parties that were clearly shot on the cheap.
review3: Atlas Shrugged: Part I is in many ways charmingly oblivious to its inherent contradictions and the fact that its capitalist titans appear to be squatting in old, abandoned Dynasty sets, eating food-court baked potatoes.
review4: Apart from its deficiencies as fiction, whatever its philosophical limitations (the rich and able should only help themselves in Rand's "Objectivism"), the book proves proudly indigestible on film.
review5: Although it's not as bad as its trailer might suggest, this first part of a projected three-part series will probably please the already converted but bore and annoy just about everyone else.

title: The River Why
review2: The River Why suffers from a pervasive lack of authenticity that inevitably (and ultimately) renders its few positive attributes moot...

title: Alleged
review1: ...it's ultimately impossible not to wonder just what Hines originally set out to accomplish with this pedestrian mess.

title: The Reunion
review1: The WWE's campaign to turn its brutes into box office deals another tepid hand with The Reunion.
review2: There's one thing to be said about WWE Studios -- they're consistent. Every one of their movies designed to showcase their stable of popular wrestling stars has been a critical and commercial disaster.
review3: If John Cena wants to follow in the footsteps of fellow wrestler-turned-actor Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, he might want to learn to smile. Or at least to pick better material than "The Reunion."
review4: Frequently ludicrous and cheerfully inept, Michael Pavone's action comedy does manage to eke out a few drops of slapdash charm.
review5: "The Reunion" has no pretensions of originality, and maybe that's just fine.

title: Boy Wonder
review1: An intriguing, low-budget look at a young vigilante whose "heroism" comes with much moral ambivalence.
review2: Sometimes I think vigilante dramas would be more tolerable if they were pure violent payback, without all the moral grandstanding about our flawed criminal justice system.
review3: I started watching it with moderate expectations and was surprised by how quickly I was drawn in; the movie works insistently on an emotional level.
review4: Morrissey displays a flair for moody atmospherics as his protagonist wanders Gotham's streets and subways at night, but the film relies too heavily on cryptic flashbacks and deliberate gaps in the narrative to create suspense.
review5: Though the story eventually develops some shading, Mr. Morrissey's enthusiasm for graphic novels is evident in every overstylized frame and underwritten conversation.

title: La belle endormie (The Sleeping Beauty)
review1: Enchanting, a bedtime story told by a wickedly literate aunt with a gleam in her eye.
review2: Sly and playful, it's a beauty.
review3: Young Besnaïnou is so lovely that her solemn independence is a wonder to behold, and her early adventures retain an eerie and compelling charm.
review4: Heartwarming entertainment, gorgeously rendered by cinematographer Denis Lenoir.
review5: The pleasures of Ms. Breillat's work are its commitment and seriousness and its raw, sometimes very funny perversity: she's lets everything hang out, without apologies.

title: Putty Hill
review1: This curious blend of documentary and narrative, held together less by any plot device than by a rigorous aesthetic, proves all the more effective for being in service of casual naturalism.
review2: Points must be awarded for nerve, but virtually every aspect of this misbegotten film misfires.
review3: Porterfield's rejection of obvious irony makes this not only a warm film, but one which shows the real face of America's poor, young and disenfranchised.
review4: With "Putty Hill," Porterfield joins the company of American indie directors Ramin Bahrani and Kelly Reichardt, filmmakers often compelled to seek out everyday souls in their textured, oh-so quotidian environs.
review5: It looks closely, burrows deep, considers the way in which lives have become pointless and death therefore less meaningful.

review1: Géla Babluani's English-language remake of his French debut loses the source's gritty, mysterious gloom.
review2: "13'' is Gela Babluani's American remake of his successful 2005 Georgian-language film "13 Tzameti.'' He should have left well enough alone.
review3: A tense, paranoid nightmare with a chilly metaphysical overview has been trampled into a blustering, bad cartoon.
review4: Making a film about the cutthroat world of Russian Roulette is a little like making a gambling thriller about the card game War.
review5: A starry cast and glossier production values simply work against the black-and-white original's strengths in this stillborn thriller.

title: The Legend of Lylah Clare
review2: An expose on the inside Hollywood scene.

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2
review1: For 10 years and eight films we've gotten to watch these young actors grow as people, as performers and as characters. It has been a true coming-of-age saga, in the fullest and most moving sense of the term.
review2: The final instalment, Deathly Hallows Part 2, is a bravura duel between good and evil. It's also a cathartic, occasionally clunky nostalgiafest.
review3: Come the conclusion, tears no doubt will be shed, probably by those more devoted than I. Whether they cry because of overwhelming emotion or in mourning an era's end, I'm not sure. Probably both.
review4: Radcliffe retains an endearingly owlish demeanor. But he also captures the quiet determination of a young man determined to confront his life-or-death destiny -- making the world safe for good folks, wizards and Muggles alike -- with admirable aplomb.
review5: It's a bittersweet end as the final adaptation of the beloved books hits the big screen. Expect tears, both from nostalgia and some truly amazing storytelling.

title: Golf In The Kingdom
review1: For anyone coming in cold, this can be a ponderous cinematic experience.
review2: Golf may be the world's dullest spectator sport, not counting soccer: it takes a long time for not much to happen. By that standard, "Golf in the Kingdom" captures the game perfectly.
review3: A story comprised of pretentious meditative fragments.
review5: Filmmaker Susan Streitfeld takes all of the mysticism at face value, shutting the audience out of pleasures that are discussed but rarely shown.

title: Larry Crowne
review1: An exceedingly minor entry on already impressive resumés.
review2: To pluck romantic comedy from the jaws of a social crisis is a laudable project, worthy of Preston Sturges, and it's a pity that this featherlight drama-written by Tom Hanks and Nia Vardalos, and directed by Hanks himself-should falter in its task.
review3: But with such timely material and a stellar cast, it comes off mostly as a missed opportunity.
review4: Bereft of conflict, the film coasts along in second gear on breezy charm, gentle humanism and star wattage.
review5: Hanks' dorky routine - right on through to the ridiculous ELO-soundtracked end credits as he and Roberts drives around on a scooter in front of a green screen - is thankfully not as draining as one may assume.

title: The Tree
review1: It's well worth seeing the performance of young Morgana Davies as Simone, a child who becomes convinced that her late father speaks and listens to her through the comforting branches of the tree next to her house.
review2: In the end, The Tree is something of a stretch; but it's a good stretch, a mix of mysticism and family dynamics both satisfying and intriguing.
review3: "The Tree" might have suffered from too much symbolism if not for writer-director Julie Bertuccelli's deft touch and Gainsbourg's appealing performance.
review4: Despite the potential for some supernatural grandiosity, the tone here remains understated and quiet, and Gainsbourg's performance feels lived-in, and deep, and right.
review5: The arboreal metaphor is overworked as the tree's roots choke off the rural home's water supply, but the story has a winning, fable-like directness.

title: The Warring States (Zhan Guo)
review1: A morass of melodramatic romance, torture, and suicide.
review2: The writer, Shen Jian, and the director, Jing Chen, have made no concessions to the non-Chinese viewer in their compressed, chaotic narrative.
review3: This busy attempt at merging large-scale CGI action filmmaking with outsized historical drama is unremarkable.
review5: Thrilling and exhilarating. Prepare to be at the edge of your seat from start to finish.

title: Griff the Invisible
review1: Struggles heroically, but unsuccessfully, to strike a balance between whimsy and pathos.
review2: Griff seems a little too psychologically damaged to laugh at. On the other hand, for a drama, his behavior is way too silly to take seriously.
review3: It tries too hard to be eccentric, kooky. So hard, it can be downright annoying.
review4: Something clicks here. Physically as well as verbally, these kids are speaking their own language.
review5: The touches of magical realism begin to feel gimmicky. By the final frame, this romance never feels real enough.

title: Beginners
review1: "Beginners" ultimately becomes so deeply resonant that you should pack some Kleenexes just in case.
review2: Mills needs to look up from the lint that's collected in his navel.
review3: Mike Mills treats love and loss with a disarming tenderness and a refusal of sentimentality that make Beginners, his second feature, something of an anomaly among male identity flicks. What a finely wrought, wryly funny, transcendently sad movie this is.
review4: It understands death better than it understands life; it understands memories more than it understands what to learn from them.
review5: Beginners, beyond its pervasive atmosphere of melancholy and loss, suffers from a little self-indulgence. It's your typical indie drama.

title: Bellflower
review1: Bellflower revs the engine of an exciting new maverick.
review2: Mr. Glodell's sexist, one-dimensional depiction of women notwithstanding, he also seems to champion domestic abuse when justified by infidelity.
review3: Girls, be careful how you break up with a guy who owns his own flamethrower.
review4: Glodell's debut is undoubtedly an immature work but it's such a genuine and energetic achievement that the flaws ultimately don't matter. Bellflower is an amazing mess.
review5: Bellflower is an all around great movie that benefits from excellent filmmaking and gorgeous cinematography.

title: Main Street
review1: With diorama staging and repetitive medium and long shots, stage director turned moviemaker John Doyle creates rigor mortis on film.
review3: It's not groundbreaking, but it's pleasant enough.
review4: Like a small firecracker that turns out to be a dud..as dead as the city it depicts..Durham ought to sue for libel.
review5: Main Street is an ensemble drama that functions as a display case for a range of regional drawls, from the authentic to absurd.

title: Serenade
review1: Sentimental tearjerker romantic drama directed with skill by the great Anthony Mann.

title: Bitter Sweet
review1: Made at the height of their popularity, this charming Nelson Eddy-Jeanette MacDonald operetta was nominated for two Oscars, cinematography and Art Direction.
If the ineffectiveness knob goes up to ten, this film manages to turn it up to you-know-what.
review2: If only "11-11-11" had arrived a little closer to Thanksgiving - the turkey connection would have been entirely appropriate.
review3: One and one (and one and one and one and one) never quite add up to two.
review4: Despite a good lead performance and a few cool ideas, 11-11-11 is also packed with a lot of airy chit-chat that either repeats established ideas or simply goes nowhere.
review5: With 11-11-11, Darren Lynn Bousman is merely insulting the audience with this poor excuse for a plot and its ludicrous ending

title: The People Against O'Hara
review1: It's not the usual strong role Spencer Tracy is noted for.

title: The Devil's Double
review1: Equally as offensive as the movie's smorgasbord of smut and violence is the lingering whiff of colonial-era orientalism, a Western predilection for regarding Eastern cultures as innately idle, lascivious, irrational, and thus ripe for intervention.
review2: It is a ghastly, riveting, dazzling piece of work.
review3: Cooper is great, in a great part. But for an actor, not for his audience.
review4: The Devil's Double is a fantastic film that features a central performance so compelling, you'd be foolish to look away even for a second.
review5: Dominic Cooper is bloody brilliant.

title: The Green
review1: Bare-budget drama of gay male couple whose "accepted" existence in a small Connecticut town gets overturned when the teacher half is accused of impropriety.
review2: Three-fifths of a good movie -- a generally well sketched drama that fumbles away its accrued admiration late in the third act, with a twist that feels like a sop to audiences of small screen procedurals.
review3: Worth tracking down to its digital release platforms..It will force you to deal with prejudices you may not even know you had.

title: Carjacked
review1: ...a disappointingly disposable thriller that simply isn't as good as it could (and should) have been.

title: Trigger
review1: A mesmerizing talk-a-thon with smart, useful things to say about life, love and rock 'n' roll.
review2: Shot simply but compellingly, it feels like a polished and practised portrait of rekindled bonds.
review4: ...an aimless and stagy piece of work that fizzles out to an increasingly (and distressingly) demonstrable degree as it progresses.

title: Sarah's Key
