review1: Thomas carries the weight of the movie, and her usual sangfroid works against her; when she finally makes contact with the deported couple's grandson, the story crumples into sentimentality
review2: Scott Thomas's portrayal of her character's emotional transition ensures Sarah's Key will keep your heart open.
review3: French director Paquet-Brenner occasionally yields to melodrama, particularly in the final act, but he is resolute about not depicting all of his countrymen as Nazi stooges, since many weren't.
review4: Isn't it a little early in the year for Harvey Weinstein to be grubbing for Oscars already?
review5: Well executed and avoids histrionic manipulation, allowing just enough breathing room without truncating the raw emotion of the book.

title: The Family Tree
review1: To judge from the talent she drew for her shaky debut, Vivi Friedman must either be very well connected or an awfully smooth talker.
review2: "Mad Men" devotees may show up for Christina Hendricks, who plays Mulroney's buxom secretary. Quite the acting stretch.
review3: Friedman's inability to successfully reconcile the film's duality undercuts an eclectic cast gamely committed to Mark Lisson's thematically ambitious, if scattered, script.
review4: The only reason I can think of to watch Vivi Friedman's flat, satirical farce "The Family Tree" - and it's not a good enough reason - is the opportunity to play a game of spot the semi-star.
review5: [It makes] a small case for not succumbing to nostalgic malaise -- too bad it's in a genre as played-out as [the] lead characters' passion.

title: Northwest Passage
review5: A rousing adventure story of epic proportions.

title: The Constant Nymph
review2: This Hollywood romantic drama is star Joan Fontaine's favorite of all her films.
review3: The Constant Nymph's most telling moments slip by rather than announce themselves.
review4: Joan Fontaine received her third and last Oscar nomination for this romantic melodrama, well played by Charles Boyer.

title: 9500 Liberty
review1: 9500 Liberty is not just about the clash of immigrant Hispanics and white nativists, but about what happens when a community's civic machinery is hijacked by ideologues and extremists -- and what exactly it takes for the silent center to push back.
review2: A compelling glimpse of a community and, by extension, a country, in the throes of change.
review3: Park and Byler began as objective documentarians who found this story being pressed upon them. They become advocates and are clear about that.
review4: The movie is such a polemic in favor of open immigration and such an attempt to demonize (through strategic cutting) the anti-immigration forces that it plays more like a propaganda piece.
review5: Most of us are good people when we're sitting around the dinner table. What happens to us as soon as we step up to the public podium?

title: Needle
review1: While it may not be innovative or stylistically impressive, this modest horror flick still delivers decent scares.
review2: Taking a fresh twist on the college campus serial killer sub genre of horror, John V. Soto delivers an engaging and well executed supernatural thriller in which mechanical voodoo (not the hip hop band) is the weapon of choice for the killer
review3: To the film's credit, it lacks the smug self-awareness that predominates the modern teen horror genre, but that commitment to integrity gives Needle a retro familiarity that the key demographic may find a little too quaint.

title: 5 Days Of War
review1: An action movie scarcely deeper than a Michael Bay extravaganza.
review2: Harlin's film begins with the familiar adage that truth is the first casualty of war. Usually that phrase precedes an attempt to revive the patient, not bury it deeper in the rubble of propaganda.
review3: The plot is culled from a variety of "war is hell but I'm covering it anyway" journalist-in-the-field movies but handled with clichéd clumsiness in a script by David Battle and doctored by Finnish writer Mikko Alanne.
review4: Flimsy dramatization of Russia/Georgia conflict fails both as historical re-enactment and as action-flick thrill ride.
review5: As propaganda, 5 Days Of War is unlikely to make a mark, though perhaps the idea of reaching people through would-be blockbusters will.

title: Kidnapped
review1: Survival horror has rarely been approached so sparingly and yet, for all there is to admire... the initial sense of potential suspense gives way to the creeping contempt of familiarity.
review2: Starting as a coldly realistic thriller, this film eventually loses its bearings as the director Miguel Ángel Vivas succumbs to a fit of nihilism, transforming "Kidnapped" into gruesome tit-for-tat torture porn.
review3: My eyes never left the screen and my attention never wandered; in a restricted, technical sense of the term, "Kidnapped" is a masterpiece.
review4: While Kidnapped doesn't add anything substantially new to the tradition, Vivas hits his marks with ruthless efficiency.
review5: Gripping but grueling, this Spanish debut feature scores on technical prowess but its nihilistic viciousness is hard to take.

title: One Day
review1: For everyone who's grown tired of the summer onslaught of superheroes, save-the-world plots and explosions, Hollywood finally offers some decent counter-programming in the form of the brainy romance One Day.
review2: Ends better than it begins -- or middles.
review3: I couldn't help but feel the film was lent shades of colour by the book; colour that simply doesn't exist on the screen. I projected 435 pages of joy onto a film that probably didn't deserve it.
review4: An average romantic dramedy, 'One Day' tips its hand so early in the game that you won't be a bit surprised by anything that ensues.
review5: ...you can't help feeling this dreary tale could have done with a bit of fancy editing or narrative reconstruction.

title: The Future
review1: Not a crowd-pleaser by any measure, but a mature, bold and recklessly inquisitive film, however unpleasant it is to consume in the moment.
review2: Miranda July may be a bit too weird for her own good. On the other hand, it is a glorious weird.
review3: Provides plenty of material for July junkies as well as July detractors.
review4: Parece apenas interessado em lançar o meme dos "Lolcatz" como gênero cinematográfico.
review5: Miranda July takes the twee and cute thing WAY too far this time

title: Another Earth
review1: Buried within Another Earth's framework is a wonderful sci-fi movie, but Cahill and Marling have unfortunately set it amongst this otherwise drab and predictable human drama.
review2: The wildly improbable set-up is merely the jumping off point for an exploration of grief, guilt and redemption
review3: I didn't hate Another Earth so much as I found it to have begun with a fascinating sci fi premise only to produce, ultimately, a conventional relationship film.
review4: Another Earth occasionally slips into chin-stroking pretention, but it flies the flags for indies with ideas bigger than their budgets.
review5: Another Earth doesn't fully come off - the slow pace stops it achieving escape velocity - but the intriguing ideas and Marling's touching performance make it a promising debut.

title: Snowmen
review1: A surprisingly effective debut effort from writer-director Robert Kirbyson.
review3: Drama has positive messages; bullying and iffy humor, too.
review4: Much like the kids in this movie who come of age, so too does Robert Kirbyson's skill as a writer-director in his debut film Snowmen.
review5: The kids are charming and the supporting cast lift this comedy from above its direct-to-video ambitions.

title: Andy Hardy Meets Debutante
review1: It's classic Andy: he gets his comeuppance and then gets his happy ending. It's also a superb [jUDY] Garland turn.

title: Judge Hardy and Son
review1: You can also see the jalopy humor becoming one of the defining elements of the Andy Hardy series here.

title: Gang de qin (The Piano In A Factory)
review1: "Workers can do anything"
review2: A mildly humorous tale set in northern China about a project designed to bring more beauty to a disgustingly ugly environment.

title: Bobby Fischer Against The World
review1: A once-in-a-lifetime character makes for a fascinating documentary subject in producer-director Liz Garbus' "Bobby Fischer Against the World."
review2: Liz Garbus's documentary about the great American chess champion Bobby Fischer does its level best to avoid the easy cliché equating madness and genius, except that, in the case of Fischer, the cliché apparently holds up.
review3: Tactfully but strongly posits a connection between the genius he brought to an infinitely complex game and the madness that defined his relationship to just about everything else.
review4: Supplies a cracked, conflicted genius trapped in his ceaseless endgame.
review5: Garbus handles this decline with tact. The sorry spectacle of the ranting codger never effaces the image of the boy concentrating his entire being over a chessboard. You have to love that kid and pity him.

title: "Life, Above All"
review1: A well-meaning but ploddingly earnest after-school special...
review2: "Life, Above All" earns the tears it inspires. The film is about deep human emotions, evoked with sympathy and love.
review3: Perseverance is the theme of "Life, Above All," a drama that is deeply affecting, if also overwhelmingly bleak.
review4: There is less in-your-face grit in Cape Town-born director Oliver Schmitz's vision for this film than there is a careful pacing of somber revelations.
review5: In such a bleak story, the redemptive ending seems rushed and unconvincing, but director Oliver Schmitz has sent us a timely dispatch from a forgotten corner of the world that is honest above all.

title: Angel Dog
review1: Heartfelt dog drama about grief has grown-up emotion.

title: The Afterlight
review1: It's hard to embrace this glacially paced, symbolism-heavy film's elusive - when it's not being elliptical - story about a city couple's escape to rural life.
review2: Unfortunately, the subdued tone only adds distance, not depth, to their unstated issues.
review3: Promises more illumination than it delivers.
review4: Afterlight proceeds without much discernible plot or character development, its objects and places exuding more backstory than its people, though Rip Torn as the father of the sole male protagonist lends a certain woodsy authenticity.
review5: Tempering the film's oppressive emotions, the cinematographer Zoë White's exquisite compositions charge leaden rain clouds and rustling branches with eerie life, and dusty indoor corners with shadowy secrets.

title: The Help
review1: Is it really appropriate for us to all stand up and applaud this courageous, fictional white gIrl?
review2: Taylor's palpably meandering sensibilities are exacerbated by an almost comically overlong running time...
review3: Lifetime Channel movie with paternalistic liberalism bordering on Paula Deen malignity.
review4: A great story and a wonderful cast combine to make this drama a must-see.
review5: If you think the summer has been lacking in sophisticated adult entertainment, don't worry, 'The Help' is on the way.

title: Rapt
review1: "Rapt'' is smooth, cool, and efficient. It's a movie with very little wasted motion - or, for much of its length, wasted emotion.
review2: What lends "Rapt" its fascination is that it represents such a dramatic fall from grace for its hero.
review3: "Rapt" fuses strands of dramatic tension in a shrewd enough way that it even saves its sharpest cuts for the kidnapping's aftermath, when a well-heeled life laid bare must reconcile with a much different form of enforced solitude.
review4: What distinguishes "Rapt" from other kidnapping movies is that, virtually as soon as he is abducted, details of his life start coming out.
review5: Both a compelling character study and a handsomely mounted procedural, at various times suggesting Hitchcock, his French acolyte Claude Chabrol, the sadistic TV series "24" and the action movies of Michael Mann.

title: Tanner Hall
review1: Codirectors Francesca Gregorini and Tatiana von Furstenberg work up some believable, easygoing rapport between the young actresses, but since the story line is hackneyed, it's rapport in a vacuum.
review2: Rarely rises above the generic, though its atmosphere of coddled young people indulging themselves in opulent surroundings is palpably authentic.
review3: Ultimately not even the gifted Mara can keep the film from feeling like a gauzy portrait of privilege.
review4: The performances aren't bad, but the film quickly collapses into an incoherent, tonally inconsistent muddle with no narrative momentum.
review5: Allows room for a lot of thinking about other things - its cast most notably, since watching their struggle to move beyond the mundane is painful.

title: The Debt
review1: How can the film convincingly preach via Ms. Mirren's voice-over that truth is more valuable than justice while her character is exacting vengeance on screen?
review2: Younger audiences will likely find The Debt too slow for their liking, but what it lacks in realistic casting it gains in meatily plotted espionage and weighty drama.
review3: A taut and complex thriller, this movie won't be easy for forget.
review4: Tense, intelligent entertainment. That's rare, and that is more than enough.
review5: A taut, historical thriller about the capture of one of Nazism's most evil.

title: Circumstance
review1: The content feels familiar, but the perspective is fresh.
review2: Keshavarz, who was born in New York City and grew up in the U.S. and Iran, shows us how young people in Tehran get around the constrictive system...
review3: We never doubt the sincerity of the emotions on display, or of the foretaste Circumstance provides of a society on the brink of radical change.
review4: About a sexy, frank and politically contentious Iranian film, two things can be known for a certainty: (a) It sure wasn't made in Iran and (b) It won't be shown there either.
review5: [The] film is too much a wounded love story to slide into polemic.

title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes
review1: Caesar [the main ape] is the reason to see this daft, breathless picture.
review2: If you're a fan of the series, you'll love it; if you're not a fan it may make you one.
review3: Save Christopher Nolan's "Batman," no film so brilliantly reinvigorated a franchise more than this, a thrilling opening act that's equally captivating and leaves you anxiously awaiting the next installment.
review4: Rise of the Planet of the Apes has some life to it as an action film, but every time anyone opens their mouth, man or beast, you'll feel like someone figured out a way to sneak in groundbreaking CGI into your middle schooler's class play.
review5: Overall, Rise of the Planet of the Apes is intermittently entertaining with a few nice nods to the original series.

title: The Brothers Karamazov
review1: Bold handling of crude unbridled passion, of violently conflicting ideas, and of earthy humor makes up The Brothers Karamazov.
review2: Very uncertain in period and atmosphere, and saddled with some terrible performances.
review3: Conspicuous assets are the striking color photography and the musical score, both of which help a great deal in enhancing the drama's savage and soulful moods.
review4: While not as terrible as his subsequent adaptation of Lord Jim, this 1958 Hollywoodization of the Dostoyevsky novel by writer-director Richard Brooks is pretty grotesque all the same.
review5: I would avoid this film as readily as one avoids Siberia.

title: "Edward, My Son"
review1: The movie silently shrieks under the pressure of constant, hectic fear.
review3: Playing a bitter alcoholic wife (married to Spencer Tracy), Deborah Kerr received the first of her six Best Actress nomination for George Cukor's well acted melodrama.

title: Catch .44
review1: A drug-deal tale featuring top-drawer actors trying to have fun with a medium-strength script. Sometimes they succeed, but not often enough to elevate the film to "Pulp Fiction" territory.
review2: Although it gives Willis and Whitaker an off-road chance to show off their character-actor chops, there's not much to recommend in this cinematic conceit.
review4: A collection of all the Quentin Tarantino mannerisms we make fun of ... but none of the understanding of human nature that goes along with them.

title: Toast
review1: Like its namesake, "Toast" is crusty comfort food with little nutritional substance.
review2: "Toast" has three things deserving of adoration: spectacular lemon-meringue pies, the songs of Dusty Springfield and Helena Bonham Carter.
review3: Director S.J. Clarkson seems oblivious to the dissonance; perhaps he's deafened by the music.
review4: For the most part, the movie feels like an emotional vacuum, mirroring the drab vanilla and mint green interiors of the Slaters' home.
review5: "Toast," is by turns sweet and tart, airy and rich and, above all, a thoroughly irresistible confection.

title: Dolphin Tale
review1: It just wants to make you leave the theater in a good mood. It certainly accomplishes that.
review2: Dolphin Tale, an inspirational tale about a Little Dolphin Who Could, will swim into your heart despite some melodrama and predictability.
review3: Middle-of-the-road milquetoast.
review4: It's an earnest, sweet film that relies on the extraordinary true story of Winter, the rescued dolphin, and little on manipulative Hollywood tricks.
review5: When I write the "Cookie Awards" in my annual Oscar-season column for the Quad-City Times, I always include this category: Most Embarrassing Crying Spell. There is no question which movie will 'win' the award. I bawled when I watched 'Dolphin Tale.'

title: Colombiana
review1: A guilty pleasure film that is more fun than it deserves to be.
review2: You keep wanting "Colombiana" to go all the way in one direction, or all the way in the other. Instead, it just sits there, content to give Saldana a lollypop.
review3: Colombiana contains some thrilling scenes as well as an interesting sense of twisted humor, but there's not enough here to really keep us engaged.
review4: Laugh out loud exploitation...See Zoe shoot. See Zoe kill. See Zoe strip (PG-13 style)
review5: Colombiana is caught somewhere in the middle of an engaging character drama and a brainless action extravaganza.

title: Warrior
review1: "Warrior" is basically an action flick for chicks. You would not believe the amount of melodrama.
review2: Warrior is an ode to valour-ruined men, in war, in peace, in the octagon.
review3: Director Gavin O'Connor tries sprucing up the material by swapping out boxing for mixed martial arts, but it's still the same old story told the same old way. At least Real Steel had robots.
review4: The punches always seem that much harder when you understand just why they hurt.
review5: A straight genre picture, but the best MMA movie ever.

title: The Tempest
review1: You expect Nicolas Cage to pop up from behind a sand dune on a Harley brandishing a rocket launcher.
review2: Julie Taymor has a theatre director's idea of how movies work. That's not a compliment.
review3: Dispensing with tableau compositions, this adaptation feels liberated from static theatrical and, to a lesser degree, cinematic convention by the overall openness of its staging and camerawork that's somewhere between handheld and Steadicam.
review4: There are two reasons to watch The Tempest: if you're a fan of Shakespeare, or a fan of Helen Mirren.
review5: Hundreds of years ago, Shakespeare would have never imagined this story could look like Taymor's vision.

title: Pete Smalls is Dead
review1: Many of the film's storytelling beats seems drawn perhaps a little too closely from "The Long Goodbye," Raymond Chandler's elegiac detective novel adapted into a classic by Robert Altman.
review2: "Pete Smalls is Dead" nearly kills itself with an overdose of cutesy mainlined hipsterism.

title: The Bodyguard (Kaavalan)
review1: Even more than its overwrought music-video numbers and needlessly complicated finale, Khan ups the movie's ridiculousness.
review2: A twist near the end sends this contrived movie into a maudlin stratosphere from which it doesn't recover.

title: In the Name of the King 2
Chop
review1: At its best moments it seems to be channeling something co-written by Neil Simon and Eli Roth.

title: My Friend Pinto
review1: It's cute, sort of, as well as crudely slapstick and sweetly picaresque, and just a bit misty and crispy.
review3: A nice idea, but just never a funny one.

title: The Tunnel Movie
review2: When scary s--- happens, the terror sticks with you because you're never shown enough to be certain of anything.
review3: [It] might sound like a mundane retread of recent creature features such as Creep or The Descent, but it manages to be something a bit more haunting in practice.
review4: Not a bad effort for a mini-budgeted fan-funded horror project.
review5: The audience is teased with fleeting glimpses of the threat lurking in the shadows and its first real appearance is played so well it is a thing of horror poetry.

title: "Tuesday, After Christmas"
review1: "Tuesday, After Christmas" goes down pretty smooth, with a sneaky-powerful aftertaste.
review2: The latest bloom from the flourishing garden that is Romanian cinema, Radu Muntean's Tuesday, After Christmas chronicles the emotional fallout from a classic love triangle, but it unfolds with the agonizing tension of a suspense film.
review3: Like an alternate-universe Woody Allen film, in which real people wrestle with what their hearts want despite the hurt it causes everyone, including themselves.
review4: More about well-observed moments of everyday life than it is about heightened melodrama.
review5: Muntean has pulled off the near-impossible, turning each scene (captured in capacious long takes) into arias of generosity for his actors.

title: The First Grader
review1: It's funny how 'real life' sometimes conforms so closely to hackneyed patterns of screenwriting.
review2: An earnest "true story" that hits many of the expected importance-of- education grace notes, but never quite achieves a lump-in-your-throat reaction
review3: achieves a poignant, humanist sincerity
review4: The First Grader is a self-congratulatory and subtlety-free slog that makes saints of its protagonists, devils out of its antagonists and narcoleptics out of its audience.
review5: With the melodrama cranked up as high as it is, it's hard to believe this was a true story.

title: Brighton Rock
review1: Drab in color, with very little of Brighton-they shot in neighboring Eastbourne, apparently because Brighton is too posh now to be its old self.
review2: As remakes go, this "Brighton Rock" is probably unnecessary, but it's a well- acted, stylishly filmed thriller and a good story well told.
review3: There's a brutish beauty to the mean world of Brighton Rock that feels very '40s even in the '60s.
review4: "Brighton Rock" doesn't rise to classic status, but it's an intriguing mood piece.
review5: Joffe commits the novice director's mistake of using every visual trick in the book and a few not yet recorded.

title: Refuge
review1: The central characters' coupledom might bring them a safe haven, but audiences will be left out in the cold.
review2: Just as unsatisfying and unrealistic as a happily-ever-after story about a damsel and a prince she has barely met.
review3: Jessica Goldberg's sluggish directorial debut feels like a leftover from the 1990s, when dank indie dramas littered film-festival lineups.
review4: Even at its well-meaning best, Refuge is listless.
review5: Complex film about family trauma has heavy themes.

title: The Greening Of Whitney Brown
review1: It's all extraordinarily predictable, made no more palatable by flat characters and a dull cast.
review2: There's a fair amount of greening, but that doesn't make Whitney any less grating.
review3: As she learns the value of public schools and pickup trucks, her erstwhile friends in Philadelphia seem happy to be rid of her. By movie's end, you'll feel exactly the same.
review4: It flies off the rails in a third act so devoid of logic it could have been concocted on the moon.
review5: Helmer Odiorne creates a suitably groomed pastoral setting for Gilchriest's relentlessly upbeat script, but does little to suggest a context larger than Whitney's limited p.o.v.

title: The Fat Boy Chronicles
review1: Earnest but flawed teen film about obesity and bullying.

title: Puncture
review1: "Puncture" has the unusual problem of being almost too intriguing; its based-on-true-events story seems to cry out for documentary treatment.
review2: "Puncture'' is based on an actual court case. But is this a story best served by focusing on the legal battle or the arc of Mike's flawed hero?
review3: Evans works so hard to look like a drug addict that it undermines the character's effort not to look like one.
review4: It's a thoughtful entry in the growing subgenre of whistle-blower dramas.
review5: Does a commendable job of merging its David vs. Goliath elements with Weiss' personal problems, doing justice to the fact that "Puncture" is based on true people and an actual case.

title: From Prada to Nada
review1: It's just predictable rom-com fare in need of a lot more spice.
review2: The broad humour and cultural caricatures in the film's opening moments will be especially dispiriting to any English literature professors in the audience.
review3: If the effort to shoehorn Austen's social commentary into a modern context sometimes seems nonsensical or forced, the actors-especially now-grown Spy Kid Vega-have charm to spare.
review4: There's something crassly disingenuous about the movie's blatant demographic pandering (hooray for immigration-panic jokes!) and half-a--ed condemnation of gluttony.
review5: Simply put, From Prada To Nada is Sense And Sensibility For Dummies, as set in modern-day Los Angeles.

title: Removal
review1: While his name isn't as instantly accessible as his costars, Mark Kelly carries this movie from beginning to end and holds his own well against perhaps more charismatic but ultimately less-deep performances.

title: Ghoul
review1: It's quite the watch, even if the final half drops the ball completely.

title: Higher Ground
review1: Vera Farmiga makes a heavenly debut as a director with Higher Ground, a compelling drama about a woman's spiritual journey.
review2: The film's quiet realism demands from us our own act of faith: We're asked to watch closely and to listen intently in the promise of a greater reward to come. Well, the promise is partly kept.
review3: The picture never settles for easy answers, and these warmly-drawn characters are granted a surprising complexity.
review4: Higher Ground is a fantastic debut for Farmiga.
review5: Farmiga challenges herself and the viewer. Some may shrink from that challenge, but thankfully, our gutsy director and star never does

title: A Mile in His Shoes
review1: Inspirational baseball tale about an autistic pitcher.

title: Protektor
review1: Though it remains a little too enigmatic, Marek Najbrt's Holocaust drama is atmospheric enough to keep us edgy on its heroine's behalf.
review2: Dipping in and out of luminous black and white, "Protektor" has a distancing glamour that prevents the story from digging in.
review3: Protektor is simply another in a long line of diluted stories about life during wartime, one whose diminished returns only further trivialize a legacy of real-life horror.
review4: Najbrt gets the look and feel of noir fatalism down, but storytelling that alternates between roughshod and lethargic means the film doesn't hold together as much more than pretty fragments.

review1: The Revolution will not be televised, Gil Scott-Heron once sang. Nor should it be filmed, we might add -- at least not as a costume drama with stirring speeches, an inspirational love story and gloriously heroic military charges.
review2: Earnest and studious to a fault. Rarely has a film about upheaval felt more like a textbook.
review3: May be slow going for anyone not well-versed in this chapter of Chinese history.
review4: Packed with so many characters and subtitled history lessons it barely allows its excellent main cast room to maneuver.
review5: What should be rousing stuff - a republic is born! the chains of feudalism thrown off! - remains a kind of lavishly illustrated history lesson.

title: Moneyball
review1: Moneyball is a winner, one of the freshest and smartest sports movies in years.
review2: "Moneyball" ultimately leaves you with goose bumps all over, except not the good kind you get from a rousing crowd-pleaser.
review3: A movie about baseball that contains surprisingly little baseball, it's more like The Bad News Bears with an economics degree.
review4: Directed by Capote's Bennett Miller, this is one helluva good sports movie. It's a terrific movie, period.
review5: Writer Aaron Sorkin works best at auctioneer speeds, and some of the best scenes involve Pitt's character working the phones, calling and stalling other teams' managers, trading players like a used-car salesman.

title: Answer This!
review1: Ann Arbor has never been more lovingly embraced and portrayed.
review2: ...a curiously misguided piece of work that squanders the talents of an undeniably strong group of performers...

title: The Wylds (The Adventures of Chris Fable)
There Be Dragons
review1: Joffe, working from his own script, presents the men's lives as evidence of difficult choices, but this pedantic movie is never fully invested in any of them.
review2: Few films about the Spanish Civil War have been any good -- Pan's Labyrinth being the big exception.
review3: Joffé is out of depth when it comes to Escrivá's religious experiences. It's clear he wants the film to show how faith works within us, but he does it by resorting to the most hackneyed imagery.
review4: Clunk, clunk, squish. That is the sound of the dead language in Roland Joffé's screenplay for "There Be Dragons" as it tramples his would-be epic of the Spanish Civil War into an indigestible pulp.
review5: I like grandeur and richly nuanced storytelling. I also like lobster bisque. But I don't want to drink a gallon of it in a single sitting.

title: Undocumented
review1: Marco Williams' remarkable film The Undocumented... considers these many burdens in a series of contexts.

title: Bombay Beach
review1: "Bombay Beach" is an oasis of creativity in the documentary landscape.
review2: Har'el's film is at times bizarrely uplifting, at others crushingly sad...
review3: That it documents rural poverty in the American West without exploiting or sanctifying its subjects would be cause enough for praise. But this doesn't begin to approach what Alma Har'el pulls off with her hybrid doc knockout Bombay Beach.
review4: More lyrical tone poem than straightforward documentary.
review5: You either like this kind of ambitious, brave, borderless experiment or you don't, and I think it's absolutely magical and tragic.

title: Courageous
review1: It takes a certain touch to pull it off, and here, the serviceable cast just doesn't have it in them.
review2: The many topics raised - gangs, drugs, immigration, absentee parents, poverty - are examined with didacticism and platitudes instead of by mining their inherent complexities.
review3: Overplotted and understructured, "Courageous" is a slog to get through at 130 minutes.
review4: Devolves into over-the-top drama and a suffocating heavy-handedness.
review5: Fails to answer the more pressing question of why religious sagas such as this treat subtlety as a sin.

title: Joy Road
review1: A riveting, gritty, palpably entertaining drama.

title: Dirty Girl
review1: Dirty Girl isn't. Sorry, but it's just faux grime, a thin layer of bad behaviour that wipes clean with a two-ply tissue to reveal the real movie beneath - all shiny sentimentality.
review2: Dirty Girl broadcasts its intent to be edgy and subversive - poking fun throughout at small-town, conservative attitudes toward sex and morality - without ever achieving subversion.
review3: The movie is all over the place, searching for an identity that proves almost entirely elusive.
review4: If your sensibility is pure trashy camp, don't expect anyone not to laugh when you try to be earnest.
review5: One can appreciate an artistic effort without actually endorsing it, which may be the most generous approach to Abe Sylvia's frustratingly uneven debut.

title: The Ides of March
review1: Why is this sleek, well-crafted movie almost impossble to get excited about?
review2: A brilliant political thriller about strategy, loyalty and idealism that is willing to unmask candidates who build their campaigns on slogans, not policies.
review3: Well-produced and well-acted middlebrow entertainment, a political "expose" that will shock only pearl-clutchers and naive dopes.
review4: A gripping, political thriller packed with tremendous performances and supremely confident direction by George Clooney.
review5: George Clooney officially passes the impish matinee idol torch to Ryan Gosling in this smart, hella-cool (does Clooney waste his time on any other kind of movie these days?) political drama.

title: Special Treatment
review1: Though the parallels drawn between therapy and prostitution grow tiresome, the duo's interaction is peppered with inspired comedic moments.
review2: At the end, there is no great revelation, but Huppert has succeeded once again in making us wonder what's going on in there.
review3: Complex, compassionate and endlessly illuminating...
review4: It isn't a lightweight erotic romp at all, but a complicated and delicate two-person odyssey that's much richer and subtler than that.
review5: As clichés trot through their sessions - it's like "In Treatment" as bedroom farce - we check out. Huppert, though, is as fearless as ever.

title: Mysteries of Lisbon
review1: The production design and costumes are immaculate, while Ruiz's camera glides around soirées, ducks under tables and peers from behind curtains.
review2: A sumptuous unravelling of secrets wrapped in tantalizing stories that gradually interconnect the lives of an ensemble of characters who seduce, betray and defend each other in the years surrounding the Peninsular War.
review3: Based on the sprawling 19th-century novel by Camilo Castelo Branco, Chilean director Raul Ruiz renders an equally sprawling tale filled with love and war, violence and vengeance and the search for identity.
review4: This isn't one of those epics that uses length as a bludgeon. Rather than sweep, the movie spirals, twisting its viewpoint to reveal tales within tales.
review5: A sprawling 19th century novel filtered through the mind of a trickster filmmaker, the late Raúl Ruiz, who both delights in and subverts his wildly complex and melodramatic source material.

title: Caterpillar
review1: The husband may look like a caterpillar, but it's the wife who goes through a transformation.
review2: "Caterpillar" is difficult to watch. But it's directed, acted and photographed well, and it's worth seeing even if it makes you uncomfortable.
review3: Blends a B-movie aesthetic, brilliant use of montage and documentary elements and a scathing critique of nationalism and militarism.
review4: Might be read as a reaction to hawkish nationalism, but it's more a cry for the unknown soldier in the kitchen and bedroom.
review5: Legendary Japanese softcore auteur Kôji Wakamatsu channels Samuel Fuller for a twisted domestic-drama-cum-psychosexual-evisceration of Japan's fascist past.

title: United Red Army
review1: If you're keeping tabs on the recent cinematic reconsideration of 1960s and '70s left-wing terrorism, Wakamatsu's devastating chronicle of the ultra-violent fringe of Japanese student radicalism is a must-see.
review2: Running more than three hours, "United Red Army" is a raw mix of documentary and fiction...
review3: The stilted and awkward physical and vocal performances in combination with the visually flat cinematography bring to mind the look, sound and visual texture of American daytime soaps, an association that perversely makes the movie more and more watchable.
review4: The film's commitment to representing the harsh truths of an unfortunate historical moment is admirable, but it tends to grate rather than illuminate.
review5: Grueling [but] engrossing.

title: Age of Heroes
review2: The gruelling training, clandestine mission and sacrifice is familiar Boy's Own stuff but the lack of a decent budget really hurts the film.
review3: Dyer has forged a career around screen violence which can leave a very unpleasant aftertaste. But this is a relatively conventional Second World War story about seizing Nazi radar technology from occupied Norway and he's all the better for it.
review4: This film's shoestring budget is just far too apparent, making it impossible to take seriously. But it has its moments.
review5: Bean and Danny Dyer butt heads in an engaging manner, and the icy locations add an atmospheric backdrop.

title: Bed & Breakfast
review1: The plotting is lazy and the broad playing of the supporting characters tips them into caricature. Jake's Latina maid thinks Ana's mannered lawyer is 'light in the loafers'. But, no, he's not gay; he's just English.

title: Restless
review1: If you haven't seen a wasting disease in real life, you might think "Restless" is romantic. If you have, you might diagnose it as terminally cute.
review2: "Restless" exudes the maturity that eludes Mr. Van Sant's previous fusions of youth and death. It's too bad he still hasn't learned to shower his female leads with the same adoring attention he lavishes on his male ones.
review3: This movie pretends it's about death -- our couple meets because Enoch crashes funerals, a literary device that has no relevance here -- but it never scratches past the perfect pale void faces of its leads.
review4: Better stock up on tissues.
review5: Quirky, death-obsessed...oddly touching...faintly amusing

title: Punished (Bou ying)
review2: "Punished" is a gripping thriller. Well-directed. Well-acted. And, a great story to boot. Paul Chambers, CNN.

review1: Rogen's vulgar, unexpected decency is quietly moving.
review2: It's a film about cancer, but it never succumbs to the morose trappings of its cinematic cousins ... it's done with such a subtle grace that it's easy to forget your heart is being tugged at by filmmakers.
review3: An honest, earnest and powerful look at a young person's battle with cancer.
review4: Even with all its faults, it's pretty difficult not to be won over.
review5: It's a brave plan to make a cancer movie that's moving, uplifting and pant-wettingly funny. But against the odds, it's definitely a case of remission accomplished.

title: The Whistleblower
review1: A first-rate one-woman-against-the-system drama, a film benefiting from grim recreations of an ugly reality and a stellar cast determined to expose it.
review2: The Whistleblower offers fantastic performances from the entire cast. It's very atmospheric with grisly authenticity and a truly moving plot.
review3: A dark, uncompromising look into the disturbing world of human trafficking.
review4: Weisz's best role, and best performance, since "The Constant Gardener.
review5: The thriller stuff is very soft, and the docudrama stuff is too focused on "Oscar moments" (i.e. huge expressions of outrage and torment).

title: Another Happy Day
review1: Levinson piles on the anguish with such abandon he never convinces you that these people would ever speak to each other, much less live under the same roof.
review2: Combines some of the stock elements of a family film with an extra something - a go-for-the-jugular quality, a kind of Ingmar Bergman-like honesty and viciousness that brings it up a notch.
review3: "Another Happy Day" becomes increasingly difficult to watch, despite its intelligence and strong cast. You wish this family well, but you're grateful to see the last of them.
review4: Sam Levinson has proven that he can get a movie made. Good for him. But he still has to prove that he has a story to tell.
review5: If you liked Rachel Getting Married or Margot at the Wedding, you probably have good taste, so you should avoid this one.

title: Shut Up Little Man!
review1: The unsuspecting stars (who died in 1992 and '96, respectively) begin to seem less like nightmare neighbors and more like the victims of rampant exploitation and voyeurism.
review2: Bate chronicles the whole wooly story with admirable clarity and resourcefulness, even when a lack of visual material forces him to resort too often to reenactment and dramatization.
review3: Casts a wide net of inquiry over this sometimes appalling story, which raises timely questions about the differences between creation and exploitation.
review4: It's a strange story, and the stylish and well-edited documentary "Shut Up Little Man! An Audio Misadventure" gets it down. But yet it doesn't quite get it.
review5: For the most part, this is a feature-length documentary that begs to be turned into a YouTube clip -- junky and ephemeral.

title: Real Steel
review1: All this swiping from Stallone, and they couldn't find room for a cameo by Paulie's birthday robot?
review2: This movie about robot boxing needs more robot boxing.
review3: Real Steel envisions a future where boxing has evolved into giant fighting robots. Great special effects and cool fight choreography makes this a must-see.
review4: Good thing we all love Hugh Jackman so much
review5: Real Steel offers plenty of fun and engaging moments -- of both the human character drama and giant CGI robot battle variety.

title: Mausam
review2: Grandiose dressing is just that, dressing, if that pair at the center doesn't connect.
review3: Fine performances, sophisticated cinematography and a melodious score give Mausam a universal appeal.
review4: Sun-drenched shots of Kapoor in full fighter-pilot mode are shamelessly plagiarised from Tony Scott's Top Gun (1986), but provide a welcome diversion from the chest-heaving 'Mills-&-Boon' moments that dominate the film.

title: Janie Jones
review1: "Janie Jones'' would feel more assured if Rosenthal had shown more inclination to commit.
review2: Nivola and Breslin make a terrific mismatched pair in a film that often resembles a mash-up of "Crazy Heart" and Sofia Coppola's "Somewhere"...
review3: A mixture of discordant notes and way-too-familiar chords.
review4: The movie works because it's essentially an old-fashioned two-hander for a couple of subtle and terrific actors.
review5: After a messy, cliched first half, Janie Jones is barely salvaged by the lightweight sweetness that emerges once it becomes a two-hander for Breslin and Nivola.

title: The Thing
review1: A misguided and generally worthless prequel...
review2: There's just no sense of dread in this "Thing," no notion that these people are truly at the edge of the world, with nowhere to escape and no one to trust.
review3: Since Heijningen already had dibs on The Thing's hallowed name, he didn't even bother trying to conjure any of its slow-burning suspense or claustrophobic vibe.
review4: For a creature feature set on the South Pole, it lacks urgency, or even a sense that it's very cold in Antarctica.
review5: The fact that The Thing falls flat is proof positive that unlike the film's industrious alien, parasitic remakes can't easily carbon copy the host.

title: Texas Killing Fields
review1: The characters will be familiar to fans of police procedural shows and TV movies.
review2: The story simply doesn't stand up, with its combination of well-worn plot elements and confusing red herrings -- or maybe they're just details that don't add up.
review3: [A] southern-fried rehash of David Fincher's Seven.
review4: Scenes do not always necessarily follow one another. I was sometimes unclear who some of the characters were.
review5: The film doesn't really go anywhere or establish any narrative sense, which is problem, since it's ostensibly a police procedural.

title: Outrage
review1: How can anyone can get excited over something so grim and redundant?
review2: It's a gangster story, told well, with no punches pulled.
review3: Kitano is clearly enjoying his powers as a master of the form, and the movie invites the viewer to share in his enjoyment.
review4: It's like a version of "Cinema Paradiso" where all the murders were saved up by a censor and strung together for a bloodbath.
review5: True Kitano fans will find its title sadly ironic.

title: The Double
review1: Questionable motives and unbelievable decisions are relatively small potatoes compared with the Sputnik-size plotholes.
review2: Like a stripper who gets naked too quickly, the lukewarm spy thriller "The Double" lays out its big plot twist early in the movie - and soon finds, shivering, that it has nowhere else to go.
review3: When the story starts to fall apart you're left wondering if the film was worth all the money and effort that went into making it.
review4: It's simply not very good.
review5: Ineptly realized in everything but its chase scenes (which are, I'll admit, pretty good).

title: The Mill and the Cross
review1: We almost feel that we ourselves have accomplished something just by being around while Bruegel doodled.
review2: "The Mill and the Cross" might not be perfect, but it's stimulating, hypnotic and, in its unique way, exciting.
review3: The Mill and the Cross may thrill you. But be prepared for a fight. Twenty minutes in, your companion may throw up his or her arms and complain, "This is like watching a painting dry."
review4: The Mill & the Cross invites us to inhabit a work of art along with the mind of the man who made it and to be enthralled by the images shared in vivid tableaux by visionary Polish director Lech Majewski.
review5: What hangs before us is so striking, beautiful, strange, vast, horrifying, ethereal, lifelike - so alive - that we're desperate to enter the other side of the canvas, to be inside the painting.

title: Drive
review1: What it had going for it was an uncanny and moving relationship between Gosling and Mulligan.
review2: It's understandable that the hipster critical mob would put its stamp of approval on this one.
review3: Swoon.
review4: I'll never forget the first time I saw Drive. I've since never been able to replicate the experience.
review5: This is pop art of the highest degree.

title: You and I (Finding t.A.T.u.)
review1: Already a somewhat fascinating (if also tiresome) time capsule of forgotten pop culture less than five years after it finished production.

title: The Sunset Limited
review2: A thinking man's drama that rolls deep, heavy thoughts around and around, trying to puzzle out where the truth lies. Or, indeed, if what we see as the truth is just that: a lie.

review1: The film is successful in an absorbing sort of way, but underwhelming.
review2: Tykwer's script is structured so that the audience knows more about the characters' connections than they do. As each faces a midlife crisis/turning point, fate sometimes appears to be calling the shots.
review3: Tykwer can't seem to turn Hanna, Simon and Adam into real people. They feel like pawns in the service of a more cerebral diversion than the game of life.
review4: It's a funny, fearless, suspenseful sex comedy that, in drawing on science and philosophy and art and death, risks accusations of pretentiousness.
review5: Despite its fascinating and humorous moments, one can't help but be frustrated when at times it switches away to spiritual pretentiousness.

title: Anonymous
review1: ...it's ultimately clear that Emmerich should stick to the larger-than-life, blockbuster fare with which he's become associated.
review2: The director offers up an unfocused but intriguing alternate look at William Shakespeare.
review3: Roland Emmerich takes a questionable literary controversy and deftly forms it into an Elizabethan political drama in the Shakespeare-themed 'Anonymous'.
review4: Bad history beautifully done.
review5: Don't let the fact that it's different - or unadulterated bullshit of the highest order - put you off a story that, in truth, is more interesting than it is wholly entertaining or accurate.

title: Bless the Beasts and Children
review1: Is it in favor of buffalo? Against parents who cause their children to become neurotic? In favor of neurotic kids because they're more sensitive than well-adjusted kids? An argument for gun control?
review2: Stanley Kramer's children tale, which is earnest and obvious in its message, is now best known for its Oscar-nominated tune.
review3: An ensemble piece from start to finish, it's difficult to single out one particular actor for comment.

title: Fireflies in the Garden
review1: This histrionic family drama must have looked good on paper to attract such a big-name cast, but on the screen it comes off as glib, rushed, and underdeveloped.
review2: The emotional effectiveness varies from moment to moment between not pushing too hard or simply not pulling hard enough.
review3: A dreadful exercise in navel-gazing that resides in a particularly trite corner of Pat Conroy-ville.
review4: A dispiriting rehash of dysfunctional family clichés that seems to last longer than Thanksgiving Day dinner.
review5: The actors are all good and a few scenes -- an opening family argument, a crucial battle when Michael finally fights back -- are painfully moving.

title: A Warrior's Heart
review1: Everything that happens is certain to happen from the first minutes, and the only hope is that these things might happen quickly or in some new or interesting way. They don't.
review2: The greatest lacrosse movie of the 21st century...
review3: Respectably crafted but thoroughly predictable.
review4: With an emotional depth roughly equivalent to that of his lacrosse stick, the lunk-like Lutz mourns his Marine dad's death...
review5: A ho-hum drama whose many moving parts feel decidedly recycled.

title: Lady and the Tramp
review1: Walt Disney has for so long parlayed gooey sentiment and stark horror into profitable cartoons that most moviegoers are apt to be more surprised than disappointed to discover that the combination somehow does not work this time.
review2: The wider canvas and extra detail work reportedly meant an additional 30% in negative cost. It was a sound investment.
review3: Disney's imagination seems at a low ebb, saddled with a shrunken, excessively naturalistic style in line with the diminished possibilities of postwar animation, and not yet graced by the inspiration that would redeem that style in Sleeping Beauty.
review4: Happily the cameo lowlife, an excellent manic beaver, the famously villainous Siamese, and classic songs rescue the film from dumb animal sentiment.
review5: The sentimentality is mighty, and the use of the CinemaScope size does not make for any less awareness of the thickness of the goo.

title: The Devil's Rock
review2: A low-budget but well-made horror flick that earns points due to two strong leads and some slick visual effects.
review3: For all its gore, The Devil's Rock is an undercooked chiller, but it cleverly uses the conventional tropes of diabolism to comment on the horrors of war.
review4: By keeping the action confined to the tunnels and cells of the blockhouse, Campion creates a claustrophobic setting, but for all the gore and demonic transmogrification, there's a distinct lack of chills and frights.
review5: Means well but ultimately lacks original thrills.

title: "Drive, He Said"
review1: Jack Nicholson's first venture into direction is very much a film of its time.
review2: Nicholson deftly illustrates the background cynicism of big time sports against the more obvious cynicism of college life.
review3: No way can it be said to work, despite the cast's cultish distinction, but it still knocks most of its quasi-radical contemporaries sideways as an index of doomed '60s/'70s causes and confusions.
review4: A disorganized but occasionally brilliant movie about two college students and the world they, and we, inhabit.
review5: All of the film's characters, and all of the performances, are touched with the kind of unexpected sensibility and decency that are rare in most films of this genre.

title: Boogie (Summer Holiday)
review1: Naturalistic performances, long takes, unfussy edits and a story that unfolds over a few hours are all present and correct.
review2: Three 30-somethings relive their gloriously lurid college days for one night only in Radu Muntean's Boogie, a restrained and honest look at the male midlife crisis in an embryonic state.
review3: Hampered by pacing that borders on glacial, the performances infuse the story with lingering melancholy.
review4: Small but sharp and extremely well observed.
review5: An impressive chamber piece by a director who needs watching.

title: All Things Fall Apart
review1: Only marginally more sophisticated in its treatment of cancer than The Room, which treated it as a bizarre aside never to be mentioned again.
review2: This quietly affecting work bodes well for the musician-turned-mogul's future creative endeavors for his Cheetah Vision Films banner.
review3: Straining to be meaningful until its blue in the face, All Things Fall Apart is a hackneyed, stilted production, held back in great part by Jackson's decision to insert himself in the lead role.

title: Elite Squad: The Enemy Within
review1: The pace is quick, the violence is rough, and the visual style is documentary as Padilha hammers home his point: Someone is forever in the pocket of someone else as The System constantly adapts to protect itself.
review2: When this Enemy Within settles into key action sequences, such as a stunning nighttime ambush or a daytime battle against Fabio, it becomes wildly entertaining.
review3: Throttles forward with remarkable aplomb and easily leaves the original in the dust.
review4: Elite Squad is just urgent and complex enough to make it clear violence is more than a matter for academic debate.
review5: A fast-paced, hard-hitting Brazilian police thriller.

title: Mozart's Sister
review1: Gilded authentic locations and restrained performances provide an effective setting for Féret's theory about Nannerl's talent being stifled by conventions.
review2: A meandering but transporting journey, which offers glimpses of a world as resplendent as it is stifling.
review3: The music, of course, resonates. And so does this exquisite heartbreaker of a story.
review4: An alternately rapturous and frustrating experience.
review5: This is a sad story in rich surroundings that makes you wonder how many women of genius were left behind.

title: The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)
review1: In stark contrast to the original's cool, clinical horror, Martin's cack-handed creation of the arse-to-mouth creature is played for cheap, sick slapstick laughs.
review2: Most children give up their poop obsession by age four. Tom Six still hasn't.
review3: Martin may lack his rôle model's surgical skills, professional tools, scientific interests or concern with clinical hygiene - but in all his sick, sweaty grotesquery, Martin is us.
review4: The gratuitous and exploitative nature of the violence, coupled with very little story development and plot, makes for a film without any real purpose other to shock and appall.
review5: Rather than trying to entertain us, director Tom Six goes all out in an attempt to make us sick, to offend our very sensibilities. He has succeeded. And screw him for that.

title: Take Shelter
review1: In my estimate, this unique and frequently arresting film suffers from the monotony of the lead players' affect, and from the film's urge to have its gloomy cake and eat it.
review2: A hallucinatory thriller anchored by a deeply resonant sense of unease.
review3: There's no suspense and little surprise. Just a long. slow grind to ruin.
review4: Tight editing and pace make for a careful and thoughtful film that is a very strong piece of cinema.
review5: Director Nichols walks a tightrope between giving us a dark, Gothic tale of misunderstood prophecy and a sobering lesson on the state of mental health care in rural America.

title: "Mama, I Want to Sing!"
review1: Preachy musical has few surprises, not enough songs.

title: Buzzkill
review1: A slow-motion car crash of miscalculated charisma, BuzzKill lives and rapidly dies by Daniel Raymont's grating lead performance.
review3: It's a bad movie, but worse, it's an abysmal representation of The Second City, an organization I once believed retained such impeccable taste in the realm of humor.

title: The Rum Diary
review1: I'm glad Depp and Thompson were so close, and I'm sure Hunter would have been touched by the tribute. But that doesn't make it any fun for the rest of us to watch.
review2: An entertaining but misfired take on the formative years of famed Gonzo journalist Hunter S. Thompson.
review3: Depp and writer-director Bruce Robinson ("Withnail & I") pack the script with pithy Hunter-isms, hurling many of Thompson's euphonious locutions at us right from the opening scene.
review4: Intriguing performances help The Rum Diary successfully capture the spirit of the source material -- even if the result is a scattered piece of filmmaking.
review5: Perhaps this material works better as a novel, where Thompson would have been able to take his time developing each story as it occurred, but as a film, it just doesn't work.

title: The Fugitive
review5: John Ford's The Fugitive is as beautiful a film as was ever lensed.

title: Glitch in the Grid
review1: Not much happens, but the most basic shifts in time and place are so badly signposted, you'd be lost without a synopsis.
review4: Live-action and animated art film, à la the Quay Brothers, of a spiritually ungrounded young man and his friends.
review5: A tour de force that combines surrealist esthetics with political and social insights timed perfectly to coincide with Occupy Wall Street.

title: Apostle Peter and the Last Supper
The Mighty Macs
review1: Sometimes a film feels a bit too pat and yet is impossible to resist.
review2: Without resorting to any trick plays, "The Mighty Macs" is the equivalent of high-top Converse All-Stars: timeless and effective, but perhaps not flashy enough for the kids at the mall.
review3: The blandly inspirational sports flick "The Mighty Macs" is warm- spirited but all too obvious, even as the charms of its lead performer Carla Gugino help sell this familiar story.
review4: There's something refreshingly unpushy about the movie and its beliefs, and Gugino seems to be sauntering through on her way to a different, spikier movie, the kind that is her stock in trade.
review5: [It's] given such old-fashioned, kid-gloves treatment that its potential warmth and excitement caves under the weight of writer-producer-director Tim Chambers' good intentions.

title: Honey 2
review1: It's fine for the genre, but one day it'd be great to see an urban dance flick with more ambition.
review3: For dance fans, it'll work. But for anyone else watching the movie, there are better films out there, and who's going to watch this if they're not a dance fan?
review4: Pointless sequel is a waste of time, too mature for tweens.
review5: It's a sequel nobody asked for, and unsurprisingly, it sucks.

title: Most Valuable Players
review2: Moving, engaging docu about high school musical theater.

title: Five Star Day
review1: Buday's script is directionless and his direction listless.
review2: 5 Star Day has a low-key air that often works, allowing its characters to behave like people instead of twee constructions.
review3: The uneven script, repetitive tropes and over-indulgence of actorly bits slow the pace, tipping youthful casualness into complacency.
review4: The script lacks the depth to transcend its cutesy gimmick and -- as with the misleading horoscopes that fuel the plot -- the film never approaches a five star level.
review5: Mr. Gigandet shows surprising sensitivity and sweetness previously untapped. He's not what I expected, and neither is Five Star Day.

title: Spork
review1: A potty and potty-mouthed junior-high school musical that is by turns both energetic and slack.
review2: Camp often means a lack of feeling and generalized disdain; not so in "Spork," which has as much heart as "Sixteen Candles."
review3: As uplifting stories of tolerance and self-discovery go, "Spork" has a messy appeal, but it's no "Hairspray."
review4: Ghuman might have managed to salvage the film from its weak script if he'd had a firmer grasp on tone, and a better melding of the mish-mash of pop culture references.
review5: For all its poignancy, "Spork" never loses sight of its goal to be zesty, sharp-witted fun.

title: The Space Between
review2: Melissa Leo shines in this story of a flight attendant and a Pakistani/American boy who feel the effects of 9/11.

title: Tower Heist
review1: A crappy Hollywood blockbuster for the Occupy movement.
review2: It is a heist movie that doesn't care about the heist.
review3: The one-liners pop and the cast delivers.
review4: All corners of the oddball comedy genre are squarely covered in a way that somehow seems fresh despite the well tried-and-tested formula.
review5: What we end up with is a film that will have you laughing all the way through while at the same time reminding you that some talent never goes away, it just hibernates in smaller or inferior movies for awhile before that right project reaches them.

title: Martha Marcy May Marlene
review1: In quiet, intimate ways, it is one of the most startling, haunting films you'll see all year.
review2: Durkin intersperses the present-day scenes with increasingly revelatory flashbacks from Martha's two years in the cult.
review3: MMMM emphasizes the social and economic discrepancies between Martha's then and now, and alludes to Lucy's guilt about not being there for her younger sister in the past.
review4: Durkin's swaggeringly confident film utilizes long takes and tension within compositions to conjure an all-consuming sense of unease.
review5: The beauty of Olsen's star-making performance is inarguable.

title: J. Edgar
review1: The Hoover material is ugly and very American, and it might have made an authentic monster story. But the picture offered is muddled, cautious, and at cross purposes.
review2: It's a deeply silly movie. American history as kitsch, played out like a drag show.
review3: With noirish lighting and most of the running time spent inside offices or cramped domestic rooms, Eastwood keeps the film claustrophobic, sometimes unpleasantly intimate.
review4: DiCaprio never measures up to the task of creating a plausible interpretation of what enabled Hoover to be both heroic and maniacal.
review5: A lumbering miscalculation...

title: London Boulevard
review1: A stylish if familiar tale of a man hopelessly entangled in his past.
review2: A movie is more than dialogue and a soundtrack. And direction is a lot more than making sure all your favorite parts of your own script make it to the screen intact.
review3: In trying to take a bite out of crime and another out of fame, [Monahan has] ended up with more than he can chew for his first time in the director's chair.
review4: Monahan's trademark tart dialogue is as strong as ever, and Farrell and Winstone make for a formidable pair of opponents.
review5: There is too much to be absorbed in too little time and not enough tissue connecting abbreviated, sometimes unnecessary subplots.

title: Taxi!
review4: How can you refuse a film that embraces non-violent arbitration and still gives a pass to Cagney taking revenge?
review5: Is James Cagney the greatest movie star in history? Watching 'Taxi!,' it's hard to vote no. As active as a terrier, as combustible as dynamite, he was made for motion pictures; he's so kinetic he threatens to ignite, like Johnny Blaze in 'Ghost Rider.'

title: It All Came True
review1: It has a winsome light touch.

title: Answers to Nothing
review1: Nearly a dozen random themes and characters have been Scotch-taped together into a single mess.
review2: An apt title that sadly recalls lesser ensemble pieces like "Playing by Heart," while wanting to be "Grand Canyon."
review3: Any movie that calls itself Answers to Nothing ought to be 100 percent sure it's about something.
review4: It begins with Dane Cook procuring sperm to impregnate his desperate wife with a little help from his mistress - and goes steadily downhill from there.
review5: There's a lack of real conclusiveness to many of the film's characters and situations.

title: Miss Bala
review1: Naranjo is unflinching in his determination not to serve up mindless entertainment.
review2: Maybe the film doesn't add up to quite as much as its talented director, Gerardo Naranjo, seems to have hoped, but it is tense and propulsive.
review3: Miss Bala is full of virtuoso single-take tracking shots and over-the-shoulder perspectives that effectively convey a sense of menace and momentum.
review4: Naranjo offers a grim subject with neither flash nor sentiment. It is a sober film done with style.
review5: This strange and eerie noir is more a collection of knockout scenes than a fully realized story.

title: Rabies
review1: Takes the standard stupid-kids-in-the-woods formula and inverts it to delicious, hilarious and extremely mean effect.
review2: While I can't say I really enjoyed Rabies (the story is just too tired and the characters too stock, for someone raised on horror movies), I do respect its fine filmmaking.
review3: One of those fascinating horror movies that never gets too weird to lose its footing but also stays completely unpredictable.
review4: a dark (if brightly lit) comedy of errors, full of tensions that... reflect a nation's complex social and political landscape, where twinned senses of entitlement and entrapment have produced a treacherous environment best trodden very carefully.
review5: A stalker kicks off an ever-escalating carnival of carnage. (Cleverer than it sounds.)

title: InSight
review1: From its unexciting transference of psychic powers to its dull police procedure to the way one secondary cop character wears a fedora two sizes too big, this thriller is late-night-cable bad through and through.
review2: A psychological-supernatural thriller that's light on thrills.
review4: Tired story and pacing issues turn this into just another generic supernatural thriller.
review5: It's not terrible... just weak.

title: I Melt with You
review1: It really is good, albeit in ways that are different from other movies.
review2: The movie captures, as well as any other, the feeling of partying into oblivion, minus the next-morning internal pitchfork stabs. Think of a wild friend you wouldn't want to emulate but can't let go of.
review3: A fanfare for the common jerk that taints every '80s-era alt-rock soundtrack tune it touches, "I Melt With You" assuredly marks itself as one of 2011's most ludicrous releases.
review4: By the end, you feel nothing, not even contempt.
review5: If it weren't played so very straight, this jaw-dropping thriller might pass for an accurate satire of Hollywood self-indulgence. Instead, it serves as a prime example.

title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover
review1: There's a lot to like here - not least disarmingly natural performances from the mostly non-professional actors.
review2: I remember 15. It was a mess. Mitchell's movie serenely amplifies the mess.
review3: The Myth of the American Sleepover is an indie movie-lover's dream, one of those rare instances where a lack of budget and experience is trumped by heartfelt vision, natural talent and amateur enthusiasm.
review4: With "The Myth of the American Sleepover," first-time writer-director David Robert Mitchell tells a coming-of-age tale with such freshness and such bemused insight it's as if it has never been told before.
review5: A one-of-a-kind teen movie, which captures that distinctive moment in adolescent life when nostalgia, loss and anxiety begin to populate one's consciousness with ghosts.

title: The Lie
review1: The acting in The Lie -- including a nice bit by Mark Webber as a stoner pal who lectures Leonard on responsibility -- is good enough to almost overlook a so-so ending.
review2: Comprising small, near-perfect scenes played out largely at dinner tables and on couches, "The Lie" wonders if it's possible to rewrite lives and remake choices.
review3: It doesn't try too hard, but what "The Lie" is working at, in its unassuming, amusing way, is a mini-portrait of growing pains in a time of extended adolescence.
review4: The Lie's payoff strikes an unexpected, refreshingly open note that makes this slight little indie more resonant than its scale suggests.
review5: Here's a film in which the actors create plausible people we would probably like. They're loose inside the skins of their characters.

title: London River
review1: The film is a matter of Brenda Blethyn's performance vs. Sotigui Kouyate's presence.
review2: It would be nice to say that Bouchareb, who also wrote and directed "Days of Glory" and "Outside the Law," succeeds. He does not entirely. But he doesn't fail, either.
review3: Blethyn and Kouyaté inhabit and expand the film's earnestly instructive intentions, leaving us with a deeply-felt experience rather than a naively-sketched lesson.
review4: "London River'' features on-target acting by its two leads, but they receive scant support from the wobbly plot.
review5: Demonstrates how great acting can infuse a banal, politically correct drama with dollops of emotional truth.

title: Mercenaries
review1: Obviously made without much money, the whole thing has a certain audacity but lacks real character or skill.
review2: The plot and dialogue is borderline ridiculous and the absence of acting Oscar nominations is not exactly a scandal.
review3: Like watching splattered paint balls dry.
review4: It looks like footage from a team-building weekend where the whole office gets to star in their own action movie.
review5: Sadly misguided from the start, this violent war-zone adventure suffers from both a very low budget and a script that seems to have been written by someone who has never been outside Great Britain.

title: Wyatt Earp's Revenge
review1: "Wyatt Earp's Revenge" is like a throwback to B-Westerns, with their no-name casts, low budgets, and everything else just a few steps closer to Boot Hill than their big-budget kin.

title: The Skin I Live In
review1: "The Skin I Live In" fails because it doesn't have a moral or anything else to say in spite of its self-seriousness.
review2: Almodóvar has a body of work as rigorously personal as any out there, and, even with its flaws, he wears this latest Skin rather well.
review3: Despite the typically invigorating sense of line and framing, The Skin I Live In withholds the director's customary satisfactions and affirmations. The result is a saga of obsession that, in its saturnine undertone, maintains a hard-to-enjoy integrity.
review4: This is a lush, deeply pleasurable film to experience on a sensory level; Almodovar couldn't produce a boring frame if he left the lens cap on.
review5: Pedro Almodovar's The Skin I Live In, a terrific, twisty thriller that is one of the filmmaker's best and one of the year's best films.

title: Gone
review1: A breakdown of international justice that deserves to be shown far and wide.

title: Like Crazy
review1: I hated, hated, hated these people and despise writer-director Drake Doremous for wasting a brutally overlong 89 minutes of my life with them.
review2: ...an uneven endeavor from a promising new filmmaker...
review3: I'll admit that my heart broke a little by film's end, as the camera rested on Yelchin and Jones's faraway looks and Stars' sublime "Dead Hearts" flooded the soundtrack.
review4: A well-made film with two strong leads that never fully appreciates the romance at its core.
review5: Felicity Jones will break your heart at least once

title: The Egg and I
review3: Starring Claudette Colbert and Fred MacMurray, this comedy about an urban couple who tries to live a happy rural life was so popuar at the box-office that it led to a sequel and to a whole series, Ma and Pa Kettle.

title: Footloose
review1: An unnecessary, though enjoyable, remake of Kevin Bacon's 1984 breakout hit.
review2: My Sunday shoes remain intact.
review3: This remake could have audiences tapping their feet... as they wait for it to end.
review4: FEMA can take a day off because Footloose is one remake that won't be called a natural disaster, in fact, it's one hell of a good film.
review5: Director Craig Brewer has Southernized the story...made it lighter on its feet.

title: The Dish & The Spoon
review1: Beautifully photographed, "The Dish & the Spoon" is awash in images of rain-soaked streets and gray wintry skies.
review2: For once, an American indie's muted modesty at least makes emotional sense, suiting a bittersweet romance that, by nature, has neither a name nor a future.
review3: Bagnall successfully exploits the seriocomic disparity between the supercharged relationship offscreen and the desultory one onscreen.
review4: Gerwig handles her character's extreme mood swings with finesse.

title: Loosies
review1: Making romance a big part of the mix dooms a movie already saddled with one of the worst titles in recent memory.
review2: Romantic comedies are often as contrived and irritating as "Loosies," but few feature a lead character so lacking in appeal.
review3: Facinelli's transformation from feckless charmer to committed caretaker seems contrived, leaving the film feeling like a series of stitched-together scenes with little internal drive.
review4: Not a great movie, but satisfying enough to hold attention and win your affection -- a rare blue-plate combo on today's overcrowded menu of movie chaos that sticks to your ribs and stays there.
review5: Loosies has a bevy of colorful character actors -- from Michael Madsen and William Forsythe to Vincent Gallo and Joe Pantoliano -- but little character.

title: House of Pleasures
review1: Nothing in this film comes as a surprise, but Bonello's intent to show the place backstage as well as onstage is fulfilled and pertinent, even though the period setting gives the picture a curio air.
review2: It's about forcing us to think about people we never would otherwise and seeing their struggles and humanity.
review3: What gives the film its haunting pull, as well as its feminist undercurrent, is the filmmaker's palpable compassion for these women.
review4: No one, male or female, has any fun, but the men behave as if they do. They are all half-stupefied by the languor in which they drown.
review5: It emphasizes setting over character and plot; and it casts a mood that's both eerie and entrancing.

title: My Week with Marilyn
review1: I believe the heart of the film, and the cleverest stroke of all, is Eddie Redmayne as Colin Clark, someone few of us will have heard of.
review2: A great big slab of middlebrow fan-fiction.
review3: Michelle Williams stuns in an Oscar-worthy performance in one of the year's best films.
review4: A fun and tender tale of infatuation backed by two outstanding Oscar-nominated performances.
review5: When Michelle Williams is singing about starting a "Heat Wave" by "making my seat wave," friends you will believe it.

title: Young Adult
review1: There has always been something so inward about [Theron;] she can seem detached or deprived. But here it's as if the script and the direction felt bound to heed that loneliness, and let the actress go with her bravery and the depressive sag of her mouth.
review2: Cody and Reitman seem mainly interested in scoring points off their characters and making cheap jokes at the expense of anybody who isn't lucky enough to be Diablo Cody or Jason Reitman.
review3: Kudos to Reitman, Cody, and Theron for crafting such a great bastard-ess, who you'll either feel empathy, like myself, or uncontrollable hatred for.
review4: You sense the teeth-chattering chill almost as deeply as you admire the bravery of a pitch-black performance by Theron that begs nothing but contempt for her scurrilous Mavis Gary.
review5: Jason Reitman and Charlize Theron create a realistic insight into what happens to the popular high school student who can't adjust to the real world in Young Adult.

title: My Joy
review1: Although discomfiting to audiences desiring a steady narrative thread (and less accessible to those unfamiliar with Eastern European history and culture), it sustains interest throughout as a devastating critique of Russian society.
review2: There are hints of Tarkovsky in the poetic exploration of place and memory and the film is a demanding, difficult work. But the sense of a Dantean journey and a vision of utter hell are powerfully conveyed.
review3: For long stretches, it appears to be a road movie headed nowhere. Still, the detours it uncovers are fascinating.
review4: [Has] a bleak, grotesque, near-perfect poetry in its soul.
review5: The world of "My Joy" is grim, though the experience of watching it and piecing together its fragmented story strands is anything but.

title: The Descendants
review1: The Descendants is humane, decent, and close to real quality.
review2: Mr. Payne's undeniable knack for naturalism makes "The Descendants" a wholly persuasive and heartfelt experience.
review3: I enjoyed Clooney's performance enormously without ever buying it for a second.
review4: The Descendants is an exercise in why women are such horrible, despicable shrews. When this film isn't demonising its female characters for daring to be unhappy in their marriage, it's condescending them for showing too much emotion...
review5: A truthful, warm-hearted, deeply moving film about loss, about death, about legacies and, yeah, family.

title: Stuck Between Stations
review1: A pleasant, inconsequential indie with deep Minneapolis roots, "Stuck Between Stations" should please youth-oriented Minnesota audiences. It's unlikely to set the rest of the planet on fire.
review2: There are no easy payoffs in "Stuck Between Stations," but the chemistry of its stars is reward enough.
review3: There's an overapplication of split-screen and woozy soundtrack cues to this end, but Lister Jones and Rosen do an appealing back-and-forth with lively dialogue, not dulled in the interest of realism.
review4: Real people may not be this glib and witty, but Rosen and Lister-Jones sell us on Casper and Becky nonetheless.

title: Bag It
review1: Enlightening docu about saving the planet from plastics.
review2: Humble documentary makes a non-biodegradable impression
review3: Recommended Earth Day viewing. At a brisk, informative 79 minutes, (the film) easily holds one's attention.

title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor)
review1: All in all-if all is meant moderately-the story leaves an agreeable aftertaste, which lingers longer than we expected.
review2: The film sidesteps all complexities and leaves us with a closing shot that should come with a bucket.
review3: The film doesn't blaze adventurous new trails, but it dramatizes the stories of those underappreciated servants with an engaging mix of romance, droll humor and upstairs-downstairs social consciousness.
review4: Beautifully filmed, well acted and a topical reminder that success isn't about how much money you have, but how you live - and boil your eggs.
review5: The unreconstructed nature of the comedy ensures that the jokes and even the shots are awfully familiar.

title: Melancholia
review1: Though far from Mr. von Trier's best, its power is still undeniable.
