review2: This is the greatest movie ever made about depression, full stop.
review3: The journey von Trier has taken to this one immaculate moment has been bold to say the least, but at long last, he has revealed his full ability, and the result is his masterwork.
review4: It's the little moments that annihilate us, every day, every normal day. Days that don't end, days when the end of the world is a comfort that the sick like Justine cannot afford.
review5: A strong central performance from Kirsten Dunst, this is one of the best Lars von Trier films yet made.

title: British Agent
review1: Sluggish political drama.

title: Jess + Moss
review1: Mr. Jeter, who has made his feature-length debut with this film, tries to capture the loose feel of childhood's open-ended summers. But the vocabulary of his imagery feels worn out, and the ambience feels handed down.
review2: Achingly sad and surpassingly lovely.
review4: Jess + Moss is a simply beautiful film with amazing sound work and nearly flawless direction.
review5: A strange and intoxicating indie constructed as a series of vignettes that capture two children grappling with the overlap of trauma and nostalgia.

title: From Time to Time
review2: Heartfelt family drama with ghosts and scary fire scene.
review3: a reminder of how enchanting a fantasy can still be if not taking over by digital imagery, if it has a few interesting characters and a few nice touches of plotting
review4: Has there been a movie with such an artificial and unengaging style since... well, the fifties?
review5: Movies are supposed to whisk you away, to make you get lost in their stories. I never got lost in From Time to Time because I was continually aware of the pieces being assembled before me.

title: Telstar (Telstar: The Joe Meek Story)
review1: Even if 'Telstar' can't quite get the measure of its fascinating material, its pluck and ambition prove infectious enough to outweigh its flaws.
review2: An overlong but fascinating look at the life of a forgotten innovator of early rock'n roll
review3: Nick Moran definitely emphasizes certain characteristics of the idiosyncratic producer over others for affect, but this is still as fascinating portraits in parts.
review4: Telstar is an embarrassing farrago, an amateurish, incoherent pantomime of a piece, stuffed with interchangeable characters, a sketchy, largely unsympathetic leading role, and - betraying its stage play origins - unspeakably stilted dialogue.
review5: This is Meek's show, and as a wild and hostile central character (the bellowed phrase "F*** off" is never far from his lips) he is likely to fascinate and alienate in equal measure.

title: Battle Royale 3D
review1: Stylistically it's a beauty, with khaki-uniformed waifs fighting for their lives to a crashing classical score.
review2: Awful deaths (and hysterical reactions to them) punctuate declarations of love and friendship, revelations of treachery and heavily armed expressions of angst.
review3: Forgive the film its small flaws of histrionic performances and cheap execution for the giddy rush of its banal, Verhoevenesque atmosphere...
review4: It may suit a certain worldview, but Battle Royale's cynicism is still a form fantasy-a balm as well as a bomb.
review5: 3D conversion of a classic teen massacre thriller raises the gore level.

title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
review1: Steve Zaillian's script trims some the novel's fat, keeping the film a lean, mean and frightening beast.
review2: Whilst Fincher doesn't exactly blow the original out of the water, he does add enough to make the project feel less like an unnecessary retread than it otherwise may have.
review3: Fincher takes repeated stabs at creating depth but seldom draws blood in attempting to flesh out characters that just aren't that interesting.
review4: David Fincher's Hollywood take on the Stieg Larsson bestseller is a sleek yet somehow soulless adaptation.
review5: A compelling ride for die-hard fans of the book series, dramatic thriller enthusiasts, as well as anyone who enjoys Fincher's darker works.

title: Carnage
review1: "Carnage" is just another in a long line of improbable movie depictions of New York as seen in "Sex and the City" and other such drivel.
review2: The funniest movie I saw last year. A short, tart, altogether delectable slice of misanthropy.
review3: The acting marathon is adroitly blocked and paced by Polanski and impeccably shot by Pawel Edelman.
review4: While the film, at a staggering and quick 80 minute runtime, plays exceedingly well off the energy of the performers, the downfall ultimately lies in a "loss of steam" vigor that is evident by picture's end.
review5: Few recent movies have been this perceptive about such immediate human conflicts, much less this funny.

title: Roadie
review1: A lot of what takes place in "Roadie" feels overly familiar, and the film could have been a wallow in pathos except for the performances, especially that of Eldard.
review2: The hugely sympathetic Eldard ("Super 8") gives this slim movie a real, beating heart.
review3: While the excellent cast does its level, honest best with the material, the material itself feels secondhand throughout.
review4: "Roadie" is short on narrative momentum, but it's a perfectly attuned character study of this rock relic and his middle-aged sorrows.
review5: Roadie has the stench of freshman-year mandatory creative writing all over it, from its cribs of Eugene O'Neill and Arthur Miller to an ending that's embarrassingly, clangingly metaphorical.

title: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy
review1: The movie is riveting in the exact sense of the word: We feel nailed to the screen in the impossible task of working out what is going on-let alone why it matters.
review2: I think I eventually put it all together in the end, but the picture makes this task neither easy nor particularly rewarding.
review3: Even an ensemble cast of a very high pedigree can't overcome a plot that's been compacted into near-incomprehensibility.
review4: "Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy," with its meticulous Cold War details and labyrinthine plot, is like a smoky 25-year-old single malt scotch whiskey. It hits you hard, but goes down smooth.
review5: A masterful adaptation of John Le Carre's 1970s spy thriller about the secret British hunt for a high-ranking KGB mole.

title: Gainsbourg: A Heroic Life
review1: It's a comic-strip version of one man's life and times, but it's tres cool.
review2: While the movie's on a roll, it's zesty, engaging and frisky.
review3: In short, Gainsbourg: A Heroic Life is a charmer.
review4: French pop star Serge Gainsbourg was as much iconoclast as icon, so it's fitting that this fanciful biopic is both affectionate and irreverent.
review5: Alas, "Gainsbourg: A Heroic Life" loses steam and grows more perfunctory as it wears on.

title: Dangerous
review3: Dreadful soap opera film.
review4: Early Bette Davis is fun to catch.
review5: Bette Davis won her first Oscar for playing an alcoholic actress bent on self-destruction.

title: The Steel Trap
review2: A gripping suspense film.

title: Thirteen Women
review1: A rarely seen, undervalued and racially provocative semi-horror film that anticipates the 'body count' movies of future decades, this is a doozy and a knockout, with Myrna Loy at her sexiest and most exotic.
review2: It's hysterical and bigoted and just plain ruthless, almost unbelievable, and perversely fun for all that.

title: The Kate Logan Affair
review1: ...a watchable yet uneven little thriller.

title: Die
review1: For something spawned in a torture chamber, it seems to think pretty highly of itself.

title: The Seminarian
review1: When Lim masters the very fine art of seamless storyline flow and purposely shows more of his point of view than he tells, a film of very high order could be the result.

title: The Yellow Sea
review1: ...does boast its fair share of gripping moments.
review2: A breakneck mix of bone-crunching freneticism and bloody close-quarters knife-fighting with a strand of romantic melancholy.
review3: A rush of a movie from South Korea that slips and slides from horror to humor on rivers of blood and offers the haunting image of a man, primitive incarnate, beating other men with an enormous, gnawed-over meat bone.
review4: The Yellow Sea is far less interested in character than in choreographing pursuit scenes spiced with Asia Extreme levels of violence.
review5: Writer-director Na Hong-Jin achieves a vibe of urban desolation right off the bat, and deepens the mayhem with acutely observed and charged details about illegal-immigrant life.

title: Some Days Are Better Than Others
review1: Like the characters, the three stories show only the most tentative signs of going anywhere.
review2: Some Days unspools in a depressive deadpan that might be more effective were the characters' plights not so clearly of their own making.
review3: Although this always interesting film doesn't quite come together at the end - it couldn't decide exactly what it wanted to say - McCormick has done a lot of things right.
review4: If you want to draw the line between a quiet, touching little movie and a wooden, deadly boring dud, you might want to see Portland director Matt McCormick's "Some Days Are Better Than Others," but I wouldn't recommend it.
review5: Lonelyhearts going nowhere fill every corner of Matt McCormick's Some Days Are Better Than Others, a film that verges on a parody of American indie cliches.

title: Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close
review1: In the end, the movie is about healing and coming to understand that some things can't be explained.
review2: Ghastly.
review3: Horn dives into one of the most complex character's I've seen created for a child and shakes loose.
review4: Dull and lifeless.
review5: Eric Roth's nimble screenplay and composer Alexandre Desplat's delicate score also help solidify "Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close" as one of the best movies movies of 2011

title: Broken Tower
review1: You should be prepared for some high-minded pretension, lots of self-consciously arty shots, and long stretches of apparently profound nothingness.
review2: The technique - and this movie is about nothing if not technique, both Crane's and the filmmaker's - isn't particularly successful.
review3: Despite earnest attempts, Mr. Franco can't bring the fervency of Crane's poetry to life in the extensive recitations.
review4: It's a pensive and heartfelt movie, assuming that you let yourself get caught up in its moody-minimalist, more-visual-than-verbal style.
review5: The Broken Tower feels unique as a young man's tribute to an adventuresome, doomed soul.

title: Camel Spiders
review1: Unfortunately not one of Corman's more notable movies.
review2: You know precisely what you're getting from Camel Spiders. Which means you'll probably watch it some time soon.

title: In the Land of Blood and Honey
review1: Overall, Jolie has nothing to be embarrassed about and much of which to be proud with this movie. Even in moments where the film doesn't quite work, she shows ample evidence of ambition and a discerning director's eye.
review2: The film's key twist seems a bit underdeveloped, but there's no avoiding the horror the film captures. Even in modern times, what monsters men can be.
review3: It's a tough, clear-eyed look at a ghastly ethnic war, with an admirably wide perspective that affords compassion for both sides.
review4: With its broad strokes, this invitation to an important discussion is hard to ignore, but the blood and honey on the table is an unpalatable mix.
review5: Although Jolie's good intentions are easy to admire, those characters are hard to believe, and the bloody narrative has an oddly bloodless effect.

title: Bedevilled
review2: The film's only suspense was whether or not the would-be priest would yield to the temptations of the flesh.

title: One Fall
review1: Starts out with an intriguing premise but grows muddier as it grows more mystical.
review2: Ends up reducing its hero's struggle (and bad attitude) to a single past trauma and its resultant daddy issues.
review3: The cast is engaging, and there are a few light-chuckle moments, but the script needed another rewrite, and the film itself needed to be guided by a thornier sensibility than Fuller's.
review4: Despite its grander ambitions, the film ultimately feels minor and superficial.

title: On the Bowery
review1: "On the Bowery" offers some of the most indelible faces in an American docudrama, faces ravaged by alcohol and poverty, creased by defeat and self-deception, surrounded by a New York City that does not care. Yet no one on screen asks for pity.
review2: On the Bowery runs only 65 minutes, but by the end you can feel skid row in your bones.
review3: Shot on 16mm in black-and-white with a Bolex camera, the results remain stunningly authentic.
review4: This landmark documentary disturbs and compels as much today in a new 35mm restoration as it did when it opened in 1956 to both criticism and acclaim.
review5: As a record of a time and a place in the history of New York, it's essential. As a depiction of men at the bottom of their lives, it has the same sorrowful, accusatory force as a great Depression-era photograph by Dorothea Lange or Walker Evans.

title: We Bought a Zoo
review1: Since "We Bought a Zoo" doesn't have much on offer, it could and should have at least been a more pointed reminder for us to rediscover nature and support local zoos.
review2: Crowe, who aims high to plant a big smile on your face, does so here more than competently.
review3: Packed with too many storylines, this drama feels like a zoo indeed.
review4: ...this is packed with all the warmth, heart and humanity that one has come to expect from a Cameron Crowe film.
review5: A muddled focus keeps We Bought a Zoo from being a guaranteed hit with kids or a captivating adult drama but there are enough compelling moments to make it worthwhile.

title: Enter Nowhere
review1: Has a nice Twilight Zone-style vibe to it, yet the story tips its hand too soon, thanks to some clues that might as well have been lit by neon signs.

title: Sket
review1: A film of real substance that shows a timely interest in how and why gangs materialise.
review2: A film that, for all its grit and attitude, lacks sufficient cred.
review3: It's a confused and confusing movie with odd good moments, but has little by way of revealing insight other than the suggestion that the girl gangsters need loving parents and the protection of a nurturing family.
review4: Thanks to the posturing, intrusive soundtrack and implausible, clichéd script, it's hard to take any of it too seriously.
review5: Despite some confusing narrative turns, writer-director Nirpal Bhogal's thriller is an impactful and authentic look at gang culture on London's meaner streets.

title: Angels Crest
review1: A garbled melodrama striving to be tragic drama.
review2: Catherine Trieschmann's script, based on the novel by Leslie Schwartz, barely scratches the potentially loaded surfaces it serves up.
review3: While there is a great deal of weeping and wailing going on in the town of Angels Crest, little of it is connected to a comprehensible or cohesive plot.
review4: Dellal gets respectable performances all around ... but they can't elevate "Angels Crest" ... beyond its one obvious and depressing note ...
review5: Despite several solid performances, the characters are too hazily sketched and too loosely linked to form a meaningful chain.

title: Redemption Road
review1: A lightly enjoyable road pic about a circuitous road to redemption, Black, White and Blues offers simple, down-home pleasures while spinning an undeniably familiar but emotionally satisfying tale.
review2: Battling-buddy road movie carries viewers on an entertaining ride into blues country.
review3: a sterilized and predictable version of life that plays out like a very special movie of the week -- albeit one with a nice soundtrack.
review4: Hope and healing wait at the end of a big-hearted musical road trip.
review5: 'Brother knew how to tell a story,' Michael Clarke Duncan says, admiringly, of Shakespeare. The same can't exactly be said of this earnest calling-card indie.

title: War Horse
review1: Etched in the simple, bold strokes of a passed-down fable. Resistance is futile.
review2: Steven Spielberg's "War Horse" is an imperfect film, but certainly is a beautiful one.
review3: They will keep trying and trying until only the blackest of hearts are left un-moved. I guess I should hand in my organ donation card because I clearly don't have a heart judging from the dismissive reaction I had to this patently artificial film.
review4: For sublime equine you'd be hard pressed to find a better mount than 'War Horse.'
review5: War Horse offers a number of memorable moments both tragic and profound.

title: Tyrannosaur
review1: The movie is cruelly frank about the ways damage cascades down to the powerless, but while it's not for the fainthearted (or for animal lovers), rewards are there.
review2: The principals are superb, with Mullan and Colman doing a masterful job of inhabiting their separate but equal prisons.
review3: You won't find two finer performances in recent times than those by Mullan and Colman, who in a perfect world would each have received Oscar nominations this week.
review4: If the script ultimately seems a bit extreme (are there no immediate consequences for Joseph's tantrums or the criminal outbursts of Hannah's abusive husband?), it's often surprisingly successful in pushing the limits of British kitchen-sink drama.
review5: Paddy Considine's first feature as writer-director comes off like a playwriting exercise, with familiar characters taking every opportunity to wage messy, cathartic arguments or exhume traumatic memories.

title: Fast Forward
review3: Bland and amateurish.

title: NoBody's Perfect
review1: A darkly funny and fascinating examination of body image, sexuality, and self-esteem.
review2: An exemplar of fresh-air filmmaking that addresses the devastating legacy of the drug thalidomide with acidic wit and grumpy honesty.
review3: The film tastefully handles the sensitive subject, but it lacks the bite that a Michael Moore would have provided.
review4: [Features] a slack, scattershot approach that ill serves the director's intermittently audacious film.
review5: Drop the impotent Michael Moore-esque exposé on the company who manufactured the drug, and this moving doc would, in fact, be perfect.

title: Caught Inside
review1: On one level, it's pure visceral filmmaker, a necessary bloodletting, and yet, it feels a little phoney and not quite right. By movie's end, the characters no longer feel real -- they're just figures, playing a movie game.
review2: So when Caught Inside finally descends into an expected them-versus-him free-for-all in the final act, it is Oxenbould's wickedly wonky way with an improvised line that keeps the whole thing fresh.
review3: It's a solid effort all round, but this really belongs to Ben Oxenbould whose brilliantly unhinged performance makes this a truly thrilling experience.
review4: It's the 'powderkeg thriller' template
review5: Caught in the web of its own making and delivers what is strictly formulaic cinema

title: Littlerock
review1: Ott has explored his theme - how each person's destiny is propelled by the past but left dangling, isolated in a seemingly formless present - with great subtlety.
review2: [Ott's] distilled the town until it floats somewhere between a hangover and a dream.
review3: This evocative, deceptively rich slice of life has its own voice, and it never fails to be enjoyable for several reasons.
review4: "Littlerock" tells a confident story that knows precisely where it's going.
review5: An ethereal and ephemeral musing on the art and artifice of communication.

title: Goodnight For Justice: The Measure Of A Man
The Iron Lady
review1: So, as thrilling as it is to watch Streep imitate Thatcher, The Iron Lady feels like a missed opportunity, not to blame and cast aspersions, but to weigh and assess.
review2: It's a pity Streep can't be picked up as Thatcher like a chess piece and placed down in a different, better film.
review3: A solid tribute to the conservative icon despite its meandering focus on her failing health.
review4: ...ignores the political and historical context of almost EVERYTHING that happens so that they can make the fabulously reductive statement that LIFE WAS TOUGH FOR GIRLS, BUT SHE WAS A TOUGH GIRL.
review5: The narrative is not well structured, and Streep's performance suffers as a result.... The scenes with Broadbent are the best. They just aren't worth sitting through a history lesson that isn't taught well.

title: Sleeping Beauty
review1: [An] arty exploitation pic passed off as a feminist parable...
review2: A fascinating, erotically charged mystery.
review3: Leigh, impressively for a first-time filmmaker, has a distinct and confident approach.
review4: Eros snores.
review5: It's a story told in quiet rooms and hushed voices - except for one devastating scream near the end - and it's ultimately a horror story, though one completely free of blood and gore.

title: A Bird of the Air
review1: Though you could fit its story on the head of a pin, "A Bird of the Air" is a gently involving character dramedy with a pair of appealing leads who help give this offbeat movie flight.
review2: At its most entertaining when the parrot does the talking.
review3: An offbeat romance fueled by pets and pithy aphorisms.
review4: Its lethargic plotting and quirky affectation are -- wait for it -- strictly for the birds.
review5: Not a bad premise, but first-time director Margaret Whitton fails to temper the sappiness with real human crustiness.

title: Vincent will Meer (Vincent Wants to Sea)
review1: "Vincent Wants to Sea" never deviates from the predictable bonding-through-misadventure script, and it has little to teach us about the nature and treatment of the traveler's respective maladies.
review2: This is a bright, broad, silly, harmless movie whose sweetness is a means to an end: "Escape From Sesame Street.''
review3: Predictability gives way to touching drama.
review4: What's missing is any of the real-life messiness that might have lifted this material from its creatively tic-ridden confines.
review5: Like a lot of recent foreign and independent films, "Vincent Wants to Sea" tends to thrash around while its creators try to locate a finale that's neither obvious nor unrealistic.

title: The Conquest
review1: The Sarkozy story glistens, snakelike.
review2: The dialogue is punchy, but the film lacks visual personality, and the insights into Sarkozy and France as a whole don't cut very deep.
review3: "The Conquest" is like a French restaurant that serves small portions of tart appetizers and calls them freedom fries, yet begrudgingly we must salute the gall.
review4: Too often ... the jaunty, overeager background music seems to be underscoring jokes the action doesn't provide.
review5: Sarkozy seems to mean exactly what he says, even when he's lying for his cause, and Podalydès has the skill to demonstrate that.

title: King of Devil's Island
review1: Rather one-note in its bleakness, and doesn't have a vast amount to say beyond 'reform school sucks'.
review2: Possibly no one else does "grim" with as much unsparing enthusiasm as the Scandinavians.
review3: Skarsgard is riveting throughout as a man whose high morality is steeped in hypocrisy and whose mask of civility easily slips, when challenged, to reveal the monster beneath.
review4: It's a very measured account of how men will accept their fates to a degree, slowly coil up and then spring with anger.
review5: A slow-burning but satisfying drama that persuasively blends elements of Scum and Papillon.

title: Rage in Heaven
review1: Disappointing melodrama.
review2: This early Ingrid Bergman movie, before she became a major star, is a well acted psychological melodrama about love, jealousy, obession and possession.

title: Joan of Paris
review2: One of the few films starring the lovey French actress Michele Moragn made during WWII, while in exile in Hollywood.

title: Getting of Wisdom
review1: Rightly regarded as one of the finest films ever made about Australian adolescents, the director Bruce Beresford's 1978 drama The Getting of Wisdom exists in a space unaffected by time
review2: The Getting of Wisdom demonstrates the painful aspects of trying to win the approval of one's peers during adolescence.

title: Shame
review1: The film's numb attitude assumes that Brandon's problem is beyond reach or rescue. So why are we watching, except for high-tone misery and something close to pornography?
review2: By the time Brandon's quite literally cruising for a bruising, the film has no credibility left whatsoever.
review3: The ferocity of the performances and McQueen's formal relentlessness left me pulverized.
review4: A solid character study that is difficult to enjoy but hard not to appreciate.
review5: The New York City of "Shame" is a place so cold, so distanced, so removed from flesh-and-blood humanity, that it's the only place a man like Brandon can truly be alone.

title: The Divide
review1: Its nihilism feels cynical rather than authentically bleak, and the increasingly histrionic scenes start to resemble an indulgent actors' workshop that has spun out of control.
review2: The film's only point appears to be lurid delight in topping one atrocity with another.
review3: Hits its stride in Act II, and once that moment has passed, you're stuck with one irritating slog toward a rather disappointing climax.
review4: It isn't long before the plot and characters have nowhere left to go but down to the depths of human depravity. And by the end it's impossible to see the point.
review5: "The Divide" is an ugly film, both visually and thematically. But it only really rubs you the wrong way if you take it seriously, which we can't imagine anyone would.

title: Man On The Train
review2: We remain puzzled as to why they bothered.
review3: Worth seeing for the hammy performance by Donald Sutherland.
review4: It's a familiar template, but it's a joy to see Sutherland get a rare chance to spread his wings.

title: The Last Rites of Joe May
review1: Joe Maggio is a sure-handed director with a good eye.
review2: Farina is terrific, getting the pathos of the character while avoiding the self-pity, and leavening the tragedy with some occasional sputtering humor.
review3: Veteran character actor Dennis Farina gives one of the best performances of the year in a rare lead part as an aging, down-on-his luck small-time hood in "The Last Rites of Joe May.''
review4: With a few vital strokes - a long, chilly walk and a tired trudge up some stairs - Mr. Farina and Mr. Maggio bring you close...
review5: Mr. Farina has never been more in control of his "instrument," as actors like to say, or more convincing.

title: Suspicion
review1: A good, if needlessly convoluted, film.

title: The Double Hour
review1: It keeps you off-balance, constantly assessing and reassessing.
review2: Capotondi's nerve-shredding puzzler will delight fans of Hitchcock and Polanski.
review3: "The Double Hour" is a tremendously entertaining take on film noir, with all the usual elements of the genre in play - crime, death, possibly murder and doomed romance. I think.
review4: While the twists and turns in "The Double Hour" indeed achieve the level of Messrs. Shyamalan and Amenábar in top form, they nevertheless reek of gimmickry.
review5: Too many of the film's curiosities are explained away with a cliched device, but Capotondi has created an unsettling mood which creeps beneath the skin.

title: Doorway to Hell
review2: A historical relic flawed by miscasting but almost redeemed by an unjustly misunderstood ending.
review3: An early talkie from Warner Brothers.

title: Reuniting The Rubins
review1: "Reuniting the Rubins" may walk like a comedy and quack like a comedy, but despite the absurd extremes to which it takes the squabbling-family formula, it inspires nary a chuckle.
review2: Theoretical laughter, tears and maudlin contrivance ensue.
review3: A frantic, badly constructed, slightly offensive muddle that doesn't so much end as run out of things on a checklist.
review4: The script includes little back story and lots of button-pushing shorthand, none of which feels genuine...
review5: What happens when you put a rabbi, a Buddhist monk, a high-strung capitalist, and a lesbian humanitarian together in the same room? Not comedy, it turns out.

title: Albatross
review1: Charmingly low-key, the British coming-of-age drama "Albatross" offsets slack plotting with creative casting and sensitive performances.
review2: The lack of subtlety makes the story's familiar beats only more obvious.
review3: The performances are compelling (although Jones is underused) but the thin narrative is less instructive of the strange way female friendships operate than of the way stories get recycled.
review4: Albatross shifts from indie fairy tale to farce, only to accept its fate as a coming-of-age melodrama.
review5: Innocence is lost -- as well as 90 minutes of your precious, precious time.

title: Daylight
review1: Replete with superior acting and visual splendor, the film is a fine instance of the overly familiar made fresh.
review2: An unusually delicate psychological thriller that favors suggestion over exposition.
review3: Barker leaves the histrionics to other thrill-makers, opting for the excruciating slow boil.
review4: Thanks largely to the exceptional actors, particularly Martin and Meierhans, Barker sporadically infuses fresh life into stale cliches, and even makes a few of them truly compelling all over again.
review5: Punctuating views of the bucolic countryside and sky attest to nature or God's indifference to human suffering, but such formalist touches don't overwhelm the responsive ensemble work in this resourceful, taboo-prodding sickie.

title: Cinema Verite
review1: ... an engaging and accomplished production and its coda offers yet another perspective on the show, the controversy, and the complexity of the characters ...
review2: Best to focus on the real standouts here: the excellence of the casting and performances.

title: Goethe! (Young Goethe in Love)
review1: Stylistically, the most engaging aspect of the picture is Stölzl's direction.
review2: An old-fashioned romance that's easy to like even if you have no interest in German literature, illegal duels or the more romantic aspects of committing suicide.
review3: Pain plus time, this film reminds us, can result in poetry.
review4: What was Sturm and Drang then veers close to camp and kitsch now.
review5: The story of a talented but not yet mature young man who stumbles upon the topic that would lead to his fame: love, and the loss of it.

title: Pariah
review1: The gay coming-of-age story's been done, but "Pariah" has something fresh to say, largely about the knotty complexities of love, and how they might keep someone in the closet: How badly do you need to be free, to hurt the people you love?
review2: Rees brings a heartfelt connection to the material, based on her own coming-out story, but the film's ingredients aren't the freshest.
review3: You don't have to be black or lesbian or even know someone who's gay to appreciate "Pariah"; you just have to have gone through or be going through the process of growing up.
review4: "Pariah" is a small film about a big subject: the struggle to be who you are, not who others would like you to be.
review5: Such a shame the rest of the picture hews so closely to the stereotypical indie playbook.

title: Crime After Crime
review1: Harrowing, moving and inspiring.
review2: Deeply flawed.
review3: Yoav Potash's moving, vivid documentary "Crime After Crime" will make you both angry and tearful, sometimes at the same time.
review4: It reminds us, once again, that little can be quite so riveting as a well-told story from a compelling talking head.
review5: Though rife with talking-head interviews and straightforwardly shot, the movie is quietly riveting and cumulatively galling.

title: The Fields
review1: Flat and lifeless, not even the odd object promised by its unlikely cast, who play it straight and with little energy.
review2: This low-budget thriller looks more expensive than it is with its imaginative use of set, like the spooky amusement park and, outstandingly, the titular cornfields.
review3: ...no higher compliment could be paid "The Fields" than its constant recollection of the Spanish masterpiece "Spirit of the Beehive"...

title: The Wicker Tree
review1: Rather likable.
review2: "The Wicker Tree" does manage to leave you with a haunted, agreeable unease.
review3: A hee-haw slam on ugly Americanism, a vast reduction of the original's notion of unraveling civilization.
review4: A gumbo of foolishness.
review5: This horror dud features some of the worst acting since you saw that community theater production of "Lil Abner." I saw you there, don't deny it.

title: Badge 373
review1: Flat-footed.

title: The Time That Remains
review1: Suleiman takes the approach of gentle observer, neither condoning nor confronting -- not violently, at least. Start with humor and perhaps empathy will follow.
review2: Living in a part of the world where politics, and the pursuit of politics by warring means, are the rule, director Elia Suleiman is the exception.
review3: Despite its abundance of deadpan and absurdist humor, "The Time That Remains," a look at the Arab-Israeli conflict from a Palestinian perspective, was clearly made with a sorrowful heart.
review4: Suleiman's obvious gift for cinema makes you wish that in connecting so personally with his past, he'd occasionally reach out to the audience, too.
review5: To keep a steady gaze, the film suggests, is not just a virtue but a form of orderly protest, when your world is breaking apart.

title: Grand Central Murder
review3: If you like raincoats, shadows, fedoras askew, and cliched staccato dialogue, you'll have a 'swell motive' to watch Grand Central Murder. All that, and Tom Conway, too!
review4: The case is as simple as a Chinese puzzle.

title: Kinyarwanda
review1: It adds texture to the central facts: This happened, and this matters.
review2: While hardly an all-inclusive look at this complex conflict, paints a heartfelt, fairly restrained picture of a nation under siege.
review3: The end result is a film that's un- deniably moving in its depiction of life under siege, in which horrific violence coexists with everyday emotions.
review4: Kinyarwanda offers glimpses into the lives of Rwandans, young and old, religious and radicalized, in the wake of nightmarish carnage.
review5: Each vignette adds to the mosaic. Characters from one turn up in another. Gradually a powerful outcome is arrived at.

title: Haywire
review1: Steven Soderbergh continues his occasional practice of using actors as found objects in his perfectly enjoyable formula action-thriller Haywire.
review2: Mixed martial-arts star Carano puts major muscle, if minor acting ability, into this enjoyable action flick.
review3: It may seem like this is merely an exercise in style and to be honest, it is. Soderbergh's clearly fascinated by the physicality of Carano as a fighter and Haywire's sole reason for existence is to highlight those skills.
review4: Soderbergh rocks this genre and Carano gives any male action star a run for his money.
review5: I bet Soderbergh secretly considers this one of his favorite films.

title: W.E.
review1: It's hard to hate a movie that escorts us to such lovely locales, but instead of marking the territory as her own, Madonna has directed a potentially provocative story like a virgin.
review2: With "W.E." Madonna gorges on glamour, architectural porn and haute couture but starves the mind.
review3: The film is stylishly shot. And, in weaving the stories of Wally and Wallis, Madonna trusts viewers to move from mood to mood, era to era without overexplanation, the way music-video editing long ago trained us to.
review4: A movie more concerned with how things look than how they feel.
review5: A marvelous 10-car pileup of ostentatious art direction and dated fashion shows in search of reason for being.

title: The Case Of The Black Parrot
Asylum Blackout
review2: Precisely what the title implies, but it does get pretty rough.
review3: A skillfully cobbled together little calling card of a film. If in the end it's a bit short on convincing payoff, its atmospheric spell should generally satisfy genre fans, and also augur good things for most involved.
review4: ...a seriously oppressive piece of work.

title: The Kreutzer Sonata
review1: Rose films on the fly using hand-held digital video cameras - which give the scenes of marital discord a convincing immediacy.
review2: A gripping, Hitchcockian marital thriller with the added value of a score by Ludvig van Beethoven himself
review3: The acting and the scene direction have a delicate, organic feel that is stomped all over by the narration and noise.
review4: It's actually pretty watchable thanks to a demented turn from Huston, a terrifyingly tense final act and, shall we say, a 'committed' performance from Liz.
review5: Rohm brings subtlety to her role but Edgar's paranoia dominates, giving the hammy Huston too much room to over-cook this thin tragedy.

title: The Genesis Code
director: C. Thomas Howell Patrick Read Johnson
review1: Earnest, talky effort to reconcile religion with science.

title: The Front Line
review1: We can be grateful that a Jang Hun comes along now and then to inscribe a human record.
review2: A potent anti-war movie with breathtaking battle sequences.
review3: A war movie not quite worth engaging.
review4: A movie that reserves its final sickening wallop for a grueling half-hour that leaves you as emotionally battered as the soldiers are forced to return to hell for one last senseless round.
review5: While its tone and humanity offset the futility of each side's need for one crucial hill, much of this intense, honorable film is too drawn-out.

title: Beautiful Wave
review1: Pensive coming-of-age surfer tale has a few iffy scenes.

title: This Is What Love In Action Looks Like
review2: Moves along briskly and subsequently doesn't allow for much nuance, but its potency can't be denied.
review3: Morgan Jon Fox's six-years-in-the-making documentary was inspired by 'a modern-day message in a bottle': a teen MySpace user's plea to be freed from a controversial 'conversion therapy' program designed to transform homosexuals into 'ex-gay' Christians.

title: The Vow
review1: The film isn't as bad as what it looks like--the Chinatown knockoff equivalent of a Nicholas Sparks movie--but that doesn't mean that those outside the target audience won't find it a painful experience.
review2: Like a less successful version of The Notebook, this works as an undemanding date movie; just don't expect much more from it.
review3: Ultimately the vision of love and marriage that is being presented here is a fairly routine, secular one, that it is love that binds us to a vow and not the other way around.
review4: "The Vow" might have been a decent film had the filmmakers taken the time to allow the characters to develop, or perhaps even if a better actor was cast in the lead.
review5: Thankfully The Vow spares us from all of that shakey-camera'd nonsense, but that's about all it spares us from.

title: Norman Mailer: The American
review1: A well-produced tribute to a complex and often exasperating personality.
review2: Staccato and compelling, this fast-paced biography recounts some of his views and opinions--writings that alienated people and won supporters.
review3: A documentary is only as fascinating as its subject, and, love him or hate him (most did the latter), Norman Mailer was one fascinating American.

title: Desperate Search
review1: Exciting, taut action/adventure programmer about the rescue by a father of his two children, who are the sole survivors of an air crash.

title: Windfall
review1: The poignant, frightening and visually striking documentary "Windfall" places debate within a very human perspective.
review2: A full-throated attack on wind energy, this feature by Laura Israel is one of the most surprising (and depressing) eco docs I've seen in years.
review3: [An] urgent, informative and artfully assembled documentary.
review4: Ms. Israel's movie proves, once again, that the best nonfiction cinema possesses the same attributes as good fiction: Strong characters, conflict, story arc, visual style.
review5: A veteran film editor making her first feature, Israel emphasizes the area's low-key beauty.

title: My Piece of the Pie
review1: True, the movie sidesteps a couple of cliches it seems headed directly toward, but I might have preferred them to the preposterous melodrama it substitutes.
review2: Paints an alluring picture of a pan-European cosmopolitan culture whose characters hopscotch from one country to another with hardly a second thought in a lighthearted floating party.
review3: A stirring if occasionally over-obvious clash of capital and labor.
review4: A Euro gloss on Pretty Woman suddenly turns into Occupy Gaul.
review5: A feeble stab at topicality from that master of overripe Gallic melodrama, Cédric Klapisch.

title: Rampart
review1: Where's it all go? Nowhere, really, just down a dirty, disappointing hole. Harrelson deserved better.
review2: A terrible movie that only works on the rare occasions when Harrelson's searing performance is allowed to shine.
review3: A powerful portrait of a seriously damaged, both internally and externally, man.
review4: [A] cop drama in the vein of Bad Lieutenant, except in this case the bad cop that is front and centre truly thinks he's doing good.
review5: Rampart doesn't end up having as much emotional punch to it as The Messenger did, mainly because it feels as though the idea was not thought out to completion.

title: The Grey
review1: The Grey remains a genuinely gripping survival story and a refreshing change from stale urban action flicks.
review2: This movie is awesome.
review3: "The Grey" is a film that reminds us how fortunate we are to be sitting in a theater or at home on the couch and not suffering frostbite, hypoxia and being in the dastardly predicament of having giant wolf fangs ripping our innards inside out.
review4: In the case of The Grey, less would have decidedly been more.
review5: It's 'Man vs Wild Wolf' in this suspenseful Alaskan survival film.

title: Afghan Luke
review1: Few people will gain a greater understanding of Canada's war from this movie. There are a handful of worthy moments, but it's too bogged down in cliché.
review2: [This] attempt to mine the material for black comedy is full of war-is-hell clichés, flat jokes and ragged storytelling.

title: Michael
review1: Another full unfaltering performance by a child. This time it's in a horror film.
review2: A strange and agonizingly engrossing drama despite its repellent subject.
review3: There are no easy conclusions here - no explanations. Events unfold with a random, even black comic abandon.
review4: What interests Schleinzer is putting us inside Michael's head, even though we're repelled by his activities, and his no-frills approach works.
review5: Objective, analytic, clinical, dispassionate-these are not words often used to describe something so engrossing and gripping.

title: Albert Nobbs
review1: As the pinched, ever-wary, heartbreaking Nobbs, Close gives a tricky, high wire, award-worthy performance yet she commendably resists any temptation to be showy, campy or spectacular in the least.
review2: An unadventurous film that has only the smallest of fires in its belly.
review3: There's no contrived moralizing bridge to modern relevance, no overt nod to contemporary gender politics and no real reason why Close shouldn't get some respect this awards season.
review4: Close, in one of her greatest performances, is quiet, still, almost invisible to those around her. It's not a stunt or an impersonation, it's a perfect realization of what someone in her position might endure just to eat.
review5: Close's performance is no less sensational than Heath Ledger's as the close mouthed Ennis in Brokeback Mountain.

title: Chronicle
review1: As pulp sci-fi this Fox release is pretty good, but it's also commendable for its sensitive depiction of adolescent behavior.
review2: Somewhere amidst a jumble of fast images and unscripted shouts, I couldn't help but feel that this all would have been more effective in a movie that played the material with a more straightforward approach.
review3: Superpowers mightn't be for everybody - especially angry, disaffected teenagers.
review4: The visual effects in Chronicle are astounding, but it's the well-drawn characters and convincing performances that keep it so wildly entertaining.
review5: Chronicle is a sometimes fun, slightly dark film about a boy and his camera.

title: One for the Money
review1: An ungainly mix of flat-footed gumshoeing and strained attempts at hilarity, all delivered with an unconvincing Joizy vibe.
review2: One doesn't need to have any familiarity with the Stephanie Plum novel series to immediately hear and see what an ill fit Katherine Heigl is for the role.
review3: Light and fluffy as a cupcake, Katherine Heigl's many talents are truly wasted in this story based on the first of eighteen best-selling Stephanie Plum novels.
review4: Didn't Jennifer Aniston already do a bounty hunter movie? Talk about sloppy seconds.
review5: One For The Money is a paint-by-numbers chick-flick that'll make you laugh a few times but won't particularly enamour.

title: Norwegian Wood
review1: The acting in the film is key. Every moment by Ken'ichi Matsuyama as Watanabe and Rinko Kikuchi as Naoko is valid yet seems distilled by memory rather than presented raw.
review2: We cover years at a bound, but when we light, we tend to spend long, lingering moments through the camera's loving eye. This is a beautiful film to see.
review3: Tran has drained the life right out of the novel.
review4: It becomes a film that, like its characters, remains elusive in its motivations and therefore detached from its audience.
review5: A master of mood and visuals, Tran proves an inspired choice.

title: Easy Living
review1: Sometimes interesting but sexist tale about football, with some good Tourneur touches.
review2: This would-be intelligent soap opera tale about the early days of pro football never reaches a boil.

title: The Black Bird
review2: The movie tells a Jekyll-and-Hyde story, with criminal greed and opportunity replacing science as the catalyst of willing transformation.

title: Mutant Girls Squad (Sentô shôjo: Chi no tekkamen densetsu)
Certified Copy (Copie Conforme)
review1: . The basic plot - a man and a woman traveling and talking - is reminiscent of Richard Linklater's Before Sunrise/Before Sunset films, but the way in which Certified Copy calls into question the nature of reality is more akin to Inception.
review2: While the people those characters encounter readily buy into their story as moviegoers ordinarily would, Mr. Kiarostami invites his viewers to second-guess his film and their own perceptions.
review3: Certified Copy reminded me why I love movies.
review4: Abbas Kiarostami's Tuscan sun-dappled enigma is the cinematic gift that is going to keep on giving for decades.
review5: Binoche and Shimell keep us fully engaged with their characters throughout their conversations, and Kiarostami draws us in with his signature mixture of long takes and intimate close-ups

title: Perfect Sense
review1: Each deprivation is preceded by a flurry of emotion that leads to the film's most vivid sequences.
review2: An intriguing apocalyptic romance with a multi-purpose title.
review3: The problem with Perfect Sense is its inability to be effective as either a character-based love story or something larger and more bold.
review4: People around the world progressively lose their senses of smell, taste, hearing and, finally, sight. Too bad the filmmakers never seem to have had a sense of humor in the first place.
review5: A solemn sci-fi parable set in present-day Glasgow, whose deepening sense of foreboding is sustained by the enigmatic, pseudo-biblical reflections of an unseen narrator.

title: The Woman in Black
review1: The moody, beautifully composed production raises it above the norm.
review2: The balance between edge-of-vision shadows and DanRad's screen-centre face puts the care into scares.
review3: Scene after endless scene of Radcliffe roaming the hallways of a spooky gothic house seeking the source of creepy noises and phantasmic movements is not compelling enough for a two-hour film.
review4: The Woman in Black successfully plumbs the atmospheric vibe of The Haunting but is even more disturbing because all its bad stuff happens to little kids.
review5: Whether or not The Woman in Black provides those chills is entirely up to whatever particular type of creep-out sends shivers down your spine.

title: The First Beautiful Thing (La prima cosa bella)
review1: Virzi approaches mawkishness but he never crosses the line.
review2: "The First Beautiful Thing'' is shameless, and, damn it, I cried anyway.
review3: Occasionally affecting but unremarkable.
review4: Virzi has hit his stride in this polished but delicate comedy-drama.
review5: It's filled with its own artfulness and warmth.

title: Red Tails
review1: There's no sense of threat or danger: this is a film with its head stuck firmly in the clouds.
review2: George Lucas's last big hurrah is a hackneyed ode to a group of heroes-the Tuskegee Airmen-who deserve better treatment than this cliché interrupted by dazzling, FX-laden dogfights, smoke-filled explosions, boring subplots, and oxygen-depleting dialogue.
review3: One longs for more scenes between the ensemble on the ground, but the emphasis on aerial (and digital) technology leaves the characters without context.
review4: A patriotic but blatantly unremarkable film that could have been much much more.
review5: The actors' convincing portrayals and realistic bond with each other, along with the spectacular visual and sound effects created by Lucas, makes Red Tails feel genuine and powerful.

title: West of Zanzibar
review3: Chaney plays a stage magician whose signature trick is to transform a beautiful woman into a skeleton: This is an absolutely brilliant -- and economical -- visual evocation of the relationship between sex and death, the erotic and the morbid...
review4: What makes this film special is the virtuoso performance of Chaney.

title: Tell It to the Marines
review1: Dated romantic, comedy and adventure tale that was popular during its release but when viewed today seems just to be silly.

title: Where East Is East
review1: Tiger (Lon Chaney) and Toyo (Lupe Velez) have an eyebrow-raising relationship: Lots of kissy face, tickling, lap-sitting and threats of spanking occur when this father and daughter are together.

title: Life Without Principle (Dyut Meng Gam)
review1: [To] wants to get us thinking about morality, and our survival instinct, and what's really important in life - conversation starters with value the world over.
review2: You might be surprised at who bends, breaks, or in some cases upholds morals in this dramatic comedy of human greed.

title: A Necessary Death
review2: These are daring, challenging themes for a young filmmaker and Stamm proves to be adept at playing with ideas that scare away writer/directors with twice as much experience.
review3: A Necessary Death presents a wholly original, fascinating and curiously terrifying documentary that's likely to either captivate or revolt audiences.
review4: 'A Necessary Death' treats the topic of sucide in a disturbing yet creative way. This is a shocking, emotionally powerful film.
review5: An experimental faux documentary on the unpleasant subject matter of suicide.

title: Memorial Day
review1: Between all the flashbacks and flash-forwards, you'll need a scorecard.
review2: A family saga as much as a war story, it chronicles a generations-spanning Minnesota military family whose servicemen harbor life-changing combat experiences they can't easily talk about.
review3: "Memorial Day" is mostly watchable thanks to the performances of John and James Cromwell. The story does its best to reel you in and feel for these characters, but may feel like it's stringing you along with no pay off in sight at times.

title: Silver Tongues
review1: Swirling with unease, its scenes set us up for a payoff that never materializes and strand its actors in a bitter present.
review3: The problem with Silver Tongues is that Simon Arthur has nothing to actually show us about the world.

title: The Aggression Scale
review1: Pits "Straw Dogs" against "Home Alone," if Kevin were a potential serial killer, and the thieves murderers.
review2: 'A satisfactory but straightforward dabbling in psycho killer hero worship.'
review3: Sort of like The Strangers meets Home Alone. Only dead serious and painfully violent.

title: Love Never Dies
review1: The desire to hoodwink an audience by trading exclusively on nostalgia is certainly a temptation that will never die.

title: Coriolanus
review1: The other actors do their best to help Fiennes define this curious anti-hero. Incapable of playing the role of peacetime compromiser, his Coriolanus comes across as a warrior who simply can't function without a war.
review2: The film has fifth-act problems, as did the play, but Fiennes' bleak overview should leave receptive viewers feeling daunted and haunted.
review3: The play's inherent difficulties notwithstanding, Coriolanus, the movie, is a perfectly sound achievement.
review4: Fiennes leads a cast that, at least in the major roles, is uniformly powerful.
review5: "Coriolanus" is a triumph.

title: Valley of the Sun
review1: The generally groan-worthy humor makes the film far from the rollicking romp the premise would suggest.

title: Man on a Ledge
review1: As befitting the blunt dullness of the title, it manages the neat trick of being curiously watchable without ever crossing the line into remotely interesting.
review2: After an interesting guessing game in the first forty minutes, it slips and falls to a terrible and clichéd death.
review3: This drama defies reason, logic and explanation but it can't defy gravity and ultimately falls flatly on its face.
review4: "Man on a Ledge" is not a film that will change the way we look at thrillers, but it is a film that has enough thrills to provide for a very entertaining ride
review5: Sam Worthington's Man On A Ledge is an absolute mess of a film, from start to finish. It's silly, dumb and ridiculous.

title: 96 Minutes
review1: The plot doesn't spiral; it falls with a thud and then just lies there.
review2: "96 Minutes" is a mere introduction to Sociology 101, but it's brisk enough to rustle the reading list and keep the conversation alive.
review3: The talented Mr. Ross makes Dre's panic and adrenaline-fueled behavior all too believable. You watch as he sees his horizons dim. What could be sadder?
review4: The feature debut of writer-director Aimee Lagos, the film feels overstuffed and overcooked, as if the filmmaker were trying to get too much out all in one go.
review5: Like 21 Grams minus the breadth, acting, or visual style, Aimee Lagos' first feature follows two pairs of friends on a collision course.

title: Hello Lonesome
review1: It's a bit scattered, and each of its three stories turns on a bit of a melodrama. It's not perfect. But it does work.
review2: The seeming randomness of the assorted human interactions in "Hello Lonesome" gradually becomes illuminating and just a little bit profound.
review3: The parts are ultimately greater than the whole, but Adam Reid's offbeat debut suggests a talent worth watching.
review4: Manages the considerable feat of creating six fully human characters who are quirky enough to transcend the stereotypes found in a typical indie film.
review5: Though it can occasionally seem like an indie-dramedy answer to The Grudge, structured to pack in the maximum moments of whimsical connection instead of supernatural kills, the film does find something deeper in its treatment of Smith and Lloyd.

title: We Need to Talk About Kevin
review1: It becomes a film about her [Swinton] scattered mind. That produces wonders from Swinton, but it ignores the plea in the title. What about Kevin? Kevin deserves so much more attention-indeed, he deserves being played by Tilda Swinton.
review2: We're not supposed to talk about a lot of the ugly feelings Kevin stirs up, but maybe we need to.
review3: As a psychological study of a shattered mother struggling to make sense of a heinous crime carried out by her teenage son, it's endlessly fascinating.
review4: A high school killing spree leads to a captivating examination of parenthood and the 'nature vs nurture' debate.
review5: A real-world horror movie -- for parents.

title: Star of Midnight
review1: Good escapist entertainment mixing snappy dialogue with pistol shots and cocktails.

title: Bridge to the Sun (Pont vers le soleil)
Private Romeo
review1: Take a couple of friends to see it, and the amount you spend may exceed the amount the filmmakers did.
review2: An earnest experiment in don't-ask-don't-tell drama as indebted to shirtlessness as to iambic pentameter.
review3: Unfortunately, "modern" additions (like the soldiers' YouTube videos and some social media moments) feel clunky, and a necessarily shortened approach trips the movie up...
review4: Private Romeo will undoubtedly be regarded by some as a curio, but it's a sweet, sympathetic and surprising one, highly recommended to the adventurous spirit in an enlightened and changing world.
review5: A pandering coming-of-ager about sexual identity and equality.

title: American Animal
review1: "American Animal" becomes a philosophically strident evening of speechifying local theater (topic: human evolution).
review2: The film equivalent of being cornered at a house party by someone's coked-out friend of a friend until your ride home is ready to bounce.
review3: It is well-acted and features witty repartee. Look for more good things to come from this talent.
review4: [An] hour and a half of pretentious mind games...
review5: It's best to imagine this movie as a study of three good young actors trapped in an indie film project with a yammering weirdo.

title: Bad Blood: The Hatfields and McCoys
Declaration of War
review1: True to its title, "Declaration of War" is a visceral, forthright visit to the front lines of battle, where superhuman courage is called for as life-or-death skirmishes turn into a long slog of survival.
review2: The tonal shifts, the "Amelie"-style voiceover and the punk-retro soundtrack may jar some viewers who expect uninterrupted violins, but "Declaration of War" is alternative therapy that really works.
review3: The subject matter is as serious as can be, yet the style is vibrant, energetic and engaging -- often tense, but without a trace of woe-is-me.
review4: "Declaration of War" movingly chronicles a unique and terrible fight: that of two parents against the cancer that has invaded the brain of their 18-month-old son.
review5: As ponderous and overwrought as a film hogged by a couple of young hipsters named Roméo and Juliette can be.

title: The Collapsed
review1: What The Collapsed lacks is the jolts that horror fans may prefer in their post-apocalyptic fare.
review3: The Collapsed manages to corral its literary pretensions well enough that it manages to avoid embarrassing itself.
review4: All the movie needs is more cowbell.

title: Tomboy
review1: Tomboy is a lovely reminder that the French have long been famous for a quite different sort of film-about children.
review2: Brisk, precisely observed, and bracingly non-preachy in its examination of a very tricky subject.
review3: Writer and director Celine Sciamma adorns the thorny dilemma with resonant allusions to gender roles...
review4: Modestly conceived and executed.
review5: "Tomboy" is tender and affectionate.

title: Five Minarets in New York
review1: ksekinaei apo realistika symbanta, protoy ksekinhsei na se plakwnei sto ena dakrybrexto a-nohma meta to allo, gia na eksontwsei kai to teleytaio anypotaxto egkefaliko soy kyttaro

title: Machine Gun Preacher
review1: it can be a bit... preachy, if you pardon the pun
review2: With an exploitation-friendly title like Machine Gun Preacher you'd think this movie would be the soul brother of Hobo With A Shotgun. Unfortunately, that is not so.
review3: Despite a competent performance from Butler, Machine Gun Preacher tackles way too much material to present a cohesive onscreen telling of the Sam Childers story.
review4: It's an uncomfortable marriage of sentimental genre conventions and real-life tragedy shown with graphic detail. It does bring you inside the main character's internal struggle, but doesn't seem focused enough as it sways into action film territory.
review5: We're given surprisingly little food for thought when it comes to the question of the complicated tensions between Christian faith and violence.

title: The Yankles
review1: This overlong movie never builds sufficient momentum.

title: Zero Bridge
review1: [Director Tariq Tapa's] neorealist approach, not supported by much technique, gets dreary, but he has an ace up his sleeve.
review2: The wisp of a story that drives the film follows the neo-realist template a little too closely.
review3: Rough hewn neo-realist drama from India has its sociological fascinations.
review4: Made for a song with a non-pro cast and DV camera gear out of his backpack, Tariq Tapa's debut feature shows the young Kashmiri-American as a filmmaker of enormous promise and precocious maturity.
review5: While the film's minimalist nature is its greatest asset in the first act, it ultimately makes its flaws and screenwriterly touches all the more apparent, resulting in some great individual slice-of-life sequences and some truly hackneyed ones.

title: Rift
review1: Even the ablest performer couldn't sell such slapdash dialogue as "Yo, we gotta get outta here!" or the risibly repetitive, "I'm tired and cold and exhausted!"

title: In Darkness
review1: Unique among Holocaust films, Agnieszka Holland's Academy Award-nominated In Darkness is set during World War II in a small town in Poland named Lvov (now a part of the Ukraine).
review2: Holland's film is extraordinarily generous with its characters in ways that take the story beyond being a historical fable of altruism and endurance.
review3: Just when you thought you could never watch another drama about surviving the Holocaust, veteran Polish director Agnieszka Holland unearths an astonishing saga from a subterranean past.
review4: Though the film's factual basis dictates an upbeat ending, much of the journey is appropriately and memorably grim.
review5: The title says it all, really.

title: Too Big to Fail
review1: Complex account of 2008 economic collapse; lots of language.

title: The Convincer (Thin Ice)
review1: It's just a little slow getting started.
review2: The movie never fully clicks.
review3: As a caustic comedy, "Thin Ice" resides just slightly south of "Fargo."
review4: At one point you're looking at the screen going, "This makes no sense!" Then after a long conclusionary explanation, you shake your head and say, "I'm still not sure that made much sense."
review5: Thin Ice's troubled production history - the film was famously taken away from director Jill Sprecher and re-edited following its Sundance premiere - can't quite dampen what is, for the most part, an entertaining little comedy/thriller...

title: Tyler Perry's Good Deeds
review1: A ridiculously redemptive finale negates almost all of the preceding dramatic tension and resurrects a cloying Richard Marx chestnut to boot.
review2: Whose life, Wesley asks in the movie's narration, is he living? Judging from all the sterile office and apartment space and his mile-long face, I'd say Bruce Willis's in "The Sixth Sense.''
review3: There aren't a lot of laughs in "Good Deeds," and it could have used more of them.
review4: An otherwise unremarkable pic that takes what feels like a very long time to unwind a drearily predictable storyline.
review5: Good Deeds honors goodness, which isn't at all a bad thing, and it's not without moments of genuine feeling. But by the film's end, after watching a seemingly infinite number of dour close-ups of sober self-evaluation, I felt bludgeoned.

title: A Little Bit Of Heaven
review1: Sap without the weight of reality, awkwardly combined with a romance without much chemistry.
review2: A little bit of hell.
review3: Kate Hudson dies prettily in this tone-deaf dramedy about a woman finding love while suffering from colon cancer.
review4: When a movie opens with a character telling you that love isn't important, that movie is definitely going to smack down that nonbeliever, because movies always believe love is important.
review5: Who knew dying could be such a laugh riot? Certainly not any of us who have actually watched a loved one in the awful final stages of cancer.

title: House Of Boys
review1: Against the odds, the indulgent mash-up of sex, old-fashioned corn, romance-novel fantasy and AIDS tragedy is a mostly winning combo.
review2: A gay tragedy in three acts and more than a dozen excellent songs, "House of Boys" conveys an emotional honesty that overrides its dated style.
review3: For all its hanging on the details of the boys' heavily eroticized performances and its graphing of the relationships between the young performers, the film is at once too drawn out and underdeveloped.

title: The Hedgehog
review1: "The Hedgehog" sneaks up on you with its heartfelt storytelling and sophisticated wit.
review2: A satisfying emotional experience.
review3: A reminder that, sometimes, the movies can get a beloved book exactly right.
review4: This a movie with such a light, stylish touch, it makes no claims to profundity and is a sweetly hopeful experience.
review5: "The Hedgehog" is a treat: a movie that's smart, grown-up, wry and deeply moving.

title: Ranchero
review1: Reaches for thematic resonance and ends up only cliché-deep.
review2: The film's inconsistencies, details that never seem to add up plausibly, along with the script's stilted dialogue, do the most harm to Kaponas' debut feature.

title: Perfect Strangers (Vacation from Marriage)
review1: A decent comedy that misses the mark, as it never becomes that enticing.

title: Keyhole
review1: Still too self-referential, too hermetic and too glacial to offer much enjoyment beyond the gorgeous monochrome visuals.
review2: Patric's performance is a deadpan treat. His can-do, take-charge character is in continual zany contrast to his surreal surroundings.
review3: 'Keyhole" is the first Guy Maddin movie that feels as if it got only halfway out of the director's head and onto the screen.
review4: Funny enough to be disarming even when it's spinning its wheels thematically.
review5: A Maddin film has a disturbing way of always seeming to exist in the present, like a dream. You know what happened and you even know what will happen, but you also see it all shifting and changing.

title: Snow on tha Bluff
review1: No one seems to have a steady job, and there's no shaking the sense of wasted souls in a forsaken sector of society.
review2: Frequently scored to hip-hop heard through car speakers, Bluff's portrait of street life has a grungy off-the-cuff realism that's only compromised by some obviously staged incidents...
review3: Immediate and unrelenting, Snow On Tha Bluff is unlike anything you'll see this year... unless, of course, you live in the Bluff.
review4: Questions of authenticity aside, Damon Russell evinces a shrewd understanding of how to juxtapose the handheld camera's finite sightline with the bursts of chaos that suddenly invade it.

title: The Conspirators
review3: Be warned, the spy film pales with the stiff Henreid taking up all the screen time instead of the smooth Bogie.

title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte)
review1: A sweet puff of a film, My Afternoons With Margueritte is as disarming as it is absurd.
review2: [Depardieu] is as emblematic of his country as Tom Hanks is of ours, and "My Afternoons With Margueritte" is his "Forrest Gump." Only better.
review3: The happy ending lays it on too thick, but what the hell: In for a dime, in for a dollar.
review4: A predictable, undernourished love story.
review5: It's a lovely movie.

title: Project X
review1: Superbad for bullies.
review2: A politically-incorrect and surprisingly uneven teen comedy that 20-somethings will likely enjoy.
review3: PROJECT X is the male gaze substantiated and concentrated into ninety sweaty minutes.
review4: Project X misses the mark some of the time, but makes up for it by hosting the party of the decade.
review5: Unlike prior 'house party' movies, Project X says nothing meaningful about its subject matter and, instead, paints teens as unlikeable and reckless automatons.

title: A Bag of Hammers
review1: It's too little, too late for Crano's Wes Anderson-inflected innocence-disrupted project...
review2: Brian Crano's very slight debut of a comedy.
review3: Mr. Canterbury's character is a Hollywood child archetype: wan and withdrawn, all monosyllables and needy stares.
review4: Woven amid the glib one-liners and contrived scenarios is an unexpected, and undeniably touching, sense of heart.
review5: It's a struggle all the way for A Bag Of Hammers, though its irony-crusted heart is in the right place.

title: The FP
review1: Rather than crafting a movie that's so bad it's good, writer-director brothers Jason and Brandon Trost have come up with something that's just plain bad -- and boring, and repetitive.
review2: "The FP" so desperately wants to be cultishly admired for its bad-taste rollout of wacko characters, ugly costumes and vulgar slang that it forgets to be genuinely offbeat or funny.
review3: You need to find a room full of people who get the joke and see this movie there, because audiences will be laughing so hard they'll be screaming.
review4: It falls all over itself to lampoon its midnight-movie forebears even as it borrows their contrivances.
review5: "The FP" works best as an operatic parody of mixed genres with lunacy on the fringes.

title: Big Miracle
review1: "Big Miracle" is quite the whale of a tale. Miraculous? Maybe. Predictable? Mostly. Delightful? Absolutely.
review2: A heavy-handed script and an obnoxious main character help sink this environmental drama.
review3: There are more subtle movies out there, but few more uplifting.
review4: Big Miracle is invested with solid craftsmanship and a nuanced view of how idealism, pragmatism, and politics intersect.
review5: This is, well, huge.

title: Cat Run
review1: It's easy to feel sucked into some kind of time warp back to the heyday of late-'90s post-Tarantino crime thrillers, cut-rate knockoffs filled with casually cartoonish violence, quippy patter, overtly flash filmmaking and incongruous pop tunes.
review2: If you can't dazzle 'em with brilliance, baffle 'em with genre baloney -- and enough shoplifted visual trickery to fill Quentin Tarantino's kitchen sink.
review3: Though John Stockwell's action comedy is shamelessly derivative, his enthusiastic cast propels it much further than it should go.
review4: An incoherent hybrid of buddy movie, "Girls Gone Wild" episode and James Bond spoof that employs cheap cinematic tricks like multiple split screens for no apparent purpose.
review5: Words like "smug," "derivative," and "shallow" could all be fairly applied to the film, but as a piece of late-night exploitation, it delivers the violence and nudity with the regularity of an IV drip, and some familiar faces in the cast help class it up.

title: Attenberg
review1: Tsangari's art-house minimalism, which never lets us forget we're watching a movie, still permits a surprising degree of tender emotion.
review2: Using occasional song-and-dance numbers with a melancholy Godardian kick, [Tsangari] creates a world that's off-center and alive with loneliness.
review3: Part of the film's success comes from Labed's performance as Marina, who infuses all that weirdness with a barely there vulnerability.
review4: "Attenberg" is a three-layered love story, anatomizing the mysterious emotions of grief, friendship and erotic attraction.
review5: The drama, at its core, is simple and conventional, but it has the aura of science fiction.

title: Seeking Justice
review1: A dumb-dumb variant on the Death Wish vigilante justice genre.
review2: [Cage] acquits himself well enough in this otherwise rudimentary thriller from deliriously unsubtle director Roger Donaldson.
review3: It's a perfectly palatable and even engaging thriller, albeit one requiring several leaps of faith and/or disengagement with reality.
review4: Donaldson ... seems to have lost all talent for pacing.
review5: [Cage] shouldn't do any more movies in which his character signals his acceptance of a Faustian bargain by buying two candy bars.

title: Nobody Lives Forever
review4: A melodrama directed by Jean Negulesco with film noir style.

title: State's Attorney
review1: The dialogue is sharp, but the script is weak.

title: Best Laid Plans
review1: This might be uneven, but it's well filmed, with a clutch of affecting scenes - a more thoughtful affair than your average Brit fight flick.
review2: A cut above recent British low-life crime pictures...
review3: Realist in tone, the film lacks much imagination and trundles along too predictably for comfort.
review4: Too stupid to be abominable, but only just.
review5: It isn't the smoothest transition but strong performances from Stephen Graham and Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje keep the idea afloat.

title: The Decoy Bride
review1: Instead of working to clarify its high-concept contrivances, the romantic comedy "The Decoy Bride" jettisons logic and detail for silly-quirky rompiness.
review2: A bland romantic comedy in the Richard Curtis style, The Decoy Bride is mainly notable for its proof, if any was needed after Boardwalk Empire, that Kelly Macdonald is a major talent.
review3: Cupid works in strange and sometimes very funny ways, as this charming, nontaxing comedy directed by Sheree Folkson makes clear.
review4: It seems to agree with its gossip journalists that celebrities are an exotic alien species placed on earth to be gawked at, waited on by personal entourages, and mocked behind their backs for their odd enthusiasms and incomprehensible emotions.
review5: Pernicious tripe suitable only for masochists and the intellectually disabled...

title: The Artist
review1: Michel Hazanavicius' black-and-white, mostly silent comedy The Artist is a gorgeously made curiosity -- a film that functions as a testament to its own obsession with other movies.
review2: This is a bauble, not a jewel.
review3: Uplifting, heart-warming, hilarious... not necessarily words you'd expect to apply to a black and white silent French film. But The Artist is no ordinary movie.
review4: Writer/director Michel Hazanavicius uses a shrewd eye for visual composition to tell an emotionally effective story never waylaid by the clever throwback gimmickry of his method.
review5: The Artist is drunk on the history of cinema and art, and culture buffs will get giddy on it.

title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia
review1: Ceylan's own growing reputation will, I hope, continue to grow. He uses the realistic film as an avenue to what lies around and beyond the realism.
review2: It runs 157 minutes, and I can't say you don't feel them. You do - but in the way you would, reading a very good book in an uncomfortable chair.
review3: A movie of such dark, smoldering intensity that it's easy to forget that half of it takes place in near darkness.
review4: A police procedural as existential inquiry, set in a remote dreamscape of mystery and foreboding.
review5: While Gökhan Tiryaki's cinematography is phenomenal, the film is, at its best, a wasted opportunity.

title: Breakaway
review1: With a script credited to five writers including its star Vinay Virmani, it is a movie that keeps skating madly off in different directions and desperately needs more coaching than director Robert Lieberman provides.
review2: [A] pleasant timewaster, which has a good cast but a not-so-good script.
review3: There are no surprises here, with father-son crisis and reconciliation, scaled-down quasi-Bollywood production numbers and the climactic big game all arriving on cue.
review5: Much better than the other reviews reflect. A feel-good entertainment that sheds light on the misunderstood but heroic Sikh peoples. Now available on Netflix streaming, see for yourself and don't rely on the critics.

title: The Perfect Family
review1: It would be ripe territory for self-reflection if this sloppy debut from filmmaker Anne Renton weren't plagued with as much self-doubt and uncertainty as its lead Catholic.
review2: At the most fundamental level, as a work of entertainment, it fails. Scenes meander pointlessly, beginning and ending without any change or story movement.
review3: A moving story of a woman's attempt to keep pace in a world that's moving too quickly for her.
review4: A leaden, ham-fisted affair that was exactly the sort of pap John Waters was spoofing when he cast Turner as a serial-killing soccer mom.
review5: The film's gentle, sentimental approach prevents it from ever really getting at the pain that's been swirling around this imperfect family for years.

title: Sidewalls
review1: With its themes of alienation in the Internet age and cutesy indie-ish trimmings, the film will feel familiar to anyone who's seen a bittersweet romantic comedy from Sundance.
review2: The preordained story line is clear from the outset, yet Taretto's knack for engineering clever near-misses keeps us guessing about how and when the happy ending will arrive.
review3: It's hard to truly hate any movie whose ending revolves around a clever Where's Waldo? gag. It's also near impossible to take it seriously for that exact same reason.
review4: Leandro Martinez's eye-pleasing cinematography complements Taretto's literate script, although the Hollywood ending is jarring.
review5: Smart, wordy and sweetly sympathetic to lives lived online, "Sidewalls" coasts on Martín and Mariana's twin voice-overs, alternate musings on themselves and their city.

title: A Thousand Words
review1: The high concept breeds lowbrow gags.
review2: A thousand words? Try two words: stay away. Murphy does a pretty good job keeping up with the various indignities heaped on him but the movie as a whole ends up sinking.
review3: a poorly conceived and startlingly miscast comedy that works to every one of its stars' weaknesses.
review4: You've got one of the funniest verbal actors in the business in Eddie Murphy, and you put him in a movie where he can't talk. It's already a recipe for disaster.
review5: 'A Thousand Words' is not unspeakably awful.

title: Summer With Monika (Sommaren med Monika)
review1: More than 50 years after its first screening in America, Monika arrives in New York again to light up the screen, this time without a trace of impropriety.
review2: Bergman's tale of heedless teenage love is a sort of neorealist Rebel Without a Cause -- except that sex is acknowledged and the outlaw is a girl.
