review3: Bergman would be no more adept a pornographer than he would be at filming hip-hop, but his camera did stare at the human surface with an intentness unmatched since von Sternberg rhapsodized over Marlene Dietrich.
review4: A tender yet unsentimental account of a love affair that turns sour.
review5: His first film with Andersson shows a developing ability to probe the psychology of a rich, vital woman without losing his objectivity.

title: God Bless America
review1: Goldthwait's bile may be cathartic, but it also feels a bit cheap.
review2: It takes dead aim at the culpability of hate-mongering politicians, the religious right and reality TV stars in making the United States the meanest, rudest country in the world.
review3: A brilliant, fearless, and merciless indictment of American culture, and how we've become the lowest common denominator
review4: Bobcat Goldthwait's God Bless America works well as a black comedy and as a satirical look at pop culture and human behavior.
review5: It's an intriguing satirical idea, and it works very effectively in places, while being tremendously didactic and heavy-handed in others.

title: The Hunter
review1: Its mostly observant temper keeps us from being greatly moved, but it holds us with its acute, almost laboratory dissection of its people's beings.
review2: The Hunter is a film of surprising scope and intimacy.
review3: It is an atmospheric and richly rewarding film that glides along at a pace akin to that of the small country local within which it's set.
review4: Slow-moving but graceful, this character study is engaging and insightful.
review5: The Hunter delivers a quiet and somewhat meandering story that wallows in self-importance and social agenda.

title: A Novel Romance
review1: "A Novel Romance" supplies a response to the question, "Is Steve Guttenberg still working?" but leaves unanswered the natural follow-up: "Why?"
review2: Steve Guttenberg is probably supposed to be a lovable loser in "A Novel Romance," a drab, clumsy film by Allie Dvorin, but he can manage to be merely annoying.
review3: The literary conceit [adds] tired self-deprecating narration and arch chapter titles to the romantic-comedy mix.
review4: Cohabitation "commandments" and talk of "chick flicks" further send the material into a cutesy tailspin, with the script's low point an egregious scene featuring Nate sneaking a peek at a silhouette of Jenny undressing behind a curtain.
review5: The film looks good, at least. But look past that, and there's not much there.

title: The Secret Diaries Of Miss Anne Lister
The American Dream (Make A Movie Like Spike)
Abel
review1: Engrossing, intelligent fare.
review2: After its edgy, deliberately puzzling first hour, it starts to run out of steam, but at 85 minutes it doesn't overstay its welcome.
review3: Diego Luna's promising debut as a director is a slight and charming tale of a troubled young boy's retreat into fantasy.
review4: Enjoyable, off-beat drama that's both darkly funny and emotionally engaging, thanks to assured direction from Diego Luna and a terrific central performance from young Christopher Ruiz-Esparza.
review5: A slow-burning but satisfying comedy that goes for gentle humour rather than belly laughs.

title: Back From Eternity
review1: ... John Farrow's 1956 aviation disaster thriller turned jungle survival drama is in fact a faithful remake of the director's own 1939 Five Came Back.
review2: Why this film was made was to see if it could save failing RKO additional expenses and make money the easy way through a remake.

title: Black Limousine (The Land of the Astronauts)
review1: Think of Black Limousine as a mini of the surreal masterwork Mulholland Drive, but with less twists and turns.

title: Margaret
review1: Even in its truncated state, this is pretty gripping stuff.
review2: "Margaret" not only faithfully captures a young woman's growing pains, it also serves as an emblem for our collective post-9/11 grieving process.
review3: This movie may be a lot of things, but finished isn't one of them.
review4: Knotty, ambitious and trading in messy human truths, it's the work of a master dramatist. Here's hoping Lonergan's next one reaches us a little faster.
review5: A messy-yet-poignant dramatic opera about the power of regret, loss, and worst of all, being a teenager.

title: Being Flynn
review1: It's been ages since De Niro tackled a character as rich and challenging as this, and he tackles it head-on.
review2: He might be guilty of showboating, but De Niro's knockout performance is a declaration that the star of "Raging Bull" isn't ready to hang up his gloves.
review3: Weitz digs diligently for emotional truths and makes the most of his excellent cast.
review4: I'm happy to report that De Niro hasn't lost his chops. At least not quite.
review5: Heads downward in every sense of the word.

title: The Flowers of War
review1: Zhang's flamboyant camera choreography and diva-ish flounces of melodrama are vivid but misplaced.
review2: "The Flowers of War" seems like a pretty good film until you begin to think about it.
review3: An unsettling mixture of spectacular brutality and sentimentality that might make even Steven Spielberg blush.
review4: The director's grip on the drama is often weakened by his penchant for creating spectacles.
review5: A florid, melodramatic tear-jerker of questionable taste but undeniable emotional impact.

title: "Non Ma Fille, Tu N'iras Pas Danser (Making Plans for Lena)"
review1: Makes you understand these spiky relationships in a visceral way. Even minor characters, with their strengths and faults and fits of irrationality, emerge as complicated, three-dimensional beings.
review2: Chiara Mastroianni's performance is the only saving grace of this tedious family drama.
review3: Christophe Honoré's character study is one monolithic mash note for Chiara Mastroianni.
review4: Lena settles into a '70s American groove, with Mastroianni making an all-in, glam-free performance look easy.
review5: It's just an accumulation of bland incidents involving the central character and her family.

title: Rose Marie
review4: the movie is primarily for fans of the source material or the stars
review5: Charming version of the operetta. Perfect of its type.

title: Quill: The Life of a Guide Dog
review1: It's surprisingly unsentimental in its depiction of people with disabilities, and the scenes of guide-dog training are informative.
review2: Its principal selling point - the supreme watchability of dogs, especially working dogs - is undeniably powerful.
review3: It's a wonderful film, though, which is - oddly - only now getting a very limited release, eight years after its Japanese debut.
review4: Yoichi Sai's movie may be a bit tough for young viewers, but it is gentle and illuminating.
review5: Save for the tearful goodbye scenes, the only real drama in Quill is that Kobayashi is a little cranky at first and believe he's doing just fine with a cane.

title: Maytime
review3: Beautifully designed MacDonald-Eddy vehicle with the bonus of John Barrymore.

title: Lockout
review1: The dialogue between the two leads and Guy Pearce's pleasant performance make this sci-di drama worth seeing.
review2: struggles to overcome the many disparate clichés thrown together by the filmmakers.

title: The Turin Horse
review1: This great poem on the end of the world is truly a film for the ages. It can't really be described, but only lived.
review2: No movie could possibly live up to the monumental, forbidding grandeur of The Turin Horse's lengthy opening shot, but [Bela Tarr]... goes ahead and attempts the impossible, and comes frighteningly close to succeeding.
review3: "The Turin Horse" is a parable, which means it's both very simple and very weighty. It's not about event and emotion, but duration and endurance.
review4: It feels like the creation story in reverse -- a terrible, unavoidable walk into the dark.
review5: Through Tarr's meticulous vision, these ordinary hardships take on cosmic weight; this is tedium vividly rendered.

title: Salmon Fishing in the Yemen
review1: It's an affable, inoffensive British comedy that just wants you to like it so much that you can't help but snicker behind its back.
review2: To say this movie requires an utter suspension of disbelief is a vast understatement.
review3: ... just because something seems absurd doesn't mean it can't happen. And just because a film seems to lack surprises doesn't mean it won't take an entirely satisfying turn at the end.
review4: As it stands, the best elements of the film become mired in the unwelcome narrative muck, branding Salmon Fishing in the Yemen the one that got away.
review5: Everything that happens is horribly predictable, and the tone varies from light and fluffy to over-the-top camp, especially with Kristin Scott Thomas as the cynical British press secretary.

title: 4:44 Last Day on Earth
review1: Though it gains traction toward the end, viewers may finally feel puzzled or indifferent. You expect a bit more from the end of the world.
review2: Rehashing old arguments in the hours before certain death is a tedious waste of time - theirs, and ours.
review3: If the end of the world was just hours away, would New Yorkers still be able to get takeout? Yes, if Abel Ferrara's mind-bending "4:44 Last Day on Earth'' is any indication.
review4: Ferrara movingly celebrates connection, cooking life down to just its barest essence: a man, a woman and a need.
review5: Ferrara doesn't give his protagonists room to do much beyond have arguments and sex (though the intimacy is shot well).

title: Mamitas
review1: Unbalanced storytelling aside, Ozeki wisely works to keep the film focused on his actors, a smart move considering their live-wire charm.

title: La fée (The Fairy)
review1: The story cuts corners, so it's not the masterpiece these filmmakers may yet create - but when they're on, this is jolly and so cute you'll sigh.
review2: There may be better films in the theaters this week, but there surely is none easier to like than "The Fairy."
review3: Do yourself and your kids a favor. On the way to multiplex to see "The Avengers," tell them "The Fairy" is about an all-powerful superheroine. Someday, they'll find the words to thank you.
review4: Its appeal is ... in watching people who have devised their own original style of comic performance and have taken it to a rare level of refinement.
review5: It's a slight film, and it's over just as you're thinking it should be, but it's both sweet and refreshingly tart...

title: Deadline
review1: Has all the dramatic punch of a community theater production.
review2: Too lifeless for Lifetime and too inept to do justice to its source material...
review3: The plot, in short, is underwhelming. It merely follows the reporters as the screenplay serves them the solution to their case on a silver platter.
review4: Although helmer Curt Hahn champions the causes of racial justice and crusading journalism, he can't seem to find a tone that's consistent or that befits the gravity of his subject matter.
review5: The fact that real-life deadly racial animus in America is often cartoonish in its manifestation doesn't excuse Deadline's cliché-ridden characterizations of bigotry.

title: Friends With Kids
review1: Westfeldt has shackled herself to such a lame gimmick that there's scarcely room to breathe.
review2: Surprisingly funny and wickedly smart, this romantic dramedy soars.
review3: As she did with her first script, the gender-bending 'Kissing Jessica Stein,' Westfeldt goes for something radical and winds up pulling her punches when things start getting interesting.
review4: Trying to figure what is the most offensive thing about this accidental mashup of 70s Woody Allen and Sex and the City...
review5: Movies of this genre normally want you to root for the couple to end up together. All this one had me doing was hoping that someone would smack them upside the head and talk some sense into them.

title: Black Butterflies
review1: Van Houten ... gives a strong performance as Jonker, and the cinematography is pleasing, but the script is cliché-ridden and ends on an overly sentimental note.
review2: The movie reminds you of the extent to which poetry has been marginalized as a cultural force since the early 1960s.
review3: Black Butterflies scarcely tries to illuminate the substance of Jonker's writing.
review4: Black Butterflies is a dark, moving depiction of the life and death of a brave rebellious, idiosyncratic woman who made significant strides toward changing the world around her and paid a heavy toll for her passion.
review5: Always feels like a life schematically condensed rather than intimately explored.

title: Get the Gringo
review1: Those who miss the days of Gibson's hardened movie characters will be in for a treat with Get the Gringo, a genuinely gritty, hard-boiled action-noir tale.
review2: Gibson, for all his offscreen controversy, still has his star-quality charisma, and Grunberg is a worthy protege for the Oscar-winning writer/actor/director.
review3: Get The Gringo is a passable addition to the action genre but it might have been better had the need to keep Gibson's fan base happy not been so pressing.
review4: This is a return to form for [Mel Gibson], playing a hard-edged tough-nut with personality. And it's easily his most charismatic role in over a decade.
review5: Things start off a little too cute with that self-aware, annoying post-Pulp Fiction faux-clever tough-guy winking narration, but it kind of straightens up a bit once the story kicks in.

title: Here
review1: [It] doesn't offer up a ton of narrative surprises, but there is plenty going on the screen to keep you engaged - and visually stimulated.
review2: You must be willing to give yourself to Braden King's debut feature, a slow, meandering and sumptuously photographed road trip combined with an intimate love story. I gave, and I got. A lot.
review3: "Here" seems motivated by a tone of searching and yearning, not of finding a single way. As Foster's character says at one point, "Getting lost was the goal."
review4: It becomes highly affecting, concerned both with the limits of mapping a landscape and with lovers' difficulties in navigating each other.
review5: The trains of thought stirred up by the film's contemplation of what is here and what is there - and where you are - are endless and stimulating. And the movie is embellished with spectacularly beautiful, enigmatic bursts of abstract imagery.

title: Midnight Son
review2: Filmmaker Leberecht takes an intriguingly askance approach to the vampire genre with this dark, romantic horror film, but after after a promising set-up seems unsure where to go from there.
review3: It's a frightening story, plausibly developed within a relatively brief running time, and the central love between the male protagonist increasingly addicted to blood and a girl addicted to cocaine is oddly moving.
review4: Visually and narratively, Midnight Son leads us confidently into territory we almost never see, but even when things start to feel familiar, Leberecht throws us a curve ball ...
review5: It might not be offering anything new to the lore of the horror film, but Midnight Son is a confident, minor work that hardcore admirers of the True Blood/Twilight cycle will want to seek out.

title: Three Strangers
review1: The intricately plotted messy film becomes enjoyable mainly because of the spirited performances.

title: My Way
review1: Given its aggressiveness in all cinematic matters, My Way manages to color in the personal stakes with enough clarity to keep you caring about the players set loose on its massive canvas.
review2: They should have spent more on the screenplay.
review3: Adolescent boys will savour My Way's bombast and solemnity. Cringing adult audiences will more likely beat a retreat before final call.
review4: "My Way," billed as the most expensive Korean film in history ($25 million) is epic, packed with action - and it's lousy.
review5: An eye-popping, empty-headed World War II epic made in South Korea.

title: The Deep Blue Sea
review1: Now a new film of the play appears, adapted and directed by Terence Davies with Rachel Weisz in that stellar [Hester Collyer] role and with Rattigan's work in a freshening treatment.
review2: The movie is an exquisite period piece, slow and dank, and unduly persuaded that it's rendering a classic.
review3: [Weisz'] performance that transforms her from actress to movie star.
review4: Weisz makes Hester's dilemma interesting for a while, but even an actress as fine as she can't begin to mold the character into someone worth caring about.
review5: By the time she learns love is less about ideal romance than "wiping someone's ass" when they grow old, it's difficult to care about a problem she created for herself.

title: Meeting Evil
review1: Writer-director Chris Fisher flirts with over-the-top exaggeration so often during Meeting Evil that auds might wish he'd gone all the way and dialed everything up to 11.
review2: It features tons of poor decisions, from the overwrought and intrusive musical score to bad-joke one liners from the main characters down to the supporting ones. The worst decision either actor made was actually appearing in this awful film.
review3: A cheap slasher flick with some talented actors masking the banality with clever dialogue...
review4: ...just another hopelessly incompetent direct-to-video thriller...
review5: If you don't mind style over substance, a bit of the old cat-and-mouse, and you enjoy watching Samuel L. Jackson making people squirm, then hop in, strap up, and hold on.

title: The Girl from the Naked Eye
review1: Newcomer Jason Yee proves plenty adept at chopsocky, but his chops are nonexistent on the thesping side.
review2: In its moments of sometimes comically violent antagonism, the movie shows some flashes of genre pizazz.
review3: At times off-putting, at other times outright campy, "The Girl From the Naked Eye" does offer a measured amount of queasy fun.
review4: There's a lot to like about the action film "The Girl From the Naked Eye," especially some crisp martial arts fight sequences and the subtle sense of humor that surfaces now and then.
review5: Could easily be relabeled Sin City Lite.

title: My Way
review1: Kang Je-kyu's big-budgeted WWII melodrama offers up a kitschy, overtly violent tale about two rival marathon runners caught in a continent-hopping battle of blood, guts and bad dialogue.
review2: [Director Kang Je-kyu] engineers one long pummel session of elaborate CGI effects, shaky battle cinematography and trial-by-fire heroics, but the nonstop adversity lacks any real sense of danger. Or, for that matter, emotional punch.
review3: This is big-boned, epic filmmaking of a variety Cecil B. DeMille or D.W. Griffith would appreciate.
review4: The paeans about national pride and brotherhood may be regional, but constant slow-motion battle scenes and squishy sentimentality are strictly wanna-be Tinseltown.
review5: Just don't expect much in the plot department.

title: Footnote
review1: At the last... Footnote is so intelligently and deftly made that we are glad it exists.
review2: "Footnote" deals with ambition, isolation, the dangers of too much success and the inevitable gap between generations.
review3: [A] mix of dry humor and bleak drama.
review4: a consistently inconsistent drama that could and should have been so much better.
review5: Who knew scholarly politics would be so boring?

title: Big Shots
review3: A hip comedy classic that's as much fun as it is a blast from the past
review4: Scripter Joe Eszterhas and director Robert Mandel squander most of the riches of this story by focusing on the boys' combat with two drug dealers.

title: Bathory
review1: More of a cinematic curiosity than true blockbuster material, despite its scale.
review4: Plays out more like a Monty Python comedy than a serious drama, with a subplot involving roller-skating friar-detectives that makes this already turgid 140-minute bore seem a whole lot longer.

title: Kahaani
review2: Essentially a one-woman show for Vidya Balan, and what a show it is.

review1: These girls are brilliantly un-victimy and always come out fighting. If only they weren't incessantly paraded about in their underwear for the viewing pleasure of men.
review2: I admire the ambition. Unfortunately, it's the execution that fails here.
review3: The plotting is clumsy, the characterisation scraggy and the dialogue clunky- but you can't accuse Clarke of lacking ambition, even if his film does display a yawning gulf between aspiration and accomplishment.
review4: full review at Movies for the Masses
review5: A complete absence of wit and some truly terrible writing and acting makes for one bluntly bad movie.

title: Le Havre
review1: We are so held by the film's impact that its ending, surprise or not, is like a bonus.
review2: Endearingly quirky, just this side of precious, but so warm and deftly executed that you go along with it.
review3: "Le Havre" is easily the most humanist, generous and hopeful movie in recent memory.
review4: Overly sentimental but warmhearted Marxist message pic.
review5: Kaurismäki returns with another of his deadpan comedies, reminiscent of the great silent comedians, though this one is arguably one of his gentlest as well.

title: The Understudy
review1: "The Understudy" isn't abysmal, though it certainly is off target.
review2: Seems at times to aspire to being an edgy look at the transgressions a would-be Broadway star will commit to land the big role. Other times, it seems unsure of what it wants to be at all.
review3: It's all sharp, well-performed stuff until things go from darkly comic to just plain dark, derailing -- and dragging out -- the otherwise absorbing story. Still, this one's a cut above.

title: Firstborn
review1: The movie creates such an urgent situation, and fills it with such interesting characters, that when everything goes wrong at the end I felt more than disappointed, I felt cheated.
review2: The best things about Firstborn are the easy, natural performances of the actors.
review3: It might have worked if Apted were as adept at creating an emotional atmosphere as he is in his portraiture of the suburban milieu, but too many unshaped scenes and redundant dialogue passages take their toll.
review4: This flawed but interesting Freudian melodrama spends about 70 minutes making points and the last 30 minutes losing them.
review5: A heavy-handed suburban sitcom.

title: Trade of Innocents
review1: The film fills up its hour-and-a-half harmlessly enough, but nothing's really memorable. Which is rather, bitterly, ironic.
review2: The movie screams of a low budget and pedestrian vision ...
review3: Yes, child trafficking is horrific; but embedding your raise-the-alarm mission in a film this inept runs the risk of arousing more amusement than activism.
review4: Not for the first time in films, noble intent is at odds with aesthetics.
review5: A middling thriller wrapped around a compelling lecture about the child sex trade in Southeast Asia...

title: Smitty
review1: Family drama with teen rebellion, heavy-handed lessons.

title: Mr. Hush
review1: It's too bad first time director David Lee Madison can't lay some responsibility on the screenwriter for the horrible script he was saddled with: he's got only himself to blame for this tedious mess.

title: Foreign Letters
review1: Subtitled coming-of-age drama explores girl friendship.
review2: A sensitive and lovely portrait of the slowly unfolding friendship of two preteen girls in America - one from Israel and one from Vietnam.

title: Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale
review1: At times, Warriors sacrifices dramatic nuance for scale, but even its most rousing passages are tempered by a sense of loss.
review2: You can see why Woo, the noted Hong Kong action director, would want to produce it: It fits right in with his "heroic bloodshed" cinematic legacy.
review3: As the war drags on, "Warriors of the Rainbow" outstays its welcome. I've never seen more severed heads in a film and cared less.
review4: An ambitious, blood-soaked retelling of an uprising by Taiwanese natives against Japanese occupiers.
review5: At 2 1/2 hours, "Warriors" is a bruising, relentless experience, one more tiring than inspiring.

title: Steve Niles' Remains
review1: Never manages to sustain any energy for more than three or four minutes at a time.
review2: Just as forgettable as the source material...
review3: All things considered, Remains is reasonably entertaining escapism and is a fun enough apocalyptic fright fest.

title: Girlfriend
review1: What begins as an absorbing exercise in glum atmosphere turns mild, meek, and desperate as the stakes rise.
review2: A modest, uneven example of regional American independent film. But it has tremendous heart and integrity...
review3: Emotionally manipulative and problematic...
review4: Doesn't miss many clichés of small-town, working-class, going-nowhere life.
review5: Implausibilities mount, and by the last act Lerner appears to have lost any compunction he might have had about using his protagonist to tug the audience's heartstrings.

title: Blue Like Jazz
review1: Just earnest enough to blend its religious theme with a beer-chugging hero for a surprisingly contemporary look at faith.
review2: The film's heart is in the right place; it just can't make the rest of its parts function smoothly.
review3: An uncommon thoughtfulness about spiritual issues distinguishes this otherwise generic coming-of-age story.
review4: "Blue Like Jazz" is a pleasant film, as well-intentioned as the character Don himself, but it ducks the thorniest questions of faith and dogma while patting itself on the back for realism.
review5: It is - somewhat surprisingly, given the heavy-handed subject - neither sanctimonious nor preachy.

title: Bel Ami
review1: "Bel Ami" is a handsome production, yet riddled with weaknesses.
review2: The supposedly cunning protagonist registers as a cipher, and the directors' tendency to shoot dialogue scenes in close-up blunts any understanding of the social milieu he's trying to conquer.
review3: The women are all elegant and intelligent, they know the ways of the world, and they know Georges' history. Why do they find him attractive? We don't, and that failure is the downfall of the film.
review4: Pattinson's passion is bloodless, his rakish George Duroy a font of undelivered potential.
review5: Good actors flit in and out of the movie - particularly Kristin Scott Thomas and Colm Meaney - but no one seems able to conquer the essential silliness of it all...

title: On the Ice
review1: The effect is stunningly effective, submerging us in a snowy, frozen, barren land with few options but plenty of opportunities for trouble. It is an offbeat gem.
review2: An authentic look at life in remote Alaska (the film was shot with a native cast in MacLean's hometown of Barrow) and at a people grappling with drugs, alcoholism, poverty and the limits of an unforgiving environment.
review3: If only because of the setting, this is an uncommonly involving thriller. I could call it a film noir, except that the sun never sets in the film.
review4: Unfortunately, the emotional landscape of MacLean's stoic main character, Qalli, is often as blank as the tundra.
review5: While Mr. Irelan and a few of the supporting players have some solid moments (the entire cast consists of nonprofessionals), the general vibe is too stilted to convince.

title: The Mind Reader
review1: The star performance by Williams and the mordant comical lines throughout, raise the film's value to watchable programmer fare.

title: Breathless
review1: I recommend 'Breathless' for non-squeamish thriller fans, but the amount of blood and gore on display may be way beyond what even those brave viewers can imagine.
review2: No kidding. If you chained-smoked half as much as the plotting ladies in this twisty dramedy, you'd be hyperventilating, too.
review3: Could be watchable because of Gina Gershon's mildly interesting manipulative and ruthless damsel-in-distress role.
review4: Now Val Kilmer is just in a race with Ray Liotta to see who can get the oldest and the fattest the fastest. It's like the tagline to "Alien Vs Predator;" whoever wins...we lose.
review5: Far more gruesome, and definitely packing more surprise punches than your average, everyday thriller.

title: Assassin's Bullet
review1: Think the Bourne franchise meets the Bond franchise, without the wit or action.
review2: [A] dippy hodgepodge of hitman action, illogical romance and geopolitical commentary.
review3: Why is Slater in this? Why are Sutherland and Spall? Why am I even watching it?
review4: Corny action scenes and borderline-hilarious direction by Isaac Florentine mark the film as an obvious straight-to-video item that somehow took a wrong turn into a movie theater.
review5: Mr. Slater valiantly tries to appear turned on by his leading lady's shimmying midsection, but he might as well be watching a performing dog for all the heat mustered between them.

title: Hick
review1: Ambles back and forth between tomfoolery and strained seriousness.
review2: It contains some effective performances, it does a good job of evoking bereft and empty landscapes, but what is it for? Has she learned anything? Have we?
review3: Hick wants to come across as trippy and offbeat but its bizarre, surreal approach is more off-putting than effective.
review4: A smarmy little road movie about a Southern teenage girl losing her innocence the hard way during the Reagan era.
review5: Mostly plays like some creepy-perv fantasia looking for mileage from the mature-beyond-her-years presence of young star Chloë Grace Moretz.

title: The Raid: Redemption
review1: My only complaint about The Raid is that it ended.
review2: A triumph of fight choreography, spatial relations and precious little else.
review3: Hollywood is particularly unsuited to producing sensation cinema these days.
review4: You really have an obligation to see it to witness what has a legitimate claim of being the best action film of all time.
review5: Gareth Huw Evans doesn't swipe plot points as much as organically build a taut, expertly choreographed heir to urban mayhem fantasies

title: The Snowtown Murders
review1: Your appreciation of this Australian horror movie will depend on whether you think its artistry justifies its unrelenting ugliness.
review2: The film is a chilling study of an evil, dominant personality and his victims.
review3: Overlong and grim to the point where some scenes are virtually unwatchable...
review4: An impressive but exceptionally disturbing feature debut from Australian director Justin Kurzel that pushes the new wave of Aussie crime films up a notch.
review5: This distressing infiltration of a family of young boys by a charismatic psychopath rewards with a stylistic talent that feels entirely new.

title: Korczak
review1: If Korczak isn't an artistic success, it's very much a historical success, offering a brief and powerful film school for interested filmmakers, and thus leading to better films.

title: Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory
review1: The new film, despite the astounding story it tells, is the most conventional, least urgent and, cinematically, the least interesting of the three.
review2: In the shadow of such sickness, all the personal dramas can't help but pale, but there are still surprising and powerful moments.
review3: Paradise Lost 3 is perhaps the most interesting and well-made film of the trilogy.
review4: The new film is more informational than resonant. But you can still sense a vacuum, a rat pit of stories waiting to be unearthed. The dark something that triggered the whole ordeal in West Memphis is still out there.
review5: First and foremost a testament to the power of the documentary.

title: Big Leaguer
review1: The boring bush league baseball melodrama tosses softball batting practice pitches, as it tells of a lost era when baseball was the national past-time.

title: The Hunger Games
review1: The film shows precious little hunger and no sense of game.
review2: A refreshingly gritty and adventurous affair that packs plenty of thematic depth, it doesn't let the ambitious source material down.
review3: Has all the technical ingredients of a great (and even important) film, but sideswipes them in order to leave the audience feeling like that they have been abandoned in the wilderness of extreme cruelty.
review4: Though not at all innovative or original, is at least a worthwhile action fantasy.
review5: Director Gary Ross does a great job in bringing the thrilling novel to life in this uncompromising drama.

title: Shuffle
review1: Kuenne's screenplay has some great twists and surprising moments that illuminate its main character, proving that he has the chops to make more than merely genre film, but the ending overdoses on saccharine and overreaches.
review2: I'm willing to overlook a film's flaws a little bit if it's clearly aiming high in what it wants to do. Shuffle is indeed flawed, yet it is also intriguing and different.

title: Freelancers
review1: "Freelancers" is De Niro's second-worst film of 2012 after "Red Lights." God help us; he's got two more to go.
review2: Truth is, [Curtis] Jackson is not a good actor; not in the slightest.
review3: Freelancers is a dull, lifeless cop drama built on cliches, powered by throwaway supporting performances from Forest Whitaker and Robert De Niro.
review4: This is a film with no heroes, no narrative rhythm, and characters with no morals. As a result, it is also a film with no sense of purpose, no authenticity and no life.

title: Bonsái
review1: It flows along placidly, heated only occasionally by a bit of sex or disco dancing.
review2: A melancholy story of romance and regret with moments of drollery and sweetness along the way.
review3: Scenes of breezy intimacy mix well with deadpan comic moments, and Noguera's face is that rare male visage that seems boyishly opaque but over time suggests deep reserves of melancholy.
review4: Bonsai illustrates the unbearable lightness of loneliness in a quiet, delicate manner.
review5: This isn't a story of Shakespearean proportions, but it's a sweet peg for this complex, carefully constructed gem.

title: A Separation
review1: You cannot watch the film without feeling kinship with the characters and admitting their decency as well as their mistakes.
review2: Dynamically shot and paced like a thriller, the film has the density and moral prickliness of a good novel.
review3: As pure entertainment, "A Separation" is flawless. But as social commentary, one could infer a conservative agenda.
review4: Ambiguous endings can work for some films, but it doesn't here. Still, the powerful performances and near seamless screenplay leave little else to be desired. A Separation deserves its Oscar.
review5: A case study in how simplicity can produce spectacular results that extend far beyond a film's budget.

title: Weekend
review1: However, to simply call it 'a gay movie' would commit it a great disservice as the fragmented kaleidoscope of fleeting romantic pains and pleasures should resonate with gay and straight audiences in equal measure.
review2: A romance that finds intimacy in intense conversation but also a very British film about private and public spaces; a potent mix of the sensually intimate and the politically confrontational.
review3: For a movie that bares the souls of its characters so completely, Weekend doesn't unfold like a complicated movie. The dialogue is natural, the sex scenes are tender, and the camera never gets in the way of the story.
review4: Probably one of the greatest films ever made on the subject of gay love, not because it deals with issues of homosexuality, but because it simply tells a tender, honest, emotionally potent love story.
review5: Weekend works beautifully in the moment, and lingers long after an initial viewing. It's certainly an affair to remember.

title: Hide Away (A Year in Mooring)
review1: A tactile, emotion-laden world of beauty, loss, recovery.
review2: In "Hide Away," Josh Lucas plays an alcoholic widower who undergoes a spiritual rebirth by fixing up a sailboat, and I really wish he hadn't.
review3: [It] feels padded even in its brief running time; it's a slight mood piece posing as a character study.
review4: Elliot Davis's pretty greeting-card cinematography, which lingers on birds, clouds and branches as it follows the seasonal changes, is better at evoking the passage of time and the rhythms of nature than all the sodden, pretentious dialogue.
review5: It's basically just Lucas going through a short story-like period of reflection and redemption almost entirely without dialogue. It's not enough, but it is what this underappreciated actor does best.

title: Post Mortem
review1: Unfortunately, the pacing also moves at a zombie shuffle, with shots held past the point of ennui to agony.
review2: Mesmerizing, somehow otherworldly...
review3: Mario's life spirals out of control in unexpected ways.
review4: Post Mortem is - intentionally - not an engaging movie.
review5: Larrain crafts Post Mortem as a slow, quiet character study, narrowing in on Castro in his home and office while the world outside descends into madness.

title: Grown Up Movie Star
review1: Grown Up Movie Star is an awkward mixture of an emotionally intimate coming-of-age story and contrived serio-comic plotting.
review2: It isn't a polished effort, but Maggs delivers a watchable movie thanks to snappy dialogue (also provided by Maggs) and outstanding work from a cast plucked mostly from The Rock.
review3: Grown Up Movie Star is unruly, tortured, crisis-prone, nervy, melodramatic and just charming enough to make you forgive all of the above. It's like a teenager that way.

title: "Captain Carey, U.S.A."
review2: Starring Alan Ladd, Mitchell Leisen's moderately engaging political melodrama, is best known for using Nat King Cole's tune, "Mona Lisa," which won the Best Song oscar.

title: Sedona
review1: Tommy Stovall's film gets bogged down in a morass of clichés, stereotypical characters and over-the-top acting, much of it committed by Frances Fisher, who you'd think might know better.
review2: If like me, you think that things like vortices and Chi are so much flap-doodle, then you have to suspend disbelief or you will miss much of the point of the film
review3: A tiny, low-budget American indie, Sedona is a love letter to this small Arizona town with its jaw-dropping red sandstone formations, a major draw for those seeking mystical transformations.

title: Edwin Boyd (Citizen Gangster)
review1: Inspired by Boyd's story, rather than literally retelling it, the movie is less a gangster film than an existential allegory of choices and limitations.
review2: Morlando has crafted a stylishly shot and evocatively designed period piece. But it's the dashing, quietly charismatic Speedman who proves the main draw, holding our attention even when the movie doesn't.
review3: Morlando has chosen to approach this material not with witty cynicism, but with quiet, and at times leaden, sincerity.
review4: A good-looking but passionless affair that remains stubbornly aloof from its audience.
review5: Citizen Gangster hits its marks when it's exploding the character's larger-than-life status, aided in large part by Speedman's career-best turn.

title: The Crowd Roars
review1: Crosses the finish line as nothing more than routine.

title: King of the Underworld
review1: It's not a very good melodrama, but it was nevertheless enjoyable.

title: Monsieur Lazhar
review1: Although it raises timeless questions about life and loss, and timely ones about mentorship and multiculturalism, "Monsieur Lazhar" would rather teach than preach.
review2: Guaranteed to have you reaching for the Kleenex.
review3: Falardeau had the good fortune to work with a powerfully effective ensemble cast, and Martin Léon's minimalist ambient score helps set the mood for a satisfying story about the healing effect brief encounters can have on emotional scars.
review4: While it may not stand out from similar movies, Monsieur Lazhar is a sweet film with a simple story and remains engaging thanks in large part to Mohamed Fellag's charming performance.
review5: Philippe Falardeau's direction is a model of the notion that less is more, and this film is a treat well worth savoring.

title: The Lucky One
review1: How bad is this Zac attack? Well, let's just say I'm convinced director Scott Hicks opted to render his buff-and-scruffy star the strong, silent type just to keep Efron from opening his mouth.
review2: Falling victim to his source material, Hicks fails to invest it with any sort of edge, rendering the cinematic version as mawkish and saccharine as Sparks' bloated prose.
review3: Even within the company of recent Sparks releases like this year's 'The Vow', 'The Lucky One' comes across as a two-dimensional cartoon masquerading as heartfelt human interaction.
review4: A pretty to look at but emotionally void film that does no favours for its otherwise lovely lead actors.
review5: The movie follows the Sparks formula so precisely, you could write out every detail of the plot just from watching the trailer.

title: The Moth Diaries
review1: Way too serious for its own good.
review2: Roiling with jealousy, suicide and latent lesbian urges, "The Moth Diaries" dances on the border between hallucination and reality without fully committing to either.
review3: Vamps-fans won't find much to gnaw on here.
review4: I'd give this moth-eaten nonsense a miss.
review5: There's a terrific sense of menace in this gothic dramatic thriller, which plays on the story's fantasy elements to take us into a teen girl's troubled imagination. It's beautifully shot too.

title: The Viral Factor
review1: Dante Lam is John Woo via Michael Bay; he doesn't want to win you over, he wants to beat you up and make you crazy. And for all its silliness, "The Viral Factor" does just that.
review2: Gunfights and explosions are audaciously played out in real urban locations swarming with people and vehicles, all unfolding with high tension, without losing sight of continuity.
review3: It takes a special kind of action director to use chaotic, human-filled public spaces for high-energy foot chases, auto stunts and gun battles yet never once get under the skin with a sense of genuine danger.
review4: Tediously overwrought and drably made, with scenes punctuated by synthesized drums out of eighties American TV drama.
review5: "The Viral Factor" wants to be both an action movie and a soap opera. But the merging of the two genres by Dante Lam, a director based in Hong Kong, is clumsy, and so is the film.

title: Nate & Margaret
review1: Blessed with natural performances and brisk pacing, this unusual little movie would like us to know just one thing: Passion is fine, but a pal is priceless.
review2: [A] moving, engagingly low-key curio.
review3: Narrative conflicts are introduced and swatted away in favor of an amiable sentimentality, two nice people being nice to each other.
review4: Director-cowriter Nathan Adloff displays real sensitivity toward the central characters, yet he hasn't crafted a story in which his observations might carry any weight.
review5: Here is a sweet, delicate story about friendship.

title: Changing the Game
review1: Although Riggs turns in a workmanlike performance, the rest of the cast is weak, with rare exceptions.
review2: Dowdell shows promise as a director and if he can reach the next level on his scripts, he'll be an independent director worth keeping an eye on in the future.
review3: Touching on a litany of timely themes, this modern morality play of Shakespearean proportions packs an emotional punch while sending a sobering message about what really matters most.
review4: Changing the Game doesn't have the resources of a Hollywood movie, that's obvious. But it has one thing many Hollywood movies do not have -- an ending.
review5: Suspenseful, intriguing, wise and genuinely heartfelt.

title: Darling Companion
review1: Between the gypsy psychic and the distracting characters, "Darling Companion" loses its way.
review2: [It] has a fine cast, but doesn't seem to have much to say other than lamenting the unfairness of getting old.
review3: It's far from a great movie - an overwritten, underplotted vanity project that's a distant echo of what director Lawrence Kasdan could do in his prime. But it has Diane Keaton, and that's enough.
review4: Possibly the least consequential movie ever made.
review5: a paean to "First World Problems"

title: Cocktail
review1: Despite a predictable plot, director Imtiaz Ali gives this run-of-the-mill love triangle a fresh makeover.

title: A Beginner's Guide To Endings
review1: The end result feels like a feeble homage to a better filmmaker. A Tarantino knockoff is forgivable, but not Tarantino Extra Lite.
review2: The veterans - Keitel and Simmons especially - do what's required. But the other players are trying too hard to sell their roles.
review4: A Beginner's Guide To Endings involves suicide and a whole family doomed to die young. Needless to say, it's a comedy.
review5: An entertainingly light-hearted romp...

title: For the Love of Money
review1: An attempted Scorsese-esque crime epic that too often feels like an underdeveloped outline.
review2: Although it's doubtful that film fans walk around lamenting the dearth of Israeli characters in gangster movies, For the Love of Money nonetheless attempts to fill the gap.
review3: It decelerates into an unremarkable good-guys-vs.-bad-guys tale that ends in a glaringly tension-free showdown.
review4: This dollar-store version of a Scorsese crime saga, "For the Love of Money" is consistently as trite as its title.
review5: A film that can't quite capitalize on the big names it has in relatively small roles.

title: Ballplayer: Pelotero
review1: [The] Directors...try to soften...ugly truths with sentimental stories of teenagers getting signed and pulling their families out of poverty, but the portrait of widespread exploitation overwhelms the intended effect...[ END HERE ]of these subplots
review2: It's an eye-opening look at a flawed, potentially exploitative system and how it is being gamed from all sides of the table -- the story of the collision of youthful dreams and a cutthroat adult cartel.
review3: Hard-hitting sports doc examines the darker side of the recruitment of young baseball players in the Dominican Republic for the major leagues.
review4: What gives Pelotero its edge is a nexus of corruption, exploitation and betrayal that transforms this well-shot, cannily edited item into an engrossing expose.
review5: The next time I see some superstar athlete giving an interview that suggests the absence of a functioning soul, I'll think of the two tense, joyless boys at the center of this quietly devastating documentary.

title: Safe
review1: An action film so cack-handed it borders on parody.
review2: It ain't too smart, it ain't too sophisticated, but it does have its charm and is entertaining enough for what it is: an action-packed, B-movie experience.
review3: Character development and storyline are treated as inconveniences to be tossed aside at the earliest opportunity.
review4: Safe is an exceptional Jason Statham B-movie that managed to sneak through the cracks during its theatrical release.
review5: Perhaps one of these days Statham will stop making the same movie over and over and try something new.

title: Falling Overnight
review1: Seems designed to have a love-will-find-you serendipity about it, but instead comes off as formless and inane.
review2: The film's sweetness is endearing but too featherweight to engage.
review3: A lo-fi romantic drama that isn't awash in self-pity or -aggrandizement, Conrad Jackson's Falling Overnight is something of a rarity.
review4: Rarely has a romantic drama been made with such genuine, pure, unadulterated emotion. Emilia Zoryan delivers a radiant, well-nuanced performance.
review5: Recalls some of the more annoying entries in the mumblecore subgenre that erroneously believe that every indiscriminate moment in a person's life is worthy of a film regardless of subtext.

title: Snow White and the Huntsman (Extended Version)
Titanic
review1: Cameron has devised a tender love story between Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio that serves as the main focus of Titanic's storyline, and it works beautifully.
review2: If computer-generated special effects have overpowered human-generated drama, Cameron seizes that dangerously cold technology and recasts it as dream and delirium, profoundly human in its sources and longings.
review3: The execution is state-of-the-art and breathtaking. Titanic offers the full compass of courage and cowardice, and it stands as an achievement that truly is a night to remember at the movies.
review4: Titanic provides an absorbing blend of historical fact and old-fashioned Hollywood tearjerking.
review5: Titanic is indeed a ship of dreams. Climb aboard and bon voyage.

title: Elles
review1: This Paris-based film from Polish director Malgorzata Szumowska is a fairly unengaging journalism procedural shellacked with a veneer of elliptical, complicated symbolism.
review2: Writer-director Malgorzata Szumowska breaks past the facile moralizing only once.
review3: "Elles" has a surprisingly deep performance in a disappointingly shallow movie.
review4: Binoche is the disappointment. More than half the problem is that the script, co-written by the director, gives her little to do but fret and mope.
review5: One of her (Binoche's) lesser choices.

title: October Baby
review1: "October Baby" looks and feels like a Lifetime movie waiting not to happen.
review2: The odds that this has happened in the real world approach those of being struck by lightning and eaten by a shark at the same time. With a winning lottery ticket tucked in your swimsuit.
review3: [An] earnest, faith-based drama, which lacks sufficient entertainment value to make its message go down more palatably.
review4: Trafficking in 2-D morality and unlikely to be seen by the unconverted, "October Baby" would have been better off as a bumper sticker.
review5: "October Baby" doesn't even meet the standards of decent propaganda. It is, in fact, indecent propaganda.

title: Goats
review1: Nibbles on a lot of stuff it never gets around to digesting.
review2: If I were Holden Caulfield, I might call it lousy.
review3: If Mr. Neil had the tonal mastery of Wes Anderson, "Goats" could have been so much more than an episodic sequence of whimsical little psychodramas.
review4: "Goats" is just b-a-a-a-aad.
review5: [The] solid cast ... can't make the film feel like anything more than a meander through the familiar-feeling angst of a privileged teenager.

title: For Greater Glory
review1: As generic as the title, this historical drama spares no cliche in depicting Mexico's Cristero War of the late 1920.
review2: It's the stuff of real life, and of high drama, but Dean Wright's directorial debut translates little of that latter quality to the screen.
review3: "For Greater Glory" is at times so heavy-handed that the movie itself seems at war. Unfortunately, the enemy is not just a repressive administration, but the audience.
review4: This historical drama about the little-known Cristero War in 1920s Mexico is more educational than involving.
review5: Despite enough good intentions to pave a four-lane highway, the ardently sincere but dramatically unfocused For Greater Glory plays like a multipart miniseries that has been hacked down to feature length.

title: Where Do We Go Now?
review1: This spirited troupe of women ... makes us citizens of the village, invested in their joys and fears. We grieve with them, under that burning sun, and hope with them for a lasting peace.
review2: "Where Do We Go Now?" is more interesting than satisfying.
review3: With elements of a musical, a melodrama and a multicultural romance, "Where Do We Go Now?" is as hard to define as the crossroads region where it's set.
review4: This is energetic, bursting with sincerity, yet also frustrating and disappointing.
review5: A ramshackle curiosity of a film, poorly made and more admirable in intent than execution.

title: Cleanskin
review1: The ambition is laudable even if the execution isn't as smooth or detailed as it might have been.
review2: Plodding, somewhat misbegotten, and never slick enough to sweep us along.
review3: There's a lovely frisson between Bean and Rampling that makes you think what James Bond and M could be.
review4: The film certainly has ambition and there are some memorable fight scenes, but it also lacks the extra oomph that could have done for Bean's action-movie career what Taken did for Liam Neeson's.
review5: It's perhaps one credibility-straining twist too many for the film, which up until then does a solid job of aping slicker, bigger-budgeted Hollywood thrillers.

title: Girl In Progress
review1: It wants audiences to know it's in on the joke though it's not always apparent that there even is a joke in the first place.
review2: Progress acknowledges clichés but has little interest in actually subverting them, instead growing more predictable and sentimental as it goes along.
review3: It never gives us a character we truly care about, or a consistent reason for watching.
review4: Girl in Progress seems like a work in progress.
review5: The direction ... doesn't do justice to the fairly novel concept of a young woman consciously constructing her own coming-of-age scenario.

title: What to Expect When You're Expecting
review1: Diaz's plotline seems to revolve solely around an argument with Morrison over the merits of circumcision. She's pro-cut. He's fanatically anti-cut. Clearly, as is the film's editor.
review2: What to Expect When You're Expecting provides a snapshot of contemporary anxieties about imminent parenthood, but it may be more worthwhile as a document for future pop culture scholars to use to understand what was trendy in 2012.
review3: The charismatic cast (particularly Banks and Lopez) manage to find the humanity in their clichéd roles but they can't transcend all the surface-level schmaltz on display here.
review4: Provides good chuckles and heartfelt drama - paired with an equal amount of familiar gags and flat story ideas.
review5: What To Expect When You're Expecting delivers a stale plot, mostly underwritten characters and almost no joy. Expect little and you may not be entirely disappointed.

title: We Have a Pope
review1: Always the star of his movies, even when he shouldn't be, the atheist Moretti gets caught up in his own papal bull. But Piccoli's blessed empathy prevails.
review2: This is rich material that Moretti mines for both superficial absurdity and deep pathos. But he refuses to forge an orthodox happy ending, let alone a tinny satire.
review3: We Have a Pope takes its shots at the institution of the Catholic Church, but this is by no means a scathing satire. It's more of a character study, insightful and nuanced, about a man grappling with a profound sense of inadequacy, questioning himself.
review4: Though skeptical, the film isn't at all mean-spirited.
review5: "We Have a Pope" is a nuanced, moving and profoundly humane exploration of doubt, faith, weakness and resolve.

title: Snow White and the Huntsman
review1: Theron gives the picture some spine. As Snow White, Kristen Stewart supplies the heart.
review2: This Snow White may not be the fairest of them all, but sometimes, especially during the heat of summer, fair-to-middling does just fine.
review3: Strong effects, good design, and an exciting use of nature help to empower Stewart and Theron, who inject a rich, double dose of feminism.
review4: Like its vain Queen, it's so enamored of its own mirror image that it's hard to see past the style and get lost in the story. But as sheer spectacle, it delivers the goods.
review5: Ostracized teacher fights to clear his name after false child molestation accusation.

title: Kyaa Super Kool Hain Hum
review1: Yardi tries hard to deliver a Bollywood version of the successful Carry On series of films but fails miserably.

title: Bad Karma
review1: As a performance driven film Bad Karma holds an ace in Ray Liotta. Fans of his work will find an interesting and surprising alternate to the usual. It's only a shame he has to travel to Australia to make that so.
review2: A gutsy, edgy and taut thriller, Bad Karma knows its genre chops and uses them effectively for a tense 84 minutes with not a moment wasted
review3: Revenge and redemption are at odds in this well made psychological thriller, where the laid-back lifestyle makes for a resonant contrast to its gangster undertones. Concise storytelling and good direction
review4: Australian revenge thriller is a terrible dud

title: Entrance
review2: A deliberately paced indie offering that bills itself as a psychological thriller but is actually an aimless tone piece about twentysomething emotional dislocation that only in its final reel leaps somewhat clumsily into genre-oriented skirmish.
review3: Proving that small of means does not equate to slight of impact, "Entrance" is a shrewdly distressing knockout.
review4: Almost aggressively slow to begin with, but be patient.

title: The Magic of Belle Isle
review1: If this were real life and not a movie, Mr. Wildhorn would be written off as a crank and ostracized within a week.
review2: It's earnest, predictable and disposable.
review3: You can quarrel with the smiley-face outcome of every ordeal, but the tenderness and optimism are so powerful and ingratiating that only a viewer with the darkest sensibility will go away untouched.
review4: Shamelessly schmaltzy and predictable from first moment to last, Rob Reiner's The Magic of Belle Isle nonetheless manages to conjure a certain spell.
review5: Madsen, a strong actress who might have matched Freeman, is portrayed in varying shades of blandness. Even Freeman, good as his is, is held back here.

title: The Victim
review1: Dreadfully paced, with the shoddy acting of everyone but Biehn magnified to punishing degrees in talky, lengthy, predictable scenes.
review2: Labeling a film grind house doesn't excuse soap-opera emoting and laughable dialogue.
review3: This is the kind of junky, hard-to-watch thriller that apologists claim is part of a long line of tough, grindhouse-style thrillers, but which is actually just amateurish gristle.
review4: It is dreary to envisage the viewer who could become emotionally involved in The Victim ...
review5: Extra helpings of off-kilter and off-key melodrama sink Michael Biehn's bewildering directorial debut, the nasty little down-and-dirty thriller The Victim.

title: Happy
review1: A pleasant if lightweight plea for folks to quit the rat race and stop and smell the roses.
review2: A grab bag of ideas about how to transcend everyday misery, using insights from an international group of scientists, religious and government figures, and regular people.

title: The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel
review1: It's a movie about finding purpose in life, late in life, that makes its point by first subjecting its characters to the most reductive grumpy-old-men/women shenanigans.
review2: A predictable, sugary-sweet confection that thrives on the liver-spotted backs of its sterling silver-haired actors.
review3: its difficult to sit through the final scenes without thinking of what Madden could have cut to earn Marigold Hotel a five-star rating.
review4: Proof that even the young can mistakenly see the aged as elderly. Their bodies may have degraded, but their minds and spirits are no less sharp.
review5: The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel is a true example of an ensemble piece where a group of veteran actors show that they are just as good as they ever were.

title: Hysteria
review1: It's the writing that sinks Hysteria, and there's no machine that can alleviate that.
review2: A lame love triangle, suffragist speechifying and a wee bit of coy tittering regarding ladies' private parts.
review3: When you think of vibrators, 'charming' probably isn't the first word that comes to mind.
review4: Given the allure of learning the origins of something as buzzworthy as the vibrator, Hysteria provides just enough pleasures to give it a pass.
review5: Don't be fooled by the period costumes and British accents, Hysteria is as obvious and pandering as comedies get.

title: Chico & Rita
review1: When a place and its people are this stylish, we can't help but be drawn to them.
review2: "Chico & Rita" is that rare thing, a cartoon for adults, with a bittersweet take on love and fate and a romantic's view of the night.
review3: A pure delight, a keenly affecting, visually ravishing tale.
review4: A buttery rich animated tale of love, jazz, showbiz, fame and politics in the late '40s and early '50s that is as catchy as its tunes.
review5: When a soundtrack this fluidly elegant is married to trite dialogue, thin characterizations, and chockablock animation, it has to go down as a missed opportunity.

title: The Magnificent Ambersons
review1: Even in this truncated form it's amazing and memorable.
review2: Ambersons is not another Citizen Kane, but it is good enough to remove Director Welles for keeps from the novice or one-picture-prodigy class.
review3: Although reams have been written about the mutilation of Orson Welles' second feature, what remains of it is nevertheless a major accomplishment.
review4: While telling this story, haltingly and clumsily, the movie runs from burdensome through heavy and dull to bad. It stutters and stumbles as Welles submerges Tarkington's story in a mess of radio and stage technique.
review5: Orson Welles devotes 9,000 feet of film to a spoiled brat who grows up as a spoiled, spiteful young man. This film hasn't a single moment of contrast; it piles on and on a tale of woe, but without once striking at least a true chord of sentimentality.

title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life)
review1: Italian film has done us another favor-it has sent us Gianni Di Gregorio again.
review2: Italian writer/director/comedian Gianni Di Gregorio plays browbeaten family men brilliantly, and in this film he's given himself a fine showcase.
review3: At times, the sad sights are enough to make a person hope the put-upon guy finds success. The problem is, as affable as Giovanni is, there's not much more to him.
review4: Episodically structured and lethargically paced, the new film attempts to convince us that there's something incredibly charming about an old guy who makes a habit of ogling young women. Actually, the whole scenario is pretty creepy.
review5: Though you can empathize with Gianni's loneliness, the lecherous buffoon is too much of a stock type to feel fresh. At times, the comedy is shamelessly broad.

title: The Girl of the Golden West
The Scarlet Coat
review1: Low key historical spy tale, with lavish color and costumes.
review2: The storyline is highly suspect.

title: These Wilder Years
review1: The film features for the first time, late in their careers, veteran stars James Cagney and Barbara Stanwyck.

title: Free Men
review1: Ferroukhi fails to communicate much of the fear and paranoia of living in an occupied city.
review2: A cannily shot thriller.
review3: The film benefits greatly from Rahim's subtle, effective performance; and it's inevitably heartening to see Jewish and Muslim Algerians identify themselves in national, not ethnic or religious, terms, while fighting a common enemy.
review4: Rahim has the eyes of the young Mandy Patinkin. If only he had some of the wildness.
review5: Free Men offers a pleasing historical escape via a story of everyone setting aside religious, colonial, and ethnic divides to unite against the Nazis.

title: Drunkboat
review1: "Drunkboat" might have come off via nothing more than acting ability and a good heart, if the dialogue didn't amount mostly to aimless chit-chat.
review2: The burnished smear of Lisa Rinzler's photography is a plus, but "Drunkboat" is ultimately the kind of pet project that never traverses from personal to powerful.
review3: Though studied and grating at times, "Drunkboat" does sustain a distinct, odd tone. Like its characters it's dreamily restless and prey to its own quixotic ideas.
review4: This enigmatic coming-of-age movie often seems destined to sail off the deep end. Yet it rights itself just often enough to keep you watching.
review5: [An] incoherent drama.

title: The Deposition
review1: What's strange for me is that my biggest criticism could actually be considered a compliment: the film looks too good...

title: The Letter
review1: The Letter is not a thriller. It is barely a film. It's a boring, self-important, disjointed and pointless pile of tripe masquerading as a movie.

title: The Tempest
review1: The film-making is rough and ready - Tempest looks like a student film and often sounds like a promotional video for Ovalhouse - but the cast is sympathetic and it's a pleasure to see them making the play their own.
review2: The kids energise it, but it's a choppy jumble of good intentions and half-realised ideas, too wind-tossed in its structure to function even as a useful teaching aid.
review3: Largely incoherent in its hyperactive attempt to cut edge.
review4: An absorbingly raw and insightful docudrama, which brings together 17 young actors to present a 21st century retelling of a heartbreakingly relevant Shakespearean classic ...
review5: Choppy cuts muddy the narrative, but the faith in grassroots art's motivational value resonates clearly.

title: 388 Arletta Avenue
review1: 388 Arletta Avenue manages to use the terrorized-couple genre to provide a timely commentary on supposedly safe homes and distant wars.
review2: The visuals in Randall Cole's paranoia chiller 388 Arletta Avenue evoke Michael Haneke's Caché and Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window in the way they make domesticity seem terrifying.
review3: There's little new: the intimidation techniques (pet abduction, home invasion) feel clichéd and the film trundles towards an unenlightening conclusion.
review4: ...remarkably compelling...
review5: A particularly egregious offender in a shaky-camera era that is the cinematic equivalent of a multi-year plague of locusts.

title: La délicatesse (Delicacy)
review1: Although there's some meat on the menu, "Delicacy" ends up as lightly sugared and as gently bent as a fortune cookie.
review2: It never hits the target, but its sincerity is surely preferable to the machine-tooled slickness of Hollywood models.
review3: Foenkinos brothers' balance of light comedy and moody desperation is conveyed with a breezy cinematic style
review4: Audrey Tautou stars in a light but charming French tale of 'Beauty and the Bumbling'.
review5: A satisfying, feather-light serving of romantic whimsy.

title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love)
review1: "Goodbye First Love" is fascinating.
review2: Hansen-Løve films with an eye toward discovering and rediscovering these characters in pure moments of simple, poignant humanity - wading in a river, clambering over rocks.
review3: "Goodbye First Love" is a very lifelike film in the sense that life does not often imitate entertainment.
review4: "Goodbye First Love" is like a postcard from a lost Eden, a painfully pure oasis where we're not allowed to linger.
review5: Writer-director, Mia Hansen-Løve, whose third feature this is, has addressed her subject with complete emotional confidence.

title: The Big Shakedown
review1: A so-so crime drama about nasty racketeers in the pharmacy industry.

title: The Corn Is Green
review4: Irving Rapper's screen version of Emlyn Williams semi-autobiographical play is well acted by Bette Davis as the spinster-teacher, but is too theatrical, sentimental and conventional.

title: Doubletime
review1: As entertaining as it is exhilarating.

title: "Peace, Love, & Misunderstanding"
review1: Beresford directs without purpose or polish, and his mostly fine cast, which includes Kyle MacLachlan and Rosanna Arquette in bit parts, is wasted.
review2: Pop songs, beautiful bucolic scenery and the joy of watching Jane Fonda fizz in a fun role that looks like a no-brainer are elements that a skilled director like Australia's polished Bruce Beresford blends with perfection.
review3: There's a great movie to be made about the survivors of Woodstock Nation and their children. But in order to make that movie, you first have to respect the ideals of that generation enough to at least give them their due.
review4: There is no casting decision or character nuance or plot turn too obvious to indulge.
review5: What's so funny about "Peace, Love & Misunderstanding"? Not enough.

title: Grassroots
review1: An enjoyable, fitfully engaging but ever-so-slightly forgettable minor-key political comedy.
review2: Grassroots is a movie where bad ideas, because they're the ones championed by the "correct" side, are king. It never acknowledges that sometimes idealism is just another kind of manipulation.
review3: At first glance, "Grassroots" doesn't seem like much of an idea for a movie. Nor at second, third or fourth glance.
review4: Although it only glosses the mechanics of local politics, it exudes an endearingly scruffy charm.
review5: This is one film as misguided as the business-as-usual subject it aims to critique.

title: People Like Us
review1: This all could have been resolved with a single conversation.
review2: these kind of movies push the buttons so hard and so shamelessly that they become annoying
review3: Alex Kurtzman taps his family tree for enough sap to start a treacle factory.
review4: ( ... ) the cinematography offers domestic drama pleasures in its own right. Thank you for caring, Salvatore Totino (Cinderella Man / Any Given Sunday).
review5: There's an intriguing true story buried inside this overly structured drama, and by playing by simplistic screenwriting rules the filmmakers make everything trite and predictable.

title: Red Dog
review1: It's not quite as blatant a tearjerker as some of its pooch-based predecessors, and frankly, it's all the better for it.
review2: Emotional dog tale features drinking, violence, and loss.
review3: It's guaranteed to bring tears and laughter to popular audiences, and those who turn up their muzzles at it are on a canine to nothing.
review4: Even hardened blokes will struggle not to choke back a few tears at the end.
review5: Pretty sappy stuff, but the film-makers use knowing humour to snare more cynical viewers and are well-served by the cast.

title: Red Lights
review1: A clever thriller, bolstered by three great performances.
review2: The film doesn't offer the sense of release, or of surprise, that it seems to take for granted.
review3: "The X-Files" is long gone. Hail and farewell. But its spirit lives on in "Red Lights." Hail, hail.
review4: By strict definition, any movie featuring Robert De Niro as a spoon-bending clairvoyant superstar ought to hold a few cards up its sleeve.
review5: A lot of talent comes up empty in "Red Lights," a thriller that doesn't thrill.

title: Funkytown
review1: There's a lot of ground to cover in this ensemble piece, and the threads are uneven -- not just in terms of depth, but quality.
review2: Some tales are more successfully told than others, but they can't elevate a cumbersome and distracted script from Steve Galluccio.
review3: There are too many characters to care about and too many storylines to follow, but the high energy will carry you along and the performances are strong.

title: The Lady
review1: The Lady is a slog, a two-and-a-half hour, painted-on-wood exercise in political iconography.
review2: "The Lady" is a two-hour trip into earnestness, from which audiences will want a little liberation of their own.
review3: The Lady is little more than a history lesson - although a beautifully presented one - wrapped in the pink gloss of a G-rated potboiler evidenced in Suu Kyi's and Michael's storybook romance.
review4: A heavy-handed attempt to sanctify one of the most dignified and uncompromising politicians and human rights champions of recent times.
review5: [It] does indeed deal with a real life, but follows so faithfully the traditional shape of film biography that it feels less convincing.

title: Sound of My Voice
review1: As a thriller, 'Sound of My Voice' tails off and its budget shows. But for Marling it's an impressive calling card.
review2: Acted with a subtle nuances throughout, this film's ambiguous ending will elicit much discussion, while the film's delicately handled politics are refreshingly two-sided.
review3: Sound of My Voice is a too-rare example of intelligent, ambitious genre filmmaking.
review4: Sound of My Voice is an eerie film that is completely supported by the performances. It's deliberately vague, which can sometimes be annoying but works fine in this setting.
review5: It does look like it was made for a buck and a quarter and is sufficiently ambiguous to be taken as profound.

title: Dark Shadows
review1: The only reason to see Dark Shadows is to discover how dire and pointless-how flat-out dreadful-a movie can be even when it has Tim Burton, Johnny Depp, Michelle Pfeiffer, and Helena Bonham Carter attached to its flimsy pretext.
review2: Not just a bad film; it's evidence of people who are barely even trying.
review3: Johnny Depp once again takes a role where he allows the make up and prosthetics to do the acting for him...
review4: The nadir of Burton's career and is likely going to be his biggest flop, a film that's not a comedy, not a drama, not a horror film, and not a fantasy.
review5: There's more than enough here for us older folks - and some younger ones, too - to have us exclaiming, Fangs for the memories.

title: What Color Is Love? (Playing for Keeps)
Rock of Ages
review1: ...the two hours watching such a tepid and lip-synched effort is not a pleasant experience.
review2: I know that in the history of cinema there have probably been worse movies. I'm just having a hard time thinking of one right now.
review3: Oscar-worthy costume design by Rita Ryack ... enliven the proceedings that are constantly mired by Tom Cruise's unattractive vanity mugging, off-putting gay jokes and questionable taste in choreography.
review4: Rock of Ages will make you want to raise your arms...and then immediately plunge your fingers into your eyeballs for salvation (you can go back for seconds to rescue your ears).
review5: Feelin' the noise ain't the same as feeling something for the characters, most of whom fail to amp it up in the soul department.

title: Prometheus
review1: Prometheus is scary only in the sum of instincts and talent for movie-making that have been lost.
review2: The best-looking stupid movie I've seen all year. It's sumptuously photographed, and often inane.
review3: Many walked into this movie expecting a science fiction thriller in the vein of Ridley Scott's original Alien. This, I feel, was a colossal mistake.
review4: It is easily the most cerebral endeavor of its kind since "Minority Report."
review5: Any lack in originality is handsomely compensated by the plethora of 3D visual treats courtesy of a crackerjack technical crew that creates an eerie interplanetary moonscape that's as epic as it is requisitely foreboding.

title: Bedeviled (Kim-bok-nam Sal-in-sa-eui Jeon-mal)
review1: Not your typical "maniacal female" horror film.
review2: It is this contrast between the two women that energises Bedevilled, a character-driven slowburner that builds ever so deliberately to its murderous climax.

title: Restless City
review1: "Restless City" is tumescent with atmosphere.
review2: "Restless City" possesses a poetic, contemplative sensibility as attuned to the vagrant beauty of polyglot urban life as to its chaotic unpredictability.
review3: Mr. Dosunmu seems to have directed all his actors to pause before delivering lines, giving a languor to the film that comes to feel studied.
review4: In its portrait of a "Restless City" the film is strangely inert and feels like the work of image-makers, not storytellers.
review5: Told in an elliptical style with a pacing and jagged rhythms that take some getting used to, the thrust and power of the film lies in its poetic imagery...

title: Lili
review5: A vehicle for MGM's new star Leslie Caron to shine.

title: A Princess For Christmas
review1: Family-friendly fairy tale romance is lighthearted fun.

title: Chernobyl Diaries
review1: Once the annoying, two-dimensional characters start getting bumped off one by one, it's just a relief that the actors have stopped improvising their own banal dialogue.
review2: For all its familiar ideas, characters, and scares, Chernobyl Diaries earns points on restraint, mood, and location.
review3: A cool concept is compromised when this film descends into predictable territory.
review4: After one effective scene involving a radiated Russian bear, the quality of first-time director Bradley Parker's narrative starts melting down like a TEPCO facility.
review5: There's nothing but many empty scares and zero resolution...

title: Dragon Eyes
review1: Maintaining an admirably straight face, this fist-flying flashback is good fun for fanboy types who take its myriad absurdities with the requisite grain of salt.
review2: Where Regeneration showcased a filmmaker ready to pound some life into dreary formula, the ugly and bafflingly dull Dragon Eyes revels in cliché, slowly falling asleep despite some gratuitously violent content.

title: Transit
review1: It's no Cape Fear, but it gets the job done with a certain bloody efficiency.
review2: A ridiculous movie, abandoning logic immediately upon commencement, yet its dedication to pace and intensity is charming and frequently effective.
review3: Director Antonio Negret apparently strove to ensure that his film looks cheap, but that would be forgivable if Michael Gilvary's script wasn't so desperately stupid when it isn't psychologically risible.
review4: Not particularly original but efficient.
review5: Its increasingly preposterous narrative and hysterically over-violent action makes it something of a guilty pleasure.

title: Last Summer of La Boyita (El ultimo verano de la Boyita)
Red Dust
review5: Gable, Harlow and a Rain Barrel. You don't need anything else.

title: Last Ride
review1: The Australian outback, the setting for most of Last Ride, an extraordinary film for which the locale is a quiet, almost secret catalyst.
review2: The title more or less gives away the film's design, but the predestined journey is taut and tragic nevertheless.
review3: Both Weaving and the movie itself do manage to show that this violent, hopelessly damaged man yearns to be a father, but will never know how.
review4: Mr. Ivin doesn't have a strong narrative line to play with or become distracted by, but he takes off on some lovely detours, whether he's narrowing in on Chook or going wide to take in the world that waits beyond.
review5: Weaving, best known for The Matrix and the Lord of the Rings trilogies, brings subtlety and poignance to the hoodlum's mercurial character.

title: Up Tight!
review1: There's no backsliding, toward a conciliatory moderate conclusion. The passions and beliefs of black militants are presented head-on, with little in the way of comfort for white liberals.
review2: It doesn't transfer well when changed from Irish revolutionists to black revolutionists.
review3: Intelligently directed tale of urban revolt starring some of the finest black actors of the 60s.

title: The Secret Six
review1: The first pairing of Gable and Harlow is the highlight of this so-so film.
