review2: Rising star Clark Gable impressed the MGM studio bosses so much in this gangster pic, they gave him a long-term contract.

title: "Small, Beautifully Moving Parts"
review1: Lazy storytelling expects a pass as indie authenticity.
review2: There's a big difference between commenting on the zeitgeist and simply acknowledging it, as this featherweight independent comedy demonstrates.
review3: This is a small film and knows exactly how to be a small film. Like many New Yorker short stories, its purpose is to strike a particular note and allow it to reverberate.
review4: Even at a lean 73 minutes, this flimsy road movie feels at least 43 minutes too long.
review5: Small, Beautifully Moving Parts isn't always completely elegant about getting its point across, but its imperfections are only human - a quality, as Sarah eventually realizes, that can have its own appeal.

title: Sleepless Night
review1: The plot is clever yet breathtakingly simple, the action is relentless but logical, and the lead role is tailor-made for Hollywood's A-list action stars.
review2: The story is loaded with implausibilities, but it moves so quickly you won't have long to dwell on them, and there are a number of neatly executed reversals.
review3: It's fast, lean, satisfying, and forgettable; nothing special, really, until you realize that the movies have largely lost the knack for brisk mayhem like this.
review4: The sort of stripped-down, Francophone picture that's been spoiling American action fans over the last few years. There are no Cuisinarted fight scenes, no pauses for awkward romantic subplots.
review5: Charging from one beating to another, wrenching diminishing returns from drunken camera angles and cat-and-mouse games, Mr. Jardin makes Vincent's predicament as hollow as a sustained scream.

title: Cargo
review1: What could have been a typically didactic message film instead resonates with thoughtful humanity.
review2: The film leans almost exclusively on the focused performances of its two leads, who create a credibly barbed chemistry that goes a long way toward distracting us from the film's low-budget deficiencies.
review3: With the certainty of bad melodrama, Cargo moves gradually into superficial moral complexity, an inevitable display of heroics, and the perfunctory title card ensuring us that sex slavery is indeed a real-life problem.
review4: Suspenseful and captivating albeit not as unflinchingly horrifying as it could have been.
review5: An intense drama about human trafficking and the yearning for freedom.

title: Take This Waltz
review1: Take This Waltz is a Remarkable, Offbeat Love Story
review2: It's such a strange little movie but beautifully acted and undeniably fascinating.
review3: Sexually charged, frank, and relatable, Take This Waltz is a bittersweet observation of adult romance.
review4: [A] sunny dramedy that lulls its viewers with pseudo quirks, but which actually hides an altogether terrifying dead heart that clubs viewers over the head with its nauseating examination of an insufferable, unhappy woman.
review5: While hardly a complete failure, 'Waltz' nevertheless finds Polley dancing to the beat of a simmering romantic triangle with two left feet.

title: Crooked Arrows
review1: An entirely predictable script that chugs along to the foregone loser-beats-odds conclusion.
review2: In another era, "Crooked Arrows" might have been an after-school special, perfect to have on the TV while cleaning the house; miss a scene while you're dusting under the couch, and you'll still know exactly what's happening later.
review3: "Crooked Arrows" gets points for its glimpses of Native American culture and history - the film's backers include the Onondaga Nation - but too many of these scenes are disappointingly static.
review4: "Crooked Arrows" might involve two lesser-seen screen subjects - Native Americans and lacrosse - but it still can't break free of the usual underdog sports picture tropes.
review5: Routh ... does a killer Tom Cruise-in-"Jerry Maguire" homage in this swift little sports dramedy.

title: Magic Mike
review1: Once you get past the thongs, the uniforms, and the sleek choreographed stripping dance routines -- admittedly, the main attraction of Magic Mike for most audiences -- it's just another day at the office for Steven Soderbergh
review2: The sexy mischief and the darkness and the earnest character beats all fit together in one terrifically entertaining, perfectly pitched success.
review3: Raucous, funny and disgracefully entertaining.
review4: Musings on the nature of capitalism wrapped in a very pretty package ... Magic Mike is a film for adventurous audiences of all persuasions.
review5: Some wildly entertaining dancing (and stripping) underscores several impressive performances.

title: "Fanny, Annie & Danny"
review1: "Fanny, Annie & Danny" may be an unpleasant story about unpleasant characters, but the acting is fabulous.
review2: The more difficult characters here (all female) and resulting character dynamics are so consistently shrill that the pic feels a bit too one-dimensional and cruel to leave the small-tragedy aftertaste it could have.
review3: Mostly the movie just gets off on how awful and/or pathetic its characters are, calling on the viewer to judge or pity rather than sympathize with its gallery of grotesques.
review5: Fanny, Annie & Danny will make anybody with a family, the more dysfunctional the better, cringe and grin.

title: Ruby Sparks
review1: Sometimes it's worth surrendering to cinematic enchantments, and Ruby Sparks makes a pretty good case for its own magic.
review2: Sure it's been done before -- man brings ideal woman to life -- but not quite like Ruby Sparks. And that sets this film up to be a smart and romantic low-key comedy that goes beyond expectations.
review3: If the result feels like a Pinocchio story that spends too much time with Geppetto, or a takedown of narcissism that never breaks free of what it's critiquing, Dano nonetheless makes Calvin compelling company.
review4: Kazan winds up indulging in the very wish-fulfillment she initially sets out to deconstruct.
review5: Ruby Sparks flirts with preciousness and has less fun with its premise than it could have, but that's because it's actually a gently touching metaphorical drama about the real essence of love.

title: Polisse
review1: [O]ne of the best based-on-facts police pictures.
review2: Whatever you think of it, you won't be neutral.
review3: Bluntly edited, with no hand-holding transitional scenes, the film is an intimate portrait of an idealistic, understaffed, sometimes wrongheaded team battling youth prostitution, thievery rings and adult predators from every class of society.
review4: "Polisse" draws us uncomfortably close to a taboo subject then rewards us with real nourishment.
review5: It has the makings for a pretty good cop show. But as a movie, this 'inside' look at the dozen or so dedicated members of the Parisian Child Protection Unit is conspicuously lacking in coherence and depth.

title: Elena
review1: Sturdy performances, fine photography from Mikhail Krichman, good use of music by Philip Glass and a pleasingly terse script make for incisive, gripping drama.
review2: In different hands, "Elena" might have been a noir thriller, but this serving of cinematic borscht is as cold as a Russian winter.
review3: "Elena" is a riveting psychological suspense film.
review4: A chilly noir about the beaten paths and icy ruts of Russian life in the capital, post-Communism. In a land of schemers, Elena suggests, the urban cloisters of Moscow's elite are as self-sealing as the lowly masses' stifling Soviet-era flats.
review5: The kind of family drama that gives family dramas a good name.

title: Americano
review1: While Hayek isn't bad, Lola is a stock character, and very little that transpires after her arrival recovers the interest so beautifully constructed in the beginning.
review2: It is wistful and nostalgic, and at the same time full of restless curiosity.
review3: The film's appeal has less to do with plot than mood. Demy balances his father's romanticism and his mother's naturalism, taking cues from both.
review4: Scenes of the director as a school-age boy in a Varda film are haunting, but end up simply sparking a desire to see Varda's work. It may take time for the son to catch his own wave.
review5: Demy leans heavily on a cinematic legacy that also seems to hold him back.

title: First Position
review1: Undeniably effective as drama, as we ponder the varying degrees of ambition and talent driving these young people to push their bodies beyond the limit in the hope of grasping a future in the spotlight.
review2: It does a great job developing its characters through its visuals - these are superphysical kids - and honing in on family dynamics.
review3: If you have a yearning to feel awkward, inadequate and lazy, watching the whirling teenage (and preteen) talents in director Bess Kargman's First Position will do the trick.
review4: The joy of watching lies in the purity of the dancer's passion.
review5: A superior example of the genre, it concentrates on six young dancers from around the world ...

title: The Miners' Hymns
review1: Morrison sketches a portrait of a vanished way of life for one Northeast England community, along with an explanation of sorts for why it disappeared.
review2: A look at ill-fated mining communities in northern England.
review3: An elegant, elegiac found-footage work from Bill Morrison, best known for his silent-film reverie "Decasia."
review4: There are some mesmerizing images of the soot-covered miners at work and of children at play on a coal-strewn seashore.
review5: It speaks eloquently about the disappearance of most any indigenous working-class culture.

title: House of Dark Shadows
review1: Even in these troubled times, the vampire has it worse than most of us.
review2: The film is well mounted and stylishly produced. In what must've seemed like a luxury, Jonathan Frid had time to learn ALL his lines.
review3: It has the unique distinction of being the only motion picture ever based on a daytime soap opera.
review4: Genuine chills and surprises. Blows away the TV show.

title: Night of Dark Shadows
review1: A modest exploitation supernatural tale, that seems better suited to be soap opera day TV fare than a feature movie.

title: That Hagen Girl
review1: The most painful part of this very painful picture is the contrast it insists on between Miss Temple and the rest of the cast.
review2: They shouldn't do such things to Shirley. It's downright un-American!
review3: This is an oddity not only for the casting of future politicos Reagan and Temple in the same film, but due to its rotten script and nearly incomprehensible resolution.
review4: You can literally hear this drama creaking.

title: The Cup
review1: A tale of heart-wrenching tragedy and uplifting triumph that never quite hits its stride.
review2: Although it canters down a well-trod path toward a predictable finish line, The Cup sustains interest through the smooth efficiency of its storytelling and the engaging performances of its lead players.
review3: It's a very decorous picture in which a sense of conflict is largely lacking.
review4: Even the most ardent lover of feel-good biopics would have a hard time backing this horse.
review5: True sports tale about overcoming tragedy has mature themes.

title: Sinbad the Sailor
review4: Colorful, sprightly actioner with Fairbanks at his best.
review5: It's a lush but humorless adventure tale about the mythical mariner and storyteller.

title: Fire With Fire
review1: Josh Duhamel fails to set the screen ablaze as a California firefighter who becomes an unlikely vigilante avenger in this very routine action thriller, but he gets no help from a damp squib of a script.
review2: If action B-movies are your thing then this is just about worth searching out.
review3: The result is breathtakingly dumb with absolutely zero redeeming features.
review4: Although it's probably the biggest movie yet to emerge from rapper 50 Cent's production outfit, this damp squib still has "straight to DVD" stamped all over it.
review5: It looks like a dozen others of its kind and hasn't a smidgeon of distinction about it anywhere, except that Willis has given up his various wigs and thus looks more like his true grizzled self.

title: What She Wants For Christmas
review1: Silly holiday flick has some adult relationship talk.

title: Chilly Christmas
review1: Forgettable Christmas fare will amuse kids with potty humor.

title: The Day He Arrives
review1: The listless execution may remind you less of 8 1/2 than of Woody Allen's whiny Stardust Memories.
review2: Sang-soo Hong has no profound point to pound home. His story doesn't need an ending. He accepts all the characters just as they are.
review3: Hong abstracts the tense network of fragile relationships to crisp, briskly sketched lines that he adorns with bubbly and self-deprecating humor and graceful wonders...
review4: Hong offers a strange mixture of magic, mystery, rueful melodrama and dry comedy that's like absolutely nothing else.
review5: The movie becomes an exploration, both playful and rueful, of desire, narrative and the idea beautifully expressed by Faulkner in "Absalom, Absalom!" that "maybe nothing ever happens once and is finished."

title: I Wish
review1: Every performance works, every character fits, every observation rings true.
review2: What's so remarkable about the happiness the film brings is its simplicity.
review3: Like a train, "I Wish" is slow to build momentum, then it carries us away in a wondrous rush.
review4: Unique, leisurely subtitled film about parental separation.
review5: All life in its haphazard glory is here, but it's the children's friendship that holds you tight - and as the two trains crossed on the cinema screen, I wished more films about childhood were as good as this.

title: Corpo Celeste
review1: For those willing to overlook its few slips into heavy-handedness, "Corpo Celeste" tells a compelling story of a 12-year-old girl thrust into a strange new world.
review2: "Corpo Celeste" often stumbles, along with its 12-year-old heroine, Marta (Yle Vianello).
review3: Alice Rohrwacher's debut fictional feature is an uncommonly insightful portrait of nascent womanhood, assisted in no small measure by Vianello's disarmingly naturalistic performance.
review4: Corpo Celeste would be a treat in any season, but it's particularly refreshing amid the summer-movie bombast.
review5: Vianello gives a lovely, unforced performance as Marta, who begins to see that the blue-eyed, open-armed fuzzy Jesus she's being sold is a fake.

title: Trishna
review1: Trishna engages the potent collisions of the rural and the urban, the poor and the rich, and considers how these interactions unfold in a romance and how they might also destroy it.
review2: While the film never delves deep enough into its characters' emotions to be truly spellbinding, it's well worth seeing.
review3: Winterbottom has complete control of the film's look and feel, but the story seems to run away from him.
review4: A rare unsatisfying swerve from an otherwise reliably provocative career.
review5: "Trishna" works largely on the strength of Winterbottom's clever updates of a century-old story.

review1: The film's generic, meaningless title is a sign of the dullness to come.
review2: 360 is a classic example of how you can't always judge a movie by its credits.
review3: Though the cinematography looks sleek, with shots through windows and in mirrors, split screens and city lights that blur and sharpen, the stories equate to a tangled mess.
review4: Much like its own characters, it dithers too much - and it dares too little.
review5: If the film had not been afraid to go a little darker, dig a little deeper and develop its characters beyond their stereotypes, it would have been a much stronger effort.

title: Your Sister's Sister
review1: It's comforting to watching dramatic and comic fiction regarding the things some of us actually have to deal with in life. When done right, those kinds of films are worth your time. YOUR SISTER'S SISTER happens to be one of them.
review2: Movies that start well and end badly occur often enough, and yet even knowing that is no preparation for what happens to Your Sister's Sister.
review3: Even when the story line tries to wrench the characters in a certain direction, they keep returning to something real and honest. I want these people to be my friends.
review4: Don't be surprised if you find yourself nodding off mid-movie, bored silly by a trio of good actors stuck in a dull scenario about a young man caught in a highly implausible kerfuffle involving two sisters and a leaky condom.
review5: It's not rollicking summertime fare, and it won't offer easy answers. But it's an entertaining failure -- just like its characters.

title: [REC] 3 Genesis
review1: "Zombieland" and possibly "Shaun of the Dead" aside, this isn't a genre with a lot of life in it.
review2: Plaza throws in more than enough ludicrous touches of his own to grab viewers by their arteries and never let go.
review3: With slapstick smothering the scares, "[REC 3]" is further marred by a plot in which the muted Catholicism of its antecedents is turned up to full blast.
review4: Like vampires, this genre is getting deadly.
review5: It's hard to maintain dread while the filmmakers are so obviously grinning at their own cleverness.

title: Changing Hearts
review1: Family drama has positive messages but heavy themes.

title: The Spanish Main
review4: It hardly seems the work of Frank Borzage.
review5: A conventional pirate story that's given a colorful treatment under Frank Borzage's helmsmanship.

title: A Burning Hot Summer
review1: While I have to acknowledge Garrel's skill, the film, which actually has its compelling moments, falls somewhat flat.
review2: Garrel's work is indebted to silent cinema style, but his recent films have shown a real flair for dialogue too.
review3: "A Burning Hot Summer" failed to persuade me of any reason for its existence.
review4: There are spirited moments, notably Angèle's torrid dance with another man at a party. But the film's observations are surprisingly retrograde, even absurd.
review5: Here and elsewhere you linger in moments that, like memories and dreams, can feel severed from storybook time.

title: Of Two Minds
review1: The intimacy and confessional nature of these stories are the documentary's strength, but the stories feel like only a part of a larger puzzle.
review2: "Of Two Minds" does give a vivid picture of what life is like for these folks, though it has a tendency to take unnecessary detours to other interviewees and to reveal a little too much about the intimate lives of the three key subjects.
review3: Show(s) what it's like to live day to day with moods that swing to the highest highs and the lowest lows
review4: Swollen with feeling -- an enormously empathetic documentary that highlights the diversity and range of experience within the diagnosis of bipolar disorder.

title: Comes A Bright Day
review1: Aboud has a strong visual sense - the framing is precise, the colours rich - but with a threadbare, episodic plot, thin characters and uninspired dialogue, this soon outstays its welcome.
review2: Ultimately, Comes a Bright Day offers insufficient excitement and - like its incompetent robbers - once it battens down those hatches the film has nowhere to go.
review3: [An] ambitious but flawed heist-cum-love story.
review4: Roberts turns in an interesting performance, but the film is treacly and contrived.
review5: Props to director Simon Aboud for trying something a little different, even if things didn't quite come together.

title: 2 Days in New York
review1: The laughs come fast and breezy, just as Delpy intends.
review2: While it's nowhere near a perfect film, 2 Days in New York is worth seeing, not only for the comedy but also for the realism of the smaller moments.
review3: [Delpy] and Rock, in the midst of free-flying French chaos, find a sweet chemistry together ...
review4: Nobody will mistake this for a great comedy, but I enjoyed the madcap looseness and consistently high spirits.
review5: There are a lot of laugh-out-loud scenes, but few hold together well enough to make for a smooth-flowing narrative equal to '2 Days in Paris.'

title: Highway
review1: Picturesque flourishes and jumpy editing can't disguise this film's soapy heart.
review2: The inter-weaving, multi-character arcs and naturalistic, overlapping dialogue...instantly invokes the works of celebrated auteurs Robert Altman and John Sayles.

title: We Can't Go Home Again
review1: It's the kind of would-be groundbreaker that continues to stir interest long after its failure as a theatrical release.
review2: [A] great, nearly lost work of reflexive modernist fury...
review3: Has a raw power that resonates long after viewing.
review4: It often comprises multiple film images projected beside or on top of each other, in a free-associative scrapbook goulash.

title: Savages
review1: The film would have been so much more interesting if the two men had been identical twins played by the same actor-like Jeremy Irons in David Cronenberg's Dead Ringers.
review2: Visually dazzling, if a bit bluntly simplistic and over-written. In other words, it's an Oliver Stone movie.
review3: A richly entertaining adaptation of Winslow's novel.
review4: A well-told tale of power, corruption and uncivilized people who use violence and murder to achieve success.
review5: An unabashedly lurid sun-and-surf ménage-à-trois cum drug-running caper, with touches of Jacobean tragedy for good measure.

title: Screwed
review1: Reg Traviss's overlong thriller spews out clichés from the off.
review3: Everything is too extreme. But there's a core of honesty here.
review4: Screwed may be based on the true-life experiences of former prison guard Ronnie Thompson but it seems to serve up every available cliché from the handbook of tough nut British prison dramas.
review5: Watchable collection of prison movie clichés, enlivened by strong performances and pacey direction.

title: I'm Not Jesus Mommy
review1: Juares is nothing if not ambitious, and he assembles the pieces of the puzzle with clarity (he also edited and photographed the film). But he bites off more than he can chew...

title: Natural Selection
review1: In the evolutionary spectrum of cinema, "Natural Selection" is like the duck-billed platypus, pretending to be warm-blooded but more than a little fowl.
review2: [Harris is] the one good thing in "Natural Selection."
review3: However gritty this indie comedy may look (cinematographer Steve Calitri seems to be aping William Eggleston's photographs of the American south), it isn't all that different from an Adam Sandler vehicle.
review4: [Harris is] the big reason that "Natural Selection" is so engaging.
review5: In Harris' hands, Linda is guileless but believable, her smile so worn and wary that it almost hurts to see it.

title: Dark Horse
review1: It would be unfair and patronizing to say that Solondz needs to grow up, but "Dark Horse" suggests that it's time for the bard of bourgeois hypocrisy to consider moving on.
review2: Solondz has made a career out of specializing in highly aberrant views of middle-class life.
review3: That Gelber can make Abe appealing in any way is a triumph. That Solondz can orchestrate such a feat is an even bigger one.
review4: Solondz will never be much for happy endings, but the film is strangely optimistic and at times borders ever-so-slightly on the whimsical.
review5: With champion bloodlines from Walken and Farrow, "Dark Horse" could have been a contender, but it gets so skittish about trodding a familiar path that it pulls up lame.

title: English Vinglish
review1: The image of the newly confident Shashi striding down a Manhattan street, a takeout coffee in hand and a trench coat belted over her sari, will make you smile days after you leave the theater.
review2: A winsome if utterly conventional ugly-duckling story about a sympathetic character's much deserved progress toward a richer self.
review3: An undemanding picture that goes down as well as the heroine's tasty ladoos.

title: The Lost Realities of Hog Caller
Barfi!
review1: Quirky deaf man gets entangled in love triangle in poignant Bollywood romantic comedy.
review2: Hopping nimbly among three distinct timeframes, helmer Basu deconstructs the film's sentimental thrust to stress his hero's in-the-moment ingenuity.
review3: Despite a hard-working cast, a lush score, exotic location shooting and scattered warmth, "Barfi!" is ultimately more endurance test than entertainment.
review4: Against your will, you may even shed a tear.
review5: It is with some reluctance that we leave the beautiful world of Barfi!, but we do so with the knowledge that the Kapoor family legacy is safe in the hands of Ranbir, who can already lay claim to the title of the finest actor of his generation.

title: Lord Byron
review1: Against all reason, Byron's televangelist-led quest for clarity compels us to follow, the film's melting, naturalistic images softening the occasional scream of dialogue repeated beyond all necessity.
review2: Vacillating between free-associative shtick and complete inertia, Lord Byron is lost in thought and allergic to reason.
review3: This microbudgeted character study of a good-natured, religiously curious and plus-sized South Louisiana gentleman with 'a thing for women' is one of the more distinctive features to emerge from the so-called 'mumblecore' movement.
review4: There is something interesting about the tension between fact and fiction, but there's also something frustrating too.
review5: Lord Byron manages to turn nonsensical gibberish into a captivating soundtrack for the equally fragmented stories of the strangers living in the same home.

title: The Last Soul On A Summer Night
Lawless
review1: It's slight and casual to the point of laziness, but it's straight fun, done with knowledge and a laconic pleasure. You could do far worse.
review2: Tom Hardy must just hate being audible.
review3: Hillcoat makes a foray into Virginia's Prohibition-era moonshine country. But the adaptation (by Hillcoat compadre Nick Cave) is a hokey piece of pop history that wearyingly insists upon its own mythos like a comic-book blockbuster.
review4: This fact-based drama succeeds because of its great cast and its strong story of loyalty and brotherhood.
review5: The movie is smart and focused on what it's trying to be.

title: The Day
review1: The film feels unbelievably long at 84 minutes, and the color-drained, hand-held cinematography serves only as a reminder of just how good "Night of the Living Dead" really was.
review2: A savage B-movie thriller with unrealized aspirations to profundity ...
review3: Every day is gloomy in "The Day," Douglas Aarniokoski's film with a creepy, paranoid atmosphere that's more effective than the performances.
review4: Towards the end, you might find yourself thinking, "Well, this could have been worse." And you'll mean it as a compliment.
review5: "The Day" is just good enough to engage audiences, but it falls well short of remarkable, leaving viewers wishing for a dawn that never breaks.

title: Burning Man
review1: Foodies looking for a good cry, bon appétit.
review2: Burning Man leans heavily on a scrambled chronology, and likewise feels tonally mixed up, but it certainly does keep you guessing.
review3: The extremity of the film's slice-and-dice approach is invigorating at the outset but may also prompt viewers to suspect they're being challenged for no good reason.
review4: It does reward the dedicated with a searing portrait of a man struggling with perspective, hunting for a way to bring himself back from the edge and prove himself to a world waiting for him. There's genuine beauty beneath the bustle.
review5: Teplitzky replaces meaningful silences and emotive strings with frenetic energy and alternate scene takes...

title: Step Up Revolution
review1: It's equal parts 'Flashdance,' 'Burlesque' and 'Lambada', all parts ludicrous - but we aren't here for the story any more than we watch Béla Tarr for the salsa numbers.
review2: The ubiquitous product placements tend to undercut the anti-corporate speechifying.
review3: The dancing is the one thing - and I mean the ONE THING - that the film has going for it, and it's not showcased as well as it should be.
review4: The story is sappy and predictable... But the dancing has a freshness and vibrancy that's infectiously enjoyable.
review5: Many of the old tropes and gimmicks from the previous films are recycled into an all-too-familiar plotline: An edgy, streetwise guy falls for a classy, upper-crust sweetie, and together they dance their way past obstacle after obstacle.

title: The Sea Gull
review1: Gets the spirit of Chekhov's play.

title: My Forbidden Past
review4: That this stodgy nonsense production is mildly entertaining is mildly surprising.

title: Sparkle
review1: Sparkle shamelessly piles on the clichés, but it's an entertaining ride throughout.
review2: Noteworthy only for featuring Whitney Houston's last screen appearance.
review3: This is the second most embarrassing thing to happen to Whitney Houston this year.
review4: Wallowing in melodrama, the film's sole highlight is Whitney Houston's supporting turn in it.
review5: Whitney Houston's vibrant, final performance adds poignancy to this likeable, breezy remake of a familiar tale.

title: The Dark Knight Rises
review1: [This] wrap-up wraps up few of the threads in the first two films, and that the climactic cliff-hangers are nothing special (as well as flabbily edited).
review2: By the thrilling... Nolan satiates his taste for the big action set piece, but all is grounded in an intricately woven world of fierce loyalty and even more fierce enmity.
review3: You should consider the overall brilliance of Nolan's series of "Dark Knight" films and wonder whether the next filmmaker willing to take on the caped crusader's story is batty.
review4: Lacking a central figure as dazzling as Heath Ledger's Joker, The Dark Knight Rises is not as strong as its predecessor, but it's still a doozy. Um, a violent, grim, nightmarish doozy.
review5: My issues with it are few and didn't detract from my love for this film, which I believe you're going to love, too.

title: The Unguarded Hour
review1: A suspenseful English drawing room mystery.

title: Beasts of the Southern Wild
review1: What is also extraordinary is that almost all the people we see are actors. So this is not a documentary but a moving enactment by people who are themselves moved.
review2: Beasts of the Southern Wild is sheer poetry on screen: an explosion of joy in the midst of startling squalor and one of the most visceral, original films to come along in a while.
review3: In a time when the cynicism of the real world often mandates the tone of our films, here is one that acknowledges it all with unwavering joy.
review4: It plays like Days of Heaven by way of The Road Warrior.
review5: As Wink, Hushpuppy's father, Dwight Henry is one of the greatest finds in Hollywood in years. Henry shows a depth and range that made actors like Denzel Washington so great.

title: Alps
review1: The reality it takes place in is heightened just enough to make the concept feel ironic, but then all attempt at genuine sentiment subsequently falls flat.
review2: An hour and a half of darkening absurdism.
review3: The film takes some deciphering, but once a viewer cracks its code "Alps" opens up into something expansive and rich.
review4: The movie contains some of the same elements that made [Dogtooth] so startling but they tend to float around rather than coalesce into a singular perspective.
review5: A film peculiar beyond all understanding, based on a premise that begs belief.

title: Silent Night
review1: Apart from some modestly inventive carnage and an undeniably humorous hambone turn by Malcolm McDowell, there's really nothing here to make genre fans dash through the snow (or maneuver through traffic) to megaplexes.
review2: Fans of nearly nude women being fed into wood chippers will not go home disappointed (except, very likely, in their hollow lives.)
review3: The movie's intended audience will likely be satisfied by its parade of gory mayhem, cheap thrills and groan-worthy dark humor. Everyone else: You're on your own.
review4: This brisk reimagining of the 1984 slasher "Silent Night, Deadly Night" delivers the seasonal goods with admirable efficiency and not a little wit.
review5: This unimaginative remake of Silent Night, Deadly Night continues the trend of mediocre remakes of '80s era horror films.

title: Last Ounce of Courage
review1: This religious-themed drama about a small-town mayor's personal crusade against "the war on Christmas" is about as subtle as the character's name -- Bob Revere.
review2: The sheer volume of what I like to call "eyebrow acting" -- in which thespian intensity is directly proportional to the angle and depth of one's forehead furrows -- is staggering.
review3: The patriot-packaged "Last Ounce of Courage" has been made with the conviction of true zealots, but also the competence of amateurs.
review4: The problem with this numbskull travesty isn't that it's fatuous and smug (which it is). It's that it's slack and dull.
review5: Bookended by a pair of Ronald Reagan quotes, "Last Ounce of Courage" is pure preaching-to-the-choir poppycock.

title: Beloved
review1: Characters traipse around city streets singing 60s-style pop tunes in this ungainly, overconceived musical.
review2: Honoré's a genuinely gifted eccentric of a filmmaker, but on the evidence of "Beloved," he could use a nap.
review3: The plot of "Beloved," I'm afraid, may try your patience.
review4: Somehow manages to feel sprawling and epic, while at the same time presenting an intimately observed view of two women's love lives.
review5: Skips around the decades, taking a minimalist approach to history - mostly by demonstrating how recent traumatic events have inconvenienced the love lives of its central characters.

title: Why Stop Now?
review1: First-time directors Phil Dorling and Ron Nyswaner can't find a coherent emotional tone, and the actors' energetic contortions can't keep the sinking story afloat.
review2: Drug abuse stories are to Hollywood what babies are to mothers: fascinating to the talkers, not so interesting for their audiences.
review3: Feels trapped in the limbo between comedy and drama where many indies gamely venture, but from which few emerge with any resonance.
review4: As "Why Stop Now?" gathers momentum, the increasingly uneasy sensation it produces is not unlike that of being in the back seat of a speeding car whose drunken driver refuses to give up the wheel.
review5: Why Stop Now refuses to keep faith with its characters, to carry them as far as they can go without tying them up in a neat bow of redemption.

title: Christmas Angel
review1: Faith-based tale is well done but has heavy themes.

title: Hitler
review1: Wants us to think of Hitler as a victim of his own sexual repression.

title: Dreams of a Life
review1: Somewhere at the bottom of this story is an ache about the value of a life.
review2: Its holes or omissions cannot diminish the gaping eloquence of the situation and the questions that arise.
review3: For all its subtext about identity and London's social fabric, "Dreams of a Life" leaves too many blanks and is ultimately more frustrating than rewarding.
review4: A riveting tale of a onetime vivacious personality, described by those who knew her as "stunning," "lovely," and "very well liked," but who nevertheless died alone, friendless and seemingly missed by nobody.
review5: Director Morley has at least restored something of a soul to her subject.

title: Gayby
review1: What lifts Gayby above its sitcom trappings is its emotional generosity and easy warmth, the sense that characters are defined by -- and made funny through -- their aspirations, not their way with a one-liner.
review2: Harris, a talented comic actress who looks more like a real person than a Hollywood facsimile of one, makes every scene she's in shine.
review3: "Gayby" is too diffuse to have much pop when it comes to the topics at hand: love and friendship, and how unconventional modern permutations might help rewrite the script of romance.
review4: [It] embraces broad jokes and obvious setups. Fortunately, these are balanced out by assertive pacing and entertaining observations.
review5: The film develops into a sweet, surprisingly persuasive comedy about friends transitioning into family.

title: Gandu
review1: It is hard not to be excited by this fiercely idiosyncratic approach to protest filmmaking and Gandu gleefully tramples all expectations of Indian culture.
review2: a vibrant provocation, aimed at showing a side of Bengali life that has never been seen, while all at once mimicking and mocking the punkish rebel spirit of its cause-less protagonist, lost in his own 'complete head fuck'.

title: Battle for Brooklyn
review1: Although not exactly even-handed, the movie proves a deft look at a reluctant crusader and how financial sway and political override can so effectively trump the power of the average citizen.
review2: Hawley and Galinsky, a longtime wife-and-husband documentary team, bring real suspense to the story, culled from many hundreds of hours of footage.
review3: A battle ordinarily requires two sides, yet this earnest, ungracefully reconstructed saga posits that opposition to the building of the New Jersey Nets' future home took place in a virtual vacuum, and that the fix was in from the start.
review4: Spins a compelling tale about the value of individual and collective resistance, even as it makes clear where power in our society really resides.
review5: Brings us inside the lives it touches.

title: Backwards
review1: Passably pleasant but thoroughly predictable.
review2: A movie whose main virtue was its honesty ultimately lands in a place that feels canned and unsatisfying. But on the way there, Backwards isn't so bad.
review3: The biggest problem ... is the characters who populate the film. For the most part, they're one-dimensional caricatures.
review4: The neatness of the plotting becomes almost comical after a while. Construction is one thing; contrivance is another.
review5: Although this modest indie may not make a huge splash, it just might inspire some hearty younger viewers - especially women - to grab a set of oars and find their bliss.

title: The Island
review2: The biggest flaw is that the pirates aren't particularly frightening or imposing, instead coming off as Peter Pan's Lost Boys all grown up -- to riff from Kentucky Fried Movie, they aren't tough and ruthless so much as they're rough and toothless.
review3: Another one of Caine's big bombs!!
review4: ragtag modern-day pirates live in a primitive island society, eschewing most forms of modern technology . . .They're kind of like Amish . . . only they're pirates

title: The Good Doctor
review1: Wants to be a twisty nail-biter, but never creates much suspense or surprise.
review2: Orlando Bloom gives one of his most interesting performances; It's a creepy, effectively chilling piece of work.
review3: Its meaning is unclear. Its vital signs are shaky. And before long, the whole frail thing's on life support, just begging for somebody to pull the plug.
review4: Targeting age-old English class consciousness, not contemporary American healthcare woes, the movie is a shrewd commentary on careerism and status.
review5: Whether you take it as a comment on our rote acceptance of authority figures or just a deliciously creepy character study, you'll come away from "The Good Doctor" wanting to keep religiously eating that apple a day.

title: Liberal Arts
review1: Poetic justice Is served in insightful LIBERAL ARTS
review2: For a film about aging and romanticism, "Liberal Arts" feels like it needs a more mature script.
review3: Liberal Arts is a resolutely vanilla-flavored concoction but still pleasant, amiable, and a little more thoughtful than your average rom-com.
review4: An exuberant, heartfelt concoction, the kind of sunny comedy that's good for the soul.
review5: Some of the insights are a bit simplistic but for most of the running time, the film is an enjoyable diversion.

title: Bro'
review1: We're not sure whether to laugh at, pity, or cheer for these people.
review2: Sends its college-age protagonist, Johnny (Will Chavez), tumbling into seductive illegality with the efficiency of those Direct TV commercials that paint exaggerated worst-case scenarios for cable customers.

title: 10 Years
review1: 10 Years is no Big Chill, but it has just enough warmth to keep it alive.
review2: A bracingly un-gimmicky, heartfelt and fresh take on the theme of growing up.
review3: Even the most exhausted, hackneyed and innately annoying genre can yield a film of breezy charm and prickly dramatic consequence.
review4: An inconsequential high-school-reunion comedy that gets better when it stops trying to make you laugh.
review5: It's easy to see how Linden attracted such a star-studded young cast. Most every character has his or her own moment, and many of them deliver lines that stick with you.

title: Sleepwalk With Me
review1: This self-deprecating comedy would make both Larry David and Louis C.K. proud,
review2: From start to finish, his character, called Matt Pandamiglio, is all by his lonesome -- reaching out of the fog. He's a funny fog person.
review3: The film acts as both a diary of a sidewinding comic stylist finding his style, almost by accident, and a reminder to all post-collegiate boyfriends and girlfriends that "OK" probably isn't good enough for either party.
review4: This is a great radio bit. Problem is that somebody decided this was a movie, and it is certainly not.
review5: Rarely these days do you come across a comedy so wholly warm-hearted.

title: Brother (Hermano)
review1: "Hermano" is well-trod acreage, but there's a vitality here that's easy to appreciate.
review2: The sports-as-savior theme is an old one, but this confident movie, alternately volatile and tender, coats its clichés in winningly natural performances and Enrique Aular's kinetic photography.
review3: The over-the-top opening, which evokes baby Moses in the bulrushes, indicates grand ambitions, but unfortunately the gritty realism of Rasquin's cinematic style is just camouflage for another cliched sports flick.
review4: Rasquin's cinema verite style brings power to the story, and he has coaxed some good performances out of his leads.
review5: Scoring goals in soccer is hard. Hermano earns its points too easily.

title: Trouble with the Curve
review1: For all its occasional tin ear, Dr Phil dialogue, its contrivances and shortcuts, this remains a fundamentally sound and solid entertainment with a deep-rooted conviction that how we treat each other matters.
review2: Doesn't just remind you what a great screen presence Clint Eastwood is; it makes you appreciate him even more as a director because Lorenz does such a terrible job.
review3: Long stretches of Trouble With the Curve make you wish you had other ways to occupy yourself.
review4: The good news is that Eastwood does his thing to perfection, Adams provides the spunky cuteness, and Timberlake couldn't scrub his eager charm off with a Brillo pad if he tried.
review5: Eastwood manages to maintain his decorum throughout, like some veteran pitcher who's lost the speed off his fastball and relies on a sneaky change-up. He does just a few things, but he does them remarkably well.

title: Arbitrage
review1: Aside from Gere's performance, there's really not much to see here.
review2: As we follow the increasingly frantic Gere down his nightmarish rabbit hole, the picture takes a satisfyingly cold, amoral stance - less critique and more cynical observation.
review3: Like something straight out of 1992, Nicholas Jarecki's debut feature Arbitrage ... is a small scale, high-gloss thriller that feels like Wall Street's cousin.
review4: A Wall Street-thriller blending elements of Chappaquiddick with a pinch of John Edwards and a whole lot of Bernie Madoff.
review5: Richard Gere is terrific and the supporting cast do superb jobs in this fascinating exploration of greed, justice and the law.

title: Red Hook Summer
review1: For the most part it's all rather pleasant, if somewhat aimless.
review2: Lee's typically paradoxical statements on race and religion muddle the narrative, and his old stylistic tricks -- saturated color schemes, characters addressing the camera -- aren't exactly inspired.
review3: The story is static for about 90 minutes, then rises to action, but in a way that seems impromptu, either made up on the spot or ill-considered.
review4: When Spike Lee fails he fails big, and he goes down in flames with "Red Hook Summer."
review5: Lee's latest film feels like several intriguing ideas in search of an over-arching story.

title: Premium Rush
review1: Just a few spokes short of a wheel, guys.
review2: An unpretentious throwback to the kind of action movie that had no need of superheroes, Premium Rush is hardly a classic but fun up to a point.
review3: Premium Rush is that rare bird: a chase picture that's just a chase picture - and a dandy one.
review4: It's a tight little thriller, briskly told. And I'm already having a hard time remembering anything else about It.
review5: Satisfying on a basic, fun level, but also stylishly produced and not insulting to the viewer's intelligence.

title: The Words
review1: This tedious and needlessly convoluted drama ... just meanders aimlessly.
review2: A movie about a bad author who steals the book of a good author, and I'm pretty certain that The Words, if pressed, wouldn't be able to tell the difference.
review3: It's nothing you haven't seen before in films about struggling artists spending more time obsessing than working.
review4: Its long, dry patches of colourless storytelling suggest it makes more sense as a book, one to read before you fall asleep to dream of better movies.
review5: In a relevant study of plagiarism, influences and lifetime experiences, The Words chiefly reminds us that the past is indelible.

title: The Well-Digger's Daughter
review1: "The Well-Digger's Daughter" isn't a mind-blower; it's not supposed to be. It's a light lunch with an old friend whom it's good to see again.
review2: Auteuil's direction is a lot like his acting -- well-mannered and likable, yet staid and ultimately inconsequential.
review3: To call "The Well Digger's Daughter" an old-fashioned film is to pay it a compliment. Here is a love story embedded in traditional values.
review4: "The Well-Digger's Daughter" is perhaps a bit too sentimental. But the performances are so heartfelt that its occasional excesses are easily forgiven.
review5: It's classical moviemaking of a sort rarely seen now, a love story of surprising joy with rounded, flawed but humane characters.

title: In The Name Of The King: Two Worlds
review1: A dumb film, but mildly entertaining if your standards are low enough to rent something called In the Name of the King 2: Two Worlds in the first place.
review2: What's not to love about a movie that features time-traveling ninjas, a CGI dragon and a scene where Dolph Lundgren literally asks the king what his name is. Genius!
review3: After starring in The Expendables, was Dolph Lundgren really strapped enough for cash to star in this?

title: Little Birds
review1: Though the plotting is problematic and at times as lost as the kids, there are bursts of brilliance and moments of aching vulnerability in "Little Birds" that make you wonder what the filmmaker might do next.
review2: The dreamy shots of a poisoned sea in "Little Birds" show an imagination sorely missing from its drab plot and characters.
review3: Despair may be an emotion of emptiness, of the absence of hope, but that doesn't mean a movie about someone spiraling down into that emotion has to feel so empty as well.
review4: There's a moralistic structure there, but it leaves Lily in a place that's scarcely more reassuring than the one she first abandoned. That's what makes Little Birds not just a lesson but, in its rambling way, an organic journey.
review5: Like its teenage heroine, "Little Birds" is stubbornly convinced of its own unique profundity. So it's a good thing this moodily self-absorbed drama redeems itself with just enough endearing innocence.

title: The Thompsons
review1: involves a clash not just of family values, but also of broad trans-Atlantic stereotypes, where the Hamiltons, far from their birthplace and out of their league, discover there is a reason their parents turned their back on the 'old country'.

title: Roadracers
review1: A slick, fast-paced greaser picture that shows off the incredible talent of director Robert Rodriguez.
review2: Rodriguez said that he cast Arquette for the "good sleaze factor." Arquette's constant sneer throughout the film proves that Rodriguez was absolutely right.
review3: A trifle, but a fun and engaging one at that.

title: Cosmopolis
review1: The rapid dialogue is dry and mannered, like a David Mamet play, there's virtually no story and Cronenberg's visual scheme is cold and claustrophobic.
review2: Quickly grows repetitive and tiresome, meandering toward messages that land softly, producing little impact.
review3: Cronenberg is not a director to be daunted by a scenario in which the antihero spends most of his time in a stretch limo. Turning it into a film that interests anyone ... is another matter
review4: Cronenberg's cold, exacting precision and emotionally removed observation may not grab all viewers, but under those perfect surfaces is a raw horror trying to claw out of the denial.
review5: "Cosmopolis" is a hypnotic examination of our modern anxieties about the dehumanization brought on by wealth, power, and technology.

title: That's What She Said
review1: It's all directed - and played - at fever pitch with an egregious disregard for real-world comportment.
review2: Problems ensue, all tedious, save Bebe's all-day struggle with a yeast infection, which is gross.
review3: "That's What She Said," an unpleasant comedy about friendship, aims to be a female twist on the bromance.
review4: The road to hell is paved not just with good intentions, but with movies that attempt to capture the way women really talk.
review5: If you see just one repellent femme-owned-and-operated comedy about unpleasant women and a stubborn case of vaginal yeast infection, you might as well make it That's What She Said, since I hope there'll never be another like it.

title: Jack and Diane
review1: "The Man With the Iron Fists" being a fairly satisfying slab of cinematic mayhem, particularly if seen in under conditions like the ones I describe from my younger days.
review2: Devoid of energy and direction, 'J&D' settles for faux-naif posturing and arty color design.
review3: Tonally, the film swings between whispery romance and ominous horror as it explores the dark side of love and lust ...
review4: Throughout, the filmmaking is tentative, as though Gray is unsure whether he wants to make a fantasy-tinged romance or a hyper-sexualized blood-fest. (He winds up with neither.)
review5: "Jack & Diane" offers a glaring example of a writer and director, Bradley Rust Gray, unable to trust in the simple strength of his material.

title: Murder Is My Beat
review2: Most of its expressionist-tinged visual flourishes are withheld until the very end, with a final twist that's legitimately thrilling.
review3: Edgar G. Ulmer was Poverty Row's poet laureate of despair.
review4: "Murder is my Beat" is not one of your better films of the film noir genre. But, this black & white thriller directed by Edgar G. Ulmer has enough going for it to permit a recommendation.
review5: Visually superb cross between the whodunit and the film noir crime thriller.

title: "After Fall, Winter"
review1: A mixed-up movie about mixed-up people.
review2: The lovebirds' dialogue has the sophistication of a junior high school romance, and Mr. Schaeffer appears to have pasted his story together from the button-pushing plotlines of other films.
review3: Like his unlucky-in-love characters, prolific filmmaker Eric Schaeffer keeps trying, to little avail.
review4: Just another faux-kinky vanity project in which its creator's neuroses are placed on an undeserved pedestal.
review5: Another sanctimonious dose of talk-therapy cinema.

title: Game Change
review1: Try as the filmmakers might, it just isn't the same. How could it be, really?
review2: Actress Moore makes one actually feel sorry for Sarah Palin at points in this wonderful film.
review3: The dramatic re-creations are somewhat uneven: The convention staging is quite convincing, the campaign trail less so.
review4: The constant use of actual news footage adds a bit of verisimilitude but also constantly raises the question of why this lightly fictionalized version of the election actually needs to exist.
review5: Game Change, which explores how smart people make dumb decisions, is a movie for all of us.

title: Compliance
review1: Dark, disturbing, confrontational stuff. Also a damn good film.
review2: Compliance is diminutively sufficient and blandly adequate with no additional layers that elevate its small independent nature. It feels rather one note riding on the promise of a distinctive tale that never totally comes to fulfillment.
review3: A frightening look at the power of authority and the human desire to avoid conflict.
review4: It never loses sight of its goal to persuade us to be more aware, more questioning of our leaders and institutions, from politicians to priests to, in this case, the police.
review5: The only film of 2012 that had me actively booing its villain - a mundane monster who doesn't need to touch his victims to scar them for life.

title: Now Is Good
review1: Hellbent on inspiring a rush of wind-beneath-my-wings, life-affirming feeling.
review2: [Spikes] the Nicholas Sparks-style teen Love Story plot with refreshing flashes of sex, drugs and Ellie Goulding songs.
review3: Stunning tearjerker about teen cancer has mature themes.
review4: Surprisingly harsh when it comes to the dented appeal of its lead character, the movie is a predictable drag, attempting to cozy up to its young adult literary origins in a decidedly tuneless fashion.
review5: There's nothing like a terminal illness for firing up a sappy romantic drama.

title: "Guns, Girls and Gambling"
review1: A movie first and foremost about other movies, a derivative of derivatives, "Guns, Girls and Gambling" is like a losing hand at cards: It could have been a winner, but just isn't.
review2: Nothing witty about this blood-soaked action flick. But for fans of the genre, it might be a decent time-passer, providing you don't mind "stupid." Most of the jokes miss the target.
review3: For a movie in which you hope to see plenty of girls and guns, you really only get the guns... of the metal kind, that is.

title: The Wise Kids
review1: Chicago indie Stephen Cone took a quantum leap forward with this moving 2011 drama about a Christian youth group in small-town South Carolina.
review2: "The Wise Kids" is a guileless exploration of the growing pains of sheltered innocents whose reticence and sincerity evoke 1950s small-town values.
review3: [Flaws are] ultimately overshadowed by Cone's excellent young actors, particularly Torem, burrowing deeply into her character's zealotry and anguish about being left behind.
review4: Cone's feature is among the best of a recent spate of dramas observing American Christian life.
review5: Honest, observant, and subtle.

title: Touchback
review1: Earnestness and obviousness compete for supremacy early on in Don Handfield's film, with the latter fully in front; happily, earnestness stages a comeback by the end.
review2: A lightweight and overlong feel-good drama that plays like a mashup of It's a Wonderful Life and Friday Night Lights.
review3: Are any of them alone reason enough to sit through two hours of warmed-over life lessons? Not particularly, but it should be said that the cast and crew have made a fair stride towards redeeming earnest low-budget filmmaking of this ilk...
review4: If George Bailey had been a high school football hero, It's a Wonderful Life might have been a little like Touchback.
review5: Touchback takes a handoff from Peggy Sue Got Married and It's A Wonderful Life and runs it up the middle for a modest gain.

title: Scene of the Crime
review4: "Scene of the Crime" is full of familiar faces from the movies of decades past. It's not all that exciting. But, it's worth a look, if for no other reason, than to see Gloria DeHaven's smoky performance.
review5: One of the few film noirs attempted by MGM.

title: Jab Tak Hai Jaan
review1: Almost miraculously, the disparate elements add up to an improbably entertaining hybrid.
review2: A sumptuous if rather soulless love story.
review3: Romance king Yash Chopra delivers a swoon-worthy Bollywood love story.
review4: "Jab Tak Hai Jaan" serves as a fitting tribute to the career of Chopra.
review5: Even though the film drags, the magic of Bollywood is that this story's muddle of twists only clarifies the urgency behind the undying desires of all concerned parties.

title: 17 Girls
review1: 17 Girls is allegedly inspired by true events, but this diffident, dreamy film is so insubstantial it's hard to believe there's a speck of reality to be found in it.
review2: The film suggests a state of grace between childhood and adulthood, but the narrative feels increasingly tentative, and the characters remain opaque - "local divas," in one teacher's estimation.
review3: The question is why this incident seemed worth dramatizing, especially in such a dreamily romanti-cized way - with perfect pregnancies and friendly baby daddies.
review4: The movie takes you inside the dreamy collective mentality of bored, mildly rebellious girls who look with horror at the lives of their mostly working-class parents.
review5: The movie needs a tighter grip, yet the narrative detours, including a beach party and one especially liberating confrontation, can be surprisingly joyous.

title: About Cherry
review1: Dramas about the porn industry range from expressions of puritanical rage to celebrations of open sexuality; this one manages to avoid both extremes, as well as anything else that might make it worth watching.
review2: Here is a movie that suggests prostitution is something that just sort of happens to you, like Lyme disease.
review3: This is just a slow-moving skin flick broken up by lots of boring discussions about Cherry's future.
review4: The fatal flaw ... is its refusal to examine Angelina's occupation from outside the bubble. You might even call it a recruitment film.
review5: Everything here is done badly.

title: Branded
review1: There's almost a Seussian vibe in this heap, but no hint that it's intentional.
review2: To borrow a hamburger chain's refrain, not lovin' it.
review3: This fantastical fable takes aim at marketing itself with an intriguing if tendentious narrative.
review4: Branded" is a confusing sci-fi thriller that takes itself much too seriously.
review5: Satire usually implies at least a little bit of humor, and Branded is mostly humorless -- if it was ever actually trying to be funny, then it fails. If a satire should be pointed, then this movie is more on the dull side.

title: "Farewell, My Queen"
review1: Jacquot has chosen wisely in casting Léa Seydoux in the key role of Sidonie, whose luminous but watchful eyes suggest a soul wise beyond her years.
review2: "Farewell, My Queen" is a layer cake of royal pleasures, rote protocols and revolutionary politics. For skeptics who thought this story had grown stale, let them eat their words.
review3: Farewell, My Queen is a knife-edge drama that steadily builds tension that at times becomes as unbearably tense as the relationship between the three leading ladies.
review4: Sidonie is a character who literally eavesdrops on history, becoming the audience's first-person yet second-hand source for such significant events as the storming of the Bastille...
review5: His portrait loses some of its eerie power through the ugly twist at the film's conclusion, but she remains a fascinating enigma, and touchingly human.

title: 5 Broken Cameras
review1: This is how the conflict looks from the other side of the barrier.
review2: A tough watch that'll leave you despairing of peace anytime soon.
review3: As raw as the material of "5 Broken Cameras" can be, it is also lyrical and elegiac.
review4: [A] bit jagged, inevitably incomplete, and in no way news-breaking: it is simply moving.
review5: Takes the rough material of one man's life and transforms it into a story that is universal and urgent, offering firsthand witness to events that are too often portrayed as distant and impossible to understand.

title: Won't Back Down
review1: Funded by conservative Christian billionaire Phil Anschutz and released by rightwing overlord Rupert Murdoch, it attempts to fashion a feel-good family-friendly triumph of union busting and privatization.
review2: While the story is predictable, it compensates for that with great acting and a noble purpose.
review3: A do-gooder movie so stupid and unoriginal it had to steal its title from a Tom Petty song.
review4: 'Dumbing down' a film about educational reform defeats any point; while proficiently made, Won't Back Down's glib feel-good message deserves to fall on deaf ears.
review5: As terrible as it sounds.

title: Wake in Fright
review1: Wake in Fright is essential viewing for anyone interested in the roots of male violence.
review2: A Conradian parable of a man succumbing to the wild, the film is remarkable for its raw, pointed dithe suggests, and you'll find the beast concealed behind the mask of propriety.
review3: This movie gets under your skin.
review4: Wake in Fright is an absolute must-see for fans of cult, off-kilter cinema.
review5: Blends staged re-enactments with documentary footage of senseless slaughter to extremely distressing effect.

title: Wild River
review1: Both sections of the flavorful, vernacular-filled screen play have been given professional treatment.
review2: This 1960 drama is probably Elia Kazan's finest and deepest film, a meditation on how the past both inhibits and enriches the present.
review3: In studying a slice of national socio-economic progress in terms of people, it catches something timeless and essential in the human spirit and shapes it in the American image.
review4: One of [Kazan's] least theatrical and most affecting films.
review5: Kazan's films are better known for showcasing stratospheric Method-emoting over visual expressiveness, which makes Wild River's gorgeous imagery a shock...

title: Hansel & Gretel
review1: Dee Wallace is the only reason to watch what is another ho hum modernizing of a classic fairy tale...

title: Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai
review1: Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai reveals yet another facet of this always-unpredictable filmmaker: a flair for compassionate, humane melodrama.
review2: A quiet, narratively layered period drama with a focus squarely on character.
review3: Miike can't seem to get enough of Hanshiro's heroics. That's not just visual excess, though.
review4: A 3-D epic that, despite its title, is more of a soap opera than a swordplay thriller.
review5: It's an indelible picture of a cold-hearted ruling class that has allowed self-interest and hypocrisy to override its own humanity.

title: Officer Down
review1: Really just an overstuffed story that comes off not as layered but rather as an unfocused jumble.
review2: these former A-listers deserve a better film to ply their trade in than this sloppy thriller-by-numbers
review3: It doesn't quite achieve its plan for a psychological breakdown, but the effort is appreciated, even in a feature as messy as this one.

title: End of Watch
review1: Ayer and his cast appear to have so convincingly nailed the way these characters talk and act that you might not even notice the film slipping from workaday grit into out-and-out myth.
review2: The actors, both excellent, get right into Ayer's groove. So by the time we arrive at the unsparing climax, we really know and care about these guys.
review3: Gyllenhaal and Pena are after a lived-in camaraderie and a street-level realism. Pena, especially, succeeds; you buy him every second.
review4: The performances here are so sharp that viewers may wish End of Watch has been shot by someone who knew how to find the right point of view for a scene and leave it there.
review5: I'm still wondering who we're supposed to assume was holding the camera during Gyllenhaal and Anna Kendrick's sex scene.

title: Nature Calls
review1: A low-watt, low-wit comedy.
review2: It almost seems like harder work somehow to get this many comedians together and then turn out a movie that is only so fitfully funny.
review3: Its jokes won't appeal to anyone older than 8, but a parent who takes a child to this crass mess would be subject to prosecution.
review4: After a lot of wandering around, we realize we've really just been walking in circles the whole time.
review5: The humor in Nature Calls tends toward the dopey and obvious ...

title: Nobody Walks
review1: This dreary independent drama is essentially an art-world soap opera, but without the melodramatic verve that makes some soap operas interesting.
review2: What we have here is a household ripe with seduction, lust, betrayal and repression, all kept below the surface by increasingly strained good manners.
review3: ...a self-important nightmare ... shallow script and boring situations. Perhaps that is the simplest way to sum up the film, boring. Offensively boring.
review4: The direction is decent, and the film is handsome. But it's finally frustrating, enigmatic in a way that suggests emptiness more than mystery.
review5: [A] lackluster indie drama ...

title: The Paperboy
review1: There's something undeniably compelling about the cast's daringly go-for-broke performances... but Daniels fragments the narrative and throws in so many tricksy directorial touches that the whole thing becomes an annoyingly indulgent mess.
review2: The sweaty, lurid, self-serious nonsense is hard to take seriously, but I'll say this much for the film: it ain't boring.
review3: I'll just get it out of the way now: The Paperboy is unbelievably awful.
review4: If you're bothered by frequent utterances of the "N-word" and the sight of Kidman spreading her talent - and her gams - wider than Sharon Stone in 'Basic Instinct,' you're gonna wanna look away from this sick, sizzling display.
review5: While there's much here about family loyalty and a 'don't mess with the swamp' aspect, Daniels' film has nevertheless been most discussed for its sex stuff, with every character having some sleazy secret or a scene devoted to their raunchy pleasure.

title: Citadel
review1: Despite its defiantly un-PC 'fear-a-hoodie' message, the film nails its urban setting, filling every frame with a richly sustained sense of despair, decay and dread.
review2: This is a basic story, simply and directly told by Irish writer-director Ciaran Foy.
review3: It's all rather nausea-inducing and a bit frightening - not the film (I can only wish) but its subtextual message.
review4: "Citadel" attempts to transform mundane anxieties into the stuff of a horror film. But the initial tension of the premise dissipates like a slow leak.
review5: While Foy's efforts to create his own distinct modern urban mythos are ambitious, the result isn't entirely satisfying.

title: To Catch A Dollar: Muhammad Yunus Banks On America
review2: ....if you've already drunk the Kool-Aid, this film will confirm that you made the right decision, but if you haven't, it quickly gets tedious.

title: The Dawn Patrol (Flight Commander)
review1: Young recruits are sent airborne toward certain death, but Hawks locates a strange joy in their grim fate.
review3: Retains a certain power because of its great aerial footage.
review4: A thoroughgoing blueprint for Hawksian valor
review5: Howard Hawks's compact economy and avoidance of stylistic razzle-dazzle allowed for concentration on storytelling, to great effect.

title: Stella Days
review1: There's no shortage of blarney in Stella Days, helmer Thaddeus O'Sullivan's largely winning drama about '50s rural Ireland, but it's blarney with a twist.
review2: Soft Irish accents and good intentions aren't enough to save the poky Irish drama "Stella Days," set in a small town on the cusp of change in the 1950s.
review3: Relaxed performances and pillow-soft photography compensate somewhat for the story's narrow ambitions, but they're not enough to invigorate a movie that clearly would rather charm than challenge.
review4: Within the square framework, screenwriter Antoine O'Flatharta and director Thaddeus O'Sullivan are able to convey a lot about the atmosphere and attitude of a community in transition.
review5: Thanks to its understated elegance and surpassing central performance, this modest, too-eagerly schematic period drama is more engrossing than it has a right to be.

title: In Our Nature
review1: horrible
review2: Plays distressingly like a photographed off-Broadway drama.
review3: The confessions and conflicts that bubble up feel real and lived, if overly familiar to connoisseurs of that dreaded genre known as the dysfunctional-family drama.
review4: This could be renamed "Mope-Faced Kingdom."
review5: Beautifully observed characterizations and fine performances enliven this sometimes static drama about an unexpected family reunion.

title: Hello I Must Be Going
review1: "Hello I Must Be Going" is at once an intriguing character study and a refreshingly offbeat romance.
review2: The movie's sharp-tongued and softhearted, a Sundance kind of film that mostly sidesteps generic Sundanceyness.
review3: Sarah Koskoff's screenplay is flagrantly duplicitous, introducing the heroine as a self-pitying sloth, then trying to pass her off as likable by making nearly all the other characters drips, snobs, or unfeeling scolds.
review4: Succeeds almost entirely on the strength of Melanie Lynskey's heartfelt and humorous performance in the lead role.
review5: Sarah Koskoff's play-it-safe script and Louiso's heavy-handed direction combine to kill the potential of "Hello I Must Be Going."

title: The Dynamiter
review1: A slow-burn, Mississippi-set drama that is steeped in atmosphere and a gritty, sweaty sense of place but that suffers from its lack of narrative momentum.

title: Flight
review1: The best movies concerning addiction are about the characters and not the Problem. Flight is about the Problem.
review2: Zemeckis has enough control as a filmmaker to overshadow Flight's structural problems, thus making the film both crowd-pleasing and emotionally involving.
review3: An ordinary drama about addiction and recovery, made somewhat noteworthy by Denzel Washington's firing-on-all-cylinders performance.
review4: Until the last 10 minutes, Flight in large part resembles one of those tough, dark character studies they used to make in the '70s.
review5: About all the film accomplishes is instilling a fear that the next time you fly, your pilot might be an irresponsible lush.

title: Deadfall
review1: Like all over-ambitious B-movies, this features solid performances by a mix of seasoned talent and promising young actors, all of whom deserve better.
review2: Despite a super-dark noir plot and respectable cast, "Deadfall" is a thriller that never quite delivers on its promise.
review3: If you want a chilly, suspenseful thriller, watch Transsiberian, which co-stars the completely-wasted-here Kata Mara.
review4: A B-movie with an A-list cast, crime thriller Deadfall sets its plot in motion with some bracing shocks in its first few minutes.
review5: A strong cast makes up for thinnish characterisation, and it's so like Fargo it might as well be called "Fargone".

title: Celeste and Jesse Forever
review1: Its bittersweet conclusion hits you square in the gut.
review2: Thematic murkiness aside, the film achieves a mostly successful mix of mainstream and indie sensibilities.
review3: Rashida Jones' first lead feature role is a likeable enough effort to step out from the tube...
review4: [A] charming, lightweight comedy ...
review5: The film bears a kinship with the underrated 2006 film The Break-Up; both are, for lack of a better term, post-romantic comedies by exploring the largely virgin territory of what happens long after the meet-cute, when life takes hold and love goes sour.

title: Little White Lies
review1: "Little White Lies" is a bit too long, but has plenty of Gallic charm.
review2: A sprawling, initially engaging French comedy-drama that became a hit in France but ultimately underwhelms.
review3: The script is banal, but the acting company and the locations are easy on the eyes.
review4: The overall tone of "Little White Lies" feels off, or maybe it just doesn't translate to American audiences.
review5: At times, it's amusing. At times, it's tragic. At times, it's romantic. But, like many vacations, it's way, way too long.

title: Saving Grace B. Jones
review1: The film ably captures the painful messiness of seemingly simple lives.
review2: Ms. O'Neal has her moments, but the decision to portray her as a raving maniac yields diminishing returns.
review3: Most of what Stevens has concocted here is hard to take.
review4: Connie Stevens' directorial debut blends family drama with psychological thriller to ultimately uneven effect.
review5: The film packs in more characters, subplots, and moments of nostalgic detail than it can gracefully accommodate, and the pacing often feels rushed.

title: The Bouquet
review1: Family drama about loss has heavy themes.

title: A Late Quartet
review1: We can note immediately that Zilberman has the requisite gifts.
review2: The result is a perfectly serviceable, well acted melodrama - but why so serious?
review3: Not without its touching moments, A Late Quartet nevertheless can't truly escape the eye-rolling determinism of its script, with only a pragmatic, wry Christopher Walken truly convincing as a man who has lived inextricably bound with his music.
review4: If nothing else, A Late Quartet captures the reality of dealing with professional classical musicians.
review5: A classical-music ensemble rosins up the bull in a tone-deaf melodrama that loves its musical metaphors almost has much as it adores afternoon soaps.

title: The Pool
review1: Patekar's ability to convey stoic forbearance with so little apparent effort, is one of the marvellous rewards of this intricately textured and compelling film.
review2: A miraculous, American-made Hindi film that is every bit as tranquil as the blue-green reservoir that serves as its abiding metaphor.
review3: Reality and fiction fuse like watercolors in this quietly compelling narrative feature.
review4: It's a movie about a time, a place and a situation that isn't going to change soon. [Director] Smith takes his time to establish the people, the landscape and the striking contrast between the lives of the very rich and the very poor.
review5: It's a bit schematic and sweet-natured, perhaps to a fault, yet the faces linger.

title: The Pill
review1: Does the title refer to contraception? Or one of this sort-of comedy's three leads? It's a toss-up; everyone involved is just so irritating.
review2: This might be more entertaining if any of the three main characters were at all likable.
review3: While their story is feather-light, Khoury and his actors have each type down perfectly.
review4: What makes Khoury's film work-at least until its cop-out ending -- is the consistency of Fred's loathsomeness.
review5: Deftly avoiding both the haphazardness of mumblecore and the fakery of studio romantic comedies, Khoury deploys a light directorial touch marked by assured thesping and a genuine appreciation for neurotic angst.

title: 28 Hotel Rooms
review1: "28 Hotel Rooms" slowly expires for lack of air.
review2: A chamber piece rooted in semi-improvisation.
review3: While Messina and Ireland are fine company, writer-director Matt Ross' conceit tires you out.
review4: In eliminating all the filler, it ends up feeling like nothing but.
review5: Dismaying affectations aside-the characters go needlessly unnamed-the movie articulates the enduring allure of a love defined, and heightened, by restrictions.

title: Teddy Bear
review1: The sex and filial troubles of 308-pound persons are not exactly common. But Matthiesen has evoked both the pathos and courage in these troubles, and, with the help of this reticent giant, explores them enticingly.
review2: This wispy story is distinguished by its sweetness of spirit, and it comes straight from Kold.
review3: A heart-wrenching central performance anchors Mads Matthiesen's intimate, empathetic drama about a Danish bodybuilder who aims to grow up as he nears middle age.
review4: Matthiesen and his cast have created a believable space, and that ultimately helps give Teddy Bear the tension of a fine suspense film once Kold sits down across the kitchen table from Steentoft to speak his mind at last.
review5: A largely likable tale about a 38-year-old man-child trying finally to grow up.

title: Yelling to the Sky
review1: This is grim, bleak material that at times is monotonous, but its woe feels authentic.
review2: Not much happens in story terms, but the film swirls with emotions that make it by turns grim and amusing, heavy and light, obvious and vague.
review3: Mahoney barely explains her characters' circumstances, which makes the movie obliquely intriguing. But whenever the story comes into focus, it's revealed as fairly conventional.
review4: "Yelling" is a prosaic look at a hard life. Like Sweetness, the movie finds its way by instinct.
review5: Little more than a résumé film for all involved, it certainly feels more Park City than Bushwick.

title: Robot & Frank
review1: FRANK & ROBOT is a poignant tale of man and machine
review2: One of the few movies I've seen where the future is not a dystopic nightmare, 3D-generated phantasmagoria, or otherwise unbelievable peek into a not-too-distant hellworld.
review3: While the premise certainly makes it stand out from the sea of dysfunctional family dramas, a cute idea alone doesn't quite cut it.
review4: A slightly futuristic treatise on aging, family and the pitfalls of mechanical screenwriting.
review5: Christopher D. Ford's seamless screenplay provides a light-comedy vehicle that Langella rides to a satisfyingly original, epiphanic finale.

title: Dangerous Liaisons
review1: They have made the film function successfully almost as well as in the original setting.
review2: Much of the cynicism, and thus the fun, of its many Western predecessors goes missing.
review3: Schadenfreude carries a delectable tang no matter the language, and as the history of Hollywood shows, stories about pretty people behaving badly remain reliably alluring.
review4: Zhang, expertly conveying someone closed off yet silently sensual, even rolls out a tear during a moment of impending intimacy as exquisitely timed as a dancer's move.
review5: Takes Pierre Choderlos de Laclos' 18th century source material to its most sumptuous silliness - I mean that as a compliment.

title: Planet of Snail
review1: "Planet of Snail" is simple, direct and magical.
