review2: Gentle, simply told love stories are as rare in documentaries these days as they are in narrative film. That alone makes Yi Seung-jun's "Planet of Snail" a standout.
review3: "Planet of Snail" offers a precious moment of clarity and simplicity amid a chaotic and poisonous summer, and tells an unforgettable love story to boot.
review4: With little story to speak of, Planet Of Snail is more of an experiential piece, closing in on the pleasure and wonder with which Young-chan takes in details like rain falling outside the window and the bark of a tree.
review5: Above all, this beautifully photographed documentary is a poetic meditation on refined sensory perception.

title: The Thieves
review1: "The Thieves" carves its own niche with moments of romance and stylish mayhem mixed with a more emotionally conflicted, winner-take-all sensibility than its American brethren.
review2: [A] sprawling, relentlessly entertaining thriller.
review3: Welcome to the K-cinema equivalent of comfort food.
review4: Easier to like than it is to follow, Choi Dong-hoon's glossy caper boasts all the pomp and cajolery of the true international blockbuster.
review5: Sadly, plot padding sees the film, lengthy for a heist thriller at 136 minutes, eventually wear out its welcome.

title: The Sessions
review1: The Sessions is an unflinching, moving and often funny story about dignity and sexuality.
review2: It's all so plodding and beige, yet giving this movie a bad review is like kicking a kitten.
review3: The Sessions is a tender, well-intentioned examination of a disabled man exploring his sexual identity, but sometimes a film needs more than just good intentions.
review4: May sound like shameless Oscar-bait, but in truth the film is simpler than that, more small-scale, with a light and unpretentious sense of humor.
review5: It's difficult not to be impressed with director and screenwriter Ben Lewin's ability to bring this distinctive and surprisingly emotional story to the big screen.

title: The Kid with a Bike
review1: The directing by the Dardenne brothers reflects their previous work: it wants to be unnoticed either for virtuosity or clumsiness, yet only virtuosos can attain this ideal.
review2: It's nonetheless immensely satisfying - not least in its commitment to a child protagonist whose near-feral intensity and unthinking ingratitude make him the polar opposite of cute.
review3: There is not a wasted shot in this stripped down, pared back fable. Yet, it accrues a deep and lasting power. You won't see many better this year.
review4: Seriously, enough is enough.
review5: The movie is so quiet that everything starts to feel heightened; the smallest motions carry great weight, and something as minor as a slammed door causes you to gasp.

title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower
review1: Satisfying enough to delight younger audience members, and maybe win over a few older ones, too.
review2: It's been a while since a movie captured so colorfully the comedy, tragedy, angst, and exuberance of adolescence.
review3: "Like real teenagers, Watson and Miller convincingly move from glowing objects of desire to comic relief to deeply troubled human beings."
review4: Bravely delves into issues of incest, depression, homophobia and most hauntingly, death. And rarely does any of it feel fake.
review5: One of the absolute best films about surviving High School ever made.

title: Kill for Me
review1: Kill for Me throws in some gratuitous Sapphic titillation, including an obligatory make-out-in-the-shower scene, but the overwrought plotting gives the distinct impression that the filmmakers are getting steamed up over nothing.
review2: What if you crossed "Single White Female" with "Strangers on a Train?" You'd still have a better movie than "Kill For Me."

title: My Worst Nightmare
review1: Isabelle Huppert may be approaching self-parody as an icon of Gallic frigidity, yet the talented writer-director Anne Fontaine puts that to excellent use in this broad, obvious, but consistently funny bedroom farce.
review2: "My Worst Nightmare," though predictable, moves along nicely enough for most of its 99 minutes, thanks to an offbeat chemistry between Huppert (who's very good at looking appalled) and the very relaxed Poelvoorde.
review3: [Huppert] can't get laughs where there are none, and she can't buy a laugh in the movie's second half.
review4: "My Worst Nightmare" isn't great, but it isn't apologizing for anything, either. Plus, I laughed out loud at least three times.
review5: No one loves a broad comedy like the French, but Gallic touches of restraint tend to keep such light entertainment pleasing rather than blundering.

title: "Noordzee, Texas (North Sea Texas)"
review1: This debut feature by noted short-film director Bavo Defurne emphasizes ambiance over storytelling, but that ambiance is so flavorsome you might not mind.
review2: It's not just that film is underdeveloped - it's that it feels unwilling to develop, preferring to leave its characters and plot points static. The result feels stunted.
review3: It's a story that's been told countless times, but first-time director Bavo Defurne has such an assured hand and visual flair (much credit also belongs to cinematographer Anton Mertens) that everything seems fresh and new.
review4: Splendidly acted, especially by Florizoone, whose every thought appears to register on his wide-open features, it's more than promising.
review5: "North Sea Texas" explores emergent sexuality and first love with a refreshing optimism.

title: "For a Good Time, Call..."
review1: Watching [Travis] add his kitschy touch to such a witless, faux-edgy movie can only be described as a Travis-ty.
review2: Constantly ducks away from any semblance of adult sexuality, indulging in garish colors and giggle fits.
review3: It's a comedy that isn't always funny as it struggles to find the right tone between raunchy and sweet. It celebrates female friendship in a way few movies do, but good intentions don't always make for a good film.
review4: the concept was rife with possibilities that could synergize with Graynor's fresh appeal as well as her rising-star status. Neither the possibilities nor the synergy happens, mainly due to an underdeveloped story.
review5: Sure, there's some ribald humor, and the subject matter is clearly edgy. However, it's really a sweet story of friendship wrapped in a sexy package.

title: For Ellen
review1: It's uncomfortably funny, achingly true - and the work of an absolutely genuine artist.
review2: "For Ellen" is a small but exquisite film, beautifully observed and impeccably executed.
review3: his quiet indie drama distinguishes itself most when writer-director So Yong Kim gets the rocker alone with his daughter for a brief visit that will probably be their last.
review4: This performance, unlike anything Paul Dano has ever done, must have required some courage.
review5: "For Ellen" tries one's patience, but what works, works for keeps.

title: Special Forces
review1: If you turned the sound off and removed the subtitles, you might actually think you were watching an old Hollywood shoot-'em-up.
review2: "Special Forces" aims to inspire but ends up wallowing in melodrama.
review3: It's not only Americans who can make leaden, video game-style exercises in dumb war action.
review4: An uneven effort ...
review5: Could have been hilariously subversive if director Stéphane Rybojad had pushed it further.

title: Death Race 3: Inferno (Unrated)
review1: Watching Death Race 3: Inferno is a lot like a casual viewer taking in the Indianapolis 500. Watching the cars go around is ok, but what puts butts in seats is the threat of wanton destruction, and there's plenty of it here.
review2: Inferno absolutely pulls ahead of Death Race 2 as far as the Death Race franchise is concerned, but that's not hard when your competition comes in at an uncontested dead last.
review3: "Death Race 3: Inferno" is like a monster truck rally. People go to see mayhem. And, people who like the "Death Race" movies are also watching to see the stunts. They don't expect a good story. Thank goodness.
review4: there's plenty of action - and plenty of boobs
review5: Ask it no questions and it will tell you no lies: a fair bargain that too many other films on this level resolutely refuse to grant.

title: Ghett'a Life
review1: The worlds of international boxing and gang-ruled Jamaican politics are twinned to initially eye-opening but ultimately welterweight effect.
review2: The view this low-budget movie gives us of a violent Kingston, Jamaica, left by politicians and the police to be run by local gangsters, rings true.
review3: Tangled plot lines and murkily choreographed fight scenes drain this fight flick of juice.
review4: Brownes's broad swipes at a political solution through pathos means this one swings wide.

title: Broken Roads
review1: [Chambers] shows an uncertain, frequently heavy hand.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Part II
review1: Seriously, if this is the best promotion of itself that the free market can manage, it really would benefit from the help of a Ministry of Culture or something.
review2: Director John Putch struggles to find balance or generate a single spark from the clunky mix of romance, political diatribe and thriller.
review3: The producers are going to have to hire a better director if they want moviegoers to be curious enough about this Galt guy to buy a ticket for the presumptive third and final chapter.
review4: It's consistent with its predecessor as a somewhat awkward translation of Ayn Rand's 1957 novel to our current era, handled with bland telepic-style competency.
review5: A disaster as a film, Atlas also is laughable in its presentation of Rand's ideology.

title: Seeds of Destruction (The Terror Beneath)
review1: The acting, the script, the just about everything associated with this film are overwhelmingly sub-par that I doubt anyone professionally associated with this production will have it listed on their résumé. It's best to forget.

title: Sushi Girl
review1: We can't all be Quentin Tarantino, but that doesn't stop some people from trying.
review2: Sushi Girl is intermittently stylish and relatively technically competent but so painfully derivative that it's at times embarrassing to watch. Saxton really loves his Tarantino and if you do too you may marginally tolerate this violent piece of fodder.
review3: There's nothing wrong with paying homage to a film that went before (Reservoir Dogs), if you make it clear that's what you're doing. I never got that vibe with "Sushi Girl."
review4: The real shock of Sushi Girl is how it manages to hold interest despite its familiar moves, working to build a grim personality of its own. Saxton and Pfaff have managed to pull off an entertaining picture.
review5: The power of great performances; Sushi Girl had me hooked from beginning to end, and I can't wait to see it again.

title: Yeopgijeogin geunyeo (My Sassy Girl)
review1: An entertaining and sad time warp romance comedy...
review2: Whatever small flaws might exist in My Sassy Girl, the charismatic leads make it more than worthwhile.

title: Hipsters
review1: What is... wondrous, the chief repression that we see-and hear-is Stalinist hatred of jazz and American hip clothes.
review2: 'Hipsters" practically vibrates with zeal and joy.
review3: It's taken the Russian musical "Hipsters" four years to reach America. That's all right. It may take audiences four years to recover.
review4: A candy-colored confection with a dark, bittersweet center.
review5: Are you ready for a bright and breezy musical comedy from Russia?

title: "Madrid, 1987"
review1: The actors give their characters a resonance beyond the symbolic, but the action doesn't quite transcend the stagy setup.
review2: Madrid, 1987 operates on a dizzying number of levels - as a romantic comedy, a sex farce, a study of culture clash, ageism and idealism.
review3: A sweet, sometimes dull and certainly overlong film ...
review4: Miguel uses her beauty and placid demeanor as a screen against which to project his memories of past adventures and the ghost of his libido.
review5: A stillborn May-November seduction makes for sexual tension and fascinating dialogue.

title: The Eye of the Storm
review1: Has taken almost two years to reach the UK; you'd be forgiven for thinking it was far longer, given its sub-Joseph Losey pretensions and doily-like styling.
review2: Sometimes a feast of acting isn't enough.
review3: A brilliantly acted semi-dud.
review4: Too often the film's moods switch unsuccessfully between the abruptly serious and the broadly bizarre.
review5: Rush and Davis are two of the best actors in the business, and their brittle gamesmanship and rue holds the screen. But the film is disappointingly lackluster -- a mild squall instead of a storm.

title: Silent Souls
review1: A meditation on death and sex, it's a melancholy and touchingly profound folk tale, though also deeply weird in places - pagan vajazzling, anyone?
review2: It's lovely and slow and melancholic and short - 75 minutes, yet you feel you've been gone for an epoch or two.
review3: ... slow and introspective, paced in long, still shots that seem to drift in time rather than march forward.
review4: Overwhelms us with meaningful silence.
review5: Shot in a series of long single takes in the remote reaches of a chilly landscape the film evokes how the acceptance of loss can bring a sense of peace.

title: Blue Is The Warmest Color
review1: Mr. Kechiche and Ms. Lacroix's gravest missteps here are their depictions of homophobia and the LGBT community itself.
review2: Exarchopoulos' performance is a miracle, with every raw emotion rippling across her yearning, endlessly expressive face.
review3: The central romance is told beautifully, and the two leads give dazzling performances.
review4: I have to admit the film got under my own skin and not simply as voyeurism
review5: An emotional and engrossing experience told in extreme close-up.

title: A Simple Life
review1: [T]he sort of film in which every detail feels unforced but essential.
review2: Here is a film with the clarity of fresh stream water, flowing without turmoil to shared destiny. No plot gimmicks. No twists and turns. Just a simple life.
review3: An exquisite and wise moment of celluloid portraiture.
review4: Often poignant but leavened with humor.
review5: Though overlong, Hui's valentine never milks the drama for tears, maintaining an unsentimental focus on the central duo's playful chemistry and the loving way Ah Tao's attention to detail is repaid.

title: The Loneliest Planet
review1: You have to see The Loneliest Planet, for it is one of those works that prepares you for life, that make you wary, alive and responsible, and which ... well, you'll never forget it.
review2: You hope for these characters, and that hope carries the film.
review3: Though it's not without virtues, "The Loneliest Planet" may try the patience of even the most dedicated lovers of art film.
review4: Writer/director Julia Loktev, a New York filmmaker born in Russia, skilfully uses stillness and the vastness of the Caucasus Mountains to frame her trio of characters in psychological quicksand.
review5: Frankly, I've greatly enjoyed discussing the film, whereas I merely tolerated the experience of actually watching it.

title: Chicken with Plums
review1: Resurrects the spirit of Middle Eastern fables, albeit with a French twist.
review2: This dreamy, visually inventive Iranian drama functions on so many levels of reality and obsession that it almost ceases to entertain.
review3: Chicken is a movie that begins with a crescendo and doesn't sustain its lyricism.
review4: "Predictability" is not in Satrapi and Paronnaud's vocabulary, and that is no small thing in this or any other movie era. But the whole those parts form never exceeds their sum.
review5: "Chicken With Plums" is a whimsical, sad, diverting and altogether delightful exploration of how cinema can benefit, not only from glancing back at its own past, but by staying open to parallel forms of presentation and play.

title: Chasing Mavericks
review1: Floating atop the explosive breakers, like an overabundance of phytoplankton, is a roiling colony of clichés that stops at nothing to dominate the screenplay.
review2: This gentle father-son(ish) tale about an expert surfer and his teen apprentice is a rare 'family' movie that isn't preachy or insipid.
review3: Moribund.
review4: While the religious undertones are largely drowned out by the endless spumy slo-mo and board porn, there's only one way this current is flowing: towards church.
review5: Despite a number of exhilarating surfing sequences, the interesting true story of surf legend Jay Moriarty is transformed into another dull Hollywood biopic.

title: Holy Motors
review1: It is never dull.
review2: By the time this film's over, you're shaken, intrigued and reminded that art doesn't need to add up to be entrancing.
review3: Holy Motors is some kind of wonderful.
review4: Jean-Luc Godard's Weekend for the digital era. Both exuberant and melancholy, it's a film about an allegedly dying art form that is thrillingly alive. Cinema is dead. Long live cinema.
review5: Holy Motors is visionary, absurd, melancholy, ecstatic, confounding, and ultimately transcendent. If 2012 spawns a better film I will eat a bouquet of flowers.

title: Fast Girls
review1: Some of the girl power stuff is a bit wincing and it's never totally convincing, but with charm and buckets of energy, you'll forgive it.
review3: ...watching Fast Girls is a thoroughly enjoyable experience, and a particularly welcome contribution to the genre because it focuses on female athletes competing in a non-glamour sport.
review4: [W]holly unsurprising... yet this flick is wholly winning thanks to its abundance of good cheer, generosity of spirit, and refusal to go too easy on its protagonist.
review5: Devoid of anything daring, Fast Girls makes some of the right motions but never rises above its cash-in status.

title: Girls Against Boys
review1: The B-horror standbys that might rescue the film from self-serious tedium are nowhere to be found.
review2: When it comes to "Girls Against Boys," it's a draw - everyone loses.
review3: In "Girls Against Boys" both sides lose.
review4: A dumb, dreary, let's-get-back-at-them slasher in which pulverized genitals pass for feminist critique.
review5: Panabaker and LaLiberte give their all, but the movie is all moral compass and mainstream emotion, and never as edgy or transgressive as it thinks it is.

title: The Master
review1: It's a mess; it's pretentious; it is thundery with dismay.
review2: In the end it may not have the emotional uplift the Academy or a popular mainstream audience craves, but make no mistake, this is an enthralling drama about a peculiarly American restlessness, and the striving for insight and grace.
review3: [A] challenging, psychologically fraught drama.
review4: It's a singular vision, and the movie haunts.
review5: There is so much spark here, so much to absorb, that the effect defies any picking of nits and just makes one grateful.

title: Beauty (Skoonheid)
review1: ...Beauty is my least favourite type of film. An 'arthouse' film with a repulsive protagonist, Beauty is slow and, eventually, vile.
review2: Director Oliver Hermanus values quiet, naturalistic scenes of domestic life to build considerable emotional tensions in this finely nuanced film.
review3: Hermanus's Cannes-feted feature serves as a bold statement on the stereotypical Afrikaans male, now struggling to remain relevant in a post-apartheid South Africa.
review4: Beauty is a confronting work that succeeds as a study of a false life lived badly and as a reflection upon a society grasping at traditional views to its own detriment.
review5: This is Death in Venice African-style, though lacking the reticence and resonance of Mann's novella.

title: Talaash
review1: Performances are uniformly impressive, with Khan proving again that he is the finest actor of his generation.
review2: This thoroughly engrossing, highly anticipated pic boasts assured direction by sophomore helmer Reema Kagti, a well-constructed script by Kagti and... Zoya Akhtar, and strong thesping by familiar Bollywood luminaries.
review3: The film grabs on tight and doesn't let go.
review4: Ultimately the movie's many strands come together for a final twist, but it's too little too late for this regrettably mediocre Bollywood import.
review5: Kapoor naturally exudes a kittenish charm that not even a violet, skintight, leopard-print dress and equally purple dialogue can entirely diminish.

title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2
review1: A feast of ripe dialogue and bloodsucking action.
review2: Winking, self-aware camp that eventually explodes into a craptacular of the highest order.
review3: If you're looking for a review that will tell you the movie is terrible and its fans are idiots, I'm afraid I must disappoint you.
review4: The film's long middle is still a slog, but the beginning and ending are loud and weird enough to supply solid entertainment.
review5: In "The Twilight Saga-Breaking Dawn, Part 2," Bella gets a much-needed fire in her belly. Her wimpy former self is suddenly a badass.

title: California Solo
review1: Lewy's script doesn't cop out with any sentimental redemption, but neither does it establish why the self-destructive Lachlan deserves our sympathy.
review2: Mainly worth seeing as a showcase for the appealing Scottish actor Robert Carlyle, who plays a has-been rocker reduced to eking out a living on an organic farm in Southern California.
review3: In some sense, "California Solo" is like meeting an engaging stranger: At first there's a certain air of enigmatic mystery that makes you want to spend time with them, but eventually things turn awkward and you just want to get away.
review4: The story trickles to a disappointing close. But Carlyle, who first gained attention here for his unforgettable work in "Trainspotting," remains an essential character actor.
review5: It treats its themes of guilt and responsibility with delicate tact and a precise eye for the neglected commitments that stubbornly dog a man trying his damnedest to efface himself from the world.

title: Heleno
review1: There's just so much one can care about this star athlete and his self-destructive journey.
review2: What you get instead of soccer is almost two hours of late-stage syphilis.
review3: Equal parts temper and tenderness, lust and incaution, "Heleno" is short on specifics but long on impression.
review4: José Henrique Fonseca's handsome black-and-white, impressionistic bio-drama goes very Raging Bull-ish, to tell a piece of the story of Heleno de Freitas, a Brazilian soccer star with matinee-idol charisma.
review5: You're stuck daydreaming about a far, far better movie.

title: Foreverland
review1: Pretty much sputters from the get-go.
review2: An earnestly made misfire, Foreverland relies on wisecracks to build a romantic drama around a character with cystic fibrosis on a legacy-building road trip.
review3: There is something to be discovered here, for a particular audience that enjoys shedding a tear or two, from a movie that, at the least, avoids the obvious path to being maudlin or quirky.
review4: If the redemption is in the journey rather than the destination, Foreverland is a bit of a meandering ramble.
review5: 'Til breath do us part

title: Orhim le-rega (Off-White Lies)
review1: The performances are so uniformly good that it's a shame the characters are stuck with such a listless plot.
review2: Making the most of its likable leads, the script (by Ms. Kenig and Dana Dimant) maintains an amused, nonjudgmental tone ...
review3: Perhaps because of the film's concern with never overplaying its dramatic hand, the resolution feels too perfunctory ...
review4: A fairly generic father-daughter story ...
review5: An Israeli drama about a father-daughter reunion that is twisted by lies and high expectations.

title: Playing for Keeps
review1: Everyone involved deserves a script with more wit, originality and sense of purpose.
review2: Dennis Quaid hammers away at a nothing role as Thurman's husband, an adulterous alpha dog; it's nearly identical to the one he played earlier this year in What to Expect When You're Expecting, but who's counting?
review3: These are actors due a break. Unfortunately, this comedy-drama about a kids' soccer coach boinking a bunch of desperate housewives doesn't appear to be it.
review4: Someone maybe should've told this guy if you want to rekindle a romance with a woman, you probably shouldn't start by sleeping with all her friends.
review5: a celluloid own goal.

title: The Intouchables
review1: Gives its subject too light a treatment for the life-affirming message to feel earned.
review2: There are much better contemporary movies about dealing with the dynamics of being handicapped or wheelchair bound and overcoming obstacles, such as Rust & Bone, Amour, and The Diving bell and the Butterfly.
review3: Without getting into spoilers, can I just say how refreshing it was to watch a film about a physically challenged person that didn't end on a total downer?
review4: This pleasant, predictable, fact-based tale of an unlikely friendship between a quadriplegic and his carer hits all the sweet spots a feel-good movie must.
review5: In the wrong hands this film could have been a sentimental mess. Luckily it's not and instead of being a film about labels, it's about people and the healing power of camaraderie.

title: Gun Hill Road
review1: Gun Hill Road is shot through with performances at once intense and relaxed.
review2: Feels like it's been workshopped, from its string of coincidences to its tidy downbeat conclusion in which Green stabs at irony with a dull knife.
review3: Before some predictable, freedom-threatening recidivism on Enrique's part, the film exhibits a simultaneously anthropological and sensitive interest in Michael's day-to-day life...
review4: In writer-director Rashaad Ernesto Green's assured hands, "Gun Hill Road" manages somehow to be gritty, delicate, in your face and nuanced at the same time.
review5: Tenderness and good intentions don't necessarily add up to a movie.

title: Abducted: The Carlina White Story
review1: True kidnapping story is intense but isn't sensationalized.

title: The Rising of the Moon
review1: It's well-produced and well-acted, but never moving and a wee bit too stagy.

title: The Playroom
review1: You have your basic family psychodrama, except there's no real heat either downstairs or up.
review2: Standout Olivia Harris and Parker are heart-wrenching as the vitriolic mother and neglected teen daughter.
review3: Modest in scale, it's the kind of American independent film that brings some honor to that shopworn descriptor.
review4: The film uses the upper-middle-class setting effectively, even as it resorts to heavy-handed symbolism and melodrama in its dour, mostly unforgiving portrait of parental dysfunction.
review5: A detailed, and depressing portrait of grim, forced independence. Lightened only by the sense that if these kids are learning anything, it is how to survive.

title: Kumaré
review1: What started as a long, elaborate joke becomes a journey, both for Gandhi's students and for the filmmaker himself.
review2: Your view of the film may hinge on whether you can accept the ethics of his fakery.
review3: There's a Morgan Spurlock narcissism to "Kumaré." It could just as well have been called "Super-Spiritualize Me."
review4: As "Kumaré" plays out, both Gandhi and the film become something else, something much more thoughtful and moving.
review5: It's a fascinating social experiment, but not much of a movie.

title: The First Time
review1: It's a hard movie to dislike. But try.
review2: There is much to like here, a sense of nuance and nonjudgmental emotional openness, yet Kasdan's teenage miniaturism never quite blooms.
review3: [An] inoffensive but bland ode to the talky high school movies of John Hughes and Cameron Crowe.
review4: No gratuitous raunchiness here and only a few tired caricatures in a genre usually jammed with them.
review5: Something of a wonder, a palm-size ball of banter and irony and earnestness that never stops rolling and almost never misses the sweet spots.

title: Smashed
review1: There will never be another Marilyn Monroe or Elizabeth Taylor, but Hollywood may have found a new Lee Remick in Mary Elizabeth Winstead.
review2: Ponsoldt keeps up a good pace and refuses to let the material get too heavy. He focuses on the characters and their slip ups, jokes, frustrations, and all the imperfections that make up a person.
review3: Winstead is immense in this picture, a true force of nature who embodies so many complexities and demons that make her this perpetually broken protagonist...
review4: The only ingredient that renders it remotely unique is an Oscar-caliber performance from Mary Elizabeth Winstead as the proverbial drunk with a heart - and liver - of Johnnie Walker Gold.
review5: Smashed is a non-judgmental snapshot of the small world surrounding this couple, and is filled with insightful moments and really great low-key performances.

title: Hitchcock
review1: Wallows in fat jokes and wink-wink nudge-nudge references that anybody with even a passing knowledge of cinema history will find eye-rollingly obvious.
review2: Without Helen Mirren, James D'Arcy and a few interesting scenes, this flat, lifeless exploration of Alfred Hitchcock's making of "Psycho" lacks depth or a suitable anchor.
review3: There are a multitude of sordidly fascinating directions a biopic on Alfred Hitchcock could take. So, when Sacha Gervasi's flat and frothy Hitchcock concludes, it's inevitably frustrating to find this film takes such a conventional path.
review4: A movie about the late great director poses a question too great to ignore: how does one truly capture the idea of Hitchcock in a span of only 99 minutes? The answer is you can't, and here is a movie that, thankfully, knows that.
review5: If you can disregard your desire for authenticity and scrupulous historical accuracy, this is light fun with a sweet relationship at the center of it.

title: Samson and Delilah
review1: Cecil B. DeMille has again dipped into the Bible for his material, made appropriately dramatic revisions in the original, and turned up with a DeMille-size smash.
review2: Wonderfully chintzy and hokey Bible epic once described as the only film in which the hero had bigger tits than the heroine.
review3: If you'll settle for gold-plated pageants, for muscular episodes and for graphic inducements to wolf-whistling, then "Samson and Delilah" is for you.
review4: The film cannot avoid the broad contours of Samson's story, of course, but it does tweak things in ways that make Samson look a little more heroic.
review5: Here DeMille, the master of the crowd scene, is in top form managing thousands of extras, particularly in the savage battle scenes in which Samson destroys the Philistine army with the jawbone of an ass.

title: This Must Be The Place
review1: Penn has created a colorful tour guide, but in "This Must Be the Place," there's no there there.
review2: Writer-director Paolo Sorrentino handles the story with surprising thoughtfulness.
review3: The cast ... is outstanding, dragging the offbeat story through the occasional look-at-me distractions.
review4: Although "This Must Be the Place" holds our attention, it's a little difficult to say where it's headed.
review5: If you give Penn (and the movie) a chance, the character works, movingly and somewhat miraculously.

title: Life of Pi
review1: Veteran filmmakers will warn you, don't film at sea and don't work with animals. Ang Lee built a vast tank in Taiwan and he whips up awesome storms. [However,] watching the water here is more rewarding than watching the characters.
review2: You'll wish you could watch it with the sound turned off.
review3: The ferocious swells and intent visual beauty Lee has brought to Yann Martel's best-selling seeking-of-the-spiritual yarn quickly evokes a second thought: "Kitty, kitty, kitty, nice kitty, here kitty, kitty, kitty, kitty."
review4: Among movies that are intended to be spiritually insightful, this is one of the most hollow and disappointing that I've seen, a surface-level rendering of platitudinous feel-good hooey.
review5: This movie is to be seen and experienced. It is not to be heard.

title: Tot altijd (Time Of My Life)
review1: Based on fact, touching, and engaging, this aptly titled feature depicts the campaign to legalize euthanasia in Belgium.

title: The Great Magician (Daai mo seut si)
review2: The Great Magician is an undeniably charming and whimsical Chinese fantasy that captures your imagination with little effort.

title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone)
review1: An emotionally gripping if slightly meandering drama marked by two powerful lead performances.
review2: Audiard visits a physicality that isn't necessarily female or male, but of the body, and toward the body, as in Cotillard's wide, lidded eyes when she watches him punching, thumping and bleeding in illegal bare-fisted takedown fights.
review3: It's a film for people who believe that fallen souls aren't inevitably destined to become lost ones.
review4: ...while all the admittedly well-wrought details engage us on an intellectual level and keep us watching, the film doesn't linger in the imagination the way truly great cinema does
review5: there is no denying the cinematic power of Audiard's fearless storytelling

title: The Big Picture
review1: "The Big Picture" ends perhaps a bit too ambiguously, but there's something refreshing about its faith in the moviegoer's intelligence.
review2: Director Eric Lartigau tells the story slowly, less interested in suspense than in character.
review3: Takes familiar material - involving a violent crime and an assumed identity - and nudges it just enough to keep us interested for most of the ride.
review4: It moves, with supple muscularity, toward a twisty and satisfying conclusion.
review5: Duris is excellent, his hair and eyes growing wilder with each step of the journey, and he has solid support ...

title: The Other Son
review1: It is easy to imagine other, darker, results after the opening accident, but Levy's film, pitched firmly as if it were the only possibility, makes it seem so.
review2: A humane but emotionally anemic message movie whose dramatic craft doesn't live up to its good intentions.
review3: Lévy generally succeeds in creating a compelling, humanistic family drama, even if some viewers may reject the movie's final note of optimism.
review4: In the end, it seems, this is not a story about two families, and two lands. It's a story about one family, and one world.
review5: The ancient question of nature versus nurture is dramatically explored in "The Other Son," a memorable film about the concept of two infants being accidentally switched at birth.

title: Atletu (The Athlete)
review1: There are perhaps two better films lurking within "Atletu," one a more straightforward documentary and the other a narrative biopic, but this hybrid falls flat.
review2: This is an ambitious and brave project which, if it doesn't quite reach the heights it might, is still a worthwhile watch and bodes well for both filmmakers in future.
review3: Told through reconstruction and archive footage, the story of Ethiopian marathon legend Abebe Bikila can't muster the drama it deserves.
review4: The essential simplicity of this tale about a true hero is often very moving.
review5: It's a blend of documentary and drama, but while the archive clips of Bikila's victories are thrilling, the performances are flat and the script tired.

title: Hey Good Lookin'
review2: Baskshi's last before he lost it. Tragic to the extreme.
review3: Sporadically a guilty pleasure.

title: Union Square
review1: It is intended for an audience that is willing to take a journey without knowing the destination.
review2: The kind of character-driven movie about whacked-out characters we need more of (the characters and the movies).
review3: Mira Sorvino is very good -- too good -- at playing a very annoying person in Nancy Savoca's Union Square.
review4: Propelled by a rangy, superbly colorful performance by Mira Sorvino, the film grabs hold of the viewer from the jump and snowballs toward a deftly moving and concise third act.
review5: It doesn't pretend to be anything more than it is - a slice-o'-life domestic drama/dark comedy of manners savvy about its limits and sufficiently disciplined to keep its convolutions to a credible, impactful minimum.

title: Les Misérables
review1: Tom Hooper's direction is an aesthetic crime.
review2: Everybody curse Tom Hooper! Everybody feel the gloom! Everybody give thumbs down to the Master of the Zoom!
review3: Ultimately the film's choppy, camera-goes-anywhere approach works well in translating a play that was never all that interested in the movement of bodies anyway-only their martyrdom.
review4: [Director Tom Hooper's] old fashioned take is frequently exhilarating and adamant in its unwavering desire to not be dolled up and be given a hip makeover.
review5: If the entire film were as good as the first 30 minutes, it would easily be one of the year's best pictures.

title: Tatsumi
review1: Western viewers might liken it to Disney meets The Dark Knight.
review2: Singaporean director Eric Khoo's stylishly impressive homage to the mangaka, converting his memoir, A Drifting Life, into a cinematic work employing animation that is true to Tatsumi's original work.
review3: It's potent stuff, delving into pornography, incest, murder and mutilation in the company of alienated men and unhappy, sometimes cruel women.
review4: If the structure sometimes disrupts the story of his life, the strong lines and melancholy sensibility of the illustration form an anchor that keep the power of Tatsumi's work firmly in view.
review5: If Khoo's film doesn't amount to more than its parts, more often than not those parts are vivid and arresting.

title: Á annan veg (Either Way)
review1: "Either Way" is a slight, ultra-dry comedy with a lot of empty spaces and plenty of silences. But the two main characters are just so endearing that their chemistry fills the gaps nicely.

title: Alois Nebel
review1: This very sombre film from debut filmmaker Tomás Lunák recalls the dazzling visual style of Christian Volckman's 2006 French action noir, Renaissance, but [with] a plot that appears to move as slowly as molasses...

title: Cheerful Weather For The Wedding
review1: The film builds up to something that never comes.
review2: Rice does a fine job of juggling so many characters and moving smoothly among flashbacks without losing sight of the main story.
review3: What it doesn't have is drama or wisdom or comedy or heat, something to temper the banalities.
review4: Not to say it isn't an enjoyable diversion. Just that it's also a superficial one.
review5: The glossy appearance and trappings may evoke standard Anglophile nostalgia, but below the veneer is a cynical portrait of bored, shallow Britons halfheartedly going through the motions of a celebration.

title: Day of the Falcon
review1: A far, far cry from "Lawrence of Arabia," but it has its diversions.
review2: A movie that's fascinating in many respects, but doesn't really work as the lavish entertainment intended.
review3: This ambitious desert epic may be a bit slow and confusing at the beginning, but I found the exciting second half of the movie worth waiting for.
review4: There's an enormous amount of perverse pleasure to be had here for those who get off on the annihilation of nuance.
review5: Pedestrian storytelling and clunky dialogue leaves this would-be epic drama about a power struggle between feuding kingdoms in soon-to-be-oil-rich 1920s Arabia bogged down in the sand

title: A Royal Affair
review1: For all its incident, A Royal Affair is slow and picturesquely framed - more of a languorously animated coffee-table book than a gripping drama.
review2: The film ends not on a happy note, naturally, but on a moment of hope. Love may not conquer all, but it has a power all its own.
review3: Although the brazen lovers, bellicose ministers and backstabbing handmaidens are familiar elements, the film is so handsomely mounted that we happily endure the ride until the turning of the screws in the tragic last act.
review4: Perhaps there's only so much to be done with a costume drama about illicit affairs and would-be coups.
review5: What a piece of work is this historical drama.

title: Bob's New Suit
review1: With good intentions and a warm heart but undone by uneven performances and shaky storytelling, "Bob's New Suit" never quite finds the right fit.

title: The Comedy
review1: The longest and dreariest 94 minutes I've spent on a movie this year.
review2: None of this is necessarily funny. That's the extent of the irony here.
review3: The joke, I guess, is that there's nothing funny about "The Comedy."
review4: A mean-spirited piece of mumblecore that tries to provoke you, but only succeeds in boring you.
review5: A character study that tries to make the revolting compelling.

title: Bangkok Revenge
review1: Thailand locations add spice but - like the plot twists and performances - fail to elevate the action beyond the generic ...
review4: The film is smart enough to keep it short and sweet and Jon Foo packs a hell of a punch (and kick and elbow and knee), but it still isn't enough to make Bangkok Revenge even remotely decent.
review5: Thai martial arts thriller miskicks from go to whoa.

title: Killing Them Softly
review1: This physical world is malleable, the means to disconcerting loveliness and expressive power... all under cover as a political parable in the form of an urgent, restless gangster picture. Rain falls, words tumble, violence erupts. Lyricism ensues.
review2: With such a strong cast, it's hard to imagine how things went so wrong.
review3: f you find Dominik's unsubtle political statements too obvious, there is still plenty else going on in Killing Them Softly to marvel at with its familiar, and yet fresh, genre elements.
review4: Ain't nothin' new about it, but it's a cool 97 minutes of seedy amusement.
review5: Dominik wears his nihilism as a badge, but that's not what it is at all: It's a crutch, and an awfully flimsy one.

title: Snabba cash (Easy Money)
review1: It's gripping stuff - even if the original title 'Snabba Cash' is way cooler than the English one.
review2: The story is overcooked and the gritty aesthetic (handheld cameras, desaturated color) borders on cliche.
review3: One of the most involving of the many first-rate thrillers that have come recently from Scandinavia.
review4: [A] smart, affecting, slow burn of a movie, a spectacular example of Nordic noir...
review5: A heavily-armed, solid thriller directed with style by Espinosa, who takes us supermarket shopping at the eye level of a child.

title: Lincoln
review1: It's very good, but that's not the point. It's necessary.
review2: Tasked with dramatizing some of the most significant moments of the 19th century, Spielberg shoots the picture as a bustling ensemble comedy.
review3: Spielberg brings a level of tension to what could have been an overly stuff historical period piece. He's supported by a superb cast highlighted by the work of Daniel Day-Lewis as the 16th President of the United States.
review4: This is a wonderful film, full of detail and behavior, and one that lifts broadened historical details into a poetic marriage of humanity and triumph.
review5: When it focuses on the political, social, and historical side of things - which is 80% of the film - it's grand, populist, high-minded entertainment.

title: Unfinished Spaces
review1: [A] fine, clear-eyed documentary about the art schools' fate.
review2: Cuban Communism doomed 5 modern wonders to ruin

title: LUV
review1: Director-co-writer Sheldon Candis stretches a lot of the time, a romantic story seems to have been cut drastically, and the film's climax is far too typical.
review2: Even the boarded-up row houses look romantic.
review3: A sometimes taut and occasionally preposterous day in the life of an 11-year-old accompanying his uncle on business in Baltimore.
review4: What begins as a promising peek into the tragic cycle of waylaid promise that's crippling broken inner-city families is itself dispiritingly pulled sideways in the Baltimore-set indie "LUV."
review5: Both for good and for ill, "LUV" has a film-school feeling about it, and channels a legacy of fatalistic American crime cinema that includes "Mean Streets" and "Treasure of the Sierra Madre."

title: Hemingway & Gellhorn
review1: When people lament the lack of sophisticated adult entertainment at the movies these days, Hemingway & Gellhorn is exactly the sort of movie they're pining for
review2: Hemingway and Gellhorn suffers because the story of a woman not wanting to be the footnote in her partner's career, whose message inadvertently becomes the footnote in a meandering mess of a biopic.
review3: Acclaimed writers don't ring true in mature HBO biopic.
review4: Certainly one expects as bit more from the likes of director Philip Kaufman.
review5: Kidman is strong here as Martha Gellhorn, using her exceptional figure and old-fashioned movie star glamour to full effect.

title: Hitler's Children
review1: A film whose core is a haunting question: When parents are monstrous, where does filial love begin and end?
review2: The moral weight of "Hitler's Children" is unmistakable. So is that weight's inertness.
review3: The sins of the fathers have seldom weighed so heavy as in the odd, intriguing and ultimately moving Hitler's Children.
review4: Haunting documentary about the descendants of top Nazi leaders struggling to endure their horrific legacy.
review5: Quiet, simple and soaked in sorrow, "Hitler's Children" takes a stripped-down approach to an emotionally sophisticated subject.

title: The Sweeney
review1: [It] feels a lot like an American-made cop movie circa 1990.
review2: Based on a '70s British program, this is a bombastic effort that, while not successful, is still as bracing as a cold pint.
review3: Winstone is, as always, perfectly believable as a tough guy and after a slow start - due, somewhat, to American ears adjusting to those problematic accents - the film hits a groove.
review4: Maybe it worked in the '70s; it's too worn to work these days. Ray Winstone needs to find better rocks to chew on.
review5: The movie blithely repeats most of the clichés of the American badass-cop flick, only in impenetrable Cockney.

title: Stitches
review1: It's like a twisted balloon animal filled with blood and guts, waiting to burst.
review2: Aiming for a gruesomely silly vibe that plays like equal parts American Pie and Evil Dead 2, Stitches preys on teenage foibles and clown clichés alike, offering mostly solid if not quite cult-classic-level fun.
review3: Stitches has all the makings of a perfect cult classic, effortlessly blending comedically dark clown work by Ross Noble with grade "A" horror shenanigans - plus you can't ignore that distinctively schlocky 80s feel.
review4: Neither funny nor scary, just amateurish in a bad student film way.
review5: Imitation blood flows like a tsunami and the aim of disgusting the audience while raising a few heartless laughs proves moderately successful.

title: Rabitto horâ 3D (Tormented)
review1: with dizzying camerawork and lighting from master cinematographer Chris Doyle (working for his first time in the 3D format), it's a psychedelic meta-J-horror that is part ghost story, part Freudian merry-go-round, and utterly in your face.

title: Zaytoun
review1: We've ... got to admit right up front: Part of our interest was simply to see what Stephen Dorff is doing playing an Israeli POW.
review2: It's probably best viewed as a fable that tries to strike a hopeful note amid the many woes of the Middle East, but the blunt filmmaking and the near-sentimentality make it hard to buy into.
review3: The resolution is a bit Hollywood, but then who says all films about the Middle East have to be relentlessly grim? "Zaytoun" dares to find common ground and hope amidst political confusion.
review4: A trek that is occasionally very unlikely, but moving nonetheless.
review5: It's just all too breezy to have any real effect.

title: Dragon Wasps
review1: this film sputs its wad early, revealing the people-snatching hymenopterans in their full CGI absurdity within the opening five minutes, from which point you just know that there is going to be a lot of cheese on the menu.

title: Jigokumon (Gate of Hell)
review1: It is hard to convey in simple language the moving qualities of this lovely film, which, among other things, was the winner of the grand prize at the Cannes film festival last spring.
review2: The film's delicately choreographed battles, its use of texture and color, and its grace of movement and composition mark it as one of those rare Japanese films that survive despite overinterpretation.
review3: It's 1160 and a good man is hard to find.
review4: a powerful drama that has rightfully taken its place once again among the films that opened Western audiences' eyes to the wonders of Japanese cinema
review5: This visually striking and dramatically compelling Japanese feature won two Oscars: Best Foreign Lnguage Film and Best Costume Design.

title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake)
review1: These showdowns feature spectacular, Lord of the Rings-style CGI settings, but not much in the way of thrills or terror.
review2: The clunky action mostly revolves around uninspired wire-fu choreography: Monks fly around while flailing their arms as hordes of CGI creatures gather around and then do nothing.
review3: A silly, derivative supernatural-action extravaganza that would have been better at a fraction of its f/x budget.
review4: Fantastic visuals and non-stop action make for a spectacular, romantic Chinese CGI feast.
review5: Beautiful martial arts fantasy with scary imagery, violence.

title: In Another Country
review1: By the time its third story kicked in, "In Another Country" lost me.
review2: If you take the film as the bauble it is, you'll be entertained by its lighthearted wit, social observations and resolute sidestepping of profundity.
review3: A beguiling set of variations on a theme, a gossamer-light étude composed for delight rather than dissection.
review4: Isabelle Huppert has reached that magical point where she gives a thrill of delight simply by showing up, her decades of great performances seeming to hover around her like a halo.
review5: A movie may be a representation of the world, but it is also something that happens in the world, which means that sustaining a cinematic illusion and breaking it are equally beside the point.

title: Hyde Park on Hudson
review1: [It] may have the look of a prestige picture, but it plays more like a version of FDR's life as told by TMZ, focusing on naughty details and ignoring the historical implications of the events depicted.
review2: A tedious affair about a tedious affair.
review3: The performances across the board are strong, but it's Murray who's most impressive.
review4: The potentially sordid FDR-and-Daisy half of the drama is feebly unrewarding, bordering on pointless, and bogged down by ponderous narration.
review5: An unconventional drama that succeeds despite an uneven plot.

title: Ring the Bell
review1: Heavy-handed Christian drama tries to recruit new believers.

title: Down the Shore
review1: The director, Harold Guskin, and writer, Sandra Jennings, show admirable patience in letting the story unspool, and the actors reward them.
review2: None of it hangs together - particularly as the film heads into his final third, and you realize director Harold Guskin and screenwriter Sandra Jennings don't have a clue as to how to wrap things up.
review3: Gandolfini and Janssen dance a delicate minuet around one another, pacing out a slow, quiet revelation of the shared past that has paralyzed their wills to happiness and change.
review4: Costa brings a nice, lived-in sexiness to the evocatively shot setting, and Gandolfini settles into his character with extraordinary skill and sensitivity.
review5: Brando-wheezing Gandolfini never slums it, but there's still no shaking the sense that a pro has shown up for amateur hour.

title: Io sono Li (Shun Li and the Poet)
review1: Segre's film captures the misty elision of land and sea in the Veneto lagoon and how it perfectly expresses the characters' yearning placelessness.
review2: There is not much happiness in the lives of these two people, but they have each other.
review3: A thin but attractively opalescent immigrant study, prioritizing exquisite, atmospheric detail over the bigger picture.
review4: The plot is preposterous, offering up not one, but two, saintly females for our hi falutin' delectation.
review5: This is haunting and affecting with visual poetry to spare.

title: The Sex of the Angels (El Sexo De Los Angeles)
The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia
review1: The rotting corpses, projectile insect vomit, and creepy geezers in black arrive pretty much on cue, as does the great Cicely Tyson as the obligatory old blind woman who "sees" more than most people with two good eyes.
review2: Ultimately nothing more than a decrepit vehicle for the moldiest of scary-movie clichés: screechy specters, inane character behavior and jump scares that a toddler could anticipate minutes ahead of time.
review3: Some decent scares are provided in this refreshingly low-key ghost story.
review4: This sequel in name only is a superior pic in almost every possible way, and deserves better than the half-hearted dump -- limited theatrical exposure day-and-date with VOD release -- it's been given by Lionsgate.
review5: Well-worn hokum.

title: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea
review1: It raises the hope that someday, perhaps, there can be a meeting of Israeli and Palestinian minds.
review2: A gentle pairing of youthful idealism and tenacious hope.
review3: What elevates [it] ... is the gentleness with which Binisti approaches his difficult subject.
review4: Although smoothly directed, A Bottle in the Gaza Sea has little visual personality or dramatic urgency.
review5: The film's notion that a little understanding and a lot of e-mailing would basically solve the Middle East crisis ... is as reductive as it is utopian.

title: Not Suitable for Children
review2: The premise sounds like a playpen for vulgarity but Michael Lucas's script is smarter than that.
review3: A film with great characters, laughs and earned emotion, Not Suitable isn't a revolutionary film, but it does what most of its romantic ilk doesn't: it actually works.
review4: A heartily welcome sex comedy with a few sneaky surprises.
review5: Performances are impressive - particularly Snook, who seems destined for greatness - with screenwriter Michael Lucas serving a suitably gentle helping of humour throughout.

title: Django Unchained
review1: Django Unchained is 165 minutes and nothing much happens beyond talk and the provision of corpses. The plot lurches around and the artful structure of Pulp Fiction has been abandoned.
review2: By the end, Django is a hero for his times: the D is silent, but nothing else is.
review3: Obscurely referential, extremely indulgent, and deliriously over-the-top, Django is -- in other words -- everything you'd expect from a Tarantino joint.
review4: Overlong, self-indulgent garbage with a portrayal of a "house Negro" that is a grotesque distortion of a sad reality.
review5: It is plainly a nonstop riot of humor and excitement, and one that matches its delicate nature with an equally calculated sense of importance in leading us to the most satisfying climax possible.

title: Save The Date
review1: Lizzy Caplan and Alison Brie lend the lightweight rom-com "Save the Date" more than its fair share of watchability. But the film is never truly interesting.
review2: While Caplan works well in theory as an antiromantic-comedy heroine, director and co-screenwriter Michael Mohan just doesn't give her enough to do.
review3: [It] may sound like Sitcomland, but Mr. Mohan's sensibility - visually, comically, in terms of character - is more naturalistic, more Sundance. It's just not particularly sharp.
review4: A merely adequate addition to the raft of romantic comedies for those pushing 30 without adult lives to call their own.
review5: Save the Date is romantic comedy with aspirations to do something new. That's admirable but it isn't enough.

title: Wu xia (Dragon)
review1: "Dragon" has enough interesting left turns in style, mood and psychodrama to make it stand out.
review2: The movie hurtles along at a pitch of sentiment and melodrama that would make MGM blush, and it's mostly very diverting.
review3: As a whole, it does not quite work, especially at the end, when Mr. Chan tries for a Shakespearean climax of filial rebellion and paternal rage.
review4: The widescreen cinematography and mountain rain-forest locations retain their interest, as does the deftly incongruous score, which ranges from samba to hard rock.
review5: The large canvas and pseudo-superhero tactics work for a bit, but then the action gets sidetracked in place of myth-building.

title: Future Weather
review1: Smart casting redeems the film.
review2: [A] tiny, beautifully acted movie ...
review3: Ever wonder what you're missing by not attending the Sundance Film Festival? Many of the entries look a lot like this little indie, a nicely observed but overly familiar coming-of-age tale.
review4: There's almost nothing to criticize. Yet the overall effect is one big shoulder shrug, because there's nothing in Future Weather that can't be found in dozens of other indie movies just like it.
review5: Deller's pacing remains uneven, taking too long to build to a too-rapid finale, but that at least gives her opportunity to focus on the film's main asset, devoting ample time to observing its tetchy, sharply drawn lead.

title: Goodbye Charlie
review1: Minnelli wanted Marilyn Monroe for the lead, and indeed Debbie Reynolds is doing too much in this comedy about gender reversal and transgressive conduct, though Tony Curtis has some good moments

title: Champion
review1: The Set-Up, made the same year, is infinitely superior.
review2: Kirk Douglas does a good, aggressive job, with a slight inclination to over-eagerness at times, which might amuse an old fight fan.
review3: In his first Oscar nomination in Mark Robson's compelling melodrama, Kirk Douglas gives a ferociously realistic performance as a boxer determined to succeed at all costs.
review4: One of the best fight films ever, also one of Kirk's best
review5: Robson's direction is all action, wasting no time in telling this compelling story, and Carl Foreman's script is sharply observant of the boxing milieu.

title: Family Weekend
review1: Don't let the innocuous title fool you. Family Weekend is a subversive little comedy in which a tightly wound misfit of a teenage girl, fed up with watching her family spiral out of control, subjects her parents to an extreme intervention.
review2: The unconventional dysfunctional family has now become a Hollywood convention. It is familiar to a fault.
review3: For a long while, director Benjamin Epps goes for breakneck farce; at its best, this is a batty mixture of family-values editorial and teen spoof.
review4: We're sitting there, trapped. An angry little teenager's yelling at us. And we're not having any fun at all.
review5: The script, by Matt K. Turner, is loaded with contradictions, its hollow flirtation with subversion amount to airplane pablum.

title: It's In The Blood
review1: This direct-to-video horror flick has some good ideas working, but the execution (especially the writing and direction) is weak.

title: The Impossible
review1: Alas, the movie tells a rather commonplace story.
review2: We've seen video accounts of this horrific tsunami, but little prepares viewers for its realistic re-enactment in The Impossible. And little prepares the film's principals for the terror that ensues.
review3: What's meant to be a triumphant true story about succeeding under impossible odds ends up feeling more like a Lifetime TV movie.
review4: Their story may not be typical, but the family represents the resilience, compassion, and optimism of the whole human race.
review5: An emotionally-captivating and well-filmed true tale.

title: Any Day Now
review1: Too much of "Any Day Now" founders in cliche and predictable table-turning and point-scoring instead of building a set of complicated characters at odds with a biased system.
review2: A movie that embraces melodrama and is elevated by its willingness to do that.
review3: As a weepy and capitalised Important Tale, the film is very good and some moments stir up emotion, but it isn't the film it should be, failing to hit the heights it is so earnestly aiming for.
review4: Young Leyva has a smile that lights up the screen, but the film makes the mistake of depicting several of the characters as though they were villains from some lesser movie. That the film overcomes this approach is testament to its essential spirit.
review5: Any Day Now is a movie of good intentions and bad wigs, warm-hearted but slightly oversimplified.

title: Promised Land
review1: The road to movie hell is paved with good intentions.
review2: Damon and Krasinski's script isn't completely solid, but it follows a believably wayward path to a lovely, muted ending.
review3: An engaging film about the dangers of fracking and the crass manipulation employed by its proponents.
review4: The film never makes a convincing argument against fracking, probably because it's too busy being cloying.
review5: Gus Van Sant's Promised Land is an engaging performance-driven drama that works more often than not.

title: Gangster Squad
review1: Gangster Squad looks the part, but it's so superficial it practically evaporates before our eyes.
review2: Okay, so maybe nobody expected Gangster Squad to be in the league of, say, Chinatown or L.A. Confidential, but even on the level of pure, bullet-spattered fun, this thing is so vaporous that it slides out of memory even while you're watching it.
review3: Gosling's smirk conveys a contempt for the material rivaled only by my own.
review4: Probably the year's most squandered cast, in a boring, by-the-numbers crime film that plays like a fifth-generation re-do of "L.A. Confidential,"
review5: A nod toward nostalgia, a grandiose display of the arrogance of the present: this seems to be the whole program of Gangster Squad.

title: Magic Journey To Africa
review2: Vivid dreamlike adventure to Africa is offbeat but inspired.

title: Wuthering Heights
review1: Arnold drastically pares back dialogue and exposition, telling the classic tale of passion and revenge with probing, harshly sensual camera work and a minimum of sentimentality.
review2: In reality it's a bit of a slog.
review3: Arnold has been successful in reimagining the story's archetypal emotions in the story, bringing it closer to its passionate elements.
review4: Arnold ... has put her stamp on Emily Brontë's 19th-century novel Wuthering Heights, but it's a smudged and imperfect stamp, to be sure.
review5: Essentially a misunderstanding of (or an inability to convey) the breathing soul of this material.

title: Wasted on the Young
review2: Wasted on the Young's pulsating soundtrack, immediate direction by first time filmmaker Lucas ... and Leanne Cole's hectic editing all lend the film a vibrancy that is sorely lacking in a lot of cinema these days.
review3: A scorching ultra modern morality fable that uses school grounds, party houses and internet connections as stomping grounds for social allegory.
review4: Visually impressive, but the script needed a big angry red pen taken to it. Oh, and does every character need to shuffle around like they're in a My Chemical Romance video clip?
review5: Wasted on the Young is a slick and striking film that presents a disturbingly recognisable world of plutocratic rule in the dark heart of Australian society.

title: Pawn
review1: Hostage dramas have conventions; if "Pawn" skirts too close to them at the end, and has too many characters, it still keeps the game interesting.
review2: "Pawn's" cops and robbers game could have been far better played.

title: K-11
review1: A sordid prison drama that struts an unsteady line between full-on camp and "Oz"-style Darwinism.
review2: "K-11" has the makings of a cult movie campfest but little of the authentic wit, edge or outré vision it would take to get there.
review3: Points for niche audaciousness, but that's all.
review4: Like an on-the-nose parody of Lee Daniels directing an episode of Oz, K-11 is a pulpy, tone-deaf mess of confused directorial intent ...
review5: Pulpy prison yarn lacks conviction.

title: Walk Away Renee
review1: "Walk Away Renee" lets us observe a mother-son bond, but Mr. Caouette hasn't found a way to galvanize this incarnation of material for strangers.
review2: Produced on a far more elaborate scale than "Tarnation,'' which Caouette assembled at a cost of $213.32 on his boyfriend's laptop computer. And that's mostly not a good thing.
review3: Renee really does feel something like a remake of Tarnation, this time with more budget and less feeling.
review4: Caouette certainly knows how to manipulate images and sound, painting on a vibrantly textured, semi-experimental canvas. But aside from visual stimulation set to some cool music, none of the fictional stuff adds much.
review5: Hermetic, autobiographical, messy, and ultimately touching.

title: Joven y alocada (Young and Wild)
review1: The film's sexual intelligence is undone by a paralyzing voice-over and an encroaching case of the blahs.
review2: The young actors' vacant-eyed brazenness may be true to life, but there's a whiff of exploitation, matched by the script's disinterest in exploring any friction that isn't skin on skin.
review4: A film that respects sex and the emotional consequences that follow once the heat wears off. It also is not a condemnation piece about religion even as it calmly exposes the hypocrisies of suppressing the natural order in order to let go of one's ego.

title: Little Red Wagon
review1: There's weighty material waiting to be processed here, but in "Little Red Wagon" it doesn't have a home.
review2: Even the cheesiest inspirational flicks have to be populated with characters who have something at stake. Conflict is the heart of good storytelling, and "Little Red Wagon" is conflict-free to the point of catatonia.
review3: Inspiring story of a boy's efforts to help homeless kids.
review4: A double whammy about the crusade of a big-hearted boy who helps homeless children and a depiction of the plunge of a mother and her son into poverty.
review5: Well-intentioned, but a little heavy-handed and manipulative.

title: Les géants (The Giants)
review1: Bouli Lanners paints his story a little hazily, perhaps, but his gorgeously unselfconscious actors are faultless.
review2: It is for discerning movie palates, prepared to go with the flow of the leisurely pace that contrasts with the intensity
review3: The tranquil beauty of rural Belgium and three outstanding juvenile performances are the highlights of this moody and haunting film that offers an unsettling glimpse of the pain of adolescence
review4: A tremendously-promising French-language Belgian film about growing up the hard way.
review5: If you watch The Giants with no strong sense of urgency it's quite a beguiling portrait of resilient kidulthood.

title: Not Fade Away
review1: The movie is a psalm to those who, far from pursuing the path of the Rolling Stones, stayed trapped under a rock.
review2: This film could have been -- should have been, even -- something special. But it's not.
review3: The period details are spot-on and the soundtrack is great.
review4: There's a nice, pop-in-and-see rhythm to the storytelling. Gandolfini's Pat descends into a rich sadness. There's wry humour to be had with Douglas and his idealizing buddies. Loneliness and longing lounge around together.
review5: Hits notes you thought only Chase's primo Sopranos could reach.

title: Broken City
review1: It's a local-government corruption thriller that doesn't care about logic or consistency or the people watching it.
review2: Broken City is passable, occasionally entertaining but ultimately uninspiring.
review3: A complete mess, this drama is packed with sophomoric political ideas, unfocused storylines and inane dialogue.
review4: the screenplay, filled with hackneyed implausibilities and trite characterization, constantly lets everyone down
review5: It is predictable procedural fodder - you can see the "twists" coming a mile away - but done with enough conviction to paper over the plot holes and cliches.

title: The Man Who Shook the Hand of Vicente Fernandez
review1: It gives film fans the chance to see the late Ernest Borgnine in his last acting gig and to see that he clearly relished every opportunity to perform. Unfortunately, the film surrounding him is a pulseless homage to spaghetti westerns.
review2: Borgnine's robust performance keeps the pic grounded in a melancholy reality of frustrated dreams, bitter resentments and last-chance opportunities for redemption.
review3: A playful paean to a movie genre and a prolific career, Ernest Borgnine's valedictory feature is a spaghetti western with a heavy helping of cheese.
review4: The late Ernest Borgnine receives a moving send-off in his final film, The Man Who Shook the Hand of Vicente Fernandez.

title: Bunohan (Return To Murder)
review1: The pace of these scenes can be trying -- and would be torture for viewers who came expecting a more conventional Asian crime film -- but it suits the movie's concern with family histories, rural isolation, and the inevitability of development.
review3: The film is too ambitious for its own skills.

title: Revenge for Jolly!
review1: I'm really not sure what the point of Revenge For Jolly! was, and I can assure you I'll never care enough to find out after my one and only viewing.

title: Safe Haven
review1: A movie whose punch line is so delightfully absurd that even after you pretty much know what's coming you spit out your Pepsi anyway.
review2: Keeping up with the movie's inane plot twists makes for a capricious good time, but an unimaginative denouement turns the whole thing into a fool's errand.
review3: All the usual romance and idyllic locations-and-vengeful-violent-ex-husband, up until the weirdest, most out-of-nowhere plot twist ever.
review4: few will leave the cinema feeling they've seen something original or affecting
review5: While a predictable chick flick, Safe Haven is never dull. It's not particularly good, either.

title: Clandestine Childhood
review1: Ávila can't quite thread the needle between telling his personal story and connecting it to larger social currents.
review2: 'Clandestine Childhood'' is the impressive first feature by Argentine director Benjamín Avila.
review3: When a filmmaker proves as reluctant as Mr. Ávila to speak up about the past, to engage with its full complexity, it can be hard to hear what he's saying.
review4: The calmer scenes are staged in staid and somewhat clunky fashion, but the graphic animation depicting the worst moments is starkly effective.
review5: Outré flourishes don't fully lift the story past the limitations of innocence-lost storytelling.

title: In The Hive
review1: Duncan commands our attention in a way he rarely had the chance to in his career.

title: Starlet
review1: Baker effectively juxtaposes two vastly different worlds, though he never makes the case that either is as significant as the gauzy visuals suggest.
review2: This is confident, engrossing storytelling, and the actors are terrific.
review3: Starlet sneaks up on you.
review4: Where it counts, "Starlet" ... allows its characters room to maneuver within the potential cliches.
review5: The film itself deserves praise for its portraits of these two women and the different worlds they inhabit.

title: Mighty Fine
review1: A well-meaning but unstable hand at the tiller, and a propensity for charting plot points, rather than a clear narrative destination.
review2: If you can overlook Andie MacDowell's Mitteleuropa accent as a Jewish Holocaust survivor (I know: big if), the cinematic roman a clef "Mighty Fine" has some quiet charms.
review3: "Mighty Fine," unfortunately, isn't.
review4: Mighty Fine is an incisive portrait of an insecure, manic-depressive tyrant that Mr. Palminteri makes entirely believable.
review5: Too many directions can be as much of a liability for a movie as too few, and "Mighty Fine" heads in all of them.

title: If I Were You
review1: Here's a safe prediction: movie critics are going to have fun with the title of If I Were You.
review2: "If I Were You'' has more than its share of laughs, but director Joan Carr-Wiggin needed to cut half an hour to make this fly without interest flagging.
review3: Harden is a wonderful actress but struggles to find the complexity in so strained a situation.
review4: Buried in the bloat of Joan Carr-Wiggin's interminable "If I Were You" are the seeds of what might have been a lean, snappy farce about duplicitous, adulterous games.
review5: Bloody awful.

title: Deep in the Heart
review1: A well-meaning tale of descent and redemption flatter than a Lone Star prairie.
review3: Gries is one of those greatly underappreciated actors, so to see him here in almost every frame of the film is a delight.

title: Norman
review1: Byrd and Jenkins earn the film its critical points, but the screenplay has too many moments that feel network-TV-bland.
review2: There's something sweet about Jonathan Segal's modest high school drama, "Norman," despite the contrivances of its protagonist's predicament and its stacking of the emotional deck.
review3: There's a winning emotional truth in the father-son scenes in this Spokane-shot sleeper, directed with skill and sensitivity by Jonathan Segal.
review4: For first-time screenwriter Wingate and Segal, in only his second feature (2004's "The Last Run), it's impressive work - they never overplay the pity card, opting for insight into the complexities of growing up instead.
review5: The director, Jonathan Segal, skillfully builds on the tension that this situation creates, though he can't quite make Wingate's ending click. Still, Segal is so good with his actors that you may not mind.

title: The Oranges
review1: The intervention of Tony Soprano, who lives not far away, is urgently called for.
review2: The Oranges dabbles with transgressive ideas (for a moment it felt like the film was implying that infidelity could be a positive force in everyone's lives) before retreating into stupefyingly predictable and safe rhythms.
review3: Although the film suffers during certain plot developments, the set-up and much of the dialogue ring true in this dramedy.
review4: It's the cast that carries a film like this, offering a strong level of acting gravitas to support a bitingly cynical script about the tawdry happenings in a suburb.
review5: The problem is that there's nothing terribly funny about families and friendships being torn asunder.

title: Barrymore
review1: Think of it as one great performer saluting another.
review2: Plummer commands the stage as easily and firmly as Barrymore must have. He makes us believe that Barrymore would indeed, as he tries to reach deep into his past and revive Richard, keep recalling his wives or breaking in to sing a pop song of the day.
review3: The interest is in Plummer himself-who he is, what he can do.
review4: Mr. Plummer stumbles beautifully, poignantly and often, leering and searching through a haze of memory or, with concern edged with panic, calling for 'a line, a line' much as Richard III calls for a horse.
review5: You wish you could be seeing this performance live, as it's meant to be seen - but lacking that, "Barrymore" on the big screen provides its own thrills.

title: Jack Reacher
review1: There is a dogged leanness to Reacher's pursuit that lifts his adventures from the generic rut ...
review2: Plain, cleanly directed meat-and-potatoes action filmmaking that aspires to competence and simplicity. A nice change of pace.
review3: Usually McQuarrie keeps things light, letting us enjoy the fantasy of one man defending himself against five enemies with nothing but his fists.
review4: Christopher McQuarrie's Jack Reacher is that rare blend of hard-hitting action and smooth-talking dialogue that makes for an entertaining film.
review5: Cruise does his best to keep a straight face and make himself halfway believable as a brainy roughhouser - think of a less intense Jason Bourne - but ridiculous plotting undermines his efforts.

title: Upstream Color
review1: What the movie points to is worth following until you're left with an enormous map that you spend the rest of the drive trying to refold.
review2: Carruth's visual approach, saved from abstraction by his own rapid, forward-leaping editing, is extremely assured. Seimetz is a fine and expressively haunted actress. I look forward to the enigmas in Carruth's next picture.
review3: If the movie is a bit of a mystery, so is Carruth.
review4: Should you see Upstream Color? A better question may be: How many times should you see it?
review5: An equally frustrating and rewarding experience.

title: Back to 1942
review1: "Back to 1942" shows the director's mastery of chaotic spectacle, massed human motion and elegant camera movements.
review2: Director Feng Xiaogang captures the epic scale of the exodus as well as the often-harrowing details, yet emotional connection proves more elusive.
review3: A chronicle of unrelenting misery, sorrow and human degradation that has powerful moments but is hardly uplifting.
review4: It catalogs agony without making you feel it.
review5: Shifting between individual suffering (performed, not felt) and extended political and business deliberations, the pic displays its budget but not its heart.

title: Cloud Atlas
review1: Whatever your age, even if life is an ocean made up of many drops, you may resolve that life is too short for this errant nonsense.
review2: Even at its most risible, this oddball picture has a groovy, inclusive spirit that feels downright revolutionary in our sterile, blockbuster age.
review3: When the narratives are formally compared as an expression of karma and reincarnation, the juxtaposition is vacuous.
review4: This is a film that will be enjoyed most by people who haven't seen many other films.
review5: Personally, I felt ennobled by the inspiring ideas, and captivated by the impressive performances both in front of and behind the camera.

title: Liz & Dick
review1: Taylor and Burton deserved better, and Lohan should have shed her protective shell and made an effort to try and understand a psyche other than her own.
review2: Bowler and Lohan never approach the kind of magnetism that a movie about Burton and Taylor must conjure in order to be convincing.
review3: It feels throughout like those behind it made a deliberately campy, dumb, over-the-top and wildly unconvincing film to satisfy the whims of an audience eager to laugh at, rather than with, it.
review4: No matter what you think of the actors, the great period stylings, not to mention Cleopatra-period costumes, make this jewel-encrusted, cocktail-soaked, often tragic saga a rip-roaring good time.
review5: Campy and overwrought, Liz & Dick is not great art, but it's great fun.
