title: Nightfall
review2: Only the superb widescreen lensing of cinematographer Ardy Lam saves Chow Hin Yeung Roy's Nightfall from immediate and utter cinematic obscurity.

title: Donovan's Echo
review1: Halfway home to being a really good little clairvoyant thriller, Donovan's Echo would have benefited greatly from a Stephen King rewrite.
review2: Billed as a "supernatural thriller," Donovan's Echo feels more like an overwrought made-for-TV movie.
review3: The indie flick's heart is in the right place but, unfortunately, its arteries are seriously clogged up with syrupy sappiness.
review4: ...a passable short film that's been painfully, needlessly stretched out to feature length.
review5: It's technically sound, and features strong performances, but the storytelling is a bit weak.

title: A Common Man
review1: The movie's tagline is "No justice. No peace." I couldn't agree more.

title: Ecstasy
review1: Ecstasy is to ecstasy what Trainspotting was to heroin. Different times, different drugs, but the Scotland-set story of addiction and redemption is pretty much the same.
review2: Not so much chemical romance as serious downer, it all seems so old.
review3: A drug-fueled landscape impacted by the Thatcher years, characterized by Scottish working class misery and massive unemployment feeding the underground drug economy. And reflecting Welsh's own conflicting personas as cult figure, pariah and antichrist.
review4: Ecstasy attempts to conjure the same sense of insanity, musical muscle, and impish wit, only to stumble repeatedly as it struggles to put on a dazzling sound and light show.
review5: Its fondness for the writer and the drug film genre may be evident; however neither can turn Irvine Welsh's Ecstasy into anything more than an inferior homage.

title: Side Effects
review1: It's difficult to escape the impression that the movie is impressed only with its cleverness.
review2: Once Side Effects gets into its crime story, medication is swept aside by movie nonsense. The storyline goes into tangles that have to be dealt with very rapidly if the audience is not to start laughing.
review3: Where's Adrian Lyne when you need him?
review4: A chilling, disturbing portrait of the dangers of the pharmaceutical industry, as well as the evil of deceit.
review5: This movie isn't nearly as smart as it wants to be. It's the dunce wearing a valedictorian robe.

title: Struck by Lightning
review1: Colfer is still very young, but he needs to learn that "snide" is not a point of view.
review2: Ultimately, it all portends a much brighter future for Colfer than for Carson.
review3: If only "Struck by Lightning" had a sharper, stronger perspective, it might have made more of its conceit.
review4: Except for Ms. Janney's monstrous mother and an Alzheimer's-afflicted grandmother (Polly Bergen), "Struck by Lightning" gives its characters no dimension.
review5: There isn't much to say about Struck by Lightning, except that it's one of those interchangeable teen movies that lands in theaters in early January, the morgue for films nobody knows what to do with.

title: Beautiful Creatures
review1: Beautiful Creatures is like the Twilight movies but with a chaperone making sure the boys dance a foot apart from the girls.
review2: There's an air of contempt to the picture, with a lot of bored, talented people openly acknowledging that they probably should be doing something more productive with their time.
review3: A superficial supernatural story that aimlessly seeks to follow in the footsteps of 'Twilight.'
review4: May tap into familiar themes of forbidden love oppression, but it's the unique texture of the world, along with the phenomenal cast surrounding it that makes this the most promising teen supernatural drama yet.
review5: Surprisingly peppy and charming -- not transcendent of its narrowly defined genre, but a worthwhile entry in it, and not a bad film all around.

title: Stand Up Guys
review1: Thematic inconsistencies abound as Stevens aims for a tone somewhere between Grumpy Old Men, The Hangover, and Goodfellas.
review2: The pace is too slack, the gags too tired and the plot too hackneyed for the film to be more than fitfully engaging for all but die-hard Pacino and Walken fans.
review3: Thanks to Al Pacino, Christopher Walken, and Alan Arkin - mostly just for being charismatic old pros who are fun to hang out with - Stand Up Guys is watchable, occasionally amusing, not altogether insufferable.
review4: A messy script isn't enough to undermine these clever veteran actors, who manage to make the most of the humour, drama and action without ever losing their dignity.
review5: Stand Up Guys probably won't appeal to anyone whose father hasn't got friends of pensionable age.

title: O Som ao Redor (Neighbouring Sounds)
review1: One of the strongest feature debuts of the last decade ...
review2: The film promises a little more than it delivers, and at over two hours there are moments where it drags. But as a statement of intent, 'Neighbouring Sounds' is incredibly bold.
review3: Economically packed with social issues of wealth, property and class, and deft cinematic references, this is a movie built for the modern global high-rise condo market.
review4: Similar to the slow-creep style of Dogtooth director Giorgos Lanthimos, the narrative unfolds with escalating tension, the cause of which is heard and felt but not always seen.
review5: "Neighboring Sounds" presents itself not only as a character study, but also as an authentic socio-economic class study.

title: Charlie Casanova
review1: Lots of attitude, little accomplishment.
review3: This relentlessly one-note, indigestibly overwritten picture duplicates the experience of being trapped in a train carriage with a bore who's spent too much time at the drinks trolley.
review4: In this low-budget Irish tale Charlie Barnham (Emmett Scanlan) is a loathsome psychopath who regards the rest of humanity with sneering contempt.
review5: Charlie is unbearably and unintentionally obnoxious. I guess we are supposed to see some devilish charisma or glamour or wit, but he is just a tiresome prat.

title: In My End Is My Beginning
Yossi
review1: Knoller is wonderful as the emotionally cut-off, yet vulnerable Yossi, who yearns for something more from life, but feels both terror at the prospect and unworthiness to claim it.
review2: Yossi is an early spring breeze of a film - too delicate to be substantial but definitely holding the promise of warmth.
review3: It's serious about its characters and their emotions, but still finds room for humor.
review4: "Yossi" has an air of lightness but never feels insignificant.
review5: Eytan Fox depicts modern gay life and contemporary Tel Aviv with sympathy and knowing insight, and he excels at creating casual rapport among actors; yet in film after film he undermines these gifts with hamfisted melodramatic plotting.

title: Once Upon a Time in Brooklyn
review1: "GoodFellas" is just one of the movies that did this all much better before.
review2: Packing the screen with wiseguy-story regulars - like Vincent Pastore and a limp Tony Darrow, perhaps distracted by his recent legal difficulties - is fruitless when your movie is as pathetically inept as this one.
review3: Cathy Moriarty and other Scorsese alums pop up, but these mean streets feel too derivative to thrill.
review4: Once Upon a Time in Brooklyn's vision of the Mafia comes filtered through a needlessly complex screenplay, as if the creators felt the need to prove they've seen a few Arnaud Desplechin films alongside Goodfellas.
review5: Solid performances can't save the film from its banal, convoluted screenplay that leaves no room for interpretation or subtlety.

title: Open Road
review1: Melancholy drama has attempted rape, profanity.

title: Picture Day
review1: What Picture Day lacks in tension it makes up for in the writer-director's astute understanding of character and acuteness of observation.
review2: This unusual coming-of-age comedy boasts excellent character development and involving performances. It's a promising feature movie debut for filmmaker Kate Melville.
review3: Maslany is fantastic as the main character, and there's just enough irony and complexity to make this slice-of-life film seem relevant.
review4: Picture Day leaves a pleasant aftertaste, and I can't help but chalk most of that up to Maslany.
review5: ...a well-intentioned yet wholly misguided coming-of-age story.

title: Mold!
review1: Don't go in with high expectations. This film is cheesy and can't always deliver. But, I was happy enough to sit through this nonsense. You might like it as well.

title: Adventures Of Bailey: A Night In Cowtown
review1: Dog caper is a little scarier than other Bailey adventures.

title: Becoming Redwood
review1: There's a fine line between quirky and overbearing, and Becoming Redwood keeps stumbling over to the wrong side.
review2: In every teary exchange and pregnant pause, Becoming Redwood is desperately striving for heart. And in the end, this much arbour ardour is bound to win you over.

title: Father Goose
review3: Watching Cary Grant shuffle about like an angry, disheveled bum is funny to a degree that it wouldn't be for virtually any other actor who could have conceivably fit the role.
review4: One of Cary Grant's last pictures (he retired 2 years later) is one of his most commercially popular vehicles, with an Oscar-winning script by Peter Stone and Leslie Caron (who's half his age) as love interest.
review5: Though Cary Grant manages to get the most he can from the role, it's not enough to cover up the film's emptiness.

title: Lore
review1: Lore, from Australian director Cate Shortland, proceeds like a long-ago fairy tale, dark-hued, grounded in real-life 20th-century horrors.
review2: The young principals here, Malina and especially Rosendahl, are superb at conveying that premature hardening, their elastic minds pummelled by inelastic forces.
review3: The sins of the Fatherland send a German teenage girl and her Nazi-connected family on the run in Australian director Cate Shortland's vividly rendered and sensual drama Lore.
review4: Remarkable. Raw, disorienting and it never bothers to tell you what it can instead show.
review5: Cate Shortland infuses a fresh perspective and a haunting moral quandary to the WWII genre, bringing a little seen part of human history to chilling life.

title: Monday Morning
review1: Movies don't come much worse than "Monday Morning," a rambling, incoherent, ineptly assembled mess...
review2: Unpredictable, intriguing and unflinching, but somewhat uneven, heavy-handed and fails to pack a strong sociopolitical punch.
review3: When will independent filmmakers understand that formulaic film style can only spoil the non-traditional subject matter of their films?

title: Generation Um...
review1: Neither the film, nor the film within the film, hold our attention. Bummer, Keanu.
review2: Director Mark L. Mann seems to be searching for the meaning in aimlessness, and in lowered expectations. But too often the narrative left me feeling the titular "um."
review3: Meandering and affected, this tedious character study is as aimless as the lives it depicts.
review4: A slapped-together sub-mumblecore exercise that at times suggests a feature-length expansion of 2010′s "Sad Keanu" meme
review5: What does it add up to? Um ... I have no idea and don't really care.

title: The Dark Command
review3: Unusual Western, with eerie, sinister atmosphere, lots of political commentary, and strange relationships.
review4: Above average western covering the Quantrill territory, full of fiction over fact, and starring John Wayne and Roy Rogers.
review5: Nominated for the Interior Decoration and Score Oscars, this John Wayne pre-Civil War adventure is better than the norm due to Raoul Walsh's direction and good cast.

title: "Joshua Tree, 1951: A Portrait of James Dean"
review1: The movie is art and borders on art-film pretentiousness here and there, but there's no question that it's also mesmerizing and sexy.
review2: A prologue featuring French poet Rimbaud underlines Mishory's vision of the American actor as part of a line of iconoclastic artists. But his pre-fame Dean seems more sullen brat than talented maverick.
review3: Mishory's film walks the same forlorn street as that of Bruce Weber's 1988 Chet Baker documentary, Let's Get Lost, and shares its palpable fascination for an iconic individual cursed by both beauty and artistic genius.
review4: Matthew Mishory's A Portrait of James Dean: Joshua Tree, 1951, some will argue, is a triumph of style over substance.
review5: Its beauty is marred whenever it opens its mouth.

title: Charlie Zone
review1: There isn't a whole lot of style to Charlie Zone, but the movie-making is as determined and efficient (and thrifty) as Avery himself.
review2: Charlie Zone, with its dark vision, intricate plot and noir-ish style, suggests Melski is a Canadian filmmaker to watch.

title: Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You
review1: This cliche-ridden coming of age story is as painfully awkward as its troubled teen protagonist.
review2: Several kinds of excruciating.
review3: His pain may be useful to James someday, but to viewers, it's annoying right here and now.
review4: It might actually make audiences understand the urge to bully.
review5: These 2-D characters might as well be wearing T-shirts that say things like "Predatory College Professor" and "Self-Obsessed Father" on them.

title: Mosquita Y Mari
review1: In terms of content or plot, this film has little new to offer. Yet it is a small prize.
review2: Guerrero's attitude toward the teenagers - understanding and affectionate, without being cloying - is what holds your interest.
review3: "Mosquita y Mari," an unassuming indie jewel, resists all of the clichés that its story of the fraught friendship between two 15-year-old girls invites.
review4: [It] doesn't aim to make any grand statements. It doesn't need to. The sweetness and sincerity Guerrero and her leads infuse into their intimate coming-of-age story is more than enough.
review5: First-time writer-director Aurora Guerrero beautifully captures the fluctuating dynamics of friendship between 15-year-old girls in Mosquita y Mari.

title: The Last Ride
review1: Alas, "The Last Ride" doesn't deliver much insight into Williams or the lifestyle that killed him.
review2: The Last Ride doesn't give us a complete picture of Hank Williams. But it does ably illustrate the final days of his life.
review3: James does a fine job of portraying a naïve youth whose eyes slowly open to glimpse both the pleasures and the pain of living.
review4: Dramatically thin, formally uninspired and thematically weak, "The Last Ride" really goes nowhere.
review5: Bearing all the hallmarks of a small-budget labor of love, The Last Ride is a leisurely paced but modestly engaging road trip that gets considerable mileage from the byplay between its two lead characters.

title: Mr Hockey: The Gordie Howe Story
The Taste of Money
review1: This is a completely unenlightening cri de coeur against the most obvious targets of financial-spiritual discontent.
review2: Both bitter and delicious.
review3: Is there such a thing as "tastefully smutty"? Director Im Sang-soo's moody and semi-Shakespearian The Taste of Money walks that line with some artfully lit humping and cross-generational seduction.
review4: As the sexual, financial and criminal shenanigans get ever more complicated, absurd and melodramatic, the film becomes increasingly tiresome; it's not even possible to enjoy its excesses in a 'so bad it's good' way.
review5: A trite and tangled potboiler that, despite its polemical pretensions, is just a glorified Korean domestic drama with classier couture and shapelier champagne flutes.

title: Eden
review1: Cruelty, bloodletting and death are evident throughout (frequently occurring just outside the frame), and Griffith's laudable discretion actually intensifies their impact.
review2: Griffiths lays bare a many-tentacled trafficking system sickening in its reach.
review3: A quite moving performance comes from Jamie Chung as Eden, repulsion sliding into fearful acceptance without the extinction of hope.
review4: Nearly every second is taken up with the horrors inflicted upon the heroine by the sorriest bunch of good ol' boy sadists since "Deliverance."
review5: Griffiths and her screenwriter, Rick Phillips Jr., manage the tricky business of evoking the specific horrors of sex slavery without languishing in the lurid and graphic.

title: "3, 2, 1... Frankie Go Boom"
review1: Though deliciously rude and crude, '3, 2, 1 ... Frankie Go Boom' possesses a surprisingly sweet heart.
review2: A sub-Apatovian farce that tries way too hard ...
review3: A noisy stab at wacky wrongness that starts with reasonably plump possibility as a dispatch from the frontlines of viral video embarrassment hell.
review4: A vibrantly vulgar comedy that never hangs around to admire its own cleverness.
review5: Tragically unfunny, Frankie is occasionally elevated by some of its gifted and game cast, but the film's nasty, comedically incoherent script limits its potential.

title: Dead Man's Burden
review1: It's a strong debut for Moshe, who, with the exception of some of the oater dialogue, shows both a reverence for and a knowledge of the genre that's intriguing.
review2: Ponderous but lovely, simple but elegant, it should appeal to fans of Westerns.
review3: Small in scale but with a grand visual ambition, "Dead Man's Burden" draws nourishment from its burned-out desert setting and ambling pace.
review4: Despite visual nods to dozens of classic Westerns, the film cannot break through with its own vision.
review5: The story is modest to the point of occasionally seeming slight, and the ending is a tad too cute in the way it circles back to the beginning, but even those flaws just make it feel more authentic. See it now, before it gets rediscovered.

title: Knife Fight
review1: Lowe's Paul is slimy, but, lo and behold, we are supposed to believe that he smells like a rose. He really wants to make the world a better place. His sentiments may be genuine but they come across as a con.
review2: Meanders aimlessly around too-familiar territory.
review3: An improbable fantasy in which the people who make political advertising emerge as chisel-jawed heroes of democracy.
review4: Whether playing it sleazy or noble, Mr. Lowe brings little emotional weight to his role.
review5: [An] underwhelming, would-be political satire.

title: Wrong
review1: There's a winning confidence to the filmmaking, which is deceptively stylish - Dupieux favours nervy close-ups and blurred foregrounds - and some real soul in Plotnick's performance.
review2: Dupieux makes the viewer work for it with Wrong. And it's not always worth the effort ...
review3: Dupieux has to be applauded for creating a unique universe, but sometimes he seems stuck in it - to the point where we feel we're not always in on the joke.
review4: In Wrong, reality and the world of the film will regularly upend themselves; it's never quite reliably clear, though, that these inexplicable events are happening for a purpose.
review5: Dupieux doesn't make films for everyone, but he does craft creative and abstract trips that are more than worth going on, even if they're fantastically difficult to explain to anyone who has yet to join the club.

title: Snitch
review1: Snitch runs close to two hours, and it's a credit to Summit Entertainment that they didn't reduce it to 90 minutes of Mexican drug loons trying to run John's truck off the highway.
review2: Effectively illustrates the great heights we occasionally rise to for the ones we love.
review3: Although hardly original, this tightly paced story will keep you invested through to the end
review4: A pseudo-serious hand-wringing action drama that uses social importance to disguise its unoriginality.
review5: It's intense and involving from the start, even when it turns preachy.

title: Masquerade
review1: There are plenty of antecedents for the story, like "The Prince and the Pauper" and "Dave." But what it lacks in originality, it makes up for in Lee's performance.
review2: As predictable as these stories invariably are, Lee's wonderful turn reignites the potent fantasy of peasant wisdom - if given the power - melting politically cynical hearts and legislating through decency rather than fear.
review3: Following in the long tradition of lavish Asian epics, this new South Korean entry is a beautiful addition to the genre of period prince-and-the pauper themed films.
review4: Competently directed, the real pleasure in this high-grossing South Korean film lies in its performances, which lighten the regal solemnity with comic warmth.
review5: As entertainment, it's a decidedly unstuffy costume drama that's compelling to the end.

title: Ring of Fire
review1: Ring of Fire is a better than average Lifetime movie that will leave viewers hand-clapping, singing along and maybe sniffling a little.
review2: June Carter Cash is the kind of performer you just naturally tend to like, and you'll like her even more after seeing this new biopic.
review3: Jewel hits the right notes as June Carter Cash, but dutiful biopic doesn't quite carry a tune.
review4: Ross, who does a creepy, sniveling guy better than anyone, is totally miscast playing big, rough, tough Cash. In fact, it's so incomprehensible that it's, well, creepy.
review5: Except for the chance to hear a few country classics, the movie doesn't offer much else.

title: The Confession
review1: This movie posses slightly more edge than the network's standard fare, and a solid tandem in Katie Leclerc and Sherry Stringfield as its leads. It's also enough of a stand-alone story one needn't have thrilled to part one to join the buggy ride.

title: Fred Won't Move Out
review1: It has a great many shots of trees, leaves and insects and some story gaps.
review2: There is recognizable pain throughout Ledes' film. Yet it never pushes through to anything beyond a surface portrait.
review3: This carefully observed slice of life is dragged down by the dreary and distracting hand-held camerawork.
review4: Except for a subplot about a missing cat that suggests that Fred may be considerably dottier than he appears, the movie gets almost everything right about the uncomfortable moment when grown children are forced to be their parents' parents.
review5: Mostly, it captures how old age decimates even the people who don't suffer from it.

title: The Happy Poet
review1: [Paul Gordon generates] good-natured humor through earthy characterization and precise observation of what it's like to run a small business. (His editing, which often approximates the rhythm of workaday drudgery, is clever without being cutesy.)
review2: It's hardly slick, but that's the selling point. The Happy Poet approaches the ups and downs of friendship, love, work and life with a disposition that is both sardonic and sunny.
review3: This mumblecore entry sometimes sacrifices ambiguity for the sake of broader, telegraphed, one-note laughs.
review4: The smiley ending, most likely meant to be ironic, feels tacked on. But the consistent comic tone of those earlier scenes--a gentle squirm--makes The Happy Poet a promising debut.
review5: A cutting edge social satire about vegetarian pushcart power. And how work, or the lack of it, informs our lives. Along with the struggle to survive in hard times, while serving up poetic revenge subversion of the Hollywood happy ending with relish.

title: Room 514 (Heder 514)
review1: We get 2-character scenes with continual over-the-shoulder shots in the airless Room 514. Histrionics cry out a theme that lines of conflict are often blurred ... a ground that's been ground to death
review2: One of the finds this year is the Israeli pressure cooker Room 514

title: Marketa Lazarová
review1: By now, this burly, seething musk ox of a movie, arguably the most convincing film about the Middle Ages ever made, should be on everyone's tongue.
review2: A wide-screen black-and-white feast for the eyes.
review3: Episodic in structure, the film proceeds like a folk saga, but its flashbacks, flash-forwards, and abrupt cuts give it a hallucinatory quality.
review4: It's stark, daring and often astoundingly dynamic.
review5: In less than a minute, before the film's opening titles even conclude, Marketa Lazarová has announced itself as something potentially unique, perhaps indefinable.

title: Jack the Giant Slayer
review1: Forget that Giant Slayer feels photocopied and is entirely unnecessary. It's just not exciting.
review2: Almost fascinating in that, as far as I can tell, it is a film with no target audience.
review3: Underwhelming, as you might expect, but it's quite possibly the best Jack and the Beanstalk film you could imagine the studio system producing. Whatever that means.
review4: Despite its many flaws, Jack the Giant Slayer is not a bad film, but rather a disappointing one
review5: When you make a movie this awful, with no hint of useful self-awareness, you're not proving a point--you're giving up.

title: Stoker
review1: It's too safe, too knotty, too wastefully handsome, too dull.
review2: The shame is that while the film is as glossy as late DePalma, essential Hitchcockiness is swapped out for random ickiness, a sorrow in light of Park's own history of crafting sleek, liquescent, swamping fever dreams.
review3: Enthralling and tremendously entertaining.
review4: Will no doubt be dismissed by a few as little more than a work of filmmaking panache. The panache, though, is what makes the film great.
review5: It's real strength, perhaps, is in its gaps and silences, which allow director Park to go to town with mood, composition and imagery.

title: Quartet
review1: The film's scant plot plays second fiddle to Hoffman and Harwood's nuanced exploration of love so long unrequited.
review2: Dustin Hoffman's directing debut about retired musicians in the third act of their lives has a winning, classy charm for older audiences.
review3: The first thing to note is that Hoffman has apparently had a grand time working with these professionals, all of whom as residents of the home are splendid.
review4: More lethargically paced than even the slowest of its geriatric characters, the movie creeps along with all the dull, inoffensive inevitability of old age.
review5: Will she, or won't she, join the others on stage in a quartet rendition of Verdi? Not to worry: it all unravels splendidly in this teeth-in-a-glass comedic drama.

title: Upside Down
review1: Soon enough the worlds of Up Top and Down Below feel like distractions, CGI Potemkin villages.
review2: A Romeo and Juliet story for the age of CGI overkill, Upside Down zigs where it should zag and dulls where it should dazzle.
review3: Absent any emotional grounding, the film is a gorgeous, sterile construction, like a dream city unoccupied by humans.
review4: Simply put, this is one of the craziest films to come along in a while and I can confidently say that anyone who sees it will either hail it is some kind of crackpot masterpiece or dismiss it as one of the silliest damn things they've ever seen.
review5: It doesn't really develop its story, or its themes. It doesn't truly draw out its characters. It evokes no serious emotions. It has - in the end - no gravity.

title: The Wedding Party
review1: Clumsily cobbled, tonally confused romantic comedy...a terrific premise with strong leads is sadly derailed by too many side stories.
review2: An offbeat and entertaining ensemble piece that disappointingly ends on a lukewarm note.
review3: I don't think it's a film that aims very high and it sort of achieves what it aims to do, I think. I found it perfectly amiable.
review4: The improbabilities and sheer banality of Christine Bartlett's screenplay are almost overcome by the quality of the cast, but not quite.
review5: The Wedding Party may well have been a better film if the underdone premise of the fake wedding had been done away with altogether, because the movie is more interesting when it picks at the foibles and fears that gather around these couples.

title: The Lesser Blessed
review1: Despite [the movie's] issues, Doron has no trouble capturing the haunting grace of place and people and the harsh realities faced by "The Lesser Blessed."
review2: Part of the long march of misunderstood movie adolescents that leads from the frozen Canadian North straight down to James Dean's Los Angeles in Rebel Without a Cause.
review3: [Doron] has assembled a uniformly solid cast, starting with an impressive debut by Evans, whose brown eyes are both soulful and watchful. It's a performance that commands our attention and empathy.
review4: The emotions present in Anita Doron's film still feel fresh and universal, even if some of the dialogue is clunky.
review5: It's an undeniably noble effort from all involved, but the dreary denouement makes viewer feel lesser than blessed.

title: Black Pond
review2: The message of the film is that normal people can be abnormal at times. One wishes there were more abnormal British films such as this.
review3: Langham's performance may not rehabilitate his career. Perhaps nothing could do that. But Black Pond is really good: haunting, melancholy and strange.
review4: An assured debut with great performances and a wonderfully odd brand of British humour.
review5: You get your money's worth of surreal quirk but also pleasingly awkward comedy in this plucky Britflick, the dark tale of a family who bury a complete stranger.

title: Battledogs
review1: An entertaining B movie with a very good cast of genre notables.

title: No
review1: Gripping and suspenseful even though the ending is already known.
review2: The best movie ever made about Chilean plebiscites, No thoroughly deserves its Oscar nomination for Best Foreign Film.
review3: The most cutting gag is just how much Saavedra's political ads resemble his recent campaign for a diet cola. And the punch line is that they work.
review4: No is an open conversation about the very means by which we understand ourselves and our societies, the way that we internalize advertising and news footage. It's a manifestation of national memory.
review5: Larraín shows how idealism and venality sat side by side, how quickly the brutal circumstances in which Pinochet came to power were forgotten and how little seemed to change once he left.

title: Pusher
review1: Just stick to the original: Fate is always more fetching than formula.
review2: The characters that populate Pusher are surprisingly naïve and hardly the brightest of bulbs. So much for the image of the wily, street-smart criminal.
review3: The chief problem here is that Frank is neither likable nor very bright. For the most part, you're thinking, go ahead, bust his kneecaps.
review4: Prieto does what he can to keep things roaring along, but the overall effect is not a lot more stimulating than your average diet cola.
review5: We're ... left to cheer someone simply because there's really no one else to root for.

title: Into the White
review1: As dramatically potent as a B-tier Disney drama, Into the White, while displaying instances of complexity, is mired by cliché and melodrama.
review2: Generates a satisfactory amount of suspense and personality to achieve its limited goals, successfully spinning routine with welcome attention to character.
review3: [The cast] acquit themselves well, forging convincing and ultimately moving relationships as they learn how little petty political differences mean when starvation's at the door.
review4: The performances are more than adequate.
review5: Ponderous pacing makes this true-life tale a lot less enthralling than it might have been.

title: Beauty and the Least: The Misadventures of Ben Banks
The Rambler
review1: Misguided exercise in genre fetishism marks a forgettable misfire.
review2: What all of this means is, frankly, nothing. But it's a handsome nothing, at least until you get sick of the screaming.
review3: Foreboding images abound - crawling lizards, mysterious lights in the sky, a funereal assembly populated by grotesques - along with occasional ambient droning on the soundtrack and moments of mild humor and raw gore. Do the tableaus add up? Not really.
review4: The kind of movie where more effort seems to have gone into the cast's wardrobe than their dialogue.
review5: Writer-director Calvin Lee Reeder's randomly splattering take on the back-country-road movie.

title: The Girl
review1: Hitchcock biopic reveals dark side of acclaimed director.
review2: Hitchcock fans have vigorously disputed the film's version of events (scripted by Gwyneth Hughes and sanctioned by the now-82-year-old Hedren herself), but on screen it makes for gripping viewing.
review3: Uses the perils of immigrating to this country without papers as a backdrop for a poor white American woman's bumpy path to enlightenment.

title: The Tower
review1: Kim Ji-hoon overdoses on visual fireworks in a way that smothers any human drama mustered by the sprawling cast, whose marquee names are treated as mere icing on the cake.
review2: "The Tower" may be skillfully executed as an effects-laden opus, but its miniature portraits in courage are ultimately too jerry-built to feel like anything but filler between the combustive set pieces.
review3: Even at its best, The Tower is beholden to unearned emotional payoffs.
review4: Don't look for character development or deep meaning, but THE TOWER is a real roller-coaster ride.
review5: There are exploitation films and then some, but this Korean twin-tower disaster epic takes the cake for callously evocative imagery and sentimental schlock.

title: Inescapable
review1: The film tries to meld politically charged personal drama with the action-movie tropes you'd expect in a story set in the Middle East. (Chase through a crowded marketplace? Brawl at the hamam? Check!)
review2: The plot unfolds at a nice clip, but at no point does director Ruba Nadda evade expectations.
review3: One hopes "Inescapable" is only a momentary stumble for this promising filmmaker.
review4: A Canadian nonthriller that plays like a heavily sedated hybrid of "Taken" and "Not Without My Daughter" ...
review5: Inescapable is Nadda's first foray into thriller territory, and her inexperience shows in awkwardly mounted fight scenes and clumsy car chases, not to mention an almost fatally explanatory script.

title: Least Among Saints
review1: This quietly affecting indie film, about a Middle East war vet and the 10-year-old boy he takes under his wing, gently pulls the heartstrings while making dramatic missteps along the way.
review2: The results are too predictable.
review3: Though both actors deliver performances more credible than the plot that frames them, their authenticity only highlights the script's affection for improbable coincidences and an ending even Garry Marshall might consider too pat.
review4: A film in which any authority figure who can't magically sober up and play surrogate daddy for a spell is treated as either a meddler or a well-meaning, do-nothing skeptic.
review5: The top notch production qualities, great direction, and fantastic ensemble performances make this film a definite recommendation.

title: An American Girl: Saige Paints The Sky
review1: Sweet American Girl story about finding your voice.

title: The Girl
review1: It's unfortunate that Riker's strong central character and evocative location work get undermined, at every turn, by a plot that not only springs zero surprises, but reduces the terror and loss of Cornish's charges to mere life lessons for her.
review2: The Girl enlightens with an unusual insight into the courage, durability and struggle of the Mexican people while taking the viewer on a guided tour of a piece of the country tourists never see.
review3: In all aspects, The Girl can't help it-this is headline-torn cinema du tearjerking at its most generic.
review4: Hernandez is soulful and affecting ... and Cornish embodies Ashley's self-centered character with nuance and subtlety.
review5: "The Girl" wants to be eat-your-vegetables cinema, but vegetables are good for you. This misery fest is more like an eat-your-bark movie.

title: Crazy Kind Of Love
review1: Crazy Kind of Love is like a dramedy set in a parallel universe where nobody can tell the heroine is a raging psychotic, more than the coming of age story it intends. The only thing that ages here are unlucky viewers.

title: Temptation
review1: Perry's movies have become so thematically grandiose, visually incoherent, and self-defensively bourgeois that the only way to receive them lately is as a cynic.
review2: Perry has some worthwhile filmic models-Temptation gestures at Woody Allen in its setup, and Douglas Sirk in its melodrama-but he isn't even in the same star cluster as those greats.
review3: Look, we know what's going to happen. The movie's called Temptation, okay? Yet we still have to sit through more than an hour of flirty glances and repetitive conversations between Judith and Harley until anything vaguely adulterous occurs.
review4: Tyler Perry's Temptation is an awful, awful film and while it is easy to mock and dismiss, it is also kind of a shame to behold.
review5: Limp pacing and countless shots of Washington's skyline plague the narrative.

title: Spring Breakers
review1: The movie is too calculated to shock. Korine just wants to be the danger he's warning us about.
review2: Actual spring breakers will probably loathe the movie; it's really for the pale art majors who never went.
review3: The most extraordinary thing about Korine's direction is how he gradually shifts the position of the viewer from self-possessed outsider looking in to complete immersion during a denouement where there is no one worth rooting for.
review4: Sort of like what might happen if Jean-Luc Godard directed a Girls Gone Wild video, it's not just a movie that has its cake and eats it too. This is a movie that has its cake and eats more cake.
review5: Korine's most entertaining film to date.

title: White Frog
review1: The opulent Beverly Hills setting, in which every character lives in a mansion and drives a luxury car, is offered up without comment or, oddly enough, any sort of visual style to complement it.
review2: Like getting a half-dozen undercooked after-school specials at once, Quentin Lee's "White Frog" serves up a medley of messages and themes while generating no discernible dramatic heft.

title: Would You Rather
review1: Hardly a most dangerous game night at the movies.
review2: This restrained exercise in torture porn benefits from its clever concept and restrained execution.
review3: A derivative horror movie with highfalutin pretensions.
review4: Director David Guy Levy's witless homage to the "Saw" franchise and its ilk.
review5: With a bit less grisliness, it could have been a mystery dinner-theater performance.

title: Boy
review1: Even the inevitable flaws of the low-budget production are winning, showcasing as they do the narrative artistry that makes Boy so distinctive amid current factory-written studio productions.
review2: A simple story of coming of age and the bitter failings of hero worship that succeeds thanks to the impressive skills of its young star.
review3: "Boy" finds hope, and love, in the oddest corners.
review4: Waititi has reached into his past for a story that belongs to him alone.
review5: A film like this would have little chance without the right casting, and James Rolleston is so right as Boy, it's difficult to imagine anyone else.

title: My Best Enemy
review1: The film plays mostly as an uneasily satirical thriller.
review2: An awkward blend of anti-Semitic atrocities and identity-swapping absurdity, the World War II drama "My Best Enemy" struggles to find a convincing tone.
review3: The script relies on too many unlikely twists, but Bleibtreu manages to sell them all.
review4: A movie largely devoid of attitude or suspense.
review5: My Best Enemy bleeds suspense like a pin-pricked tire. It wants to be clever, but survivor tales bring with them too much muck.

title: Tyler Perry's The Haves and The Have Nots
The Power Of Few
review1: The picture... can't be said to break any new ground in the gritty, mean-streets genre. But it has a better-than-average cast and a few clever plot twists, and it ends up being an occasionally amusing time-killer.
review2: A ham-fisted, timeline-altering variety pack of crime set in New Orleans.
review3: The Power of Few still feels very "independent" and, more importantly, original. Even if its cast is filled with well-known actors, the film embraces risky, unconventional storytelling.
review4: I had never heard of screenwriter/director Leone Marucci before. But you can bet I will remember his name after seeing 'The Power of Few.'
review5: A jumbled, offbeat mash-up of conspiracy-tinged action and armchair philosophizing that is hamstrung by a strange combination of slapdash plotting and its own self-importance.

title: Bidder 70
review1: Though viewers may already be aware of how DeChristopher's 2011 trial ended, the film maintains a gripping air of tension and mystery leading up to the verdict (he was sentenced to two years in federal prison for fraud but released after 21 months).
review2: As dully earnest, disorganized and self-righteous as an editorial in a student newspaper ...
review3: "Bidder 70," for all its clumsiness, nails the way that a spontaneous act of courage can focus the mind and clarify an ideology.
review4: Seems designed primarily for teach-ins and rallies.
review5: DeChristopher's ability to move with intellectual seriousness and a light heart between festivals and courtrooms complicates the popular idea of The Man and what his brand of power can achieve.

title: The End of Love
review1: Creative people often mistakenly assume that the trials of their profession are compelling.
review2: "The End of Love" is an exceptionally intimate, human-scaled picture. It's also quite a special piece of work.
review3: Mr. Webber, a skilled actor, has not devised a narrative with sufficient momentum or tension to sustain much interest.
review4: There is plenty of evidence that Webber has something significant to say, and the gifts with which to express himself. Once he's ready to commit fully to his own vision, there's no end to what he might accomplish.
review5: Shot with tiny digital cameras to minimize the sense of intrusion, The End Of Love sometimes feels like a home movie, but that's also the source of its strength.

review1: A dramatization of what Robinson did and what it required, 42 will not disappoint.
review2: It's not easy to play a stoic, but Boseman anchors the movie, and when he smiles, 42, already such a warm story of such cold times, gets even brighter.
review3: The style of the film, lush and traditional, is nothing special, but the takeaway, a daily struggle for dignity, is impossibly moving.
review4: So 66 years after Robinson became the first black major league baseball player, here we are with 42, which has been made with such reverence for Robinson's importance that Robinson is barely there.
review5: A hero without imperfections can be problematic. But Jackie's nobility is more than well-earned, and tarnishing it for the sake of balance would be churlish. Besides, there's enough evil at loose among the white characters.

title: Wild Bill
review1: There's no faulting Fletcher's unfussy, quietly impressive directorial style. A solid start.
review2: With a concept and influences consciously in mind; fine performances by Creed-Miles, Poulter, and Williams; and approving cameos...Fletcher is able to put his best foot forward in this creditable debut.
review3: There's a lot more to this likeable crime flick than your usual dunderheaded Danny Dyer vehicle.
review4: An unusually affecting movie, with pitch-perfect comic moments, a lot of heart, and a beautiful final shot that acts as a crowning achievement for Creed-Miles.
review5: Dexter Fletcher doesn't overplay the cowboy angle. Instead, he puts most of his efforts into creating a believable dynamic between the father and his sons, and it's in this tangled skein of shyness, suspicion, loyalty and love that the film's heart lies.

title: From The Head
review1: Despite its claustrophobic setting and small-scale concerns, this low-key drama proves unexpectedly diverting.
review2: A remarkably assured debut.
review3: Griffith's wry dramedy is both a character study and a personal showcase, but his fatal flaw is that Shoes just isn't as interesting as the drunks, jerks, goons and dreamers who stumble into his lair to relieve themselves.
review4: An intriguing pop-psychology character study -- a movie of minor revelations but shrewd behavioral observations.

title: Will
review1: It's a silly symphony of embarrassment, a sentimental journey along a road paved not with yellow bricks but red cards.
review2: Barely five minutes in, Will is already choking on an airless script and bumping desperately off its flyweight supporting players...
review3: The idea is sweet enough, recalling Africa United, but the execution is painfully amateur. Improbable, hackneyed and very dull.
review4: This superficial family drama will appeal to many Reds' fans, but it's also so twee compared with Danny Boyle's Millions (2004) that it's unlikely anybody else will want to go near.
review5: It just feels rather silly, as if it assumes such a reverent audience couldn't possibly need anything as pedestrian as believable characters or a likely plotline.

title: Loose Cannons (Mine Vaganti)
review1: As virtual tourism, it's a success but as dramatic fare it's a distinctly thin bowl of zuppa.
review2: The feel is somewhat cloistered and the pace rarely gets the pulse racing but this is engaging and affecting stuff, handsomely shot and well acted: Ilaria Occhini is a stand-out as the grandmother.

title: Hunky Dory
review1: Golden-hued, feel-good treacle, the sort that the U.K. has tried to export ever since Billy Elliot.
review2: The golden-hued cinematography (a filming cliché that really needs to be retired) and the sometimes slack direction by Marc Evans are minuses ...
review3: At various moments this endearing but sudsy movie, which spills all over the place, evokes "High School Musical," "Glee" and "Billy Elliot."
review4: Hunky Dory flits along blithely from number to transporting musical number until it ends - with a sigh - and dodges any authentic engagement with its own ideas.
review5: Enthusiasm carries the day in this paint-by-numbers period tale, which is just charming enough to coast on its own clichés.

title: The Place Beyond The Pines
review1: What Cianfrance has written has scraps of surprise and a fine chase sequence, but it doesn't reach for the stars or the emotional cosmos -- or, at least, it doesn't know how to get there.
review2: Derek Cianfrance could probably be a great filmmaker if he wasn't trying so hard to be a Great Filmmaker
review3: Utterly compelling with a magic wand of storytelling from writer/director Derek Cianfrance along with co-writers Ben Coccio and Darius Marber, The Place Beyond the Pines is one of the more natural and stylistic endeavors of 2013.
review4: The Place Beyond the Pines isn't a bad movie; it's three bad movies strung together by implausible logic.
review5: A jumbled triptych that frequently meanders without finding its center.

title: Graceland
review1: Graceland ... has a ruthlessness rarely attempted by its North American counterparts.
review2: The film feels increasingly exploitative as it becomes more overtly political, illustrating various forms of injustice with blunt, sensationalistic imagery.
review3: A potent combo of hostage thriller and high-impact morality play.
review4: The social and economic pitfalls facing the vast urban underclass of Manila's sprawling metropolitan area are depicted with unflinching regard in Ron Morales' observant low-budget Filipino feature, a blend of ruthless crime drama and grim thriller.
review5: A tense, twisty cinematic artichoke brimming with moral complexity and intriguing shades of gray.

title: Cost of a Soul
review1: Technically accomplished but dramatically unconvincing.
review2: Kirkpatrick keeps stomping on the drama pedal while blowing the cliché horn, yielding scene after tired scene of predictable developments as the principals keep shoving guns into mouths and screaming obscenities.
review3: This low-budget drama has a gutsy handle on what makes a crime drama crackle.
review4: As one bloody encounter treads on the heels of the next, all that remains is a tiny indie undone by its own vicious ambitions.
review5: It's a lousy movie, but it has spunk.

title: The Silence
review1: Twisted, sad and undeniably disturbing, "The Silence" is a study in the sick ways of men.
review2: This is film noir at its noirest.
review3: A story of obsession, of the permanence of loss, of how deeds of the past haunt us, closing over our heads like water. It leaves you shivering, yet thrilled; waiting anxiously for this talented new filmmaker's next work.
review4: "The Silence" is framed as a multi-character police procedural, but like "Mystic River" and "Zodiac," its inquiries probe deeper and darker.
review5: Its measured pacing whispers art while its lurid subject matter screams commerce.

title: Kiss Of The Damned
review1: "Kiss of the Damned" is rather a hoot.
review2: An ambitious, if deeply flawed, vampire love story ...
review3: The confident, female-driven sensuality of "Kiss of the Damned" anchors this handsome nonsense.
review4: Cassavetes can film an erotic encounter worthy of the 1970s and the golden age of sex scenes, and that is no small compliment these days.
review5: "Kiss of the Damned" tries to give the vampire movie something it most definitely does not need: class.

title: Arcadia
review1: The ever-reliable Hawkes does what he can with the material, but his part is too thinly written to convince.
review2: The characters overall lack definition, and the writer-director is only moderately successful at accessing the pathos of a story that should be steeped in it.
review3: Ms. Silver's ability to translate the liminal into cinematic terms, to catch those moments between innocence and knowing, childhood and adulthood, unforgiving and forgiving, makes her someone to watch.
review4: Hits the mark as an emotionally authentic coming-of-age drama.
review5: The story is too slight to go the full distance of 3,000 miles cross-country without this viewer losing some interest.

title: Love And Honor
review1: "Love and Honor" suffices as old-fashioned, pie-in-the-sky entertainment.
review2: "Love and Honor'' may be politically clueless, but Hemsworth and the student journalist he hooks up with (fellow Aussie Teresa Palmer of "Warm Bodies'') do make an undeniably attractive couple.
review3: This trifle about two soldiers who sneak away to America while on leave unfolds in a world about as realistic as a flashback on a sitcom.
review4: Hemsworth has presence, but he also represents this film's biggest problem: It feels like a bunch of good-looking kids putting on a show.
review5: Everybody learns something about the illusion of love and the power of honor. It's hard to believe it wasn't written by Nicholas Sparks.

title: Pieta
review1: There is a touch too much of the handheld camera, but in general one senses that the very quality of the way this film was made is one of its justifications for being and for its raw moments.
review2: After being subjected to disturbing scenes of abject cruelty, rape and torture, my reactions shifted from squeamish revulsion to a reluctant yet growing appreciation for Kim's thematic ambition.
review3: The film's big reveal may not come as that much of a surprise; you may figure out where it's going well before the end. But it's the getting there that is, if not exactly fun, then certainly hypnotic.
review4: Fascination returns at the stirring climax, when the plot neatly twists and the film's apparently simple message turns deeper, and blacker.
review5: A vicious, torture-happy debt collector with some severe sexual peccadilloes is, erm, softened by the return of his estranged mother in Kim Ki-duk's deeply unsettling Pieta.

title: Ginger & Rosa
review1: Coming from anyone else, Ginger & Rosa would be a sensitive if predictable coming-of-age tale set in the mists of the distant past. But coming from writer-director Sally Potter, it's a major surprise.
review2: A near-flawless film, beautifully shot and cut, excitingly performed and deeply felt.
review3: Fanning is nearly perfect as Ginger navigates choppier waters than most teens have to. There is not a false note in her performance; no matter how melodramatic things become, everything about Ginger remains genuine.
review4: Anchored by a brilliant performance from young Elle Fanning, who renders the usual teen angst and disillusionment as something both deeply felt and oddly mysterious. The kid is a natural.
review5: Ginger and Rosa is a small flick that reminds audiences how exciting it is to see raw and sincere performances despite what kind of package they're delivered in

title: Black Rock
review1: 'Black Rock' is never dull, but it's hardly the attention-grabbing calling card its creator presumably intended.
review2: The writing tanks while the actors try to stay above water, but nobody leaves a trace on the radar.
review3: This is a lean and mean variation on a familiar theme, tense throughout, with some terrific performances.
review4: A tight-fisted little piece of gender-centric survival horror.
review5: Black Rock is a simplistic, predictable thriller that fails to become engaging thanks to idiotic characters and a by the numbers approach that has the audience two steps ahead of them.

title: Night Across the Street
review1: Elegiac, witty and deeply reflective, "Night Across the Street" strikes a mature and complex tone.
review2: It all has a sense of regret and almost relief. It haunts.
review3: Raúl Ruiz's elegiac, enigmatic and mischievous final film.
review4: Unusually suffused with the contrast between experience and memory, reality and surreality.
review5: These are the dreams of a man stepping out of this world, perhaps never more lucid and full of life.

title: Assault On Wall Street
review1: The film seems inexplicably tame, the least interesting execution of a radical concept.
review2: Boll spends so much time painting Jim into the corner required to "justify" his bonkers actions that once the film's fuse is irrevocably lighted, viewers may have already checked out.
review3: This zeitgeist-tapping revenge fantasy doesn't deliver enough guilty pleasures.
review4: It's as subtle and as silly as you would expect, with an ending that's both a rally cry and request for a sequel.
review5: Seemingly inspired by "Taxi Driver" with its security guard stand-in for Travis Bickle wasting Wall Street brokers who are arguably worse than the pimps in "Taxi Driver".

title: Khyi rgan (Old Dog)
review1: Old Dog has the look and feel of a documentary, which adds senses of urgency and immediacy to a tale that moves at a languid, but never boring, pace.
review2: While the rigid framing and wispy plot create an unfortunate inertia, they also magnify the occasional whimsical moment ...
review3: It's both a sly piece of ethnography and a social satire that reads like a cosmic joke...right up until its climax makes the chuckle catch in your throat.
review4: Stunning mixture of understated social criticism and minimalism a la Kurismaki.
review5: To the eye of the Occidental moviegoer, nothing much goes on. Underneath, however, roils a "cultural genocide" of generational, cultural, social and political upheaval.

title: Cloudburst
review1: It's a delight to see Olympia Dukakis and Brenda Fricker, superb talents and Oscar winners both, share almost every frame of Cloudburst.
review2: An affectionate twist on a classic tale of lovers on the lam, sprinkled with renegade hints of Thelma & Louise, Cloudburst is a life- and heart-affirming journey.
review3: The two actors...bring out the best in these two women in spite of the plot lapses and odd tonal shifts...you believe wholeheartedly that these two are deeply in love, and Dukakis and Fricker gift their characters with a real bond of intimacy.
review4: A rough-edged Olympia Dukakis steals much of this comedy road movie about two ageing lesbians who go to Canada to get married. Enjoyable, but unremarkable.
review5: In its peaceful moments, it's a gem, but the wild stabs at wacky comedy are usually groaners, a shame in a story that's so smart and savvy when it isn't showing off, being dense, or winding down to a painfully pat ending.

title: Filly Brown
review1: A routine music business cautionary tale, the film shuffles its decks ever so slightly by casting a Latino actress as its lead, but doesn't do enough to shed the exasperating confines of the star-is-born genre.
review2: More heartfelt, humanistic, and entertaining than such a clichéd showbiz cautionary tale has any right to be.
review3: Almost despite our will, the cast keeps us invested in Filly's furious resurrection.
review4: Unfortunately, the film is marred by a story, situations and stereotypical characters that strike all-too-familiar chords.
review5: A trite piece of storytelling, with character development and plot points that feel not so much lived in as borrowed from other movies.

title: Between Us
review1: What's left is an unpleasant visit with a pair of hateful married couples who, in due time, prove mirror images of one another. Symmetry has rarely been so dispiriting.
review2: The play-turned-film about marital friction is no Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
review3: This is what happens when artists with the best of intentions run up against the worst of artistic impulses.
review4: An attempt to gain insight into the complex, complicated, and often contradictory ways each and every one of us behave.
review5: "Between Us" is a showcase for great actors who could have used more consistent material to springboard off of.

title: Rushlights
review1: Polished but unmemorable.
review2: Maybe noir just feels a bit old at this point. No matter what, the movie isn't worth the Texas heat.
review3: They say it isn't nice to kick a dog when it's down. But man, there are a lot of dogs in "Rushlights"...
review4: There are too many twists in Antoni Stutz's uninvolving "Rushlights."
review5: It all dwindles into "Who cares" long before the end of the road.

title: The Demented
review1: The Demented plays out like every other generic infection thriller that you've probably already forgotten about, being much more safe and watered-down than insane. Not quite sure the title fits this snoozer...

title: Absence
review1: It's been 15 years - can we stop remaking "The Blair Witch Project" already?
review2: Mundane conversations and outings drag on while the central mystery takes baby steps forward, suggesting that a shorter running time or a more developed script might have better served the originality of the premise.
review3: Imagine for a moment what someone like Roman Polanski could do with such a loaded nightmare scenario. And then marvel at how thoroughly it's wasted in this threadbare throwaway ...
review4: There are many things absent from this found-footage horror movie, including suspense, logic, and originality.
review5: There's nothing here the best entries in V/H/S didn't do better in 10 minutes or less, and with the decency to kill off their unbearable protagonists much faster.

title: Raising Izzie
review1: Intense movie about orphans heavy on grief, faith.

title: Mud
review1: Glorious vision of youth and truth, love and loss, your name is Mud.
review2: An evocative highlight of the American movie year so far.
review3: Sadly, Nichols, who made the superb Take Shelter, gets mired in mood this time around. But there's still an evocative sense of childhood exploration, and a gritty performance by Matthew McConaughey.
review4: The type of film that's miraculously heartwarming, while also mournful and filled with sorrow.
review5: McConaughey masterpiece as a a man on the run in Mississippi.

title: The Sapphires
review1: This charming Australian import has a groove much like other low-key, let's-put-on-a-show indies such as Hear My Song and The Commitments, and never uses its social conscience as simply backbeat.
review2: The harmonies they strike in this reality-inspired charmer are sweetly sublime.
review3: You could drive an Abrams tank through the film's plot holes, but you'll likely be too busy enjoying yourself to bother.
review4: "The Sapphires" feels like a movie you've already seen, but it's nonetheless thoroughly enjoyable, like a pop song that's no less infectious when you know every word.
review5: "The Sapphires" sparkles with sass and Motown soul.

title: Antiviral
review1: How sick can fans of a celebrity get? Very, answers "Antiviral." Imagine fan fetish culture metastasizing. A pox on consumers and capitalists alike, Brandon Cronenberg sneers.
review2: If Cronenberg's not yet a dead ringer for his iconic dad, he's taken an intriguing first step.
review3: The pace is uneven, the energy sluggish (even the arrival of Malcolm McDowell in the third act doesn't pep things up) and the film feels overlong.
review4: A tough, almost willfully difficult movie, but it's fascinating more often than it is dramatically off-putting.
review5: Antiviral is what happens when you make a movie around a fleetingly interesting idea but forget to find a story in it.

title: Paradise: Love
review1: The striking compositions mingle childlike curiosity with adult decadence -- and natural beauty with garish consumer culture -- to provocative, even profound effect.
review2: That churning in your stomach may be unpleasant, but it's necessary for the film to deliver its knockout punch.
review3: The whole affair curdles into a feeling of unearned, defensive superiority.
review4: Ulrich Seidl: sadomasochistic provocateur or compassionate observer of the human condition?
review5: One of the most disturbing films I've seen in a very long time.

title: On the Road
review1: It's not a wreck of a movie; it's not a sleek race car either. But there's heat to be felt here.
review2: Walter Salles's warm but strangely staid adaptation of a piece of literature that was never meant to be tamed as cinema.
review3: Although the film is sensationally photographed and artfully directed and scored, it's ultimately strictly dullsville, man.
review4: Despite the obvious enthusiasm of the screenwriter, the director, and the actors for Kerouac's novel, they get it wrong. Probably nobody can get it right, since the power is in the words, not the story.
review5: Salles can't recreate the feeling of finding oneself in Kerouac's prose

title: Magic Magic
review1: The first half of Magic Magic is greatly enjoyable: the performances are strong, the photography is crisp and immersive, and the mood is ripe and ominous.
review2: It's refreshing to see something with a dramatic heart beating beneath its discomfiting exterior.
review3: It's a big load of much-ado-about-nothing dressed up in writer- director Sebastian Silva's arty movements.
review4: Magic Magic's odd denouement is a dramatic curveball that smacks the viewer square in the face.
review5: A shapeless mess.

title: The Story Of Luke
review1: When it works, the film serves as a modest reminder that the challenges of autism may sometimes be no more daunting or fearsome than those that face anyone in search of an independent life.
review2: "The Story of Luke" is not a saga of epic proportions, but with a huge assist from Pucci's layered performance, takes a premise that could easily be movie-of-the-week sappy and finds a humanizing lightness.
review3: A feel-good story about an autistic man's quest for independence, The Story of Luke is a charming little film in need of a bit more grit.
review4: The first comedy gem of 2013.
review5: The outsized nature of their insensitivities is meant to reinforce the pain and humiliation from Luke's perspective, but it makes for a movie with an uneven tone.

title: Not Today
review1: Jon Van Dyke's "Not Today" doesn't qualify as a good movie, but it's built on an admirable foundation of good intentions.
review2: Writer-director Jon Van Dyke offers rugged production values, and his real agenda - getting Christian viewers to help end sex trafficking - mires the movie in self-conscious angst and speeches.
review3: Touching and Important
review4: Vitally important theme unstrung by shaky direction, writing and acting and a major flaw in subtitling.
review5: Well-intentioned, but slow, with no urgency and a lot of preaching.

title: To The Wonder
review1: Malick is employing his usual style of montage and voice-over narration but in a new, contemporary setting that makes Wonder feel like his most vital work in years.
review2: Love is a many-splendored thing, except when it isn't in To the Wonder, a wispy romantic movie about the death of a romance.
review3: What is most affecting is Malick's intent. He plainly devised the story to give him a series of panels for the expression of feeling.
review4: Your response to all this depends extremely heavily on how much philosophizing and pretty pictures you're willing to accept in lieu of a story.
review5: To the Wonder shouldn't be passed off as "self-parody," but as Malick's self-destructed misfire.

title: Cavalcade
review1: A gloriously, heart-rendingly beautiful, stirring picture of a generation in British family life.
review2: It's rife with fey, unintentional camp like the scene in which a newlywed couple pledge eternal love on the deck of an ocean liner -- only to move away and reveal a life preserver labeled Titanic.
review3: Almost certain to be near the top of the list for 1933.
review4: This is the first big film out of the Fox studio since Sheehan's return there and this is a big picture from and on every angle.
review5: Nary a tear-jerking trick is missed (our family loses one son to the Titanic, the other to World War I), and the strangulation is compounded by the staginess since the film.

title: Dog Pound
review1: Without a strong political point (unlike its source material), "Dog Pound" feels hollow and hopeless.
review2: Neither the film's bark nor its bite leaves much of a mark.
review3: [A] snarling but predictable survival tale...
review4: Overheated melodrama of inmates at a juvenile detention facility hits all the prison-movie clichés.
review5: The plot willfully denies our satisfaction, often at the risk of compromising its own structural integrity.

title: Compulsion
review1: At the very least, Compulsion is easy to watch, even if doesn't ultimately come together as the shocker Coccimiglio imagines it to be.

title: Errors Of The Human Body
review1: An underheated mad-scientist tale cares more about emotional baggage than thrills.
review2: Benefits from a riveting lead performance by the piercing-eyed Michael Eklund, who brings a brooding, destructive impulsiveness to his geneticist Geoff Burton.
review3: More brooding thinkpiece than sci-fi thriller, and yet fans of brooding thinkpieces may not be wholly satisfied, either.
review4: A tight, twisty little sci-fi thriller, directed with skilful economy by Eron Sheean.
review5: A brooding drama set in a medical research facility, Errors of the Human Body combines some elements of sci-fi and horror, albeit in passing

title: The Deep
review1: Kormakur's film suggests that the enigma of Gulli can somehow be found in his peasant humility, his connections to his community.
review2: Even knowing the outcome ... doesn't diminish the intensity and awe of watching it recreated in this deftly framed docudrama by prodigious Icelandic auteur Kormakur.
review3: Baltasar Kormakur's latest is a touching, low-key depiction of an incident in which a fishing boat sinks a few miles from shore.
review4: Director Baltasar Kormákur filmed on an actual trawler, which he sank, and its authentic-looking scenes will leave you shivering and reaching for a cardy.
review5: While filmed on the sea for the first half, the pic is powerful. Problem is when it goes ashore for the second half it loses some of its power.

title: Reality
review1: It's clear that Garrone is lamenting the death of culture. But the movie is more compassionate than screed-y. It's a portrait of the preoccupation with fame in an age in which in fame is cheap.
review2: The satire here is finespun, and the film's conclusions ambiguous.
review3: A dark allegorical comedy about the nature of fame, about obsession, about madness - and the point where they converge: on Big Brother, a TV show watched by millions.
review4: For all its ups and downs and occasional detours into boorishness, it's an original that will surprise if not necessarily delight fans of Garrone's very different crime drama, "Gomorrah."
review5: In this echo chamber of fame-for-fame's-sake, real life imitates reel life. There's a lurid, Felliniesque sheen to Garrone's floating camerawork; this is reality tweaked, dialed up to 10.1. And there's a cheeky, sideways satire of Roman Catholicism.

title: Olympus Has Fallen
review1: Olympus Has Fallen is made from action-movie mix. Just add sweat.
review2: A lot of footage of Gerard Butler skulking around dark hallways and neutralizing terrorists.
review3: To those who enjoy the Action Movie Fantasy, Olympus Has Fallen is one of the best examples in years.
review4: Let's be upfront. Olympus Has Fallen is dumb, violent, overlong, jingoistic, racist, predictable, derivative, and whatever other adjectives those with no sense of B-grade fun wish to throw at it.
review5: While never scaling John McClane-level excitement, Fuqua's film is good popcorn fun

title: The Guillotines
review1: The lack of rip-roaring martial arts or even a half-decent storyline will leave genre aficionados feeling short-changed.
review2: The plot is of little importance - the spectacular action and gorgeous landscapes and costumes are what matter.
review3: The blades fly as do the heads, but the movie remains disappointingly aground.
review4: The Guillotines expends most of its energy in its first 30 minutes, leaving the audience with roughly 90 minutes of soapy Qing Dynasty fan fiction.
review5: A historical action epic set during the Qing dynasty that amounts to a bait-and-switch for wuxia fans stoked for steel-meets-flesh mayhem.

title: The Odd Angry Shot
review3: A flavorful movie with stout performances and a distinct cultural atmosphere to help it maneuver through a few passages of stagnant storytelling.

title: I Killed My Mother
review1: As a director, Mr. Dolan has a freewheeling style, and he's self-dramatizing enough to want to call attention to it without being too much of a visual show-off.
review2: There's much to praise, especially the oh-so-real dialogue, but true psychological penetration is lacking and Dolan's hunger to prove his talent results in a superfluity of styles.
review3: Uneven but funny and audacious adolescent comedy from a talented beginner.
review4: A coming-of-age tale as ferociously raw as its teller -- the very young Xavier Dolan.
review5: What makes it extraordinary is its depth of feeling, which Dolan's age makes all the more impressive: he was just 19 when he made this.

title: Savages Crossing
review2: This low-budget direct-to-video might be worth a peak. Or, maybe not.

title: Post Tenebras Lux
review1: Reygadas' jagged, broken-logic drama lurches from fantasy to earthbound complications, though it is often hard to tell one from the other.
review2: The result calls for a viewing as different as looking at a Vermeer against Rothko or de Kooning or multiple other modern painters.
review3: Along with Bela Tarr and Terrence Malick, Carlos Reygadas is one of today's few genuinely religious filmmakers.
review4: Moviegoers beholden to clean narrative may feel they need their own explanatory GPS and audio guide. But the richer reward lies in allowing oneself to be led by this gifted director's instinct for lyrical, sensory exploration.
review5: This one delivers a grand pictorialism and piercing existential moments that float atop the maundering narrative like noodles in soup.

title: The Unspeakable Act
review1: Sensitive subject-matter is handled with tact and intelligence in this tart if talky US indie.
review2: [It] is about the familiar more than it is about the forbidden.
review3: You couldn't accuse the cast members of being good actors (several struggle to be merely amateurish).
review4: The result is a film as sensuous as it is intelligent.
review5: Sallitt dedicates "The Unspeakable Act" to Eric Rohmer, and there is some of the cloistered hush of Salinger's Glass family here, but this fluent film has its own serene yet vivid life.

title: Vampire
review1: The storytelling that veers between amateurishness and the kind of oddball dreams you wake up scratching your head about.
review3: Vampire is an agonizing bore, traipsing along on the assumption that just because it is trying to be different, that does not make it special.

title: Shadow Dancer
review1: The film relies on terse dialogue and boggy colors to create an atmosphere dense with anxiety -- all well handled by director James March.
review2: A respectable political/psychological suspenser, but not a wildly entertaining or enjoyable one.
review3: A tautly minimalist, occasionally generic study of betrayal and family ties.
review4: [Riseborough's] work is indrawn and riveting. It's hard to read the look in her eye, but we never stop trying.
review5: This British thriller by James Marsh is a little too neatly scripted and tightly edited for my taste, but there are galvanizing performances from Andrea Riseborough... and Clive Owen.

title: Amour
review1: This is realism that enlarges our conception of the term.
review2: Now at the end of the year comes a masterpiece, not just the best of the year, but one of the best ever: Michael Haneke's Amour.
review3: It's a chilling, pitiless vision that offers no relief, just a portrait of decline.
review4: Michael Haneke's profound new film Amour is far from your standard Hollywood romance. It is also a more nuanced, challenging and thought-provoking experience than that one word might lead you to believe.
review5: Amour is a brutally difficult viewing experience, but it's in no way a film you'll desire -- or be able -- to forget.

title: Floating City
review1: Ho's direction, his beautiful capture of the figurative and literal city and bold choices in editing, keep the entire film engrossing and worth every moment of the time it takes to view.

title: 33 Postcards
review1: Innocence meets experience, unconvincingly, in the strained redemption drama "33 Postcards."
review2: Were it not for the staccato bursts of violence, this Chinese-Australian co-production about how an adorable orphan brings love into the life of a hardened convict would feel like a film from Hayley Mills' heyday.
review3: It's all in the name of heartstring tugging, and the film, directed by Pauline Chan ("Little White Lies"), does that pretty well.
review4: There's no explaining the presence of Guy Pearce in Pauline Chan's sappy, atonal family drama. But it's easy enough to understand why he looks so uncomfortable throughout.
review5: A clunky hybrid-half feel-good weepie, half preposterous thriller-that functions primarily as an elaborate travel brochure ...

title: At Any Price
review1: The disappointment and malaise of a modern farmer's life comes through, but almost as an afterthought. As Bahrani makes clear, it's worth a more focused film.
review2: Bahrani fills the frame with weathered faces and "At Any Price" feels like it unfolds in something close to the real America. But he wants to give us larger-than-life drama, and his strengths are life-sized.
review3: "At Any Price" is so driven by its plot that it fails to connect its characters with moviegoers in any meaningful way.
review4: After fearlessly diving into a character that's self-centered, wretched, and downright degrading, Quaid outdoes most of his earlier works of cinema.
review5: Tough, engaging, and brutally honest, At Any Price is one of those quiet gems you hope others will have the opportunity to discover for themselves.

title: Kon Tiki
review1: Kon-Tiki is a widescreen man-against-nature epic, beautifully shot and boasting seamless, stunning visual effects.
review2: While requiring little effort to get immersed in this tale, such is the strength of this compelling story - if there is one thing to take away from proceedings, it's that it is worth catching this in its original, more authentic form.
review3: Directors Joachim Rønning and Espen Sandberg certainly seize the opportunity to deliver a spirited high seas adventure, taking some creative liberties along the way, but remaining true to the spirit of the times and the participants.
review4: Considering we all know the outcome, the levels of tension remain impressive, while an atmosphere of melancholy tempers even the most triumphant moments.
review5: It is beautifully shot and has the same fierce intelligence about it that you find in its producer's other epic "quest" movies.

title: Upon a Midnight Clear (Born This Way)
The Great Gatsby
review1: For all the antic, manic itchiness of his Gatsby, for all the jazz hands, the movie doesn't reach out and grab you.
review2: Luhrmann is quite content to stay on the surface, to rub elbows with tuxedoed gents and bewitching flappers.
review3: Based on a book that's not particularly well-suited to movies, the film is a chintzy, 3-D muddle in which Leonardo DiCaprio happens to be amazing.
review4: ...of such bacchanalian proportions that it requires an act of will to sit there passively as the senses are not merely assaulted but pummeled into submission. It's akin to watching a play staged on a carousel.
review5: As a filmmaker, Baz has fine technical knowledge but he never knows when to call cut.

title: "Life, Love, Soul"
review1: "Life, Love, Soul" has its heart in the right place. Unfortunately, nothing else is.
review2: Mannered dialogue and a limited number of functional set locations (living room, classroom, bedroom) leave the material feeling stilted and claustrophobic, constricting any sense of genuine tumult or passion.

title: A Company Man
review1: With a more interesting storyline and better supporting actors to pair with its terrific action sequences and emotive leading man, A Company Man could have been more than half of a great movie.

title: Stranded
review1: It's a scrappy, unpretentious movie, with nicely calibrated pacing, but there's no logic, little motivation and above all, no personalities.
review2: It may be time for everyone to agree that if you've seen one trapped-in-space-with-an-alien-presence movie, you've seen them all.
review3: Sometimes an earnest, easily forgettable B-movie is just what you're looking for. But rarely do you feel like spending 12 bucks to see it - especially when that appears also to be the film's entire budget.
review4: "Stranded" stops at being merely seriously dull and trite, rather than tipping into train-wreck silliness.
review5: Slater is supposed to be incredulous about the existence of the alien threat, but he mostly seems incredulous about the script.

title: The English Teacher
review1: A potentially incisive character study is buried under layers of fluff in The English Teacher.
review2: Apropos of its title, The English Teacher feels like a movie written as a homework assignment.
