review3: The report card for low-key high school comedy The English Teacher would read something like this: Weak effort; this student is too easily distracted, fails to follow through and turns in unfinished work.
review4: Pleasant is the perfect word with which to describe The English Teacher, an ingratiating little comedy that aims to please and succeeds at its modest goal.
review5: The movie doesn't do enough with its cast or its idea; it's an underachiever that simply doesn't try hard enough.

title: Camp
review1: The film, though nicely performed, rarely builds into the kind of gripping emotional journey it clearly intended.
review2: The world could use a few more movies like Camp.

title: Going Down In La-la Land
review1: It's...familiar plotting and by-the-numbers characterization that sinks this earnest, gay-contoured take on the evergreen making-it-big melodrama.
review2: A young acting hopeful finds that things are tough in Tinseltown in this not exactly revelatory gay-themed drama.
review3: "Going Down" falls well short of compelling, either as a coming-of-age film, a satire or a romance.
review4: A lo-fi feature blend of True West Hollywood Story and a gay fairy tale.
review5: A creditable if familiar portrait of one aspiring-actor newbie's disillusioning wade into the rough waters of Hollywood.

title: Beyond the Walls
review1: The arthouse normalization of the gay romance continues apace in [this] carefully crafted, gently moving debut feature.
review2: Solid in construction and persuasively acted, the drama is strongest in the establishing sections of intoxicating passion.
review3: This is a slow burning film that takes a while to get going but ultimately packs a bigger punch than you'd expect.

title: I Do
review1: The combustible possibilities surrounding a same-sex marriage involving partners of different nationalities is turned into rather tepid stuff in I Do.
review2: Uneven comedy/drama tackles hot button issues like gay marriage and immigration.
review3: A sweet, sincere, yet ultimately tepid story ...
review4: Someday, when gay Americans enjoy full equality, we can all hope their sexuality will finally stop being used as fodder for dopey, hopelessly contrived dramas like "I Do."
review5: In a better movie you might play along with contrived plot twists and fake obstacles, but watching "I Do," a movie with thin characters and a languorous pace, you find yourself talking back to the screen.

title: Blancanieves
review1: What Berger does with the actors, the sight gags, the close-ups, the music, the photography is close to perfection.
review2: This year's crowded field of Snow White movies has a winner, at least in terms of quality, in Pablo Berger's delightful Blancanieves.
review3: Berger, like his rad forebear Luis Bunuel, marries poetry to film.
review4: While the story, shorn of its supernatural elements, is mired in abuse and tragedy, its effect is sensual and superficial.
review5: We're not in Disney's world. Berger knows his Grimm, and he suffuses his entrancing fairy tale with a moving sense of melancholy.

title: Petunia
review1: It's possible to make a great movie out of family dysfunction, but this one is too short on insight to rank with the best of the genre.
review2: The movie is never deeper than the average sitcom episode ... which makes Lahti's A-game that much more valuable.
review3: Petunia augurs more titillation than it delivers and only works occasionally.
review5: Dysfunctional-family farce which, as a comedy, doesn't function at all.

title: The Iceman
review1: A low-rent movie with an expensive cast.
review2: Lack of originality and insipid screenwriting may soon be read as the autopsy of this actively tiresome genre.
review3: It's as though they were in a rush to get so much killing in that they forgot all of the important elements that would make us care. As a consequence, a fascinating story and character have been flattened and turned into a hurried mess.
review4: 'Big bad' with a side dish of bats--t crazy is the specialty of Michael Shannon, and so scarily good he is in mining this wheelhouse that one does not dare to complain about him repeating himself.
review5: An exploitation film trapped in the stifling body of a respectable crime drama.

title: Empire State
review1: Despite being based on a true story, Empire State is nothing but a bland and predictable tale that completely lacks originality.
review2: Montiel's worked through this type of tough guy material before, yet there's still no sign of creative growth. Maybe it's time for the filmmaker to move out of New York City and see what the rest of the country is up to.

title: Arthur Newman
review1: An offbeat, sometimes self-congratulatory road movie romance.
review2: They embark on one of those maundering, life-lessony odysseys that filmmakers love but audiences rarely do.
review3: One of those many indies that exist to give actors a chance to go slumming.
review4: Well-acted but ultimately unmemorable ...
review5: The film equivalent of a dysfunctional computer sloppily assembled from discarded parts of other machines.

title: Violeta Went to Heaven
review1: The formulaic storytelling has the unfortunate effect of making her extraordinary story feel familiar, though Wood's impressionistic style is a refreshing antidote to the portentousness one comes to expect from movies like this.
review2: With its clarity and depth, Gavilan's singing is as good as her acting.
review3: The biographical bits soon feel like a distraction from the music, performed by Gavilán. It's heard often, but not often enough.
review4: poignant portrait of an artist unable to escape the stamp of her class or the burdens of aging.
review5: Unlike most awards-grubbing biopics, this one feels no need to telegraph its own difficulty.

title: Sharknado
review1: It's bloody good fun.
review2: Oh sure, it's easy to pick holes in a story about a weather system that makes it possible for sharks to fly and take to the streets, but that's the whole point of movies like this: fabulous in-home commentary.
review3: Every so often, something comes along that puts a skip in your step, makes your heart flutter, and sets your imagination ablaze with possibility.... If you're really lucky... it'll be a swirling mass of bloodthirsty sharks.
review4: Sharknado is an hour and a half of your life that you'll never get back. And you won't want to.
review5: With few tricks up its sleeve, Sharknado only adds to the list of hysterical Syfy monster-dramas that make for a shamelessly brainless 90 minutes well-spent.

title: Extracted
review1: Sci-fi fans will definitely notice its various inspirations, and probably have some fun while doing it.

title: Three Worlds
review1: Each thread of the plot is followed to its dangling, ragged conclusion in a movie that may be painful to watch but that maintains a chilly integrity.
review2: Corsini sends her fine cast down a recognizable route, but wisely stands back, allowing them to navigate the twists and turns.
review3: Feels like an overdrawn soap opera about everyone's simultaneous fear of and longing for consequences.
review4: Worlds don't so much collide as politely bump into each other in [this] glossy, well-meaning but dramatically listless study of class relations in contemporary Paris.
review5: This stiflingly restrained French dirge about morality, guilt and atonement is chilly and constipated, mistaking ponderousness for intensity.

title: Electric Man
review1: If you're prepared to overlook its financial shortcomings, then you'll enjoy what is an entertaining and knowing little yarn.
review2: Here is a film with humour and energy and heart, made by people whose primary objective appears to have been to make a movie they themselves would like to see.
review3: Utterly dismal, can't-quite-believe-it's-really-this-bad Scottish comedy that's inept on every conceivable level.
review4: The film's main problem is that it's a good 25 minute short padded out to an hour and a half.
review5: It's difficult to imagine that this will be of much interest to anyone, apart from the people who made it.

title: Phil Spector
review1: Even with a Mamet screenplay and actors like Mr. Pacino and Ms. Mirren there is not much anyone can do to make the audience care.
review2: It's better than most films of its kind, even as it remains unsatisfying as historical re-creation, philosophical meditation or pure drama.
review3: Pacino and Mirren's teamwork keeps Phil Spector watchable even when it's dousing itself in dramatic ethanol and lighting a match.
review4: The film is an engrossing drama, with a dazzling performance by Al Pacino in the title role.
review5: It's an insidious whitewash of a convicted killer and an infamous smear of his victim. It's a shame on all involved.

title: After Lucia
review1: After Lucia builds to an almost unbearable level of tension, and although you may think you know how the story turns out, Franco has a different idea
review2: Credibility issues aside, the film has undeniable impact because the intensity and sobriety of Franco's focus make its ugliness inescapable.
review4: A failed script that comes to life with bad visual discourse. There's no story, no progression, no character development. [Full review in Spanish]
review5: 93 more riling minutes of cinema you will not find.

title: War Witch
review1: It may be hard for a viewer to accept some of the paranormal goings-on in War Witch -- the ghosts, the superstitions, the otherworldly powers -- but they're nothing compared to the realities that Komona has to endure.
review2: Atrocity and beauty somehow co-exist in War Witch.
review3: War Witch gives us a continent's tragedy in a young girl's face.
review4: Nguyen brings the harshness of this world alive not with big dramatic flourishes but with an everyday tone that makes it all the more frightening. This is how it is - how else would it be?
review5: Canadian writer-director Kim Nguyen spent nearly a decade researching this docudrama about child soldiers in Africa, and the film feels as authoritative as a first-hand account.

title: Wish You Were Here
review1: An Australian mystery-thriller dominated by Joel Edgerton's fearless performance as a compromised married man.
review2: Joel Edgerton gives one of the year's strongest performances.
review3: Wish You Were Here is an excellent idea for a State Department video, to remind travelers the obvious things not to do when visiting an unfamiliar country. As a drama, it feels a little empty.
review4: The mysteries unravel at a steady pace and the dialogue and acting feel naturalistic, adding up to a taut and progressively tangled portrait of familial relations.
review5: A dull drama about domestic squabbling that hopes to be mistaken for a thriller.

title: Love Is All You Need
review1: Result: sufficient pleasure.
review2: The middle-aged romance between the central characters is a lovely thing, and that makes up for everything.
review3: Bier is daring to deal with both familial dysfunction and mature romance without painting either in the standard broad strokes.
review4: We've seen enough romantic comedy to know these two are destined to fall for each other, but Bier is that rare filmmaker who can make you wonder if there will actually be a happy ending.
review5: Pierce Brosnan isn't the only reason to see Love is All You Need. He's merely the best reason to seek out Danish filmmaker Susanne Bier's entertaining if familiar romantic comedy.

title: Our Wild Hearts
review1: In this summer of big blockbuster films with robots, monsters and men of steel you may need a break from all of the loud noises and bright lights. May I suggest "Our Wild Hearts," a quiet family film with a message.

title: This Is Martin Bonner
review1: This Is Martin Bonner takes a magnifying glass to everyday goodness and lingering pain, illuminating their contours and complexities but pulling away before the movie can ever burst into sentimental flame.
review2: This contemplative drama draws strength from day-to-day ordinariness and a terrific lead performance from Paul Eenhoorn, yet sadly falls short.
review3: Mr. Eenhoorn (whose patient expressions here suggest a kindly priest) gives his character the shy charm of palpable decency.
review4: Patience is privileged, nothing is forced, and by the end of this quietly devastating character study, the ordinary has become extraordinary.
review5: By calling on his leads to underplay nearly every moment, Hartigan calls into question our deeply ingrained instinct, as moviegoers, to witness a steady parade of amped-up emotions.

title: New World Order: The End Has Come
In the Fog
review1: As remorseless in style as it is in message, "In the Fog" offers little hope and few pleasures, but earns admiration for its elegant exploration of the lowest depths of the human condition.
review2: Intimate in the telling, sweeping in the implications, Loznitsa has created an unusually incisive film.
review3: In the Fog, which seems to me a masterpiece, is about occupation and the destruction of an understanding of one's own history.
review4: Even when the pace wanes, the images are still gripping.
review5: The world and its choices are often cruel, but for all the devastations visited on the characters, Mr. Loznitsa is searching for the human good amid a human catastrophe.

title: The We and the I
review1: Credit Gondry, like Tocqueville before him, with at least re-examining tired clichés and scraping the rust off stereotypes.
review2: An occasionally interesting glimpse into the lives of a diverse group of urban teens and their struggles, but also a film that's overly long and often annoying.
review3: All of the kids are good in their roles, mostly as characters one assumes resemble themselves. And as any actor will tell you, playing yourself is one of the toughest gigs around.
review4: Gondry has talent, and I think he enjoyed being with these youngsters, but the film suffers in trying to impose something vaguely like a story on a framework that boils down to teen high jinks during a bus ride.
review5: "The We and the I" is a collection of very thin stories, many of which feel incomplete.

title: Shanghai Calling
review1: Daniel Henney is personable as Sam, and Eliza Coupe is even more so as Amanda. Daniel Hsia wrote and directed with agility, and he makes sure that his story doesn't get in the way of his presentation of the city.
review2: [A] modest charmer.
review3: Though Mr. Hsia, a television alumnus who also wrote the script, has created a somewhat predictable story infused with stereotypes old and new, he gains mileage from light humor, buoyant energy and some appealing performers.
review4: Shanghai Calling doesn't aspire to fresh insight, let alone profundity. But it's nice to see the American migration narrative get out of the house for some fresh air.
review5: A clear affection for its subject and setting help deepen Daniel Hsia's otherwise shallow romantic comedy.

title: Drift
review1: This poor-surfers-make-good drama from Morgan O'Neill and Ben Nott relies more than it should on toned thighs and taut gluteals. Be grateful; there's nothing to see on dry land that's anywhere near as compelling.
review2: I'm a sucker for films with great surfing footage, let alone wacky '70s hairstyles. But this overlong, cliché-infested Aussie period drama tested my patience.
review3: Has genial moments, but they're lost in a sea of boilerplate incidents and prefab characters. Surfing sequences are easily as striking as what we see in documentaries about the sport.
review4: The leads are engaging, and Pollard in particular projects an easygoing, friendly machismo. Where the movie routinely disappoints, though, is in pursuit of a perfect storm of conflict story lines ...
review5: Writer and co-director Morgan O'Neill based Drift on true surfer stories from the era; however, the movie mostly comes across as a grab bag of tired tropes.

title: Greetings From Tim Buckley
review1: Penn Badgley delivers a pivotal performance as the younger Buckley, coming off with just enough pretentiousness and attitude.
review2: Algrant's desire to reunite father and son through music is admirable, but "Greetings from Tim Buckley" is too meandering and ethereal to have any lasting impact.
review3: Badgley does a credible take on the signature falsetto that Jeff would later bring to his only album, Grace ...
review4: The concert may have seen the reluctant birth of a second-generation rock star, but this movie, if nothing else, is a similarly suitable showcase for its own leading man.
review5: In paying homage to two iconic performers, he's given a former small-screen star the chance to announce his own cinematic arrival.

title: And Now A Word From Our Sponsor
review1: A mild, toothless satire - a "Being There'' where there's barely any there there.
review2: With the nimble Greenwood and a kinder, gentler-than-usual Posey in charge, "And Now" proves a thoroughly engaging lark.
review3: To describe "And Now a Word From Our Sponsor" as a one-joke skit stretched well beyond the breaking point isn't entirely fair, because when used ingeniously, which is very seldom, the joke lands.
review4: Plop plop. Fizz fizz. Oh, what a missed opportunity it is!
review5: Always-good Greenwood ambles through on charm and bemusement, but the film is still an idea in search of meaning.

title: Augustine
review1: By the film's end, it's clear what Augustine is running from, but it's hard to grasp where she was in the first place.
review2: That the film raises interesting questions might be good enough, except that, while the movie goes about denying us information we want, it gives us details we don't need. "Augustine" churns slowly and doesn't make for compelling viewing.
review3: French physician Jean-Martin Charcot hypnotized, photographed and exhibited a hysteric, as does French director Alice Winocour for a clinical love story and empowerment tale.
review4: Ultimately, while this character-based drama proves consistently engrossing, it leaves various pertinent and fascinating issues frustratingly unexplored.
review5: The psychosexual drama plays out beneath the surface -- the movie is so understated it sometimes feels inert.

title: Disconnect
review1: Disconnect turns out to have a complicated view of life in the digital age. Rising to scenes of real intimacy and insight, the movie is stimulating, and, at times, touching.
review2: Handsomely shot and judiciously edited, the film benefits from a superlative cast ...
review3: It's left to the actors to make up for the gaffes, and they're definitely up to the task.
review4: Reefer Madness with smartphones.
review5: Disconnect succeeds most when it's pulling at the heartstrings.

title: Gimme The Loot
review1: Amid all the copycatting and pricey bombast and genericness, here's a movie that looks like it hails from a real place; whose characters sound like they come from somewhere; whose stakes are stresslessly low.
review2: 'Gimme the Loot' is ... meandering and a little shallow. And even at 79 minutes it feels a little too long for what's essentially the film equivalent of a short story.
review3: A film brimming with so much life and mischief that it left me in an almost insufferably good mood for days afterwards. I didn't want it to end.
review4: Watching this film reminded me a bit of 'Friends,' the funny TV show where nothing ever happens. Here, there is a lot of activity, but nothing much is accomplished, except for the creation of a funny, entertaining movie.
review5: What gets this slight episodic film to first base is the likability shown by the non-professional leads.

title: The Bling Ring
review1: It's smart and droll.
review2: The sense of detachment that is a signature of Sofia Coppola's work -- the coolly distant, stylishly dreamlike way she regards her characters -- works to her detriment in The Bling Ring.
review3: ...Coppola definitely finds a captivating way of telling the tale. Her script and the performances give us something thought-provoking out of something superficial.
review4: Antonioni watches too much TMZ in Sofia Coppola's detached portrait of hollowed-out youth culture.
review5: Five children-four princesses and a prince-run in gentle Angeleno night from enchanted castle to enchanted castle, gathering treasure-beads and raiment and gold and currency-spending themselves afterward on endorphins and coke.

title: Simon Killer
review1: Simon Killer is a sensory, experiential film - more of a state of mind than a straightforward story.
review2: Self-consciousness passing for style.
review3: "Simon Killer" is a beautifully made look at ugliness and brutality, the kind of oxymoronic exercise that fascinates some and repels others.
review4: Another terrific performance from Brady Corbet, but it's in the service of a parade of horrors that never leads anywhere interesting.
review5: It is brutally raw and difficult watching.

title: "Bless Me, Ultima"
review1: Aassured, sensitive, and commendably unpretentious.
review2: The lyrical book is filled with touches of magical realism. On the other hand, the movie is sorely lacking in both magic and realism. It's all very empty and blah.
review3: An offbeat slice of Americana will intrigue thoughtful moviegoers.
review4: Theater firebrand and big-screen presence Miriam Colon portrays Ultima with a minimum of fuss and a gorgeous supply of elder authority.
review5: Writer-director Carl Franklin offers up a tone of heightened reverence that weighs down the material, but there are small, lovely moments when the magic realism approaches the magical.

title: Showgirls 2: Penny's from Heaven
review1: A grand artistic statement with bargain-basement production values and a remarkable lack of talent onscreen.
review2: The film itself is a daunting and swirling phantasmagoria of storylines, weird back-and-forths, and just as much bizarro character vacillation as its predecessor.

title: Lean Like a Cholo (Perfect Sunday) (American Lowrider)
Paranormal Asylum: The Revenge of Typhoid Mary
Java Heat
review1: The film's anthropological interest in Indonesia is the smartest thing in an otherwise familiar scramble of kidnapped babes, expensive jewelry and millions of bullets.
review2: The potential fun is all thoroughly undone, however, by an eye-roller of a script and a leaden lead performance from Twilight heartthrob Kellan Lutz.
review3: Lutz ... doesn't have half the charisma required to hold together this jumble of cheesy shootouts and chases, but at least Rourke provides some unintended laughs with his comical attempts to be evil.
review4: A better title for "Java Heat" might have been "Java Noise," since that is mostly what this uninvolving action film produces.
review5: This otherwise generic '80s-style actioner benefits from the presence of the ever-colorful Mickey Rourke as an exotic villian.

title: The East
review1: Marling and Batmanglij don't fear or resent entertainment: They make effective thrillers... If they reach a major studio and bigger budget, they could be the right kind of dangerous.
review2: The whole thing feels strident and naive, a well-meaning drama composed by a couple of college kids for their Environmental Science final.
review3: The total effect is affected, annoying and off-putting.
review4: Provocative and exciting, with bigger set pieces and a fierce devotion to character development, this is the sort of smart genre thriller that Hollywood needs more of.
review5: Marling's committed performance is offset slightly by Skarsgård's glumness and the 'surprise' casting of Page, who plays the part like Juno grown up (sort of) and turned vengeful communist psychopath.

title: Behind the Candelabra
review1: As deeply entertaining and creative as it is socially enlightening.
review2: Douglas seems to be having fun playing such a flaming swishy character and hams it up.
review3: Douglas made his name playing powerful, morally questionable men, and this is a clever addition to the canon.
review4: Michael Douglas transforms himself into the Las Vegas entertainer with style and, most of all, believability. Liberace was larger-than-life to say the least, and it would be easy to go the SNL route with a character by painting him with broad strokes.
review5: Soderbergh and LaGravenese go deep beneath this voyeuristic fascination with wealth, fame, and the secret lives of celebrities.

title: Deux hommes dans Manhattan (Two Men in Manhattan)
review1: It might be Melville's weakest film.
review2: Melville's script churns along with the dutiful pace of a procedural...but he mostly seems interested in leading the audience through different places rather than supplying it with twists and turns for their own sake.

title: Call Me Kuchu
review1: The film is impassioned and powerful but not frenzied, riling the viewers' emotions without giving in to them itself.
review2: Stirring, heartbreaking and thoroughly infuriating ...
review3: Both Senyonjo and Kato light up the screen.
review4: This alternately harrowing and inspirational doc puts a human face on the fight for gay rights in Uganda.
review5: Horrific and uplifting ...

title: 1/2 Revolution
review1: Well-lensed hi-def scenes of police and soldiers attacking demonstrators and deploying assault weapons, as well as frequent, pitched street battles, are queasily riveting.

title: Something in the Air
review1: Something in the Air is a splendid title for a one-of-a-kind film -- a political mood movie that's more revelatory and exciting than almost any political melodrama.
review2: A wispy picture, likeable certainly but lacking in crispness and clarity.
review3: Assayas captures a season in the lives of a group that envisioned themselves as bearers of truth ...
review4: Free of nostalgia and not overly critical in hindsight, it captures the immediacy of youth in hugely endearing fashion.
review5: A film about fading out, about how youthful passions dissolve over time.

title: Aleksandr's Price
review1: A frank, blunt and realistic look at the dark side of life in New York City - for many young men and women.

title: Ephraim's Rescue
review1: Issues with the script and a methodical pace yield what feels like a missed opportunity. Earnestness in filmmaking does not necessarily equal excellence in filmmaking.

title: Cody the Robosapien
review1: Despite the tissue-thin plot, slipshod performances and predictable single-mum family dynamics 'Robosapien' is surprisingly easy to endure - a freewheeling kids' film. Nothing more, nothing less.
review2: The film's cloak-and dagger plot barely passes muster, but Cody's antics - which include break dancing, tantrum throwing and blowing raspberries - will probably appeal to those young viewers whose behaviour they mimic.
review3: There may be shades of E.T. To this, but it just hasn't got that depth or emotional edge that makes kids films so poignantly well-rounded at times.
review4: Inspired by the titular toy, Robosapien combines CGI and live action with fairly banal results.

title: Scenic Route
review1: It's actually a well-made, well-acted low-budget thriller that is more resonant than expected.
review2: At the very least shows you how to make a smart, cheap little movie with only two actors, one main exterior set and no special effects.
review3: Kyle Killen's script is generally uninspired and fairly predictable ...
review4: It begins with energy, dulls in the middle stretches but redeems itself with a final destination that makes the trip feel worth it.
review5: Fogler impresses with some brooding edge, but neither he nor the location photography is enough to recommend you join him on this doomed trip.

title: My Brother The Devil
review1: It's an impressive debut by a director blessed with a strong voice and a knack for bringing a specific cultural milieu to vibrant life, defying convention even while working within its strict limits.
review2: My Brother the Devil brings a fresh and mature perspective to a story of shifting relationships between siblings, clearly marking the Egyptian-Welsh writer-director as someone on a path to greater things.
review3: A story of brothers that's both tough and tender.
review4: "My Brother the Devil" is a promising debut that marks El Hosaini as a filmmaker to watch, but one still very much in the developmental stages.
review5: For at least part of its length, "My Brother the Devil" brings refreshing changes to a genre badly in need of them.

title: Fill the Void
review1: This is an extraordinary first film, nerve-tingling in its intensity, and assembled with a finesse and control even the great Austrian director Michael Haneke might envy.
review2: Beautiful and mysterious, the[se] first glimpses are an ideal primer for the Israeli film, which never rushes to spell out the meanings of its subtle and quiet moments.
review3: Emotional issues an an insular world
review4: A man and a woman, alone, on a path at night, forbidden to touch, speak, confront, describe passion: the man moves closer. That's all. The smallest of moves, infinitesimal motion. The world tilts on its axis.
review5: ...an entertaining yet uneven debut from a promising new filmmaker...

title: The Power of Love
review1: Between the poor acting, the terrible dialogue and the lack of a compelling story, it's pretty hard to believe in The Power Of Love.

title: Unfinished Song
review1: The crescendo of two resonant careers makes the false notes of "Unfinished Song" forgivable.
review2: Shamelessly sentimental, cute to a fault, but the acting is first-rate.
review3: The gentle story of a marriage, and of how music can help make a broken heart whole again.
review4: Unfinished Song is full of predictably poignant moments; you'd be lucky to survive the film dry-eyed.
review5: [A] modest, tear-jerking charmer ... Just don't expect too much more than what shows on its paint-by-numbers surface.

title: Stick
review4: The unfairly maligned Stick is actually a very good underworld thriller with Burt Reynolds at his absolute coolest.
review5: A pretty awful Elmore Leonard adaptation.

title: Laurence Anyways
review1: "Laurence Anyways" is a formidable display of French Canadian director Xavier Dolan's prodigious talents, but also a case study of a young talent still finding his way to greatness.He'll get there one day, soon, but this film doesn't quite do it.
review2: Lushly romantic and daringly original.
review3: It's all too much, really, including its 21/2-hour-plus running time. But it's also engrossing, an ultimately tender story of a transsexual's transformation over 10 years and its effect on him and the people around him.
review4: At nearly three hours, it's by turns an extraordinary and exhausting work.
review5: Poupaud's quiet moments convey a lofty, poignant introspection, and Clément erupts with grand, if scattershot, furies.

title: This Is the End
review1: There's wonder here that films with quadruple the effects budget would kill for.
review2: "This Is the End" does not crack jokes at the expense of Christianity. It does, however, consider both kicking a severed head around like a football and the prospect of raping Emma Watson to be hilarious.
review3: This movie is flat out crazy.
review4: The movie's very self-amusement makes it go down easy.
review5: Probably the most self-indulgent wank in movie history, yet on occasion it's hilarious.

title: The Frozen Ground
review1: A taut procedural with atmospheric location work that traces Cage's clock-racing efforts to find evidence against Cusack ...
review2: The movie's only fresh element is the wintry setting, which shrouds everything in a mood of weary fatalism. Otherwise, it's the same old, same old, efficiently discharged and utterly disposable.
review3: The movie's late-night cable feel and skeevy salaciousness grinds everything to a snowy slush.
review4: Although writer-director Scott Walker seems committed to not overly exploiting his lurid subject matter, the movie is just too dreary, disjointed and generically creepy to be persuasive.
review5: A vague and forgettable crime thriller that would have benefited from more character development or at least a grounding of the narrative in one central protagonist.

title: Fright Night 2 (Unrated)
review1: A quick, cheap, churn-it-out product that offers nothing you haven't seen before.
review2: Fright Night 2: New Blood is a remake unfairly masking itself as some sort of sequel, slowly revealing itself to simply be an inferior, unnecessary production compared to 2011's surprisingly satisfying effort.
review3: expends too much effort following the story laid out by Tom Holland in 1985

title: Morning
review1: An initially intriguing but ultimately exhausting tale of grieving parents left quite literally dazed and confused in the wake of their young son's death.
review2: Orser, to his credit, never resorts to psychobabble, cheap sentiment or emotional shortcuts.
review3: It often seems like an acting workshop: Behave as if you are the parent of a dead child.
review4: Leland Orser makes a raw, soul-searching feature debut as writer, director and star in "Morning." He plays the devastated father opposite his real-life wife, Jeanne Tripplehorn.
review5: One of the more harrowing explorations of grief ever brought to the screen. By the end of its 95 minutes, only a faint ray of light has penetrated the gloom.

title: "Turtle Hill, Brooklyn"
review1: "Turtle Hill" is inconclusive from start to finish, and while that appears purposeful, it's also pretty dull.
review2: A spirit of free play defines the proceedings, as the script, penned by the two leads, allows characters to reveal themselves through believably precise bits of booze- and weed-fueled conversation.
review3: ...its general tone of hipsterish pleasantness is a welcome sign of how much gay life has changed in 45 years.
review4: The dreariest party ever filmed. Don't bother to RSVP.

title: The Big Parade
review4: Masterpiece of Vidorian ardor
review5: It was strong stuff in 1925 and it remains strong today.

title: Aliyah
review1: It's the kind of serious, thoughtful, yet accessible portrait we see all too little of these days.
review2: Far from being the Promised Land, Israel represents a shaky new beginning in a country Alex barely knows. This smart, sober movie makes you feel the full weight of the challenges he faces.
review3: Wajeman introduces some unexpected elements, which he handles with surprising dexterity considering this is his feature debut.
review4: A marvelous film, stripped of false urgency.
review5: A character piece should have some sense of a character's who, what and why, right?

title: The Look of Love
review1: Frankly, the guy just isn't very interesting.
review2: Groovy period soundtrack aside, "The Look of Love" has almost nothing to say of any interest, importance or humor.
review3: Double-billing comic and tragic tones, the biopic "The Look of Love" follows a father and a daughter over three decades in London's swinging Soho.
review4: Director Michael Winterbottom and screenwriter Matt Greenhalgh provide the essential outline of Raymond's story, but they're a little too preoccupied with its glitzy aspects.
review5: A puzzlingly misconceived biopic: a tasteful, subdued movie about a man who was as tasteless and unsubdued as they come.

title: Static
review1: Truthfully only salvageable because of its final act.
review2: Any appreciation of the film will come after it's over and you might say, "oh, that's why that happened." I'm not sure the ending is worth the time invested.
review3: [Blu-ray Review] One of those movies where none of the pieces quite fit when the viewer thinks back on them, "Static" takes a crafty idea, but debuting director-cowriter Todd Levin doesn't always play fair with the audience.

title: Home Run
review1: The strongest scenes take place in dingy hotel rooms, on a deserted farm or in the rehab sessions. It's during these moments that "Home Run" swings for the fences, and often connects.
review2: It's preaching the gospel of a 12-step recovery program with a heavy helping of Jesus for guidance. And the corn can get pretty high ...
review3: Almost from the beginning the message overwhelms the medium.
review4: As Christian-themed movies go, this one may not be an over-the-fence hit, but decent enough acting almost compensates for a clichéd plot that's intended as a too-obvious illustration/inspiration.
review5: This slightly better-than-average family film is all paint-by-numbers.

title: Approaching Midnight
review1: Short, slow and amateurish home-from-the-war mystery thriller

title: Stuck in Love
review1: Perfectly adequate airplane reading.
review2: The story, while unsurprising, is also quietly satisfying. Everyone comes to accept some hard truths about themselves.
review3: Cliched literary trappings come together in "Stuck in Love," but the final product feels more like a footnote than a finished work.
review4: Although "Stuck in Love" is an indie film, it hews slavishly to Hollywood formulas right down to its comfy Thanksgiving Day ending. It's all so easy, isn't it?
review5: Just like most romantic comedies (though this is more of a "rom-dram"), Stuck In Love. believes nothing is worthier than refusing to give up after you've been rebuffed in no uncertain terms.

title: The Lifeguard
review1: Although writer-director Liz W. Garcia's wistful, angsty tale treads familiar ground, the filmmaker has crafted a credibly flawed and conflicted heroine who holds interest.
review2: The central character simply comes across as whiny and entitled instead of troubled and dark, and the central theme of getting your groove back by acting like a kid again has been done many times by much more talented filmmakers.
review3: The movie really depends on Bell, and her story, and neither is interesting or compelling enough to engage us.
review4: This directorial debut by Liz W. Garcia, a writer for television, bears some echoes of its creator's origins, going from deft to trite in its drama and setting up character arcs that feel sappily resolved within its feature length.
review5: The movie's being billed in some quarters as a comedy, which is a hell of a stretch given that the plot expands to take in statutory rape and teen suicide.

title: Resolution
review1: A strangely tense and humorous meta-narrative about two friends experiencing weird goings-on at a remote cabin.
review2: A smart and chilling indie horror from co-directors Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead ...
review3: Resolution makes its own creative crisis the star, trying to make something original out of elements so hackneyed, the filmmakers can't bear to reproduce them.
review4: Ambiguity enlivens the smart, knotty Resolution, which routinely nods to its own artificiality while positing storytelling as a constantly evolving beast apt to save your life one moment and consume you the next.
review5: "Resolution" is a notch above your average low-budget horror flick. It has the usual gore and scares and head-scratching events. But, the story is what locked me in.

title: The Man in the Iron Mask
Revelation Road 2: The Sea of Glass and Fire
To Jennifer
review1: A scrappy, strange, and inconsistent little "gimmick" flick, but it's also a testament to what a small group of filmmakers can pull off with very little money

title: Embrace of the Vampire
review1: The film is caught in a spin-dry cycle where there's a ton of conflict (nightmares, school pressure, peer pressure) but no mounting action.
review2: In spite of this clear connection with its namesake predecessor, Embrace of the Vampire actually more closely resembles a different film: 2010's ballet thriller Black Swan.
review3: Sexy? Yes. As sexy as it thinks itself to be? Sadly, no.
review4: Just look at the cast and walk quickly past the rental shelf...quickly...

title: Plush
review1: It feels so inauthentic at every turn, it's as if the film itself is unsure of what it's supposed to be.
review2: Plush is all over the map, but when its characters prattle on about how important their art is amidst all that terrible pose-heavy music, its really insufferable.
review3: Plush feels too familiar to leave any sort of impression. It throws together a cast that is mostly full of actors from similar genres, but even then Plush seems like a rehash of everything each actor did previously.
review4: Plush is a twisted tale of obsession, and the great performances from the entire cast make for a delightfully dark movie.
review5: Plush is just a B-movie B-side that few will take note of, a modern riff on Fatal Attraction that shoots for edgy, and lands on silly.

title: Ingenious
review1: A terrific little yarn about pluck, perseverance and friendship overcoming the odds, Lightbulb is exactly what's needed in these troubled times.
review2: Cute enough.

title: Die Wand (The Wall)
review1: Bleak and beautiful, harrowing yet inspiring, "The Wall" ("Die Wand") is a stunning tale of isolation and survival in a wild and silent world.
review2: An elegant, slow-burning exercise in narrative minimalism.
review3: Pölsler's film is quietly deliberate without ever feeling slow, thanks to a few handy assets at his disposal.
review4: It's a shudder-inducing original.
review5: This mesmerising, austere and contemplative film provides a rarefied yet utterly immersive viewing experience.

title: Paradise: Faith
review1: Much like his fellow Austrian filmmaker Michael Haneke, Seidl knows how to keep his audience captivated while rattling us with a discomfiting precision.
review2: Scenes are dramatic without a hint of melodrama, so when a flash of intensity does occur, it does so out of nowhere and registers even more powerfully.
review3: Now, here's the trilogy's second installment, in which the jolly Austrian makes it clear that women of a certain age do not have his permission to overdo it with religion, either.
review4: Like it or not, "Paradise: Faith" sticks in your head.
review5: A brutal, unflinching, anxiety-inducing, almost unbearably hard to watch film.

title: Homecoming
review1: Thoughtful reunion-themed film has mature themes, drug use.

title: Who Needs Enemies
review1: The film is too smitten with its loathsome small-time crooks to generate much interest in the plight of the victims or portray any women as anything but hapless bystanders.
review2: Another week, another set of mouthy geezers in suits mugging one another off.
review3: First-time writer and director Peter Stylianou demonstrates future potential with Who Needs Enemies, but his debut feature fails to entice thanks to weak dialogue and stereotypical characters.
review4: Solidly played but the pieces audibly clunk into place.
review5: It's a promising feature debut for Stylianou; let's hope he explores fresher territory next time.

title: Almost Perfect
review1: A distinct lack of directorial oomph prevents "Almost Perfect" from feeling anything but regrettably middlebrow.
review2: Hackneyed and forgettable though it may be, Almost Perfect is also pretty watchable until its breezy first half gives way to ill-advised melodrama.
review3: 'Almost Perfect' is a slight romantic comedy that refreshingly views people of color and a mixed marriage without that being its central focus.

title: As Cool As I Am
review1: This coming-of-age drama might trade in familiar narrative developments, but its characterization is rather nuanced.
review2: Simplistic plotting, pedestrian visuals and poorly-handled melodrama do lend the project a cheap, made-for-TV feel, which is underscored by the fact that Danes and Marsden don't seem obliged to turn in their best work.
review3: Oh no: Claire Danes as the mom? Already? What's next, Chelsea Clinton for president?
review4: It is as if chunks of the film had landed on the editing-room floor in a desperate, last-minute attempt to trim its length. Just when its parts should come together, "As Cool as I Am" crumbles to bits.
review5: Mayer doesn't find a way to make the ritual traumas of adolescence feel new again.

title: The Internship
review1: You don't need a heart to like this movie. You need an MBA.
review2: Similar to Eddie Murphy's hard right turn from daring and profane comedy to family-friendly romps, Vaughn and Wilson have gone all soft and gooey here.
review3: "The Internship" is less a pageant of Google's products and services than an agitprop of the company's corporate philosophy and culture.
review4: It isn't really a movie about friendship or new beginnings - it's a movie about selling Google.
review5: 'The Internship' isn't as funny or exuberant as 'Wedding Crashers' and the plot is formulaic, but as lightweight entertainment goes it's . . . well, light and entertaining.

title: Hello Herman
review1: More redundant than offensive.
review2: At least it doesn't lack in big moments where people cry and scream.
review3: It barely tries to offer insight into its much-debated subject, content to rip the scab off an ever-fresh wound for the sake of controversy.
review4: The dialogue is all surface: Emotions are laid out on the autopsy table for the audience to dissect and analyze, but rarely feel.
review5: Hello Herman suffers not so much from its boldly stated anti-bullying agenda but from its failure to come to any conclusions.

title: Only God Forgives
review1: Only God Forgives is an extremely misunderstood film.
review2: Even as their shadows fall across these walls, the characters are not supermen; they're humans reduced to chiaroscuro. Characterization is even more minimal.
review3: It's a fragmented affair, relying on its visuals, sound design, and mythological villain to carry the day. It kept me riveted, though by the end I did feel the overall experience was a bit empty.
review4: Ryan Gosling reunites with Drive director Nicolas Winding Refn for the ultra-violent, ultra-slow-moving Bangkok-set revenge thriller Only God Forgives, whose unflinching gore and crawling pace will probably prove equally off-putting to most viewers.
review5: Not only a disaster area but will also have you questioning your affection for Refn's last film in the first place.

title: OKA!
review1: It's a pleasant, if slow-moving, trip down a lazy river.
review2: The plot is somewhat pedestrian and the dialogue needs more zip.
review3: Oka! is a fascinating movie with many free-form charms.
review4: Yearning for an exciting African adventure? "Oka!" isn't it.
review5: What's refreshing about Oka! is its aversion to any kind of cliches.

title: Storm Rider
review1: Horse drama deals with heavy themes of family separation.

title: The Way Way Back
review1: The film has been complacently concocted for likability even as it gives you very little that's real, structured, or spontaneous enough to enjoy.
review2: Nice comedic work from Sam Rockwell and Allison Janney buoys this pleasant but routine coming-of-age drama by Nat Faxon and Jim Rash.
review3: This film's masterstroke is showing everything from Duncan's point of view, without the traditional cloying narration.
review4: An astoundingly sweet, lovable, immensely enjoyable little film that hits all the right notes as you're watching it thanks to its excellent cast.
review5: The story has some of the lighthearted fun a boy should have working for a fun-loving boss and enjoying the company of a hot girlfriend, but he should be having a lot more fun than this.

title: Before Midnight
review1: This is a universal X-ray of bourgeois love, one that in a few decades will get around to something like Amour.
review2: The Greek ruins, once the perfect backdrop for ancient tragedies, now complement the Bergman-esque domestic discord and disillusionment that are about to unfurl.
review3: Everything about Before Midnight rings wonderfully and achingly true.
review4: Hawke and Delpy, who co-wrote the screenplay with Linklater, make this oscillation between badinage and feistiness, cosiness and irritability, look effortless.
review5: The chemistry is so good it is pratically tactile and their conversations, in the natural way of long-term couples, are free-ranging and show how at times of high emotion, arguments and resentment can resurface suddenly to powerful effect.

title: Just Like A Woman
review1: Like belly-dancing itself, this drama is meant for the soul, not the mind - or as Marilyn's instructor commands, "Brains! Stop using them!"
review2: The problem with the film, directed by France's Rachid Bouchareb from a script by Joelle Touma and Marion Doussot, is that the men are mostly one-dimensional louts.
review3: This well-intentioned buddy-road-trip flick lacks the danger, the drama and the sex appeal that most moviegoers will be looking for.
review4: Just like its meaningless title, Rachid Bouchareb's disappointing drama evokes better works without developing any distinct identity of its own.
review5: Bouchareb fails to turn his outsider's point of view into new insights, and instead takes the easy route, falling back on familiar stereotypes in his tour of US misogyny and xenophobia.

title: Margarita
review1: The cast works valiantly and the cinematography is crisp, but trite characterizations and an earnest-cutesy tone make this movie feel like too much domestic labour.
review2: Suffers from predictability and unrealistic episodes of household idiocy ...
review3: As a look at what's going on in the gentrified core of Canada's biggest city, it's as hard to buy as one of those renovated houses, just steps from the subway and a bike ride to the food market.

title: Tabu
review1: It takes a while to get to the meat of the movie, but it's well worth the wait.
review2: It almost seems a parody of willfully obscure art-house fare. Yet it has an undertow that sucks you in as often as it strands you back on shore.
review3: A kind of jigsaw puzzle, spiced up with references to "White Mischief," "Out of Africa" and "The Snows of Kilimanjaro," that will frustrate some audiences and fascinate others.
review4: The audience is left to imagine much of the story, though it is clear it involves love, betrayal, guilt, regret and a recurring crocodile.
review5: Portuguese director Miguel Gomes' latest film moves through different styles and eras, and proves that shooting in black and white is as versatile as it ever was.

title: Free Samples
review1: A modest but pleasant small-budget movie with two bits of laziness in the script, but one particularly sweet performance that makes up for them.
review2: Weixler is a delight, and director Tom Gammill captures the right level of deadpan to pull this off.
review3: "Free Samples" is a film about wasting time, and it feels like it.
review4: A modest pleasure that greatly benefits from Weixler's charismatic presence.
review5: An angry indie that favors hollow ridicule over credibility.

title: Byzantium
review1: Jordan is no stranger to the yearnings of vampires. He directed Interview With the Vampire. But Byzantium is a kinder, gentler yet pretty durn bloody affair.
review2: Go ahead, bite.
review3: A drama that feels both strenuously earnest and impossible to take seriously.
review4: Byzantium has a few moves that might surprise you. They have nothing to do with blood, but everything to do with the heart.
review5: A confusing yet eye-pleasing tale that struggles to breathe new life into the well-worn mythology.

title: Bounty Killer
review1: Turning its low budget into a self-mocking plus, this umpteenth 'Mad Max'-style dystopian actioner delivers trashy fun for genre fans.
review2: It's all utterly silly and derivative but also undeniably entertaining.
review3: Watching this movie feels like viewing a very long, expensive car commercial and waiting for the real film to begin.
review4: Intentionally cheap, silly and bloody from beginning to end, "Bounty Killer" is custom-made for those seeking out self-aware garbage. To those: enjoy! To all others: beware.
review5: It isn't the worst thing to blow an hour and a half on a film where everyone - including supporting players Gary Busey, Beverly D'Angelo and Kristanna Loken - seems to be having a good time.

title: Out in the Dark
review1: It's one of the most powerful films about the Arab-Israeli conflict that has ever been attempted on the screen.
review2: "Out in the Dark" isn't a political film by any stretch, but the intrigue and prejudices of the Arab-Israeli conflict certainly fuel the romance and thrills of this entertaining, taut movie.
review3: By the end, Nimr and Roy have become heavy-handed symbols for the ongoing clash of ideologies in the Middle East. "Out in the Dark" fared better when it treated them as people.
review4: Even though the plot defies credibility at several points, "Out in the Dark" is gripping, and Nimr's tearful exile from his family breaks your heart.
review5: Tel Aviv and the West Bank may be worlds apart in terms of culture, politics and religion, but Mayer cleverly merges them into a single claustrophobic continuum of paranoia, violence and corruption that corrodes everything it touches.

title: All American Christmas Carol
review1: Redemption story has underage drinking, heavy innuendo.

title: Lovelace
review1: Seyfried, with her huge features crowding her small face, looks like Alice in a very strange Wonderland. But whatever possibilities she may have as an actress are eradicated by the filmmakers ...
review2: Ironically, even a movie about Linda Lovelace's rather sad life uses her more for her body than her character.
review3: Amanda Seyfried is a game performer, and the Linda-like freckles sprayed across her cheeks, which all and sundry in the film comment on, are fetching.
review4: Amanda Seyfried acts out of her skin.
review5: I understand that movies based on true stories take plenty of liberties, but if those liberties can be blown apart with a five-minute visit to Wikipedia, they went too far.

title: Renoir
review1: With its warm colors and sweet streams of light, its love of both the countryside and the human form, it makes you dream of painting. Or making movies. Or just luxuriating in the brilliance.
review2: Thanks to ace Taiwanese cameraman Mark Ping Bing Lee, it conveys the inspirational qualities of sun-dappled light and rosy flesh.
review3: a bittersweet delight
review4: Beautiful-looking but largely boring...There have been some terrific films about artists, but this isn't one of them.
review5: Michel Bouquet's wonderful characterisation of Auguste Renoir remains the shining achievement of this delicate, reverential and sometimes gobsmackingly beautiful film

title: Broken
review1: The comic and tragic elements are nicely balanced, and the three families' stories neatly and economically knit together.
review2: Although there are some light moments and traces of dark humor, Broken's overall aura is one of dread.
review3: [It] drives its plot via an interesting and unusual character: the female victim who's actually a wholesale liar.
review4: "Broken'' embraces the sort of unappealing British miserabilism perfected by "Ratcatcher" director Lynne Ramsay.
review5: At a certain point, Mr. Norris forsakes realism for theatricalized fantasy, and "Broken" ultimately loses its stylistic cohesion, if not its humanity.

title: White House Down
review1: While none of the tentpoles this summer are doozies, this one is at least something worth cheering about.
review2: The best Die Hard movie since Speed.
review3: Instant blockbuster camp.
review4: This isn't a Guilty Pleasure, just a pleasure.
review5: While fun in a harmless, artificial sort of way -- like Pop Rocks or costume jewelry -- White House Down is little more than Die Hard at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.

title: Passion
review1: What we have here is a tale of lust, deception, manipulation and murder. Quintessential De Palma, in other words.
review2: One's ultimate reaction is likely to one of indifference, bemusement or outright disdain considering the pedigree of the filmmaker helming the project: Brian De Palma.
review3: A throwaway by a gifted filmmaker who has run out of ideas.
review4: Despite De Palma's lavish proof of what he can accomplish with classical technique, the movie comes off as too much for too little, a collection of mechanisms that decorate mechanisms.
review5: After the clinically dull first half, it's more desperate pantry raid than feast.

title: A Christmas Wedding
review1: Heavy dialog, mature themes in family conflict drama.

title: Parkland
review1: A ( ... ) pragmatic, four-day, fly-on-the-wall view of Dallas when the 20th Century's most documented death arguably facilitated the birth of 24-hour rolling news, citizen journalism and You Tube.
review2: Had Landesman spent a bit more time on his characters and narrative, he might have made a more watchable movie.
review3: Parkland is a movie of simple motives. It doesn't waste time with pomp or theory, and the material is acted by those who connect with the characters like reflections in the mirror.
review4: Ultimately Parkland is not thought-provoking, inspiring or even brave enough to be offensive, but it does raise some interesting scenarios and is full of some very solid acting.
review5: While not bound for classic status, the film still manages to capture a moment in time that changed our country.

title: The Fitzgerald Family Christmas
review1: Resentments, pregnancies, cancer, spousal abuse and the struggle of a recovering alcoholic all come and go on cue.
review2: These Fitzgeralds are loud, selfish and often maddening, but they're a loving group, and you wouldn't mind spending more time with them.
review3: Burns remains an agreeable presence throughout, and the emotions mostly ring true, even if the comic elements feel overly broad and individual episodes are hit-and-miss.
review4: A holiday-themed piece shot through with humor and heartbreak. No bull. And low on sappy.
review5: Too much of the film is taken up by creaky plot devices and one sibling vowing to track down and talk to another one to resolve a problem.

title: As I Lay Dying
review1: I don't pretend to have a clue how to adapt William Faulkner's "As I Lay Dying" for the screen, but unlike James Franco, I, at least, didn't try.
review2: As a whole ... "As I Lay Dying" conveys some of Faulkner's themes, and the details of the Bundren family story, with clarity and concision.
review3: It remains to be seen whether James Franco can live up to his outsized ambitions.
review4: Like Franco's other directorial efforts, it ends up coming across as an academic art object, somewhere halfway between a graduate thesis and a video installation-interesting, but only in context.
review5: Faulkner fans... need not be up in arms about this version of his Nobel Prize winner.

title: Syrup
review1: It's tempting to say that Aram Rappaport's Syrup sticks, but it's also true.
review2: Syrup is an unsatisfying blend of romantic comedy and scathing social satire, slamming the high-stakes games of product marketing and sales.
review3: The actors are young and beautiful, the soundtrack kicks and the camera zips around with precision. But the script never seems to match the carefully orchestrated mood.
review4: The story works hard for winking relevance. But this dark lark is like walking around Times Square looking at the flashy logos and lights and thinking you see the message behind the medium.
review5: A great performance from Amber Heard can't save Syrup from its half-baked, sluggish script and obnoxious complacency.

title: Bonnie & Clyde: Justified
review1: At best the film is an enticement to the viewer to look back at the lives of Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow and perhaps watch the better films made on the subject. There's no real justification for watching or re-watching this film, however.

title: Grabbers
review1: Off to the pub!
review2: Wright checks off the expected genre boxes with the gleeful mischief of a gremlin trashing a plane engine.
review3: The tough thing about genre hybrids is that they have to fulfill both genres, and Grabbers only nails one of them.
review4: A group of Irish villagers have to stay drunk to keep alcohol-fearing alien monsters at bay. Yup.
review5: Recommended only for those peering through the thickest of beer goggles.

title: Footprints
review1: It's original and poetic, and if you see it you will probably remember scenes from it a year from now, because it's not really like anything else.
review2: "Footprints" looks like a Jim Jarmusch film set inside an Edward Hopper painting.
review3: Ambitious if airlessly microcosmic.
review4: The script's so incoherent and the acting so amateurish that it makes the worst old-time Hollywood B-flick seem like "Citizen Kane."
review5: This often risible head-scratcher never cracks the surface of its muddled ambitions, largely wasting its iconic settings on a series of motley interactions, Tinseltown trivia and self-conscious philosophizing.

title: The Citizen
review1: The story's accumulation of contrived setbacks strains credulity.
review2: It's ridiculous, but Kadi seems determined to stay in this comfort zone, trusting in the banality of melodrama to communicate simple ideas on life, love, and the pursuit of happiness.
review3: It's pushing its agenda at every moment, first gently, then relentlessly.
review4: Tired and worn out immigrant's saga with a 9/11 hook that isn't compelling

title: A Country Christmas
review1: Big-hearted, kid-friendly holiday film with shallow plot.

title: Home Again
review1: All three actors acquit themselves well, particularly Bent as Dunston, a soulful man trying to leave his violent past behind.
review2: Rather improbably, two of the three are handed happy endings so the requirements of drama do belatedly trump political lessons in Home Again.

title: Paradise
review1: The movie goes nowhere, and Ms. Cody's screenplay is relentlessly talky while standing still.
review2: Cody's satiric knocks on Christians couldn't be more blundering and obvious. Yet her dialogue is often funny, and the unusual three-way friendship is refreshing.
review3: The script needed another draft. And the screenwriter needed another star - and a real director.
review4: Cody has concocted a modern-day "Alice Through the Looking Glass," with none of the danger or wit.
review5: The problems with "Paradise," Diablo Cody's first directing effort and fourth produced screenplay, begin almost immediately ...

title: I Declare War
review1: This Canadian feature cleverly mixes archetypes from war films and coming-of-age movies, defamiliarizing both genres in the process.
review2: Co-directors Jason Lapeyre and Robert Wilson do little more than repeatedly echo the pic's theme after establishing the basic conceit of Lapeyre's script in the opening minutes.
review3: [A] surreal, strangely effective look at childhood imagination.
review4: The performances may be slightly uneven across the cast of a dozen distinct personalities (plus a dog), but overall the effect works because, after all, they're just playacting ... right?
review5: Imagination is what these filmmakers could use more of, as their ingenious concept doesn't develop much beyond gimmick.

title: Barbara
review1: It persuades us early on that its aura of political tension and suspicion, its taciturnity, its very strictness of silent observation as it begins, are fostering an intelligent thriller.
review2: Though the film runs a mere 105 minutes, it weighs on viewers like an eternity.
review3: The movie examines the possibility of maintaining one's humanity in a truly oppressive society.
review4: Hoss, wearing her blond hair pulled back tight, and wearing an expression of inscrutable melancholy, gives a performance that doesn't feel like a performance at all.
review5: The occasional ravings of the patients, ringing off the walls in Petzold's measured quiet, provide an appropriate backdrop to the heroine's need for freedom, yet the movie's politics never trump its humanity.

title: Prince Avalanche
review1: One of the most intriguing and thoughtful American films of the year.
review2: For those who've come for the juvenile humor, the film has very little to offer. Unfortunately, there is nothing particularly moving or substantive, either.
review3: Most of the film feels directionless... Yet, I can't deny that Prince Avalanche has a charm about it
review4: Prince Avalanche certainly takes its time getting anywhere, but it's hard to complain too much when the company's good and the scenery is this nice.
review5: An offbeat story with an unfocused director and narrative, Prince Avalanche becomes a mere lucid dream of cinematic enjoyment.

title: The Attack
review1: Screenwriters Ziad Doueiri and Joelle Touma pull quite a few punches here, making the doctor improbably naive about Israeli-Palestinian tensions so that his transformation seems profound.
review2: "The Attack" doesn't force us to pick a side. But it does force us to question our outsiders' hope in conciliation.
review3: Arouses profound questions about fanaticism, cultural identity, and the essential mystery of other people, even those we think we know best.
review4: It's set up as a descent into the heart of darkness, but it ends up playing out in pallid shades of grey.
review5: Imagine a blissful life taken away: Story of an Arab man who's assimilated into Israeli society but finds out that his wife was a suicide bomber. Nothing new here about the conflict, fair portrayal of the sides, thought provoking without solutions.

title: All Is Bright
review1: You might think you can see where Almost Christmas is heading but it never quite loses its acerbic edge or goes emotionally blooey.
review2: This engaging if somewhat underwhelming tale of unlikely redemption builds a funny-sad web of intersecting interactions around its strong central perfs.
review3: The film is happy to observe wryly as boredom and failure threaten to overwhelm the men.
review4: The film has an accomplished mood of cantankerous despair, but it's still little more than downbeat fluff.
review5: Worth enduring only for a rare lead performance by Paul Giamatti, whose expert delineation of rage and frustration lends form to Morrison's otherwise shapeless script.

title: Blue Collar Boys
review1: Nistico seems to have achieved what he wanted: He validates the question, If the American dream was stolen, wouldn't you want to steal it back?
review2: Nistico's clichéd, sledgehammer dialogue alone is enough to shut this one down.
review3: The film scores as an honest and often disturbing portrait of contemporary working class life, and it certainly deserves to be seen.

title: Violet & Daisy
review1: A thriller that might as well have been released in 1996, when everybody and their brother and their sister and their cousin twice-removed was trying to be Quentin Tarantino ...
review2: Of course, the violence is cringe-worthy and, at times, over the top. But view this as a modern comic book/fairy tale, and it's easier to accept this saga of girls with guns and the life lessons they eventually confront.
review3: The film's subtle visual allure is all but stamped out by the impression that the director tries too hard to be an idiosyncratic auteur in the vein of Quentin Tarantino.
review4: Violet and Daisy are just violent and crazy - which is, ultimately, the real problem. And why we should care about them remains the one mystery no one here can quite unravel.
review5: A rather dull affair.

title: Thérèse
review1: A remarkably pretty, if equally dour, portrait of the bored, oppressive life led by the provincial bourgeoisie.
review2: Exquisitely tasteful but suffocatingly dull ...
review3: While there's a certain staid feeling to the production, it does deliver a solid working-over to the era's gentry.
review4: The film looks great. As for the human element, the mood is more apathetic than tragic, and star Audrey Tautou has to take much of the blame for the film's failure.
review5: The magnificent nature that surrounds Therese becomes her prison. It's an interesting paradox, but not necessarily an especially satisfying experience.

title: Paranoia
review1: There's nothing wrong with Paranoia that a stronger director, livelier leading actors and several hundred fewer narrative conveniences wouldn't cure.
review2: This is a film at odds with itself, wanting to be a 99 percenter rallying cry but wallowing in and fetishizing 1 percenter accoutrement at every turn.
review3: Paranoia, a ho-hum thriller about corporate spying in the high-tech world, comes off as a lot more preposterous than paranoid, and it takes no more than a few frames for the eye rolling to commence.
review4: Corporate thrillers just aren't what they used to be.
review5: Paranoia is professional in every way, but there's no pulse to it. It is entirely adequate, livened up only by a few supporting turns.

title: Breaking The Girls
review1: An erotic thriller with too many twists and back stories to count.
review2: [Zima] saves some of this plodding thriller - a police investigation alone seems to go on forever - but not enough to make the steaminess pay off.
review3: What remains is a bland, perfunctory erotic thriller that lacks the courage of its would-be-trashy convictions ...
review4: It woefully lacks subtlety and suspense, and its characters aren't the least bit sympathetic.
review5: Gratuitous sex, double-crosses and more gratuitous sex await in the silly but always-entertaining sexcapade.

title: And While We Were Here
review1: For every such moment there's a sappy montage or overt visual reference to Rossellini to cheapen the effect.
review2: [A] familiarly snoozy romantic drama.
review3: Though the film plays like late-era Woody Allen - not necessarily a good thing - and Goldberg's rambunctiousness is more annoying than liberating, there's a serious depth of feeling here.
review4: The marital crisis at the movie's heart has lost its allegorical weight. Jane and Leonard are just another unhappy couple with problems that have nothing to do with the direction of Western civilization.
review5: "And While We Were Here" is just good enough to pique your curiosity, but never quite good enough to captivate.

title: 2 Guns
review1: Washington and Wahlberg have a good time robbing banks and blowing up buildings and barreling through military security checkpoints and double-crossing people and shooting each other because none of it really means anything.
review2: That a movie this fleet and lean succumbs to action-blockbuster bloat in the home stretch is both disappointing and predictable, although the director deserves credit for keeping the climactic shootouts slick and spatially coherent.
review3: Mark Wahlberg reunites with Contraband director Baltasar Kormakur for an action movie that's even more cynical and sadistic than its predecessor.
review4: What it lacks in robots and superheroes it more than makes up for in laughs, gunplay and personality.
review5: Generic, by-the-numbers buddy-action flicks don't come much more generic than this forgettable project.

title: Hannah Arendt
review1: Barbara Sukowa delivers a beautifully modulated performance, showing the rigor of Arendt's thought and convictions while revealing the contours of a passionate woman with complex relationships.
review2: [Barbara Sukowa] invests Arendt with a steely fury, but the film, set during and after the 1961 trial of ex--Nazi official Adolf Eichmann, has an entertaining cocktail-banter superficiality.
review3: ...actors in supporting roles telegraph the controversies surrounding Arendt's personality as if they were attempting to literally touch the viewer's nose.
review4: Von Trotta doesn't do justice to this strong woman and her contribution to thinking about the nature of evil.
review5: A crisply measured character study with plenty of intriguing ideas, elevated by a terrific, finely calibrated performance by Sukowa.

title: The Canyons
review1: It believes it's taking risks it actually has no interest in taking, that it's seeing profundity in the showbiz shallows.
review2: Very little animating emotion to explain why the film had to be made, why the story needed to be told.
review3: With the pungent combination of a script from novelist Bret Easton Ellis, a performance by Lindsay Lohan and direction by Paul Schrader, The Canyons might have been a micro-budget sensation, but sadly it reeks of laziness.
review4: Schrader's idea of a modern-day noir has promise but Ellis' script lets him down and leaves the actors adrift with no scenes to play.
review5: Merely confirms Schrader as an all-but spent force (it's been largely downhill since the dismal Dominion) and nails Bret Easton Ellis as a one-trick pony.

title: Myn Bala: Warriors Of The Steppe
Red 2
review1: It's not that surprising coming from a Bruce Willis flick, but its thesis of gun lovers being morally superior to bomb lovers is still entirely suspect.
review2: A highly-watchable but stilted sequel that serves as a complacent sequel to the fun original.
review3: Much of the originality has faded and Morgan Freeman's absence is keenly felt, but the end result is still a fun, exciting adventure.
review4: Red 2 fails to capture the fun of the first film, but manages to hold on to its weaker traits, such as a bloated runtime and an inundation of mindless action sequences, turning this into a rather forgettable affair.
review5: The cookie-cutter action sequences - car chases, fireballs, shoot-outs - are so-so and whereas the first film had a giddy cheekiness to it, the vibe here just feels forced, a common trait of sequels we really weren't hankering for.

title: Romeo & Juliet in Yiddish
review1: A charming and entertaining movie that instills a little fantasy into the mix.
review2: The performances are uneven, but there's a grimy thrill to seeing scenes from the play in subway cars and on fire escapes.
review3: Oy, such terrible jokes and choppy direction.
review4: The film, written and directed by Eve Annenberg (who also stars) is sprawling and sometimes confusing, but its premise is charming and not at all far-fetched.
review5: There have been many untraditional film adaptations of Shakespeare's, but few have been as unorthodox as this one...

title: Battle Ground
review1: While Forbidden Ground can't match the scope of Peter Weir's Gallipoli and Stanley Kubrick's Paths of Glory in its tough-minded depiction of the First World War, the film successfully captures the personal tragedy and human sacrifice of the experience.
review2: An impressive and memorable film that should have a long life in digital form, even though its cinema releases are limited

title: The Watsons Go to Birmingham
review1: Warm family drama brings the civil rights movement to life.

title: Jobs
review1: The critics screwed up on this. It is a much better film than its rating here. Take that from someone who worked in IT for 44 years and who knows the difference between "fresh" and "rotten".
review2: The movie is littered with small details of lore that should make Apple fanatics happy.
review3: A noble but unworthy effort that will likely disappoint viewers looking for a thoughtful look into the technological genius.
review4: Matt Whiteley's clumsy script attempts to sync Jobs' personal story with the corporate history of his brand but as any affirmed Android/PC users will gladly tell you, syncing with Apple can be problematic at the best of times.
review5: This movie would be exponentially better if it were called Twenty-Something Jobs or Jobs, Woz And The First 2 Apples.

title: Le Joli Mai
review1: What helps make Marker and Lhomme's documentary all the more remarkable is its occurring at a moment in history whose specialness only became evident later.
review2: It's never fully uninflected like authentic vérité, but the material gets at a kind of truth: the chatty anxieties of shopkeepers, passersby, mothers and sons, all grappling with the changing world of May 1962.
review3: Documents on-the-street talks with a wide variety of Paris residents.
review5: The people and cinematography are compelling, and so, by extension, is this 1962 documentary.

title: Fear and Desire
review1: Treat it like a wobbly, precocious demo from a 24-year-old with mighty aspirations, filled with hints of what he would become, and you'll be properly enthralled.
review2: If Fear and Desire is uneven and sometimes reveals an experimental rather than a polished exterior, its over-all effect is entirely worthy of the sincere effort put into it.
review4: A dismal expression of a lousy script... every bit the work of a young kid with lots of ideas and no clue what to do with them.
review5: Kubrick does show some brash invention and a yearning to experiment with angles.

title: Il Futuro
review1: In the complexly stoic Martelli and masterfully craggy, haunted Hauer, an alluringly opaque pas de deux of loss and uncertainty is wonderfully realized.
review2: Ms. Scherson's style - backed wholeheartedly by the cool cinematography of Ricardo de Angelis - may value mood over information, but it's the perfect vehicle for a portrait of two damaged souls grasping for a security they no longer possess.
review3: a curiously effective coming-of-age tale
review4: Il Futuro, aptly bereft of actual Italians, teases out the idea of thrown-off foreigners, bridged by fluid identities.
review5: Alicia Scherson's enthralling Il Futuro asks the question no one wants to hear: How would you see the world after a personal tragedy?

title: The Deflowering of Eva Van End
review2: A slight story that never gets past its shock scenes.

title: Shahid
review1: Mr. Mehta has done something difficult. He has made a film of conviction that's neither plodding nor preachy.
review2: Mehta's drama establishes strong humanistic qualities and a deeply personal protagonist before launching into the courtroom fireworks.
review3: The film, which apparently was made by Mehta to battle growing negative allegations against the late Shahid, includes numerous fictionalized moments. Solidly acted by all, Shahid would no doubt have benefited from a more documentary feel.

title: Hawaii
review1: Hawaii will likely act as a 100 minutes of groin-stirring cinematic foreplay ... the film is a wonderful creation that radiates and which allows audiences to experience its heart-pounding rhythms with every bit as much intensity as its characters.

title: Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion
review1: Its portrait of a loner and his lusts comes up frighteningly fresh, and the whole conceit would collapse without the muscular, rousing presence of Gian Maria Volonté in the central role.
review2: A paranoid police procedural, a perverse parable about the corrupting elements of power, and a candidate for the greatest predated Patriot Act movie ever ...
review3: A provocative political thriller that is as troubling today as when it came out in 1970. Maybe more so.
review4: The movie survives beautifully both as an elegant thriller and as a study of the twisted infantilism that shapes the fanatic heart.
review5: A potent study of power as pathology.

title: Boss
review1: "Boss" is billed as an action comedy, but it isn't always clear what is part of the joke and what isn't.
review2: "Boss" is a film suffering from one fundamental problem, to wit: a lack of commitment to its central purpose.

title: Winnie Mandela
review1: This biopic is part hagiography, part expose, and gravely incoherent.
review2: It would have benefited the film if Roodt had been as bold with the mechanics of his storytelling as he is with his inclusion of the title character's less savory moments. But its strengths, particularly the two lead performances, far outweigh its flaws.
