review3: "Winnie Mandela'' really stumbles when it comes to depicting the couple's painful separation, which the film suggests resulted more from politics than Winnie's infidelity.
review4: Despite the marquee names and their obvious talent, the film feels like a made-for-TV movie.
review5: Distant and obvious, it takes a story with many angles and reduces its edges, becoming a glorified TV movie.

title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones
review1: It didn't help that the execution of the complex storyline was so messy and confusing that it was difficult to understand why the villain was doing what he was doing.
review2: 'Author' Cassandra Clare assumes that you have never seen a film or read a book in your entire life. She steals plot details from Star Wars, Harry Potter and Twilight and assumes that no one will notice. I did.
review3: Awful, expensive, over-long, unremittingly dull attempt to start a Twilight-like franchise... plans were already underway for the sequel before this was released. They might just want to wait to see if anybody's interested first.
review4: If you can overlook the lack of originality, the film actually makes a good fist of making something fresh and appealing from its second-hand ingredients.
review5: Way to give overwrought fan fiction a bad name. No amount of fairy dust can make this bewitching.

title: Drinking Buddies
review1: Every aspect of this film fits together nicely, even when the drama going on in the film is a little messy.
review2: This is a giant nothing. I can't think of a recent picture where I've seen less effort to enlighten or entertain.
review3: I was a bit skeptical when I first learned about Drinking Buddies, because I did not expect Wilde and her cohorts to be up for the task; thankfully, I was proven wrong, and the actors go places that I would never expect studio-seasoned actors to go.
review4: A beautifully observed dramedy about modern friendship and romance; funny, poignant, unforgettable.
review5: It finds its groove with sincere, nuanced performances and a realistic attitude to romance as refreshing as a fistful of Citra hops.

title: Things Never Said
review1: The result may not be a big movie, but Things Never Said makes a big emotional impact.
review2: When it comes to writing the poetry that Kalindra recites, Murray knows how to do more with less; he needs to apply that lesson to his filmmaking, too.
review3: A powerful statement about the plight of women held back by sexist tyranny.
review4: The film's stars ... are hugely charismatic individually and have chemistry with each other. But the soapy melodrama and ferocious, on-the-nose poems threaten to overpower their budding romance.
review5: The movie's poems are unambiguous rants, delivered with theatrical ferocity. On-the-nose dialogue propels its lessons in self-respect.

title: Fighting For Freedom
review1: Its reasonable message gets lost amid teary-eyed exhortations and grandiose speechifying.

title: Heart of the Country
review1: Faith-based drama has heavy themes but positive messages.

title: The Angels' Share
review1: Modest in scale, expansive in emotions, this movie is a rarity: a contemporary tragicomedy.
review2: Despite its ultimate sense of optimism, the Glasgow-set dramedy nevertheless carries a sense of foreboding. And yet, that might not have been the intention.
review3: The result is a sometimes gritty, occasionally charming Highland hybrid, but the final balance feels slightly off-kilter.
review4: Loach takes us through the mysteries of whisky making, exploring the subtle tastes and scents in ways that will have audiences wishing they had a dram at hand. But a glass also serves more symbolic purposes ...
review5: If you want to look for it, you'll find a layer of metaphor (the distilling process as a symbol of the characters' evolution) and social-realist commentary amid the gentle, life-affirming laughs.

title: Jayne Mansfield's Car
review1: There's a terrific movie struggling to escape from this overplotted, overedited, overdetermined stew ...
review2: It's one thing to explore the messiness of familial relationships and regret against the backdrop of the Vietnam War, and something else entirely to try and shove every jot and tiddle in place before the closing credits roll.
review3: Jayne Mansfield's Car isn't likely to set America's theaters on fire, but it's a powerful whisper of a film.
review4: Overall, the rambling "Jayne Mansfield's Car" is almost as big a wreck as its namesake.
review5: In its best moments, you can see what the film might have been with half a dozen fewer characters.

title: Twenty8k
review1: The film's ensemble cast is an impressive mix of old hands and fresh faces, but their efforts are let down by some very contrived plotting.
review2: The pacey but formulaic action rapidly loses credibility.
review3: Badly let down by some silly plotting that negates the film's ability to be taken seriously and a screenplay that all too often reduces a lot of the characters to stereotype.
review4: One expected more from a script co-written by Paul Abbott.
review5: There's a good cast here, but it's hard to shake off the feeling that this would probably work better on TV, the subject matter being very familiar to those who like their drama delivered in episodes.

title: Some Girl(s)
review1: Attains the occasional moment of clarity, but ultimately has neither the dramatic heft nor the anchoring talent to justify an hour and a half in the company of a boring sociopath.
review2: There are a lot of truthful notes in "Some Girl(s)," but there are also false ones that let you know that you are being played with. You'd best beware.
review3: Mayer does little to open up LaBute's original play, and the staginess often feels oppressive. The performances are mixed, too.
review4: The deft and merciless director sides with the girls, and to stack the deck she's hired five tremendous actresses who thrill to tear poor Brody apart
review5: The title's parenthetical plural sums up the problem with Some Girl(s): Five slow-cook dialogues that reveal the nice-guy protagonist as a super-tool is four too many.

title: The Hunt
review1: You leave The Hunt unsettled in the best sense. Its images and implications are likely to stay in your head a long time.
review2: The Hunt's inexorability feels derived more from thematic or ideological concerns than any organic necessity.
review3: Thomas Vinterberg's The Hunt conveys the sinister swirl of persecution more vividly than any film I can remember.
review4: The Hunt has left me more shaken than any other film I've seen all year.
review5: It's moving, yet unsettling throughout, especially with an open ending that refuses to give the audience the closure that we foolishly think we'll get.

title: The Seasoning House
review1: The film's downbeat switchback ending is neither convincing nor earned.
review2: While lead actress Rosie Day turns in a phenomenal performance, The Seasoning House is more bite than bark, creating an uneven and empty watch.
review3: An expertly crafted thriller and manages to show a heartfelt side of the issue.
review4: It's atmospheric and a tense journey, arguably not unlike Gravity if you were to replace the vacuum of space with a bunch of angry, accented dudes
review5: The whole thing is laugh-out-loud dumb.

title: Battle of the Year
review1: its dramatization of a U.S. dream team's journey to the international showcase is leaden with predictable character types and storytelling clichés, neither of which its well-executed but oddly infrequent dance sequences are able to overcome.
review2: The actual dancing scenes are occasionally electrifying, if far too sparse, but other than that and the welcome sight of co-star Chris Brown getting clocked in the face, the film barely gets off the ground, much less sticks the landing.
review3: A dead-in-the-soul cash grab of a movie set in the competitive world of B-boy dancing that thinks clichés, phony melodrama and product placement can substitute for real storytelling and actual characters.
review4: Battle of the Year clearly features lots of brilliant dancers, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy watching them move. But you wish there were more dancing here.
review5: Despite the reasonable dancing scenes and passable acting by singer Chris Brown, Battle Of The Year is a string of clichés, stock characters and unbearable melodrama.

title: The Ultimate Life
review1: "The Ultimate Life" is hampered by a predictable story, stereotypical characters and wooden acting.
review2: A terminally dull piece of faith-based family-values filmmaking designed to appeal strictly to the converted.
review3: The message of "The Ultimate Life" could be summed up on a greeting card.
review4: 'The Ultimate Life' is an awkward, mostly dull, but well-intentioned faith-based movie, among the less-than-stellar offerings that, unfortunately, often presented to the sadly under-served faith-based audience that deserves thoughtful screenplays.
review5: Drew Waters talent helps make this family film with a moral message entertaining.

title: Adore
review1: With its soap-operatic performances, bonkbuster plotline and sparkling seafront setting, all 'Adore' really lacks is a cameo from Alf Stewart
review2: Would Fontaine have made this film if the mothers looked like and were as old as Barbra Streisand and Kathy Bates and the sons weren't built like surfers? Of course not.
review3: This isn't an Oedipus complex. This is a Preposterous complex.
review4: Cast actresses with the skills that Naomi Watts and Robin Wright bring, give their obliviously icky story some arthouse visual lyricism, and you've got "Adore."
review5: This film needed serious judgment: someone to rewrite the underwritten draft of the script and to have a firmer opinion on these terribly unappealing characters

title: The Rooftop
review1: The candy-colored musical from Taiwanese heartthrob Jay Chou is two-thirds delightful.
review2: "The Rooftop" is frenzied, funny and knowing, drenched in lavish, often surreal, imagery.
review3: "The Rooftop" is a restless boy-fights-for-girl fantasia, too stylistically bulbous a misfire to allow for easy enjoyment as either a demented throwback or a genre hybrid.
review4: Chou, who also wrote and directed, has a good eye for visuals, but when it comes to his screenplay, he could have used a lot more originality.

title: Toad Road
review1: Mr. Banker teases us with a dizzy, dislocating shooting style that throws up a succession of eerily arresting images. Even so, his film never overcomes the fact that watching drugged-out wastrels is rarely interesting ...
review2: Think of it as the CliffsNotes version of Dante Alighieri's "Inferno."
review3: The first unique horror film to come along in years.
review4: Director Jason banker finds the ironic beauty that arises from his characters' self-contemptuous and misplaced acts of destruction.
review5: ...(often)too much about the party and not enough about the paranormal.

title: Touchy Feely
review1: Despite its hints of New Age mysticism and serviceable performances from an able cast, Touchy Feely is too entrenched in its dour tone to be uplifting.
review2: The actors are all first-rate and the performances are fascinating, though Shelton, who shuns exposition, makes you work to figure out the interrelationships.
review3: There's something fresh and new here, something that wasn't so dominant in [Shelton's] previous work.
review4: A work that gestures toward depths without truly plumbing them.
review5: There is strong character work in here, one or two genuinely touching moments, and some good laughs too.

title: Our Children
review1: It's an interesting way to tell a story and a devastating journey, particularly since it's based on a real-life incident.
review2: This is a taut psychological study, based on a true story, of the complexities of personal power relationships that begins with the kind of shattering revelation that would be the conclusion of most films.
review3: There is no whodunit here -- the horror is plain in the opening shots -- and the how is presented with great restraint, but the why remains veiled and mysterious long after the film has ended.
review4: Our Children was inspired by a real-life Belgian tragedy, but director Joachim LaFosse has built that news item into his own micro-portrait of coercion dipped in kindness.
review5: At once beautifully realized and brutally uncompromising ...

title: Contest
review1: "Contest" more than makes up for some first-time-filmmaker shortcomings with its sincerity and unexpected strengths in the storyline and cinematography.
review2: Strong anti-bullying tone outshines movie's low-budget feel.

title: Prisoners
review1: The last half hour, despite the occasional jolt of excitement, is an embarrassment.
review2: I was shocked to learn this is an original screenplay and not an adaptation. Everything about the story stinks of a crappy novel someone bought at an airport.
review3: This film haunted me for days and weeks after seeing it, and the feeling still lingers.
review4: Prisoners is in the best thriller traditions, but goes deeper into a reflection of one of the greatest moral dilemmas in modern society ... choosing to not only be memorable, but to matter.
review5: Prisoners is a devastating ordeal through the Villeneuve's impressionistic prism. It's a testament to all involved that you want to revisit the ugliness of the story for the artistry of its construction.

title: The Family
review1: The movie is a curious mess, but the cast is having a grand old time.
review2: De Niro's deadpan humour suits a garden burial perfectly, but we just don't see enough of how we really want him to be.
review3: Features a contender for worst subplot of the year.
review4: A terrible waste of many wonderful talents in front of and behind the camera.
review5: Could've been an inoffensive enough 90 minute feature, but the film insists on garbling the narrative with useless subplots that...bloat the movie beyond the breaking point.

title: Ain't Them Bodies Saints
review1: Director Lowery, in only his second film, offers us a fine modern-day interpretation of classic Terrence Malick.
review2: Please stop it with the goddammed chicks twirling through fields of sun-dappled what already.
review3: Lowery's beautiful Ain't Them Bodies Saints is about sometimes letting go of who you are for a second chance to be who you to want to be.
review4: The [film's beauty] is not just in the incredible cinematography ... but in the way the film holds back information, blindsiding you with tiny revelations.
review5: A mixed bag of gorgeous images and sounds trapped in an only partially-developed narrative.

title: Museum Hours
review1: Sommer is perfect. So is O'Hara. This is the "Before Sunrise" for a very different (and platonic) pair of individuals.
review2: Amid all the looking and dissection, Cohen demonstrates an understanding of the individual need for increasingly elusive privacy that feels urgent, wistful, and quaint.
review3: The quiet time that Johann and Anne spend during museum hours -- and after his shifts on trips around the city -- offer solace in their mutual solitude. Museum Hours is an introverted companion for its viewers.
review4: The two leads contribute fresh, genuine performances, and what might have been a musty academic exercise gains in tension from Cohen's deft juxtaposing of vocal narration, character detail, and majestic artwork.
review5: It's as if Cohen had lived for centuries among these places, and sometimes with art that encapsulates these centuries, and is pleasantly imprisoned within its strength.

title: Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters
review1: ...impressively fares almost as well as its above-average predecessor...
review2: the film might have been more charming with Ray Harryhausen effects than with CGI
review3: Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters doesn't present a world with depth or originality... but as far as cinematic adaptations of young adult novels go, it thankfully strikes the right tone."
review4: A good special effects family movie that's every bit as accomplished as 'The Lightning Thief' and possibly better-even if it doesn't follow the fantasy novels like a road map.
review5: With sequels of this type, we tend to see the stakes raised and the action increased to even more exciting levels than before, but for "Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters," things are pretty much the same, but somehow made even blander than before.

title: Elysium
review1: Any thematic audacity is snuffed out by action sequences that you can now buy at Dollar General.
review2: It has no particular voice. It's too clotted with plot and strategy.
review3: Neill Blomkamp has created a beautifully designed and realized world. If only he'd spent half as much time focusing on the people that inhabit it.
review4: With "Elysium," Blomkamp not only fills the film with enough exciting action to make it fly by, but he also provides an interesting commentary on the continuing division of classes, turning it into something more than your average monotonous action flick.
review5: While not the slam-dunk that his first film was, Neill Blomkamp has created a compelling vision of a wealth-dominated future.

title: Railway Children (Children of a Darker Dawn)
Cottage Country
review1: Wellington can't quite pull off the tone of this dark comedy, where the jokes and drama often fit awkwardly together ...
review2: For the audience, it's a weekend they'll wish to forget.
review3: Moments of delicious insanity, but screenwriter Boxen can't sustain the frantic tone, leaving the feature top heavy instead of building to a devastatingly funny and frightful conclusion.
review4: The premise is promising, but this Canadian effort squanders it like the spoilsport who spends his time up north watching old VHS tapes.

title: Una noche (One Night)
review1: A compelling portrait of a population decrement via the Florida Straits.
review2: Mulloy's camera is fully alive to the geographical possibilities of her location, hustling after the hustlers, pausing for a shot of a caged bird or a nightclub singer. It's quite a stew.
review3: [Mulloy] brings a documentarian's objective eye to "Una Noche," yet the actors - non-professionals - convey exactly the emotions she is looking for.
review4: Writer-director Lucy Mulloy displays much promise in her first feature, a gritty teen drama shot in Havana with a nonprofessional cast.
review5: Una noche thrums with the vibrant energy of restless youth taking their fates into their own hands.

title: Caesar Must Die
review1: It is almost an impertinence to think that we understand the thoughts of these actors and those in the audience who are relatives and friends. But this is the intriguing privilege that the Taviani brothers have given us.
review2: A film somewhere between documentary and neo-realist drama.
review3: There's barely a wasted moment in the film, which runs a brisk 76 minutes and contains no female roles.
review4: There's an intensity and emotional accuracy to the performances that's just stunning, particularly Striano's Brutus, as he longs for death and release.
review5: It's an arresting, playful and moving film ...

title: The Berlin File
review1: There is something sharp, exciting and more original tucked within "The Berlin File" - and it is in moments a sleek, crackling film - but it all feels somehow misshapen.
review2: As soon as "The Berlin File" takes flight with its exhilarating action set pieces, memories of any muddles evaporate amid the tension and vivid engagement with settings, from courtyards to fields.
review3: The Berlin File benefits from gritty surroundings that add a cold war realism to this otherwise confusing tale of conflicted loyalties and secret agendas.
review4: The story feels fairly perfunctory - not to mention unnecessarily knotty - but the well-connected leads do their best to ground it.
review5: [A] formulaic but solid Cold War-style spy thriller, with North Korea pinch-hitting for the Soviet Union.

title: C.O.G.
review1: Modest and good-looking, the film starts as dark comedy and ends in pathos. Director Alvarez makes the Oregon scenery a character unto itself.
review2: Despite smatterings of wit and a stable of skilled performers, "C.O.G." struggles to find a consistent tone, its episodic structure veering from farcical to poignant to dangerously raw.
review3: a dramedy that keeps you guessing where the main character is going (emotionally and physically) as he drifts from one odd situation to the next.
review4: The film features snappy, hilarious bits among the coming-of-age vignettes, but it loses momentum as it winds toward a finish. You won't grow bored with the characters, but you might check your watch a few times.
review5: For Sedaris fans, "C.O.G." is a regrettably patronizing washout.

title: Savannah
review1: This is a Southern "Downton Abbey," minus the loopy plot turns and wisecracks that make that series so addictive.
review2: The film's tale ends up being less rich than its lovely Georgia settings.
review3: "Savannah" should win some sort of award for most amount of times you'll ask, "They roped that guy into this turkey, too?"
review4: The movie's story is limp, its romances are flightless and-despite the talented cast-its performances are toothless.
review5: The story overflows with reverence but is drastically short on passion or suspense ...

title: Percentage
review1: Though obviously made on the cheap, and with choppy direction by Alex Merkin, the film - which includes plenty of sexual objectification along with Gray's girl power - doesn't take itself very seriously, and neither should you.

title: Last Love
review1: This sentimental Michael Caine drama is so dull that doctors could prescribe it to treat insomnia.
review2: This somber work about the worthiness of living has little life in it.
review3: "Last Love" starts out promising enough, but alas, it doesn't last.
review4: This dull, dawdling film, adapted from Françoise Dorner's novel "La Douceur Assassine," eventually succumbs to sentimentality.
review5: Caine's brave attempt to speak pigeon French with an American accent produces some unintentionally comedic moments. Every time he says 'Merci', for example, you'll think he's spotted a horse. As in "mare, see!"

title: Sweetwater
review1: This oater with shades of Weird West comic books has a plot too easy to foretell and a thrill level that dips with the rising of the body count.
review2: A revenge-fantasy Western that wants to luxuriate in its B-movie roots but suffers from dull direction and an even duller central performance.
review3: It bludgeons with intent, even dabbling in some "Deadwood"-level verbal shock-and-awe; without wit or intelligence, it's merely baroque affectation playacting at depth.
review4: As violent act begets silly exchange begets another violent act, "Sweetwater" squanders its noteworthy resources ...
review5: There are worse ways to spend 90 minutes than with a mediocre Western.

title: Don Jon
review1: A barn-door broad burlesque of Joisey stereotypes and holy-cannoli accents. It's Saturday Night Fever drawn in crayon.
review2: It's in movies like the ribald but surprisingly endearing sex comedy Don Jon that Gordon-Levitt has connected best with audiences.
review3: Don Jon is no kind of resonating masterpiece, but it's intelligent, thoughtful, funny, and dedicated to the cause of finding a personality and sticking with him through the excess of his addictions.
review4: Thankfully, the women of the film are what save the movie, bringing something fresh to the table-for Jon, a chance at lasting love, and for us, some seasoned comic chops.
review5: Wondering what exactly is revealed as a cure to Don Jon's addiction? Why, good sex, of course! Thanks, geniuses!

title: CBGB
review1: The music rocks, but little else does, in Randall Miller's sitcom snapshot of New York's iconic punk incubator.
review2: Alan Rickman's lead performance highlights a sincere but insubstantial rock pic.
review3: "CBGB" ain't no party, it ain't no disco, it ain't no foolin' around.
review4: If you really want to remember those times? Get out "Horses." Or "Talking Heads: 77." Or "Blank Generation." Preferably on vinyl, with all the pops and scratches. And play them. Loud.
review5: I would swear on a stack of Dead Boys T-shirts and a first pressing of Richard Hell and the Voidoids' "Blank Generation" that it could not possibly have been like that: so silly, so trivial, so boring.

title: La memoria del muerto (Memory of the Dead)
Runner Runner
review1: The actors hit the jackpot, but only in terms of their paychecks. The audience gets a tension-free, tight-assed, Casino ripoff that leaves them thoroughly fleeced.
review2: The mannered speech is fun, the players are charismatic, and director Brad Furman maintains an agreeably brisk pace.
review3: It looks like everybody's lying, and that's only because the acting is pretty bad.
review4: The movie mostly wants to look timely and seem topical. Instead, it feels irrelevant.
review5: Various subplots are given short shrift and the whole thing feels more like a Cliff's Notes version of a longer piece than an actual finished motion picture.

title: Tiger Eyes
review1: It's a pleasant-enough movie, but offers little that the book doesn't give its readers; far too quickly, it fades away.
review2: Remarkably, the story, adapted by Blume with her son, director Lawrence Blume, seems as fresh, painful and poignant as when she wrote it.
review3: There are no surprises among the characters - depressed mom (Amy Jo Johnson), controlling aunt (Cynthia Stevenson), new boyfriend (Tatanka Means) - but the cast is strong enough to build on familiar elements.
review4: Time has robbed Blume's subjects of shock value, but her perceptiveness hasn't dimmed. The movie's sincerity carries it along, and makes this story endearing despite its filmmaking clichés.
review5: This attenuated coming-of-age tale oozes heart and perhaps too much respect for its source material.

title: Thanks For Sharing
review1: Thanks for Sharing might best be described as being like Steve McQueen's sex-addiction drama, Shame, if it were rewritten by Neil Simon at his most schmaltzy.
review2: It's frankly exhausting to keep up with these neurotic over-sharers, who are neither serious enough to care about nor humorous enough to laugh at.
review3: At least most of the cast is appealing, with Mark Ruffalo, Gwyneth Paltrow, Josh Gad, and Alecia Moore (better known as pop singer Pink) delivering the uninspired dialogue with relative finesse.
review4: Be warned: viewers may experience a violent urge to shake the characters, one by one, and tell them to get a life.
review5: You get a very talented ensemble, but the material just isn't strong enough, leading to a lot of star power, but no staying power.

title: The Hunters
review1: Family adventure has positive messages, but muddled story.

title: We Are What We Are
review1: A provocative film about the horrors we can find within the usual comforts of family and tradition.
review2: Another welcome entry in the ongoing revival of horror movies that rely on character and setting rather than shock and gore to chill audiences to the marrow.
review3: And sometimes we are who we eat.
review4: Remakes may get a lot of stick in Hollywood, as filmmakers can be accused of being somewhat lazy and uncreative in that regard.
review5: An ambitious (if somewhat uneven) slice of downbeat American gothic which interweaves grim melancholia with pointed satire, doomy portent and moments of gnawing revulsion.

title: StreetDance 2
review1: So slapped together it feels less like a movie than an extended montage...
review2: If you're hoping for intricate plotting, suspense or even nominal character development, StreetDance 2 is unlikely to waltz away with your heart.
review3: Boutella shows promise beyond her day job as one of Madonna's dancers but otherwise speaking parts are sensibly limited to those who can act.
review4: Sexier dance sequel light on plot but heavy on dancing.
review5: When the provocative rhythms of Latin fuse with funky street-dancing, the result is sexy, visceral and exciting. Sofia Boutella is a sensation; watching her dance is sure to drive young men to distraction.

title: Fresh Meat
review1: While Fresh Meat is sometimes hard to swallow, I admittedly had more fun than I should have with this cannibal caper.
review2: while Mulheron's film works perfectly well as an over-the-top caper-like cluster***k of clashing values and transgressive tropes, it also has just enough locally sourced meat on the bone to emerge with its own peculiar textures and flavours.

title: Voodoo Possession
review1: Voodoo Possession does not do, that voodoo, it was supposed to do so well.

title: You're Next
review1: Given its title, you can be forgiven for assuming that Adam Wingard's home-invasion thriller will be just another blood-soaked body-count flick. But You're Next is better than that. A lot better.
review2: By slasher standards, the writing is good, with interesting turns and surprises. And the acting isn't bad, either, though Vinson is the one to remember.
review3: Flirts with being a meta-horror movie, which can be a way of making a routine slasher flick while making fun of routine slasher flicks.
review4: You're Next might be one of the most audience-gratifying horror films I've seen in quite a long time, rewarding the viewers as much as it likes to screw with them.
review5: Not the perfect horror movie, but GORE-iffic nonetheless.

title: Terraferma
review1: Terraferma offers a sun-splashed meditation on compassion, tradition, tolerance, and generational change.
review2: For the most part the multi-faceted story works.
review3: Crialese and co-screenwriter Vittorio Moroni portray a way of life on that island in complete uproar ..
review4: Involving, thematically rich ... yet also quite timeless ...
review5: Emanuele Crialese's film burns with a sense of this situation's inhumanity, and he gives a palpable sense of life in a place where the beauty attracts tourists, but the natives are barely getting by.

title: Lee Daniels' The Butler
review1: It's not an interpretation of actual history as much as it is a reduced revision of movie history.
review2: The excitement comes from watching the director's rude energy chafe up against the constraints of a traditional Oscar-bait biopic.
review3: The Butler is often impressively acted, beautifully shot and clearly designed to try to pick up a heartfelt award or two. But, as a film, it's too fragmented to carry its own weight on its shoulders and is over- burdened by a starry cast.
review4: The Butler tells an obviously important and inspiring story, but the actual movie is laughable.
review5: A large-scale, middle-of-the-road work that is entertaining and moving in the way that many other movies about the struggle for race equality have been.

title: Getting That Girl
review1: Vapid teen comedy full of profanity, sex, drug use.

title: Café de Flore
review1: A forgettable film.
review2: It's terribly long and repetitive for so delicately dreamy a diptych, and at times the modern-day story feels like little more than a drawn-out apologia for the wandering male gaze.
review3: Goes from intriguing to irritating.
review4: Feels less like a movie than like a cinematic jigsaw puzzle whose agitation undermines the very continuity it wants to portray.
review5: Decade-hopping metaphysical romance descends into overwrought histrionics.

title: Canela (Cinnamon)
review1: Subtitled film about grief and cooking is heavy but sweet.

title: Four
review1: [It] never achieves its intended weightiness.
review2: The close-ups of faces convey reams of inchoate emotion and enhance the stumbling poetry mouthed by characters whose urge to connect conflicts with their innate sense of caution.
review3: Four goes believable places but avoids the trappings of traditional melodrama.
review4: A cautionary tale featuring spectacular Fourth of July fireworks of the emotional variety.

title: I'm In Love With A Church Girl
review1: Even having God on the production team can't save this 'Church Girl' from its heavy-handed sermonizing.
review2: This overlong drama plays like a threefold infomercial: for Christianity, the cheesy resort chain Sandals and Jeff "Ja Rule" Atkins, the rapper-turned-actor playing drug kingpin Miles Montego.
review3: A message film with the narrative sophistication of a recruiting pamphlet.
review4: Suffers from the same ills as too many movies that preach to the choir: a laborious length, formulaic plot and dialogue and, disappointing for a film that stars a rapper, a stock score.
review5: We're apparently supposed to root for these two to make it, although Vanessa is outlandishly jealous and pushy.

title: Short Term 12
review1: Larson delivers one of the great performances of 2013.
review2: Here is a movie overflowing with compassion, warmth and good humor.
review3: Raw, intense, human and absorbing.
review4: It's a wild, unruly mess of rampant emotions, and yes, some of them are painful, but there's a great deal of warmth and love here too. It's a truly wonderful movie.
review5: ...the best film of 2013 so far. ... It will devastate you without warning and break your heart, all while showing you how to move on and feel hopeful again...

title: Underdogs
review1: There's scarcely a moment that doesn't feel hackneyed; at its best, it's like Friday Night Lights (movie or series) drained of everything remotely distinctive.

title: Fruitvale Station
review1: It's a gentle film, with deep reservoirs of empathy and understanding. And so terribly sad.
review2: As well as being a superb piece of filmmaking and writing that tells an important story of what happened, it's also a thought-provoking tribute to what could have been.
review3: [Fruitvale Station] has a profound emotional impact by keeping things simple.
review4: Coogler's realistic debut recreates Grant's final day with affection, refusing to cast him as either saint or sinner.
review5: There's a sincere clarity that Michael B. Jordan achieves from beginning to end. Raw and proficient in delivery, his performance places him near the top of the most exciting actors to watch.

title: Blue Caprice
review1: Coolly controlled and extremely well-acted.
review2: Spare yet deeply atmospheric, the film is charged with dreadful fatalism.
review3: The film creates one of the most chillingly becalmed portraits of insanity I've seen.
review4: This lyrical, frightening film is a portrait of a man consumed by self-hatred who decided to take it out on the world.
review5: If Moors and Porto were aiming for gun-debate relevance, they've failed; "Blue Caprice" has nothing to say about a society plagued by violence, nor does it focus on mental illness as a probable cause.

title: Big Sur
review1: There's a strange heft to its hollowness.
review2: "Big Sur" cracks the code of how to adapt Jack Kerouac for the screen.
review3: Sometimes feels like a beautiful illustration, rather than an adaptation, of Kerouac's prose.
review4: With Kerouac declaring that "the only thing that matters is the conceptions in my own mind," we're still left waiting for the filmmaker who can take us there.
review5: Nobody's given the opportunity to do much more than brood prettily and occasionally shout carpe diembromides into the pounding surf.

title: The Spectacular Now
review1: James Ponsoldt's The Spectacular Now is one of the uncommon pieces of teen cinema that rings true.
review2: Every time the film teeters on the precipice of a generic plot point it satisfyingly withdraws into more subtle and nuanced territory that ultimately coalesces in a final act that is sentimental without being sugary.
review3: t's a coming-of-age-slash-first-love story, with beguiling leads, a frank, bittersweet script, a lived-in, rustic setting (the outskirts of Athens, Georgia), an intense awareness of class difference and a mood that's all its own.
review4: The key to The Spectacular Now's success is in its insight, empathy, and fantastic performances.
review5: Far superior to most teen films, Weber and Neustadter's irreverent and unpredictable writing repeatedly upturns the clichés of the genre.

title: Enough Said
review1: These are the subjects that Holofcener does exceptionally well -- the myopia, vanity and insecurities of the moderately privileged.
review2: It's a wonderful movie-funny, sad and wise about the crazy ways we torment ourselves in this thing called love.
review3: A slate of great performances cap off a compelling look at the way we build up and destroy the very relationships we want to engage in.
review4: How it all plays out, even without the unexpected layer of wistful Gandolfini remembrance, is sad and funny at the same time.
review5: Dreyfus and Gandolfini generate chemistry aplenty!

title: A Single Shot
review1: An odd mix of beautifully bleak atmosphere and hammily mannered performances, "A Single Shot" is simultaneously understated and overpowering.
review2: Both predictable and outlandish.
review3: "A Single Shot" is a singular pleasure, and worth seeking out.
review4: None of these characters, no matter how trashed-up for the down-market occasion, are believable.
review5: Sam Rockwell is one of Hollywood's most underrated actors and he shows why that's the case again in A Single Shot, a rural, neo-noir thriller that slowly pulls the viewer under its veil of mystery.

title: Captain Phillips
review1: Over and over in this movie we hear variations on the phrase "everything's going to be OK." It's just impossible to head out of the theater and back into the wider world believing that's actually true.
review2: We're in the steady hands of Paul Greengrass, a director fully aware that convincing crisis stories involve conflicting interests and passions.
review3: But once the pirates are aboard the Maersk Alabama, any semblance of nuance is out the window and into the sea.
review4: This film sticks in your gut.
review5: Bring your defibrillator and a bottle of Xanex to make it through the picture as your heart will be beating outside of your chest.

title: Sunlight Jr.
review1: Urine tests and evictions, drunken brawls and rare outbursts of tenderness and grace. Collyer takes it all in, with a clear eye and no judgment.
review2: Collyer paints a sobering and important picture of the way many of us live now.
review3: Despite the intensity of their performances, Ms. Watts and Mr. Dillon are only fleetingly convincing as these desperate young Americans trying to maintain a foothold.
review4: Collyer never looks down on her characters; instead, her films have the quality of a good Springsteen song.
review5: A compelling portrayal of the grinding life of America's working poor, brought into sharp focus by intense lead performances from Naomi Watts and Matt Dillon.

title: Bad Milo!
review1: Here is a movie that, much like its eponymous character, never quite figures out what it wants to be.
review2: What could have been a very funny short film about self-control and befriending your id instead becomes a rambling commentary on father-son dysfunction and the limits of proctology.
review3: "Bad Milo!" is a cult classic in the making.
review4: This movie is about a monster that crawls out of a man's butt and starts killing people.
review5: Like a lot of intentionally shoddy or derivative movies, Bad Milo! can't overcome what it's trying to be.

title: In a World...
review1: Can't wait to see what Lake Bell the filmmaker does next.
review2: A fascinating look into the realm of voice over performance.
review3: Very funny semi-satirical look at the bitchy, male-dominated world of movie trailer voice over people.
review4: Writer-director Lake Bell is also the star of this quick-witted beguiling comedy of female identity, family ties and an unseen but fiercely competitive aspect of the film business.
review5: The entire cast operates at the top of their game. Yet it's Bell who is undeniably the main attraction.

title: No se aceptan devoluciones (Instructions Not Included)
review1: The film's counterintuitive success is largely due to Derbez, who demonstrates why he is beloved, both south and north of the border.
review2: This sporadically amusing but unduly protracted dramedy devolves into a shameless tearjerker in its third act.
review3: There's a lot of movie here with unexpected developments, held together by the irresistible chemistry between Derbez and his adorable pint-sized co-star.
review4: "Instructions Not Included" is a sweet little movie that is more than it seems to be.
review5: Surprisingly touching father/daughter story. Humor and heart make a winning combination.

title: I Will Follow You Into The Dark
review1: A rather turgid ghost story with a simultaneously murky and silly take on the afterlife.
review2: The question why ... persists.
review3: Good for nothing besides the employment of insipid young actresses ...
review4: An embarrassment for everyone involved. Pay for a ticket, and that'll include you, too.
review5: Content-wise ... it's little more than a gooey, life-affirming parable about keeping the faith.

title: A Perfect Man
review1: Too bland to inspire strong feelings of any kind.
review2: One of those projects whose very existence should baffle anyone hardy enough to endure all 94 minutes.
review3: It's a confusing, awkward picture, though Man has its fair share of compelling incidents. Just not nearly enough of them to make the effort shine.
review4: Flat and uninteresting, both visually and dramatically, this is a waste of two appealing actors.
review5: In its elliptical presentation of its characters' lives, brings to mind the latter-day films of Philippe Garrel, but Kees Van Oostrum's genre experimentation aligns him with Paul Verhoeven.

title: I Used To Be Darker
review1: Porterfield's film doesn't offer much in the way of plot, but the ways the characters bounce off one another in small spaces are precisely observed, and the actors have a lot of soul ...
review2: Unfolds like a music album, with emotive songs supplying information that doesn't need repeating in the lean screenplay, which the director co-wrote with Amy Belk.
review3: The couple, both musicians, are in the midst of a bitter breakup, and Porterfield frequently trains the camera on one or the other as each performs his melancholy tunes; this stops the narrative dead in its tracks.
review4: The visual style of third-time director Matthew Porterfield ("Putty Hill," "Hamilton") is emphatically lyrical, beginning with a widescreen shot of a Maryland Ferris wheel that suggests a celebration of Americana.
review5: Nuanced performances by the non-professional cast and a haunting soundtrack help fill in the deliberate narrative gaps.

title: Rush
review1: An entertaining movie with two solid performances that only occasionally stalls because of its sometimes heavy-handed treatment of Hunt and Lauda's differences.
review2: Considering the subject matter, Rush delivers the expected visceral jolts; what's surprising is how endearing it is, even when its two protagonists are behaving like little more than boys with very fast toys.
review3: Thuddingly obvious and proud of it, Rush is a slick, breakneck entertainment.
review4: "Rush" does for Racing what "Rocky" did for Boxing.
review5: Howard's good sense on Rush is to repeat his Frost/Nixon success by surrounding himself with superior writing and acting talent

title: Seasons of Gray
review1: It's a simple story effectively told, as Seasons of Gray manages to sidestep the problems that hamper most faith-based films: poor production values, amateurish acting and heavy-handed writing.

title: Isle Of Dogs
review1: Fans of arch dialogue (Howard chews the considerable scenery in a monologue about dogs, bitches, and loyalty) and those who know their giallo (there's a wonderfully voyeuristic stalk and slash scene) will not be disappointed.
review2: By the time the plot reached its ridiculous conclusion, I was resigned to sitting back and enjoying the absurdity of it all.
review3: Every surprise feels contrived, the many twists soon become tied in knots, and all the comings and goings, all the rug-pulling revelations, all the skeletons in the closet and expository flashbacks, end up resembling little more than a daft farce.

title: House Of Bodies
review1: Sluggish and unscary.

title: The Fifth Estate
review1: This breathless thriller that treats the speed of data as a matter of life and death.
review2: Benedict Cumberbatch's performance is the knockout, precise, conflicted, mysterioso, wily, his own charm alloyed with the Aussie oddness of Assange.
review3: The film never seems to know what it wants to be, or where it is going with all of these gimmicks, gadgets and subplots. It ends up as a yawner, a thriller with no thrills, history without context.
review4: A great performance surrounded by a very bad movie.
review5: [Blu-ray Review] "The Fifth Estate" is not a disasterfar from itbut it is understandable why it failed to capture an audience or much critical support.

title: Concussion
review1: The suggestion that prostitution is a risk-free route to self-discovery for suburban soccer moms is glib bordering on offensive, but Robin Weigert is tough and terrific in the lead.
review2: Unfortunately, Passon can't seem to figure out her own protagonist; there are plenty of sexual climaxes here but not much of a narrative one.
review3: An engrossing meditation on modern alienation and the ways we cope when we discover something missing in our lives.
review4: It's on the dull side, despite a fair amount of tasteful, non-explicit sex.
review5: Perhaps aimed to be a combination of Desperate Housewives and Belle de Jour, with a lesbian twist, Concussion turns out to be surprisingly bland.

title: Waterwalk
review1: Emotionally, the film is rich. Something is forged here, something strong and worthwhile.
review2: From the beginning, you'll know exactly where "Waterwalk" is headed, but the journey is not without its pleasures.

title: Nuit #1
review1: Some of their dialogue is twaddle -- they're not philosophers -- but the feelings are electric.
review2: Like a filmed stage piece, a series of monologues in which the characters reveal their unhappiness without offering a hint that they might change.
review3: Returning to some of the same themes she explored in her short films, Émond continues her smart contemplation of youth and the difficulties of making meaningful emotional connections in these times.
review4: This is a different kind of movie, as graphic as porn, but not porn, not titillating and not unintelligent.
review5: Despite the allure of the actors and some witty lines, it's ultimately quite wearying to be confronted with such determination to turn youth and good looks into existential burdens.

title: Code Red
review1: Despite the camera cop-outs, 'Code Red' still struck me as a surprisingly decent addition to a subgenre that's crowded with substandard entries.

title: Finding Faith
review1: Christian-based film about child predators aims to educate.

title: Dark Tourist
review1: Michael Cudlitz's first leading role is the sole selling point of this repellent character study.
review2: Griffith's vulnerable performance is a standout. But the film's final third seems needlessly graphic.
review3: "Dark Tourist" takes an effectively unpleasant trip down the lost highway of a morbid mind before its bad choices start catching up with it.
review4: Griffith can break your heart as a good woman staggering under the weight of life, especially after her character places her last bit of faith in a dangerously damaged man.
review5: "Dark Tourist" gets bogged down in insufferably slow-moving scenes - interestingly, when Jim is interacting with others, despite consummate performances from Cudlitz and Griffith.

title: Wings
review1: Wings plays it safe at every turn, and the result is an utterly forgettable family film.

title: About Time
review1: Even in a work of science fiction like this, Gleeson seems beyond real. All those foam-faces being made in the dark? They're for him.
review2: Some people will revel in this warm front of innocence; others will reach for their Voltaire.
review3: [Gleeson] fully embodies Tim's affability, and the chemistry between him and Rachel is lovely. But even better is his chemistry with his on-screen dad, Bill Nighy.
review4: "It's just so overflowing with ideas and characters that the main point it's trying to make nearly eludes it."
review5: The film matures from a mere romcom into something older and wiser, as Tim and his dad have some heart-to-hearts that end up becoming lessons for all of us in how to live.

title: Romeo and Juliet
review1: "Romeo and Juliet" is too soapy and improbable to count among the Bard's very best plays, but it surely has some of his best dialogue, and messing it up this much is close to inexcusable.
review2: There are reasons to see this Romeo and Juliet-it's just a shame that Romeo and Juliet are not chief among them.
review3: A stuffy, old-fashioned production shot on distractingly spotless sets. It lumbers along in search of a reason to exist.
review4: Pretty but, ultimately, flat.
review5: Been a while since Shakespeare's star-crossed smoochers got some big-screen love. Going on the so-so outcome here, no one would have minded waiting a little longer.

title: Dallas Buyers Club
review1: This movie earns each and every one of your reactions because it brings forth honest characters in a true, captivating story.
review2: The great thing about Dallas Buyers Club is that it proves someone can be kind of an ass and also a great man.
review3: It follows the template of every Bill Murray slobs-vs.-snobs comedy from the '80s, except this time people are dying.
review4: Hollywood is mourning the late Philip Seymour Hoffman, but fear not... others will be waiting in the wings to grab their chance. Matthew McConaughey has even come back to replace himself!
review5: A still very relevant exploration of an epidemic that's taken far too many.

title: House of Versace
review1: Fashion biopic mixes messages of hard work, drug abuse.

title: Champion (My Dog the Champion)
review1: Teen and dog save the farm in wholesome, predictable film.

title: The Lady Vanishes
review1: It forgoes the crackling pace, light touch and surprisingly sophisticated sexual banter of the original, opting for melancholy, ominousness and sentimentality.
review2: The result is entertaining without either dethroning Hitchcock's 1938 film or embarrassing itself.

title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete
review1: This is an impressive piece of grass-roots filmmaking.
review2: A gritty, sometimes downright heartwrenching story of two young boys left to fend for themselves for weeks during a boiling-hot summer in a Brooklyn housing project.
review3: Pitched fascinatingly, at times uneasily, between misery and uplift, "Mister & Pete" tells the story of an endlessly resourceful child who survives the unimaginable over one long summer.
review4: They may be tiny little kids, but they deliver outsize performances.
review5: "The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete" is a moving bit of mischief and mayhem that will break your heart, give you hope, make you laugh, possibly cry.

title: Mother Of George
review1: After a while it's hard to take Dosunmu's barrage of off-center compositions ... dialogue sequences that have the actor converse with empty space, and close-ups that reduce faces and objects to blobs of light.
review2: It takes about 60 seconds before the elegant "Mother of George" has you firmly inside the world it has created.
review3: Serious cinema of the globalist sort.
review4: In the end, "George" becomes almost as irritating as that mother-in-law.
review5: It's a powerfully sensual movie, gorgeously lensed colors and textures conveying its characters emotional states while thoughtfully exploring the range of human sexuality through Adenike's experience.

title: Pit Stop
review1: One of those small miracles that cinemaphiles justly revel in and it's a supreme addition to the queer-cinema canon.
review2: Emotionally raw, unrelentingly honest, and dramatically feasible, here's a terrifically acted romp that deserves a lengthy art house run.

title: Live At The Foxes Den
review1: Eyeballs will inevitably roll as the film sets a bar brawl to "Sabre Dance" and an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting to the sea chantey "Drunken Sailor."
review2: The script putters around aimlessly; the camerawork was more varied on "Cheers."
review3: A slight movie that could have been significantly better with a little story doctoring.
review4: Its content is culled from so many different movies that it seems the end product of a particularly unfocused pitch meeting.
review5: Live at the Foxes Den is like a sketch of an idea of what life might be like if you could keep doing re-dos.

title: Dear Heart
review2: A pleasant offbeat romantic comedy about middle-aged opposites making a love connection against all odds.

title: Someone to Love (And Then There Was You)
Bottled Up
review1: A terminally quirky indie dramedy, "Bottled Up" risks trivializing prescription drug abuse in service of a trite middle-age romance.
review2: A small, intimate, bittersweet, and wonderfully crafted love story, it may very well add a spring to your step as you exit the theater.
review3: You watch "Bottled Up" feeling that the screenplay needed a few more drafts; the dialogue, in particular, doesn't always ring true.
review4: The intentions feel authentic, but not enough else does.
review5: Like Sylvie's wardrobe of oversized hoodies, the humor is loose and natural. It breaks up the tension of this addiction story with small, bright moments of pure joy.

title: Wadjda
review1: ...a well-intentioned yet terminally uneven endeavor...
review2: There are important films and there are good films, and the two do not necessarily always overlap. Wadjda is both important and very, very good.
review3: Filmmaker Haifaa Al Mansour uses the simple story as our entry into a complex culture and a pointed perspective on how women are treated in Saudi society ...
review4: This is a film to be admired for both its on-screen and off-screen story.
review5: A warm, winning, restless film...Beautiful, modestly progressive and heartfelt, with a wonderful, brash central performance from first-timer Waad Mohammed.

title: Diana
review1: Diana might have been flawed and scheming and love-starved, but this film doesn't help explain that. Nor does it illuminate the common touch and humanitarian side that endeared her to a global audience.
review2: Not a lot different from whatever movie Katherine Heigl has made lately.
review3: The film can't find the woman beneath the façade, despite Watts' best efforts. Maybe she didn't exist. Or maybe there's a better movie to be made.
review4: It's ... a pity that her life is reduced to such a forgettable movie.
review5: This visually polished, Oscar-baiting docudrama chronicles her final two years, and even in death she's a subject of invasive speculation.

title: 2 Jacks
review1: Bernard Rose's fourth ultra-low-budget Tolstoy adaptation suffers from a slack narrative and abysmal dialogue.
review2: Based very loosely on an early short story by Leo Tolstoy, "Two Jacks" has a much less interesting second act ...
review3: Unfortunately, these inconsistencies cause more confusion than the magic Rose is presumably going for.
review4: Playing these self-infatuated flimflammers, Danny and Jack Huston obviously know the drill. It's in their blood.
review5: Mostly, it makes you feel like the only sober person at a party you can't leave.

title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model)
review1: This film has its own nature, almost its own reality. The sudden finish almost seems meant to make it our responsibility to comprehend the whole.
review2: That old arthouse chestnut, about the restorative power of naked young women, gets another outing in this pretty but superficial musing on the creative process.
review3: The film's insights about beauty are ... superficial. They amount to such commonplace observations as the fact that no two leaves are alike.
review4: "The Artist and the Model" is a contemplative ode to creativity and imagination.
review5: It is about inspiration and beauty, of course - and Folch, as a vagabond who escaped from a Spanish refugee camp, is certainly inspiring and beautiful.

title: Life of a King
review1: Solid performances-especially from star Cuba Gooding Jr.-elevate the film slightly above the familiar trappings of its genre.
review2: An effective, even heartwarming, tale of one man's commitment to teaching that playing by the rules is more important than winning.
review3: The furious energy with which Mr. Gooding stifles his own intensity becomes a fascinating subtext in what is otherwise a forgettable film.
review4: Gooding gives a strong performance, but viewers might be better off seeking out the...documentary Brooklyn Castle, which focuses on the championship chess team at an inner-city New York middle school.
review5: Even if the story is faithful to the way the events played out in real life - and the official description is that the picture is a "dramatic retelling" - Life of a King couldn't feel more formulaic.

title: Killing Kennedy
review1: Ginnifer Goodwin as Jackie and Michelle Trachtenberg as Oswald's wife acquit themselves well in this solidly watchable, quickly forgettable dramatic snapshot of indelible history.
review2: You won't come away from it with any new answers, but it's a useful reminder of why the drama of that day has transfixed Americans for half a century.
review3: The dialogue is painfully clumsy, and the pacing is pure Wikipedia.
review4: Killing Kennedy is subversive in a great way. The more the pathology of Oswald is developed...the more it resembles what propels many conspiracy theorists.
review5: Killing Kennedy easily could have been twice its length, the better to add both nuance and context. Instead it's a watchable film with many missing parts, a broadly drawn Classics Illustrated version of what happened and why.

title: Austenland
review1: Although...mostly a nice, light, little trifle, it's ultimately half a soufflé at best-one that never quite rises to the occasion.
review2: an interesting diversion that holds a lot of promise at first, is pleasant but generally underdelivers throughout, and then almost redeems itself with a last-minute twist that almost makes sense considering the movie's core weakness.
review3: Austenland is a pretty film to look at, but underneath its look, there's just not much there.
review4: Rom-com fanatics and Austen aficionados may find gems in Austenland, but others will see this as a film with little sense or sensibility.
review5: Based on the 2007 book by Shannon Hale, all the ingredients for a deft, sly, sleight-of-hand comedy are there. But the film is all over the place. The tone is off, the timing is off, the cutting is off. And it's just not funny.

title: How I Live Now
review1: Refreshingly free of digital apocalyptics and unnervingly prone to random violence.
review2: Based on the YA novel by Meg Rosoff, How I Live Now finds itself hindered by its source material, even as it seeks to surpass it.
review3: Saoirse Ronan supplies what the screenwriters do not
review4: Lush and bewilderingly rich with portent and moment, Kevin Macdonald's gently wrought apocalyptic-pop teen romance takes place in a deadly near future in the English countryside far from the center of modern war.
review5: How I Live Now is likely to appeal to both teens and older viewers, and it thankfully doesn't blindly follow formulas, but allows itself to drift and flow.

title: Reaching for the Moon
review1: Attention is retained by the commendably unhistrionic leads, who convincingly etch the pair's enduring devotion even when passions run dry.
review2: The life of American Poet Laureate Elizabeth Bishop furnishes surprisingly vivid emotional material in Reaching for the Moon.
review3: It's hard not to admire the intentions of a movie that depicts two exceptional women living exactly the way they wanted, together, outside the expected societal norms of the time. But the tone of the film itself feels unfortunately conventional.
review4: If Blue Is the Warmest Color is the gloriously messy supernova of this year's lesbian dramas, this is the J. Peterman catalog version: elegant, tasteful, and two-dimensional.
review5: A classy, grown-up drama.

title: Grace Unplugged
review1: It should satisfy its intended audience and maybe even bring a few new viewers into the flock.
review2: Tepid and predictable ...
review3: Feels like a religious tract more than a movie.
review4: Predictable prodigal daughter tale with Christian message.
review5: A movie with a moral lesson about what is to be valued is effective without being preachy

title: 22 Bullets
review1: As violent as this mob thriller is, it also has a terrific sense of its central characters, focussing on strong emotions and moral decisions. And even though it's overcomplicated, the result is a sleek and very classy.
review2: Without a compelling plot to hold our attention, this only amounts to an impressively bloody bullet-a-thon: 22 seems a very conservative estimate...
review3: An unremarkable French thriller that feels like a Seventies Charles Bronson effort.
review4: When the chief baddie both stutters and slaughters puppies, you know you're in trouble.
review5: A stylish but desperately uneven French thriller that's clearly trying to be the next Godfather. Alas, it never comes close.

title: Ode to Billy Joe
review5: Very weak plot, acting based on flash hit song of the '70s.

title: Fists Of Legend
review1: Shot with some wit and considerable speed, its short, sharp beatdowns are a refreshing change from the bloated action sequences favored by some of Mr. Kang's genre contemporaries.
review2: Director Kang Woo-Suk spins an epic swirl of masculine psychodrama over his many punishing fight sequences, including flashbacks to the trio's origins as gifted scrappers who take one too many wrong turns.
review3: At 2 1/2 hours, Fists of Legend goes on too long. But Kang Woo-suk's take on a genre often relegated to the level of cartoon is a refreshing change of pace.
review4: Stretches its runtime to a ridiculous 154 minutes ...
review5: boisterously entertaining template serves as sly cover for commentary on the way that Korea's corrupted social and corporate structures have for decades been holding down the nation's real talent.

title: Afternoon Delight
review1: The story doesn't hold together, but Hahn and Temple are terrific.
review2: Mistaking smug self-awareness for satire, the film attempts to skewer yuppie privilege while accidentally wallowing in it.
review3: As Rachel enters her late-30s wilderness, Hahn only gets better.
review4: Kathryn Hahn is outstanding as the unraveling Rachel ... capable of significantly more depth than she's had the chance to display in her regular goofball comedy roles.
review5: Relaxed, intuitive performances from the top-notch ensemble cast pay dividends, with Hahn commandingly stressy in the central role, and Michaela Watkins impressively abrasive as neighbourhood organiser-in-chief.

title: Watchtower
review1: Hauntingly beautiful film about two lost souls seeking redemption in the ruggedly beautiful mountains of the Black Sea region in Turkey. Art film at its best.

title: Anazapta
review3: a baroque parable of sin and and retribution, with all the dirt and filth barely concealing the community's much deeper stain of moral contagion and corruption.

title: "The Tundra Book: A Tale of Vukvukai, The Little Rock."
El Ultimo Elvis (The Last Elvis)
review1: Droll and delusional, the title character of The Last Elvis will win over plenty of fans to Armando Bo's parable of obsession and denial.

title: Silence
review1: Enigmatic and rewarding.
review2: An uneasy mixture of fact and fiction ...
review3: It's a film in which the mere arrival of birdsong on the soundtrack is as a narrative event but there are rewards for the patient; even those easily bored should leave the cinema feeling soothed.
review4: Anyone caught trying to smuggle in popcorn should obviously be taken outside and shot - using a noise suppressor, preferably.
review5: Think of Brian De Palma's Blow Out, then imagine it re-filmed by a team of Trappist monks.

title: The Wait
review1: Ms. Sevigny is the unsteady center of a movie that uses awkward silences, cryptic dialogue and self-consciously arty images to signify emotional limbo.
review2: The dialogue is so vague, and the plot so minimal, it all feels like a rather pointless exercise.
review3: Questions mount and answers are slim, distracted by a score that veers from synth to symphonic.
review4: I could no more tell you what it's trying to say than I could successfully stow away on the first space shuttle to Saturn, although I promise you that trip would be half as long.
review5: We're stuck watching two normally interesting performers moodily flail about, trying to lend weight to an enterprise that revels in tedious art-house opacity.

title: Amber Alert
review1: All things considered - micro-budget, unknown actors, no real special effects, the point of view of a single video camera - "Amber Alert" proves a resourceful little thriller.
review2: If the sound of child being molested and moronic lead characters endlessly bickering is your thing, perhaps the feature won't feel like swallowing glass for 70 minutes.
review3: We've seen ghosts and Blair witches and demons and zombies in this growing "found footage" genre. But Amber Alert brings a little something new to the form - the urgency of pursuit, risks with real-world consequences.
review4: There is, perhaps, a smart film to be made on the same frightening subject. This isn't it.

title: You Will Be My Son
review1: Mystery lovers will delight in the sophisticated murder scheme, oenophiles will love the Wine Expo atmosphere, and admirers of restrained menace will lose themselves in the icy pools of Arestrup's eyes.
review2: How much you enjoy "You Will Be My Son" depends on how much you can take an unbearable, arrogant jerk as your lead character.
review3: Gilles Legrand's draggy melodrama about miserable characters who persist in their folly and never wise up is strictly vin ordinaire.
review4: French director and co-writer Gilles Legrand shows great mastery of tone and pacing in his third feature, which begins life as a domestic drama set at a family-owned vineyard and slowly morphs into a tense thriller.
review5: A strongly acted, character-driven melodrama, concerned with the dynamics of family in general and father-son issues in particular, it presents situations so emotionally supercharged that the whole story could have come straight out of Balzac.

title: Gravity
review1: A work of techno-art, with images of humbling grandeur and scenes almost painful in the depth of horror they evoke.
review2: The CGI is flawless, and the beautiful shot construction is staggering.
review3: You don't have to love sci-fi to love Gravity, you just have to love the power of cinema to provide a transcendent experience.
review4: One of the greatest man-versus-nature movies in cinematic history.
review5: $90,000,000, a hundred, whatever they spent: this is a taut thriller built for audiences but also one of the most expensive experimental movies ever made. It's a thrill ride, but a work by a visual artist at the extremes of his acuity.

title: Pulling Strings
review1: The movie boasts an understated sweetness, largely fueled by Camil's movie-star charms. He's the kind of performer who doesn't have to work hard to win over an audience; he is instantly likable. In a movie like this, that's money in the bank.
review2: This entertaining crossover vehicle for Mexican star Jaime Camil sets a familiar love story to a mariachi beat.
review3: Serving mostly as a strong calling card for star Jaime Camil, the film has an appealingly loose, slightly ramshackle charm.
review4: This bilingual romantic comedy is overly long and has a paper-thin plot, but it's too sweet-natured to dislike.
review5: Sweet subtitled romcom hinges on night of drinking.

title: Bullet
review1: Such mediocrity extends right up until the final moments, with a hugely anticlimactic finale.
review2: At least on DVD you can hit the fast-forward button.
review3: Low-budget action thrillers don't come with any less velocity than Bullet.
review4: It's just a terrible, lazy, cheapo-looking film with no laughs and no interest.
review5: Trejo - despite his headliners in the Machete series - is not a leading man. But that doesn't mean there isn't some dubious fun to be had.

title: Twice Born
review1: It's debatable whether the best love stories are also the "weirdest," as Emile Hirsch's character declares in "Twice Born." But they do require chemistry, the missing piece in his pairing with Penélope Cruz.
review2: Sergio Castellitto's film projects a tumultuous love story against the backdrop of the Bosnian War for independence, and then seems unaware that the foreground overshadows it in the worst possible way.
review3: "Twice Born" chokes to death on its own melodrama.
review4: A magnificent performance from Penelope Cruz.
review5: Yes, it's all as clunky and tasteless as the description suggests, and the awkward casting doesn't improve this overlong drama.

title: Nebraska
review1: Mr. Payne has already achieved a batting average rivaling Pixar's, but here he has finally established himself as a visionary.
review2: I got angrier at Nebraska the longer it trudged on.
review3: Everything about Nebraska feels secondhand. It's a gimmicky sitcom script gussied up with 'artful' affectations borrowed from the New Hollywood heyday of the early '70s.
review4: There are insights into old age, pearls of wisdom and gags galore, all wrapped up in a coating that's more akin to a bitter lemon than sugar.
review5: It's a surprising performance from Forte, tasked with much of the heavy lifting opposite a tight-lipped Dern.

title: Mr. Nobody
review1: Never mind that several characters seem to gain or lose British accents throughout the course of the film. The lack of continuity only enhances the sense of deliciously dizzying disequilibrium.
review2: As philosophy, Mr. Nobody seems sillier than it is profound. But in a parallel reality, more movies would have this degree of insane ambition.
review3: This big-budget English-language co-production shows that Europeans can compete in the sci-fi realm where high production values are king.
review4: While Mr. Nobody contains some truly moving scenes, it eventually starts to try your concentration when you suspect all the space/time continuum shuffling may never become more than the sum of its parts.
review5: [Writer-director] Van Dormael seems unsure of what exactly it is he's trying to say, and thus Mr. Nobody rambles on for nearly two and a half hours.

title: Wicked Blood
review1: Picture 'The Sopranos' transplanted to the South, with . . . all of the mob action happening in an area that seems so rural you'd think they'd be dealing in raccoon pelts instead of meth.

title: Cold Comes The Night
review1: "Cold Comes the Night" provides Eve with an opportunity to showcase yet another side of her talent.
review2: A bland and preposterous thriller in which Alice Eve and Bryan Cranston play unlikely partners in crime.
review3: A tense little thriller that provides juicy roles for its deft lead actors, Alice Eve and Bryan Cranston, as well as some well-played action and several neat twists.
review4: Cold Comes the Night is a serviceable low-budget thriller with a pair of strong lead performances and intermittently suspenseful scenes.
review5: It's hard not to be impatient with a movie as openly lazy as "Cold Comes the Night," which is redeemed only by its performances.

title: Oldboy
review1: Everything is wrong with [Spike] Lee's version of Park Chan-wook's notorious, super-violent super-action-thriller. For one thing, it's far from super. Not the quality, per se (although, for Lee, that's off, too), but the energy.
review2: Compared directly, the difference between both films are more than a little disappointing, but with all of that said, 2013's Oldboy still has pleasures to be witnessed.
review3: Lee takes his time crafting fiery characters and an impenetrable, who-and-why mystery only to rush through a series of arbitrary clues and explanations.
review4: For a "pointless" and "unnecessary" remake, there's actually some really solid stuff in this one.
review5: Sloppy when taken on its own and abhorrent when compared to its predecessor.

title: Hours
review1: Walker's performance - along with the film - gets more and more engrossing.
review2: While uneven, the film is uniquely involving - right down to a final shot that will break your heart into a million pieces.
review3: Hurricane Katrina has already been pretty thoroughly mined for documentaries and fictional stories, but "Hours" holds your interest nonetheless.
review4: Most of the movie elicits tense empathy, which builds to a genuinely nerve-wracking sense of dread.
review5: Take away the on-the-nose title and some half-hearted stabs at symbolism, and what's left is a B-thriller of the "they don't make 'em like they used to" variety.

title: The Grandmaster
review1: The movie's problems are, in part, those of a great artist trying something new. It's a fine mess.
review2: The narrative structure is a little shaky at times, and it perhaps inhabits too many genres to be fully successful in any of them, but my goodness it's compelling.
review3: It's difficult to work out if Wong really had some biopic-subverting purpose in mind or if he just found himself unable to tell the story in a way that gelled with his sensibilities
review4: Often poetic, but lacks dramatic punch.
review5: The Grandmaster interweaves themes of ancient loyalty and modern betrayal around a narrative predicated upon the interplay between the differing schools, traditions and movements of myriad martial arts disciplines.

title: 12 Years a Slave
review1: It speaks to the courage and resilience of one man, the savagery of many, and the potential, for both good and for ill, in us all.
review2: McQueen approaches the narrative straight on and sober, with long, long takes bearing the weight of cruelty.
review3: We've seen movies about the horrors of slavery before. This one is about the mechanics.
review4: It is so fluent and so certain -- both in its humanism and its depiction of institutionalised savagery.
review5: We are surely watching one of the transcendent performances of the year in Ejiofor's sensitive, moving portrayal of the miserably oppressed Solomon.

title: Codebreaker
review1: Excellent and engrossing due in large part to the work of director Clare Beavan, editor Leigh Brzeski and actor Ed Stoppard.

title: Crave
review1: The guy fancies himself a hero, when in reality he's the person constantly thinking of witty comebacks after the fact.
review2: Helmer-writer Charles de Lauzirika's accomplished debut feature is too funny and self-aware to be disturbing, but it's certainly memorable.
review3: Psycho film noir in the crumbling inner city has the right idea but lacks depth.
review4: A tedious bore from start to finish...
review5: An artful if overlong howl of urban lamentation that puts an intriguingly melancholic top-spin on notions of vigilantism.

title: The Time Being
review1: A brittle, pompous drama about artists and the price they pay for inspiration.
review2: "The Time Being'' looks sharp, but it's about as dramatically satisfying as watching paint dry.
review3: An exhaustingly pretentious heave of artistic self-involvement, "The Time Being" takes an exceptionally handsome journey to nowhere at all.
review4: While the underdeveloped script - co-written by Richard Gladstein - never earns its sense of self-importance, the visuals are evocative enough to draw us further into the movie's ultimately unsatisfying mysteries.
review5: Not to be glib, but sitting through the art-centric chamber piece "The Time Being" is truly like watching paint dry.

title: Dark House
review1: Salva certainly gets points for creative repurposing. Much of what transpires in "Dark House" has been seen before, just not all in the same movie.
review2: Mere minutes into "Dark House," it becomes depressingly clear that the deficit of imagination displayed by the title will not be made up for by the content.
review3: There's plenty of blood in the supernatural horror flick "Dark House," but what really defines director Victor Salva's latest effort is flop sweat.
review4: Sometimes there's a thin line between terrifying and goofy.
review5: Dark House is one nutty horror movie, but what's crazier still is how well it works - until it doesn't.

title: Commitment
review1: Lots of family tragedy, saccharine love, and high-impact tae kwon do.
review2: For all the shooting, knifing and nattering about sleeper cells, the film feels weirdly static and terminally tired.
review3: In this expansive, even elegant movie, Myung-hoon turns from assassin to knight-errant in pursuit of a virtue he barely has time to understand. His rapid evolution is nothing short of moving.
review4: The filmmakers are committed to tragic romanticism. If they muster few thrills and no surprises, at least they don't stoop to a happy ending.
review5: When Commitment isn't a perfectly forgettable action film, it's either an oil-thin melodrama or a charbroiled treat for meatheads.

title: Out of the Furnace
review1: A humorless, ponderously solemn dirge that chokes on its own oppressive aura of self-importance.
review2: The grittiness of the tone... will bring to mind films ranging from The Fighter to The Deer Hunter, but it's that lack of cinematic gloss that makes the film come to life.
review3: Looking totally unlike his fattened persona in American Hustle, the unrestrained Bale offers explosive unpredictability fuelled by family loyalties.
review4: Beautifully shot in and around the depressed town of Braddock, Pa. Out of the Furnace is generally well acted by a top-notch cast, but a bit weak on the storytelling side.
review5: Set in a place where the American Dream has been dead for so long that no one even thinks to question its loss, the picture features terrific performances from its game cast.

title: The Broken Circle Breakdown
review1: The movie swings like a pendulum between elation and despair, with little time devoted to anything in between.
review2: Traditional bluegrass songs of loss and grief provide the inspiration and score for this innovative Belgian, Flemish-language musical drama.
review3: It's the music that really brings Broken Circle to life, an excellent collection of old-timey country classics and originals that reconnects the broken bits of the story and resonates with its deepest emotions.
review4: Breakdown gets the music right and has the benefit of strong acting, but its unapologetically melodramatic plot has a tendency to throw everything at you but the kitchen sink.
review5: Invigorating musical elements and the lead actors' potent chemistry can't entirely protect this tragic relationship drama from its encroaching shortage of subtlety.

title: Easy Money: Hard to Kill
review1: Thin, intense and yet somehow cool, Kinnaman is on his way to stardom, and it's easy to see how these movies gave him lift off. This is a tough, crackling crime story, well-executed and tense throughout.
