review2: A deep pool of underworld characters and a focus on multicultural tensions in Stockholm lend crime drama some added interest in "Easy Money: Hard to Kill" ...
review3: Because JW isn't the strutting, duplicitous peacock he was in the first movie, the role isn't as rewarding this time out.
review4: Though "Hard to Kill" forges new ground on the rich character histories developed in the first film, they feel like a random trio assigned the same punishment whose lives eventually intersect - and as such, the emotional moments never land.
review5: Najafi stages action scenes with an intense, queasy beauty and elevates what is in its outlines a routine crime drama to near-operatic proportions ...

title: Homefront
review1: I can barely remember who lives or dies. I barely cared.
review2: Homefront manages to hit all the right notes and even a few you wouldn't expect, and there's nothing expendable about that.
review3: Statham is not the English Clint Eastwood yet, but if someone fancied calling him Dirty Jason... who knows?
review4: Homefront is as gleefully dumb and thoroughly entertaining.
review5: Oh, and did I mention that Sylvester Stallone adapted the screenplay for this from a novel? Because that.

title: The Book Thief
review1: Ultimately not much more complex than the moment in which two children yell "I hate Hitler" across a lake, it imparts the message that Nazis are bad, books are good, and Geoffrey Rush would make a great dad even in WWII Germany
review2: This extremely moving drama suggests the Holocaust story Ray Bradbury might have written: Events are seen through a child's eyes; books are shown to contain a healing, transformative power; and the supernatural is real, if symbolic.
review3: Zusak's story is stirring, and it holds the film up during most of its predictable parts, but The Book Thief never rises too far above that. The narration from Death only serves to make it more like some sort of fantastical fairy tale.
review4: Regrettably this poignant and profound story, does not feel very poignant nor profound at all.
review5: Showing tragic events through a child's eyes can be a powerful storytelling strategy, but there's something altogether too cosy and bland about Downton Abbey director Brian Percival's handling of the material here.

title: Inside Llewyn Davis
review1: Still, after enjoying nearly three decades of enormous critical and commercial goodwill, the Coens come off as completely disingenuous when they explicate the struggles of an artist largely by blaming the system.
review2: As always, the Coens get the external details precisely right.
review3: My favorite movie in years.
review4: It may be the Coen Brothers playing well inside their comfort zone, but what a fine and thoughtful comfort zone it is.
review5: "Inside Llewyn Davis" is one of the best pictures of the year, plain and simple. It's the Coen Brothers finest film since "Fargo."

title: The Patience Stone
review1: It requires a leap of faith, but this handsome-looking film offers a disarming combination of insight, compassion and provocation.
review2: Directed by Atiq Rahimi and based on his novel, "The Patience Stone" speaks for all oppressed women, for all oppressed people for that matter.
review3: With a piercing edge, "The Patience Stone" is a cry from behind the veil, where a suffocating woman weaves a new life of her own design.
review4: The bare room where the husband lies helpless becomes a confessional where Farahani pours out the woman's life story in a performance that grabs you with its quiet yet searing power.
review5: A startling fantasy of Muslim feminist empowerment that allows the Iranian-born actress Golshifteh Farahani to put on what amounts to a one-woman show.

title: Hollow Triumph (The Scar)
review1: Gets over despite an unbelievable plot.

title: Sparks
review1: Busks its 1940s saga of dark redemption with considerable visual energy, if not always coherence or competence.
review2: Here's a hearty keep-at-it award for Christopher Folino and Todd Burrows, directors of this restless, reckless superhero crime curio ...
review3: This film is far better than it has any right to be.
review4: Sparks shows plenty of cinematic muscle. It deserves a place among the legion of superhero movies.
review5: A very original and unique indie and spin on the superhero film...

title: FLU
review1: Mostly works on a visceral level in spite of its familiarity; these tropes exist for a reason.
review2: Buried beneath a melodramatic plot rife with unlikely coincidences and a love affair with fewer sparks than Robert De Niro's 1990 wooing of Jane Fonda in "Stanley & Iris."
review3: A well-made, edge-of-seat action thriller that's no more serious - and often just as much fun - as Channing Tatum's White House Down.
review4: the shift in Kim Sung-soo's infection disaster movie FLU from buddy laughs and cutesy child antics to what can only be described as Holocaust imagery was too much for this viewer, with poor CGI compounding the alienation.
review5: Kim Sung-su rallies the crowd and action scenes with ease, although the intertwining strands of the overcooked narrative occasionally threaten to unravel.

title: Reasonable Doubt
review1: Cooper and Jackson never really develop as characters, and the film hurtles towards a pat, violent conclusion.
review2: Had Mr. Croudins focused more on Mitch's desire to distance himself from a wrong-side-of-the-tracks upbringing - and less on ticking genre boxes - his movie could only have been the better for it.
review3: Contrived and predictable yet fairly tense ...
review4: It moves fast (a rare quality for a contemporary thriller), but doesn't end up going anywhere interesting.
review5: There's no doubt in my mind that this dull, preposterous mess will be gone from my memory by this time tomorrow night.

title: Tentacle 8
review1: "Tentacle 8" proves to be a convoluted shell game, packed with high-tech espionage jargon about servers, data breaches and black sites, but hobbled by a muddy plot.

title: Jamesy Boy
review1: True second-chance story doesn't come to life onscreen.
review2: A film with a message of inspiration, to be sure, but not much in terms of innovation.
review3: For such a seriously street film, Jamesy Boy has some surprisingly sappy moments. But the redemptive ending, while thin, is genuinely gratifying.
review4: The screenplay by Lane Shadgett and director Trevor White relies far too much on telling rather than showing.
review5: White's decision to shackle his film to a redemptive arc ends up making Burns's story an argument for juvenile imprisonment.

title: Swerve
review1: As it zigs and zags, its plot unravels rather than tightens, and its curveball of an ending is bound to leave audiences feeling as double-crossed as some of the characters.
review2: You've got your duplicitous blonde, a briefcase full of money, the hapless patsy, the angry cop, the loose cannon and the speeding train. Everything's so in order that you could doze off and catch up with the plot within seconds of reawakening.
review3: It's enjoyable enough, but low on novelty, beyond the stark beauty of the sun-bleached Outback landscape.
review4: As the title of "Swerve" suggests, there's a lot of driving, and cars and characters veer, though never far enough for either to arrive at some place, some narrative, that's remotely new.
review5: The story is uninspired, Lyons looks lost, and Booth makes for a bland femme fatale.

title: Kill Your Darlings
review1: Few [Harry] Potter fans will be tempted to chance their luck while most adults will be left with fearsomely bright but relatively unlovable characters.
review2: The best thing about the enthralling, super-smart Kill Your Darlings is director John Krokidas's ability to capture the excitement of young men's minds on fire.
review3: Kill Your Darlings is by no means perfect, but it's an ambitious and promising first film that gives a handful of young actors the chance to work with a director who has a great deal on his mind.
review4: A convincing, evocative drama that captures a key moment in history with aplomb.
review5: Kill Your Darlings underwhelms on several fronts, but it's difficult to dislike a movie when you find yourself liking everyone in it.

title: Saving Mr. Banks
review1: Travers hated what Disney did to her creation, and she would have hated what his studio has now done to her.
review2: The picture is eventually about the therapeutic limitations of art even while celebrating the very real effect it can have on people who need it.
review3: It's a wonderful film that deserves your attention, and that you deserve to experience.
review4: Beautifully ambitious and eagerly constructed, the success of Walt Disney Studios' homage to its heritage is anchored magnificently by the crowning work of Emma Thompson's career.
review5: A familiar and very satisfying collision of art versus commerce or lowbrow, mainstream taste...versus highbrow sophistication.

title: American Hustle
review1: Save your admiration for the performances, especially Lawrence, who is now Hollywood's most important presence in front of the camera.
review2: Vaults heedlessly between bedraggled comedy and serious-stakes scenes in which the director shuts off the fun.
review3: Pure, raw energy.
review4: Few are the films that can be described as profoundly artistic and deliriously entertaining, substantial and soufflé-like. Noble, and screwy.
review5: David O. Russell has made an amazing film here, filled with some of the most complicated, well-developed, and fascinating characters to grace the screen this year.

title: Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom
review1: No matter how savvy the screenwriter, it's hard to adapt a 600-page autobiography to the silver screen.
review2: This Justin Chadwick biopic offers no surprises in technique or script (by William Nicholson) but is nevertheless a notch above average.
review3: This film is only superficially illuminating, briefly informative; the drama is only mildly engaging, the imprisonment distantly horrific. It insists upon keeping us at an arm's length for its not inconsiderable running time.
review4: A potent mix of uplift and corn.
review5: It works... kind of. If you were new to the Nelson Mandela story and were looking for a neat summary of his upbringing, his struggles and his achievements, you'll find it here.

title: The Happy Sad
review1: Sexy and soapy, this modern-day romance about sexually adventurous couples mixing things up is a gem.
review2: Evans directs energetically, and the personable actors help to keep us involved, but the picture skims stubbornly along the surface.
review3: An engaging look at a pair of New York couples whose love lives intersect, crisscross, circle and backtrack in hip and provocative ways.
review4: Strong acting and occasional dives into deeper territory redeem this somewhat contrived chamber piece.
review5: Deadly earnestness and sex don't mix well at the movies.

title: Contracted
review1: The ending to this fable misses the opportunity for broader metaphorical resonance, but getting there has its own unnerving rewards.
review2: "Contracted" can best be described as "Contagion" meets "Blue Is the Warmest Color," without all those explicit sex scenes.
review3: There's no payoff to the paranoia.
review4: A body-horror opus that will satisfy genre fans who like to be grossed out, but doesn't have much to offer on any other count.
review5: A very adult and straight faced glimpse at an ugly human being rotting from the inside out...

title: HairBrained
review1: A campus comedy that tries to transcend its many formulaic elements with an insufficient dose of absurdism.
review2: "HairBrained" is painfully contrived and self-consciously quirky from the word go.
review3: Unfortunately, the movie lacks strong enough players to fill in subtext to Mr. Kent's formulaic setups, and the story flounders once Ms. Posey is out of the picture.
review4: Aside from some nice autumnal shots of Ivy League college campuses, there's nothing in HairBrained to sustain much interest.
review5: Early potential fizzles away too quickly in this underachieving buddy comedy, which just barely skids along on the charm of its co-stars.

title: Free Ride
review1: It's unspeakably depressing to see Anna Paquin playing the mom (of a teenager!), but the pointlessness and mediocrity of the Paquin-produced "Free Ride" is even more depressing.
review2: The result, while sincere and nicely evoked, feels choppy, familiar and, despite the script's heavily stacked deck - and a few harrowing episodes - lacks sufficient momentum.
review3: From top to bottom, it feels authentic, and its laid-back, nonjudgmental tone evokes the easygoing world of Jimmy Buffett songs celebrating how changes in latitude bring changes in attitude.
review4: While this true-life odyssey should be the basis for a compelling drama or even a taut thriller, slack direction and a weak screenplay undermine the plot's inherent tension.
review5: In between bizarrely low-octane moments of authorities circling the ring, the soulful up-and-comer crafts a far more perilous tale, one of a teenage caretaker getting a crash course in growing up too fast, too soon.

title: Loves Her Gun
review1: "Loves Her Gun" is one of the most soothing examinations of fear you're ever likely to see.
review2: Marslett has a real feeling for this place and these people ...
review3: Arrives at a destination that may strike some as too pat, but getting there is nonetheless consistently interesting.
review4: Though the film is generally sedate for its first hour-plus, small moments of violence sporadically keep us on our toes just as Allie is.
review5: Geoff Marslett's Loves Her Gun studies the fine line between rational and irrational fear, as well as what it means to feel safe.

title: "Camille Claudel, 1915"
review1: Juliette Binoche gives a wonderful performance as Camille, conveying the intelligence, anxiety, anger and isolation of an artist abandoned by her family.
review2: With a stripped-down, bare-faced performance, Juliette Binoche is utterly wonderful in this tense French drama.
review3: A powerhouse performance by Juliette Binoche provides the beating, tortured heart of this finely wrought and very affecting film about the later life of sculptor Camille Claudel.
review4: This is a stark film, about the human condition at its most base and degraded.
review5: This is a difficult film, but made with impressive formal rigour.

title: Cold Blooded
review1: Appealingly minimalist and sharing some DNA with the early work of John Carpenter.

title: Viola
review1: Piñeiro's bold but graceful camera movements, exploring space with unselfconscious joy, speak to a young filmmaker's emerging mastery.
review2: A Buenos Aires production of "Twelfth Night" is point of departure for a buoyant examination of love's labor's lost offstage.
review3: It's a pleasant, negligible wisp of a movie, notable mostly for what it suggests of its director's potential.
review4: You have been privy to a series of seductive, ephemeral moments, drawn into the eternal rhythm of youth and connected with something old and durable, one name for which is art.
review5: A movie that leaves us with a smile on our faces but also more than a few thoughts in our heads.

title: Gordon Family Tree
review1: Sweet, slow-paced family film about finding your path.

title: Angels in Stardust
review1: "Angels in Stardust" ends up being too tidy to be a great coming-of-age movie, but it's a decent one ...
review2: [It] has some offbeat charms. They are not, however, strong enough to carry such a heavy load of cliches.
review3: A creaky coming-of-age fantasy-drama whose luminous lead actress, A.J. Michalka, has hopefully seen the last of this kind of ungainly corn pone.
review4: From broaching (and ultimately shrugging off) domestic abuse to murdering a pet cat for emotional effect, Stardust is a catalog of bad ideas.
review5: Dismal coming-of-age tale features sex, alcohol, violence.

title: The Wolf of Wall Street
review1: It may be the most exuberant film about sin ever made.
review2: A marathon of depravity. The relentless vulgarity feels heroic.
review3: DiCaprio's powerhouse performance, and Scorsese's brilliantly energetic direction make this a must watch for film lovers.
review4: A terrific watch, and bound to be one of the funniest films of the year, but perhaps a tad indulgent and lacking the emotional resonance that could've escalated it to truly unmissable status.
review5: A forgiving nature and lots of stamina is needed for this no-holds-barred hedonistic ride into the Roman orgy-style excesses of the 1990s' financial world

title: The Truth About Emanuel
review1: The universal truths Gregorini ostensibly hopes to unearth here actually end up feeling more than a little murky.
review2: Tackling the pain of motherhood and guilt of daughterhood, director Francesca Gregorini builds unbearable tension into scenes that otherwise risk tilting toward melodrama.
review3: A film so self-serious that it demands to be remade as a Seth MacFarlane farce, "The Truth About Emanuel" mixes the ludicrous and the pretentious in a story about mommy issues gone wild.
review4: It's not so much a thriller as it is a ride on a runaway crazy train.
review5: A tedious wallow in female damage and the indulgence of same ...

title: The Great Beauty
review1: The Great Beauty is an utterly ravishing portrait of listless luxuriance, a fantasy of decadent wealth and beauty that evokes Fellini's La Dolce Vita by way of Baz Luhrmann.
review2: A richly symbolic meditation on aging, mortality and precious time wasted.
review3: Sometimes too overblown, surreal and obtuse for its own good, director Paolo Sorrentino's film is nonetheless an exquisitely composed portrait of vapidity and decline.
review4: Exceptional, mature film dazzles, offers haunting insights.
review5: "The Great Beauty" is a great romance: a man and a city and a love that cannot be consummated but which will consume you surely. Somewhere, Baz Luhrmann weeps.

title: Le passé (The Past)
review1: In the end, so much of The Past just doesn't have that crucial ring of truth to it. Disappointing and underwhelming.
review2: The revelations Farhadi relies on to propel the story are not as compelling as he gives them credit.
review3: One of the most impressive things about Farhadi's film is the way he reveals facts about the tale and his extraordinary timing in which he reveals them. The movie unfolds like a surprise birthday gift.
review4: Um filme povoado por pessoas que tentam encontrar sentido onde não há nenhum.
review5: It's a testament to Farhadi that I could even consider a movie as good as 'The Past' to be any kind of disappointment.

title: No Holds Barred
review1: The movie never takes itself seriously and director Tom Wright (TV's "Beauty and the Beast") has fun with the wrestling montages. Hogan himself has an appealing screen presence -- like a gallant teddy bear who goes berserk every 10 minutes or so.
review2: Maybe we should mention that the gruesome violence in the movie was enough to make this adult wince.
review3: For months now, Dustin Hoffman and Robert De Niro have been sitting in their dens and nervously clutching their Oscars. They knew that an unprecedented challenge was looming... the arrival of Hulk Hogan in his first starring role in a movie.
review4: The film is utterly lacking in the campy quality of the World Wrestling Federation telecasts.
review5: As cartoonish as its star.

title: Twogether
review1: "Twogether" is a terrific love story, one of those independently made intimate movies that comes out of nowhere to captivate you with its passion and integrity.

title: Forgetting The Girl
review1: First-time director Nate Taylor skillfully evokes a clammy sense of dread in this stealthily suspenseful indie thriller.
review2: The frequent use of direct-address narration feels too much like a fiction writer's device, however much it wants to be a hook.
review3: Written with a poet's ear and directed with an artist's eye ...
review4: Thanks to some well-drawn characters and tight casting, including Anna Camp and Lindsay Beamish as an exceptionally troubled makeup artist, Taylor overcomes the script's minor implausibilities.
review5: Surprising, clever and twisted with a convincingly sweet and creepy performance by Christopher Denham.

title: 47 Ronin
review1: Samurai movies may not be everyone's favorite yuletide entertainment, but there's something to be said for Ronin 47.
review2: 47 Ronin looks from the outset like a picture that went off without a hitch.
review3: This $175million Hollywood reworking of Japan's most celebrated tale of honour and revenge is a mostly plodding affair, notwithstanding some fantastical sword-and-sorcery flourishes.
review4: the movie is its own worst enemy
review5: At the helm, Rinsch turns in a movie that's deadly serious yet entirely lifeless.

title: The Bag Man
review1: By the time the intricate plot and not particularly satisfying payoff are revealed at the film's end, many viewers will feel like they were the ones left holding the bag.
review2: A noirish kill fest stocked with offbeat characters, lots of gunplay, unlikely plot turns and a lavishly coiffed Robert De Niro.
review3: Whatever you do, do not look inside the bag.
review4: There's much sub-Coenesque violence, corpse disposal and skulduggery with the underhanded De Niro always maintaining the upper hand.
review5: "The Bag Man" has more attitude than panache. Yes, we eventually get to see what's in the bag. But by the time its contents are revealed, you may no longer care.

title: In the Name of the King III
A Field in England
review1: It's the English Civil War on magic mushrooms!
review2: A Field In England is mad monochrome mayhem that's utterly hypnotic.
review3: It's about shifting power games, mostly, and suggests a period film made by Samuel Beckett in one of his more playful moods.
review4: It's dementia for its own sake, an empty head-trip.
review5: A challenging piece of work to be sure, due for eventual midnight-movie cultdom.

title: Young at Heart
review3: Young At Heart is a smartly cast, expertly acted ensemble film, but it unmistakably belongs to Sinatra.
review4: Glossy and slick musical remake of the 1938's Four Daughters.
review5: Fine Doris Day and Frank Sinatra 1950's weeper.

title: August: Osage County
review1: Every ill-considered editing choice here bears the sticky fingerprints of statuette-grubbing producer Harvey Weinstein, attempting to tame this rough material for mass consumption by Oscar voters.
review2: Sure to be divisive, "August: Osage County" is tenacious and beautifully constructed. Soulful and unafraid to show the gritty and ugly of the American family,
review3: Nothing makes you feel better about your dysfunctional family at the holidays than watching a messed-up clan unravel on screen, only armed with better zingers and prettier faces. That describes this adaptation of Tracy Letts's star-studded drama.
review4: New Hollywood motto: Never act with kids, dogs or Streep--when she's in Mommie Dearest mode, that is.
review5: It isn't so much a movie as it is a competitive act-off.

title: Everyday
review1: Moment by moment, it all adds up. The scenes of the family huddling and hugging, greeting and parting, and reaffirming primal bonds are quietly moving.
review2: The film's day-to-day aches are quiet and lovingly rendered.
review3: For better and for worse-mostly for worse-it sticks to the mundane promise of its title.
review4: Even with the actors' laudable work-especially Simm, who finally shakes off the notion that he's a poor man's Simon Pegg-there's not enough going on past the temporal trick to make the humanistic elements pop.
review5: Wise and involving ...

title: Back in the Day
review1: [A] stale, schmaltzy and testosterone-drenched comedy.
review2: There are a lot of odious movies yet to come in 2014, no doubt, but they'll have to work to beat "Back in the Day" for awfulness.
review3: Cloying and smug when it's not being unfunny and crass, the high school reunion comedy "Back in the Day" hits lows with a frequency that suggests a world-class sharp shooter or free-throw king.
review4: Good for a couple of fart jokes and otherwise utterly forgettable.
review5: There aren't many laughs along the way (unless you count fart jokes), nor is there any nostalgic value.

title: Holy Ghost People
review1: The horror-oriented turns one might expect from these filmmakers never really arrive, and the eventual plot revelations feel a bit undercooked even for a straight thriller.
review2: Long before its feeble, drawn-out ending, it's clear no miracle can cure this film's many frailties.
review3: Director Mitchell Altieri helms the thriller with a sure hand ...
review4: Manages to touch on some compelling points before committing to its familiar but satisfying finale
review5: Utterly suspense-less, noxious missing-person would-be thriller, overflowing with tired clichés and off-putting revelations.

title: Reipu zonbi: Lust of the dead 3 (Rape Zombie: Lust of the Dead 3)
Lizzie Borden Took an Ax
review1: The movie itself apparently isn't sure the murders themselves are lurid enough. So it adds a few things that didn't happen, plus some 21st-century music.
review2: The movie ends on such a note as to cause the audience to wonder how long it will take before "A," of Pretty Little Liars fame, starts leaving Lizzie Borden an incriminating text or two.
review3: It's slow and heavy-handed, tedious almost throughout. An average episode of Oxygen's Snapped isn't this dull, and has more interesting things to say about women who kill.
review4: Lizzie Borden takes an ax to many assumptions -- including the one that Lifetime movies aren't worth watching.
review5: Lizzie comes across more as a whiny, moody teen than a psychotic murderess, and Ricci is much-too-attractive to play the dowdy, crazy-eyed Lizzie familiar from those faded black-and-white photos (just sayin').

title: Snake & Mongoo$e
review1: Hot rod fans will race to this sports bio-drama drenched in period authenticity.
review2: Snake & Mongoo$e is a lovely little gem of a film, though, like all gems, it's not flawless.
review3: This chintzy, awkward dramatization of a real-life racing rivalry is a real drag.
review4: A flawed but essential film for its target audience.
review5: Enjoyable drag racing movie has smoking, mild profanity.

title: Grudge Match
review1: "(Not only) is this sports comedy poorly timed, it has more than just a whiff of desperation, both on the part of its remaining cast and the filmmaker."
review2: Grudge Match certainly has enough successful elements to be moderately entertaining, although it's hard not to wish it contained fewer distractions.
review3: If you're from my generation, it's worth checking out for the nostalgia factor, even if much of the film will be lost on the younger generation.
review4: I do have to marvel at the way Stallone has always been able to make himself the underdog. This is a massive monster of a man who should by any account be the Goliath to any movie's David, yet he's always able to play vulnerable.
review5: Grudge Match is one of those ideas that works as a passing joke rather than an actual film, but the film's brazenness is admirable, and it is possible to have a good time with it. Just make sure your expectations are suitably lowered first.

title: A Touch of Sin
review1: A grueling experience. One that feels sadly necessary.
review2: A kind of Chinese Pulp Fiction with a political pulse, it adds up to a powerful portrait of desperate individuals driven to extremes by official corruption and runaway commercial development.
review3: It's a movie that's bitterly violent, both physically and emotionally, and a tremendous exploration of the have-nots in a society that is mostly known for its haves.
review4: It might be my least favorite of (Jia's) movies, but I still count it as one of the best films of 2013 which should tell you what I think of this extraordinary filmmaker.
review5: It's a brilliant lyrical film, shot on a grand-scale.

title: Bastards
review1: An imperfect film but a perfectly mesmerizing one.
review2: This is a film so anxious to be taken seriously that it has evaded seriousness itself.
review3: The movie ends where it might have begun, and merely states mysteries that remain unexplored.
review4: "Bastards" is a thriller truly etched in darkness, pools of black broken mostly by the stricken yet soldiering faces of her main characters, like ships in a sea of stormy nights.
review5: There's nothing wrong with dealing out a dense, noir-like plot in tiny scraps - unless, like "Bastards," the film remains flaccid and tensionless.

title: Justin Bieber's Believe
review1: When the movie occasionally does confront its hero's foibles, its answers are disappointingly pat.
review2: Films like this work best when exalting is the task, and when it comes to displaying Mr. Bieber in his milieu - on stage - it shines.
review3: My daughter wants you to know that the movie is great and that you shouldn't listen to a hater like me. I envy her belief.
review4: When it strays from the glitzy pyrotechnics of a Miami concert, it descends into another manipulative PR stunt.
review5: A documentary that supposedly chronicles the 2012-2013 tour but stays so relentlessly on message, it offers no insights and few anecdotes about the real Justin Bieber.

title: Tyler Perry's Madea's Neighbors From Hell: The Play
Murder on the Home Front
review1: You've got a classic whodunit story with breezy lead performances and darkly humorous plotting.
review2: The investigative interests and murderous happenings are better suited for a shorter program, where the natural pleasures of a criminal hunt can avoid the fatigue of dramatic padding.

title: Confine
review1: A meagre narrative is cynically doused in torture and cleavage shots, while any tension withers on an overlit set.
review2: Director Tobias Tobbell keeps the tone taut, but is let down by over-familiar ground, underdeveloped ciphers and a payoff that's not half as clever as it thinks it is.
review3: Confine makes clever use of its single-location shots, but the flawed script and a weak and inexperienced performance by Daisy Lowe means it ultimately falls flat.

title: Living Things
review1: Shapiro does not seem quite ready to trust his audience to reach their own conclusions.

title: Boys of Abu Ghraib
review1: Boys of Abu Ghraib is a credible depiction of the tedium, frustration and humiliation of wartime service.
review2: Writer-director-star Luke Moran's drama about Abu Ghraib is an ambitious if not particularly revealing debut.
review3: A halfhearted attempt at truly getting inside these men's and women's heads to make sense of their actions, which is ostensibly the purpose of dramatizing such a recent and shameful ordeal.
review4: The film hardly scratches Abu Ghraib's surface.
review5: Its tendency to water down the realities of Abu Ghraib trivializes its subject instead of providing depth or context.

title: Better Living Through Chemistry
review1: "Better Living Through Chemistry" as a whole feels rather superficial and safe.
review2: By the time the film gets to its ridiculous stretch of an ending, we've all seen the great fun to be had with drugs while also learning of their danger. How convenient. How empty.
review3: Sam Rockwell's committed performance can't save the glib debut of filmmakers Geoff Moore and David Posamentier.
review4: An ill-conceived if mildly amusing comedy about middle-class ennui, sexual frustration, and drug abuse.
review5: "Better Living Through Chemistry" ... is too much like the pretty suburbs it was shot in - neat and slick and comfortable. But ultimately, and deliberately, safe.

title: Flowers in the Attic
review1: V.C. Andrews' popular and creepy 1979 novel Flowers in the Attic gets no favors from the scriptwriters in this latest adaptation.
review2: The problem is not that it's just terrible, but that it's also no fun. At all.
review3: It was adapted into a middling creepy film in 1987. Now Lifetime has remade it as a sharper creepy TV movie.
review4: I was particularly delighted when the children figured out that their mother was trying to kill them with powdered rat poison sprinkled on donuts, but this should all be a lot more frightening - or at least more unsettling - than it winds up being.
review5: The problem is [it] always sounds like it's more fun, or at least more kooky, than it actually plays onscreen.

title: Our Paradise (Notre Paradis)
review2: You know It's time to retire from the sex-for-cash industry when a fellow hustler asks you to find another corner because 'you're older than my tricks.'

title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty
review1: This is one of the more disappointing efforts of the holiday movie season.
review2: While the original Mitty was a heartbreakingly sad figure, this Mitty is a weak parable for living life to the fullest (or something like that.)
review3: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty provides fun and laughs, but also meaningful thoughts on life and how we choose to live it, along with a touching lead performance you'll want to root for.
review4: Steve Conrad's script is a jumbled farce, misfiring on comedic executions and inserting beats that have no real relevance to the story.
review5: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty is one charming film to see, and there's nothing wrong with a feel-good movie that makes you feel good about liking it.

title: Great Expectations
review1: The crucial central roles go wanting.
review2: It is skillfully made and adeptly performed; even so it doesn't really add anything to the canon.
review3: This Great Expectations is an absorbing addition to the roster of Dickens films that continues our 21st-century fascination with the worlds created by a 19th-century storyteller.
review4: Director Mike Newell approaches the sprawling bildungsroman with a stiff formalism, sacrificing all cinematic excitement for the sake of exalting great performances.
review5: Honors the source while making some small but significant alterations.

title: Nae-ga sal-in-beom-i-da (Confession of Murder)
review1: With dark, compelling components similar to that of The Chaser and Memories of Murder, Confession of Murder feels like a great film wrapped inside of a dreadful one that suffers from disastrous editing and shoddy writing.
review2: The film also fills the screen with spectacular stunt work, set pieces that thrill with both insanity and absurdity, and a generous helping of tension-releasing humor.

title: Trap For Cinderella
review1: The erotic thriller "Trap for Cinderella" is neither erotic nor thrilling, but rather reliant on cheap nudity and multiple mistaken-identity switcheroos in hopes of keeping us on edge.
review2: Softley negotiates layers of deceit with skill, but an uncharacteristic visual and narrative tightness leaves one wondering what might have been.
review3: The plot is ludicrously far-fetched, but despite some plodding dialogue, committed performances from leads Tuppence Middleton and Alexandra Roach make this tale of jealousy and betrayal a heady treat.
review4: Despite some strong performances and an interesting style, there are just too many holes in the story, keeping Trap For Cinderella from being a completely compelling thriller.
review5: Initially intriguing, but essentially a forgettable B-movie that's more exhausting and frustrating than fun or suspenseful.

title: Copperhead
review1: So much taste and intelligence went into these finely wrought costumes, props and sets in order to tell a story of such tedium.
review2: Though the tale, based on a novel by Harold Frederic, remains relevant to our time, the film is too self-conscious and tedious for the message it delivers.
review3: If every war has more than one side, this story of one man who dares to stand against the tide of history has a contemporary relevance that remains uncontested.
review4: Sluggish drama ... defines this morality lesson about the unimpeachable virtue of loving thy neighbor.
review5: Less like a peering examination of the turbulent political environment than a reenactment of a Ken Burns documentary-or a museum tour.

title: Black Nativity
review1: All of Black Nativity proceeds with sort of clumsy obviousness.
review2: By the time the credits rolled, my eyes were sore from all the rolling.
review3: Even the movie's most wretched characters glow in the Harlem lamplight.
review4: Takes Hughes' nativity story and shoves it into the far background of a sincere but tritely told modern drama about family, faith, and redemption.
review5: To call it preachy isn't necessarily a critique; the entire film is essentially built around a closing sermon.

title: Möbius
review1: "Möbius" makes the international world of espionage and high-dollar finance downright boring.
review2: Eric Rochant's weird and lengthy fixation on De France reaching orgasm twice in one session allows Möbius to unexpectedly transform from a low-stakes Notorious to a high-end Red Shoe Diaries.

title: Wrong Cops
review1: No doubt a labor of love, the result is just plain laborious for the audience.
review2: Pitched somewhere between a DIY alt-humor video and a knockabout comedy, this meandering lark about a corrupt, spiteful and hopelessly distracted police force in a decriminalized, sun-scorched city never quite finds the funny bone.
review3: A tedious exercise in self-consciously hip lowbrow comedy.
review4: Improves on its predecessor by being effectively plotless.
review5: It's tonally weird and totally forgettable.

title: Philomena
review1: Dench gives a superb performance as a simple, trusting woman of faith.
review2: Dench and Cooper could do this stuff in their sleep and keep us entertained, which they do, but it's the nuanced twists and turns in both the characters and the story that elevate the picture beyond the familiar.
review3: I'd be a grouch to call the two leads anything but delightful, and they both stretch in directions you mightn't expect.
review4: Director Frears handles the story with enough dramatic weight and light comic fare to make "Philomena" a sweet and very compelling human tale...
review5: Be not fooled by the marketing materials, which make the film look like an aged-up version of The Trip with Judi Dench in place of Rob Brydon. Philomena is a terrifically made, entertaining work.

title: The Invisible Woman
review1: Far more attentive to visual storytelling than most actors who step behind the camera, Fiennes conveys shifting dynamics through his characters' positions within the frame.
review2: It's unhurried yet confident, familiar yet provocative. With fine cinematography by Robert Hardy (Blitz), most 'Expectations' will, indeed, be met.
review3: The performances are first-rate -- Fiennes and Jones are stellar, as are Kristin Scott Thomas as Nelly's mother and Tom Hollander as playwright Collins -- and the score and period details are sumptuous. But the film still drags.
review4: The Invisible Woman is a beautiful picture with strong performances, but made unnecessarily convoluted.
review5: The Invisible Woman is so subtle and secretive that it sets a record as the most low-keyed of its usually feverish genre.

title: A Farewell to Fools
review1: That loneliest of creatures: the comedy that inspires almost no laughs.
review2: Call it a dark farce, human comedy or wartime satire. But however you slice it, the ill-conceived morality tale "A Farewell to Fools" is a bust.
review3: An extremely low-boil wartime farce, content to wring quiet smiles and silent laughs, that more or less works as a sort of lightly affected, darkly comedic parable.
review4: Despite the presence of Depardieu and Keitel, not nearly foolish enough.
review5: Dreyer's work is still an enjoyable story that ultimately triumphs as sweet little comedy that doesn't make any attempts to shake up the world of historical cinema.

title: JFK: A President Betrayed
review1: Fifty years later, this is one of many additions to the Kennedy catalog. Although it's more suited for the small screen, it is a worthy entry nonetheless.
review2: The film, narrated by velvet-voiced Morgan Freeman, weaves a suspenseful narrative from eyewitnesses ...
review3: Rather than doling out scandal and conspiracies, Taylor focuses on the one thing so often unmentioned in discussions of our first modern celebrity president: actual policy.

title: Barefoot
review1: The gradual revelation that there's more to Daisy than meets the eye is no great surprise, but it does at least negate - too late! - some of the more troubling subtext.
review2: It's all thoroughly, intentionally lightweight, and the film's final 10 minutes is a rush of highly unlikely smiley face resolutions. Still, Wood somehow makes it work as well as it can.
review3: He's a rebellious trust-funder who specializes in strip clubs, one-night stands and gambling debts. She's a possibly schizophrenic mental patient raised in near-captivity by an abusive mother. How could these two kids not fall in love?
review4: Really, the emotionally ill have enough stigmas to contend with. They don't need the patronizing-yet-popular movie one of "They're just like us - only, you know, more innocent."
review5: A sorry throwback to sentimental 1960s movies -- the ones in which an offbeat woman repairs the soul of an emotionally clueless man.

title: Maybe Tomorrow
review1: A strong story and good-looking visuals are only enhanced by the performances contained within..

title: Mischief Night
review3: Despite its shortcomings the film whips along at such a mischievous pace, you are carried away on its wave of enthusiasm.
review4: Scruffy and rambunctious, this lively film takes on the personality of its characters.
review5: Mischief Night is like a feature length episode of Shameless - it's funny, moving, well written and superbly acted by an impressive ensemble cast.

title: The Lies We Tell But the Secrets We Keep
Fetih 1453 (Conquest 1453)
review1: Making history may require only bravado, but making historical movies demands subtlety as well.
review2: The movie, a hit on its home turf of Turkey, is a straight-up shot of martyrdom and extravagance, honor and glory.
review3: If you see only one Turkish epic about the siege of Constantinople this year, it should be Fetih 1453. Fetih has intrigue, dancing girls, hunky men, and a spunky heroine.

title: Junction
review1: A quietly effective thriller with a few clever narrative tricks up its sleeve, Tony Glazer's debut feature overcomes its low-budget limitations with clever variations on its familiar genre as well as a taut execution and strong performances.
review2: Bledsoe leads an impressive cast, but there's only so much the actors can do with writer-director Tony Glazer's underdeveloped script.
review3: Executing a tonal shift that might challenge a more seasoned director (this is his first film), Mr. Glazer provides carefully choreographed action and violence that's both credible and divorced from sadism.

title: Big Bad Wolves
review1: A suspenseful, violent horror film that touches on the inner lives of sexual predators, the question of guilt and remorse in the human soul, and the practice of torture.
review2: Unpredictable, with a twisted surprise around each corner, Big Bad Wolves is a clever and arresting shocker.
review3: There's little to the movie other than shocks and gross-outs.
review4: It is an intriguing film with much to admire, but it doesn't always earn its pitch-black attempts at humor.
review5: While Big Bad Wolves delivers the Hostel-like torture jolts with ruthless precision, the movie is also a rudely funny satire of a macho, paranoid culture where the protection of children is used to justify any conduct.

title: Gambit
review1: When the movie veers away from the verbal gymnastics of a bunch of colorful dopes out-dumbing one another and into overindulged farce, the specificity of the Coens' writing begins to fade.
review2: This nominal remake of the 1966 art caper that starred Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine has all the fizz of flat soda ...
review3: "Gambit" is a trans-Atlantic delivery of "meh."
review4: Firth is solid as always. He fits his tailored suits and rectangular glasses to a T. Diaz fares less well.
review5: So-so remake of '60s caper has slapstick, brief nudity.

title: Gloria
review1: We don't make movies in America like Gloria, so we have to import them. I wish we'd import more -- and make a few, as well.
review2: Whether you appreciate Gloria as a portrait of a vital woman, muddling through life's middle chapters, or as an allegory of Chilean resilience, the message is the same: Let's face the music and dance.
review3: One of the best Chilean films of the 21st century. [Full review in Spanish]
review4: Lelio fulfills its purpose after making his protagonist fight and then rewarding her with the contradiction of her desire for a great escape. [Full review in Spanish]
review5: The film's pulse comes in many ways from García's brave and beautiful central performance.

title: The Easy Life
review1: When I first saw it 25 years ago, I couldn't wait to see it again right away. I've been waiting ever since.
review2: It's a sunny, lazy day in early-1960s Rome - the city is "like a graveyard," with everyone away on holiday.
review3: Yes, the frame is filled with the era's bikini-clad pulchritude, but the fuel here is primo neurosis.

title: Bucksville
review1: It's an insightful portrayal of an extreme point of view without the expected self-righteous critique.

title: El Capitán Trueno y el Santo Grial (Captain Thunder)
Gimme Shelter
review1: The result is awkward, hyped propaganda for faith-based initiatives and against abortion.
review2: What remains is a poor man's Precious, with all the earlier film's go-for-broke melodrama but none of its weirdness or empathy for the impoverished.
review3: An after-school special blown up on the big screen, it stridently aims to inspire you. More likely, it'll make you cringe.
review4: Hudgens captures both the defiance and fear of a girl at this crossroads. Her performance elevates what's often a trite and heavy-handed script.
review5: The kind of film that outfits a potentially compelling story with politically convenient signposts - not understanding that sometimes, getting out of the way of a good tale is the best kind of polemical strategy.

title: Bad Country
review1: A blandly executed action-thriller whose cast names (Matt Dillon, Willem Dafoe) and mild '80s Louisiana flavor offer only modest compensations for the story's workmanlike construction and routine twists.
review2: [A] thoroughly routine, straight-to-video-reminiscent action thriller set in Louisiana.
review3: Action fans need more than bullets and bodies. "Bad Country" is a disappointment.
review4: True to its name, Bad Country falls short on almost every count, but it's not just bad - it's also lazy, lifeless and guilty of squandering many fine actors.

title: Locker 13
review1: Only those scared of being bored to death need fear "Locker 13," an omnibus of horror stories that could hardly be more tame, talky and tepid, both individually and as a whole.
review2: An alternately creaky and intriguing ride, one of earnest ambition and dashed potential.
review3: The transition from comedy to horror (and back) never fully gels, and nobody seems "on the trolley" with the period jargon.
review4: As a die-hard fan of the horror anthology film, I take no pleasure in stating that Locker 13's few stray glimmers of quality are not worth the slog it takes to find them.
review5: Locker 13 isn't a film so much as a dire symptom of a culture in which the ability to fund a movie has become reason enough to make one.

title: Escape From Tomorrow
review1: Definitely a great stunt, but you spend the film thinking how much more the "Jackass"/"Bad Grandpa" crew could have done with a premise like this.
review2: It feels much like a theme park itself -- really exciting at first, but then your senses are dulled, and eventually you just want to go.
review3: Suggests an R-rated Twilight Zone episode with a twist of Fellini-lite, in a trite film school kind of way.
review4: It's really just a middling fantasy about a middle-aged dad having a meltdown during a family vacation to the Magic Kingdom, with a few scattered sci-fi and horror elements thrown in.
review5: As a conversation piece for hardcore film buffs and Disney fans, it's a fascinating little curiosity -- but that's about it.

title: The Best Offer
review1: The movie's an eyeful, though, thanks to the intricate production design and many artworks on display; it's also an earful, thanks to Ennio Morricone's fittingly lush score.
review2: "The Best Offer" is at its best when it's decidedly weird.
review3: An uneven but weirdly mesmerizing drama/thriller, Giuseppe Tornatore's "The Best Offer" offers an acting showcase to Geoffrey Rush.
review4: Italian writer-director Giuseppe Tornatore... designs beautiful sets around Virgil, who holds the screen in nearly every shot.
review5: The film has several smart twists and surprises up its well-tailored sleeve.

title: The Selfish Giant
review1: "The Selfish Giant" is a story of dependence, damage and desperation, told with grit and grimy frankness. It's also a portrait of friendship born of need and emptiness, on the road to nowhere.
review2: Clio Barnard's The Selfish Giant isn't the Oscar Wilde children's story, but more an inspired take on it in the kitchen-sink style of a Ken Loach drama.
review3: Ultimately, it's a sad, tough sit - but worth seeing for its gritty honesty and strong cast.
review4: Much of the movie is hard to bear, yet it never drags, thanks to the momentum that Barnard finds in the fable, and, above all, to the energy that she unleashes in her young leads.
review5: [A] wrenching story of working-poor desperation in northern England.

title: The Rocket
review1: In some ways, it feels like a throwback to many '80s teen movies, where everything comes down to a competition at the end, and the hero will finally get the chance to prove his worth.
review2: It follows a search for personal salvation while painting a portrait of Laotian life that's both revealing and relatable.
review3: A powerful, deeply moving drama about a young boy who comes to terms with the tragedies that have befallen his family by creating a thing of beauty - a gorgeous, high-flying rocket emitting triumphant bursts of color - out of refuse left by the war.
review4: Mordaunt doesn't always succeed at balancing the sentimental, the political and the ethnographic, but at its strongest the story is a seamless melding of history's dark undertow and a child's indefatigable optimism.
review5: If the Laotians in the film appear to be superstitious simpletons, it's not because they actually are - it's because Mr. Mordaunt made them so.

title: Labor Day
review1: If you have even the tiniest cynical bone in your body, avoid. You'll find Labor Day more sugary than a cronut.
review2: It sort of sits in a blank, defeated slump.
review3: So histrionically abysmal that it makes you realize how lazy and complacent most other movies are in their banal mediocrity. The atrociousness is thrilling. As I left the theater, I felt alive again.
review4: It's unlike anything we've seen in memory - and all the more absorbing as a result.
review5: It dares to diverge from the current culture of cinema by opting for a small scale, an open heart, and a sincere interest in the lives of small-town Americans.

title: The Strange Woman
review3: The production is strange, but for the wrong reasons.
review4: Despite its higher budget and starrier cast, the tale is no less mad than Ulmer's Skid Row hallucinations
review5: Grim look at an evil femme fatale and the men she lures into murder, it is far from Ulmer's best.

title: Brownian Movement
review1: Brownian Movement becomes feminist not through Charlotte's agency, but rather in the sense that she is irreducible to a stock type due to her contradictions.

title: Brightest Star
review1: Lowell's considerable charm goes a long way toward filling in the gaps and the story's emphasis on self-discovery over romantic couplings supplies enough interest to sustain the brisk 80-minute running time.
review2: Gives us a story of love among 20-somethings without telling us enough about the main characters to indicate why we should care about their perfectly ordinary entanglements.
review3: Beware any movie that talks about what it is before being what it is.
review4: Straining to meld a love triangle with an astronomy lesson, the rom-com "The Brightest Star" disappears into a black hole of cliché.
review5: Far from burning bright, this earnest indie starts out dull and gets duller.

title: Abby in the Summer (Making the Rules)
review1: Robin Thicke's debut as an actor in this year's Making the Rules is probably the least embarrassing thing to have happened to him lately.

title: Sugar
review1: As a whole, the film's characters touchingly illustrate the tolls of living with unresolved trauma and chronic uncertainty, as well as the solidarity and relative freedom this community of outcasts enjoys.

title: Simon and the Oaks
review1: "Simon and the Oaks" branches out in ways unusual and interesting enough to hold your attention and then even shake it a bit.
review2: The sheer sincerity of everyone concerned bolsters the whole enterprise so that Ohlin's historical novel-on-film holds us.
review3: "Simon and the Oaks" is not merely the story of two boys from opposite sides of the tracks. It's also a larger meditation on life's hardships and what endures: love, art and civilization.
review4: With its fool's-gold cinematography, over-emphatic musical score and self-important protagonist, "Simon and the Oaks" is a puny acorn that dreams it's a towering achievement.
review5: [A] lush, handsomely crafted middlebrow epic ...

title: Veronica Mars
review1: The film is an obvious labor of love for all concerned, and the good times are infectious.
review2: The uninitiated may not go for the all-too-convenient crime solving, melodramatic love triangle, and playful banter, but cultists will find all the show's pleasures intact.
review3: Veronica herself is such a breath of fresh air as a strong female character: smart, secure, resourceful, loyal, funny and not the slightest bit chickish.
review4: This isn't just a nostalgia trip. Almost a decade has passed, and the characters aren't just older, they've changed in recognizable and gratifying ways.
review5: Despite its middle-class magnolia feel in one respect, it has some sharp lines, twists and turns, revived characters, a neat score and good jokes about Warner Bros' stalwart Clint Eastwood.

title: After the Dark
review1: Both smugly clever and at times distastefully clueless.
review2: An unusually creative and ambitious film of ideas that offers so much more than its forgettable title and sensationalized publicity may imply.
review3: This ambitious teen-oriented fantasy is like taking a university philosophy course in The Twilight Zone.
review4: A shaggy dog story but an intriguing and frequently beautiful one.
review5: A heavy-handed and manipulative work of philosophical fiction featuring strong performances, but a troubled narrative.

title: Still Mine
review1: Growing old together can't be easy, but in this case, it's certainly beautiful.
review2: Writer-director Michael McGowan covers all the bases here -- the long-standing romance between the aging couple, the hovering concerns of their son and daughter, the constant head-butting with the building inspector -- with well-paced confidence.
review3: Writer-director Michael McGowan (Saint Ralph) shows affinity for the subtle undercurrents of a long, happy marriage, but the friction between Cromwell and the government bureaucracy stays one-note.
review4: Bring a handkerchief, or possibly a bedsheet, to "Still Mine"; this fact-based, beautifully acted drama could wring tears from a brick.
review5: [A] tough-minded tearjerker, based on a true story ...

title: Call Me Crazy: A Five Film
As High As The Sky
review1: bittersweet story of loneliness and family relationships
review2: The end resting point at which As High As the Sky arrives is a heartfelt one. One merely wishes its path was a bit more deeply carved.

title: Chlorine
review1: Some of "Chlorine's" scenes go for a pat lifestyle satire that can be diverting enough but feels secondhand. Elsewhere it makes wobbly overtures toward unearned dramatic poignancy ...
review2: Mired in the blahs, the blues and the midlife crazies, this poor man's "American Beauty" slowly sucks your will to live.
review3: It's not a good movie, and yet there are persistent good bits.
review4: Unfortunately, better movies have already been made about the subject, from the underrated film The Joneses to the current Wolf of Wall Street.
review5: A flat, undercooked suburban comedy. Or is it a drama? Or maybe a kind of satire? Regardless, it's short on style, substance or any clear raison d'être.

title: Stay
review1: The steadily affecting relationship drama "Stay" is a great example of how a film can rise above its terrible dialogue.
review2: The film was adapted from a novel by Aislinn Hunter, but the characters' inner lives remain elusive.
review3: Static and uninvolving despite a decent cast.
review4: Despite the affecting performances by the two leads, this overly muted drama fails to make much of an impact.
review5: The somber mood lifts like clouds after a storm, at a pace just sluggish enough that the happy ending doesn't seem too gratuitous.

title: A Tiger's Tail
review1: Predictable tiger cub tale has lots of stereotypes, bullies.

title: Hamlet & Hutch
review1: Alzheimer's drama has strong messages, mature themes.

title: Poseidon Rex
review1: The filmmakers forget the fundamentals of B-movie 101: Skin-baring spring breakers make for the most qualified carnage.
review2: At the end of the day, Poseidon Rex is not a good film. Its cheapness and corny clichés are too powerful to ignore. But Poseidon Rex is a sincere film, and that can go a long, long way.
review3: Poseidon Rex is boring with few laughs to be had, be they genuine or at the expense of the cast and crew.

title: Stalingrad
review1: Too often does [Bondarchuk] goad his characters to brim over with righteous bloodlust-and, despite the occasional obligatory misgiving about the barbarism of war, goads the audience to lust right along with them.
review2: If you thought Saving Private Ryan needed to be more like 300, then Stalingrad is the movie for you.
review3: Overall, Stalingrad is a bizarre concoction, part Putin-era patriotic chest-thumping and part creaky war melodrama, all set in a superbly recreated ruined city.
review4: Stalingrad is long and operatic, but its message is simple enough: War is hell, but hell, it makes for good cinema.
review5: To wave a flag, sing a song and celebrate it as the uncomplicated and inevitable victory of good over evil is the sort of easy message only an old propagandist - or a president for life - could really cheer.

title: Tanta agua
review1: An engrossing family drama about a 14-year-old girl's coming-of-age during a spa vacation with her father and younger brother.
review2: A poignant and well-observed family drama.

title: Educazione siberiana
review1: Despite its faults, the film is worth viewing not only for Malkovich's brilliant performance.
review2: Dark and in moments engrossing, the film hints at shades of crime-drama classics but just falls short of joining their ranks

title: Special ID
review1: There's little suspense to speak of but plenty of roundhouse kicks to keep you shocked and awed.
review2: You know there's something wrong with a martial arts movie when the only character worth caring about is the hero's mother.
review3: Insanely dangerous stunts? Check. Obnoxious evil baddie? Check. Intricately choreographed fight sequences that are the film's raison d'être? Check, check, check.
review4: With tender moments coming off like they were ripped straight from the Lifetime network, and nearly every action scene featuring enough wire work to look ridiculous, Special ID is a huge step back for the extremely talented Donnie Yen.
review5: They don't match the eye-popping athleticism of The Raid 2. In fact, some of it seems kind of stodgy.

title: Generation Iron
review1: For a documentary about extreme discipline, the filmmakers lack restraint: the movie, about 20 minutes too long, undercuts much of its own momentum.
review2: The oversized men who compete for the title of Mr. Olympia in this illuminating documentary are articulate and serious-minded, with some muscling through adversity to find a way to their dreams.
review3: "Iron" opens a window to an exclusive club and gives valuable insight into a small, dedicated and proudly unique community.
review4: Yudin's deft cameras admiringly capture these iconically sculpted men without overly objectifying them, should the prospect of eyeballing all that posing-strapped beef give any potential viewers pause.
review5: A gorgeous meditation on age-old existential concerns.

title: After Tiller
review1: You may or may not be convinced, but you will be affected.
review2: "After Tiller" does viewers the great service of providing light where there's usually only heat, giving a human face and heart to what previously might have been an abstract issue or quickly scanned news item.
review3: What makes this well-edited film compelling are the stories of the patients and the agonizing moral quandaries that the doctors express in doing their work.
review4: It's a calm, thoughtful film about an incendiary subject, and it has a clear point of view: to allow these doctors (and some of their patients, who we hear but don't see) to explain why they do what they do.
review5: Any viewer with an interest in this issue, whether pro-life, pro-choice or agnostic, ought to see this heart-piercing report from the front lines.

title: Her
review1: While parts of it are hilarious just as one would expect, the rest of the film takes on a surprisingly somber tone.
review2: It sticks to its premise and goes deeper and expands there.
review3: The quasi-science fiction story of the film feels entirely possible, as Phoenix stares around him at passersby, all entranced with an electronic device in their hands.
review4: A provocatively-relevant film about how technology can make people dangerously introspective.
review5: Her explores fantastical ideas in ways we wish more films would: cerebrally, maturely, and non-reliant on action.

title: Stranger by the Lake
review1: A stunning minimalist erotic thriller that explores with arresting photography and economical use of dialogue how human identity is defined, and sometimes imprisoned, by our desires, drives, and passions.
review2: Carefully and often brilliantly creates its own Eden-like universe.
review3: There's too much metaphysical packaging material in the story; it's half Styrofoam peanuts. But its ideas are intriguing and its murky suspense is undeniable.
review4: What sets the engrossing "Stranger by the Lake" apart is that its excesses seem to point to a moral purpose beyond shock or entertainment value.
review5: While I found the characters interesting, the story was not very compelling and it was slow-moving as well. I learned a lot more about homosexual sex techniques than I wanted to know, and less about the characters than I wanted to know.

title: The Patrol
review1: Unfortunately, the writing and acting aren't quite sharp enough to make The Patrol a must-see for curious liberals. And the visual effects will underwhelm audiences in search of action.
review2: The wearing tedium of conflict is effectively evoked, broken occasionally by bursts of violence that are rightly harrowing.
review3: A rough experience, bracingly free of the usual macho posturing that characterizes movies about the military, and a compassionate and humane portrait of modern soldiering.
review4: First-time British writer-director Tom Petch makes a powerful impression with this tough, smart war movie on a shrewdly managed small scale, about a British army patrol in Afghanistan.
review5: This bungled sortie in Helmand province presents a robust idea that's been executed poorly.

title: Pleased To Meet Me
review1: The chief pleasure of this unassuming indie drama comes from watching veteran musicians try their hand at acting.

title: Weekend Of A Champion
review1: "Weekend of a Champion" will appeal mostly to motor-racing enthusiasts and movie archaeologists.
review2: Polanski and Stewart reunite at the film's end to reminisce, but it's the original footage that thrills.
review3: Weekend Of A Champion serves as a terrific primer on auto racing.
review4: Weekend of a Champion begins as a motorsports movie but ends up a portrait of two wily elder statesmen who have survived into their seventies by skill, stealth and sheer luck.
review5: Even racing aficionados might find the chitchat a little vague.

title: Sophia Grace and Rosie's Royal Adventure
review1: Adorable young TV stars sing, dance in sweet fairy tale.

title: Like Someone in Love
review1: Making only his second film outside of his native Iran, Kiarostami undercuts the rigid protocols of polite Japanese society with intimations of violence.
review2: I was enraptured by Like Someone in Love, taken with a visual intelligence and thoughtfulness we seldom see onscreen. It's one hell of a riff.
review3: Kiarostami still possesses a remarkable knack for crafting vivid supporting characters from just a few details.
review4: It superbly plays out as an homage to Ozu family dramas.
review5: There's some artful fiddling with plot expectations, but the film's evident self-regard makes this a rather undergraduate provocation.

title: In Secret
review1: Olsen is one of Hollywood's best young actresses. There is nothing she can't do. In the long run, it's the men who'll wish they'd done more to support her suffocating sense of loneliness here.
review2: The film's most striking performance comes from Jessica Lange, evoking both distaste and sympathy as the heroine's overbearing mother-in-law.
review3: No knocks to Emile Zola -- who wrote the 1867 French novel which serves as In Secret's source material -- but the story is stretched excruciatingly thin in this adaptation.
review4: Lange at least has an angle on her character; the rest of the cast simply hit their marks and spout dialogue like robots, delivering lines which should evoke erotic fervour, but are exchanged without urgency, conviction or belief.
review5: Notable largely for the anguished, nuanced performance of Jessica Lange ...

title: Pompeii
review1: Its impact is muted by the dull foreground figures.
review2: Pompeii 3D is a swords-and-sandals disaster epic that contains all the B-movie tropes you might hope for... The only element missing is a decent script.
review3: Hammy performances, poor editing, straight-to-DVD special effects, and bland direction.
review4: Sure, every character beat is hammy and predictable, but hey, not everything can be fine dining. Sometimes you just want a good cheeseburger and fries.
review5: Rapidly burnt by a volcanically ludicrous story, Pompeii rumbles and crumbles, over-baking itself into a frothy crisp--puffery on the outside and clichéd passions within.

title: Vampire Academy
review1: This is a garbage heap of weak quips, delivered by an assortment of pretty boys and girls and amped up with some cheesy moments of animal cruelty.
review2: Not only plays like the crassest possible mashup of "Harry Potter" and "Twilight" elements, but seems designed to make those franchises look like eternal monuments of world culture by comparison.
review3: This attempt to capture the magic of the "Twilight" and "Harry Potter" franchises tries too hard to pack all the backstory and borrowings into one film.
review4: ...I hoped for better but am not displeased with slightly messy, campy but funny and entertaining vamp dramedy I got.
review5: It's too transparently a ploy to hook teenage girls by combining vampires, Hogwarts, and princesses, three things that teenage girls presumably adore.

title: McCanick
review1: The premise that bruised feelings can get blown so far out of proportion and propel a veteran cop to risk his reputation and jettison his entire career is simply preposterous.
review2: The dour "McCanick" banks way too much on what it is not telling us, making for a movie that thinks it's being cryptically suspenseful but is really just annoying.
review3: It's a shame the script doesn't offer anything beyond loose-cannon-cop cliches.
review4: The only reason to suffer through a grim wack job called McCanick is to see the late Cory Monteith in his last film role.
review5: [A] numbingly inert series of dirty-cop clichés that abruptly builds to an ephemerally poignant climax.

title: The Monuments Men
review1: We may have gained something in humor by not taking the saviors in the art-rescue story very seriously, but we've lost just about all of the romantic pleasures of heroism.
review2: Clooney's lugubrious direction mimics the worst of those star-studded early-1960s epics, with lots of long dissolves and chunky inertia.
review3: I respect the inspiring story being told, but the film's screenplay doesn't have the necessary weight in its pages, or the depth in its characters.
review4: The Monuments Men scatters its cast all across Western Europe as they hunt down the world's treasures, but fails to provide them with narrative thrust to move things along.
review5: Clooney's a great guy, but as a director, he's his own worst enemy.

title: Cold Turkey
review1: [Writer-Director Will] Slocombe may not carve up his kin for Cold Turkey" but he serves a wry repast.
review2: Cold Turkey is a simmering piece of holiday dystopia with a good, scorching boil-over.
review3: [A] tiresome cavalcade of bickering - which feels like it lasts even longer than your typical Thanksgiving dinner.
review4: "Cold Turkey" has some fine actors who put effort into their roles, but it's getting harder and harder to care about or laugh at adult characters who have botched up their affluent lives and are still obsessed with events from childhood.
review5: Writer-director Will Slocombe presents a familiar buffet, but there's good stuff to pick over.

title: Journey To The West
review1: Another exquisite, snail-paced cinematic perambulation from Tsai Ming-liang and Lee Kang-sheng.
review2: Liang's ravishing conceptual film achieves a rare blend of sensuous delight and documentary specificity.
review3: Journey to the West works so well because Chow has a flair for grand comic-action set pieces, and his imagination seems to actually draw energy from these rapid-fire tonal shifts.
review4: By turns daffy and dazzling, awkward and artful, "Journey to the West" takes an ancient tale and gives it contemporary flair.
review5: Mr. Chow has perhaps achieved more sustained and elaborate adventures, but he hits a sweet spot of comedy that never grows too self-aware or forgets the value of a good, clean demon whomping.

title: Endless Love
review1: None of the players exhibits much personality, but it's hard to fault them, given how thinly the characters have been imagined by screenwriters Shana Feste and Joshua Safran.
review2: Things go desperately wrong after the opening promise ...
review3: for a younger audience seeking out a serious exploration of teen sexuality, Endless Love will prove to be soporific and - most disappointing of all - sexually tepid and timid.
review4: Smart couples can surely find more diverting ways of soaking up Valentine's Day.
review5: Shana Feste's bland and timid remake will be lucky to be remembered beyond this paragraph.

title: Run & Jump
review1: Writer-director Steph Green develops it so patiently and notes its emotional dislocations so carefully that it never descends into cliche.
review2: Insightful and often touching ...
review3: "Run & Jump" pretty much paints itself into a corner, but it has a nice time getting there.
review4: It's sensitive and winsome, like a modestly budgeted independent film should be.
review5: "Run & Jump" is surprisingly alive, full of jolts and unexpected bursts of humor and earned emotion.

title: Could This Be Love? (Je crois que je l'aime)
Small Time
review1: Small Time plays out in plodding fashion that seems engineered to keep the audience at arms' length.
review2: Coming-of-age drama delivers some laughs, but loses its way when things gets serious
review3: "Small Time" is agreeably sentimental meat-and-potatoes fare with strong dashes of humor, executed with a sincerity that's hard to resist.
review4: Don't let the title of this indie gem fool you, "Small Time" has humor and heart big time.
review5: "Small Time" has its heart in the right place, but its screenplay's in serious need of a tuneup.

title: Parts Per Billion
review1: There's sadness everywhere, as the end of humanity collides with private matters, yet the production only truly concentrates on relationship woe, imagining that viewers will be pulled in by such a personal touch.

title: The Trouble with the Truth
review1: Who knew My Dinner with Andre could be reworked into such an engaging romantic comedy?
review2: Jim Hemphill's "The Trouble with the Truth" is a pleasant surprise that gets better as the movie unfolds.
review3: Although they talk enough to qualify for radio, John Shea and Lea Thompson make the high-wire act of "The Trouble With the Truth" a convincing, moving and provocative two-hander.
review4: A divorced couple rehash their relationship in this touching indie drama.
review5: The ambition is laudable, the results less so.

title: Goodbye World
review1: If there are roving bands of rogue soldiers, angry and distrustful neighbors and biker gangs running convenience stores, would you be high and naked in the outdoor hot tub? Would you really be picking at old jealousies from the college days?
review2: Obviously, the potential for shifting tones here is great; unfortunately, those tones shift rather erratically.
review3: For all the outside threats and watchable cast members, the story falls apart from within.
review4: An unconvincing, poorly conceived hybrid of end-of-the-world thriller and relationship drama.
review5: Apocalyptic visions are no longer enough to shock us. By this point, if you want to imagine the end of the world, you really need to say something new about it.

title: Son Of God
review1: Aimed at a devotional middle-American audience, this never risks the sort of individual perspective necessary to bring the story to life onscreen, for good or ill.
review2: At best, this version succeeds as a Sunday school supplement. But the blandness is enough to make you long for Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ.
review3: At times, the script displays a welcome sensitivity to the issues at play. But at other times, it misreads them so badly it gets downright goofy.
review4: Son of God is the simple case of an adaptation that doesn't have anything new or original to add to a tale that has been told many, many times before.
review5: Not that this cobbled-together film is done badly, but it is a choppy, by-the-numbers bland-out.

title: The Motel Life
review1: Sensitive lensing and acting render an unusual story of brotherly love touching in a promising first film.
review2: Alan Polsky and Gabriel Polsky propel the material in a way that can feel over-determined. But they grasp the eccentricities and desperation of fringe dwellers, and at its strongest their atmospheric film has the pull of a sad outlaw song.
review3: We have seen many films about losers on the run, but in the directorial debut of former Chicago siblings Alan and Gabe Polsky, we get an intriguing new take on brotherly love not only gone wrong, but clearly hopeless from the beginning.
review4: This independent drama effectively captures the spirit of much contemporary fiction: the tone is at once precious and stark, and the narrative drifts from one episode to another (and from realism to fantasy) as though it were playing out in a dream.
review5: As good as "The Motel Life" is for the actors, that's how bad it is for the viewer.

title: Tim's Vermeer
review1: Tim's Vermeer refers not just to the replica Vermeer he seeks to paint, but to his understanding of who Vermeer was and how he accomplished his work.
review2: Perhaps the ultimate take-away from Tim's Vermeer is the unquenchable curiosity of certain people, albeit those with the money to finance that inquisitiveness, to get to the bottom of history's mysteries. In that respect, Jenison is an artist.
review3: The lengths to which Jenison goes to ensure he is working with the same tools, limitations and liberties that were available to Vermeer are nothing short of gobsmacking.
review4: What it turns out to actually be about is Tim Jenison, and what it means to be a member of the new (techno) rich in the United States of the 21st Century.
review5: Tim's Vermeer is both enjoyable as entertainment and as an intelligently mounted case study of how art and technology complement, rather than grind against, each other. As Penn eloquently puts it: "The problem is we make that distinction."

title: Devil's Knot
review1: If anything positive can be gained from Devil's Knot, it's that hopefully it will lead new viewers to the magnificent experiences that await them by watching the superior Paradise Lost trilogy and the conclusive West of Memphis
review2: It doesn't quite gel as either a proper whodunnit, an insight into a killer's mind, a debate about lyrics in heavy metal music or a gripping legal case.
review3: In its way, this is the most terrifying horror movie I've seen in a long time; the woods where the kids die are like something out of Evil Dead. I was left angry and wrung out.
review4: This blandly made dramastisation by Atom Egoyan is an extremely average courtroom piece that, despite strong work by Reece Witherspoon and Colin Firth, feels like a 1970s telemovie.
review5: It compares most unfavourably with the recent Prisoners, which told an entirely fictional story about missing children with far more intrigue, suspense and cinematic skill than Egoyan's muted effort.

title: Capital
review1: Director Costa-Gavras takes a vaguely facetious tone toward the evils of global finance, which he concludes is a game for gluttonous boys.
review2: It's a bit like what The Godfather would have been if it had been set in "The Bank of Evil" from Despicable Me -- and if its antihero were a cipher instead of Michael Corleone.
review3: What's lacking is most surprising from this dissident filmmaker: the emotional outrage.
review4: The famously left-leaning Costa-Gavras is preaching to the choir in his indignation, but he does so in slick, brisk fashion.
review5: In the end, "Capital" is just a dark comic sketch of bald-faced greed, with little nuance or real feeling.

title: Omar
review1: This gripping Palestinian thriller evokes Gillo Pontecorvo's The Battle of Algiers in its depiction of not only the psychological pressures faced by people under occupation, but the murky moral consequences of retaliating.
review2: It's told with a stark, pitiless clarity that leaves you with fewer answers than before.
review3: Omar is romance and thriller. Of course, trust is at the heart of the matter.
review4: A fraught film ...
review5: Beautifully shot, complicated, smart, and undeniably intense ... well-deserving of its place as the Palestinian nominee for this year's Best Foreign Language Film.
