title: Perfect Sisters
review1: A cartoonish and crudely staged dramatization of a disturbing true crime.
review2: The film owes whatever persuasiveness it has to the teen leads' sharp performances - their sisterly chemistry and their filial friction with an alcohol-addled mother, well played by Mira Sorvino.
review3: Ms. Breslin and especially Ms. Henley are quite good, elevating a film that seems like an oft-told tale.
review4: This kind of thing requires a velvet touch, though director Stanley M. Brooks hits only hammer-heavy notes.
review5: Any potential for an in-depth examination of the adolescent psyche pushed to its limits goes unmet, though not for lack of trying.

title: Redwood Highway
review1: The mostly gentle drama has integrity without feeling caught up in its own nobility.
review2: While this road movie may not have great originality or huge box-office potential, it's a low-key charmer with a large-souled performance at its center.
review3: The script (by director Gary Lundgren with James Twyman) is modestly feel-good to a fault and the scenery expectedly beautiful, but it's the unforced acting providing the most nourishment.
review4: Solid acting overcomes a lack of dynamic tension in this family-friendly film.
review5: It is, among other things, a sharp distaff rejoinder to the male-centered, sour-faced "Nebraska."

title: Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit
review1: "Shadow Recruit" is fun in a minor, winter-season way.
review2: I'm aware that commercial and cultural forces require everything to be rebooted triennially with fresher, hotter stars. But this is the second time the Jack Ryan franchise has rejected a youth transplant.
review3: The vulnerability of the Jack Ryan character is still present, something very important that keeps us rooting for him.
review4: Pine deserves another shot at a stronger more daring Jack Ryan film...
review5: It succeeds on several levels, fails on others, and ultimately offers an acceptable albeit not particularly stand-out restart for the series.

title: The Missing Picture
review1: Panh fulfills his debts to the dead not just by adding to the visual record of genocide, but also by creating a transcendent work of art.
review2: In narration that is poetic and historically astute, Panh layers his own memoir atop his nation's.
review3: Many films have examined from many vantages the Khmer Rouge's nightmare reign, notably Roland Joffé's 1985 Oscar winner The Killing Fields.
review4: As haunting as it is haunted, "The Missing Picture" leaves viewers' heads rattling with ghosts.
review5: A uniquely subjective account of the Cambodian genocide of the 1970s, "The Missing Picture" is the work of Rithy Panh, a Cambodian native who left his homeland when he was an adolescent.

title: Alpha Alert
review1: Overall, Alpha Alert delivers a decent thriller for a smaller direct-to-video scale production.

title: "2 Autumns, 3 Winters"
review1: The movie reminds you with a series of gentle nudges that whether you want it to or not, the future happens.
review2: The film strongly evokes the spirit and playfulness of the Nouvelle Vague ...
review3: What separates this film from others of its type is the highly specialized manner in which writer-director Sebastien Betbeder has elected to recount the lives and loves of a group of young Parisians ...
review4: In general, imagine some classic Woody Allen devices, but amped up to the point where they dominate the movie rather than providing intermittent stylized distance.
review5: An innovative and engrossing French romantic comedy.

title: The Monkey's Paw
review1: ...scripter Macon Blair instead opts for an almost astonishingly generic approach that rarely (if ever) exploits the larger-than-life premise to satisfactory effect.
review2: There's so much padding and filler here, you could cut it down to fifty minutes without missing much.
review3: It's got some good horror elements and strong performances, but it needed more development of the characters to reach its fullest potential for scares.

title: Judex
review1: Nostalgic homage to Louis Feuillade's silent serials.

title: The Odd Way Home
review1: The actors manage as best they can with the material, but it's an uphill struggle.
review2: The mismatch-couple, road-trip indie "The Odd Way Home" has all the hallmarks of a director - in this case, one Rajeev Nirmalakhandan - eager to announce, "Look what I can do!"
review3: Its essential contrivance works against the earnest emotions it's aiming for ...
review4: Superficiality and cliché mark the film's notions of family, dysfunction, and even survival.

title: A Fighting Man
review1: Irish guilt, redemption, opportunism, alcoholism ...writer/director Damian Lee puts all across with about as much nuance as a bruising left hook.
review2: Lee has drawn nicely underplayed performances from everyone, and there's probably an affecting movie somewhere in all its stories. As it is, A Fighting Man is a boxing film with a particular problem: It can't fill its broad canvas.

title: The Attorney
review1: A familiar yet compelling South Korean courtroom drama, propelled by Song Kang-ho's strong performance as an unlikely hero.
review2: What makes writer-director Yang Woo-seok's feature debut special is how it handles this shocking incident with verve, style, and humor.
review3: Every scene does its job, tears flowing on cue.
review4: Just when a viewer is lulled into believing "The Attorney" is a lighthearted comedy about a doofus of a lawyer, this powerful South Korean feature takes a sharp turn toward brutal political thriller.
review5: The Attorney features a powerful, energetic performance by Woo-Seok.

title: Joe
review1: A real movie, for grown-ups, fighting for table scraps in a marketplace dominated by spider-men and x-persons.
review2: Nicolas Cage, in 2014, gave about 15 horrible performances and one great one
review3: For two hours, Cage's bad-thriller past doesn't catch up with him.
review4: A fantastic story of destiny finally calling for a drifter ( ... ) except that Gary Poulter was found dead two months after shooting wrapped, a victim of the alcoholic, hard-living, cancer-ridden existence he had somehow put behind him while on set.
review5: Powerhouse performances from Cage and Sheridan and Green's engaging direction assure Joe is a film that will rattle around in your mind for days.

title: The Grand Budapest Hotel
review1: "The Grand Budapest Hotel" is not his grandest work yet, but it is one worth an extended stay.
review2: The Grand Budapest Hotel is not a callous work, but it's about packing painful experience in storage.
review3: Wes Anderson's superb eye for visual storytelling comes to a head with this luscious murder mystery that starts out in an exclusive luxury hotel and thrills the audience throughout Europe.
review4: A grownup storybook of a movie spun out of candy-colored nonsense that challenges you to embrace its falseness and deny its romance.
review5: Even a squirrelly director finds a nut once in a while.

title: Test
review1: Here is San Francisco as it was in its bohemian twilight, on the eve of catastrophe.
review2: "Test" is woefully inadequate and unnecessary when compared with "Parting Glances" (1986) and "Longtime Companion" (1989).
review3: Test is most effective when it prioritizes mood over psychological melodrama (which is often), but Johnson's approach is torn between Albert Camus and Brian De Palma.
review4: Six years after his debut feature, The New Twenty, writer-director Chris Mason Johnson returns with a film that's less polished but braver.
review5: If Test can portray a dark time with an underlying sense of hope for the future, it's because almost thirty years later, looking back at 1985, it has no ambivalence about the progress that's occurred since.

title: Jimmy P.
review1: This intelligent movie becomes a gentle reproof of prejudice and ignorance, and I wish I could find some excitement in it.
review2: Honestly, it's hard to see why "Jimmy P." was ever made.
review3: Avoiding the usual therapy-drama story beats, Desplechin has made a densely satisfying drama about Freud, racism, and sympathy in its largest sense.
review4: A fascinating cross-cultural experiment that eventually runs itself into the ground.
review5: [A] ruminative, gentle and absorbing new film.

title: Once Upon A Time In Dublin
We Are the Best!
review1: A pallid and terminally cutesy movie that succeeds by stoking blandly happy feelings.
review2: Moodysson gives his characters the perfect mix of love, protection, and freedom
review3: For all their moodiness and irascibility, the girls come across as warm and believable, and there are funny moments when they take to the streets to raise money for a new guitar.
review4: The music here is really just a Macguffin, a way into Moodyson's real subject: the complex and often unequal dynamics of adolescent friendships.
review5: Watching We Are the Best! is a genuinely positive experience, one that leaves you smiling inside and out even days later as you think back not only on scenes from the film but also to memories of your own life.

title: Solo
review1: Canuck indie summer camp thriller Solo suffers from a bad case of inspiration overload.
review2: A first feature from Toronto writer/director Isaac Cravit, Solo flies high on its cinematography, music, acting and atmosphere. That leaves the story, which is a little thin but still solid.

title: Nicky's Family
review1: Nicholas Winton is a figure who deserves a worthy documentary in his name; unfortunately, Matej Minac's Nicky's Family only gets about halfway there.
review2: In addition to the force and the officialdom, dizzying and stark, there are particularly sharp stabs of feeling.
review3: The unfathomable tragedy of the Holocaust is beyond the scope of "Nicky's Family," and even as the credits roll, Winton's simple decency is as mysterious as ever.
review4: An enthralling documentary by Matej Minac...
review5: What's nettlesome about director Matej Minac's clunkily constructed documentary is what it says about our perverse but understandable need to spin some kind of happy ending onto the Holocaust.

title: Two Lives
review1: The personal drama is "I can't tell any more lies!" obvious, the international intrigue is lukewarm, and the big payoff, which should be a shocker, is so poorly staged as to be laughable.
review2: "Two Lives" is an absorbing, well-acted, moderately suspenseful mystery, although its time line of events is fuzzy to the point of impenetrability.
review3: Two Lives unfolds in a slow boil of rage at the government that allowed all this emotional destruction. But Maas treats Katrine with compassion, as a victim of forces more damaging than her own ravenous hunger for love and family.
review4: This sober look into how war, peace and politics splintered lives is circuitous, but worth puzzling out.
review5: For an issue movie "Two Lives" is something of a nail-biter.

title: What Richard Did
review1: You may be shocked by your own reactions to "what Richard did," but you won't soon forget the movie in which he did them.
review2: Abrahamson's penetrating film asks - and does not answer - whether one viciously criminal moment is an aberration, or whether it reveals the weak, shabby person who was there all along.
review3: Mr. Reynor's portrayal of this man-child is an extraordinary screen performance in which his face registers all the conflicting emotions gripping Richard. We see every layer of him, from the scared inner child to the suave, entitled ladies' man.
review4: [Feels] like a Bergman homage without earning the clunky label "Bergmanesque."
review5: A satisfyingly knotted moral fable with some very memorable performances, including a fine piece of charismatic brooding from Reynor.

title: Some Velvet Morning
review1: With Some Velvet Morning, LaBute returns to the provocative style that made his name.
review2: Though LaBute wrote this for the screen, I mistakenly decided that it must have originated onstage... because the oblique, heavily freighted dialogue seems too elegant and artful for a medium dominated by hacks.
review3: A sad example of what sometimes happens when a writer of gripping stage plays controls his own independent movie to his own selfish, labored self-satisfaction.
review4: I came away from this malevolent exercise with the sense that these two add up to little more than the sum of their awfulness.
review5: This smallest of films marks a welcome return to the world of interpersonal miniature for the writer-director. I hope he stays here a while.

title: Lucky Dog
review1: Routine rom-com with talking dogs and mild potty humor.

title: Rob the Mob
review1: It's a story so outlandish that it needs to be served by a combination of drama and comedy, and "Rob the Mob" finds that balance quite well.
review2: As Tommy and Rosie, Pitt and Arianda are just the right kind of nuts, the right kind of dumb, the right kind of desperate and the right kind of in love to make it all go down like pie.
review3: De Felitta has a feel for this world and its atmosphere, from the clutter and casual ugliness of the streets, to the insularity of the mentality, to the unexpected sweetness and vulnerability of the people.
review4: One of the pleasures of Rob the Mob, director Raymond De Felitta's serio-comic crime drama, is watching Pitt and Arianda as the rambunctious, lovestruck pair who can't believe the scam they've stumbled upon.
review5: "Rob the Mob" skims over the lifted-from-the-headlines exploits of an outlaw couple and gleans a humanist drama steeped in sentimentality.

title: Faust
review1: A grueling side show of a film, a morbid, mightily uninvolving piece ...
review2: The movie expands in its frame, surpassing simple comprehension and continuing to grow in your mind - and perhaps to blow it - long after it's over.
review3: Faust's worldview may be esoteric, but its vision is lucid.
review4: Aleksandr Sokurov's demented, gunky take on the Faust legend tumbles from one scene into the next with loping, loopy energy.
review5: Settle in, because this requires your charity, but you'll dream it all back up the next night.

title: 300: Rise of an Empire
review1: Tries hard to follow in Snyder's footsteps - plenty of speed-ramping slow-mo action - but it just comes across as an imitator.
review2: Black Sabbath's War Pigs coats the end credits in the aural equivalent of liquid metal, the final guilty pleasure of a senses-battering 106 minutes of military mayhem.
review3: So utterly mind numbingly dull.
review4: If you liked 300, you're probably going to really like 300: Rise of an Empire. ... it's got more character development, a smarter story, and is just gorgeous to watch and amazingly good fun.
review5: Eva Green is flat-out spectacular here, giving a fully physical and genuinely shaded star turn that is almost as exciting as all of the hacking and slashing.

title: Winter's Tale
review1: The only way to even potentially sell any of this was to play it so straight that it hurts a little, and Akiva Goldsman and crew did that, even when it broke the film.
review2: Exquisitely awful. I was reminded of M. Night Shyamalan's Lady in the Water, in that both are attempts at building a magical fantasy world by someone who has no clue whatsoever how to go about the task.
review3: This is an adaptation that simply doesn't have much of anything that is engaging about it, leading to two hours that end up being more of a slog than the celebration of life and love it should have been.
review4: "What the hell did I just see?" That was my first comment to the studio representative after I screened "Winter's Tale." Allow me to save you two hours. of your life:
review5: One can only hope this story works a lot better on page than on screen.

title: Blood Ties
review1: If you hear an unearthly sound during Blood Ties, it might be Sidney Lumet's ghost attempting to contact his lawyer.
review2: Seems to be the continuation of a narrative that only exists in its characters' heads.
review3: Everything is in place to have created a truly sensational piece of cinema, and yet you can't help feeling somewhat cold towards this film, despite the memorable, impactful finale.
review4: While the story centres on twisted moral dilemmas, this 1970s-set thriller takes such a hesitant, internalised approach that if never lets viewers under the characters' skin.
review5: The film is too sprawling and unfocused to deliver real emotional clout, but there are are some gripping stand-offs along the way.

title: Sister
review1: What a beautiful and desperate film.
review2: [An] absorbing French drama.
review3: The movie takes a refreshingly low-key, observational approach to storytelling ...
review4: "Sister" avoids sentimental indulgence. There's no room for wallowing in this spare, almost ascetic exercise ...
review5: French-born director and co-screenwriter Ursula Meier balances the scenario's bleak, wrenching aspects with a stirring confidence in the redemptive power of love.

title: 11 settembre 1683 (The Day of the Siege: September Eleven 1683)
Small Small Thing
review1: There is no gore here, and no on-screen violence, but this is in every way a horror movie. With a devastating ending.
review2: There are many reasons to see this very difficult film, not least to face the grim realities in Liberia ...
review3: An equally heartbreaking and enraging exposé about an important human rights issue.

title: For Those In Peril
review1: The film's finale is wild and daring and so perfectly executed that it marks Wright as one of the film year's most audacious new voices.
review2: The haunting and powerful psychodrama "For Those in Peril" marks an auspicious feature debut for its visionary writer-director, Paul Wright.
review3: Wright's strongest achievement here is an evocative depiction of place, where young teens flee from adult supervision and danger lies in wait.
review4: For Those in Peril is a strikingly original feature debut from the 31-year-old Scottish writer-director Paul Wright that resists simple categorization.
review5: As a portrait of encroaching mental illness, For Those in Peril works superbly.

title: Afflicted
review1: There's life yet in the found-footage horror genre.
review2: Runs smack into a number of generic clichés, from the back-and-forth bickering about how to deal with the situation to a lazy underlying misogyny.
review3: A nifty found-footage thriller that marks a promising debut for writing-directing duo Clif Prowse and Derek Lee.
review4: Ambitious in scope and practically flawless in execution, Afflicted is good news for horror fans seeking something fresh and chilling from two impressively assured young filmmakers.
review5: Nonetheless, we all know this terrain pretty well by now, and as Derek begins to change, each phase of his transformation feels overly familiar to anyone with a working knowledge of popular horror tropes.

title: The Lunchbox
review1: The perfect date film, guaranteed.
review2: Batra allows Ila and Sajaan's relationship to develop slowly and subtly, like an old photograph, and the tender humor adds exactly the right amount of spice to what is already a delicious mix of melancholy and hope.
review3: It dragged for me a tiny bit towards the end but, generally, I really enjoyed it.
review4: Somewhere in [its] moments of joy, lies the film's optimistic message about life, and how it should be lived. Which sounds syrupy, but it's far from it. It's magical.
review5: Though this much-touted, cuter-than-cute, try-hard romantic film from India has been showered with festival glory and glowing reviews from across the world, it unspools as a likeable but pretty unexceptional little confection.

title: "Like Father, Like Son"
review1: If you've seen any of Koreeda's previous films, and especially the wrenching children-alone saga Nobody Knows, it won't surprise you to learn that the observation of children in Like Father, Like Son is unfailingly acute ...
review2: Koreeda's film never feels gimmicky; he uses the situation to examine both nature and nurture while dealing with ties that simply can't be broken. "Like Father, Like Son" ponders the meaning of family.
review3: Writer and director Hirokazu Koreeda does not pretend that there are easy answers in his film, which at times plays almost like a fable. But the emotions and heartbreak are always grounded in reality.
review4: Completely realistic because it is in keeping with the reserved temperament of the culture.
review5: Powerful Japanese film about children switched at birth who challenge the love and hope of their rediscovered parents six years later. Beautiful and heartbreaking, from the masterful Hirokazu Koreeda.

title: Lullaby
review1: A raft of fine actors -- including Amy Adams, Richard Jenkins, and Downton Abbey's Jessica Brown Findlay -- are wasted in a sour, callow family drama that mistakes constant yelling for emotional tension and fortune-cookie aphorisms for wisdom.
review2: A film like "Lullaby" should both enlighten and inspire debate. Instead, it feels simultaneously superficial and overbearing, albeit with a few moments that do indeed resonate.
review3: The digital photography is crummy, and the characters who most need to convince ... feel created out of whole cloth. Polyester cloth, at that.
review4: The kind of manipulative, cliché-infested hokum that alienates moviegoers by its insistence on hogging all the tears.
review5: With the ever-expanding number of adults able to stay alive longer because of medical advancements, quality-of-life issues are top of mind for many folks. It's the way the filmmaker makes the point that is the problem.

title: Ragamuffin
review1: Thoughtful faith-driven film on Christian artist is intense.

title: Don Peyote
review1: The film gets more woolly and unfocused; many scenes feel improvised and only occasionally hit their marks.
review2: All the controlled substances in the world couldn't improve a viewing of the execrable "Don Peyote," a tedious, incoherent look at a paranoid stoner's emotional and spiritual unraveling.
review3: This Don Peyote doesn't even have a windmill to tilt at.
review4: You feel as if, at any moment, anything could happen. The problem is, seemingly everything does.
review5: ... an incoherent series of hallucination sequences that are neither amusing nor visually compelling.

title: Lost Moment
review3: Too bad Gabel didn't direct another film--this one is brilliantly Gothic.

title: Kid Cannabis
review1: A rollicking tale of border-running teenage pot entrepreneurs based on the real-life story of Nate Norman.
review2: Energetic and involving ...
review3: Nate comes across as an insufferably arrogant twerp stupid enough to believe there's loyalty in the underworld.
review4: Writer-director John Stockwell finds the perfect loose yet manic tone for his ode to weed, filling his script with mordantly pungent lines
review5: The film works best when it shows Jonathan Daniel Brown's drug kingpin at his most inept and incapable, rather than elevating him to a pothead martyr.

title: Caught
review5: ... belongs as much to the murky world of American film noir as to the polished European dramas of high society social appearances and power games.

title: A Night In Old Mexico
review1: It's hard not to wonder if Duvall got passed over for a role in Last Vegas and, not to be outdone by that snake Kevin Kline, decided to make the Western version instead.
review2: The director Emilio Aragón wisely trains the camera on Mr. Duvall. "A Night in Old Mexico" is his baby, and he rocks it.
review3: The movie doesn't have the same kind of emotional depth that Duvall and Wittliff managed to pull off decades ago. Worse, the dialogue often sounds stilted.
review4: This poky, clichéd, slackly told picture, directed by Emilio Aragón, would've felt dated a few decades ago; now it feels like a downright relic.
review5: Not a second of this feels real, but at least we see Duvall croon "Mexicali Rose."

title: Torment
review1: Despite Katharine Isabelle's best efforts, Torment becomes a tiresome genre affair that never hides its obvious influences.
review2: It is all very derivative - but masked children will always have a creepy uncanniness which Baker certainly know how to exploit.

title: The Face of Love
review1: The Face of Love's story runs and blotches like cheap mascara.
review2: Many are going to find the plot questionable and the protagonist's actions deplorable. But for those who've experienced loss and grief that seems irreparable, it is a film that will strike a deep and melancholy chord.
review3: Bening and Harris pour so much genuine emotion into their roles in this Vertigo-like romantic melodrama that they just about carry the film's fanciful premise.
review4: Both leads take on the task of the dysfunctional couple admirably, but their efforts crash against a stubbornly creaky script.
review5: Sadly, this all feels like a wasted effort.

title: SX_Tape
review1: It's a bad movie, the kind that presents itself with countless opportunities to create suspense or dread and wastes them.
review2: It is difficult to become fully absorbed in goings-on when the characters keep having to deal with plummeting IQs.
review3: Do you like your horrid "found footage" ripoffs riddled with amateur pornography? If so, SX_Tape is just the movie you've been looking for!
review4: Its creepy setting, lighting and sound designs deliver some scares, but there's not enough in terms of surprises or cleverness.
review5: There's no reason or logic in this found-footage yawner, and nothing rises to the level of even adolescent notions of sexy-scary.

title: Road to Paloma
review1: An effective throwback to the loose-limbed, my-way-or-the-highway road movies of the "Easy Rider" era.
review2: None of this is riveting, but the film's loose naturalism and strong acting - Chris Browning, as a liaison between the F.B.I. and the reservation, is especially enjoyable - are slyly seductive.
review3: Momoa makes much of it work through sheer force of will as Wolf, a chopper-riding Native American hunted by venal lawmen and seeking his mother's killer.
review4: Road To Paloma features perhaps the most motorcycle-riding footage of any actor-directed vanity project since The Brown Bunny.
review5: This film is numbingly dull, an outlaw-on-the-run saga as laconic and slow-moving as its fierce, hirsute protagonist.

title: Wrinkles
review1: Rare is the "cartoon" that penetrates and even haunts; Wrinkles is not easily forgotten.
review2: Unfolding in simple yet wonderfully expressive hand-drawn frames, the film's unsparingly observant plot depicts the slide into senility with empathy and imagination.
review3: Wrinkles doesn't offer the aesthetic rewards necessary to make its sad material compelling.
review4: Heavy doses of humor and empathy, along with gorgeous hand-drawn animation, keep things from getting too morbid.
review5: A beautiful, subtle horror movie about the rigors of old age, made all the more horrifying because it will happen to all of us fortunate enough to live a long life.

title: Bethlehem
review1: Bethlehem's plot is nothing new; it's the oft-told Cain and Abel story updated for the age of suicide bombers and tactical strikes, as a tautly structured mix of melodrama and ticking-clock thriller.
review2: Cinematographer Yaron Scharf shoots Bethlehem like a modern western, every grimace, twitch and drop of sweat playing in stark relief against an implacable landscape that has seen much spilled blood.
review3: The politics of "Bethlehem" are complex, but the relationship at its heart is simple: a kid who needs some kind of stability in his life, even if it comes from a most unlikely, and dangerous, place.
review4: A rich, multilayered character study cleverly garbed as an action thriller, Bethlehem is a searing critique of the conflict and its toll - not just in human lives, but also in two peoples' gradual, overall loss of humanity.
review5: Bethlehem remains a fairly powerful experience because so much of what we see is inflamed by a violence that seems to have no end.

title: Red Wing
review1: The pic remains earthbound and anemic, and never elicits much in the way of emotional investment.
review2: Red Wing flaps hard, but never achieves flight.
review3: A sweeping love story. Engaging, uplifting and genuinely heartfelt.

title: The Angriest Man in Brooklyn
review1: A schmaltz opera that indulges Robin Williams' most melancholy tics and themes.
review2: The film never quite manages to figure out what it's actually about.
review3: The movie is predictably sentimental at its root, but it's also meant to be comedy, partly resting on Mr. Williams's energetic but failed attempt to play a jerk.
review4: Every scene between two people comes off like drunkenly shot video of a play rehearsal gone horribly wrong.
review5: Considering its outlandish premise, what the film lacks are any outlandish scenes-or, if not outlandish, then at least ones in the realm of the creative.

title: Cesar Chavez
review1: It should have been made 40 years ago, but this biopic about the Mexican-American leader who spearheaded the fight for farmworkers' rights couldn't be more timely.
review2: Cesar Chavez makes for a fine history lesson, but as drama, it leaves something to be desired.
review3: Michael Peña brings a centered, beckoning beauty to the title character that manages to speak to Chávez nonviolent approach without becoming hagiographic.
review4: Biopics about civil rights icons are usually staid affairs. Cesar Chavez, directed by Diego Luna, is no exception.
review5: With Peña, the question is this: Are the movies brave enough to give him the chance he deserves? He's a wonderful Cesar Chavez.

title: Doonby
review1: Ultimately, it's the polarizing ending that will have moviegoers talking long after they see it.

title: The Legend of Billie Jean
review4: The Legend of Billie Jean does remain interesting and entertaining throughout its run, even if it is a bit short on plot and a lot short on realism.
review5: Has a straight faced camp about itself that makes it a blast from the past worth sitting through

title: Dom Hemingway
review1: Dom is effusive with self-destructive charisma, the kind of loose cannon you'd follow into an all-night bender in spite of your better judgment.
review2: You don't so much care where Dom is going as how he's getting there, and he's getting there loud.
review3: "Dom Hemingway" has two terrific things going for it: snappy dialogue (I was quite fond of the accusation "You disrespected my cat") and Law, who's both funny and scary in equal measures.
review4: The results are so delightful you can't help hoping Law lets his hairline recede and gym membership expire.
review5: Dom Hemingway lives or dies by the audience's identification with its protagonist.

title: The Single Moms Club
review1: The moral here is that no challenge is insurmountable if you form a club. And keep a wine opener handy.
review2: In Tyler Perry's latest opus, "The Single Moms Club," he demonstrates how disparate stereotypes can find common ground through the power of a single cliché.
review3: [T]his is a film about catharsis and camaraderie, not logic.
review4: This is How Stella Got Her Groove Back for the Pop-Tart crowd, a wish-fulfillment weepie that narrowly clears Perry's low bar, thanks mostly to Wendi McLendon-Covey and Cocoa Brown
review5: Mr. Perry's latest film touches upon some recognizable and realistic challenges with efficient compassion, but there's probably more dramatic tension in a car pool than in this film's collection of predicaments.

title: Make Your Move
review1: A slick, disposable soap opera about a poor white boy and a spirited Korean girl who fall in love despite hailing from rival corners of Brooklyn's club scene.
review2: A soapy, flashy confection that juxtaposes Mr. Hough's tap dancing with the Japanese drumming style Taiko, tossed with liberal helpings of contemporary hip-hop moves.
review3: Whenever actor Derek Hough and BoA stop leaping and twirling ... "Make Your Move" is an underwritten mess.
review4: Scenes from the competing clubs include impressive choreography and gravity-defying moves. If only the poorly delivered, trite dialogue and predictable plot aimed as high.
review5: It's cheesy fun for sure, but fun nonetheless.

title: Transcendence
review1: The movie is rhythmless, shapeless, and, with the exception of a few shots, cheesy-looking.
review2: This would all fit better in a Wired op-ed than in a movie.
review3: [Transcendence] is more than just a big budget version of Siri Goes Wild.
review4: At once both convoluted and shallow, something like a feature movie version of a Wired sidebar, and just about as fleet-footed.
review5: Pfister seems afraid to recognize the humor inherent in a story that requires Johnny Depp to become a grim sort of Max Headroom...

title: Heaven Is for Real
review1: Unlikely to convert any skeptics, but if they wander into the multiplex, they'll find that that the prettily photographed sermon goes down easily.
review2: This is a big-tent Christian film that wriggles around a lot seeking to accommodate multiple varieties of religious experience, and ends up terminally infected with the virus of postmodern relativism.
review3: A well-acted, family-friendly and timely movie for Easter audiences that is just as much about appreciating life on Earth as it is about what comes after.
review4: There's no antagonist, no resolution, and no real climax - just a series of mildly charming scenes in which Colton shares heavenly knowledge while his family reacts with awestruck tears.
review5: Kinnear does an excellent job of capturing Burpo's obvious dilemma and the turmoil he and his wife endure as they work through this critical time in the life of their family.

title: American Girl: Isabelle Dances into the Spotlight
review1: This one is intended for girls ages 3-12, and few outside the target audience will want to watch. But it IS going to be popular with girls who like dance, and that would be, what, most of them?
review2: Young dancer learns lessons in sweet live-action movie.

title: Wild Guitar
review2: Gained cult status over the years as one that's so bad it's good.

title: The French Minister
review1: There are enough moments of inspired lunacy to make this worthwhile.
review2: The films of Bertrand Tavernier have often been fringed with humor, of a rueful kind; now, in his seventies, and in a rousing rebuke to tranquillity, he has turned to farce.
review3: Mr. Tavernier's filmmaking here is loose, almost casual, and you may not always notice what he's doing with the camera as he frames the ministry's choreographed chaos with its whirling people and parts.
review4: In the first comedy of a 40-year career that includes A Sunday in the Country and The Princess of Montpensier, director and co-writer Bertrand Tavernier tries to do too much.
review5: It's pleasant, and at times very funny, but the meandering episodes mean that despite the long running time, the satire never builds to a payoff.

title: Dragonwolf
review1: Dragonwolf is this really clumsy fusion of Kill Bill and The Room with a hint of Crank. It's nothing but two miserable hours of absolute torment.

title: Shirin In Love
review1: There's a glint of a clever idea here, but writer-director Ramin Niami's reliance on tired rom-com tropes only serve to drag down the film, which plays out like a Harlequin romance.
review2: Too bad you must endure dialogue that's sappy and a story that's drippy.
review3: Although Boniadi makes Shirin nearly as likable as she's supposed to be, writer- director Ramin Niami's movie is crudely contrived and sloppily edited.
review4: Apart from its Iranian-American milieu, this innocuous romantic comedy is strictly formulaic.
review5: The only possible reaction to an amateurish romance like "Shirin in Love" is: Do the filmmakers think we're all idiots?

title: Noah
review1: The kind of stubborn art-epic we get once in a blue moon, the sort that makes me feel protective of it, grateful for it.
review2: Just as the Bible speaks in many ways to many people, so does Darren Aronofsky's epic Noah.
review3: Darren Aronofsky's Noah was the most exciting big-budget studio film of 2014. While comic book movies are all the rage, Aronofsky's Noah treats the great flood as the ultimate origin story: the origin of life as we know it.
review4: The film sometimes plays like a Bible story filtered through the lens of a Snow White and the Huntsman -type re-imagining.
review5: Noah isn't exactly the epic that bible-thumpers wished for, but Aronofsky's vision is masterful enough to create truly mesmerizing moments without being swept away by the murky waters of blockbuster boredom.

title: The Amazing Catfish
review1: Writer-director Claudia Sainte-Luce heralds herself as a new talent to watch with "The Amazing Catfish," an outstanding debut of tremendous heart and appeal.
review2: If there's a certain depth missing in "The Amazing Catfish," the film brings forth the small-scale pleasures and poignancy of an ambling short story.
review3: Claudia Sainte-Luce's semi-autobiographical indie has a knack for subverting stereotypes without making a big deal about it.
review4: This glorious 2013 debut feature by Mexican writer-director Claudia Sainte-Luce takes one of the most shopworn melodramatic premises and makes it feel spontaneous and new.
review5: This movie has a lot of personality, its own voice, and it delivers its message straight and direct... maybe a little too direct. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Half of a Yellow Sun
review1: Biyi Bandele has excerpted their story from a much wider-ranging narrative, but the action here is still so tightly compressed that this feels like a precis for a movie twice its length.
review2: The best of the movie finds a way to abridge the novel and still allow the scenes to breathe.
review3: Like many a lengthy novel, it might have worked better as a television series.
review4: "Half of a Yellow Sun" winds up being one of those movies in which a pesky event of great historical import keeps getting in the way of a soap-opera romance.
review5: The result is that melodramatic soap opera elements win out over Bandele's attempts at stirring historical drama. That said, it's still a story worth telling.

title: Five Dances
review1: A lovingly shot valentine to work and body and art, and a generous, ultimately happy little story of a lost boy finding a community and a kindred soul.
review2: Five Dances should well impress dance aficionados even if its skimpy narrative proves less than inspired.
review3: Rather than adapting the pieces to conform to his paper-thin narrative, Brown explores the tensions and contortions of dancers expressing fresh emotion through a pre-existing art form.
review4: There's an interesting vibe there, but it's not enough to save what seems like a failed experiment.
review5: Though the film's untested cast struggles with the drama, and the sketched-out story is often banal (there are several amateurish calls-to-mom scenes), the presentation of a specific city subculture is etched from the heart.

title: It Felt Like Love
review1: In Gina Piersanti, also making her feature debut, Hittman has found the perfect actress to portray the difficult undertaking of growing up, or at least trying to.
review2: Hittman draws attention to the pervasive cultural forces (rap music, Internet pornography, suggestive dancing on TV) that present young girls as sexual objects, making the scenes of exploitation seem sadly inevitable.
review3: Rarely has the zone between girlhood and womanhood been captured with such urgent honesty than in Eliza Hittman's superb teen drama "It Felt Like Love."
review4: It's easy to be seduced by the loosely observational vibe of the movie, even as its tale of a shrinking violet struggling not to be a late bloomer fails to strike more than a single note of dismay.
review5: Gorgeously shot in Brooklyn's beachfront neighborhoods and devoid of easy sentimentality, "It Felt Like Love" features realistic performances all around, understandable given the cast of mostly first-time actors.

title: Clip
review1: The aesthetic, if you can call it that, is almost entirely derived from amateur porn. Everything's the color of putty or concrete, and that includes the faces; I've seen prettier prison movies.
review2: The film's brutally honest parade of callous behavior and casual, almost cruel sex has a depressing prurience that wears you down.
review3: Maja Milos's aggressive and upsetting first film ...
review4: The Dutch were not wrong in awarding it for its bravery, but the old maxim of whether the glass is half full or empty takes on a whole new meaning with Clip because the glass is shattered into pieces too small for reconstruction.
review5: This gritty Serbian character drama has audacity and attitude to spare, yet lacks sufficient emotional resonance beneath its sexually explicit surface.

title: I'll Follow You Down
review1: Although it mostly falls flat, I'll Follow You Down does deliver an ending that serves as a satisfying payoff.
review2: Ponderous in spots and not as smoothly crafted as it could be, I'll Follow You Down is also held back by Osment's performance, which never seems comfortable or convincing ...
review3: Writer-director Richie Mehta's characters aren't especially thoughtful. Like their creator, they make massive leaps in logic before they do anything.
review4: Indie science fiction with a rare humanism, a scientific and emotional mystery with a solution Hollywood wouldn't dare go anywhere near.
review5: ...a disappointingly half-baked endeavor that feels, for the most part, like a padded-out episode of The Outer Limits.

title: God's Not Dead
review1: Despite the campus setting, little about the story is intelligently designed.
review2: Even by the rather lax standards of the Christian film industry, God's Not Dead is a disaster.
review3: The film is slickly produced, with a competent cast, and although it sometimes stacks the deck shamelessly in defense of its credo, it does allow a few dissenting voices to slip into the debate.
review4: The Almighty deserves better advocacy than he gets in this typically ham-fisted Christian campus melodrama.
review5: Will likely get a mildly, if unenthusiastic, passing grade from its target audience, but for the non-believers, it's going to prove a tough and condescending experience.

title: Around The Block
review1: The film's musty premise, about a novice instructor trying to deter an Aboriginal student from crime with Shakespeare, renders it the cinematic equivalent of warmed-over soup from the school cafeteria.
review2: Every single development in the Wood family's plot trajectory is telegraphed, and these actors deserve to be in a less emotionally bogus drama.
review3: Well-intended yet cliche-ridden.
review4: 'Around the Block' may have its exasperating flaws, but it cannot be accused of not having its heart in the right place.
review5: Appealing performances, a few tweaks to the clichés of the inspiring-teacher genre, and a sincere desire to counter outrageous racism go a long way toward making this worth a look.

title: Oculus
review1: Oculus is about one adjustment away from being a superior thriller.
review2: Praised on the festival circuit, it's got what it takes to succeed outside of that rarefied atmosphere.
review3: What's missing? A sense of the ineffable.
review4: Oculus, a cleverer-than-average haunted-house movie... speaks to a couple of widespread anxieties-one topical, the other sadly timeless.
review5: Good script, strong cast, several quality scares... yeah, it's actually a decent haunted mirror movie!

title: The Perfect Summer
review1: Wholesome surf drama has positive messages, some bullying.

title: The Trip to Bountiful
review1: This Lifetime version of The Trip to Bountiful feels appropriate to remind people to go to the theater, to go seek why shows keep being turned into films and TV miniseries. The Trip to Bountiful, as it is here, isn't always worth the ride.

title: Drones
review1: A middling real-time thriller that chronicles a fictive crisis for two Air Force personnel, who find themselves at loggerheads when they spot an apparent terrorist thousands of miles away on surveillance video.
review2: Drones is the equivalent of an issue-driven movie about the NSA featuring agents who feel really creepy about spying on people. That's not the problem.
review3: While Rick Rosenthal's Drones has the balls to attack the issue head on, the lack of nuance in tackling a complex issue undermines his efforts and that of a game cast.
review4: Drones is in constant combat against itself, poorly balancing searing commentary on excessive drone use and rampant stupidity.
review5: When horror movies and history meet. And with a disturbing and discomforting persistent dread, Drones is in no way standard entertainment, nor should it be. Or as Dirty Wars doc director Jeremy Scahill solemnly observed, 'You can't surrender to a drone.'

title: The Girl on The Train
review1: A paper-thin plot ornamented with distractions: a nonlinear narrative, unreliable narrators, flatulent dialogue and awkward post-production work.
review2: The Girl on the Train believes it's far more intelligent than it actually is, both in structure and in storytelling.

title: Coming Home for Christmas
review1: Sentimental holiday fare with strong messages about family.

title: Nous ne vieillirons pas ensemble (We Won't Grow Old Together)
review1: The notion that "love means never having to say you're sorry" sits there bleeding, a stake right through its broken heart.
review2: Pialat compared the structure of We Won't Grow to that of Ravel's "Boléro" for the gradually increasing fortissimo of its subtly varied-yet-repetitious phrases, variations that here show as a gradual shift in the balance of power.
review3: It's intelligent, measured work from the helmer (who adapts his own novel for the screen), easing entrance into a particularly toxic pairing.
review4: The film's emotional and physical violence is startling enough, bluntly realized through Pialat's visual plainspokenness; but his refusal to situate the viewer in time and place has an unsettling effect that's harder to identify.
review5: The apricots, blues and sand of summer gradually incorporate the yellows, rusts and greens of autumn as the relationship slowly dies.

title: The Past Is A Grotesque Animal
review1: How exhilarating, and exhausting, it must be to wake up every day and be Kevin Barnes.
review2: While Kevin Barnes, and the band, are different in some ways from other musicians and bands, they are also similar in a lot of ways. This is a slightly above average musical documentary, not very different than many others in this genre.
review3: Jason Miller's fantastic new documentary ... presents a frank, complex portrait of an artist who has been pushing the limits of his medium for almost two decades.
review4: Laced with plenty of performance footage, "The Past" peels back the curtain on one of the strangest--or some might say most pretentious--music collectives currently going.

title: The Railway Man
review1: The filmmakers don't have the nerve for a serious consideration of trauma, vengeance, and forgiveness.
review2: The critical problems are an overbusy time-jumping script and reliance on the conventions of the trauma drama - flashbacks, fragmentation, distorted time and space - that prove more a barrier than a window into the character's inner lives.
review3: Beautifully acted, The Railway Man is profoundly moving, and yet, somehow, its sentimental ending manages to be both unearned and predictable.
review4: Why does the movie leave one cold?
review5: The quality of mercy isn't just strained in The Railway Man, it's measured out by the teaspoonful.

title: The Cold Lands
review1: Writer-director Tom Gilroy has worked with Yelich previously and makes his youthful character the quiet, watchful center of this 2013 indie drama.
review2: Gilroy takes all of this to a more realistic, more interesting place, and he manages to find an ending for the story that offers a touch of optimism but doesn't feel like a cheat.
review3: Mr. Yelich is even more emotionally reticent than this central character requires, and "The Cold Lands" feels as if it were just taking hold when it reaches the end of the road.
review4: "The Cold Lands" is aimless and dull, but has a rich tone and upstate authenticity.
review5: Thoughtful and touching ...

title: Summer in February
review1: Compared with the tepid contretemps of "Summer in February," the soap-opera theatrics of "Downton Abbey" have the depth of Chekhov.
review2: Cooper stomps around ineffectually, Stevens makes for a blandly tame suitor, and Browning is unable to ignite any chemistry with either. The scenery is stunning. But the swooning has all the heat of a midwinter's swim.
review3: A ceaselessly bland take on the famed Lamorna artists' colony in Cornwall, circa 1911.
review4: Blah Britpic offers scenery but little else.
review5: A poor script and patchy performances drag down this Edwardian-era drama.

title: Kilimanjaro
review1: Apart from its conceptual bait-and-switch, Kilimanjaro has nothing much to offer.

title: Proxy
review1: [With] performances better suited to a high school play
review2: When almost everyone on screen is nursing a pathology, interest in their fates is far from guaranteed.
review3: Whatever "Proxy" lacks in narrative cohesion and psychological realism, it makes up for in its compelling fever-dream quality and its probing questions about the darker side of parenting.
review4: Proxy's greatest attribute is its deliberate dismantling of the audience's assumptions. Writer-director Zack Parker has made a genre whatsit whose central mystery lies in the stealth motivations of its characters.
review5: Like a lot of conspiracy thrillers, the questions it raises prove more compelling than the answers it slowly teases out.

title: Hateship Loveship
review1: Wiig's underplaying, a repressed otherworldly Sissy Spacek sort of thing, has its moments of humor, but this proud, simple woman is never for an instant comic.
review2: It doesn't take long for us to get lost in Wiig's thorough portrayal of a dowdy housekeeper who must soldier on in the face of a cruel prank to find some kind of love in her life.
review3: Liza Johnson's nicely tuned, and turned, adaptation of the Alice Munro short story "Hateship, Friendship, Courtship, Loveship, Marriage."
review4: We've never seen a protagonist quite like Johanna, who on the one hand personifies female self-abnegation at its most domesticated, but on the other embodies the sheer will at its most stubborn.
review5: Short fiction can be a marvelous blueprint for film and revisiting Nobel Prize-winner Munro's story in this era of "catfishing" makes a lot of sense: People are no less desperate for connection than they ever have been.

title: Breathe In
review1: There's something flimsy and unformed at these characters' cores, something that no amount of jumpy close-ups, skittering sideways glances, and rainy music can make up for.
review2: Buoyed by some nicely nuanced performances (especially by Pearce and Amy Ryan as his dream-dashing wife), Breathe In never quite rises above its predictable potboiler premise.
review3: Every moment between stars Guy Pearce and Felicity Jones feels so much like an explosion about to go off that viewers may hesitate to so much as take a breath at the wrong time for fear of disturbing the film's delicate equilibrium.
review4: A breathy tale of a not-quite love affair, Drake Doremus' "Breathe In" is yet another skillfully acted indie drama that's never quite good enough to be memorable.
review5: The superb acting can't turn narrative lead into gold with this story about the attraction of a foreign-exchange student pianist to her married host and teacher.

title: Locke
review1: [Hardy's performance is] the reason you'd see Locke, and the reason you may remember it fondly, long after the ride ends.
review2: Yes, it sounds like a gimmick. But Tom Hardy is so compelling, multilayered and terrific in the title role, this one-man show is never dull.
review3: As you'd expect from a story that never leaves the confines of a car, Locke is intense and claustrophobic.
review4: Tom Hardy's visceral performance in this one-man meltdown packs more drama than a half-dozen multi-character stories.
review5: The fact that Locke delivers, then, is splendid news, especially for fans of onscreen minimalism and alternative approaches to familiar stories.

title: Filth
review1: "Filth" lives up to its title and then some, but a no-holds performance by James McAvoy is reason enough to watch.
review2: Credit the filmmakers with descending persuasively into the swampy squalor of a diseased mind. If you're in the mood to go there with them, Filth offers an indecently bracing wallow.
review3: I'm not sure I can recommend the movie, but this actor and this performance are something to behold.
review4: Viewers hungry for a catch-all dose of Welshian sardonicism would be better served checking out Trainspotting. Better soundtrack, for one.
review5: Unlike Jude Law's similarly offensive title character in Dom Hemingway, McAvoy is given a far better story to work from.

title: The Moment
review1: "The Moment" is a psychological thriller more muddled than the mind and the maze it is caught up in.
review2: Watching the movie becomes a kind of parlor game: Is Lee capable of murder? Which moment is the moment?
review3: You don't ever really know what's going on, but at least the heavy-handed music tells you what to feel.
review4: The Moment is another in a long string of thrill-free psychological "thrillers" that fail from start to finish.
review5: Viewers must work as hard as Lee to determine past from present; you may feel amnesiac yourself by film's end.

title: Love Streams
review1: Love Streams is at once a culmination of the director's obsessions and his most atypical film.
review2: There's no other American director who can do what John Cassavetes does on the screen.
review3: John Cassavetes's career of risk taking comes to a climax in this rich, original, emotionally magnificent 1984 film.
review4: The movie is exasperating, because we never know where we stand or what will happen next. I think that's one of its strengths: There's an exhilaration in this roller-coaster ride through scenes that come out of nowhere.

title: Worm
review1: Nothing creepier than a worm going up your ear canal. But, the new horror flick, "Worm," is more like ear wax. You can't wait to be rid of it.

title: Frankie & Alice
review1: Frankie & Alice feels like a film that might have been groundbreaking 40 years ago but has cable-TV movie of the week written all over it in 2014.
review2: Berry has proven she's willing to take on enormous challenges, and she certainly exceeds her grasp here. Perhaps that's why Frankie & Alice plays more like an elaborate acting workshop than a movie.
review3: While all this channel-switching and inevitable unearthing of psychic demons generates a great awards-season clip, it doesn't necessarily lead to a satisfying drama.
review4: It may be that this genre has been forever ruined, or just that it requires a more subtle hand than the one exhibited by Geoffrey Sax, the director here.
review5: Lamentably by-the-numbers, treated like an affliction-of-the-week TV movie by its eight (!) credited writers and directed by Geoffrey Sax as if he knew where commercials should go.

title: Reunion
review1: No one's problems inspire much interest, and the stuffy banality of the dialogue is multiplied by the lackluster surroundings.
review2: A drearily pretentious, ultra-stagy exercise in middle-age self-loathing.
review3: A respectable B-list cast (Cynthia Stevenson, Jessica Hecht, Christopher McDonald) wades through a sludgy script that finds estranged friends reuniting decades after college.
review4: This may not be quite the moment to solicit our sympathy for self-absorbed beneficiaries of Ivy League privilege.
review5: Since no one in the cast is a household name, the series of confessions and critiques resemble nothing so much as actors' auditions.

title: A Brony Tale
review1: Cheery docu dispels stereotypes of male My Little Pony fans.
review2: This is an accessible, briskly paced documentary about a phenomenon that warrants exactly the level of investigation Hodges has given it here.
review3: While it could have benefited from more insight from the people involved with show and follow-up commentary from Bryan, the movie poses interesting questions about gender roles in modern society.
review4: At the same time, it's fascinating to watch Hodge peel back the curtain and show this community in all its perplexing glory.
review5: As Brent Hodge vividly illustrates in his entertaining, insightful and affectionate documentary about a seemingly bizarre subculture, there's more to this phenomenon than meets the eye. Heck, it might even make a Brony out of you.

title: I Am Happiness on Earth
review1: At one point my notes included the gut reaction "This is awful."
review2: Not to be a killjoy, but had Hernández simply made a more straightforward, conventional movie about the life and loves of a rising gay Mexican film director, he might have had something.
review3: If the film defies conventional form, it does so without the gravitas that conceptual cohesion brings, quickly rendering its experimentation into gratuitous aesthetic masturbation.
review4: (Director Julian) Hernandez provides loads of sexy scenery but not much sense. The film is heavy on slow, sensual storytelling that more often than not demands viewers' intuition rather than offer clearly delineated characters and relationships.
review5: ...Hernandez merely revels in his own pretentiousness, staging one dully limp encounter after another with self-conscious camerawork and absurdly stilted drama that renders the entire project a pseudo-porny slog.

title: Go For Sisters
review1: John Sayles is too talented, too authentic and too original to make a flat-out bad movie, but he flirts with it in "Go for Sisters."
review2: This buddy/road film builds tension with its missing person quest in a border-crossing underworld.
review3: A sci-fi-horror yarn stocked with a winning cast but hobbled by a lamebrained script and dull set pieces.
review4: Once Olmos joins the proceedings, "Go For Sisters" begins to resemble a banal prime-time cop show.
review5: Reminds us that you can give characters guns and tense face-offs without creating brain-dead action trash.

title: When I Saw You
review1: When war or other disasters strike, children suffer the most. Uncomprehending, powerless, they can only endure.
review2: Here's a story of refugee life from the perspective of a brash and attentive kid, one just discovering - and often rejecting - the political realities grown-ups accept.
review3: A soft-centered child's-eye view of alienation, toughened by fine acting and Hélène Louvart's full-bodied photography.
review4: An earnest piece of social realism from a child's point of view.
review5: Political without point-scoring, Jacir remains true to a child's-eye view, with Asfa's delightful, exuberant performance always upfront.

title: The Empty Hours
review1: Fernandez is astute in the way he fills the empty hours on screen. He sets a slow steady rhythm and embraces lingering shots and long silences to catch the way the days are lazy about unfolding, especially for Sebastian.
review2: This second feature by the Mexican director Aarón Fernández is a delight.
review3: Eventually you begin to wonder what these series of standstill moments represent.
review4: A studied, coming-of-age narrative that makes a familiar tale sing.
review5: The movie has a small story but a big theme; the theme being experience, and it conveys the emotions and moods of its characters by taking things nice and slow.

title: Two: The Story of Roman & Nyro
review1: The fact that Child and Shaw share writing and producing credits here almost assures it will be a self-aggrandizing puff piece.
review2: Almost completely drama-free, a sugared-over account that takes pains to say absolutely nothing that isn't safe pap.
review3: Too often, Two feels like a stranger's camcorder footage that's been edited on the fly.
review4: Captures well (if in sometimes blandly straightforward fashion) the hopes, frustrations, sacrifices and ultimate success (its subjects) experienced.

title: The Amazing Spider-Man 2
review1: It could easily be shorter and no one would be mad, but personally, I thought it was a tonal improvement on the last film and actually made me care that I was watching a movie about Spider-Man.
review2: Although it drags at times and is simply too long, dampening the emotional impact of some key plot points, the fine performances -- particularly Garfield's and a fine closing scene -- will leave you thinking this Spider-Man is still kind of amazing.
review3: Everyone has done an excellent job on director Marc Webb's exciting, well-crafted sequel to his first Spider-Man film. But it's impossible to reboot audiences' brains, and forget the same job was done even better, only the other day.
review4: The Amazing Spider-Man 2 certainly has its moments, but for the most part it's just middle-of-the-pack blockbuster fare.
review5: Frustrates as much as it entertains.

title: Watercolor Postcards
review1: A fine and gripping drama...

title: Only Lovers Left Alive
review1: If Jamrusch's comedy is snobby and misty is precisely because vampires should be that way. [full review in Spanish]
review2: A great theme and visual compendium. [full review in Spanish]
review3: A delightful Jim Jarmusch film. [full review in Spanish]
review4: The most interesting thing about this movie is the way Jarmusch toys with us to reveal to us a simple thing: it's a vampire story. [full review in Spanish]
review5: If you are able to tolerate the quiet and smooth tempo of Jarmusch , this is a great story.

title: Le démantèlement (The Auction)
review1: Director Sébastien Pilote tells his story simply, and gets terrific, real-life performances from all of his actors.
review2: A modern twist on the King Lear tragedy. Captures the rhythms of farm life as much as any documentary, depicting a way of life fast disappearing.
review3: It punches the viewer in the gut with a belly full of reality, that emotionally has knock out power.

title: Grigris
review1: Distills a vast swath of history and experience in the travails of one striving man.
review2: [An] uplifting underdog story, complete with dance numbers and a sweet romantic subplot.
review3: The movie loses its way with too much plot (including an unconvincing love story), weak dialogue, amateurish acting, and a frustratingly recessive main character.
review4: This elegant, geographically vivid pic is considerably leaner than its melodramatic premise might suggest.
review5: Haroun previously won the Jury Prize in Cannes for his 2010 drama A Screaming Man, and this low-key crime story unfolds with the same kind of thoughtful, resigned fatalism.

title: Varsity Blood
review1: Varsity Blood is the student who coasted through high school, achieving the bare minimum just to pass through without drawing any attention.

title: Septic Man
review1: The crappiest chiller in recent memory, quite literally.
review2: Former wrestler Maillet is the only performer who generates any empathy.
review3: It's a grotesque, deadly dull piece of cinematic upchuck, a horror film minus tension or chills. Think "The Toxic Avenger," minus the avenger.
review4: Theaters showing Septic Man should be required to issue hazmat suits at the door.
review5: Ick

title: Greencard Warriors
review1: The horrors faced by Mexican illegals on the L.A. mean streets get a familiar indexing in this well-meaning but familiar ghetto melodrama.
review2: Ms. Kruishoop's direction and Helle Jensen's cinematography, on dark streets and in small rooms, create an all too foreboding sense of danger.

title: Xingu
review1: In all, "Xingu" is a fitting tribute to the Villas Bôas vision.
review2: We know how this story plays out wherever it happens, and halfway through, the film switches from Dances With Capybaras to an Exodus tale ...
review3: Ignore the jaded Village Voice critic. This is a compelling story about the key question of our age: the right of indigenous peoples to live in peace and freedom.

title: Cinemanovels
review1: A thoughtful thesis on the melodrama but a letdown in its attempt to serve as an affecting example of that genre.
review2: The actors make up for the relative thinness of the material. Smith navigates the emotional terrain with great skill.
review3: Smith gives a stellar performance in the role, building a character whose motivation is a mystery but whose emotions are deeply felt. Too bad the film doesn't really have anywhere to go with such talent.

title: The Normal Heart
review1: There is less reporting on poverty in America than on any other major societal issue. So it is with AIDS. That alone makes The Normal Heart an important film.
review2: If anger and suffering were all there were to The Normal Heart, watching it would be torture. Luckily, it has heart to match its guts.
review3: Matt Bomer is heartbreaking as a New York Times style reporter looking for love in a loveless city. His physical transformation is astonishing and agonizing.
review4: Time, and rewrites, have softened some of the play's stridency. More important, the romance between Weeks (Ruffalo) and his lover, Felix (Bomer), is given a more prominent role as is Felix's death spiral, giving the story power both broad and intimate.
review5: Moving, well acted and important for a generation who may be unfamiliar with the source material. But the TV version, also written by Kramer, doesn't have the emotional heft of the play.

title: Falling Away
review1: Proves a sincere, authentic, generally stirring effort.

title: Belle
review1: A good-looking and exceedingly polite film where perhaps a more complex one with less good manners would have been better.
review2: More or less single-handedly saved by its actors.
review3: Though having the kind of pedestrian pace which often hits British costume dramas (Keira Knightley's 2008 film The Duchess excepted), Belle is sumptuously filmed and feels relevant.
review4: The teenage Dido Elizabeth Belle is impressively played by Gugu Mbatha-Raw with a tender sensibility and a growing awareness.
review5: The film works as both an intimate character piece and as a broader glimpse into socioeconomic conflicts regarding tolerance and perception.

title: Aftermath
review1: The shocks, and the repressed wickedness, as in all well-done horror films, build slowly, then reach a crescendo that is hard to bear and harder to shake off.
review2: A sense of dread suffuses this film, which offers yet another slice of World War II history.
review3: There is something especially unsettling about groupthink, particularly when it comes to evil.
review4: Jozek's and Franek's characters (and Czop's and Stuhr's performances) are continually surprising and ultimately indelible. You can read how their mindsets shift as they stumble onto new truths.
review5: Director Wladyslaw Pasikowski has made the mistake of going about his business as if he were fashioning a horror film.

title: Project Wild Thing
review1: It always feels like we're watching a campaign video, so the preaching-to-the converted vibe is inescapable.
review2: The film isn't full of revelations but it's playful and makes trees look very huggable indeed.
review3: This is a project we should all support.
review4: An engaging, persuasive and often funny film, strategically highlighting the worrying truth about how little time British children spend outdoors.
review5: This is the longest environmental campaign film ever. Yawn.

title: A Promise
review1: Despite decent performances, a promising dramatic set-up leads to little of real interest.
review2: The anguish of the lovers' decade-long separation can't be evoked in a matter of minutes ...
review3: The actors are smoothly professional and the production feels polished. But it's hard to recommend a romance without passion, no matter how pretty it looks.
review4: The magnetism between these stiff nonstarters wouldn't stick to a fridge, especially when the war-ex-machina forces them apart for years but the only credible passing of time is our own.
review5: This awkward, passionless drama conveys neither the sensuality nor the drawn-out sense of longing required by its period tale of a young secretary who falls in love with his employer's wife.

title: Stress Position
review1: These intellectual angles are never fully fleshed out.
review2: The political allegory functions on a meta level, showing an abusive auteur taking his personal vision too far.

title: Young & Beautiful (Jeune Et Jolie)
review1: It became clear, as the movie wore on, that Ozon isn't interested in explanations, psychological insights, lessons, judgments, diagnoses, or any of the other stuff that normally preoccupies storytellers.
review2: This is a different kind of coming-of-age story.
review3: Prostitution in polite society is still a nettle fearfully grasped. You see, society is not polite and it's about time movies stopped peddling that fluff.
review4: Never amounts to anything more than its title's shallow descriptors.
review5: Ozon keeps things simmering without quite boiling over, even when convention might demand it.

title: Trust Me
review1: There's a fine tradition of acerbic movies that skewer Hollywood: Think "Sunset Boulevard," "The Player" and "What Just Happened," to name a few. The dark-humored "Trust Me" is a worthy addition to the list.
review2: There's certainly humor running through writer-director-star Clark Gregg's "Trust Me," the tale of an inept agent for child actors; it's just that not all of it feels intentional.
review3: As long as Gregg, as both actor and director, is anatomizing the Hollywood viper pit, Trust Me rings true.
review4: As the movie picks up speed and undergoes sudden, confusing plot reversals, it loses its satirical edge.
review5: "Trust Me" contains so much terrific writing, acting and observation that it becomes a bit easier to forgive writer-director-star Clark Gregg when his ambitions best him during the movie's convoluted last third.

title: Aleister Crowley: Legend of the Beast
I've Always Loved You
review1: Here's a musical drama in the wholesome Deanna Durbin format but with the clandestine erotic charge of King Vidor
review2: The film is redeemed, finally, through the sheer, crazy belief in romance that Frank Borzage imbues in the film as it goes on.

title: The Rise (Wasteland)
review1: This British heist picture is familiar but energetic genre filmmaking, more interesting in its particulars than in its overall conception.
review2: A British heist movie that's well deserving of an American audience.
review3: The shallow, derivative and contrived British heist thriller "Wasteland" lives down to its unfortunate name.
review4: To borrow from a term for the gritty, working-class British dramas that this film also nods to, it's a kitchen-sink caper.
review5: It creates two admirably entertaining storytelling strands - one a friendship saga, the other a robbery caper - yet can't merge the two successfully.

title: A Teacher
review1: The movie is lifeless for its first hour, and the last-minute outpourings are too little, too late.
review2: An evocative but ultimately hollow indie drama.
review3: The diminishing returns in part are due to Burdge's performance, which too often settles for the same look of fraught anxiety. But they also result from Fidell's decision to pare her film down to the barest elements.
review4: Ms. Fidell ... has a fine eye but not the makings of a feature-length movie here and, it quickly becomes clear, isn't interested in this relationship or the moral, ethical and legal issues it raises.
review5: Fidell's mature style and Burdge's lack of guile are engaging. As the film's emotions grow darker, a lack of ideas comes through.

title: From The Rough
review1: Henson nicely captures Starks' determination but also her doubts and personal demons.
review2: Solid sports tale has positive messages, feel-good themes.
review3: Henson's performance goes a long way toward selling the uniqueness and importance of Starks and her story--which Bagley almost appears determined to flatten out in the most cookie-cutter-familiar way possible.
review4: A well-deserved, if syrupy sweet, overdue tribute to an African-American role model and trailblazer.

title: God's Horses
review1: Anyone seeking to establish an incubator for suicide bombers could hardly improve on Sidi Moumen, a slum on the fringe of Casablanca.
review2: "Horses of God" is one of the most forceful entries in a growing body of cinema that interrogates the causes and effects of terrorism, nationalism and fundamentalism in the Arab world.
review3: Director Nabil Ayouch does a remarkable job of putting you inside this brutal world, from the garbage dumps that serve as playgrounds to soaring aerial shots of the endless tin roofs that form their neighborhood.
review4: Ayouch film casts a sharp gaze on tragedy, and the larger socio-economic issues that beget fanaticism.
review5: A compelling contemplation of the roots of Islamic terrorism in poverty and hopelessness.

title: Chavez Cage Of Glory
review1: Argentinian MMA star Hector Echevarria makes an ill-conceived bid for cinematic 'Glory.'
review2: Good intentions go just so far when a movie is hobbled by such risible, place holder dialogue, contrived plot points, wildly uneven performances and awkward camera work.

title: Night Moves
review1: I'd say this is a movie about alienation that, in the spirit of the boldest activism, isn't afraid to be ostracized itself. You may beg to differ, and I'd say that's the point.
review2: The film serves as a reminder that our greatest fear isn't necessarily getting caught in the act; it's getting caught down the line.
review3: Reichardt has crafted a mesmerising, unsettling film about the ripple effects of our decisions and how we live with them.
review4: The actors in the story give very good performances. The story is fairly solid. It is a bit subdued and there are some logical holes in it, but on the whole it is a fairly realistic scenario.
review5: The actors give down-to-earth but emotionally charged performances distinguished by a subsurface simmer that sometimes intensifies into a slow boil.

title: Draft Day
review1: Ivan Reitman's dull-witted movie about the flurries of player trading on N.F.L. draft day might be a commercial for professional football.
review2: However unintentionally, "Draft Day" confirms that sports rewards heroes and villains alike. Remember Jerry Sandusky?
review3: It all gets rather corny, but Costner's charisma will keep you watching until the final whistle.
review4: Sports film fans will lap [Draft Day] up but others may struggle to keep their heads in the game.
review5: This is a dangerous slice of propaganda that actually has the temerity to end with a family unit walking arm-in-arm into a rosy sunset.

title: Whitewash
review1: Largely because of a pitch-perfect final line and a Haden Church performance that brings a dose of needed compassion, Whitewash manages to keep its footing.
review2: The viewer is left in a snowblind limbo that makes it awfully difficult to stay engaged.
review3: An airtight demonstration of the maxim that no good deed ever goes unpunished.
review4: Thomas Haden Church bridges the credibility gap in snowed-in fugitive tale.
review5: Whitewash is a small but sparkling gem on ice.

title: Brick Mansions
review1: This is ultimately a movie about class warfare and social oppression that isn't remotely science-fictional. It's real, and as dumb as this remake is, it sends you home thinking.
review2: Follows the bog-standard formula perfected by Besson: combining functional storylining with competent action highlights and an occasional air of whimsy.
review3: It's fun to see Walker do a double take at a perilous move of Belle's and then find a less risky alternative. The pair seem like they're having a good time in this buddy action movie. It seems a fitting curtain call for a likable actor gone too soon.
review4: "Frankly, there are a lot of actors who have a lot of worse 'last films' on their credits."
review5: Routine all the way, although Belle's moves are thrilling to watch.

title: God's Pocket
review1: Its crazed whirlwind of tones suddenly made perfect sense once the location is established. If you're from Philly, you'll get it.
review2: The colour balance, locations, set designs and dialogue have an authenticity we rarely see in bigger budget movies and the characters are, well, characters.
review3: God's Pocket is strange one, but a strange one that I can't stop thinking about.
review4: A tonally scattershot indie film. The biggest misstep of the movie is the trite narration from Richard Jenkins, who espouses a kind of low-level loser pride in his columns for the local paper.
review5: So unlikeable are these characters and disinteresting their plight that investing even a crumb of energy into their story is an investment wasted.

title: Victim
review1: This is solidly made, but once you get past the attempts at realism - the banter, the backstories, the music, the clothes - it's a desperately corny yarn.
review2: The set-ups are familiar, the characters well worn and the film-makers' message (we are all victims) writ cornily large. But co-writer Chin is an imposing screen presence of whom we may expect more in future.
review3: Preachy and cliched, Victim has some merit in the bantering dialogue and fresh, appealing performances but all the good intentions don't necessarily add up to a good film.
review4: It doesn't quite come together, yet there's some rough'n'ready force.
review5: A few solid observations aside, this is the urban thriller running on low-fi autopilot.

title: The Road
review1: If it's patchy and derivative it also has a compelling, soapy undertow that kept me watching.
review2: [Laranas] delivers a maximum of suspense and horror, working wonders with a small budget.
review3: This philosophical film helps elevate the film above the usual scared-teenager shocker although, sometimes, the film ignores the bread-and-butter demands of the genre.
review4: The film's three-pronged narrative does a fair job of laying a spooky groundwork for the revelatory emotional sadism that lies behind most acts of evil; it just takes a bit of clunky exposition to get there.
review5: A powerfully atmospheric blend of ghostly encounters, horrific situations and missing-persons mysteries from the Philippine director Yam Laranas.

title: Burning Blue
review1: Top guns in love struggle against institutional homophobia in a tone deaf melodrama well past its sell-by date.
review2: The script, by Mr. Greer and Helene Kvale, rolls along with lifeless, profoundly unimaginative dialogue ...
review3: Earnest but terribly ham-fisted ...
review4: What can any actor do with dialogue like, "We are warriors paid to defend this country, not spill our guts and frolic in the daisies."
review5: Honorable in intent but risible in execution ...

title: Words And Pictures
review1: Barely qualifies as a motion picture.
review2: A romantic comedy about a match neither written nor pictured in heaven.
