review3: It is a joy to see a film that tackles the topic of art and its value in the world, and all the better that actors of Owen's and Binoche's caliber can lead it.
review4: The opposites-attract business exchanged by Jack and Dina is so efficiently scheduled throughout the script, you could almost imagine these moments were timetabled by software.
review5: The performances are first-rate.

title: Palo Alto
review1: The drama is scaled to just the right size: kids get into trouble or inadvisable situations, but there are no major melodramatics. We see them in their natural habitat.
review2: James Franco's collection of autobiographical short stories is adapted into a remarkably evocative film by Gia Coppola, granddaughter of Francis.
review3: Another week, another glacial outing from the ever-expanding Coppola clan depicting the oh so beautiful emptiness of American teenage wildlife.
review4: Palo Alto is as fuzzy, scattered and aimless as its protagonists' lives.
review5: The story tends to meander but the kids' ups and downs are delicately observed and the performances, especially from Roberts, are never less than believable.

title: Louder Than Words
review1: Hope Davis and David Duchovny give solid, moving performances as grieving parents in this inspirational heart-tugger.
review2: Is this story compelling? Will it keep your attention for its 95-minute running time? Is it worth the ticket price? Sadly, the answer is: not quite.
review3: The title refers to the adage that actions speak louder than words, but a movie that reduces children and parents to cardboard saints doesn't say much.
review4: They've made a film about bereavement in which the departed person rarely disappears for long.
review5: A true story, good intentions and meandering filmmaking make for bland uplift in the family drama "Louder Than Words."

title: A Long Way Down
review1: The movie criminally wastes Sam Neill and Rosamund Pike in barely there supporting roles, and the picture has exactly two tones: grim and gooey. They do not coexist harmoniously.
review2: Whatever the intent of the filmmakers, a story that hinges on existential despair requires at least a modicum of emotional credulity.
review3: As British comedy sometimes will, "A Long Way Down" has an occasional attack of the cutes, but the actors' commitment keeps the movie on the plus side.
review4: Tackles the topic of life-ending despair with all the delicacy and grace of a Hallmark greeting card.
review5: Author Nick Hornby establishes a tone of sentimental black humor, and director Pascal Chaumeil orchestrates the encounter as the formation of rag-tag band where each player gets a stirring solo number.

title: Borgman
review1: What Marina sees in Borgman is one of the countless implausibilities that make the film more annoying than disturbing.
review2: The black humour and perversity can occasionally startle, but the film takes far too much sadistic delight in punishing these entitled dopes.
review3: A creepily comical story about an insistent vagrant turned insidious home occupier.
review4: It's the hypnotic little thriller's disturbing twists that make it such a singular -- and singularly weird -- experience.
review5: Though it's too enigmatic for its own good and often feels like it's being made up as it goes, the Dutch import "Borgman" holds interest if only to see what might possibly happen next.

title: Dead Within
review1: A compelling, and maddening bit of zombie apocalypse fodder that examines the psyche of the survivor...
review2: Ben Wagner's cabin-fever creation is a sharply nuanced survivor's tale that leaves the viewer to disentangle the genre tropes from their underlying triggers, and the reality from its delirious breakdown.

title: As Dreamers Do
review1: Unauthorized, overacted Disney biopic falls flat.

title: Petals on the Wind
review1: There's enough of the all-out V.C. Andrews flavor to make this installment worth a look for those who want to catch up with a family of soap people 30 years in the making.
review2: Where Flowers was airless and po-faced, Petals is manic and sudsy, speeding through a treasure trove of sleazy plot twists like CliffsNotes on crack.
review3: Soapy, sudsy, and scandalous, this take on the much-beloved (and much-reviled!) V.C. Andrews' book is a lot more fun than Lifetime's previous Flowers in the Attic.
review4: [Petals on the Wind] commits the deadliest of movie sins: it does not shock, it does not move, it does not provoke...unless yawns count, it is simply a bore.

title: The Fault In Our Stars
review1: The Fault In Our Stars could indeed become this generation's Love Story -- mildly implausible, but genuinely moving.
review2: The film has enough charm and humor to keep it appealing to a wide audience, and dumbing things down doesn't feel particularly smart or canny, and proves to be a minor distraction to an otherwise majorly entertaining feature.
review3: Far from the shameless emotional pummeling it might have been, this adaptation of John Green's cherished YA cancer drama finds a conduit to earned, understated tears -- a tricky accomplishment given the material.
review4: "The Fault in Our Stars" may not show the true messiness of cancer, but it does grapple with death and the ability to survive great loss. Maybe that's enough truth for one movie.
review5: Although certain plot points skirt dangerously close to clichés that more cynical viewers will have been dreading, somehow they manage to resolve plausibly.

title: The Battery
review1: Taken as a two-person character study/reluctant buddy movie/legitimately novel slant on a very oft-told tale, there's certainly a lot to like here.
review2: An engaging and thoughtful work of horror, one that admirably puts carnage in the back seat so that something more emotional/humane can do the driving.
review3: Gardner puts the monsters in the background while he concentrates on the growing difficulties between the two friends.
review4: [Director] Jeremy Gardner's zombie horror drama is a masterpiece.

title: The German Doctor
review1: Puenzo's initial premise is more promising, though, than her sensational tone.
review2: Quietly unnerving.
review3: This curious, surprisingly safe melodrama fictionalises the postwar life of brutal Nazi surgeon Josef Mengele.
review4: A thriller with a historical basis, 'The German Doctor' is a somewhat fictionalized glimpse at a ghastly real-life villain.
review5: The picture is beautifully shot and the serenity of the Argentine mountain landscape works as an effective contradiction to the deranged, demented narrative at hand.

title: Ilo Ilo
review1: Chen builds his case not with sentimentality and obvious plot points, but through everyday life -- showering, doing laundry, dropping the boy off at school, phone calls.
review2: The crowded compositions convey a sense of life in the dense Asian city-state, but also the intimacy of this semi-autobiographical story.
review3: Anthony Chen, a Singaporean writer-director with a half-dozen shorts to his credit, makes his feature debut with this vividly characterized domestic drama.
review4: Characters who may seem hopeless begin to suggest a vulnerable side, and none truly deserve the situations that afflict them.
review5: "Ilo Ilo" is writer-director Anthony Chen's first film, but breathtaking intimacy in storytelling is already second nature to him.

title: Shôjo wa isekai de tatakatta (Danger Dolls)
Fort McCoy
review1: If the film has a major flaw, it's the profusion of subplots in a 100-minute running time. Still, it is a real accomplishment.
review2: "Fort McCoy" is an obvious labor of love. That doesn't make it a good movie, but it's a nice sentiment all the same.
review3: The period details are so lovingly burnished in this uneven, if heartfelt, feature that for a while they threaten to overpower the story, which delves gently into a rarely explored aspect of the war.
review4: A heartfelt, personal film with great performances aims for the stars and falls back to earth.
review5: An old-fashioned, appealingly sentimental drama about homefront life during WWII.

title: After
review1: "After" catalogs so many clichés in the dysfunctional family at its center that the film could be taught in a screenwriting class as a lesson in what not to do.
review2: Viewers ... are left with little to do but endure a lot of seemingly unprovoked family tensions while waiting for the inevitable revelation.
review3: [There's] a fairly far-fetched twist that feels out of place in this realism-based drama.
review4: A frequently absorbing miserablist family drama shot in appropriately chilly winter tones ...
review5: Gaspersz embeds you with this family's struggles, and almost makes you care about what happens to them all in the end

title: "Run Silent, Run Deep"
review4: A better submarine film has not been made.
review5: Solid WWII drama with two can't-miss stars.

title: Hero of the Day
review1: Keeps the viewer guessing just where the story might be going.

title: It Was You Charlie
review1: At once overly eccentric and underdeveloped.
review2: [A] bleakly funny debut.
review3: Shirinian, a homegrown filmmaker making his feature-length film debut, is clearly talented behind the camera. It's in the screenwriting that he falters.
review4: An alternately morose and quirky tale about a suicidal doorman that, despite a sturdy lead performance, fails to generate either droll laughs or poignant drama.

title: Raven's Cravings: A Bmore Love Thing
Serena and the Ratts
review1: None of the actors appear confident carrying out the physical tasks - cocking a gun, brandishing a knife, strangling a target, even just talking on the phone - they've been assigned to perform.

title: Come Morning
review1: In the end, Come Morning succeeds on the strength of a simple narrative with personal dynamic complexities that reveal themselves slowly.
review2: It isn't for everyone, and it certainly won't be considered one of the feel-good movies of the year, but if you appreciate beautiful cinematography and a well-crafted story that still leaves space for thought, Come Morning is an absolute must-see.
review3: ...a taut, atmospheric and, given its budgetary restraints, extraordinarily well-realized suspense film set and filmed in southern Arkansas near Kingsland. It's a fine example of what can be accomplished outside a studio paradigm.

title: See You Next Tuesday
review1: A black comedy that offers no apologies for its dysfunctional characters and scorched-earth dialogue.
review2: A movie whose forced outrages aren't nearly as funny as intended and whose hysterics produce hives instead of the desired catharsis.
review3: Tuesday locks the viewer into a disturbed character's head space, generating terror from the possibility it will erupt upon the world at large.
review4: The actresses bring heart and nuance to their characters, whose verbal pushing and shoving go with their sisterly and maternal bonds.
review5: One of the most refreshing things about See You Next Tuesday is its refusal to regard Mona as a tragic subject to be lamented from a dramatic remove.

title: Ida
review1: Now that Paweł Pawlikowski's haunting Polish film has been nominated for a foreign-language Oscar, Ida is back in the conversation. Let yourself be enveloped by a modern cinema classic.
review2: Nestled within its sins-of-the-elders narrative is a faintly charming cross-generational bonding picture, pairing a worldly cynic with a young girl taking her last gasp of secular air before giving her life to the Lord.
review3: With her brassy, determined aunt, Ida sets off to find answers and discovers life beyond the convent walls in this leisurely but satisfying journey.
review4: Slow, beautiful Ida is more impressive cinematically than narratively
review5: Deep undercurrents run beneath the simple surface

title: Very Good Girls
review1: Very Good Girls has a breezy yet bittersweet, vaguely nostalgic vibe.
review2: Despite a finely wrought lead performance by Dakota Fanning, the drama feels more like the stuff of a mild - and dated - YA novel than an involving exploration of female experience.
review3: One insurmountable problem is that the stars, especially Ms. Olsen, 25, are too old for their roles. Another is that the movie has more characters than it can begin to accommodate in 91 minutes.
review4: Disappointingly, Foner's young heroines are defined primarily by their reactions to other people. It's a great credit to Olsen and, especially, Fanning that they manage to make these characters vibrant and sympathetic anyway.
review5: A drama that feels like an old person's idea of what young people are like.

title: The Young Savages
review3: quaint to the point of incoherence and inconsequence
review4: It's a West Side Story without the romance and music.

title: Taras Bulba
review3: It seems to be in genre form when showing hordes of Cossack horsemen flying across the steppes to do battle.

title: Wolf
review1: Its intrigues, its graphic violence and Mr. Kenzari's performance make for a worthy addition to the annals of gangster films, Interpol edition.
review2: It's refreshing that director Jim Taihuttu is more interested in the humdrum goings on of those who split their time between illegal and legitimate activities.
review3: Those who aren't completely turned off by [the lead character] might find themselves increasingly drawn into his story.
review4: It may spend more time paying homage to classics than finding its own voice, but Wolf picks and chooses its influences very well indeed.
review5: Like a stale Big Mac served in gold leaf, [Wolf ] offers up some central meat that never matches the aspiration of its textured flourishes.

title: Space Station 76
review1: At once a spoof of, and loving tribute to, '70s-era visions of the future, Space Station 76 nods to 2001 in numerous ways.
review2: This may look like a wacky spoof of 1970s sci-fi, but Jack Plotnick's beautifully designed comedy-drama actually has a lot more on its mind.
review3: "Space Station 76" stretches every penny, from the curving white walls of the station to the men's wide-collared shirts, but it also demonstrates the kind of talentand determination that no amount of money can buy a filmmaker who doesn't have them.
review4: It's hard to say what the creators of "Space Station 76" were aiming for. But whatever it was, they didn't achieve it.
review5: A protracted, scattershot comedy sketch that never quite nails its tone.

title: Cold in July
review1: A well-paced story that will keep audiences on the edge of their seats as it bucks and rolls in unexpected directions to a bloody and satisfying climax.
review2: A few too many twists and turns, but Johnson and Shepard help save it
review3: A heart-stoppingly tense, cunningly twisty crime thriller
review4: The 'That's for the hat' speech is a delicious bit of fun, but the film's final third is so derivative and keen to shock if feels like a different movie entirely.
review5: If you want to recreate the experience of watching a movie on HBO at 12:50 a.m. in 1991, Jim Mickle's "Cold in July" is your movie.

title: Hellion
review1: Despair is not quiet for a broken father (Aaron Paul) and his troublemaker sons in Kat Candler's brisk, transfixing drama, which takes place in blue-collar southeast Texas.
review2: "Hellion" pads its slender, commonplace, but potentially rewarding premise with contrivances, clichés, repetitiousness, and, when all else fails, implausible, arbitrary melodrama.
review3: Wiggins gives the boy's struggles a raw realism, but it's not enough to shore up this slackly paced slice of sunbaked Texas miserabilism.
review4: Not that inarticulate characters can't be compelling if they are written with subtlety, acted with insight and, most of all, framed by a directorial vision, but "Hellion," despite a promising debut from Wiggins, falls short in at least two of the above.
review5: The acting overall is strong, but Paul, still testing the waters after "Breaking Bad," is extraordinarily controlled.

title: Lucky Them
review1: Has any movie made during the past 10 years not presented female journalists as sluts?
review2: A clever, fun, and affecting romantic dramedy about love and rock-and-roll.
review3: This pleasant but eminently forgettable indie comedy is the sort of thing that makes you wonder whether the big names in the cast were having serious career problems, doing someone a favor, or just had a few weeks to kill.
review4: "Lucky Them" has that rare gift: It leaves its audiences warm and happy, as the best romantic comedies do.
review5: Collette, as amazing as she can be when given something to work with, can't lift this limp story through sheer will.

title: Third Person
review1: The question is if he realizes he more or less admitted to being a sociopath who remorselessly exploits the pain of those around him for the sake of drama.
review2: A pretentious wreck of a movie that severely tests the patience.
review3: Third Person has a number of distinct themes at work, manifested through characters and plots that are a mixed bag of believable and baffling.
review4: When we reach our finale you can't help but feel somewhat detached and uninvolved in this title.
review5: Third Person suffers from a script that fails to hook you in during its opening section and drags on without sufficient emotional connection for 137 minutes.

title: Decoding Annie Parker
review1: Decoding Annie Parker is a movie about resilience, about staring doom straight in the face - with a smile, with hope.
review2: This modest indie with major ambitions is directed by veteran cinematographer Steven Bernstein, making a solid feature debut.
review3: Tears are shed in "Decoding Annie Parker," but they aren't accompanied by the kind of sad, misty soundtrack music that can leave you feeling used and abused. Instead of jerking tears, the movie edifies.
review4: "Decoding Annie Parker," though uneven in its execution, has at its heart two remarkable women and one remarkable performance.
review5: It sticks mostly to one track, taking audience members on a journey that, sadly, via the movies or their own lives, they already may know a little too well.

title: Al Capone
review2: Rod Steiger gives his Method acting technique a workout as he captures the fiery persona of Al Capone and makes the gangster a lively larger-than-life subject.
review3: ... the most comprehensive film portrait of the notorious racketeer and mob boss who literally ruled Chicago for years.

title: 4 Minute Mile
review1: A by-the-numbers tale of inspiration through perspiration.
review2: 4 Minute Mile at least has the decency to acknowledge that it's aware of its underdog sports-movie clichés, especially the ones that made The Karate Kid such an '80s classic.
review3: Even if the story itself has been around the track a couple of times, veterans like these know how to bring it safely home.
review4: More than one interior scene looks underlit for effect,but that's at least something else to think about as the film goes through its paces.
review5: It's a moving, if occasionally heavy-handed, sports drama that deserves a wider audience than it is probably going to find in its limited release.

title: Advanced Style
review1: They reject the youth-culture diktat that age makes you invisible, and offer us all an example of self-acceptance.
review2: "Advanced Style" is appropriately fun, frivolous and baroquely ornamented by its subjects who sing, perform, model and occasionally sound like teenagers, while dressing a lot better.
review3: The way the women occupy Cohen and Plioplyte's spotlight is a lesson in aging well, a lesson that begins with the refusal to play by the rule that says to grow older, especially for women, is to fade into the shadows.
review4: These women are living life to the fullest - and they are inviting us to do the same.
review5: Inspired by Ari Seth Cohen's blog by the same name, "Advanced Style" is a love letter to older women who've elevated dressing to an art form.

title: Blackbird
review1: The clock starts to drag, and some energy is lost. But the movie displays a lot of promise both in front of and behind the lens.
review2: Credit to Buxton here for extracting conviction from such young actors. The performances aren't wholly redemptive, but they are compelling.
review3: This well-paced chase thriller stars Eric Bana and Olivia Wilde as sibling crooks on the run from a botched casino heist.
review4: This debut feature from Nova Scotia filmmaker Jason Buxton offers a series of subtle revelations that challenge expectation without a hint of soapbox grandstanding or raging primal screams.
review5: Though I appreciate Buxton's rookie attempt to present an alternative look at teen rage, I can't help seeing that this overreaching film goes nowhere with only clichés to guide it.

title: Englewood: The Growing Pains in Chicago
review1: To simply dismiss the film as derivative is to discount the distinctive perspective and personality of Cochran's work.

title: Billion Dollar Brain
review5: A clever, brisk, entertaining spy picture that has a lot more Ken Russell in it than you might suspect.

title: Topkapi
review1: The story never quite adds up, but with help from Ustinov and Robert Morley, Dassin conjures up a superior light entertainment.
review2: Ustinov has probably the meatiest part in the film and one that allows him to use many of the unsubtleties in dominating scenes he has at his command.
review3: It's a far cry from his classic American thrillers or his brilliant British noir, Night and the City.
review4: If you like heists and holidays, it's almost foolproof entertainment.
review5: Jules Dassin's popular heist comedy-adventure is an enjoyable film, boasting an international cast headed by wife Melina Mercouri and Oscar-winner Peter Ustinov.

title: Against the Wild
review1: Unexciting adventure film about lost kids has mild peril.

title: Jack and the Cuckoo-Clock Heart
review1: "Jack and the Cuckoo-Clock Heart" stubbornly remains less than the sum of its parts. But its rich visual imagery suggests the talented artists involved could create something exciting and truly original if they had a better script.
review2: Malzieu has created a fully-realized, wildly imaginative storybook world and populated it with eccentric characters.
review3: This is a special gem of a movie.
review4: Imaginative steampunk musical is too dark for little kids.
review5: Even while wearing its obvious, name-dropped influences on its sleeve, Jack and the Cuckoo-Clock Heart feels original in the sincerity of its magic.

title: Radio Free Albemuth
review1: Modestly budgeted but professional, this film has some imaginative visuals and a strong cast.
review2: Simon hews closely to his source. That decision is likely to endear him to Dick fans.
review3: A quaint labor of love blinkered by fidelity to an outdated text.
review4: It's easy to glean why this unapologetically niche film nearly died on the vine.
review5: The pic operates successfully as a study of enlightenment and a straight-ahead conspiracy thriller.

title: Million Dollar Arm
review1: The art of the deal gives way to matters of the heart, giving viewers a game changer both charming and uplifting.
review2: "Million Dollar Arm" is bland and overlong at 124 minutes. Simply put, there is nothing here of interest.
review3: Based on a true story, this is one of those relentlessly uplifting Disney movies that mixes comedy and emotion to inspire and move the audience.
review4: Craig Gillespie's by-numbers schmaltzathon never transcends its tourist's-eye views of India or patronisingly cliched views of its people.
review5: Jon Hamm turns on the charm and scores a home run.

title: School Dance
review1: It's woefully stereotypical and unfunny, even for the least discriminating viewers.
review2: It's not actually a film, but a 77-minute-long cry for help from a network talent show host and Disney personality who's desperately trying to shed his squeaky clean image.
review3: A 21st Century update of the beloved Shakespeare classic about a pair of star-crossed lovers from the opposite side of the tracks.
review4: Cannon is a big believer in the power of repetition. He apparently nurses a strong belief that if a gag isn't funny the first time around, it will somehow become hilarious the eighth or ninth time it's repeated.

title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow
review1: This is one of my favorite movies of the year so far.
review2: Edge of Tomorrow feels like it's about something more than action. Neat trick.
review3: It's easily the highlight of the summer movie offerings to me so far.
review4: Before too long, the plot begins to cut significant corners, things get terribly convenient and, by the end, the suspect plot logic utterly falls apart in favor of an idiotically beatific ending.
review5: To have a fun summer blockbuster with good characters, good action, and a tight and exciting script these days is almost unheard of. The smart sci-fi action movie is back. Let's hope it happens over and over again.

title: Sidewalk Stories
review1: Laughs, romance, and even something of an adventure flower in Lane's New York.

title: True Confessions
review1: Two exciting, dangerous actors have little to do: Duvall spends too much time pacing and waiting; De Niro's big scene has him hanging up his vestments.
review2: Given the powerhouse topline casting combo and provocative theme, True Confessions has to be chalked up as something of a disappointment.
review3: Numerous vital characters are dropped and the case-solving stripped of its complexity, with the resulting film over-linear and one-dimensional.
review4: True Confessions contains scenes that are just about as good as scenes can be. Then why does the movie leave us disoriented and disappointed, and why does the ending fail dismally?
review5: Quite simply it's one of the most entertaining, most intelligent and most thoroughly satisfying commercial American films in a very long time.

title: Level Five
review1: A poetic if occasionally opaque film essay on the 1945 Battle of Okinawa.
review2: "Level Five," a passionate and cerebral science-fiction adventure ... belongs equally to the past, the present and the future.
review3: A richly digressive, provocative meditation on the cross-currents of technology, engagement with history and wounded national identity ...
review4: By using Laura as an avatar, Marker actually helps us see the visuals and their knotty meanings much more clearly.
review5: An ode to selective memory and oblivion

title: Beneath The Harvest Sky
review1: The languid pace effectively communicates the characters' crushing boredom, yet the dramatic interest never flags.
review2: While the climax of Beneath the Harvest Sky is a jumble of crosscutting, thunderstorms, and an inconveniently collapsing house, the movie never loses the pulse of people and tragedies it knows too well.
review3: For all its missteps, the film feels authentic. Through thick and thin, it stubbornly maintains a thorny integrity.
review4: Directors Aron Gaudet and Gita Pullapilly are documentarians making their fiction debut, and they pack the movie with seemingly authentic, nitty-gritty details about life in the potato country of far northern Maine.
review5: Teenagers in a dead-end town aren't exactly a trailblazing topic.

title: Violette
review1: She [Emmanuelle Devos] gives a tremendous performance, somehow managing to turn an emotion as ugly as self-loathing into something beautiful to behold.
review2: "Violette" demonstrates how suffering produces great art, and that the artist isn't the only one who suffers for it.
review3: It's a perfect approach to Leduc, whose work is so grounded in the messy, fleshy realities of life, it scandalized critics with its frank treatment of taboo subjects such as lesbianism and incest.
review4: A literate, leisurely and lovely telling of one woman's attempt to find what Virginia Woolf famously called "a room of one's own."
review5: So compelling, even thrilling, in its frank depictions of female sexual voracity, professional egotism and twisted variants on the Electra complex that it's easy to overlook [its] shaggy, uneven plotting.

title: Los Angeles Plays Itself
review1: Andersen's inspired ruminations about his city as a filming location and as a repository for other filmmakers' daydreams and nightmares.
review2: One of the great films of the century to date, poignant and affecting.
review3: CalArts professor Thom Andersen poured a lifetime of moviegoing (and his own complex affection for the city he calls home) into this revelatory two-part documentary, a film that trains you to look at things askew.
review4: Using well-chosen clips from roughly 200 films, many of them obscure, Andersen makes a powerful and impassioned case for reassessing his beloved city.
review5: It's like being squired through town by a wisecracking cabbie with a PhD in semiotics.

title: Crossfire: The Plot That Killed Kennedy
Fort Bliss
review1: Fort Bliss is a small film, but it addresses big issues, in ways that are never simplistic or dogmatic.
review2: "Fort Bliss" joins "Coming Home" and "The Best Years of Our Lives" as a movie deeply in sync, not just with the military characters it depicts, but also with the civilian world that awaits them with such confoundingly mixed messages.
review3: [A] well-observed and endearing account of one woman grappling with allegiances to her fellow soldiers and her estranged 5-year-old son.
review4: Maggie's agonizing zero-sum struggle to balance a life of military service and a steady relationship with her son feels fresh, raw, and real.
review5: [Myers] is good at capturing the revealing, offhand moments in this story, but Maggie's conflicts about motherhood and the military needed a greater psychological scope than this film provides.

title: Persecuted
review1: Persecuted squanders the talents of its impressive cast -- including James Remar, Bruce Davison, Fred Dalton Thompson and Dean Stockwell -- with its bizarre premise and inept execution.
review2: A heavy-handed and didactic drama which also manages to be totally mushy in terms of the message it's trying to convey.
review3: Just why one particular TV preacher is so all-fired important isn't clear, and neither is anything else about this overwrought mess.
review4: Straw-man cinema doesn't get much more ludicrous than this heavy-handed, Christian-themed minister-on-the-run thriller.
review5: The Lord works in mysterious ways but "Persecuted" works in blundering, obvious ways, straining a Christianity-under-attack theme through a dopey thriller.

title: Casse-tête chinois (Chinese Puzzle)
review1: Viewers coming to this film without having seen the others would have no problem following the action; whether they'd care about it is another question.
review2: A hectic, convoluted French comedy about a Parisian novelist and the three women in his life.
review3: An amiably daffy look at perpetual adolescence, French-style.
review4: Once the story picks up, it's easy, breezy and enjoyable. It seduces you into thinking: Wouldn't it be fun to reconnect with Xavier in another five years or so?
review5: The film flits from one subplot to another and not in that delightfully freewheeling European kind of way.

title: Venus in Fur
review1: Like "Carnage," "The Pianist," "Rosemary's Baby" and more, Roman Polanski's latest is a creepy exploration of claustrophobia and perversity that should not be missed.
review2: "Venus in Fur" is a stellar achievement.
review3: Perhaps he is more drawn to Mr. Ives's quasi-feminist rationalization of sexual fetish than Sacher-Masoch's explanation of it as mastery over repressed feelings, and somehow sees parallels between the play and his own sexual felony.
review4: Polanski makes an intriguing battle of the sexes out of a filmed play
review5: Desire makes buffoons of us all. Now strike dear mistress, and cure his heart.

title: Nothing Bad Can Happen
review1: Gebbe elicits strong performances from her actors and succeeds in inspiring a certain sick fascination with the material, yet the film's oppressive unpleasantness yields no new insights into psychology or religious faith.
review2: Pitting good against evil with striking intelligence and a near-operatic commitment to extreme suffering, Ms. Gebbe neither mocks nor celebrates Tore's love for his God.
review3: Gebbe appears to be a misanthrope who subjects her male protagonist to senseless cruelty.
review4: Its world is so remote, its characters behavior so unexplained - despite the fact that the film is based on true events - that our connection to the story slackens significantly over time.
review5: A revenge flick where the hero refuses vengeance. We want that catharsis, but if Tore ever stopped turning the other cheek, he'd lose the only thing he has left: forgiveness

title: The Last Sentence
review1: Unfortunately, Troell chose to shoot the movie in digital black-and-white; the imagery seems anachronistic in its precision, undermining the period decor and clashing with the occasional low-grain newsreel footage of Nazis on the march.
review2: Troell invokes '50's and '60's Swedish cinema: masterly black-and-white cinematography, philosophical angst, a lifeless marriage and loved ones visiting from the afterlife.
review3: It's a thoughtful and workmanlike portrait, but a less than profoundly moving one.
review4: Amazingly, Troell still operates his own camera. "The Last Sentence" was made digitally, and his attention to detail is remarkable.
review5: The great 83-year-old Swedish director Jan Troell specializes in movies about men of great stature in furious conflict with both their countries and themselves.

title: Coming Up Roses
review1: There's nothing here to catch our eye, or our interest - just AfterSchool Special plot twists and family battles-and-bonding, spiced up with secrets and revelations that aren't nearly as unexpected, or revealing, as the filmmakers might hope.
review2: Director and co-screenwriter Lisa Albright uses Peters to lend some needed verve to a pretty standard, down-market milieu.
review3: This first feature from Ms. Albright does not augur a brilliant future.
review4: A modest drama most notable for its heartfelt performances.
review5: After a hoot of an entrance by Bernadette Peters showboating a tune from the rafters at a church wedding, Coming Up Roses takes a nosedive into despair and stays there.

title: Autumn Blood
review1: An enigmatic, visually stunning, but uneven parable about the rape and attempted murder of a young girl in a tiny Alpine community.
review2: Novice filmmaker Markus Blunder just lets the violence snowball all the way down a slippery slope.
review3: A one note and tedious thriller with a misogynist undertone that couldn't salvage an attempted dramatic "poetic justice" finale.
review4: But ultimately, Autumn Blood, which proceeds at a pace that could be equally described as measured or glacial...feels less like a fully realized film than a half-imagined idea for one.
review5: Striking scenery, novel storytelling style, wasted on a poorly executed and pervy exploitation thriller

title: Siddharth
review1: Simple but engrossing, Canadian director Richie Mehta's Siddharth is the story of an Indian father searching for his missing son, and offers a window into the lives of India's working poor that goes beyond the familiar issues of food and shelter.
review2: Tension builds along with hopelessness but Mehta avoids making judgments or giving easy answers about the circumstances that led to Siddharth being sent off to work.
review3: Though at times "Siddharth" can resemble a well-photographed report on India's social and economic ills, Mehta subtly employs different styles to sustain the poetry, poignancy, and drama.
review4: "Siddharth" provides something more valuable than a tidy resolution: a glimpse of the complicated nature of life a world away.
review5: Like Vittorio De Sica's "The Bicycle Thief," the film uses downbeat themes to make a point about this particular society and life in general.

title: Canopy
review1: A brave experiment in stripped-down, visceral filmmaking, writer-director Aaron Wilson's World War II drama "Canopy" is ultimately upended by its minimalist conceit.
review2: While not much is said in the Australian director Aaron Wilson's small-scale first feature, "Canopy," the film conveys volumes about war and humanity.
review3: This is a film that eschews epic battle scenes and carnage to delve into the quieter, no less terrifying, moments of waiting and watching.
review4: To the suddenly white-hot adventure subgenre of one or two souls alone against nature... add the more modestly scaled but no less absorbing wartime survival adventure "Canopy."
review5: Much like his fly-boyflyboy underdog in the opening sequence, Wilson simply can't stick the landing.

title: Gabrielle
review1: Writer-director Louise Archambault uses a free and easy camera style and mosaic-like editing to suggest how intensely Gabrielle responds to elements of everyday life.
review2: Casting Marion-Rivard in the title role was a risk that paid off, giving the film its authenticity, also its imperfections, which are easy enough to live with.
review3: If "Gabrielle" is a likable crowd-pleaser, it would be much better without the extra dollop of organic honey.
review4: Frequently charming.
review5: Archambault has a rare light in Marion-Rivard, whose wide smile is infectious: When she sulks, it feels like the whole world is tumbling down.

title: King's Faith
review1: Don't let this film's faith-based themes keep you from going to see the movie. Even if you ignore the message, the movie stands up simply as a good family-based drama.
review2: Carefully crafted with Evangelicals in mind, this modern parable will certainly resonate with the faith-based demographic as well as secular individuals interested in an entertaining, wholesome family flick with a sobering message.

title: Plynace wiezowce (Floating Skyscrapers)
review1: There's a startlingly honest tone to this difficult Polish drama, which confronts issues of sexuality and machismo in complex ways.
review2: I found it hard to care. Still, the bit where the title gets explained is sweet.
review3: Builds a compelling narrative on the back of its understated performances, sexual realism and austerely beautiful cinematography.
review4: Stylishly shot, and reflecting Polish society's conservatism, this is a coming-out tale riddled with pain and anguish.
review5: A punchy, well-acted and devastating coming-out drama.

title: A Coffee in Berlin
review1: In spite of its insufferably whimsical tendencies - exemplified by its original title, "Oh Boy" - the film may have turned out to be a deeply profound modern postscript about fascism.
review2: Niko's problem is not just that he's spoiled and lazy, but that he's a wimp about it. He only maintains viewer sympathy because everyone else in the film is so obnoxious.
review3: It manages to make an entertaining story out of nothing in particular. And just when you get comfortable passively observing a passive observer, the minutest of twists becomes its own call to action.
review4: The cheerful Dixieland soundtrack implies "A Coffee in Berlin" is a comedy, but the story line smears the screen with melancholy.
review5: As sure of itself visually in its black-and-white evocations of Berlin as its protagonist is unsure of himself and his future.

title: A Letter to Momo
review1: A sweet, heartfelt, yet never maudlin story about an 11-year-old girl's coming to terms with the loss of her father.
review2: It's difficult to imagine any children's movie retaining the attention of its intended audience for two hours, but this movie feels especially monotonous.
review3: Despite the hand-drawn film's supernatural edge, one of Okiura's lyrical strengths is acquainting a viewer with the poetry of the real - animated reflections of ordinary, beautiful things we see in everyday life without actually noticing them at all.
review4: A sweet tale of a sad girl who moves to a new place and meets supernatural pals.
review5: A striking example of Japanese hand-drawn animation, it casually combines things you wouldn't expect in one place.

title: For A Woman
review1: There's storytelling vigor here and fine performances, plus some pointed exchanges about the burdens of cultural identity and emotional preservation in the aftermath of immense upheaval.
review2: A framing device isn't needed, but the film is compelling overall.
review3: An inviting sense of mystery hangs over the events of 1947, Ms. Kurys's origin story. There are some things, she seems to say, that we never fully understand, including the people we are closest to.
review4: The striking Thierry brings her character to nuanced life on screen, torn between loyalty to the man who saved her and passion for his Nazi-hunting brother.
review5: This is engrossing stuff, not only in the remarkable details of the parents' lives, but in the psychological nuance with which Kurys imagines them.

title: Dormant Beauty
review1: It's well acted and gorgeously and tenebrously shot.
review2: The film pits their honest passion against the stylized desperation of the actress' religious theater and the decadent hollowness of Berlusconi's political theater.
review3: If "Dormant Beauty" does not rank among Mr. Bellocchio's best movies, it nonetheless still occasionally shows him at his best.
review4: Unlike most movies that rely on TV-news reports to drive the story, Dormant Beauty is complex and humane, and never shrinks to mere spectacle.
review5: Though the movie eschews facile sloganeering, few of its characters or narrative threads are able to develop beyond their function as metaphors.

title: LFO: The Movie
review1: LFO is ambitious and bizarre enough to work on levels that some might not hear ringing clearly, yet its presence cannot be ignored.
review2: Tublén's wryly banalised, tone-perfect scenario builds with disorienting humour to a bleak, thought-provoking close that suggests it is ultimately impossible to escape one's own darkest interiors.
review3: Tublen's last-act feels like a purposefully cheap gag, but LFO is nevertheless a consistently humorous lo-fi sci-fi story.

title: The Forgotten Kingdom
review1: The message here is one that any city-dwelling migrant can relate to.
review2: Adults might find this overly sentimental... though it's ideal viewing for kids -- informative, visually impressive, and generous in its worldview.
review3: Director Andrew Mudge's expansive film combines death, romance, poverty, mysticism, philosophy and friendship while holding steadfast to its realism; it sticks with you.
review4: The resolution proves heartfelt and touching, and if the script sometimes waxes too mystical for its own good, the film's ultimately so genuine it's hard to resist.
review5: Were it not for the novel USP of its setting, The Forgotten Kingdom would be classifiable as entirely unoriginal.

title: Beethoven's Treasure Tail
review1: Silly adventure full of pratfalls, comic action.

title: Behaving Badly
review1: This ruthlessly unfunny misfire should be quickly relegated to an IMDb trivia question after a brief theatrical bow.
review2: Aside from a few lines of juicy bad language, Gomez plays the innocent in this fast-paced screwball farce, which is full of cheerful vulgarity but dangerously low on wit, charm or narrative logic.
review3: Behaving Badly is a contender for the worst film of the year...
review4: Raunchy high school comedy is a big disappointment.
review5: For a comedy that so desperately wants to be rude and sexy, this movie is remarkably timid. It does a great job putting up a front as an anarchic laugh riot, but the genuinely funny moments are few and far between.

title: Life Of Crime
review1: Schechter's staging is so flat that Leonard's dialogue never pops. You hear the words but not the music.
review2: Perhaps Schechter should have started with a prequel to Death Proof and worked his way up from there.
review3: An abiding insignificance looms over the film, but it's a fun 98 minutes.
review4: Though a decidedly down-market adaptation of the great Elmore Leonard crime novel Switch, Life of Crime is never down-and-out.
review5: It's good, solid Leonard, which, for me at least, is a cosy, comfortable, and extremely fun place to be for ninety-eight minutes.

title: Good People
review1: A fairly standard white-people-in-peril thriller.
review2: Good People provides the degree of entertainment one expects while sitting on a sofa watching a direct-to-video effort rather than the higher standards one sets for paying $10 for a movie ticket.
review3: "Good People" goes from being simply pedestrian to outright preposterous without batting an eye.
review4: James Franco and Kate Hudson are uncharacteristically muted in this watchable but wholly unsurprising London crime caper.
review5: Good People grinds to its predictable, pat conclusion and betrays its generally solid performances and respectable artistic pedigree. Sometimes good people do bad things, sometimes they just make movies that start well and end badly.

title: Jamie Marks Is Dead
review1: "Jamie Marks Is Dead" admirably refuses to hew to conventional horror tropes and is acted with integrity by its young performers, but the film nonetheless has a nagging pulse problem.
review2: Temperate in tone but screaming with subtext, "Jamie Marks Is Dead" climbs above the current glut of supernaturally inclined entertainment by dint of a hushed unease that permeates almost every frame.
review3: The film uses its phantasmagoric conceit, a sickly-hued poetry, and eerie sound design to build metaphors for closeted homoeroticism and melancholic unfulfillment.
review4: Writer-director Carter Smith got his start as a successful fashion photographer. But you wouldn't know it from the murky look of this generic thriller.
review5: The potentially ludicrous story is handled artfully enough here to cast an eerie but not off-putting spell throughout, though the ultimate point is more than a tad murky, and the desired poignancy doesn't fully come across.

title: The Prince
review1: If filmmakers were put on trial for hackery, a good prosecutor might ask director Miller why The Prince contains no discernible prince but does feature a closing-credit shout-out to "Prince Yoohanhwesa."
review2: Unless you're a fan of yawn-worthy shootouts and showdowns, "The Prince" is a "Taken" retread hardly indicative of any special set of skills.
review3: An idle Netflix user could certainly do far worse when browsing for mindless actioners. But the overall air of shrugging obligation from those both in front of and behind the camera proves contagious.
review4: 'Taken' without any of the charisma or energy.
review5: Originality, either in terms of writing or direction, in in short supply in this assembly-line vigilante thriller.

title: Moebius
review1: [Moebius] would be easy to dismiss if Kim weren't so sincere and sober in pursuit of his Oedipal and other emotional concerns.
review2: It's one from the heart, and a twisted tale it is.
review3: Such is Kim's plotty momentum that the whole thing feels like an extreme joke made of pained silences, one that somehow strips bare the subtext of overbearing parents.
review4: When it comes down to it, this a movie where the only major female characters are intentionally interchangeable and exist only to castrate men.
review5: Moebius is almost weird enough to be a creation myth, and that's no small accomplishment.

title: Child Of God
review1: Beautifully shot, well acted, and the score is lovely, but the film has nothing to say about the human degradation in which it wallows. If you're gonna make me smell dung for two hours, at least fertilize my lawn.
review2: There's no denying Franco's ambition, and in "Child of God" you can see evidence (almost for the first time) that he's reaching for something he may one day attain.
review3: "Child of God" fascinates like a song sung just out of tune but rhythmically sturdy enough to keep you listening in the hopes it'll right itself.
review4: Surprisingly pretty good.
review5: This wrong-headed adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's taut 1973 novel, as interpreted by director James Franco, spends too much time trying to create an element of compassion for this devilishly aberrant killer.

title: Begin Again
review1: The trouble with this movie -- aside from its lack of visual wonder and musical shape -- is that you don't trust its priorities.
review2: Begin Again is a delight, not only because of its infectious musical vitality but because it follows the unexpected forks in the road.
review3: It's not nearly as good as "Once" but still very charming and entertaining.
review4: Gretta's own songs aren't the type to grab you by the throat, but performed with soulful sweetness by Knightley they slowly sink their hooks into you, just like the film itself.
review5: This movie is inspired by the success of the film 'Once', written and directed by John Carney. Carney's new movie has a similar story, but this time, with more money, better music and actors, he's made a better film.

title: Wish I Was Here
review1: Braff directs a Soggy sitcom of a movie
review2: Braff clearly wants us to find his hapless hero's travails funny and affecting. Instead, they come across as self-indulgent navel-gazing.
review3: Zach Braff's second effort is a tricky one to value.
review4: Since the adorable, simple Garden State, Braff's ambitions as a filmmaker have grown. He's reaching for answers to really big questions, but they are, just slightly, beyond his grasp.
review5: As Aidan, Graff combines depth of insight with an endearing naivety, and the rest of the cast could hardly be better.

title: Grace
review1: ...a generic, thoroughly run-of-the-mill horror effort that wears out its welcome almost immediately.

title: About Alex
review1: Neither the script's up-to-the-minute signifiers nor its cheekily self-aware humor can entirely dispel a formulaic feel.
review2: The intelligence and unhackneyed humor of the believable, unself-conscious screenplay by fledgling director Mr. Zwick (son of veteran director Edward Zwick) deserves special praise. It never hits a false note.
review3: The chronicle of a less self-absorbed generation, it's less annoying than The Big Chill but also less funny.
review4: Only Plaza's performance as the troubled Sarah comes close to creating a three-dimensional character.
review5: The insight that social media fosters false intimacy is old news. The film shows only a half-formed sense of how careers have changed in 30 years.

title: Exhibition
review1: Hogg maintains a probing detachment and a cold intimacy. As befits the title, she presents her subjects like specimens in an exhibit, with a rigorously structured style that is non-judgmental and unsparing.
review2: If "Exhibition" lacks conventionally developed characters and dialogue, it is visually enthralling.
review3: A film that's all airy, abstract pretentiousness.
review4: The whole thing teeters between very boring and completely fascinating.
review5: Beautifully shot with an acute eye for crisp composition, this intimate mood piece explores the subtle intricacies and low-level power struggles of long-term love in forensic detail.

title: The One I Love
review1: Ethan and Sophie are never more than playthings of the premise; Moss and Duplass are the sole sources of nuance and vitality, and they seem unduly hemmed in by the movie's unimaginative confines.
review2: Like figures in a funhouse that is both philosophical and phantasmagoric, the characters in "The One I Love" spook you, both inside your head and inside your heart.
review3: "The One I Love" is a weird but gutsy exploration of what happens when we alternately idealize and find fault with our romantic partners.
review4: at #4 on the top10 Indie films in the iTunes store.
review5: It's gently funny, it's compelling, the performances are excellent, and it flies in the face of conventional romantic films, always carving its own path. Satisfying, charming and recommended.

title: A Five Star Life
review1: Flatly told and highly familiar.
review2: Its refreshing conclusion is more suited to ambiguous European sensibilities than the all-American desire for happy endings or at least concrete resolutions ...
review3: There is a warm naturalness to the dialogue, and Buy is wonderfully evocative.
review4: A frothy romantic comedy tinged with melancholy and yearning.
review5: One of those rambling European films with little plot but lots of atmosphere ...

title: An Evergreen Christmas
review1: Well-meaning but generic holiday story with mature themes.

title: A Most Wanted Man
review1: Hoffman's an actor who could do just about anything, but being authentically German is not one of them.
review2: One of the countless sad things about losing Hoffman is the realization that we'll never get to watch him single-handedly elevate an otherwise OK movie again.
review3: Cobijn doesn't totally conquer le Carré's complicated plot
review4: Kudos to Hoffman in this good-enough le Carré spy tale
review5: The end result may look good but it never feels distinctive despite the wealth of talent involved in front of and behind the camera.

title: The Christmas Candle
review1: Melds the intriguing with the hokey in a variation on the standard template of a nonbeliever who changes his outlook amid a holiday miracle.
review2: Relates the weak-tea parable of a town that receives a wish-giving candle every 25 years from an angel.
review3: This holiday movie about a man of God who regains his faith thanks to a miraculous candle is as picturesque as a snow globe and just about as full of human life.
review4: This odd Dickens-meets-Sunday-school movie is as artless as the setup is muddled.
review5: "The Christmas Candle," based on a book by Texas minister Max Lucado, might be the ideal movie for Christians in search of family-friendly entertainment, but its appeal won't stretch beyond that demographic.

title: Step Up: All In
review1: "All In" is a lesser effort in this franchise, but not without its charms.
review2: Reuniting, or really, introducing, the gang is a gimmick. It's also self-destructive-cramming in all these characters chokes up the plot, and who watches a Step Up for the plot?
review3: It's the rare movie that knows its limitations, but also understands how to use form to best convey its strengths ...
review4: When the cast isn't dexterously spinning, "All In" turns into a promotional video for Caesars Palace.
review5: The dancing is the star of any of these movies, and Sie knows when to get out of the way and let it do the heavy lifting.

title: Frontera
review1: In trying to create a balanced portrait of the conflicts and the ordinary people affected by them, director Michael Berry... chips away at the authenticity and intensity that an issue-driven film like this sorely needs.
review2: It captures the desperation of illegal immigrants and the confused rancor that often greets them on the American side of the border.
review3: The actors are compelling, and the issue is, of course, always worth discussion. It's not a great movie, but, if nothing else, Frontera is worthwhile on those fronts.
review4: "Frontera" is a well-cast, well-made, well-acted drama that you will probably forget about soon after you've seen it.
review5: You wish that a filmmaker like John Sayles had grabbed the story by the throat and teased out its complexities.

title: The Dog
review1: Questions of identity reverberate through The Dog, a documentary by Allison Berg and Frank Keraudren that chronicles Wojtowicz's storied and terribly sad life.
review2: There's a brashness to this documentary that sneaks up on you.
review3: Sidney Lumet's Oscar-winning Dog Day Afternoon was based on a true story - and John Wojtowicz doesn't even try to hide his glee in sharing every juicy, crazed detail in revealing documentary, The Dog.
review4: The result does justice to their subject's foul-mouthed charm and braggadocio.
review5: In numerous interviews that careen from profane braggadocio to tender reminiscence, the lustily bisexual Wojtowicz comes across as almost bizarrely self-satisfied.

title: Nowhere Safe
review1: Teen cyberbullying tale has solid message, predictable story.

title: War Story
review1: For much of the early going it's the burdened physicality that Keener brings to the role that tells us everything we need to know.
review2: Jackson's spare, quietly powerful sophomore feature demonstrates an impressive control of mood and tone and the ability to tell a story largely without words.
review3: There's minimalist filmmaking that's quietly intriguing, and then there's emotional detachment that's stultifying to the point of being nap-inducing. War Story falls into the latter category.
review4: In Keener's hands, the collapse feels urgent but not unhinged, and Lee's trajectory from steely and determined to openly distraught lends an otherwise meandering film a strong core.
review5: Catherine Keener rarely gets the chance to grab the spotlight all for herself. That makes this turgid drama especially disappointing.

title: A Long Way Off
review1: Faith-based family drama uses excess to teach lessons.

title: Summer of Blood
review1: It's all mellowly funny rather than creepy, something like a stand-up conceit elaborated into scenes. But who would want to be stuck with this running monologue for eternity?
review2: Any 30 minutes of Summer of Blood might have me in hysterics. But the sputtering torrent of Eric's yakking proves wearying over 90: Dude's built for speed-dating.
review3: The vestigial desolation of urban waste spaces is nearly a character in the antic action; when the story's gears grind, Tukel gives it a metaphysical kick that lends its final arc an eerie spin.
review4: The story's resolution suggests that the curse of trivial self-absorption is harder to shake off than any ancient bloodlust.
review5: Director-writer-star-Turkish Zach Galifianakis, Onur Tukel, pays tribute to the horror movie trope while completely upending it with the hipster sensibility so commonly associated with the borough.

title: El Desierto (The Desert)
review1: an intense Sartrean character drama, rather than just another low-budget zombie flick.
review2: stand[s] out as a welcome oasis amidst the arid uniformity of so many other zombie films. The apocalypse may be equally bleak wherever you go, but it is at least a whole lot more original, intense and internalised in the Argentine wastelands.

title: I Am Santa Claus
review1: Docu about holiday helpers has mature themes, profanity.
review2: [I Am Snata Claus] does a great job at pulling down the beard and showing the true faces of the man everyone thinks they know.

title: Mr. Pip
review1: It's a weak-tea imitation at best.
review2: Mr. Pip doesn't start going seriously awry until its second half, when things get more eventful in ways that are compacted from the novel yet seem more disconnected.
review3: Adamson mixes magical realism with hard-hitting historical drama in a way that feels both contrived and questionable, even if the filmmakers clearly have their hearts in the right place.
review4: Know what you're in for, because what you're in for is difficult.
review5: ... has difficulty finding cohesion among its divergent elements.

title: La casa del fin de los tiempos (The House of the End Times)
review1: It may look like a standard haunted house movie on the surface, but this is really a finely crafted supernatural thriller of a very different -- and startlingly complex -- kind.
review2: The great intricacy of its paradoxical plotting only really becomes apparent in retrospect, and will have you mentally revisiting its rooms and corridors for some time afterwards... replays in the head much better than it plays on the screen.

title: Happy Christmas
review1: Swanberg's naturalistic, improvised style lets the conflict come about organically, repeatedly putting the characters in situations to which they could react with clichés but instead go with something more empathetic and nuanced.
review2: This semi-improvised indie accomplishes its modest goal, which is to explore the way a vexing relationship between in-laws can yield unexpected personal growth and warm bonds of affection.
review3: I suppose it's because his father in this movie is played by his father, but I've never seen a better performance -- or whatever you want to call it -- from a two-year-old.
review4: The script doesn't just leave things unsaid but unnoticed, and the film's conclusion isn't much more than a half-hearted well, yeah, whatever.
review5: A slightly above average example of a kind of movie - and of a trend within movies - that needs to be encouraged.

title: Abuse of Weakness
review1: "Abuse of Weakness" is 20 minutes of a great movie and another 85 minutes of nothing much.
review2: With clinical dispassion and narrative elegance, Breillat has constructed what she calls "a thriller about denial."
review3: The film's title refers to the French legal term for taking advantage of a person of diminished capacity. The story, though, suggests other interpretations.
review4: As a portrait of what it's like to be suddenly helpless, Abuse Of Weakness is never less than fascinating ...
review5: [A] chilly, dark portrait of two control freaks locking horns.

title: I am Yours
review1: How to be a mother, a lover and an aspiring actress all at once?
review2: I Am Yours is a pensive, perceptive study of a woman adrift whose expectations of a relationship are never quite matched.
review3: Actress Iram Haq makes a solid directorial debut with this tale of clashing cultures.
review4: Acharia's electric performance is impressive, while director Iram Haq brings an insider's sympathy to the protagonist's plight.
review5: Haq has the storytelling style of a lawyer calmly presenting the facts of a case leaving it to the audience to decide whether to focus judgment on Mina or unsympathetic circumstances.

title: White Lightning
review4: Shot through with radiant natural light and Reynolds's scalawag grin
review5: The film has plenty of rip-roaring car chases (Hal Needham was the stunt coordinator), but it also has genuine emotion, in the pain and anger the hero feels over the loss of his brother and in the incidental reactions and attitudes of almost every support

title: Too Late Blues
review1: It's pretentious, lugubrious, mawkish, and full of both naivete and macho bluster. It also has moments that are indelible and heartbreaking.
review2: One of the more impressive Hollywood movies to be set in the hip, flip jazz world.
review3: John Cassavetes' first Hollywood-made project shows a tendency to force casebook psychology on the characters at a loss of spontaneity.
review4: An uncompromising movie, for good and for ill.
review5: One of the better and more honest jazz films ever made in Hollywood.

title: Jiu huo ying xiong (As the Light Goes Out)
review1: As the Light Goes Out shows promise early on, but replaces any potential with cliché story points, flat characters, and utter predictability. The film is unfortunately a disappointing disaster film effort despite its talented cast.

title: Coldwater
review1: The film transcends its B-movie template with realistic performances and taut direction, yet never spares the thrills.
review2: The best thing about it is its star, P.J. Boudousqué, who locates a sense of terror and betrayal that the script lacks.
review3: A punishing, predictable drama that's almost rescued by strong acting and good intentions.
review4: There's a compelling, perhaps important thriller to be made about dark doings at for-profit juvenile detention camps, but "Coldwater" misses the mark.
review5: Grashaw effectively charts the unhealthy power dynamics, though he seems still to be finding his way at conceiving characters, directing actors, and establishing tone.

title: All Things To All Men
review1: The spiralling plot becomes increasingly academic while it seems to think it's being terribly clever.
review2: Watching producer-turned-director George Isaac's debut you can't help feeling that somewhere, lying lost on a cutting room floor, there might be a better movie.
review3: Despite Sewell's laconic ruthlessness, Stephens's steely taciturnity and Byrne's world-weary arrogance, there's an all-round lack of conviction.
review4: The latest attempt to make a British Michael Mann-style crime epic based on a fundamental misunderstanding of what Michael Mann actually does as a filmmaker.
review5: Sadly, there has been such a glut of gun-packed London crime thrillers, that it simply isn't enough to make one that looks good and has a fierce energy: you need a solidly structured plot that goes somewhere unexpected.

title: If I Stay
review1: The title refers to Mia's fraught decision-should she cling to existence or just give up?-and, well before the end, even loyal viewers will be begging her to hurry up and choose.
review2: Documentarian R.J. Cutler, in his feature debut, joins Moretz in delivering this pap as if it meant something. Cue eye rolling.
review3: For a drama pretty much aimed at 12-year-old girls, this is less superficial than you'd expect.
review4: A true middle-of-the-road effort, provoking neither scorn nor admiration
review5: If I Stay never explains whether Mia's is a special case or if everyone who hovers between life and death has that decision to make. And if it's the latter, does that mean your gramps and meemaw simply didn't love you enough to stick around?

title: My Last Day Without You
review1: It's not often a competent if forgettable movie can be completely torpedoed by one of it's stars, but that's the case with "My Last Day Without You."
review2: My Last Day Without You has the true kind of special effects that many Hollywood films lack these days: warmth, depth and a soul.

title: In Bloom
review1: Directors Nana Ekvtimshvili and Simon Gross adopt the long, contemplative takes of the new wave; much of the film feels familiar, but the location shooting and period details are nicely drawn, a result of Ekvtimshvili's autobiographical script.
review2: The viewer becomes keenly aware that she is only getting part of the story. But when the truth is so troubling, sometimes part of the story is more than enough.
review3: As arthouse coming-of-age films go, this is brilliant -- smart and sensitive with a screw-you feminist streak.
review4: Despite the seeming inevitability of tragedy and despair, "In Bloom" remains true to its title.
review5: The world painted by directors Nana Ekvtimishvili and Simon GroB is almost relentlessly grim, and even the giggles of two schoolgirls get drowned.

title: And So It Goes
review1: Everything about the movie is as uninspired as the title.
review2: [A] depressingly monotonous Rob Reiner-directed comedy starring Michael Douglas and Diane Keaton.
review3: And So It Goes may touch the frayed heartstrings of some older viewers, but it's pretty bad - the failed attempt to Heimlich a venerable movie genre.
review4: ... has some modest charm but overall remains mired in obvious plotting and cheap sentimentality.
review5: Everything seems to work out so perfectly here that the film is less about life's rich rewards and more about light-hearted convenience.

title: A Summer's Tale
review1: A Summer's Tale is one of those movies where it looks like nothing is happening ...
review2: Few directors could say as much with as little as Eric Rohmer.
review3: There's a purity to the experience of watching a film so naturalistic, like living in someone else's life for two hours.
review4: The best films leave space for viewers to interpret the action. Here Rohmer insists on it.
review5: This is a movie of high innocence, set at a time in life when romantic love is still a frolic and the seaside is a balm that quells all ills.

title: Boy Meets Girl (1984)
review1: The director's slight uncertainty creates a fascinating tension that works in Boy Meets Girl's favor. You empathize with the characters' struggles even as they are both kept at a critical distance.
review2: A debut feature of extraordinary passion and vigor.
review3: Ecstatic cinema and ecstatic living join together in a pressurized promise of glory and misery, a flameout waiting to happen-and to be filmed.

title: The Skinny
review1: The large ensemble deliver mainly endearing performances and the tech elements are solid despite the obvious budget.
review2: Is it a good movie? Not really.

title: Rhymes For Young Ghouls
review1: As a history lesson about Canada's unjust treatment of Native Americans, it's often eye-opening, but as storytelling it's clunky and highly familiar, and the period re-creation is seldom convincing.
review2: Writer-director Barnaby weaves a surprising amount of tenderness into the fabric of violence, as well as a good measure of magic realism, to keep the gritty story engaging.
review3: Barnaby puts a mythic frame around a grim history, shaping it in a way that feels always like a creative adventure, not a duty.
review4: With a tone alternating between mournful, defiant and hopeful, Rhymes for Young Ghouls is a rewarding experience by a talented director who's sure to make his mark on Canadian cinema.
review5: The film is told with a mix of lyricism and kicks to the gut, and is all the better for these shifts in tonality. It's remarkable how the narrative feels both highly specific to this community, yet near mythic in a more universal, classic sense.

title: Beyond the Edge
review1: It's all rendered in 3D, with the archival footage reformatted; you'll feel the Everest chill and gape at the astonishing vistas.
review2: Recalled in the somewhat breathless History Channel-style voice-overs of the participants and their families, the journey was a triumph of guts, perseverance, endurance, ingenuity and teamwork.
review3: This absorbing account of the first recorded summit of the world's highest mountain is a rare documentary for which re-enactments make complete sense.
review4: Though impressively shot, the doc is a weak advertisement for 3-D.
review5: Like a mountaineer grappling on sheet ice, the film's focus on performance can result in a loss of footing.

title: The Aviation Cocktail
review1: There are rich veins to mine here had writer-director David R. Higgins bothered: vigilantism, guilt, substance abuse, infidelity, spousal abuse, post-traumatic stress disorder, small-town dread, postwar America.

title: Ni guang fei xiang (Touch of the Light)
Lines of Wellington
review1: A film to admire, with moments here and there to fully embrace
review2: It's an odd experience, a Ruiz film (if it deserves to be called that) devoid of dreamy mystery, reduced to a mere handsome historical epic, albeit capably mounted by Portuguese producer extraordinaire Paulo Branco.

title: The Long Goodbye
review1: It tries to be all genre and no story, and it almost works.
review2: [Altman] attempts the impossible and pulls it off.
review3: ... one of those movies that always flits through my mind when someone asks me to name my favorite movies of all time. I usually don't mention it, but it's always there, on the periphery. It's at least one of my two or three favorite Altmans.
review4: The Long Goodbye as a whole peels back the surfaces of private-eye stories, paying special attention to their macho bluster and abused women.
review5: A playful de-romanticizing of the detective genre...

title: Mockingbird
review1: Mockingbird plays like an over-bloated V/H/S anthology segment that wastes a jolting start on generic, recycled "found footage" tropes seen a billion times before.

title: The Giver
review1: Another adaptation of a popular young adult novel
review2: A seriously flawed adaptation of a wonderful book that tries to focus too heavily on elements best left to more recent post-apocalyptic adventures instead of the bittersweet agony of Lois Lowry's original story.
review3: Wrapped in an exciting movie with beautiful special effects, 'The Giver' makes the case for the beauty of grown-up freedom.
review4: Due to its relentless action-film momentum, much of the book's central themes of humanity and love conquering all are entirely lost.
review5: Brenton Thwaites' maverick teenager rebels but this bland sci-fi adventure conforms to type.

title: The Last Fall
review1: This is an involving, sympathetic film unafraid to wear its sizable heart on its sleeve.
review3: The Last Fall is an honest, heartfelt and authentic film that is filled with a good script, good production values, and fantastic performances.
review4: Lance Gross displays a heretofore unseen depth and piercing subtlety to match his natural charisma.

title: Ddongpari (Breathless)
review1: Although his first film is only a partial success, Yang Ik-june is a filmmaker worth watching for.
review2: Breathless pummels viewers with nearly the same ferocity and frequency with which the characters assault each other.
review3: Amid the violent outbursts are moments of warmth and tenderness, some featuring the protagonist's young nephew, the best hope for breaking the generational cycles of domestic tragedy.
review4: Blending a thoughtful cycle-of-violence subplot with a piercing study of how even the most hateful and isolated people inevitably affect those around them, 'Breathless' is a challenging, dynamic experience.
review5: We will give Yang, the film's writer, director, and star, the benefit of the doubt by assuming his chronicle of relentless cruelty is not autobiographical.

title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes
review1: Way better than it has any right to be.
review2: Matt Reeves, the director of another end of the world type scenario in found footage film Cloverfield, takes the reins of this smart and attractive franchise and runs confidently with visceral wanton destruction and a blunt message about gun control.
review3: This is a confident sequel from Reeves and company; gripping, moving and recommended.
review4: [Dawn of the Planet of the Apes] is a text book example of how to stay true to the basic genetic code of a movie while also letting it evolve into a different, altogether more sophisticated beast.
review5: Dawn of the Planet of the Apes works precisely because it believes in itself and will brook no arguments.

title: The Hundred-Foot Journey
review1: If the movie is high on gastronomy, it also redefines cooking with gas.
review2: ... a film for our culture: a feel-foodie drama of racial tolerance, cross-cultural acceptance, and fusion cuisine.
review3: ... dishes out a mostly flavorful blend of comedy and drama, with a dash of poignancy, which helps to overcome its blander ingredients.
review4: Doesn't show enough vitality, in spite of a good cast
review5: Familiar yet diverting

title: Les Apaches
review2: Considering its novice cast, sophomore director and miniscule budget, "Les Apaches" is a solid thriller that presents a gritty look at a place where few would bother to examine - except here.
review3: De Peretti favors observation over plot-driven dialogue and packs a punch in a scant 82 minutes.
review4: A sad drama set in Corsica about class warfare, youth, and greed.
review5: Peretti's violence resonates. Mostly kept offscreen, it echoes ominously in the animalistic tendencies of the teens ... or in something as surprising as the bump and swoosh of a carwash.

title: Field of Lost Shoes
review1: An impressively rendered if decidedly old-fashioned retelling of the American Civil War's one-day Battle of New Market.
review2: Save for a brief prologue, there isn't a pro-slavery Southern man to be found in this fantasyland vision of the Civil War ...
review3: Fierce, violent Civil War tale takes liberties with history.
review4: it is a real pleasure to see a new film in which the heroes wear Civil War uniforms and not superhero spandex
review5: Not awful, but never lets us forget that it's hard to do The Civil War on an indie film budget

title: Witness to Murder
review2: The story is strong and well told, building tension in the final act, delivering a satisfying payoff
review3: This threadbare little thriller looks like it was written and shot over a weekend.
review4: The camerawork of John Alton is the star of this vehicle.

title: Down And Dangerous
review1: The implausibilities rack up faster than the body count.
review2: 85 minutes' worth of cheap thrills. In a 95-minute picture, that ain't bad.
review3: There's a weirdly dirty charm to this curio, which has more going for it than not.
review4: Miraculously Kickstarter-subsidized for $38,000, it's illogical, incoherent and tedious.

title: "Norte, the End of History"
review1: Powerful and humbling, this 2013 drama is worth every minute you're willing to give it.
review2: A political and spiritual parable, but related with such subtle realism and incantatory rhythms that it is far more mysterious than didactic.
review3: If the movie's universal themes don't impress, its specific details do.
review4: More than four hours long, filmed in expansive takes with almost no close-ups and very few camera movements, Lav Diaz's "Norte, the End of History" is a tour de force of slow cinema.
review5: Norte is formidable cinema that doesn't shy away from exploring history, philosophy, politics and religion at length. But it's also a story of three individuals, through whom these topics gain sharper focus.

title: Catch Hell
review1: This is [Phillippe's] feature-length directorial debut, and the suspense isn't well orchestrated.
review2: Catch Hell suffers from both a drowsy start and a dragging ending.
review3: Catch Hell wastes a generic hostage story on cartoonish characters who redefine what we deem to be stereotypical.
review4: Timely, reasonably tense exploitation thriller that is a tad too obvious and safe with its commentary on celebrity culture, social media and bayou bumpkins
review5: The meta-narrative leanings of Ryan Phillippe's directorial debut almost predictably give way to self-congratulation.

title: 186 Dollars To Freedom
review1: Unable to shape these events into a dramatic structure, the director, Camilo Vila, resorts to a meandering tale of random indignities suffered by a lead so bland he comes across less as principled than as stupendously naïve.
review2: On every level this production-from Robinson's callow performance to Vila's hackneyed handheld camerawork, punching beats in the stead of the actors-remains firmly on the level of the obvious.

title: Dolphin Tale 2
review1: While the kids talk smart, there is a bit of a condescending tone to the script - where some good old fashioned science might have been more effective.
review2: Barely there Morgan Freeman and Kris Kristofferson pick up the easiest paychecks of their careers, while top acting honors go to Mavis the sea turtle and Rufus the comic-relief pelican.
review3: ... wholesome and occasionally moving but hardly memorable.
review4: A beautifully shot, powerful, old-fashioned family flick told by smart and responsible adults.
review5: Admirable intentions are no substitute for a compelling storyline.

title: Calvary
review1: The tension of Calvary is fitful at best, and much of the movie trips into silliness, but in Brendan Gleeson -- in his proud bearing and his lamenting gaze -- we see the plight of the lonely believer in a world beyond belief.
review2: Brendan Gleeson delivers a typically towering yet warm performance in "Calvary." Too bad the movie's something of a mess.
review3: McDonagh's rotted-out take on the Stations of the Cross is a strange film, often hilarious yet always heavy and forlorn.
