review4: Gleeson is just magnificent.
review5: Writer-director John Michael McDonagh has crafted a bleak and bitter film. I kept waiting the for the film to make a wrong turn, to cheat, to take the easy way out, to lean on film cliches and formulas, but it never did.

title: I Origins
review1: Cahill spends the entire film bringing a sense of wonder to the desperately rational Ian, and if the film takes on a glow toward the end, that glow feels well-earned.
review2: When it shifts away from the relationship, it really starts to feel forced. You can feel Cahill's hand leading you down the path toward another "discovery," and you can only hope the end will justify the means. Put simply, it doesn't.
review3: Shame then that it lets itself down with some iffy dialogue and a slightly anticlimactic ending.
review4: Though not every element of the grander mystery story works, there's plenty here to keep you thinking.
review5: Arresting, ambitious and a bit of an acquired taste, Cahill's extraordinary second feature bursts with big, bold ideas.

title: Frank
review1: Beneath those puppet-headed antics, and true to its title, Frank is improbably, disarmingly honest.
review2: With the soulful Gleeson and a sweetly menacing Fassbender (under a giant helmet-head) at its center, the movie never loses its acerbic edge or its oversize heart.
review3: A finely grained ensemble piece, more sober than it needed to be, and more complexly engaging.
review4: This is a fundamentally sad film, yet one full of slapstick, silliness, and laughter.
review5: The film tries very hard for quirky, but (barely) manages annoying.

title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears
review1: As tiresome as the relentless, indulgent inscrutability and lack of story momentum can be, it says something for the movie's visceral power that there isn't an urge to quit on it.
review2: I found a few lines and images in the second half intellectually stimulating, but it wasn't enough. "Strange Color" exploited little but my patience.
review3: Enervatingly synthetic, "The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears" slices and dices the images and tropes of Italian giallo-style slasher films into an inert pile of style.
review4: What "The Strange Color" lacks is the heart that separates a good film from a great one.
review5: The filmmakers' command of the form extends to intentionally dopey performances and a total rejection of plot, all of which gets tiresome.

title: When The Game Stands Tall
review1: When the Game Stands Tall is one of those cliché-riddled feel good movies that, by trying too hard to be inspirational, ends up as cloying and overly sentimental.
review2: The real-life story behind When the Game Stands Tall sounds amazing. But for all its exciting sports scenes, the movie version falls flat as drama.
review3: The moral that football isn't everything seems inherently irreconcilable with a football movie, though.
review4: Mixes bland dialogue, formulaic sports-movie plot points, and vague Christian teachings with some disturbingly naïve racial overtones. The story risks inducing concussion as it pounds and thumps its message home, over and over.
review5: We've seen the 'Full eyes, clear hearts, can't lose' ethic before on screen, and more winningly dramatized, but When the Game Stands Tall does a good, and family-friendly, job of encapsulating Ladouceur's 'winning' approach...

title: The Missouri Breaks
review1: A Western-as-capitalist-critique piece shanghaied by Marlon Brando's eccentric bounty hunter trying on brogues, mumus, and buckskin Nudie suits.
review2: As a film achievement it's corned beef and ham hash.
review3: Enjoyable, if forgettable, New Hollywood shtick.
review4: One of the few truly major Westerns of the '70s, with a very clear vision of the historical role played by fear and violence in the taming of the wilderness.
review5: ... worth seeing if only for the madness of Marlon Brando ... it's not hard to see why some charge him with sabotaging the film with a genuinely bizarre performance

title: The Skeleton Twins
review1: The real surprise of the film is Hader, graduating from more juvenile cinematic entries ... and giving a beautifully crafted performance that allows his knack for voice and facial expressions to shine in the stronger material
review2: A wonderful and brutally engrossing dramedy about family and the lasting effects of growing up in dysfunctional households.
review3: The Skeleton Twins makes for an engaging film that gets you emotionally involved, while also giving you some good laughs in the process, and for that intelligent mixture, it's a dramedy that's definitely worth seeing.
review4: Wiig, Wilson and Hader all give great performances in this movie, almost enough to lift it out of the dark emotional pit at the heart of the story. It doesn't quite make it there in this comedy about a suicidal family.
review5: The Skeleton Twins is beautiful, infectious and painfully honest in a way that's normally reserved for someone that you shared a womb with.

title: Magic in the Moonlight
review1: It's an accomplished, stately movie -- unimpassioned but pleasing.
review2: Magic is an enjoyable film in its minor way. You will not leave it disappointed or feeling in some way cheated.
review3: This is a funny romantic comedy with some feeling. It is witty, well-written, well-acted and well-directed. The characters are interesting and complicated.
review4: Although somewhat disposable, [Magic in the Moonlight] stands as further proof of Allen's undiminished talent for finding new ways to say the same things.
review5: It may not rank in the top tier of Woody Allen's incredible filmography, but it provides just enough for a worthwhile experience that fans of his work will no doubt enjoy.

title: Coyote
review1: Writer-director Joe Eddy's debut is sincere but relies on obvious tropes: Look how shallow Brian's family is! Look how loving Manuel's is!
review2: The sharp, funny Coyote documents the narratives of two people disconnected from the realities of cross-border politics.

title: Kids for Cash
review1: A vital, urgent and infuriating look at the devastating failures of the juvenile court system and the insidious reach of prison privatization.
review2: In his directorial debut, Robert May examines in granular detail the causes and effects of the scandal, and interviewed dozens of people over a number of years.
review3: May errs, however, in styling this human interest saga.
review4: A carefully measured, admirably precise account of this sordid business.
review5: This provides enough valuable information to constitute a worthy public service announcement.

title: Kurôn wa kokyô o mezasu (The Clone Returns Home) (The Clone Returns to the Homeland)
Lost Christmas
review1: Mystical, heartwarming holiday tale with mature themes.

title: Naked As We Came
review1: As in too much queer cinema, Naked is weighed down by wooden, charisma-free hunks in leading roles, but McWilliams proves a revelation whose passionate performance more than compensates for the distracting eye candy.
review2: Writer and director Richard LeMay's film plays from the heart, sometimes almost too blatantly. But on the whole, it nicely underscores how silences and shouts often come from the same place.
review3: Here is the way it should happen when a family says goodbye: Making peace. Making connections. Smelling the orchids. Seeing the light.
review4: On the other hand, when LeMay focuses on family drama and lets the calmer moments (albeit with roiling emotions just under the surface) rule the movie.

title: The Zigzag Kid
review1: Simon is immensely appealing in the lead - smart, resourceful, weighed down with a few more cares than a kid his age should have.
review2: Say yes to the cute and clever "Nono."

title: The Notebook
review1: The relentless calamity becomes a grind, offering few insights beyond ones that are obvious in the first half hour.
review2: In adapting the novel, Szasz and screenwriters Tom Abrams and Andras Szeker tread carefully, leaving a lot to the imagination ...
review3: A bleak, despairing testament to the cruelty of war, and how it mangles and defaces everyone it touches.
review4: If only I could figure out what all this was meant to stand for.
review5: Thoroughly unpleasant and at the same time completely unedifying.

title: Tyler Perry's Hell Hath No Fury Like A Woman Scorned The Play
Pride
review1: In its total inspirational sweep, it earns comparison to the movement it chronicles - as an organized, well-calculated piece of political theater.
review2: This film moves effortlessly from some pretty intense dramatic moments to hilarious scenes showcasing the contrasting lifestyles of the gay and straight worlds to some vignettes of incredible poignancy.
review3: This portrayal of the unlikely 1980s alliance between London gay-rights activists and striking Welsh miners is, quite simply, one of the best movies of the year so far.
review4: The important twist is that Pride seems to capture the essence of reality, giving it the recognition it deserves. Truth really is stranger than fiction, and Pride tells that truth with flair.
review5: In this age of cultivated buddy lists, location-based hookup apps, circuit parties, Fire Island summer shares, open relationships and via-surrogacy parenthood, the reminder that "Pride" serves couldn't have come at a better time.

title: Gong-mo-ja-deul (Traffickers)
review1: Traffickers is a riveting thriller with compelling performances from Im Chang-jung and Choi Daniel, but the film loses its momentum in its final act. The film is just unable to overcome the massive convoluted hurdles it constructs for itself.

title: The Trip To Italy
review1: This hedonistic japery is shot through with middle-aged melancholy and the fear of death.
review2: If it's your cup of tea, you're likely to spill it from laughing so hard. Somebody send these two on another holiday.
review3: It's that melancholy within each man that saves the film from disposability.
review4: It's 'second verse, same as the first.' Thank God.
review5: You wish they'd challenged themselves a bit more with this film, and not gone the "if it worked once, let's do it again" route.

title: Two-Bit Waltz
review1: Dysfunctional clans fairly litter the indie-verse these days, but there's a strange charm in this young Mamet pretending it's original.
review2: Rising star Clara Mamet makes a memorable writing and directorial debut with this semi-autobiographical coming-of-age tale where she also plays a suicidal teen struggling to find her place in the world.
review3: Rising star Clara Mamet makes a memorable writing and directorial debut with this semi-autobiographical coming-of-age tale where she also plays a suicidal teen struggling to find her place in the world.
review4: Miss Mamet is no Wes Anderson as a writer-director, no Tea Leoni as a quirky actress and whatever she got out of watching "Harold & Maude," maybe she needs to watch it again.

title: The Good Lie
review1: There's a sense that The Good Lie wants to say something profound but the message is as muddled as its delineation of history is.
review2: The main characters are played by actual refugees-two of whom were child soldiers-and their uninflected, authoritative performances compensate for the feel-good simplifications of Margaret Nagle's script.
review3: A well-told tale that illuminates the experiences of the 20,000 "lost boys" (and girls) of Sudan, with such grace, insight and humor, it can be forgiven a few simplifying liberties taken in the name of moving the narrative along.
review4: Strong performances from Arnold Oceng, Ger Duany and Emmanuel Jal ensure that the characters of Mamere, Jeremiah and Paul are never reduced to "exotic" victimhood.
review5: A Unesco educational resource cast in the style of an unreconstructed 1970s sitcom.

title: Hemel
review1: Sure, for viewers-turned-voyeurs, it's hard to look away from the screen, but the film is less successful from a psychological point of view, even with plenty of daddy issues.

title: Uncle Kent
review1: The prolific and daring independent filmmaker Joe Swanberg captures the loneliness of the long-term D.I.Y. artist in the age of social networking.

title: Kelly & Cal
review1: The movie turns a little soapy as it tries to locate a satisfying ending, and there are too many self-conscious statements of life's little lessons, yet the passion remains.
review2: It's difficult to be fully invested in the Big Emotional Developments of the final act.
review3: There are complex situations, well-acted characters and a central relationship that feels authentic and mature - and yet it's missing some element to bring it fully into focus.
review4: Juliette Lewis and newcomer Jonny Weston bring terrific sensitivity to their roles.
review5: A sly satire that's sexy, touching, and funny, if seriously flawed.

title: Reach Me
review1: At times "Reach Me" is undeniably intriguing, mostly because it's just so weird and disconnected. Eventually, though, it just becomes tiresome.
review2: Nothing in the proceedings is remotely convincing, let alone entertaining.
review3: 'Reach Me' is the sort of movie where careers go to die.
review4: A kitchen-sink mess with no discernible narrative drive or thematic resonance beyond uninspired batches of bad behavior, gunplay, eccentricity and weak uplift.
review5: Casting Sylvester Stallone as a gossip-site publisher obviously modeled on Matt Drudge is one of many counterintuitive ideas that backfire in "Reach Me."

title: Submarino
review2: Any study on Scandinavia will tell you that the region is one of the happiest and most peaceful in the world; a look at its recent cinema will suggest just the opposite.

title: A Will For The Woods
review1: The movie feels entirely promotional, provoking separate, unanswered questions about green medicine too.
review2: It's possible to admire the four directors' unflinching depiction of the dying process, but the film is mostly unilluminating and grim - not least because almost all of the deaths discussed are untimely.
review3: Less an introduction to the green-burial movement than a portrait of one man who embraced it after being diagnosed with a terminal illness, A Will for the Woods is more sentimental than journalistic.
review4: While the film also captures many private, sometimes heartbreaking scenes, it takes a lot of time to make its simple point.
review5: n the film's sobering final act, we get to see the man's beliefs put to practice...fulfill[ing] his wishes--including using this film to share his philosophy with the world.

title: Das finstere Tal (The Dark Valley)
review1: This takes itself far too seriously and suffers greatly as a result.
review2: Centered on an uninvolving hero, and proceeding in unsurprising ways, the film's cinematographic competence can't compensate for an overwhelming sense of "ok, and?" to the whole endeavor.

title: Missionary
review1: Taken strictly as a Cinemax-grade potboiler, "Missionary" is often a hoot, and more effective than it has any right to be.
review2: This lean thriller deftly shows how the fervency needed to wholly embrace any one belief or institution can, if unchecked, yield dire consequences.
review3: A Southern Gothic thriller that begins on a high note but fails to deliver.
review4: The tension in Missionary is surprisingly effective, especially given how easy it should be to put out an APB on a guy on a freaking bicycle ...
review5: Things spiral downhill in predictable fashion, squandering a premise about faith and temptation that should have been much edgier and more provocative.

title: Miele
review1: [Honey is] never really laid bare as a character; her helpless, beseeching customers leave a much deeper impression.
review2: Seek it out.
review3: Trinca delivers a marvelously unfussy performance, rendering her complex character gradually, along with the effects of the opposing forces that tear at her.
review4: The title character of "Honey" is a fascinating and complex figure, and Jasmine Trinca inhabits the role with a detached intensity that's thoroughly compelling.
review5: The film shies from directly addressing anguished existential questions. It is finally a story about the puncturing of one young, headstrong woman's personal belief system.

title: A Horse For Summer
review1: Faith-based film about rebellious teen has heavy themes.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt?
review1: Prime Mystery Science Theater 3000 fodder, cut-rate to the point of incoherence.
review2: The prior installments weren't very good movies, and it should surprise few that this last one is the worst of the lot.
review3: Rand's parable is meant to showcase just how much our world needs the best of us, but this adaptation only does so accidentally -- by revealing what movies would be like if none of the best of us worked on them.
review4: A missed opportunity to speak to anyone other than the converted, but at least as the culmination of its makers' will.
review5: To find fault with the Atlas Shrugged franchise because of its politics is like complaining about Birdemic because it gets the ornithology wrong. Why dwell on the details when there are giant, embarrassing flaws staring you in the face?

title: Get On Up
review1: The screenplay from Jez and John-Henry Butterworth inserts some actual discussion of his songwriting and groove technique, giving the man credit for virtually inventing the funk.
review2: The film's relative lack of any actual drama in the narrative is ultimately the result of a biographical approach too dedicated to flattery.
review3: Chadwick Boseman is electrifying as Godfather of Soul James Brown in this daringly offbeat biopic, which matches its subject's brass-necked, go-for-broke audacity with its own bold cinematic risk-taking.
review4: Hard to imagine anyone else in the role of singer James Brown than actor Chadwick Boseman. He nails it.
review5: The production numbers steal the show.

title: Horns
review1: It seems to have been made by people who couldn't decide if their film was a horror flick, a whodunit, or a Hellboy knockoff.
review2: At nearly two hours, "Horns" is about 30 minutes longer than it needs to be. But it's doubtful even a shorter version would cure what ails this film. Maybe you have to be tripped out on LSD to appreciate it.
review3: Draws out a heretofore unseen compassion in Aja, who dials the grue way down and focuses on the terrific cast he's hired.
review4: There are times when you will want to look away from the horrors shown on the screen but it will be hard to wipe the smile off your face.
review5: Horns appears to be of the persuasion that everybody is a liar and inherently evil, and it's a disappointingly one-note approach to a premise that could use a lighter touch.

title: West Of Thunder
review1: Oddly absorbing, just not the way writer and star Dan Davies probably meant it to be.
review2: [It has] an unvarnished quality that remains curiously engaging.

title: Ways To Live Forever
review1: A forthright and surprisingly buoyant drama about facing death before you have really lived.
review2: The result is as sugary as a fatal toothache, though it's hard to hate a film that merely wants to give the world a hug.
review3: The overarching sentiment of Ways to Live Forever is curiosity. Does dying hurt? How does someone live forever?
review5: ... more uplifting than sentimental, even if it never exactly feels authentic.

title: Ai Weiwei: The Fake Case
review1: If you want to provoke an artist, try to stifle him.
review2: Ai granted Johnsen significant access to his personal and professional lives following his release, including his tender interactions with his young son, and the film's intimate nature recalls the verite style of Ai's own video work.
review3: Remarkably intimate and astute.
review4: Although expertly edited, Johnsen's film, whose soundtrack ends with Nina Simone's "Feeling Good," presents a less effective portrait of Ai than Klayman's does.
review5: The film quietly and slowly reveals a man struggling internally to find the right response to the restrictions imposed on him and determining that to stop speaking out would itself be a kind of death.

title: Boyhood
review1: We can quibble with small stuff in Boyhood. Supporting performances are variable, the sister drops out as a dramatic character ... I could go on. But the cumulative power is tremendous.
review2: While everything about Boyhood is done with extraordinary care, the master stroke was clearly the casting, 13 years ago, of a little Texas boy named Ellar Coltrane.
review3: It's like a time-lapse photo of an expanding consciousness.
review4: Ambitious and an absolutely excellent endeavor.
review5: Intimate and insightful even in its weaker moments, Linklater finds strength and value in normality.

title: Dinosaur 13
review1: The storytelling raises more logistical and legal questions than it's equipped to answer. But what Miller does have, for anyone unfamiliar with Sue's fate, is a story with a suspenseful climax.
review2: In his eagerness to create a David-and-Goliath story, and with his distractingly pro-BHI bias, Mr. Miller fails to ask a lot of questions.
review3: The fate of some very old bones may not sound like compelling cinema, but when they compose the 65-million-year-old skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex that was 41 feet long and 18 feet high back in the day, all bets are off.
review4: These events would have been better handled in a single installment of Dateline.
review5: "Dinosaur 13" may not be the best documentary, but as a scientific soap opera, it's a doozy.

title: Salvo
review1: A soulful romance, an existential action flick and something of a miracle movie - the appealing slow-burner "Salvo" hovers at the crossroads of genre.
review2: Viewers looking for a shoot-em-up will be disappointed, but those hankering for an old-school Italian broodfest will find plenty to soak in.
review3: It's not the tale, but the telling of it, that distinguishes this Sicilian drama.
review4: Hits the heights in its first forty minutes ... Later developments prove disappointingly predictable.
review5: Very stylish Sicilian mafia movie. One part Antonioni and one part Calvin Klein commercial.

title: The Houses October Built
review1: Never transcends a predictable narrative trajectory to deliver much in the way of creepy atmosphere, let alone actual scares.
review2: The Houses October Built" proves one of the more successful attempts at the found-footage horror flick since Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones.
review3: If you're relatively easily scared or are in a theater full of people who are, the film might be good for a few screams. But only if you're the patient sort.
review4: The scary Halloween house at your local amusement park is child's play compared to the "extreme haunts" that fill this uneven but intriguing found-footage horror flick.
review5: What sets this film appart from other found footage movies is the fact that it tries to be a documentary at times, adding more credibility to what we see on screen. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Bound
review1: Just because Bound stumbles into something resembling insight from time to time doesn't mean that it isn't, at heart, just another product of the Asylum assembly line.
review2: With an undercooked narrative and questionable performances, it's hard to recommend Bound as anything beyond a curiosity.

title: Bird People
review1: People are just like birds, this French drama asserts-over and over again, with mind-numbing obviousness, until you might feel like spreading your wings and flying away yourself.
review2: An airport hotel may not seem the most inspiring of locations for a story of life-changing consequence, but French filmmaker Pascale Ferran's delicate, compassionate "Bird People" is just that sort of risk-taking existential adventure.
review3: The vehicle for the message feels haphazard, as if Ferran were trying to create a patchwork of various film types rather than one cohesive piece.
review4: Bird People has ideas about nature, human and otherwise. It's got a sense of romantic wonder.
review5: An artful experiment that only half works.

title: Lootera
review1: It's not at all trite to state that by the hauntingly bittersweet end, everything magically falls into place, for there is true magic in Motwane's mastery in crafting a such a poetic, passionately felt, and perfectly realized work of art.

title: May In The Summer
review1: Dabis's character comes off as a self-serving fantasy.
review2: Dabis covers a lot of ground as a storyteller while delivering a smart, focused performance.
review3: Ultimately you're left with a drama so contained, it can be neatly wrapped up in single sentences of passed-on wisdom.
review4: You believe in these people, you care about them and their struggles. And in the end, you wish them all the best.
review5: There's goodwill to go around in Dabis' modestly engaging yarn, from its appealing performances to the times it zeroes in on the ways culture, tradition and individuality cause headaches and heartaches as much as comfort.

title: Bhaag Milkha Bhaag
review1: The conflation of sports and politics in Bhaag Milkha Bhaag always feels strained, with Singh's story remaining most absorbing as a story of personal -- rather than national -- triumph.
review2: Farhan Akhtar's intelligent performance is a highlight of the film.
review3: There are triumphs, both in front of and behind the camera, but they often get overshadowed by a story that tries to do too much.
review4: The way the movie strikes its chosen couple of notes resoundingly, making clear what makes Singh run.
review5: Often an engrossing example of the sweeping, stirring biography.

title: Mall
review1: The biggest problem with Hahn's film is that it is incredibly hard to tell whether the movie glorifies the violence perpetrated upon innocent people, or if it condemns it.
review2: [T]he real pleasures come from considering the deeper layers, and from the oldschool nods to grindhouse sensibilities and psychedelic theater.

title: NightLights
review1: NightLights achieves something admirably genuine about the queasy mixture of anguish and joy attached to caretaking for the most needy of loved ones.
review2: There are moments in director David Midell's NightLights that play like PSAs, but that earnestness is paved over by wonderfully affecting performances.

title: The Identical
review1: Where is all this going, you ask? Good question.
review2: It's stocked with clichés, but they're arranged in such weird ways that the end result is both predictable and certifiable. If only any of it actually went somewhere.
review3: Connoisseurs of the most wonderfully terrible cinema need to run out and catch this one early and often.
review4: This is a terrific premise for a movie. Too bad they do so little with it.
review5: Heartfelt Story & Loved the Music

title: Honeymoon
review1: For those who have ever nursed suspicions that the answer is "not enough," Honeymoon will inspire chills much more bone-deep than the ones provoked by, say, some poltergeist flinging around chairs.
review2: Leslie and Treadaway extract plenty of existential doubt and distressing emotion from what is essentially a claustrophobic two-hander.
review3: Covers a lot of emotional and intellectual terrain for such an unassuming and modest indie horror film, and that's only part of what makes it so impressive.
review4: A skin-crawling thriller without compromise, "Honeymoon" is unpleasant, whip-smart and mesmerizing.
review5: Janiak does find a great deal of success turning that dreamy romance on its head, plunging her leads into a nightmarish scenario and ensuring you'll never forget what happened to them.

title: Jimi: All Is by My Side
review1: A hip-looking mess of a movie, made tolerable by Benjamin's spacey-cool Hendrix. Great costumes, few insights.
review2: ... an interesting curiosity that takes chances and gets at a certain truth about its enigmatic lead character.
review3: [A] disjointed and clumsily made biopic of rock icon Jimi Hendrix.
review4: André Benjamin does a fair job of conveying Hendrix's languid charisma and grace... But the soapy drama remains about as convincing as the troop of rock lookalikes who file past at intervals.
review5: Andre 3000 makes an A-grade Hendrix, but this biopic sees the legend's legacy fall into a bit of a haze.

title: Middle of Nowhere
review1: A film remarkably true to life's haphazard rhythms.
review2: Made by a black American woman, about a black American woman, it's a study of a culture where the matriarchs are strong by necessity and trapped by circumstance - adrift in the middle of nowhere.
review3: [A] hushed, tenderly observant drama about a young woman trying to do right by herself and her marriage while her husband is in prison.
review4: This is a tough-minded story of change that happens in almost imperceptibly tiny increments - as true growth so often does in reality.
review5: This film is about a particular African-American experience, true, but it's also about the human experience. It will haunt you. It should.

title: The Two Faces of January
review1: [Hossein Amini's] polished storytelling carries this along, generally compensating for the mundane visuals and the actors' skilled but unmoored performances.
review2: At a certain point, it's akin to reading a mediocre murder mystery. You finish it because you're too far in to quit, as opposed to actually caring how things wrap up.
review3: What the movie lacks in suspense, it could make up for with erotic tension. That's missing, too.
review4: Everything about The Two Faces of January is right, even as the events it describes - a couple's idyllic Grecian holiday, a charming American's adventures abroad - go terribly wrong.
review5: The movie never reaches a boil. Instead, it simmers and simmers until you're suddenly shocked at the hot water you're in.

title: A Walk Among the Tombstones
review1: Frank's film is much more of a noir outing than a straight action feature, and Neeson slips right into the tone and feel of the hard-boiled detective offering.
review2: As a throwback to a type of nasty, ugly crime film of yesteryear, A Walk Among the Tombstones cleans up.
review3: As nauseating as the film's inventive sadisms can be, Frank succeeds far more in the details than in the larger picture that tries to relate this world to ours.
review4: While we're waiting for the release of Taken 3, the man who was Oskar Schindler is keeping us in an action hero frame of mind with the moody-but-essentially-empty A Walk Among the Tombstones.
review5: A slick, ugly and brutal crime thriller set in NYC, in 1999.

title: That Burning Feeling
review1: The dilemma and the denouement are stock, but James has a light touch, and the movie has the safe, familiar look of a sitcom.

title: Memphis
review1: "Memphis" is poetry.
review2: Even those who find it a bore will agree it's a pleasure to look at, and not only because Beal cleans up nicely as a suit-wearing slacker in a snappy chapeaux.
review3: The film feels like a sketch rather than a portrait, beautifully rendered but incomplete in the details.
review4: The film is less than 80 minutes and if you cut the shots that go on too long it would be less than an hour.
review5: Tim Sutton's second feature, starring the young contemporary musician Willis Earl Beal as a musician with the same name, captures the mood of the blues with pitch-perfect sensuality.

title: Gone Girl
review1: But for once, Mr. Fincher actually allows us something to ponder: the elements of perception and performance, both on screen and in our daily lives.
review2: Gone Girl is easily one of the best thrillers to come out of Hollywood in years.
review3: The most loathsome movie I've seen in the twenty-eight years I've been reviewing films.
review4: A pulpy, sweaty and often insanely preposterous thriller. Gone Girl is a blast.
review5: Very fine Fincher, and a thriller that was just filled with excellent twists.

title: Young Ones
review1: In the hot, dry world of Jake Paltrow's dystopian western, Young Ones, the characterizations are as sparse as the desert foliage.
review2: "Young Ones" is a futuristic look at a world with little water, but the most barren thing in this Western-sci-fi flick is the character development.
review3: Young Ones has some interesting twists but falls short as a reworking of a classic Hollywood oater.
review4: No matter how grim the future may be, it deserves a better movie in the here and now.
review5: The setting is futuristic, but the themes are ancient in "Young Ones," Jake Paltrow's eccentric merger of frontier western and science-fiction gadgetry.

title: Love Is Strange
review1: Its slice-of-life concerns may seem trivial, but "Love Is Strange" is genuinely funny, tender and moving in spots.
review2: Love is Strange is one of the most haunting love stories we will get to see in theaters this year. [full review in Spanish]
review3: Love is Strange is a powerful fable about love and relationships. [full review in Spanish]
review4: "Love is Strange " is an unpretentious film, made for those times when you just want to relax. [full review Spanish]
review5: In a few words, this is a great film. [Full Review In Spanish]

title: "Men, Women & Children"
review1: The name of the film is "Men, Women & Children." Don't forget the animals, because this one's a real dog.
review2: Ultimately, when it comes time to tie the film all together into something memorable, Men, Women & Children offers only its equivalent of a shrugging emoticon in reply.
review3: Much of the film's hard work is undone by a weak finale. Most of the characters go through a life-changing epiphany that doesn't ring true.
review4: Though a couple of the storylines have some of the bite of Reitman's earlier work, the film mostly resorts to look-how-crazy-this-is handwringing ...
review5: A new film, but the themes are old and tired.

title: Bad Turn Worse
review1: Bad Turn Worse is a taut noir tale, bolstered by a trio of excellent lead performances and a well-plotted script.
review2: Directors Zeke and Simon Hawkins add air-quote references to Jim Thompson, Steven Soderbergh, and the Coen brothers but are too proud of the movie's twists to make them truly snap.
review3: "Bad Turn Worse" simply peters out by the night of the big heist, never achieving more than being imitative of small-town noir instead of getting inside it.
review4: A juicy neo-noir like "Bad Turn Worse" doesn't have to make total sense to grab you. All it has to do is spit like a snake enough times to show that it means business.
review5: This cowboy noir works fine as a genre riff, but screenwriter Dutch Southern draws so liberally on the work of Jim Thompson, Cormac McCarthy, and the Coen brothers that he ought to take them all out for drinks.

title: Silent Youth
review1: What else haven't you told me?

title: Jessabelle
review1: As the film racks up incidents and characters and explanations, the mystery dissipates. It's a strange spectacle: a horror film that spends as much time dismantling suspense as it does building it.
review2: An ineffective, derivative, and awkwardly executed mash-up of ghost flicks and voodoo movies.
review3: Credit lead Sarah Snook's gentle, sympathetic performance for holding together this atmospheric film, especially during its silly-campy third act.
review4: How are VHS tapes, voodoo and the specter lurking in a house connected? Your impatience for answers is likely to eclipse your trepidation.
review5: One of the nice things about Jessabelle is that it isn't trying too hard.

title: Winter In The Blood
review1: The story captures a slipstream of memory and regret, interweaving past and present and what might be happening in Virgil's mind as he reflects on lost family and lost chances.
review2: Cursed with a vague, rambling script and an equally indistinct lead performance, the film is a scattershot series of vignettes about self-definition that, ultimately, never coheres into a lucid whole.
review3: The journey from page to screen may have battered Mr. Welch's novel, but its lamenting heart beats loud and clear.
review4: Winter in the Blood turns out to be the wrong kind of heartbreaker.
review5: [An] audacious, funny and often tender movie.

title: The Drop
review1: As a vehicle for those two actors, The Drop is gangbusters.
review2: It's a classic case of a little becoming a lot onscreen on the basis of a single impressive performance.
review3: Gandolfini, of course, owns this turf, and the late actor goes out strong -- he can suggest a lifetime's frustration just by the way he shoulders his bulk out of a car.
review4: The Drop is one of the finest crime dramas you're likely to see in a long time, graced by some truly exceptional performances.
review5: Hardy does his sweet-and-tender-hooligan specialty.

title: The Zero Theorem
review1: Say this for Terry Gilliam: Even when he repeats himself, he's unique.
review2: Gives one the sense that the ex-Monty Python-ite thinks he's at a filmmaker version of the Last Chance Saloon, manufacturing and recycling as fast as he can.
review3: It's bursting with Gilliam's trademark manic energy, but the focus and execution are so soft that that energy ends up derailing the film instead of invigorating it.
review4: The culture's caught up to Gilliam. Everybody's doing Orwell now. But Gilliam's appropriation feels both aptly skeptical and unfashionably utopian.
review5: There is something so generous and so full-hearted in this profusion that to complain seems churlish, but "The Zero Theorem" has a bothersome ratio of misses to hits.

title: Life's a Breeze
review1: Life's a Breeze spins a sitcom plot into passable yet predictable entertainment.
review2: A small sweet film, the sort of unexpected pleasure movie fans often find at a small film festival or on some second-tier cable channel.
review3: "Life's a Breeze" is a small film with a considerable amount of charm. Comic and idiosyncratic, it takes a warmhearted view toward its protagonists while still seeing them for exactly who they are.
review4: "Life's a Breeze" is ultimately about as cutting and memorable as its title.
review5: The film's surface naturalism and visual grit simply cover up a screenplay that's as full of crap as the average recent Hollywood comedy.

title: White Bird in a Blizzard
review1: "A melodrama about numbness and detachment, writer-director Gregg Araki's adaptation of Laura Kasischke's novel is a paradox on paper and an anesthetized dud on screen."
review2: Green in particular seems to be channeling the bride of Frankenstein for half her scenes. It's an awkward mix of styles, and it doesn't work.
review3: Araki never digs deep enough, wasting the opportunity to expose Kat's resentments.
review4: This should be a profound character study, but the cliched use of flashbacks and the mawkish elements to the piece detract heavily from our own enjoyment.
review5: This dreamy/nightmarish weirdie finds Araki reining in his anarchic excesses with rewarding results, as his satirical sensuality reaps the benefits of a heavily orchestrated deadpan formality.

title: Coherence
review1: The larger questions Coherence asks us to consider about parallel worlds are interesting, if not exactly original, while absurdist touches help elevate it from more traditional thrillers.
review2: At once a suspenseful mind game and a wily mash-up of surreal quantum physics theories, this low-cost thriller proves that something approaching brilliance is not just a function of budget.
review3: Coherence's brilliance comes from forcing the question of whether we truly know what we're capable of.
review4: Coherence is, at times, somewhat incoherent, but always on the right side of farcicality.
review5: Considering how much of the film consists of a single group of people becoming increasingly unhinged in a suburban living room, it's impressive how effectively Byrkit manages to suggest multiple realities and ominous other worlds.

title: Rudderless
review1: Rudderless is humane and almost entertaining.
review2: The film is a roller-coaster of emotions and the jolt, when it comes, will send you reeling.
review3: For all its noble intentions and loaded emotions, "Rudderless" proves a largely hollow, uninvolving affair.
review4: The story takes an even sharper left turn in the last half hour, raising emotional issues it can't adequately address.
review5: "Rudderless" isn't always smoothly paced, and features a plot twist that's awkwardly handled, but at its heart is a performance that resonates - and a director that, I hope, has more stories to tell.

title: The Mule
review1: An excremental but hardly execrable Australian comedy-drama that plays like the klutzy, sheets-soiling stepbrother of "Maria Full of Grace."
review2: The Mule proves a tough sit, but by the end you might be satisfied you gritted through it.
review3: While the film suffers from its own occasional sluggishness, it picks up as the lawmen watching our hero grow as strained as he is.
review4: This gritty, claustrophobic film will not be to everyone's taste -- and if I say that phrase also has a double meaning, you have a hint of just how gross Ray's week gets before it's over.
review5: Angus Sampson co-directs and stars in the most unglamorous vanity project of recent memory... A slickly-produced black comedy.

title: By The Gun
review1: A strong contender for laziest mob movie ever made, the Boston-set Italian mafia tale "By the Gun" proves that what was once thrillingly exotic and coolly dangerous about gangster films is now hopelessly monotonous.
review2: While By the Gun does incorporate much of what you'd expect from films of its ilk, it's also surprisingly self-aware.
review3: Cliched, confused and thoroughly unnecessary, "By the Gun" features a meaty role for Boston rapper Slaine ("The Town") as Nick's best friend George, but writer Emilio Mauro deep sixes the character's early promise in a laughable "Mean Streets" ripoff.
review4: Certain scenes in By the Gun pack a powerful punch, but it doesn't coalesce into a satisfying whole.

title: World for Ransom
review4: Nervy burlesque of Hustonian exotic thrillers
review5: Fascinating early Aldrich, visually creative.

title: Born of War
review1: You can respect that it was made for a fraction of the cost of the average, similarly politically superficial American action-thriller, but that doesn't make the failure any more noble.
review2: Ultimately, despite all its toughness, the film's flaws make it a little too vulnerable to stand up on its own.

title: Miss Meadows
review1: May we be excused, "Miss Meadows"?
review2: It exists somewhere between serious character study and satirical fish-out-of-water story, never figuring out which it wants to be.
review3: Despite an eccentric streak (which turns erratic), the script doesn't allow much room for the premise to take flight.
review4: Hopkins fails to fulfill the potential of her own script.
review5: As an ostensible work of satire, it lacks bite, never truly questioning or complicating its heroine's actions; the film isn't even outrageous enough to be appalling (which paradoxically makes it appalling).

title: My Old Lady
review1: It's too twee and theatrical to take seriously.
review2: I needed a little something to lift my spirits, and I found "My Old Lady" did the trick.
review3: Kline and Smith have some nice moments together, even if the transition from breezy comedy into more serious drama is clumsy.
review4: Just when you think the story is going to proceed on a well-worn, cosily romantic track, its characters unpack their emotional baggage, revealing unexpected depths of hurt and taking the film into bittersweet dramatic territory.
review5: It's solidly predictable and somewhat grating, only partially redeemed by a reliably watchable cast.

title: The Judge
review1: Yeah, so it's practically Oldboy. Except they don't make a big deal about it. Just a casual incest comedy subplot
review2: The Judge picked me apart in ways that I wasn't prepared for.
review3: When attorney Robert Downey Jr. returns to his Indiana hometown early in the film, he drives through an utterly phony CG cornfield. The unnecessary effect is an indicator of the sham emotions, spurious sentiment and -- yes -- corn headed the viewer's way.
review4: The best thing I can say about "The Judge" is that I didn't mind watching it. The movie, starring Robert Downey, Jr. and Robert Duvall covered a lot of familiar territory, but it was a comfortable journey.
review5: The Judge will say and do anything to win over the jury of public opinion, but look at the facts, and you'll see nothing but pandering.

title: The Color of Time
review1: "The Color of Time" is an odd bird in that its 12 cooks don't necessarily spoil the broth. The problem is that they leave it as broth.
review2: The film is too sincere an expression of admiration for this poet's work to feel pretentious, but it's like a music video for the poems, often literal in its biographical readings.
review3: A cool concept, and A for effort.
review4: Franco makes a lot of art, both good and bad. But no one provides a bolder example of the vanishing lines that used to separate movie stars, fringe artists, and working actors.
review5: The uniformity of its languorous, lens-flared visuals may wear on all but the most ardent Terrence Malick devotees, many of whom, I suspect, are also grad students.

title: Fury
review1: An impressively solid World War II movie of the kind they don't make anymore.
review2: While these orgies of violence are staged with tense, gruesome precision, they don't convey much beyond what we already know. Namely, that war is hell. Message received.
review3: Pitt, who at 50 still looks great with his shirt off, has the gruff charisma to play a dauntless soldier with killer courage and a vestigial streak of humanity.
review4: It's an "unflinching" account of war -- "unflinching," in quotes, because every moment of the film is composed to grind your face into the muck and be proud of itself for doing so.
review5: Pitt is at the top of his game, playing a man who has forgotten whatever he used to be and has wholly embraced his role in this war.

title: Days and Nights
review1: The cast, so packed with talent that Jean Reno and Cherry Jones barely register, is stuck with stagey dialogue. Juliet Rylance, in the Nina part, has a particularly hard time.
review2: In a movie, nothing good ever seems to happen at a country house. And when it comes to this film, nothing very interesting happens, either.
review3: One can certainly give this movie A for effort, but the achievement falls far short of the lofty intentions.
review4: At 92 minutes, Days and Nights feels choppy and hurried, pushing the narrative toward inevitable tragedy rather than exploring how these dispirited people got there.
review5: Lines are read as if unrelated to the ones that came before it, giving conversations a stilted, unnatural coldness.

title: Every Man for Himself
review1: Is Godard the prostitute or the pimp?
review2: has a pungent melancholy to it
review3: Even in the same year as Raging Bull, Melvin and Howard, Dressed to Kill and The Long Riders it was still the freshest, most thrilling movie to behold.

title: "1,000 Times Good Night"
review1: This potent Norwegian drama by Erik Poppe, himself a veteran war photographer, opens with a gripping sequence.
review2: The whole cast is good, but as always, all roads lead to Binoche, who is wonderful.
review3: Poppe can't match the stunning opener of Binoche photographing a suicide bomber in Kabul with scenes of domesticity. But Binoche never falters. She's the film's fire and grieving heart.
review4: Poppe crafts some powerful scenes that pose questions not easily answered.
review5: What makes "1,000 Times Good Night" more than a dramatic essay on wartime journalism is Ms. Binoche's wrenchingly honest portrayal ...

title: Hector And The Search For Happiness
review1: Hector may indeed learn that narcissism stands in the way of happiness, but he also walks away with his privileges intact and unchallenged.
review2: A movie bearing as faux-naive a title as this has to make a pretty good case for itself. This it decidedly does not do.
review3: Potential peeps out occasionally in Hector and the Search for Happiness, but then flounders and gets lost in a bland sea of sentimentality and cultural myopia.
review4: While there's limited value in Hector's search for happiness and the dozen-plus "lessons" he learns about the emotional state, the film works nicely as a character piece.
review5: This film is a winner. It will not only entertain you, but also make you think about what it takes to bring happiness into your own life.

title: Dear White People
review1: The best moments get to the heart of Simien's thesis that what is supposed to be post-racial America isn't all that much different from what came before.
review2: A timely and important look at black identity and how it's informed by by stereotypes in the media
review3: Where it scores big is its wealth of ideas-visual, emotional, cultural-and its deep well of bitter, voice-of-experience rage
review4: Screenplay is tight, funny, smart and insightful, and [the] direction has just enough indie feel without becoming too self-conscious or preachy.
review5: Dear White People is less than the sum of its very polished parts -- a first feature that's just impressive enough to be frustrating.

title: The Overnighters
review1: It develops into a study of obsession, hypocrisy, righteousness and self-doubt, questioning motive and then gob-smacking the audience with the wholly unexpected.
review2: Moss uses images of drill towers or blistering flame as visual metaphors for other things transpiring on screen: the fracturing of a family, the heated fury that comes with a sense of betrayal.
review3: "The Overnighters" is commendable for many reasons, not the least of which is the way it allows complex issues to remain complex. There is a clear conflict between the pastor and the town, but there's no good vs. evil.
review4: So much of "The Overnighters" tells all sorts of truths, and Moss earned the trust of his subjects, whatever they might think of the result.
review5: The movie might seem like just another liberal do-gooder profile, yet a shocker ending throws new and disturbing light on the situation, amplifying the Christian themes at the heart of the story.

title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them
review1: American movies are running perilously low on fresh, youngish talent. Who knows what [director] Benson will do next. I just left his first movie desperate to experience the second one.
review2: Chastain delivers a brilliant performance that could earn her another Oscar nomination.
review3: Worth it for the talent on display, disappointing for what the talent has been given, or not given, to work with.
review4: McAvoy and Chastain offer his-and-hers perspectives
review5: A nostalgic, moving and tender story of love, change and loss, made beautiful by the mesmerising performance of Jessica Chastain.

title: The Retrieval
review1: The Retrieval's potency transcends its scope. It shows you, in microcosm, the sacrifices that forge the conscience not only of a boy, but of a nation.
review2: "The Retrieval" comes at you like a haunting slip of a memory, one that writer-director Chris Eska retrieves from a mostly forgotten era in unforgettable ways.
review3: It is indeed a beautiful film, but with each horizon tinged with sadness. If it was an Instagram filter, it would probably be called melancholy or something.
review4: The movie's flaws are not missteps, but steps not taken.
review5: Low-budget period indies rarely inhabit their world as convincingly as does this drama, which is set in the South in 1864.

title: Starred Up
review1: Director David Mackenzie has empathy for the characters, but also knows how to ratchet up the tension and make the scene of mayhem pack a wallop.
review2: [An] unusually cohesive and exciting prison drama ...
review3: "Starred Up" manages to be sympathetic, not only because of O'Connell's galvanizing turn, but also Asser and director David Mackenzie's unwavering commitment to portraying his character with as much compassion as brutal honesty.
review4: A great ripple effect is felt throughout David Mackenzie's Starred Up, a gritty British prison drama that puts most gritty prison dramas to shame.
review5: The intention seems to be to create a ferocious film without an iota of fakery...

title: Three Days In Havana
review1: Cuba won't top most people's list of exciting vacation destinations. Neither is 3 Days in Havana likely to score highly with dedicated cinephiles, especially thriller fans.
review2: At a brief 82 minutes (including a long credit sequence), it doesn't have time to fill in any of the plot gaps: it plays like a pitch, rather than a full film.

title: Dracula Untold
review1: [Evans] carries Untold by admirably fulfilling the two essential functions of a period-movie hero: to enunciate comic-book dialogue with Shakespearean authority and to look great with his shirt off.
review2: Might be worth seeing solely for the moment when Dracula says, "I'm worth 1,000 boys and you know it."
review3: It's just a bunch of nonexistent people getting knocked over by nonexistent bats.
review4: Toothless, poorly scripted and drowning in an overload of pointless CGI, Dracula Untold just plain sucks, both as a medieval epic and as the supposed launching pad for a new generation of movie monsters.
review5: "Dracula Untold" is the story of how one man tried to save his homeland from an invading army. It's not about Bela Lugosi feasting on tender white necks in polite society. If you can get past this, then you might enjoy this origins story.

title: Tricked
review1: Can the wisdom of the crowds work for screenwriting too?
review2: The film is experimental in the way that the final product is much more of a labor-intensive challenge for the filmmakers than a cerebral one for the movie-going audience.

title: The Best Of Me
review1: The melodrama feels so hurried and half-baked that the end result isn't just disappointing. It's borderline infuriating.
review2: You know what to expect: a star-crossed romance for lovers from different worlds, kisses in the rain, moonlight swims, fateful separations and the tragic death of at least one leading character.
review3: The Best of Me's chemistry lives in the idea of a second chance at first love - would you take it if you could? - but not between the actors, unfortunately.
review4: I would be amazed to hear even the most ardent Sparks fan defend it as anything more than rubbish.
review5: The Best of Me turns into a half-baked dramatic thriller, with violent confrontations, gunfights, plenty of nasty characters and one big scary action scene.

title: Historias que so existem quando lembradas (Found Memories)
review1: The drama in "Found Memories" is subdued, sometimes almost invisible, but it moves with quiet assurance toward a startling conclusion.
review2: The feeling of twilight permeates Found Memories, which doesn't feel so much like a tale of discovery as it does a eulogy.
review3: Initially treated like the parasite she appears to be, over the course of this crisp, gracefully inflected meditation on time's passage, Rita develops the interest in her subjects that turns an image into more than stolen light.
review4: Brazilian filmmaker Júlia Murat's first narrative feature is a mesmerizing, slow-build marvel.
review5: A pic immersed in the passage of time.

title: Stray Dogs
review1: Stray Dogs really starts to come alive in its second half, when... the family-of-outcasts narrative tips completely into the slippery realm of the avant-garde.
review2: In its most evocative moments offers images that will stick in your mind even longer than they stay on the screen.
review3: [A] glum, humorless exercise in Asian miserablism ...
review4: An extreme, compassionate magnification of the minutiae of second-to-second existence (brushing teeth, counting money).
review5: If this is Tsai Ming-Liang's last film, he's leaving the cinema farther along than he found it.

title: Conte d'hiver (A Tale of Winter)
review1: This winter romance by Rohmer, then in his 70s, demonstrates that faith and art can work miracles.
review2: Rohmer's style, over the years, has become so easy and natural that, at its best, his work never seems like fabricated drama... While this low-budget Tale of Winter may seem simple, it's a masterly simplicity.
review3: As usual, Rohmer works magic with his generally unfamiliar casts, drawing from them more they perhaps realize they're yielding.
review4: Rohmer has become such a master of his chosen classic genre -- the crystalline philosophical tale of character and romantic choice -- that this is a nearly perfect work, in performance as well as execution.
review5: With A Tale of Springtime and A Tale of Winter, Eric Rohmer has given us a pair of wonderful motion pictures... I wonder what Summer and Autumn will bring.

title: Force Majeure
review1: Force Majeure is the best foreign language film I've seen this year. It's one of the best films in any category I've seen this year.
review2: It all comes down to the electric toothbrushes.
review3: When Joanna Hogg (Exhibition, Unrelated) directs this kind of thing, you feel the horror of the situations but here the couple's tension merely becomes irritating after a while.
review4: There's palpable tension here, but how much it emotionally grips us is another matter.
review5: If anything undermines this knowing comedy of manners, it is the sense that it prides itself on being a knowing comedy of manners.

title: The Lookalike
review1: Director Richard Gray, the writer's husband and a man obsessed with slow motion, doesn't build necessary tension into the playfully pulpy material.
review2: The movie, instead of embracing its budgetary limitations, gives off a distracting sense of trying to punch above its weight class.
review3: It simply tries to juggle too many characters, plots, back stories, and motivations; by the time it all comes to a head, viewers might feel that they've missed something.
review4: Fans of neo-noir thrillers could do worse than to give The Lookalike a look.
review5: it's neither clever enough to get away with being stupid, nor stupid enough to just be nasty fun.

title: Laggies
review1: Shelton's comedy isn't just smart, but cheerfully wise; not just funny, but cleverly and endlessly so.
review2: The limbo between adolescence and adulthood provokes a shrug
review3: While a bit hard to buy as an unmotivated screw-up, Knightley gives Megan an endearing bouncy quality, which jibes with the movie's pleasant tone and helps viewers believe Craig's feelings for Megan.
review4: A shrewd little dramedy directed by a woman, written by a woman and told from a woman's perspective, which on those merits alone constitutes a rare and special film worth seeing.
review5: Shallow, smug and bizarrely myopic ...

title: Lilting
review1: A more fitting title for the film would be "Limping."
review2: If "Lilting" was a play, it would run for months.
review3: It is, as the title suggests, sweet - but also slight.
review4: Guilt hangs over "Lilting," a suffocating haze so thick that it permeates every unspoken, non-understood word between characters trying to traverse a frustrating gulf of language and grief.
review5: Hong, who makes his feature debut here, has a masterful command of rhythm, beautifully weaving each strand of the narrative around that momentous opening scene.

title: Kill the Messenger
review1: The muddled movie contains all the elements of a top-notch muckraker, deployed erratically and to increasingly diminished returns.
review2: It's sporadically gripping but ultimately rather frustrating fare, leaving us intrigued enough by the conspiracy-theory backstory to want hard documentary evidence rather than mere dramatic licence.
review3: Jeremy Renner is on terrific form... but the rest of the movie doesn't quite live up to his impressively nuanced performance.
review4: [Renner gives] is a rousing performance but the film is a little one-dimensional in its portrayal of Webb as a result.
review5: Kill the Messenger is earnest and righteous but almost entirely lacking in thrills.

title: Rosewater
review1: Despite a few stylistic flourishes, the production is an earnest and straightforward account of what happened, with moments of naturalistic humor based on some major miscommunication.
review2: Stewart proves himself an adept visual stylist here, using simple techniques such as lighting scenes using the glow of a laptop screen to reflect the darkness that comes from being physically cut off from the people Bahari cares about the most.
review3: The story is engrossing and enraging, and Stewart takes care to remind us that the real victims of oppressive regimes are those who live with them on a daily basis.
review4: The end result isn't always gripping, but it's a solid piece of work that deserves to be seen.
review5: Would you confess to crimes you hadn't committed? I know I would. I'd crack before my tormentors had even cleared their throats, which may be why I found Rosewater so inspiring.

title: Southern Baptist Sissies
review1: Designated for a safe space containing a receptive audience, the play neither provokes nor challenges. It preaches to the choir instead of spreading the word.
review2: The pieces of the play fit together a little too neatly, but "Southern Baptist Sissies" has many powerful displays of heavy emotion, building to a cathartic climax.
review3: To call it stagey is an understatement, since it is simply a filmed version of a performance of (Del Shores') play. As such, it is also overlong at 138 minutes without the benefit of an intermission and comes across as preachy and pedantic.
review4: A filmed staging of Del Shores' provocative stage play, this movie is an engaging exploration of the point where religion and sexuality collide in the American South.

title: Nightcrawler
review1: Like an alternate version of Network in which Faye Dunaway cannibalizes the conscientious William Holden character, Nightcrawler cleverly dispenses with any debate about the tyranny of ratings and the erosion of privacy.
review2: For a movie that tries so hard to be disturbing, Nightcrawler is actually quite comforting. It takes a societal sickness and blames it on a boogeyman.
review3: It takes place almost entirely at night and director of photography Robert Elswit... carves out a marvelous neo-noir atmosphere of Los Angeles at night with his razor-sharp photography of the streets after dark...
review4: In a knockout performance, Jake Gyllenhaal plays Louis Bloom, the type of guy who would not only sell his own mother but would chop her up into tiny pieces to facilitate the transaction.
review5: The fascinating, disturbing Nightcrawler questions the line between crime reportage, and reportage that's a crime in and of itself. That is, if that line still exists at all...

title: The Song
review1: With its strong performances, musical and otherwise, this romantic melodrama is many cuts above the faith-based norm.
review2: The performances are uniformly fine, which keeps things involving. Powell, in particular, is terrific.
review3: A ceaseless, hurtin' tune of a music-driven romantic drama, "The Song" plays out its tired refrain with all the subtlety of a Sunday sermon.
review4: The actors, none of whom have much experience, are quite convincing, but the story - Jed falls, then sees the error of his ways - is an oft-told one.
review5: Predictable, faith-centric film about marital fidelity.

title: Xiu Chun Dao (Brotherhood Of Blades)
review1: Brotherhood of Blades shows promise early on. A good conspiracy can always ignite a stagnant story and the action in the film is swift and impressive. But the feeble special effects take you out of the action and the conclusion is a bloated misfire
review2: Brotherhood Of Blades is a gripping, entertaining martial arts drama in which the cut-and-thrust of the narrative is as important as the swordplay action.

title: After The Fall
review1: The basic story's narrative and psychological simplicity - characters stating their beliefs over and over again - becomes an increasing burden.
review2: "After the Fall" belongs to a type of movie that is too lazy to connect the dots and fill in the blanks between its supposedly teachable moments.
review3: If you can avoid dwelling on its derivative qualities, "After the Fall" has its own case to make about how far the middle class has fallen - and continues to slide.
review4: [The film] has much to recommend, including gorgeous New Mexico landscapes, sumptuous digital cinematography and -- as we might expect from Klein -- virtuoso editing.
review5: Scanlon's desperate dive into a life of armed robbery is simply not believable, despite Bentley's best efforts.

title: Addicted
review1: Woodruff's direction is smooth enough on a technical level, but the film's storytelling has little dimension, even for a melodrama.
review2: The actors are uniformly handsome and mostly serviceable, though the same can't be said about the filmmaking or the writing.
review3: Watching "Addicted" is like eating Cheese Whiz straight from the jar. There's no nutritional value. It's kind of embarrassing. But it does satisfy a base craving for cheap, immediate sensation.
review4: The film unfortunately depicts black female sexuality, a topic rarely portrayed onscreen, with all the depth and subtlety of a late night Cinemax offering.
review5: "Addicted" doesn't know whether it wants to be a modern-day bodice-ripper, a morality-tinged cautionary tale or a serious snapshot of sexual compulsion. Whatever the case, it fails on all fronts.

title: The Perfect Wave
review1: Unfortunately, it's not enough to resurrect this film that boasts lots of message but very little plot and character development.
review2: Christian moviegoers will no doubt appreciate a family-friendly movie with a message they can endorse. But it's going to take more than pretty pictures to convert doubters.

title: Skating to New York
review1: In all, something of a squandered opportunity.
review2: Any meaningful sense of adventure is chilled by an emphasis on domestic strife in this wildly uneven Canadian coming-of-age drama.
review3: Beautifully shot teen wilderness adventure suffers from shallow characterizations and a highly troubling plot misstep.

title: The Casebook Of Eddie Brewer
review1: Blending 'found' with 'objective' footage, Brummy banality with Gothic horror, and reason-defying goings-on with a running meta-commentary from the partisan players, [it is] a singular curiosity.

title: Jake Squared
review1: Goldberg buries the heart of the movie beneath several layers of pretentious film-school effects.
review2: Quotations from sources as varied as Thelonious Monk, Mark Twain and Dr. Seuss appear on screen, imbuing the movie with unearned significance.
review3: Goldberg doesn't display the kind of control needed for this sort of meta-storytelling.
review4: The characters natter endlessly and summon printed quotes from Jean Cocteau, Mark Twain and e.e. cummings onto the screen. But they say nothing that's original, insightful or even interesting.
review5: More enervating than it is ambitious, Jake Squared is partly a romantic comedy and mostly a pseudo-philosophical apology for self-absorption.

title: The Homesman
review1: A stubbornly uncommercial and richly challenging inversion of Americana, this time with an eye towards the pioneer women pushed to the margins of our history books.
review2: It reminds us repeatedly of how fragile civilization was in the Old West.
review3: Actor Tommy Lee Jones again proves himself a fine director with this quietly remarkable revisionist western.
review4: ... this story presents the West as a hard place that creates hard people and destroys the rest.
review5: The Homesman is a strange, challenging western that confounds expectations at every turn.

title: Allies
review1: A winning pair of lead performances make for a tense, thrilling WWII film.

title: Dying of the Light
review1: The rushed and often inchoate execution means there's little in the film that gets the benefit of more than a moment's reflection.
review2: A weirdly misshapen, fitfully intriguing depiction of one man's wayward quest for justice, plainly compromised in ways that only a director's cut could properly illuminate.
review3: On a commercial level, "Dying of the Light" sometimes plays as just another high-concept vehicle for a comically overacting Mr. Cage. But Mr. Schrader's vision is strong enough to rage against the hackier calculations.
review4: Cage's loop-di-loop performance, the movie's surviving asset, at least hints at the themes of institutional illness and mortal decline that must have fascinated Schrader.
review5: Not much good to say except "Cage, Cage against the dying of the light." Apologies to Dylan Thomas.

title: The Theory of Everything
review1: The acting lifts the highly fictionalized story out of the realm of banality and bromide.
review2: A glossy, manipulative but affecting portrait of a brilliant man struck, but not struck down, by a terrible malady.
review3: Redmayne's astonishing physical transformation is the film's showiest feature, but the subtler emotional transformations he and Jones display over the course of their characters' embattled marriage are just as impressive.
review4: Sometimes superficial examination of the life of a genius that never adequately explains how its title applies to its content.
review5: A very convincing and affecting portrayal of an important figure in modern science.

title: The World Made Straight
review1: The film illustrates how the most powerful and welcome stabilizing forces in human life - history, family, geography - can turn so easily into deadly traps.
review2: A strong sense of place emerges, if not a consuming narrative, as the filmmaker strains to connect a 1970s coming-of-age story to historical records and bigger thematic arcs - namely, bloodlines and bloodshed in a rural community.
review3: An overcooked adaptation of a novel by Ron Rash.
review4: The performances are strong... and Earle is particularly memorable. The film glows with a dark energy when he's on screen. But it's too long, has a musical soundtrack that's often intrusive, and sometimes sags when it should be taut with tension
review5: Jeremy Irvine is the sympathetic focus, but it's Noah Wyle who holds the movie together, as a former teacher who lost his job through a malicious student's prank.

title: A Darker Fifty Shades: The Fetish Set
Cyber-Seniors
review1: Who could dislike something so innocuous?
review2: There is nothing earth-shattering here, but it is enough to make you feel bad if you have ever gotten short-tempered while doing technical support for your parents and grandparents.
review3: Though there might have been some real drama to tap in following some seniors' efforts to reconnect with their long-lost loves, Cassaday either doesn't find any such intrigue, or didn't bother looking for it.
review4: A likable intergenerational tale with a bit of unexpected pathos.
review5: If there's a film that will make you want to finally accept that friend request from your grandparents, this one is it.

title: Whiplash
review1: Writer-director Damien Chazelle, who previously co-scripted "The Last Exorcism Part II," ascribes horror characteristics to a naturalistic story masterfully so that they are effective but never intrusive or gratuitous.
review2: The film offers up a breathless battle of wills that inspire a whirlwind of emotions before leaving you on an exhilarated high.
review3: It's a musical, a sports movie and an 'inspirational teacher' movie rolled into one -- and it subverts the clichés of all those genres.
review4: Go and see Whiplash. It's as simple as that. Whiplash is incredible. I really can't believe how good Whiplash is. I can't stop telling people about Whiplash.
review5: Could have easily been a sports film.

title: Beyond the Lights
review1: In every scene here, Prince-Bythewood calmly and sensitively melts our resistance to the outlandish, outsized quality of her plot and stays true to the message she wants to deliver without ever getting pious or preachy.
review2: Has the elements of a classic backstage story, but they don't quite crystallize into an integral drama.
review3: It's a movie about a rising superstar that features two of them-Mbatha-Raw and Parker, both enormously appealing, impossibly attractive performers with big futures ahead of them.
review4: "Beyond the Lights" is a faint shadow of 1992's "The Bodyguard," without the star power of Whitney Houston or Kevin Costner.
review5: The type of mainstream, commercial romance that's increasingly rare: one that never loses sight of actual tangible pain and hope in its beautifully portrayed characters.

title: Traitors
review1: Traitors operates according to a standard drug-smuggling-drama template, though it colors its familiar elements with just enough distinctive personality to allow it to stand on its own.
review2: A rare genre film from the Maghreb that centers on a female universe, Traitors benefits immensely from a spiky lead turn from newcomer Chaimae Ben Acha, whose innate charisma helps paper over the film's at times overly familiar plot twists.
review3: Gullette strains to make the outcome upbeat, which damages credibility somewhat. Still, lead thesp Chaimae Ben Acha has charisma, and the pic makes the most of a manifestly low budget.
review4: There are not a lot of actual incidents in the film: no chases or shootouts. Yet Gullette creates real tension, through silences, quiet encounters with the drug lord and the extremely expressive face of Ben Acha.
review5: Takes some unexpected turns in its last act.

title: Test Pilot Pirx (Test pilota Pirxa)
review1: This Eastern European co-production has engaging ideas floating around, but feels off-balance through the entire story.

title: Last Summer
review1: Last Summer suffers from a sparse storyline which will make it too slow for many, but Thiedeman's moody camerawork gives the film a lyrical quality that perfectly captures the sadness of a season about to end.
review2: One of the finest directorial debuts of recent years is Mark Thiedeman's. Here a young helmer paints the screen with complex textures and sound, perfectly capturing the joys and throes of teens in love in a very small Arkansas town.

title: Loitering With Intent
review1: It all adds up to not much from director by Adam Rapp, although Tomei is effortlessly captivating (as usual) and Rockwell is always worth watching.
review2: There's too much loitering and not enough intent.
review3: Simply the latest in a string of pointless low-budget exercises in angsty Big Apple self-reflection.
review4: Ms. Tomei, Mr. Rockwell and Mr. Geraghty get stray laughs, but "Loitering With Intent" mostly plays like an excuse for its makers to hang out.
review5: The title may suggest acts of indecency, but if there's anything this mild dramedy could use, it's a little more raciness.

title: To Write Love on Her Arms (Renee)
review1: To Write Love On Her Arms is a symphonious specimen of the melding of dazzling visuals, masterful musical scoring, and remarkable performances.
review2: Dennings is quite effective, creating a plausible depiction of ruination without slipping into a showy performance, emphasizing hysterics.
review3: Harrowing, fanciful and beautifully filmed bio-drama built around a coy and confident performance by Kat Dennings. Deserves to be an instant cult favorite.

title: Private Peaceful
review1: Melancholy runs deep in "Private Peaceful," a richly appointed British period piece about fraternal loyalty adapted from the book of the same name by "War Horse" author Michael Morpurgo.
review2: A World War I fable that's as stiff as an Eton collar and as plodding as a draft horse.
review3: A long, long, trail a-winding, to be sure. But fans of PBS, history and a certain kind of old-fashioned moviemaking may fall in.
review4: O'Connor captures all the beauty of these rural childhoods without skimping on the harsh realities of 20th-century feudalism.
review5: O'Connor shows his old-school expertise in the charming country childhood sequences, where the film feels most individual and alive.

title: Black November
review1: There's little going on in the final product other than good intentions, as Jeta Amata always seems overreaching for the right buttons to push.
review2: Hollywood and Nollywood collaborate to underwhelming effect in Jeta Amata's impassioned but inert issue thriller.
review3: At once passionate and cynical, Amata skillfully lays out the ways that Nigeria is screwed.
review4: There's a go-for-broke vigor to the way Mr. Amata cuts to the conflict in most scenes, but the heavy-handedness across the board imposes some significant limitations. Mr. Amata, though, pulls no punches with his ending.
review5: Filled with declamatory speeches, stereotypical characters and heavily telegraphed, melodramatic plot developments, the film fails to work as either thriller or politically themed drama.

title: Ask Me Anything
review1: The edgy coming-of-age tale "Ask Me Anything" begins with a snarky, bubble-gum vibe that gives way to something far deeper and meaningful.
review2: Suffers from a limp story, but banks on good actors trying to make the best of the hand they've been dealt.

title: Life Partners
review1: The two stars display a winning chemistry in this amusingly observant study of female friendship.
review2: Meester and Jacobs have an easy, authentic chemistry, but there isn't enough structure or storytelling thrust to sustain interest in the plot: Triumphs, calamities and reunions keep happening, but none contains real dramatic heft.
review3: Fogel refuses to pander by pretending that the girls can fix everything with a hug. Sacrifices must be made.
review4: The charming story about millennial confusion is deftly written by Susanna Fogel (who also directs) and Joni Lefkowitz, and the dialog actually sounds like the way a pair of smart and funny twentysomethings might really talk.
review5: Most of the time, the banter doesn't sound like banter; the movie shares Sasha and Paige's unforced shorthand.

title: The Better Angels
review1: It feels more like a poem. Or, at times, a symphony. But it's much less effective as an actual movie.
review2: "God tells truths in parables," someone says - a line that Edwards most likely aspires to take possession of, as if his poetic, pictorial parable had its own truths to tell.
review3: The narrative is gentle and sparse. The beautifully photographed imagery, shot in elegant, deep-focus black-and-white, is exceptional. The music is richly classical.
review4: A gorgeous look at the raw, wooded Indiana of the early 1800s and a dreamy study of the boy Lincoln who was destined to leave it behind.
review5: History, as subject matter, is hard enough to sell as cinema. The Better Angels will not make the struggle any easier.

title: Foxcatcher
review1: It''s remarkable to see this movie turn a lurid murder into a takedown of the myths we Americans like to tell ourselves.
review2: The movie remains fascinating because of the fine performances of the three key characters and the mystery of what is happening in du Pont's head.
