review3: Foxcatcher pins the viewer to the mat with its emotionally bruising tale of class, ambition and the pursuit of sporting excellence.
review4: Here is a movie that regards people with sympathetic gazes rather than details, fully aware how all things will pan out but fascinated enough by the inner-workings of flawed psyches to keep our eyes watching on in sobering deliberation.
review5: Plays like a slow-motion wrestling bout, the characters edging and circling each other, occasionally finding an emotional grip before sliding apart to re-assess the stakes and manoeuvre positions.

title: Big Muddy
review1: It's a quintessentially Canadian idea mixed in with the material Moneo borrows from various hard-boiled film noirs and sun-dappled westerns.
review2: Big Muddy often looks darkly sublime but the script, expanded by Moneo from his 2011 short, isn't quite up to the task.
review3: It dawdles and meanders a little too much in the getting there, but at least once Martha and Stan are in the same house, Big Muddy starts livening up its beat-up setting.
review4: Jefferson Moneo, tackling his first feature, has a good handle on storytelling economy, and gives his unique setting ample time to shine.
review5: A muddle, with a badly miscast femme fatale

title: The Last Of Robin Hood
review1: [It] looks lowly and limp, and we seldom feel just how much is at stake.
review2: The film becomes a showcase for Kline and Sarandon - and a reminder of how great actors can light up the screen, staying with you even as the rest of the film slips away.
review3: A character study of an ultimately pathetic man.
review4: Terrific performances help mine the poignancy in a legendary tabloid story.
review5: Since it's impossible to see what the attraction would be, the film's emotional logic fizzles.

title: The Humbling
review1: This is Pacino's best film performance in years. In playing an actor who has lost the art of fooling himself, he reveals with mordant wit the terrors of diminished capacity. To watch him do it is a master class.
review2: "The Humbling" reveals an ominous gulf between the director and his theme ...
review3: Pacino gives a refreshingly quiet and understated performance with poignant moments of vulnerability. It is the most consistent factor in a film that is frustratingly inconsistent.
review4: An unusually charming dark comedy about an actor teetering on the edges of reality, fantasy and career.
review5: The movie is too shrewd to qualify as a jeremiad, but underneath the comedy are boiling undercurrents of anger and despair.

title: To Write Love on Her Arms
Racing Hearts
review1: Colin is such a duplicitous example of manhood it's extremely hard to warm to him or his existential crisis. It's certainly not helped by Dornan's lacklustre performance that recalls nothing of what made him so watchable in The Fall.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1
review1: A solid lead-up to the finale.
review2: I appreciated its more downbeat intellectual grasp of how wars can be fought through film and media.
review3: A very odd film that ends as abruptly as it begins, so I guess we must all tune in next year to find out if it actually amounts to anything. This is just how big movies work now.
review4: A franchise inches toward its conclusion
review5: It may not have the visual panache of the first two films, but it makes up for it with a thrilling series of events that set us up nicely for the final film in the franchise.

title: The White Haired Witch of Lunar Kingdom
review1: "White Haired Witch" is plagued with a copious cast and an overly complex storyline. Keeping track of everyone is difficult and the screenplay is laughably bad in spots, making it even less palatable.
review2: The performances are stiff and uninspired, the storyline is trite, the awkward special effects stand out like a sore thumb, and everything is just so elongated that a couple of decent action scenes won't save an hour and a half of complete boredom.
review3: With lame action, dull storytelling and a cast that look like they simply don't care, it's sub-par style over non-existent substance as The White Haired Witch of Lunar Kingdom laboriously plods through its 104 minute running-time.
review4: [a] kitsch-fu confection, with its overblown sentimentalism matched only by its tacky day-glo backgrounds... The action choreography, however, is imaginative and excellent.
review5: With an incomprehensible plot and boring fight scenes there's not much to recommend when it comes to The White Haired Witch of Lunar Kingdom.

title: Life of Riley
review1: As in all of Resnais's theatrical adaptations, the performances are warm and naturalistic, countering the artificiality of the stage conventions and illuminating the universal struggle to create personal meaning in lives bound by social convention.
review2: So frothy and chiffonesque it threatens to burst its own cheeks.
review3: Where the director's early work was haunted by the Holocaust, the atomic bomb and the Algerian war, Life of Riley blithely celebrates love, possibility and absurdist surprises.
review4: "Life of Riley" is neither especially profound nor riotously funny.
review5: If this isn't a grand finale (2012's "You Ain't Seen Nothin' Yet" felt that way), it's still an affectionate coda for a master.

title: Listen Up Philip
review1: If Philip showed a bit of personality beyond being a boor and a bore, he might be worth almost two hours of attention.
review2: Perry's acerbic sense of the literary/academic lifestyle - which, oddly enough, involves less actual writing and teaching than drinking and "thinking" - is both exceptionally funny and deeply sad.
review3: If the point of Listen Up Philip is that talented people can also be colossal jerks - well, that's about as eye-opening as saying that pizza is a hugely popular menu item.
review4: A scalding look at a writer's life
review5: It's a relief when the narrative abandons its verbose antiheroes and turns instead to Moss's silently expressive face, which speaks volumes.

title: Low Down
review1: Somewhere over the rainbow the skies are blue, that's the dream. Some make it, some don't - this eloquent daughter's tale shows both sides.
review2: Gets stuck in a cycle of addiction and morning-after regret while missing a chance to explore the how and why of its characters.
review3: "Low Down" nicely evokes a smokey mood of '50s jazz and Hollywood noir and deserves points for its emotional straightforwardness, but its tired story and deliberate pace never really draw you in.
review4: Whiplash is like one of those Buddy Rich solos the kid idolizes: hot, sweaty and in-your-face. Low Down is like the version of Billy Strayhorn's Lush Life played in one of this film's club scenes: somber, moody and cool to the touch.
review5: The acting makes it a far more compelling ride than it otherwise would have been.

title: The Liberator
review1: Simple enough for audiences who know nothing about Bolívar, poetic enough for those who grew up reading about El Libertador in school books.
review2: Arvelo, a Venezuelan like Bolivar, touches many of the essential bases in Bolivar's story. But, perhaps inevitably, he is only able to achieve little more than mere touches.
review3: As if the film's ostentatious aerial vistas, merely functional scene-writing and score weren't distracting enough, Mr. Sexton's dialogue freezes dead any simulation of the period with tone-deaf lines amid Bolívar's impassioned rhetoric.
review4: How disappointing that a movie about challenging authority should be such a slave to convention.
review5: Édgar Ramírez is electifying as Simón Bolívar, the Venezuelan land owner turned warrior. But even Ramírez cannot liberate this movie from a clichéd script.

title: Pioneer
review1: Skjoldbjaerg is unable to make us care as much as we should, and gives the film a kind of muddy look that translates directly into the viewer's mood.
review2: "Pioneer" has the necessary parts for a finger-pointing thriller that could boil the blood if handled well. Alas, this story of workers wounded by corrupt oil industrialists and politicians sinks from drawn-out scenes and too few surprises.
review3: A brooding psychological drama where everything that happens is open to multiple interpretations and figuring out who if anyone is on your side gets harder and harder to do.
review4: Mr. Skjoldbjaerg, who also tapped Norwegian history with his bank robbery re-enactment "Nokas," doesn't convey a creeping atmosphere of moral rot so much as an irksome glumness.
review5: The underwater sequences stun and terrify - nothing says claustrophobia quite like two weeks in a pressurized diving bell with someone you can't necessarily trust - and there's almost as much moisture and terror on land to drive Petter round the bend.

title: R100
review1: "R100" suggests that extreme and perverse films allow the everyman to seek thrills in his otherwise-monotonous life.
review2: Matsumoto works overtime to keep this vital once the basic premise has been established, but the cultural subtext is so potent that he really can't go wrong.
review3: A little punishment goes a long way, especially for the rest of us, yet on it drags, torturously, slap, kick, slap, kick.
review4: Matsumoto says he wanted to make a film that transcended the idea of genre, and in that respect, he has succeeded admirably.
review5: You'd expect more yucks from the country that bequeathed tentacle porn.

title: Late Phases
review1: A sprightly horror movie about finding new purpose for old bones.
review2: Late Phases fails to deliver either shocks or real drama.
review3: The narrative ends up working in a smaller scope than one might expect given the premise of a beast plaguing a community, but the journey getting to the finish is exhilarating all the same.
review4: Less ambitious but more satisfyingly resolved than Bogliano's last effort, Here Comes the Devil, Late Phases is a reminder of how much monster movies rely on what happens when the monster's not on screen.
review5: Features some great performances, a worthwhile sense of strange humanity, and, ultimately, a handful of truly cool werewolf sequences.

title: The Divine Move
review1: Excessive violence and off-the-wall plotting undermine an intriguing game-based premise.

title: La Peau douce (The Soft Skin)
review1: Francois Truffaut's "The Soft Skin" is being revived at the very moment when it seems uncannily prophetic
review2: François Truffaut's fourth feature, The Soft Skin, has never gotten much respect -- even though many people (myself included) regard it as one of his best.
review3: Truffaut does show that he can make a solidly carpentered film like anybody else.
review4: [A] steely 1964 study in the cruel mechanics of illicit love.
review5: It's a curiously crude and hackneyed drama to come from Mr. Truffaut, but this way of using his actors and working his camera is up to his style.

title: The Way He Looks
review1: Brazilian writer-director Daniel Ribeiro displays an assured sense of tone in this debut feature, sustaining an air of fragile beauty but never once slipping into preciousness.
review2: Ribeiro lacks a sense of dramatic construction, with the narrative stumbling about thoughtlessly, retracing the same ground over and over.
review3: A warm, smart and thoroughly delightful coming-of-age story.
review4: "Admirable throughout is the balance that Ribeiro strikes between dewy eroticism and the contextualization of sexuality as just a single aspect of one's identity, albeit an essential one."
review5: The Way He Looks almost collapses at several points into a saccharine mess, but Ribeiro manages to keep the dramatic tension alive.

title: Annie
review1: The song selection and its presentation seems out of his control.
review2: Even Sandy the dog looks like he's had enough.
review3: After its sly opening--meta-jokes about the Annie we expect; a song-and-dance about class divides--the flick mostly gives us a cocky, fully-formed child, broadly shticked-out adults, a musical-ness that seems show-offy, and almost no political savvy.
review4: Annie has a fun, fizzing feel-good factor but, unfortunately, little in the way of lasting resonance.
review5: Despite an authentically enthusiastic performance by Oscar nominee Quvenzhane Wallis, "Annie" sinks and sinks hard with the sounding of more than a few false notes.

title: The Physician
review1: For those who miss the substance and scope of films like "Lawrence of Arabia" and "The Man Who Would Be King," Philipp Stoelzl's "The Physician" restores one's faith in the medium - if not necessarily one's faith in faith.
review2: Old fashioned, absurdly overlong, but a lovely recreation of the Dark Ages and an entertaining ride, thanks to Ben Kingsley, Stellan Skarsgard and Tom Payne.

title: Exodus: Gods and Kings
review1: Ridley Scott never answers the important question: Why?
review2: Yet I say unto thee that this hath many moments which be good-ish and watch-able enough and by-the-Book, and yet smacketh of being too graven and tablet-y in their images. If only this wereth not a moment-y mega-movie but an actual, feeling-filled film...
review3: When it comes to the plagues and the parting of the Red Sea, Scott pulls out all the stops. The Nile doesn't simply run red; it has ferocious crocodiles snapping up the locals, too. It's the stuff in between the set-piece scenes that's the problem.
review4: It is devoid of any sort of compelling emotional background or natural storytelling acumen. This last detail is especially damning, as this is one of the best-known tales in the Western World.
review5: The movie wastes its fine actors and, more importantly, its rich subject matter.

title: Son of a Gun
review1: A not-so-thrilling heist thriller that drones along mechanically between explosions and car crashes with Ewan McGregor, who is making entirely too many movies these days, none of them worth writing home about.
review2: It's all put together with a crisp confidence that suggests its writer-director will swiftly move on to bigger things.
review3: When the focus is firmly on McGregor and Thwaites, the movie crackles; the actors rip into the toxic father-son dynamic between their characters, and their rapport gives the key action sequences a real kick.
review4: Julius Avery wrote and directed with an eye toward a fast pace and grim atmospherics.
review5: It's done extremely well and with a great deal of verve.

title: Veronika Decides to Die
review1: There's never a moment when Young seems in control of her material, while the performers flail and flounder, trying to unearth some measure of truth in the hoariest plot twist.

title: Three Night Stand
review1: "Three Night Stand" gives us the kind of unromanticized romance that you rarely find in an escapist rom-com.
review2: What makes Three Night Stand work is Kiely's willingness to occasionally let things get dark, a welcome change from the constant chirpiness of typical American romantic comedies.
review3: [The set-up] suggests we're going to get a frisky screwball farce, but with more regrets and recriminations than jokes, the outcome is a lot more downbeat and a lot less fun.
review4: "Three Night Stand" is refreshingly unsentimental in a lot of respects, and gimlet-eyed about romantic relationships, rare in the genre, but the film lacks a strong center.
review5: Sam Huntington excels as the hapless, puppy-dog kind of guy who, despite the odds, continues to believe in romance and happy-ever-after endings.

title: Unbroken
review1: A long, grinding tribute to The Passion of the American.
review2: Jolie's solidly old-fashioned film doesn't probe particularly deeply into its hero's psyche, but striking Oscar-nominated cinematography and O'Connell's compelling lead performance ensures it remains a rousing celebration of human resilience and courage.
review3: Jolie's sentimental direction is forceful rather than reflective, stiffly moving from one tribulation to another without pausing to reflect on what any of this actually means.
review4: "Unbroken" is the film that will bring hope and inspiration not only to American audiences, but those suffering in war zones and under dictators the world over. That makes it a far more dangerous movie to oppressors than "The Interview" could ever be.
review5: Treads over familiar waters that still inspire and despite its flaws is a solid piece of work by its fledgling director.

title: Song One
review1: Despite the delicate shadings Hathaway brings to the role, Song One moves inexorably from wan to wearying.
review2: There are no real surprises here, just lives played out quietly and succinctly under the seductive spell of music.
review3: The film, like the world it's part of, remains just a little too precious, a little too self-involved, a little too insular. Instead of singing out, directly to us, it hums its little tune only to itself.
review4: Starts off as a singularly strong slice-of-life drama before dissipating into thin air.
review5: Anyone with the slightest allergy to emo-tinged millennial attitudinizing should steer clear.

title: Digging Up the Marrow
review1: Digging Up the Marrow is a playfully self-reflexive exercise whose endless in-jokes will best be appreciated by only the most ardent genre aficionados.
review2: Much of Digging Up The Marrow plays like Green's love letter to his fans and to the importance of fandom in genre filmmaking.
review3: Loses me in a haze of winks and Adam Green celebrating Adam Green.
review4: Works as a dry comedy, a slow-burn campfire story, and as a clever look at our frustratingly one-sided relationship with the paranormal.
review5: The concept feels strained at feature length as it never establishes consistent tension or generates any meaningful suspension of disbelief.

title: The Imitation Game
review1: Dazzlingly performed with great creativity. [full review in Spanish]
review2: A flawed biopic anchored by solid performances and fascinating drama even if it poorly handles its gay subject matter.
review3: A very thoughtful and bewildering drama about a man who was meant to do great things in a world that was not ready to accept his eccentricities.
review4: An enthralling spy thriller-turned-prestige bio pic that features a world-class performance by Benedict Cumberbatch.
review5: The intriguing subject matter is, to an increasingly dismaying degree, rendered moot by filmmaker Morten Tyldum's run-of-the-mill sensibilities...

title: Wild Card
review1: It's hard to not feel a slight sense of disappointment when what looks like a steaming hot slab of fresh action filmmaking hot off the grill turns out to be microwaved leftovers.
review2: There will be abundant laying waste of unworthy opponents, and the groans you hear will not be his.
review3: Much of the climactic energy is focused on a series of trumped-up, ultraviolent fight sequences. Most of the narrative depth gets lost in the process.
review4: Piles of noirish exposition get the better of Jason Statham in this unpleasantly retrograde crime drama. What happened in Vegas should have stayed there.
review5: Unjustly ignored.

title: 3 Nights In The Desert
review1: Needless to say, a lot of unresolved issues rise from hibernation during this rural weekend, but the characters, situations and dialogue too seldom escape cliche in Gabriel Cowan's watchable but unmemorable feature.
review2: The film features three gifted actors -- Wes Bentley, Amber Tamblyn and Vincent Piazza -- doing their best to animate a very stale script.
review3: If the aim of the picture is to trigger introspection in an audience about the consequences of the choices one makes in life, then bull's eye!
review4: ...3 Nights in the Desert is a thoroughly unpleasant homecoming of three friends getting the band back together...
review5: A three-handed "Big Chill" that goes on two nights too long, and still feels rushed, underwritten, under prepared.

title: Wild
review1: It captures an emotional memoir without making it feel like a didactic tale of triumph over adversity.
review2: Thanks to a powerhouse performance by Reese Witherspoon, Vallée succeeds in avoiding those potential cliches again and again and again.
review3: The movie may not be as convincing as the book in depicting Cheryl's journey toward spiritual fulfillment, but Wild's considerable power is bound up with Reese Witherspoon's performance and what we know about her.
review4: If you're looking for a film that's contemplative, honest, and engaging, you can't go far wrong with Cheryl Strayed's trip into the Wild.
review5: We may not doubt that Cheryl will finish the hike, but we're not at all sure what kind of woman she will meet at the end of it.

title: WWJD What Would Jesus Do? The Journey Continues
The Strange Affair of Uncle Harry (Guilty of Murder?)
review4: Had it ended two minutes earlier, it would have been a considerably more successful film. Like many Hollywood dramas of the 1940s, it stumbles during its dismount.
review5: Couched in snapshots of provincial America as fond and sardonic as any in Shadow of a Doubt

title: Remembrance (Die Verlorene Zeit)
review1: An engaging but uneven melodrama.
review2: Emotionally powerful and achingly romantic, despite the origins of the story in a WWII concentration camp, Remembrance is compelling viewing ... the gentle, subtle, restrained ending is exquisite
review3: A moving film and one that is deserving of attention

title: Home Sweet Hell
review1: [A] noxious piece of crud.
review2: If Katherine Heigl thought the unappetizing dark comedy "Home Sweet Hell" might somehow help her flagging film career, she was greatly mistaken.
review3: While the oafish men come off poorly, the treatment of women as nothing more than schemers and monstrous Martha Stewart clones seems woefully past its expiration date.
review4: It's high time Katherine Heigl sent up her image as a controlling bitch in heels; too bad her dark comic turn takes place in an otherwise dreadful, misogynistic slog of a film.
review5: Wilson is an engaging actor, but he's stuck treading water in a movie with little action. Heigl, on the other hand, seems bored and aloof. She's playing against type, but she's stiff and doesn't make a fun villain here.

title: Human Capital
review1: The film is further undone by an overwrought ending and toneless conclusion that proves too soft to energize the movie's implied though underdeveloped social critique.
review2: Valeria Bruni Tedeschi contributes an affecting performance as the rich boy's spiritually bereft mother, whose self-worth has been smothered by luxury.
review3: Paolo Virzi's electrifying film is a murder mystery. The main question is, Who killed Italian society?
review4: With its stylish lines and creamy production values, "Human Capital" combines the luxurious look of a classic wish-fulfillment fantasy with a stinging critique of capitalism's excesses and psychic costs.
review5: In "Human Capital," the destinies of two Italian families become intertwined after a hit-and-run accident in which the victim is a waiter.

title: Salvation Army
review1: For a film rooted in a personal story, "Salvation Army" feels awfully remote.
review2: Writer-turned-filmmaker Abdellah Taïa's lovely and elliptical adaptation of his autobiographical novel about growing up gay, effeminate, and powerless in Morocco.
review3: Though the film's European scenes carry too little dramatic weight and might be confusing for those unfamiliar with the novel, the Morocco-set opening 40 minutes are beautifully and quietly observed.
review4: Young Moroccan scribe Abdellah Taia moves into the director's seat with the screen version of his autobiographical novel Salvation Army, losing much of the texture in translation from pen to camera.
review5: A tale that serves to subvert the romanticized version of gay life in Morocco found in Paul Bowles or William S. Burroughs.

title: Tom Sawyer & Huckleberry Finn
review1: Lackluster version of classic Twain tale has some violence.

title: The Immigrant
review1: The physical look of the movie is a revelation of a lost past.
review2: The film is an achievement. Its complex reckoning of moral decency deserves a bigger audience.
review3: The Immigrant functions quite impressively as a character piece (or pieces, as the film is as much about Bruno as Ewa), a condemnation of the subjugation of foreigners and as a uniquely beautiful period piece.
review4: One of the wonders of the film is how Gray reveals unexpected depths and dimensions of these characters throughout their journeys.
review5: The Immigrant's handsome Blu-Ray transfer should be welcomed with open arms, even if there's little meat on the bone here for fans of special features.

title: A Most Violent Year
review1: A Most Violent Year moves so sluggishly that it allows a great deal of time to notice many distracting elements.
review2: Chandor is paying respect to a serious American moviemaking style employed 40 years ago by directors like Sidney Lumet and Francis Ford Coppola, in which a system's structure is brought into the cold, hard light.
review3: This is serious filmmaking for people who want to think about what they have seen long after they leave the theater.
review4: The film bears comparison to Lumet's Dog Day Afternoon and Prince Of The City for its sense of place and time, and to Coppola's first Godfather for its depiction of a man who places himself at a moral crossroads in defence of his family.
review5: A Most Violent Year resonates as the rare film to not simply take its superficial cues from The Godfather, but to truly understand its underlying ideas -- and, more impressive still, to re-work them into something thrillingly unique.

title: Killers
review1: This seemingly generic thriller has plenty of twists in store, but perhaps none as surprising and impressive as its ability to manipulate the viewer - first to side with the villains, then to question one's own core beliefs.
review2: Though hardly immune to cliché ... this squirmy tale of dueling addictions gets points for skillful spikes of humor.
review3: For those of you who like it, have at it. Count me out.
review4: Amateurishly realized sensationalism trumps character-driven drama throughout Killers, so Nomura and Bayu become generically morbid sociopaths with way too much time, and blood, on their hands.
review5: "Killers" has plenty to offer genre fans - provided they don't bolt during its opening scene of a tied-up woman being beaten to death with a mallet ...

title: Happy Valley
review1: It's not a groundbreaking thesis, but we still get a fascinating tour of a town that may never be the same again.
review2: The film could've benefited from another 15 or 20 minutes of detail and nuance. What's there, though, is strong, thoughtful and disturbing.
review3: Here it is, folks, in your face. Will you look or return to your own private Happy Valley?
review4: [A] thorough, thoughtful and disturbing documentary ...
review5: The documentary offers a compelling overview of the case, but Bar-Lev spends too much time painting Paterno as a victim and scapegoat. That advocacy doesn't sit well.

title: Straight Outta Tompkins
review1: Zephyr Benson wrote, directed, produced and starred in this fitfully engaging but unconvincing account of his own tumultous, drug-addled youth.
review2: "Straight Outta Tompkins" undeniably commands attention but also strives for authenticity ham-handedly.
review3: Only in his early 20s, Zephyr Benson makes a remarkably assured debut as writer, director and star of "Straight Outta Tompkins," his tongue-in-cheek title for his past as a middle-class drug dealer in lower Manhattan.
review4: Straight Outta Tompkins is rarely boring, but neither does it come close to attaining the hard-hitting moral force its creator is clearly striving for.

title: Beside Still Waters
review1: Any interesting comment or funny remark must have happened off-camera.
review2: Scenes flirt with cliché, yet the writing has spark (one very funny sequence cuts among radically different interpretations of the previous night's revelries), and Tim Naylor's photography is pretty.
review3: In sticking with seven friends and one outsider/interloper, Lowell hews so close to the reunion-film formula he ends up stifling anything new that may otherwise have resulted.
review4: ... manages some amusing moments and shows flashes of visual flair along the way, but it treads familiar territory with scenarios that gradually feel more contrived than authentic.
review5: Beside Still Waters grows a bit choppy in the third act, but like the best ensemble films the ensemble itself is enough of a reason to travel these rough narrative waters.

title: You're Not You
review1: Despite offering a well-timed look at the realities of the disease, the movie clunkily eschews cinematic creativity for emotional manipulation. Inquisitive ice-bucket challengers, consider yourselves warned.
review2: This well-intentioned weepie never quite rises far enough above its movie-of-the week architecture to hit all its intended emotional pressure points.
review3: Despite holes in the storytelling, Ms. Swank and Ms. Rossum keep it real.
review4: Nicholas Sparks didn't write You're Not You, but he might as well have, given its familiar disease-of-the-week plot filled with scenic locations and gorgeous people.
review5: Wolfe overplays his hand at almost every key turn.

title: The Babadook
review1: The line between terrifying reality and terrifying fantasy isn't so much blurred as altogether obliterated.
review2: This simple yet shiver-inducing tale, the auspicious feature debut of Australian writer/director Jennifer Kent, makes for one of the better horror movies of recent times.
review3: It presents grief as a demon, questions reality, and creeps out the viewer by making psychopathology seem like something that could happen to anybody.
review4: At its heart, "The Babadook" is a story of mother and son, whose relationship ultimately determines whether they survive the demon - or die trying.
review5: In the running with Boyhood as my favorite movie of 2014 is another work that turns on the challenges of parenting. This one is a tad more insane.

title: Odd Man Out
review1: This may be Reed's most pretentious film, but it also happens to be one of his very best, beautifully capturing the poetry of a city at night.
review2: Carol Reed has made his film with deliberation and care, and has achieved splendid teamwork from every member of the cast. Occasionally too intent on pointing his moral and adorning his tale, he has missed little in its telling.
review3: Carol Reed's first great postwar film.
review4: Odd Man Out is a picture to see, to absorb in the darkness of the theatre and then go home and talk about.

title: No Man of Her Own
review1: Most of the strength of the movie rests on Stanwyck -- one of the greatest of all screen actresses -- and her ability to sell this story.

title: Adieu au langage (Goodbye to Language)
review1: I'm attaching four stars more out of helplessness than critical acumen, by the way; if the film is beyond language, it's certainly beyond a traditional rating system.
review2: Throughout this enigmatic film's short running time, I couldn't for the life of me make out what Godard was trying to say.
review3: A film that's stuffed with language, its title notwithstanding.
review4: Anyone interested in the possibilities of the moviegoing experience - what can happen in a dark theater - owes it to themselves to say hello to "Goodbye to Language."
review5: At 84, Godard is still looking for new ways to express himself, though he thinks it harder than ever to achieve meaningful interpersonal communication in the information age.

title: Manny
review1: It makes for a choppy, unsatisfying portrait when any topic outside the worshipful career momentum and expected dazzling fight footage - personal demons, his growth in a corrupt sport, the weight of being an icon - is addressed.
review2: Banal, stentorian narration by Liam Neeson ("Once victory is stolen from you, what are you left with?") mostly gives the sense that it's the viewer being carried around the ring.
review3: Only a fool would say it to his face, but eight-time divisional boxing champ Manny (Pacman) Pacquiao has a limp swing as a documentary subject.
review4: Even as a promotional piece, Manny is too thin a nonfiction portrait of Manny Pacquiao, one of the greatest boxers of the modern era and the only one in history to win titles in eight different weight classes.
review5: Boxing docu glorifies Pacquiao but skims the surface.

title: God Help the Girl
review1: God Help the Girl is about aspirations and goals, musical or otherwise. Murdoch is working some things out here, gracefully on the whole.
review2: "Girl" meanders narratively and with random chronology ...
review3: The movie is like a milk shake so sweet that you want to keep drinking, even as you begin to gag.
review4: It's adorable. It's also very thin.
review5: Browning, staring down the camera and singing up a storm, brings buckets of soulfulness to a script that might not be terribly deep.

title: Echoes
review1: Must be plenty of space between the ears of the guy who thought up this horror flick. Perhaps that's why it's called "Echoes."
review2: Echoes is a perfectly good-enough ghost story that shines a noteworthy spotlight on the inherent horrors of sleep paralysis.
review3: Thanks to a lazy and amateurishly-written screenplay, Echoes is nothing but a bland horror offering that is more likely to bore you rather than give you the slightest chill.
review4: Puts its horror elements on the back burner for a shaggy, nonsensically developed supernatural murder-mystery involving characters who are the diametric opposite of brainy.

title: Love Hunter
review1: The film's a sad, gentle valediction for a young artist's dream.
review2: The premise might remind you of John Carney's Once, but this is grittier and less sentimental, grounded in disappointment and working-class drudgery.
review3: Love Hunter is consistently engaging, mainly thanks to its star's winning personality.
review4: In its feel for nocturnal light, this is one of the most refreshing New York independent features since Ramin Bahrani's "Man Push Cart."
review5: Lots of bittersweet charm, but lacking some reality checks. Like hey, the American dream is currently located under the rubble of the ongoing economic crisis in progress. Not to mention how US bombs buried Serbia under rubble 16 years ago this week.

title: Kidnapping Mr. Heineken
review1: One capably staged chase sequence apart, it's not one to set the pulse racing.
review2: Not only is Hopkins's Freddy incomparably more charismatic than any of his captors, he's the only one who, weirdly enough, seems to be enjoying the ordeal. But maybe that's simply a matter of pay scale.
review3: It fails to accentuate the peculiarities of its from-the-headlines tale and instead turns itself into a rather generic and predictable kidnapping thriller.
review4: Anthony Hopkins sleep-walks into his cell as a captive lager magnate.
review5: A disengaging thriller that struggles to compel the viewer, telling a unique, real-life story in an all too generic fashion.

title: Big Eyes
review1: A feminist psycho-melodrama made without insight or dramatic excitement.
review2: Big Eyes is the most substantial film Tim Burton has made since Ed Wood.
review3: That Big Eyes is the best film Burton has directed in almost a decade is no exaggeration.
review4: Burton is telling a fascinating story here, and his confident sense of time and place, allied to Adams's adept performance as the increasingly assertive artist, provide many pleasures.
review5: Athough this is not an entirely successful change of pace for director Tim Burton, there's enough in the story to make his version of events very watchable.

title: Living Is Easy With Eyes Closed
review1: "Living Is Easy With Eyes Closed" is subtle in the truest sense, in that it says and suggests much, and does so definitely, but through a minimum of means.
review2: Javier Camara, best known here for his work with Pedro Almodovar, is quite good as the teacher, delivering a performance of real tenderness and depth. In Spanish with subtitles.
review3: Ultimately good-hearted and gracefully handled enough to transcend the leisurely slightness of its material.
review4: The actors help to bring this engaging tale to life.
review5: An evocative portrait of a time and a place and also a subtly rewarding character study of three ordinary people in search of that extraordinary dream, a taste of freedom.

title: Avenged
review1: "Avenged" unabashedly revels in vigilantism and poetic justice.
review2: Call it a rape/revenge movie with an occult twist, or a simple slasher flick with something to say about the hidden power of certain minorities.
review3: Playing out like The Crow meets I Spit On Your Grave with a Native American twist, Avenged is frenzied, ferocious, and a bloody good revenge story.
review4: a mixed breed of torture porn, supernatural action and beyond-the-grave romance. Though played entirely straight and often unnervingly nasty, it is also undeniably silly,... without once bothering to find any tonal consistency
review5: The action in Savaged is so ambitious despite its limited means, it feels like the way movies should be made.

title: "Like Sunday, Like Rain"
review1: Whaley has made a provocative, well-acted movie about infatuations that turn awkward, but he struggles with the ending.
review2: Whaley aims high for this sort of material, but his film, sweet as it is, gets a little too precocious.
review3: Whaley nicely calibrates this wistful dramedy's emotional quotient, never allowing sentiment to turn into sap. He also smartly dials down Reggie's initial precociousness to reveal a kid who's deep, resourceful and strangely sensible.
review4: It's a bittersweet story that thins out toward the end as it turns too obviously sentimental, but it's still a nicely etched tale of the intersection of two unrelated lives.
review5: Unsurprising given its laughably affected title, Like Sunday, Like Rain boasts what may be the most insufferably precocious protagonist in cinema history.

title: The Wicked Lady
review4: It's all so delightfully over-the-top that it could only be disliked by persons approaching it as a serious drama.

title: Supremacy
review1: Feeding over-the-top language to underdeveloped characters, Deon Taylor's "Supremacy" dramatizes racism with an unvarying intensity that quickly becomes wearing.
review2: The film plays out almost like a conventional Hollywood hostage thriller but for the incendiary, racially charged subtext.
review3: It's so grueling an ordeal that its revelations barely penetrate the murk.
review4: [A] dour, dreary drama ...
review5: A pretty preposterous plotline, but who am I to argue with a tale presumably based on a true story?

title: Life Inside Out
review1: This low-key drama so insistently resists epiphanies that it verges on bland.
review2: Earnestness doesn't fully excuse the low-key schmaltz peddled by Life Inside Out, the type of indie that your mother might politely describe as "touching" if she could manage to stay awake for its entirety.
review3: When the telegraphed feel-good moments arrive, the smiles feel unforced.
review4: "Life Inside Out" is a gentle, poignant drama whose heart and head are squarely in the right place. Engaging, naturalistic performances and nicely explored real-world issues add to this absorbing film's down-to-earth appeal.
review5: The earnest film's straightforwardness and down-to-earth characters have a gentle appeal, but its tendency to spell out every emotion and theme in on-the-nose dialogue undercuts its potential impact at nearly every turn.

title: Little Accidents
review1: Nothing feels forced in this movie, which is testament to Colangelo's skill as well as the cast's. You believe the coal dust on these people; you grieve for their secrets.
review2: Little Accidents paints a vivid portrait of a community facing an imminent existential crisis.
review3: To her credit, the writer-director tries for complexity. Now if she can just get the storytelling to match the quality of the filmmaking, I suspect there will be fewer little accidents.
review4: Owen tries with lurching uncertainty to ease back into normal, even as the writer and director Sara Colangelo clutters his path with enough obstacles to challenge the most heroically determined traveler.
review5: There's a quiet desperation to all the lives depicted in writer-director Sara Colangelo's assured indie about a West Virginia mining accident that upends everyone in town.

title: Cake
review1: Whether or not Aniston ever gets another role like this one, I have a hard time imagining anyone else in it -- and that's the sign of a genuine actor.
review2: The slack and purposeless direction leaves the entire cast emoting in a void.
review3: Cake usefully reminds us that Jennifer Aniston can actually act. I wish she'd do it more often and in better movies than this one.
review4: The film doesn't quite prevent sentiment seeping in before the end, but Aniston's deadpan comic timing as she delivers Claire's bitter put-downs and complaints is brilliant: the deliciously sour cherry on the cake.
review5: Cake is a so-so Lifetime special and a pretty lousy film.

title: Walter
review1: A lovely and touching third act helps make up for a wobbly, at times convoluted first hour in the quirky fantasy-dramedy "Walter."
review2: What a strange little indie film this is.
review3: The narrative is effectively constructed and the cinematography is crisp. Even so, in touching lightly on themes without committing to any of them, the movie falls flat.
review4: What's not to love, after all, about a therapist who calls a mentally unbalanced man crazy to his face? But it's also an appropriate response to both Walter the movie and Walter the ridiculous construct of a movie character.
review5: An outstanding cast goes a long way toward helping the movie to leap past its outlandish gimmick.

title: Affluenza
review1: The generational conflict -- overly ambitious parents and their disaffected millennial children -- plays so on-the-nose it almost seems like satire, but it's really just bad writing.
review2: Kevin Asch's sophomore feature attempts to tackle weighty themes but ultimately feels as shallow as the lives of most of its principal characters.
review3: "The Great Gatsby" Lite screenplay by Antonio Macia hasn't the sharpness of satire or the momentousness of an American tragedy, veering instead toward middling melodrama.
review4: An empty recasting of 'The Great Gatsby' among Long Island rich kids circa 2008.
review5: Straining to find a correlation, even metaphorical, between teenage hedonism and economic collapse, "Affluenza" never coheres.

title: Boy Meets Girl
review1: The profoundly sensitive, often wryly funny look at friendship, romance, sexual attraction and gender identity carries themes and dynamics that feel as timeless as they do up-to-the-minute.
review2: Often, it feels conspicuously educational.
review3: Boy Meets Girl is a funny and touching comedy/drama boasting a superlative debut performance by Michelle Hendley.
review4: The film's potentially most affecting moments are too often smothered by the hackneyed characters and setups that surround them.
review5: Under the guise of a conventional romantic comedy, this independent feature explores gender politics and sex-positive themes with depth and passion.

title: The Devil's Violinist
review1: Though his dramatic performance is somewhat too mild, classical-pop violinist David Garrett brings an electrifying musical authenticity to the lead role in "The Devil's Violinist."
review2: Even if, like me, you're a sucker for men with tossable hair and precision eyeliner, you can't help noticing that "The Devil's Violinist" is hysterical - and possibly historical - hooey.
review3: Garrett, making his acting debut, isn't a strong enough presence to carry the nonmusical sequences.
review4: David Garrett's musical gifts far outstrip his acting chops in Bernard Rose's creaky 19th-century melodrama.
review5: [Garrett's] handsome and fiddles something fierce, but his acting aptitude is more "Chopsticks" than Caprice no. 24 in A minor.

title: Northern Borders
review1: Craven's erratic tonal shifts from the whimsical to the sentimental trip up the episodic plot.
review2: The movie's a charmer with sense of integrity.
review3: The most interesting thing about the movie is its origin story.
review4: Sad family secrets abound on the secluded homestead in Jay Craven's adaptation of the novel by Frank Mosher, and though these mini-revelations go a long way ... it doesn't make their complicated dynamic much more involving.
review5: The coming-of-age of a patient and resilient boy during his stay with his eccentric grandparents in Vermont.

title: The Duke Of Burgundy
review1: [Peter Strickland's] new movie has more going on than cinematic mind games.
review2: There's voyeurism, fetishism, bondage, lingerie and high-flown naughtiness galore, but that's hardly the movie's most conspicuous achievement.
review3: The Duke of Burgundy is no mere style exercise or slavish homage. Strickland finds both humour and pathos in the situation of Cynthia and Evelyn, who are every bit as trapped as the insects they collect and catalogue.
review4: The Duke of Burgundy is like Fifty Shades of Grey as staged by Masterpiece Theater.
review5: It will appeal to a limited group of high cinephiles, and those who always got off on the kind of fantasy soft-porn the film so dutifully replicates, and most of all, to the subset of folk who are both. That would be me.

title: Mommy
review1: A work of haunting power.
review2: Many words describe the Canadian film, "Mommy." Unpleasant, violent and heartbreaking are just a few.
review3: Like so much cinema, Mommy functions at a gut level - you either instinctively get it or you don't. As to whether or not it amounts to much more than a French-Canadian, ADHD-style Instagram film, I'm unconvinced but fascinated as to Dolan's next move.
review4: Intense tale of unstable teen is full of profanity, violence
review5: Mommy is going to linger. The love, the laughter, the anger and the sorrow--it sticks.

title: 50 to 1
review1: The true-life horse-racing tale "50 to 1" takes forever to get galloping - and when it finally does, it's too little too late.
review2: If "50 to 1" were about 15 minutes shorter, all of this might have made for a passable diversion. As it is, "50 to 1," much like Mine That Bird, flags before reaching the finish line.
review3: Wilson has owned and raced horses for years and once had a 190-acre ranch in California. And he has made the kind of film he might have seen as a kid, one where patience and hard work get rewarded at the 11th hour.
review4: Though infinitely more real than the symbolically bloated Seabiscuit of over a decade ago, 50 to 1 never completely gets under the skin of horse racing.
review5: Earnest but cliche-ridden...you're left with the feeling you've seen it all many times before, and needn't have seen it again.

title: Inherent Vice
review1: Inherently a Coenesque film noir, it features an uncannily Coenesque universe of cartoonish oddballs and a distinctive vernacular.
review2: It is no exaggeration to say that this could become the new Big Lebowski -- something that will not just stand up to repeat viewings but positively reward every single rewatch of its twisted, lunatic glory.
review3: Both Doc's hopeless pining for Shasta and his efforts to reunite a detoxed wife with her on-the-lam musician husband carry enough emotional weight to keep Inherent Vice from being just an exercise in random weirdness.
review4: The film's funny and absurd enough to make its maddeningly veiled musings on the death of the hippy dream engrossing. A large part of this is down to Phoenix, whose protagonist... is an undeniably rich creation.
review5: You might not have a clue what is going on; but enter into its freewheeling spirit and [the] film turns out to be unexpectedly captivating, with a touching undertow of melancholy detectable beneath the off-kilter humour and bizarre plotting.

title: The Gambler
review1: Mark Wahlberg is intense and compelling... but his character's self-destructive behaviour strains the viewer's sympathy almost as much as it strains that of the people around him.
review2: A lame remake of the 1974 original, this Gamble doesn't pay off
review3: The screenplay by William Monahan bears great responsibility on the finished product. It's important to get the characters right. It's not happening here.
review4: He's an interesting character... but I can't use that same adjective for the film itself.
review5: But every single scene of this film features a man treating everyone around him like dirt while pissing their money up against a wall and acting like the world owes him a living.

title: Winter Sleep
review1: Such miserable people; why should we care? Maybe because Ceylan does.
review2: The easy gag about the 196-minute "Winter Sleep" is that it's so good it makes 3  1/2 hours feel like two, but that's no joke.
review3: These scenes are talky, yes, but what talk!
review4: "Winter" feels very much like an epic novel, mirroring the pacing and themes of Chekov, whose work was its inspiration.
review5: Think of it as dramatic slow-cooking where the ingredients take their time to come together.

title: Against The Sun
review1: All three actors turn in solid, committed performances despite physically limiting surroundings, even as you're left with the inescapable feeling that this raft has sailed.
review2: A groaningly tedious survival story that will at least leave you with a renewed commitment to wearing sunscreen.
review3: Made on a fraction of the budget, "Against the Sun" works more effectively than Angelina Jolie's "Unbroken."
review4: Eventually all the movie has is the talent and chemistry of the three actors; fortunately, that's enough to keep it afloat.
review5: Tremendously inspirational. It's more thrilling and engrossing than Life of Pi.

title: Amira & Sam
review1: The script is thoughtful, but its anger is diffuse, with laissez-faire capitalism and the problems of illegal immigrants and returning soldiers jostling for attention.
review2: Chief among its pluses is the low-key warmth of leads Martin Starr and Dina Shihabi.
review3: "Amira & Sam" is all over the map in terms of tone. But it does score a few points as an unusual tale about the casualties of war.
review4: This indie drama is unconvincing as a love story and heavy-handed in its message of tolerance.
review5: It gets by on low-level sweetness and guile until delivering an unexpectedly powerful emotional sucker-punch at the end.

title: Miss Julie
review1: The film is visually bland, with only a couple of bookending outdoor sequences around a handful of interior sets.
review2: It smoulders and smokes and generates some heat but it never really bursts into flame.
review3: Anyone interested in spellbinding performances, however, should see Miss Julie.
review4: Morton, one of the least artificial actresses in the world, charts her character's heartbreak without any of the self-pity normally assigned to ordinary women.
review5: What Ullmann's done is create the ideal conditions for these three to do electrifying work with each other. She maintains control so they can lose it.

title: Black or White
review1: The films strength is its performances. Costner is especially good as a man whose grief brings forth a deep seeded anger, especially when confronted with the threat of losing the one thing left in his life that he loves.
review2: Leaves no room to explore the gray areas that could have made the scenario interesting
review3: Writer-director Mike Binder, who drew one of Costner's best performances in The Upside of Anger, does it again here, and for good measure, he does the same for Spencer.
review4: Really great performances... but this inspired-by-fact tale... only just skims the many provocative issues it touches on, and is rather anticlimactic in the end.
review5: A plea-filled, soapish human-interest story that's too sudsy, Black or White can't lather over its basic message-movie-ness, but its moral's hardly Shakespearean in its profundity: "What fools these adults be, bickering over a sweet little girl."

title: Selma
review1: This rousing, passionate civil rights drama is exquisitely timed, a quality that's just as important and elusive as greatness.
review2: Unforgettable. [full review in Spanish]
review3: A powerful examination of one of the key moments of the Civil Rights movement and the man who sacrificed made it possible.
review4: A treasure trove of outstanding performances, brilliant writing and heartfelt direction.
review5: The breadth of the film's scope is impressive, as it manages to sketch in the enormity and diversity of the movement without being spread too thin.

title: The Frontier
review1: An intimate family drama that subtly and delightfully subverts expectations of what kind of a tale it is and where it's headed.
review2: The film means well but feels generic, strained and claustrophobic (despite several scenes at a deserted beach), with tight close-ups and sudden confrontations.
review3: There's clearly a troubled history here, but co-writer/director Matt Rabinowitz doesn't artfully withhold information so much as lay it all on the table a bit earlier than he might have.
review4: While its theatrical prospects are limited...The Frontier could find a strong second life via cable and streaming video, particularly among older moviegoers looking for character-driven dramas rather than action-heavy genre pictures.

title: Spare Parts
review1: Though based on a Wired magazine story, this sticks closely to the formulas of inspirational-teacher and sports-team dramas; distinguishing it from the pack is the fact that all four students who formed the club were undocumented.
review2: Sequences and scenes end unceremoniously, everyone in the movie seems to know each other's backstory before they're properly introduced, and mild jokes land with uncertainty.
review3: Spare Parts tries too hard to be a based-on-a-true-story, feel-good, crowd-pleasing, triumph-of-the-underdogs movie.
review4: While the appropriately titled "Spare Parts" might feel like it has been assembled from bits and pieces of other inspirational movies, that doesn't mean the fact-based drama is any less effective ...
review5: This blatantly big-hearted product isn't half as vibrant as the original 2005 Wired article on which it's based, and myopically neglects to address Arizona's troubling anti-immigration legislation through even a splash of hindsight.

title: Hoovey
review1: Uplifting story of Christian athlete's health struggles.
review2: Audiences looking for a fresh take on this type of story will be sorely disappointed by its refusal to deviate from the norm. But those in the mood for a sweet, uplifting, faith-based film will find it a pleasant way to spend an hour and a half.

title: Murder of a Cat
review1: A dead pet isn't the only inert element of "Murder of a Cat," a plodding comic caper that fails to deliver.
review2: "Murder of a Cat" is a pleasant enough comic thriller, though it's the lead character - not the cat - you might most want to see murdered.
review3: Despite the presence of actors like Simmons, Greg Kinnear and Blythe Danner, this trying-too-hard comedy is as annoying as chasing a ball at the end of a bouncy string.
review4: Swing a dead cat here and you'll hit a piece of limp dialogue.
review5: I saw it with three people. One walked out. The second stayed to the bitter end because Blythe Danner and Greg Kinnear were in it. You needn't bother.

title: The Pyramid
review1: Like so many filmmakers before him, Levasseur doesn't seem to grasp that in the horror genre, less can be more.
review2: If you're looking for cheap scares and have 90 minutes to kill, you could do worse than The Pyramid. But not a lot worse.
review3: The air inside the pyramid isn't the only thing that's stale in this ludicrous yet mildly likable horror film.
review4: A stinker in every sense.
review5: "The Pyramid," despite an unpretentious matinee vibe, is mostly interesting in seeing how little light can be on screen before a bare minimum of suspense and coherence dissipates. There is, truly, not much to see in this movie.

title: Immigrant
review1: Dixon does a fine job with otherwise limited, melodramatic material.
review2: So melodramatic and relentlessly grim that any passion [Shurchin] feels for the material isn't reflected onscreen.

title: Mr. Turner
review1: Mike Leigh's biopic is so richly detailed that it feels like a documentary. Spall goes for broke in the outsize title role.
review2: Another finely reenacted if longwinded history lesson from director Mike Leigh.
review3: "Mr. Turner" painstakingly paints such a detailed portrait that those with enough patience to hang in there will be able to appreciate the complete picture and the filmmaker's craftsmanship.
review4: You have to work to follow the narrative but Leigh's interest isn't on what he did when. It's all about how and why he paints.
review5: Imaginative and richly detailed 19th century period biopic on the last 25 years of the revered English artist Joseph Mallord William Turner.

title: Black Sea
review1: Cliches abound in this waterlogged post-Cold War thriller from director Kevin Macdonald.
review2: Director Kevin Macdonald successfully ties the psychological tension with the physical, using the tight confines of a submarine setting rather masterfully, squeezing each drop of tension and expertly pacing every plot twist in Dennis Kelly's screenplay.
review3: With stunning underwater visuals, and a story that is engaging enough despite its obvious turns, there may be gold here yet.
review4: The plot doesn't entirely hold water... but Law exudes brawny charisma and helps the film build up a good head of sweaty, claustrophobic tension.
review5: Black Sea is another strongly made drama from British filmmaker Kevin Macdonald and, like The Last King of Scotland and State of Play, is about a protagonist in an untenable situation.

title: La religieuse (The Nun)
review1: Measured and sensible, The Nun lacks the full-on claustrophobic horror of a film like The Magdalene Sisters and moves through events at a matter-of-fact distance.
review2: Pauline Etienne as the heroine is a harmonising centre, believable, luminous, quiet-spoken, poignant.
review3: It's an affecting and frank take on the loneliness of faith as well as faithlessness, whose horrors come in odd contrast to the plush production values.
review4: It's a generally classy yet dramatically underpowered affair traversing a steady path between respectable costume drama and habit-lifting exploitation.
review5: Looks as tasteful as can be but, in terms of emotion, lacks any kind of finesse.

title: My Mistress
review1: The fact that My Mistress looks out of place, set as it is in suburban Queensland, doesn't detract from the director's ambition and obvious promise.
review2: Debut director Stephen Lance makes it all look pretty enough, but the film is so staid, safe and polite it's often just plain dull. If only the film had a real taste for the transgressions it gingerly depicts, it could have been Australia's Blue Velvet.
review3: While it's good that Lance eschews the conventional, the question becomes, what does he have in its place? I was left unsure of the answer.
review4: In the story of Kate's fractured relationship with her son is a tough and potentially tender film, but Beart and her pout get in the way.
review5: Most of the problems in My Mistress stem from the fact that it is steeped in cliché.

title: The Last 5 Years
review1: Anna Kendrick, of all-round-awesome fame, is singing again in this adaptation of an off-Broadway musical.
review2: It doesn't help that the songs, while solid, become repetitive in melody. And there's not a home run in the bunch. I walked out humming ... nothing from this movie.
review3: Richard LaGravenese's adaptation of Jason Robert Brown's The Last Five Years presents an intriguing and compelling spin on the standard musical, and on storytelling in general.
review4: It's a film to bring tears to the eyes of a cynic - in fact, a cynic might relish it more than anyone, since it's the counterpointing of exuberance with unashamed bleakness that makes The Last Five Years so rich.
review5: A musical lives or dies based on the quality of its songs, and though The Last Five Years delivers some solid tunes none of them are earworms that'll stay with you beyond the closing credits.

title: Brush With Danger
review1: Though not entirely an original concept, this vibrantly shot, East-meets-West fusion of Wushu and Washington never feels like a cheap forgery.
review2: Although the characters repeatedly express their worship of "original art" in gilded frames, the script consists of singularly unoriginal dialogue.
review3: Brush With Danger's few action scenes, all poorly choreographed, do nothing to extenuate the film's offensive characterizations.
review4: There's precious little here that hasn't been done better before, at least when it comes to the martial beatdowns.
review5: Brush with Danger appears to mean well...But the movie's laudable message is undermined by some terrible acting.

title: Infini
review1: For a while, it's exciting enough to feel brand-new.
review2: It's rare to see a film, much less a genre film, in which clarity is so willfully -- brazenly -- withheld.
review3: Infini is a space zombie movie that features decent production design but an undecipherable plot, which is not at all helped by the pages of expository dialogue bellowed at lung-busting volume.
review4: This clunky, claustrophobic, Aussie-made dystopian thriller has a plot that seems to have been constructed out of odds and ends from Ridley Scott and Christopher Nolan sci-fi movies.
review5: Ambitious stuff but there's a lot here which simply doesn't hold up under scrutiny.

title: A Year In Champagne
review1: It's A Year in Champagne's dedication to sharing the winemakers' own experiences, along with their anecdotes about this most quintessential of wines, that makes the film so enticing.
review2: Informative, but there's not much fizz to this rather flat documentary about how the bubbly is bottled.
review3: The premise amounts to numerous raised glasses and classical music cues, but little of this schmoozing strikes a notable chord beyond the démodé back-patting engaged throughout.

title: Wo kou de zong ji (The Sword Identity)
White Rabbit
review1: It sometimes reads as a cheap, sleazy horror film, but its heart seems to be in the right place.
review2: Neither screenwriter Anthony Di Pietro or director Tim McCann ("Desolation Angels") has a sure grasp of this uneasy mix of nature and nurture.
review3: All too much of Tim McCann's drama about this disturbed loner comes to feel like a checklist of warning signs.
review4: First-time screenwriter Anthony Di Pietro pulls off a couple of nice character reversals.
review5: "White Rabbit" is a deeply unpleasant viewing experience.

title: The Sleepwalker
review1: The setup has mysterious promise, but the film cheaps out on a satisfying payoff.
review2: With strong assists from the cinematographer Zachary Galler and her ex-husband, the composer Sondre Lerche, Ms. Fastvold, previously a director of music videos, has painted a resonant tableau of dysfunction.
review3: Among the many unanswered questions, I ask: Where do they find this junk, and where do so many amateurs get the money to finance it?
review4: The Sleepwalker distinguishes itself from most entries in this angst-ridden genre by way of superb writing, smoldering performances, and hauntingly beautiful imagery from first-time director Mona Fastvold.
review5: None of the characters is particularly likable or admirable, leaving little opportunity for sympathy or curiosity to penetrate the constantly heightened air of psychodrama.

title: [REC] 4: Apocalypse
review1: With [REC] 4, Balagueró returns to the main storyline and to the kind of claustrophobic setting where [REC] really thrives, ditching the slapstick splatter of [REC] 3 without sacrificing zombie gore.
review2: As an above-average adrenaline-driven roller-coaster ride, which offsets its multiple cliches with raw, controlled energy, it works.
review3: After an underwhelming third chapter, this Spanish horror franchise largely bounces back.
review4: Doesn't come close to eclipsing the first two entries, but is certainly an improvement over Part 3.
review5: There is plenty of ferocious tension here, but also some very well-pitched goofiness, with even a cameo from the Sumatran rat monkeys of Peter Jackson's proto-romzomcom from 1992, Braindead.

title: Just Before I Go
review1: Anchored by a nicely understated performance by Seann William Scott, "Just Before I Go" effectively juggles a wealth of genuine, at times profound, emotion with quite a bit of nutty-raunchy humor.
review2: Lurches along a wobbly line between salacious comic nastiness and nauseating sentimentality.
review3: Courteney Cox's misbegotten project is a comedy-drama that, to Cox's credit, doesn't feel at all like a TV sitcom. The former "Friends" star clearly wanted something special, but sadly the result is ... this.
review4: Courteney Cox's directorial debut "Just Before I Go" is a "Garden State" retread in which filthy jokes gradually cede ground to sentimental slush.
review5: A serious misfire.

title: Two Men in Town
review1: It'll be easy for some to dismiss this as a familiar story told all too coolly, but look closer and you'll see it has a raging heart.
review2: The desert landscapes are gorgeously shot by Yves Cape, but "Two Men in Town" never seems to fully inhabit its setting. Nor does the schematic, occasionally clumsy story do justice to the skills of the cast.
review3: The setting is striking, the cast impressive. But "Two Men in Town," a drama that's built on dread and circles the question of redemption for a newly released prisoner, falls short of the mythic territory it aspires to.
review4: The movie's melancholic, atmospheric tone, coupled with a muted performance from Whitaker, offers a new way into the material.
review5: Even if the accents are questionable or inconsistent, there's still a sense of place and geography that's rare in contemporary American film. This is the county-sized world of a parolee, where everything seems small except the horizon.

title: Beloved Sisters
review1: It's epic stuff, and at 170 minutes it's a commitment. Schiller seems to be blazing a trail for German über-confidence, seeing his modern man as the grand product of all that's been right with history.
review2: If nothing else, "Beloved Sisters" is one of the most visually striking biopics around. Too bad you have to wade through so much verbiage in order to enjoy it.
review3: Without at least the tawdry pleasure of a little bodice ripping, the film moves along sluggishly, even though it is well acted and handsomely shot.
review4: When an occasional blast of purple dialogue is triggered (such as ''Save me from my passion!''), it only makes you wish for the unintellectual bodice ripper that the movie should have been.
review5: If more historical movies were like Beloved Sisters, the term "costume drama" would be less of an insult.

title: Still Alice
review1: While Still Alice occasionally overstates, relies on its melancholy soundtrack or those home movie-style flashbacks, it can also be delicate, even brilliant.
review2: Despite Moore's fine work, Still Alice comes across as one of those old made-for-TV, disease of the week movies.
review3: Still Alice is not an easy film to watch, but it is a movie well worth seeing.
review4: More sincere than convincing, Still Alice is the rare picture that earns plaudits for its star dimming, not glowing. In a real sense, Moore gradually disappears from her own movie.
review5: It does have a predictable trajectory -- how could it not? -- but it's certainly not movie-of-the-week fare.

title: Blackhat
review1: It's still no return to form for Mann after the disappointing Miami Vice and Public Enemies.
review2: Blackhat feels like the vehicle that Mann wanted to explore the hacking world but the casting and the script's counterintuitive motivations it mutated away from his intent. It's a shame.
review3: Get over the shock of seeing Chris Hemsworth as a keyboard-clicking computer hacker rather than a hammer-heaving Marvel hero and Michael Mann's stylish cyber thriller Blackhat will soon have you gripped and intrigued.
review4: Such a deranged, half-kidding symphony of color, movement and sheer cinematic muscle, I spent most of the running time trying to pick my jaw up off the floor.
review5: This is visionary filmmaking of the first order.

title: The Immortalists
review1: The age-old search for the fountain of youth is engagingly appraised in "The Immortalists," a lively documentary focusing on a pair of very different biomedical scientists who are equally obsessed with eradicating the ravages of time.
review2: This sly documentary rises above its speculative hook by shifting to show the very human, and very mortal, sides of these would-be warriors of eternity.
review3: Should you find the prospect of immortality terrifying, as I do, the film has a vast philosophical hole at its center, and passes with only occasional spikes of interest.
review4: Would that the film encouraged some deeper thought on the matter instead of inviting viewers to gawk at the subjects as if they were freak-show attractions.
review5: Even if it doesn't convince us they're likely to conquer death before it comes for them, the film does prompt interesting debates about just how desirable an unlimited stay on Planet Earth would be.

title: The Living
review1: "The Living" presents itself as a searing genre piece about domestic violence, but it proves to be only a shell of its potential.
review2: An effective modern day noir.
review3: The emotional dynamics in domestic violence, for the abuser and the abused, are often too disturbing and complex to be treated as superficially as "The Living" does.
review4: The Living could be something kind of interesting, if only it weren't trying so hard to emotionally goad its audience.
review5: The Living is one of those unfortunate films ignorant of any world outside its author's head.

title: The Blue Room
review1: The ultimate triumph in what Amalric has done is to show us all the different forces that can be at work in an affair.
review2: A dazzling deconstruction of the mystery genre that turns its conventions on their heads.
review3: 'The Blue Room" is a tight little look at love gone wrong, something of a stripped-down French "Gone Girl" without the surprises.
review4: It's an accomplished film, if a bit cool and tidy; you wish there were a little more to it.
review5: The pleasure of a whodunit generally derives from trying to figure out who done it, but in the case of this arty, terminally obscure French mystery, most of the story has already transpired before one can even piece together what was done.

title: All The Wilderness
review1: Affected and slow, and more concerned with mood than plot, this moony first feature from Michael Johnson uses its Portland, Ore., setting as a canvas for mapping a course from isolation to companionship.
review2: "All the Wilderness" seems tailor-made to play to the actor's strengths - Johnson's script is as lean as Smit-McPhee, both proving adept at doing more with less.
review3: A familiar but insightful debut.
review4: First-time writer/director Michael Johnson falls back on coming-of-age clichés. But overall, his sensitive, moody camerawork and the cast's strong performances go a long way toward making the familiar feel fresh.
review5: Johnson unquestionably has his heart in the right place, but he's made a commonplace film built around one of those too-fragile-for-this-world teens who can be traced directly back to Timothy Hutton in Ordinary People.

title: Girlhood
review1: The movie captures that heady adolescent sense of time stopping and the moment mattering while standing far enough back to let us acknowledge all the pitfalls Marieme is moving too fast to see.
review2: In her previous features, Water Lilies and Tomboy, Sciamma focused on young characters in states of transition and discovery. Girlhood follows a trajectory of transformation, something that Toure achieves with effortless fluidity.
review3: Very good, very punchy social drama from France about Marieme (Karidja Toure), a prospectless, poverty-stricken black French teenage girl who succumbs to the ego-boosting allure of being in a gang.
review4: ...has wonderful moments in which the carefree nature of childhood is held in bittersweet tension with the yearning to be an adult.
review5: [From] urgent, fast-moving cinematography, intense close-ups. . . and percussive soundtrack. . . to cautionary tale of the limits of being a young black female in France.

title: Leviathan
review1: Cinematographer Mikhail Krichman's stunning images complement the narrative. The cool gray dawns and barren landscapes express Kolya's despair and isolation.
review2: Leviathan is a hoot, a tragedy and a masterpiece.
review3: How can a bleak film be dazzling? It can, when you think about it.
review4: Zvyagintsev literally and allegorically depicts modern Russia's runaway corruption but also captures universal fears about the shaky ground on which we construct our lives. [Blu-ray]
review5: Despite having slight issues with an overlong runtime and a narrative that downshifts in the second half, Leviathan manages to power through with a compelling story and a beautifully-crafted look.

title: Before I Disappear
review1: "Before I Disappear" would be a better movie if would-be triple-threat talent Shawn Christensen got out of his own way.
review2: Before I Disappear is ultimately hampered not by a messy plot but by bland characters who, for the most part, don't so much talk to each other as they monologue at each other.
review3: It has the unfortunate taste of something lean that's been plumped up with empty calories.
review4: "Before I Disappear" wears its big, aching heart on its sleeve with a sincerity so unwavering that it's borderline goofy. And in a film about a burnout bonding with a cute kid, that lack of self-awareness proves critical.
review5: Throughout the movie, you have the feeling of being dragged along on an impromptu journey by a filmmaker who is traveling without the benefit of a GPS device.

title: American Sniper
review1: American Sniper has a perspective that's recognizable from the classic Westerns Eastwood has long been associated with, both as an actor and a director. It's an existential critique of violent machismo that doubles as a celebration of violence.
review2: Eastwood makes the moral stakes almost nonexistent.
review3: It speaks emotionally to audiences who sense that we lost something in Iraq, yet still want to honor the heroism of those who risked their lives for the cause, whether or not it was ultimately a great one.
review4: Clint Eastwood's American Sniper is an often lazy and somewhat hazy propaganda film about American heroism and hell in the Iraq War.
review5: Although Cooper succeeds in resembling and sounding like the real Kyle, this isn't some cheap impersonation trick. Cooper gives maybe the best performance of his career.

title: The Journey
review1: Standard Cold War/romantic triangle story.

title: Dial A Prayer
review1: Kiley is mostly successful at keeping Hallmark banalities at bay, relating Cora's crime in a series of tense flashbacks and populating the film with funny characters played by a top-notch cast.
review2: "Dial a Prayer" doesn't work.
review3: Somber meditation on belief, redemption has heavy themes.
review4: A rather touching portrait of a young woman's human growth, laced with a salutary number of small yet piquant observations along the way.
review5: I recommend Dial A Prayer for its actors - Snow is well-cast, Macy is of course golden in every single thing he does, and the supporting cast is likeable - and a story that's got a good message yet is not overly preachy in delivering it.

title: État de Siège (State of Siege)
review1: Rather than playing into the prejudices and biases of any one political stripe, State of Siege boldly dares to look at both sides, finding both fault and virtue.
review2: Costa-Gavras captures how it feels to live under martial law, and how even some committed populists will scrap their ideals to protect their comfort and privilege.
review3: Purposefully frustrating Yankee-Go-Home pamphlet

title: Ballet 422
review1: For arts, music and dance aficionados, "Ballet 422" is a documentary that will speak (and perhaps sing) to them.
review2: It's filled with delicious moments, particularly for dance fans ...
review3: There are few titles and no interviews or narration. Entire scenes go by without anyone speaking. Instead, Ballet 422 is a very intimate look at the process.
review4: For fans of dance, "Ballet 422" will produce plenty of pleasures. But as with great ballet, great movies always benefit from a little drama.
review5: What makes Jody Lee Lipes documentary so interesting - even transfixing at times - is the fact that nothing is editorialized or explained. There are no interviews or voice-overs.

title: Seventh Son
review1: A fantasy adventure film needs more than "cool creatures," a rousing score, and two certifiably over-the-top performances to make a lasting impression.
review2: The film is basically a rich man's Uwe Boll version of Dungeons and Dragons -- a lot of tacky visuals, world-building mumbo-jumbo and gooey CGI creatures encased in a narrative vacuum.
review3: Seventh Son wraps itself in a bland colored shroud of clichés, making you find reality much more interesting than fiction.
review4: It's difficult to comprehend quite why this stellar cast all signed up to this distinctively lacklustre project.
review5: You have to admire a movie which takes a gold-star cast (Julianne Moore, Jeff Bridges, Alicia Vikander) and creates such an unpolishable turd.

title: The Loft
review1: Erotic thrillers are a time-tested genre, but this effort, scripted by Wesley Strick, is neither erotic nor thrilling.
review2: This new iteration proves such a dour hodgepodge of bad behavior, bald-faced misogyny and ping-ponging alliances, it's more alienating than alluring.
review3: The Loft is a film that can't decide what it wants. It's a male fantasy, and a cautionary tale. It's sleazy in concept, and timid in execution. It punishes its protagonists for their transgressions, then lets them off the hook.
review4: There's no redeeming this softcore nonsense, which plays like a script that Storage Wars stumbled across in Joe Eszterhas's old locker.
review5: The twisty plot translates to any culture where swinging-d--- businessmen cheat on their wives -- which is to say, any culture.

title: See You in Valhalla
review1: The ensemble dramedy "See You in Valhalla" could be the death knell for dysfunctional family reunion movies. It's that bad.
review2: As deadly as its funereal subject matter.
review3: The characters feel familiar and the scenarios are contrived in this low-budget drama.
review4: It's material we've seen before and the few oddball stamps feel painfully forced. It's not even good for a cry, dammit. At least these family dramas are usually good for a cry!
