review5: Steve Howey, as a stoner-sage gay Hawaiian personal trainer, almost makes this worth watching all by himself.

title: Da Sweet Blood of Jesus
review1: "Da Sweet Blood of Jesus" is a bold but wildly uneven, bloody mess of a film, sunk in large part by the subpar performances by nearly every major character in nearly every major role.
review2: Never once does the film feel sharp on black identity (as did Bill Gunn's original), and the terror is theoretical only.
review3: Unrepentant, uneven and unique, "Da Sweet Blood of Jesus" proves that Lee can still make a film worthy of the arguments it will most certainly start.
review4: Da Sweet Blood of Jesus is a mess, but it's the kind of mess only one of our greatest filmmakers could make.
review5: While this return to indie roots frees up Lee's often gifted image making, his usual pace issues and penchant for jagged flourish over sustained feeling keep it from achieving a rich, strange, sexy and sad whole.

title: As Night Comes
review1: There's power and authenticity here. And by the movie's incendiary climax, some tension. If only it were presented in a more magnetic package.

title: Know How
review1: This could be "Rent" for a new generation. The myriad social issues have been properly contextualized into a powerful big picture.
review2: "Know How" is a robust, youthful call to be seen, heard and appreciated - to be a little less invisible.
review3: Despite a handful of immediately upsetting sequences, DIY hip-hop musical Know How never coheres into a cathartic fictional account of its creators' turbulent adolescence.
review4: Unfortunately, the dramatization of these personal accounts often feels flat and uninspired, an earnest but clumsily rendered high-school project.
review5: Overall, the film's educational prerogatives tend to overwhelm its more interesting formal properties.

title: Li'l Quinquin
review1: Heavyweight French auteur Bruno Dumont demonstrates his gift for deadpan comedy.
review2: The action seems to rise organically from the locale, and Dumont's grand yet intimate fiction fuses his inner world with the historical moment.
review3: We may find ourselves both frustrated and riveted. Something tells me Bruno Dumont wouldn't want it any other way.
review4: This is not funny stuff, but then Dumont isn't after the sort of laughter that makes viewers feel better. His idea of the human comedy remains as grim as it is absurd.
review5: "Li'l Quinquin" is a quasi-epic farce that mostly wears a poker face as it elaborates his continuing obsession with the collision of humankind's bestial and spiritual impulses.

title: Monsters: Dark Continent
review1: A desert-set men-on-a-mission movie complete with jabbering jihadis, macho hysteria and the occasional extraterrestrial waving its tentacles in the background as if to say: 'Isn't this supposed to be about me?'
review2: Although Edwards is onboard for the new "Monsters: Dark Continent" as an executive producer, the sequel bears no resemblance to his original, thematically or stylistically.
review3: Plays like a dorm-room answer to modern war films, complete with the constant profanity and masculine hysterics that pass for impact in an immature script.
review4: It's taxing to watch, and Green moves between scenes with Malick-inspired ellipses, frustrating momentum.
review5: Whatever the filmmakers' subtextual intentions may be, the film certainly gets stronger and more compelling as it goes on, thanks in part to intense emoting on the part of its cast.

title: Camp X-Ray
review1: Camp X-Ray raises quite a few fascinating questions about power, sexism, and war, yet fails to explore them in any real depth. More troubling still, it's a character study that does little in the way of character development.
review2: It's invigorated, somewhat, by strong central performances from actors on opposite sides of a locked steel door.
review3: Writer-director Peter Sattler... grounds his story in the cold operational detail of Gitmo, showing how the soldiers there administer the legal limbo of indefinite detention and insulate themselves from the cruelty and injustice of what they're doing.
review4: On another movie, the high-corn finale might have worked; here, it just feels patently false.
review5: Has a great idea behind it - a young female soldier assigned guard duty at Guantanamo Bay forms a kinship with one of the incarcerated Muslims - but first-time writer-director Peter Sattler doesn't go anywhere interesting with that notion.

title: McFarland USA
review1: Yes, "McFarland USA" has the obligatory coda where we found out how everything played out for the coach and the key members of that 1987 team. You should stick around for that.
review2: There are no great surprises here but the cultural backdrop - almost everyone in the town is Mexican - adds interest and Costner is at his most relaxed and appealing.
review3: Niki Caro uses every device at her disposal to make a rousing, feelgood movie but risks turning the film into a glorified fairytale in the process.
review4: McFarland, USA is a modern anomaly -- a Kevin Costner sports movie that's genuinely rousing.
review5: Kiwi director Niki Caro, best known for the Maori fable Whale Rider, makes underdog stories you keep wanting to get behind, and Costner's born-again-good-guy routine doesn't disappoint.

title: Focus
review1: If it feels like the prequel to a smoother, pacier heist film, at least this is sufficiently charming that we might see a follow-up one day.
review2: Can't con us into believing
review3: After a solid decade of dreck, the seductive con man rom-com Focus allows star Will Smith to slip into a little suave adult sophistication, while rehabbing his image by playing the familiar part of the brash, smooth-talking charmer.
review4: No new ground is covered, no unknown secrets revealed, but instead you get a mildly entertaining trip into the world of professional crime by some attractive, terrible people.
review5: A good con-job movie, unlike a real-life con-job, finds a way to make you enjoy getting taken for a ride. Focus offers some of that giddy pleasure but it can also be, like its lead character, a bit too smooth and slick and sure of itself.

title: Eastern Boys
review1: Writer-director-editor Robin Campillo has crafted an unruly yet pointed drama that should intrigue patient viewers.
review2: The movie argues that these teens' lawless, selfish mentality is a by-product of having grown up in war-stricken countries such as Chechnya, where they lived through horrors that permanently skewed their moral compasses.
review3: Both surprisingly resonant, and something of a thrill-ride.
review4: Explores interlocking themes of sexuality, immigration and power dynamics with a cleareyed sensitivity and refuses to demonize even its shadiest characters.
review5: By turns a frightening home-invasion drama, a tender love story and a tense hide-and-seek thriller, with far more control over these unsettling tonal slides than initially seems feasible.

title: Wish You Well
review1: It's not a particularly original message, but it's hard to fault a film trying to earnestly spread a little love around the world.
review2: Well-shot, moving drama is uplifting but has lots of tragedy

title: A Song to Remember
review4: The music is fine, but the story is not.
review5: The melodrama is pretty forced, but the music is superb.

title: All Relative
review1: A misguided indie romantic comedy to watch with someone you hate.
review2: Although the resulting tonal shifts between funny and serious aren't always executed as seamlessly as they might be, Khoury deserves props for defying rom-com conventions more often than he succumbs to them.
review3: [It] thinks it's being surprising, but really it's merely weaving several male sex fantasies together and making nothing insightful out of the resulting story.
review4: Imagine "The Graduate" as rewritten by a golden retriever, and you'll have some inkling of the intelligence level in the rom-com "All Relative."
review5: Does Hollywood have so little to offer women that well-regarded actresses feel obliged to accept demeaning indies like this flatly unfunny, morally vacant comedy?

title: The Squeeze
review1: Between plot and character, there are definitely 18 holes in "The Squeeze."
review2: Within the legacy of golf movies, this subpar thriller doesn't reach the leaderboard.
review3: A moralizing, paint-by-numbers parable lifted right out of the Hollywood hack playbook.
review4: Worthy addition to the annals of golf movies and a decent gambling-caper film, marred by a subpar final act.
review5: Here's a movie that would benefit from being broken up by late-night television commercials.

title: Cas & Dylan
review1: There's a full tank of clichés for the mismatched-strangers road movie "Cas & Dylan," the feature directing debut of Jason Priestley, and the sputtering is cacophonous even with two gifted actors leading the way.
review2: This Canadian movie, from a screenplay by Jessie Gabe, begins in Winnipeg and ends in Vancouver and jounces along on the crackle of smart-aleck dialogue mouthed by its stars, Richard Dreyfuss and Tatiana Maslany.
review3: Leading man Richard Dreyfuss is so irrepressibly charming that he almost saves Jason Priestley's dismal buddy comedy Cas & Dylan from its awkward humor and trite sentimentality.
review4: Cas & Dylan may have big-name talent for a small Canadian movie but mainly it has tired Hollywood formulas.
review5: Even if Cas & Dylan isn't as polished as it could be, there are still enough pleasing moments to make this road trip worth the ride.

title: Serena
review1: Absolutely nothing works. No one seems to understand the place or the people. And the only thing gleaned from the lumber industry is that you can build an entire movie from performances made of wood.
review2: In other words, a lot of people realized they had an epic clunker on their hands.
review3: Given these unpromising circumstances, I was expecting something truly awful, and perhaps that might have been more fun to watch than this lugubrious period piece. The production values and the costumes are the true stars.
review4: The actors don't just look uncomfortable in their period duds, they also look uneasy in their own skins, which is a feat for two such natural, physically confident screen performers.
review5: The performers are as beautiful to look at here as they are intriguing to watch.

title: Papadopoulos & Sons
review1: The cast is pleasant enough to enliven the generic material, though much of writer-director Marcus Markou's dialogue is beyond salvaging.
review2: There are zero surprises here, but a strong cast and a decent script add up to dependable entertainment.
review3: Just like Arnold Schwarzenegger was told his name was too big for movie posters, Marcus Markou's inspirational debut feature film has an impossible title on purpose.
review4: A late pitch at pathos isn't quite so convincing, but otherwise this is a fresh, funny and poignant snapshot of ethnic life in London.
review5: This flat, feelgood family story transposes the cliches of Zorba the Greek to the present day.

title: The Novack Murders
review1: [It's] a bad movie that revels in its tackiness, amps up its tawdriness and emphasizes its campy qualities. And as a result, what might have been a channel-flip-inducing failure instead turns out to be a couple of hours of guilty-pleasure TV fun.

title: Electric Slide
review1: "Electric Slide" has some of the mordant absurdity of the novels of Bret Easton Ellis. Like its dim hero, it's going nowhere, but traveling in style.
review2: Jim Sturgess as Dodson is meant to be a charismatic, effete dandy. He merely comes off creepy. Vinessa Shaw, Chloë Sevigny, and Patricia Arquette are utterly wasted in nothing parts.
review3: Electric Slide turns a pulpy story into a turgid, humorless, undernourished slog.
review4: "Electric Slide" becomes a vacuous, numbed viewing experience that's more interested in the positioning of lights than the decay of its characters.
review5: Self-consciously arty dreck of the most agonizing variety.

title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem
review1: It's tough and unsparing, but the grimness is never gratuitous.
review2: Ultimately the movie is wearying, but then it's likely supposed to be. If Viviane's going through the wringer, you're going through the wringer too.
review3: Shot in intense close-ups, the better to study the emotions burning off the characters' skin, the film is all talk and gestures, but it begins to take your breath away like a chase movie would.
review4: Stand out roles include Menashe Noy, who plays Amsalem's lawyer, and Sasson Gabai, who plays Elisha's lawyer and brother. However, it is Elkabetz's performance that carries the film.
review5: I never thought I would enjoy a film that takes place in such a small space for so long. Well, not since Hitchcock's "Lifeboat" anyway.

title: Wild Tales
review1: Wild Tales is a showy exercise, and Szifrón has undoubtedly punched his ticket for bigger and better things. He'll have to deliver something more than a scattering of gotchas next time.
review2: [A] deliciously nasty anthology.
review3: Given the construct of "Wild Tales" it's too early to induct Szifrón into the company of Alejandro González Iñárritu and Alfonso Cuarón as the next great Latino auteur, but he's a sure contender.
review4: You'll certainly never think about getting your car towed or calling out someone too slow on the highway the same way ever again.
review5: One of the most shocking movies in recent cinema history. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Welcome to Me
review1: There's not much plot here and very little in the way of character development. Alice is defined by her disorder and the screenplay isn't interested in delving into her life and relationships.
review2: No shortage of talent here. Pity they're all underused.
review3: Welcome to Me is an unsettling comedy, and I mean that in the best possible way.
review4: "Welcome to Me" has its charming, funny and sensitive moments, but it also suffers from its own form of instability.
review5: It's a tricky business playing someone who is mentally ill and perhaps should be confined for observation, especially in a dark comedy. Wiig manages to make Alice funny as hell, endearing, sad and sometimes a little frightening.

title: Old Fashioned
review1: The leading man often seems more like a brooding menace in this handsomely produced but painfully slow faith-based romantic drama.
review2: Disturbing is the film's apparent conviction that the surefire way to a woman's heart involves lots of candles and a mani-pedi, the sort of notion that isn't so much cute and old-fashioned as it is acutely offensive.
review3: It must be pretty neat to make a movie that mostly consists of people telling you how chivalrous and morally right you are and how much everybody loves you, but that's no excuse for making it this boring.
review4: Just because it's clean doesn't mean it's a good movie.
review5: Even if you agree with Clay's rigid moral stance, you'll probably be put off by this remarkably dull, tone-deaf argument for chastity.

title: 9 Full Moons
review1: Though the film's second half could be tighter, the details and atmosphere ring true throughout, especially in the walking-wounded chemistry between Seimetz and Roberts' tentative dreamers.

title: Marfa Girl
review1: "Marfa Girl" was filmed in 2012 but is only now reaching theaters, and as we've seen with the recent "Serena" and so many other delayed releases, that's almost never a good thing.
review2: Clark's sympathy for his subjects is more evident than ever.
review3: It's refreshing to see a film set amid the daily life of an impoverished, rural immigrant community. It's a shame the only aspect of the social world that is explored is the sexual exploits of a few teens.
review4: For all its meanderings and indulgences - verbal and visual - this free-form snapshot of a circle of townsfolk in tiny Marfa, Texas, proves a sneakily immersive, weirdly memorable affair.
review5: The scandal of Mr. Clark's more recent movies, including "Wassup Rockers" and "Ken Park" and this new one, resides more in its tedium and lack of insight than its strenuously provocative content.

title: All the Wrong Reasons
review1: The result teeters uncomfortably between dead-end-job slacker comedy and high soap, but it shows enough potential to bode well for Milani's future.
review2: The primary frustration with All the Wrong Reasons is it takes so long to get where the story is so obviously going.
review3: Cory Monteith is a particular revelation. The late actor sinks his teeth into the crunchy material with clear purpose and absolute fearlessness, ensuring that our de facto hero has endless dimensions.
review4: This is a film that's trying for a lot of things, and accomplishes exactly none of them.

title: Stop The Pounding Heart
review1: Minervini places these two non-actors in the same arena and no sparks whatsoever fly. It's a tedious, patience-testing experience that could reward only cinephiles and the curious.
review2: Authenticity is the warm blood that pumps through "Stop the Pounding Heart," a low key but mesmerizing look at adolescent awakening in a fundamentalist family.
review3: "Stop the Pounding Heart" transcends both the red state-blue state split and limited, didactic ideas of cinematic realism.
review4: A modest film made with an authenticity that commands respect, Stop the Pounding Heart adopts fundaments of neorealism and cinema verite to consider issues of faith, family and personal conviction.
review5: Characters who might have been portrayed as Bible Belt nut-jobs come off as unconditionally loving.

title: Druid Peak
review1: While undeniably gorgeous, at some point all those sweeping vistas can't help but feel like a pitch for Wyoming tourism.

title: Pound Of Flesh
review1: Conceptually pedestrian but decently handled in all departments.
review2: It's not enough for Pound Of Flesh to be likable. Its existence isn't an affront to the God its characters keep talking about, but it's not exactly a reason for giving thanks, either.
review3: That it's not terrible despite its debits is probably the most generous assessment of Jean-Claude Van Damme's latest, a watchable oddity.
review4: The car chase is a combination of bad f/x, a lack of speed and "close calls" & "collisions" that make it the saddest thing I've seen since all of Dear Zachary.
review5: The feature wants to be a massive action event, but it doesn't have the resources and the simplicity to snowball through 100 minutes of excitement, wasting a perfectly good revenge plot on tedious domestic woes.

title: Spike Island
review1: Though the story is drawn in broad strokes and overloaded with melodrama, director Mat Whitecross' exuberant feature understands the communal joy and personal necessity of rock 'n' roll.
review2: The film has an engagingly zippy and colorful visual style, evoking the splashy Summer of Love motifs around the Roses, with allusions to their music videos and paint-splattered, Jackson Pollock-esque sleeve artwork.
review3: [The Stone Roses'] debut long player is one of the few rock albums that might justly be assessed all killer, no filler; Whitecross and Coghill's sincerely intended love letter to the era, not so much.
review4: None of this ever feels remotely honest or real.
review5: Taking its cue from the sort of pandering nostalgia that usually gets peddled to Baby Boomers, Mat Whitecross' irritating Spike Island follows a teenage gang of the Stone Roses' superfans in 1990 Manchester.

title: Timbuktu
review1: Director Abderrahmane Sissako, a Muslim from neighboring Mauritania, has made a movie that is worthy of comparisons on several levels to Terrence Malick's wheat-field tragedy "Days of Heaven."
review2: The performances are hushed and memorable. Cinematographer Sofian El Fanicaptures the beauty of this desert land. Amine Bouhafa's score is its own act of gorgeous grace and defiance.
review3: A mesmerizing political tone film of our times about intolerant Islamic fundamentalist taking control of a Muslim community in Timbuktu.
review4: The movie makes sure to never forget that these are all people, stupid, flawed people; the banality of evil is so prevalent here that you'll occasionally laugh just to keep from cry.
review5: What makes it so unusually compelling as a protest film is that it's also a richly poetic work of cinema - witty, beautiful and even, sobering though it is, highly entertaining.

title: All American Bully
review1: Disturbing indie thriller has rape, intense violence.

title: The Forger
review1: What is happening! If you check out "The Forger," you might well find yourself saying that time and again, as the entertainingly terrible performances keep piling up while the plot dares you not to chuckle at the audacity of it all.
review2: In attempting to spin out its competing storylines, the crime drama "The Forger" never quite gets a handle on either one.
review3: Occasionally a movie comes along that's such an awkward compilation of ideas it fascinates: The Forger, a Boston-set melodrama involving cancer, Impressionist art and deadbeat dads, is only about half that good.
review4: Mr. Travolta teeters between tough-guy menace and soulful, artistic intensity, but you don't ever believe that he can paint or that he can beat up a whole squad of younger, bigger, meaner dudes.
review5: This limply directed tale emerges as a case study of an all too familiar type of art crime: the making of bad movies.

title: Childless
review1: The movie, written and directed by Charlie Levi, is a deftly shot and edited succession of monologues, primarily from four aging, affluent Angelenos.
review2: The uncomfortable truths of these unpleasant people can be revelatory, especially when the childless Mary and Natalie dig into their strained interactions with Katherine.

title: "Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter"
review1: File this one under "odd and interesting but ... "
review2: If Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter takes its time, it's time worth taking.
review3: ... a rigorous if miniature work of art, a movie that betrays tremendous discipline in every aspect, from its traditional, almost formal, visual approach to the eerie score ...
review4: Like the money from 'Fargo' that inspires Kumiko's quest, this movie something of a buried treasure itself.
review5: For all its formal beauty and dry comedy, there is a certain heartlessness in inventing a bleak, artsy fantasia on the grave of a real dead woman.

title: Danny Collins
review1: Pacino delivers his best turn in a very long time, hiding the fact that he can't even carry a tune behind a magnetic presence that screams "star".
review2: Al Pacino delivers a master class in acting. [Full review in Spanish]
review3: What could have been a cheap piece of hackwork becomes a pleasing little trifle, thanks to its actors.
review4: An above average drama with good dialogue, great characters and even better performances. [Full review in Spanish]
review5: The scenes between Pacino and Holly Hunter's character are the best parts of the movie. [Full review in Spanish]

title: While We're Young
review1: I'm so glad Noah Baumbach has lightened up.
review2: Baumbach has satirical fun with both the younger duo's retro-chic poses and the older couple's delusions. He also stages some knockout farcical episodes.
review3: Cinema's most vicious, mean-spirited denunciation of the millennial generation yet
review4: None of the characters have any kind of inner life, and they only exist in relation to Stiller's character.
review5: The pains of ageing, and the chasms that divide generations, are mined with witty precision in this latest comic outing from Noah Baumbach.

title: Zero Motivation
review1: A delightful, sharp dramedy that skewers the topic from every angle imaginable.
review2: Divided into three loosely connected stories involving the same players, "Zero Motivation" is strongest in its characters and its connection to an Israeli reality we can feel even if we've never experienced it.
review3: The office comedy is weak. The gross-out gags are too safe. A covert lesbian crush is underused.
review4: There's method in the madness, but little of it elsewhere in "Zero Motivation."
review5: An engaging, desert-dry, feminist-minded comedy ...

title: Alex of Venice
review1: Chris Messina's "Alex of Venice" is as much a love letter to the Los Angeles neighborhood as it is a well-observed drama.
review2: An appealing portrait miniature of a woman who loses and finds her bearings ...
review3: The film is so uneven, the characters and relationships so undeveloped, it's hard to work up much sympathy.
review4: As she flails through a few dubious choices, the character may be on the kind of self-discovery path we've seen in countless other films; but Winstead makes the outcome seem far from preordained.
review5: Although it's enjoyable, actor Chris Messina's directorial debut is somehow less than the sum of its parts, wading only through the shallow end of familiar human conflicts resolved too conveniently to satisfy.

title: Tiger Orange
review1: Among the actors, Marcel has the most screen wattage, deftly conveying a full, interesting character despite very little to back him up.
review2: [A] small but well-observed character drama.

title: Uncertain Terms
review1: It's a letdown ... that the final act turns to a melodramatic showdown ...
review2: At a mere 71 minutes, this naturalistic snapshot set at a bucolic residence for pregnant girls feels like it needed more gestation before cameras rolled.
review3: Pivoting off pop music cues, "Uncertain Terms" can feel slight, and, oddly for this filmmaker, it dips into clichéd dialogue.
review4: The film is brisk, brief, well acted, smartly crafted, and shrewdly judged.
review5: A rural group home for pregnant teen-agers is the setting for this intimately detailed, sharply observed modernist melodrama, directed by Nathan Silver.

title: Gone Doggy Gone
review1: The clever premise eventually loses steam as the convoluted plot unfolds... But there are still plenty of laughs along the way.
review2: The film's oddball assortment of broadly played characters feel like sketch comedy escapees stretched beyond their limits, an attempt to fill the demands of a feature-length canvas.
review3: The film's sweetness, its story line and the script's cartoony characters recall Raising Arizona, though Gone Doggy Gone isn't as tightly structured. But, being looser, it has a little more room to breathe.
review4: It's a vanity production in which only the dog should be vain.
review5: A funny, low-budget indie that's at its best when it diverts from what is purported to be the main plot. It proves that Brown and Walter are talented comedic writers who aren't afraid to get more than a little absurd for a laugh.

review1: '71 makes so much effort to be suspenseful that it doesn't have much time to get into nuance.
review2: Somewhere on the continuum between "spells absolutely everything out" and "bordering on incomprehensible" -- nearer to the latter than to the former -- is this "come on, throw us a bone" narrative.
review3: The real breakout from this impressive thriller is director Yann Demange.
review4: The violence in '71 is sudden and devastating and immediate -- you feel it -- and although the characters are often a little light, Demange navigates this 1970s urban war zone with the intensity and clarity of a born filmmaker.
review5: Part historical drama and part action thriller, '71 makes for gripping viewing.

title: Maggie
review1: Maggie is magnificent -- but in ways we might never have expected from a film toplined by the former Governor of California.
review2: Breslin is affecting as the ordinary young woman beneath the festering flesh, while Arnie shows a delicacy you'd never have suspected, at least not from his current TV ads with meerkats.
review3: The measured pace allows Schwarzengger to show unaccustomed emotional depths as the grief-stricken father and gives Breslin another chance to shine as the teenager whose mortality is cruelly written on her skin.
review4: A missed opportunity.
review5: Gripping and genuinely moving, Maggie is a film of subtlety with a different kind of horror that tears at the heartstrings more than the flesh ...

title: Echoes of War
review1: [A] sluggish post-Civil War drama directed and co-written by Kane Senes that wears its shopworn ideas too heavily on its sleeve.
review2: The somber period western "Echoes of War" retraces some well-traveled moral ground but is invigorated by a cast that includes James Badge Dale, Ethan Embry and William Forsythe.
review3: A gloomy, somewhat underwritten story of two families just after the Civil War, an exploration of the kind of disruption that lingers after fighting on the battlefield is over.
review4: There's something stale about Kane Senes's tepid historical drama Echoes of War, which utilizes the genre's symbols without delivering on its potential for moral or narrative satisfaction.
review5: This tale of the futility of revenge works well enough on its own modest terms.

title: Deli Man
review1: Anjou is not chintzy with the upbeat schmaltz - again with the bouncy klezmer music! - but his chatty story on the decline of the urban eatery's ubiquity is not just about chopped liver, but the loss of Jewish culture.
review2: Heartfelt and heartwarming, Deli Man is documentary filmmaking at its tastiest.
review3: Gruber's sense of a calling to tradition is a common denominator among the many deli owners we meet in this fun and interesting film, mostly stressed-out men who somehow find deep satisfaction in being part of a long history.
review4: Like a fat slab of pastrami, "Deli Man" is the cinematic equivalent of comfort food: warm, generous and made with love.
review5: The audience gets a crash course in kreplach, pastrami and matzo-ball soup. Nothing fancy here - no tarragon top notes, says one of the interviewees - but big portions and good company.

title: Ruth & Alex
review1: A cinema can be a cosy place for an afternoon nap.
review2: Keaton and Freeman's chemistry goes a long way toward selling this trifle, and whatever it may lack in drama, it is refreshing to see a happy golden-years marriage depicted with such affection onscreen.
review3: It's all very cosy and undemanding, but Keaton and Freeman are such amiably engaging screen presences you will probably enjoy spending the time in their company.
review4: A dusty, undemanding piece of Sunday afternoon liberalism.
review5: Typically amenable performances from the leads make all this watchable up to a point, but the material is decidedly stretched out over feature length.

title: Merchants Of Doubt
review1: A movie about manufactured consensus would be a vital public service. But "Merchants of Doubt" isn't quite that movie.
review2: Aside from an eye-opening investigation of useless and harmful flame repellents pumped into furniture, it sticks to climate change without broadening its scope to other examples of corporate spinning, which must be plentiful.
review3: A compelling exposé of professional propagandists, though the movie itself is not agenda-free.
review4: You leave "Merchants of Doubt," as you do any good muckraking documentary, both fascinated and enraged ...
review5: Merchants of Doubt shouldn't be a hard sell. The fact that it is should make you very mad.

title: The Road Within
review1: The presentation of Tourette's syndrome may be authentic, but everything else about the movie - the emotions, the characters, the situations - rings false.
review2: he Road Within backfires by emphasizing the same quirks and imbalances it seeks to soften. Reducing it to the genre of idiot comedy doesn't advance the cause, either.
review3: "The Road Within" suffers from midfilm wandering and a hasty ending, but the message of self-acceptance rings true and clear.
review4: Riveting, full-blooded performances from the young leads and a tough-love ending raise it above what you may expect.
review5: It ultimately succumbs to the bland, sentimental uplift we've come to expect from such outings.

title: 5 Flights Up
review1: If you're looking for a film completely free of loud explosions, raised voices or anything actually happening, you can't go wrong with this fusty New York fairytale.
review2: A couple of pros, playing attractive characters in an amiable yet topical story.
review3: Sometimes you see a play and you can imagine it being a movie. Sometimes you see a small movie like this, and you can imagine it working better as an intimate stage play.
review4: What begins as a sweetly sentimental story ends up being cloyingly melodramatic.
review5: What a pleasure to see a simple, finely tuned dramedy about real adults with real emotions in a real-life situation.

title: Woman in Gold
review1: [A] fascinating true story... gets turned into an uneven mix of historical thriller, courtroom drama and odd-couple comedy.
review2: A synthetic drama devoid of any originality or genuine feeling that reduces an inspiring real-life legal odyssey to a hackneyed tale of the little guy triumphing over impossible odds.
review3: Simon Curtis has made a masterpiece. [full review in Spanish]
review4: A highly recommended story about justice, the importance of family, and reconciling the past and present. [full review in Spanish]
review5: The Woman in Gold is very poorly structured. [full review in Spanish]

title: Alone Yet Not Alone
review1: A surprisingly good movie about the dangers of life in our country in the mid 1700's.

title: Goodbye to All That
review1: The movie's tone never quite evens out, but there are still sweet minor-key moments, and some good lines in all that.
review2: A charming supporting cast fails to invigorate "Goodbye to All That," a relentlessly flat seriocomic take on contemporary relationships marking the directorial debut of "Junebug" scribe Angus MacLachlan.
review3: The film's tone remains playful -- there are even some broad, laugh-out-loud moments involving a sex toy -- but poignant little moments sneak in, hinting at darker, more troubling themes.
review4: Otto Wall, the protagonist of Goodbye to All That, is well-meaning, clumsy and a little dull. The movie embodies his character perfectly.
review5: Despite its flaws, the first feature from "Junebug" writer Angus MacLachlan is a heartfelt, bittersweet and often amusing portrait of early middle-age.

title: 24 Days
review1: Knowing the outcome behind the true-life tragedy "24 Days" doesn't diffuse the horror, the tension or the sadness of watching one family's drama unfold day after agonizing day when a son is kidnapped and hope dies.
review2: 24 Days takes strength from real-world specifics. But the most powerful thing about the movie is its rejection of omniscience. The crime it reconstructs is beyond understanding.
review3: Sadly, "24 Days" isn't nearly as involving as it should be.
review4: As a suspenseful true crime story, "24 Days" succeeds. As a warning against the ever present dangers of anti-Semitism, it is eloquent and disturbing. It's in combining the two that Arcady mishandles the case.
review5: 24 Days is neither subtle nor particularly sophisticated as filmmaking, but its refusal to reduce lived reality to generic tropes is admirable.

title: Freedom
review1: The preaching is earnest and the intentions are good, but the corn is high and the presentation is amateurish.
review2: "Freedom" takes a compelling chapter in American history - the flight of slaves from Southern bondage to Canada via the Underground Railroad - and flattens its drama.
review3: The film leaves us with the impression that slaves' survival had more to do with sheer luck than dogged resilience.
review4: The film tries to have the scope of "12 Years a Slave." But it's ruined by the sanctimonious songs that turn the drama into a half-baked musical. Much worse: the filmmakers' need to show that not all whites employed in the slave trade were evil.
review5: A schmaltzy, deeply sentimentalized drama about American slavery and the rise of the Underground Railroad.

title: Ex Machina
review1: Ex Machina has a precise visual sheen that evokes David Fincher, and earns the sudden, quiet, powerful scares of his best work.
review2: Ex Machina is one of the year's best films because it's smart, entertaining and disturbing, and also because it never underestimates the viewer, creating a perfect balance between entertainment and deep ideas. [Full review in Spanish]
review3: A deliberately paced 'hard science fiction' film if ever there was one, this is graced by three terrific performances.
review4: Ex Machina, ever muted and somber, is imbued with a looming sense of dread.
review5: Ex Machina uses state-of-the-art special effects to deliver a smart new take on A.I.

title: Clouds of Sils Maria
review1: What you won't see coming is the nuanced and confident performance by Kristen Stewart, better known to the world as Bella the pouty vampire lover from the "Twilight" series.
review2: Multi-layered complexities and stand-out performances make this a rich experience, with Kristen Stewart surprising the most.
review3: Clouds of Sils Maria is talky and slow moving, yet the interplay of its leading women is as mesmerising as the strange weather phenomenon - a cloud bank pouring through an alpine pass - that gives the film its title.
review4: ...a challenging and deeply engaging film that's remarkably beautiful and grounded in universal experience.
review5: The film explores the psychology of female role-play with depth and intelligence, and the performances are outstanding -- Binoche brings her expected ethereal complexity, and Stewart cuts through her aura like vinegar through grease.

title: The Longest Ride
review1: For once, a movie based on a Nicholas Sparks book appears to be populated by relatively realistic approximations of human beings dealing with relationship conflict in realistic ways.
review2: Like all of Sparks's stories it's corny as hell, but there's an unabashed, old-fashioned charm that gradually warms the cockles and moistens the eye.
review3: Thanks to the scenery, the performances and a rich vein of unintentional silliness, The Longest Ride feels a whole lot shorter than it is.
review4: Devotees of author Nicholas Sparks's work will no doubt be delighted with The Longest Ride's bonanza offering: two militantly preposterous love stories for the price of one!
review5: Sometimes it's better just to hold your hands up and welcome movies as cheesily inoffensive as this.

title: Dawn Patrol
review1: The film, directed by veteran filmmaker Daniel Petrie Jr., attempts to stuff too many elements into the premise.
review2: "Dawn Patrol" has a lot on its plate and manages to drop it all.
review3: A repulsive and disgustingly manipulative roundrobin of revenge that veers from softcore porn to an emotionally ignorant parody of a family drama.
review4: By the time the film gets to a genuinely interesting moment in the final scenes it will be hard for most viewers to stop stifling their laughter.
review5: Dawn Patrol feels distended and awkwardly paced despite a lean, 87-minute runtime.

title: Kid Blue
review1: Kid Blue has a meandering jug band sensibility and a premise hilariously relevant to Hopper's situation.
review2: Kid Blue is a well-meaning, liberal, anti-fascist Western, dressed up with some good performances by Peter Boyle, Lee Purcell and Janice Rule. But it's not a very good movie.
review3: A gentle little fable about the mechanization of the west and its effects on a small-time outlaw.
review5: It was a keen satire of the last of the frontier days, but its hipness failed to rub off on me.

title: Set Fire To The Stars
review1: Gorgeous, evocative and well performed ...
review2: The film wallows too much in its subject's glumness, but it comes alive whenever TV actor and co-writer Celyn Jones, whose only previous film credit is 2005's Lassie, plays Thomas as a big shaggy dog.
review3: "Set Fire to the Stars" barely skims the surface of characters you wish had been given more dimension, but as a snapshot of postwar academia and its pretensions, it exerts a creepy fascination.
review4: Stylistically assured and tastefully appointed.
review5: [A] watchable but thematically repetitive drama about Welsh poet Dylan Thomas' arrival in America in 1950.

title: Wild Horses
review1: [Duvall] loses the thread - and our attention - one too many times in a sea of lackluster conversations and unremarkable plot strands.
review2: Could Robert Duvall's incoherent melodrama "Wild Horses" have been salvaged by a skillful editor? Probably not.
review3: What a shambles.
review4: These competing narratives are connected haphazardly by visual transitions that feel like someone sat on the DVD remote, plus jarring tonal shifts between intimate conversations and tire-spinning car chases.
review5: The theatrical performances don't come close to matching Duvall's 1997 directing breakthrough The Apostle.

title: What We Do In The Shadows
review1: Delightfully satisfying.
review2: The most important thing to know about What We Do In The Shadows is that it's laugh-out-loud hilarious and we urge you to see it as soon as possible.
review3: What We Do in the Shadows is both a refreshingly different take on vampire conventions and one of the funniest comedies of the year.
review4: Waititi and Clement's collaboration is irresistibly amusing.
review5: If there's an angle of vampire mythology that Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement didn't find a way to turn into a great joke, I'll be damned if I could tell you what it is.

title: Glass Chin
review1: It's Crudup who steals every scene, whether he's waxing philosophical about the benefits of iCloud or blackmailing Bud with a charming, unsettling grin.
review2: Story-wise, nothing in Glass Chin will surprise you. But stylistically, the film's got something cool going on.
review3: Despite an appealing fondness for New York locations and habits, Mr. Buschel and his cinematographer, Ryan Samul, have embalmed their film in style.
review4: Punchy dialogue, sharply drawn characters and excellent performances fuel "Glass Chin," an intimate drama that's set in the boxing world but is about so much more.
review5: Corey Stoll is the only reason to sit through this muddled Jersey-set drama.

title: 3 Hearts
review1: It leaves behind a nagging feeling, a suggestion there's more to the story than its story.
review2: Despite a slow start and jarring narration, "3 Hearts" entertains with its melodramatic amour fou.
review3: A tasteful, mildly intriguing romantic drama from writer-director Benoît Jacquot.
review4: 3 Hearts" brings together an all-star team of French actresses in a movie about a love triangle that could not be more French unless everyone smoked more.
review5: A French romantic drama directed as though it were a thriller.

title: White God
review1: If someone wants to make a case that our four-legged actor friends deserve to be considered for Oscar consideration, right alongside Streep and McConaughey, they need only offer White God as evidence.
review2: What it all means is open to interpretation. Read it as a parable or as a horror movie. Read it as the story of love between a girl and her dog. Read it however you want. No matter what your take, you won't be disappointed.
review3: White God offers a dark - very dark - take on the way humans exert authority, and superiority, over our fellow creatures.
review4: Kornél Mundruczó shows great ability to create atmosphere, generate emotion and get heartwarming performances from those who you'd least expect... [Full review in Spanish]
review5: More than the political metaphor we see on screen, the movie's best parts are seeing 300 dogs on screen running through the streets of Budapest. [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Water Diviner
review1: Indeed, this is the 51-year-old Crowe's first time as a movie director, but he's hardly a novice actor stepping behind the camera for some sort of vanity project.
review2: It's clear that Russell Crowe has poured his heart and soul into the historical romance The Water Diviner, his first feature as a director. If only the film were better.
review3: A sloggy, heartfelt piece of quasi-magical realist storytelling.
review4: Russell Crowe's well crafted if tonally uneven historical drama... [is] sometimes stirring, sometimes sentimental and sometimes far-fetched.
review5: The film is well-acted, beautifully photographed, and thematically rich. Russell Crowe may have a second whole career ahead of him.

title: Jauja
review1: This fifth feature by the brilliant Argentine filmmaker Lisandro Alonso is his first with professional actors and a period setting, yet it meshes thematically with his other work.
review2: Alonso sustains an atmosphere of otherworldly immanence in a vivid setting, with a style involving long takes with characters posed as if in tableaux vivants.
review3: Viewers who can accept a defiantly slow pace, a few loose plot threads and a directorial style that works by intimation, will be rewarded.
review4: If you applauded the genre-tweaking twists of Gus Van Sant's "Gerry" and Kelly Reichardt's "Meek's Cutoff," you may have a good time (or at least an interesting one) at acclaimed Argentine director Lisandro Alonso's latest puzzler, "Jauja."
review5: 'Jauja' is a film to make you wonder.

title: Comet
review1: Just when you think you're about to fall for this fuzzy sci-fi romance, it disappears into its own navel.
review2: Justin Long is a fine actor, but you have to like him a lot to get through "Comet," Sam Esmail's trippy, overly mannered romance.
review3: Watching a not-very-interesting couple break up is one thing; watching them break up and get back together numerous times in different universes and dimensions is, well ... to paraphrase "Jaws," I'm going to need a bigger popcorn bag.
review4: Its conceits ... get in the way of its characters, making it feel fussy and convoluted when it aims for something more simple and elegant.
review5: These occasionally obnoxious, certainly neurotic young lovers have beating, sometimes broken hearts, and that, as the apostle Paul once noted, tends to trump all.

title: 52 Tuesdays
review1: Brings deft emotional nuance to the seemingly inexhaustibly complex relationship between individual identity and family ties.
review2: A frustratingly fragmented yet warmly intimate portrait of an evolving bond that frays but doesn't sever.
review3: Grippingly plotted and exquisitely thoughtful, 52 Tuesdays is a poignant reminder that neither confusion nor crisis is doomed to be calamitous.
review4: The sensitively observed drama is distinguished by its structurally adventurous approach and the intimacy of its storytelling.
review5: There are interesting moments throughout and the performances of the non-professional cast, particularly Cobham-Hervey, are very good.

title: Runoff
review1: Promising work that's worth checking out.
review2: The low energy pace and performances strive for naturalism but just don't achieve compelling tension or suspense.
review3: The 90-minute movie is a tightly compressed exploration of forces that make it next to impossible to operate a small business when a voracious corporation moves in for the kill.
review4: Even when Levin's symbolism is a little on the nose, these elements are balanced with enough small details and moments that they blend in to the larger texture of the characters' lives.
review5: The movie achieves an understated resonance through Levin's emotionally sensitive compositions and her clued-in portrayal of life in a middle-American farming community.

title: Faults
review1: The wan drama is enlivened by bursts of black comedy, some bits more effective than others, and though it ultimately disappoints, there's promise in the understated creepiness of Riley Stearns' debut feature.
review2: While "Faults" glances at the narcissism of cult leaders, its most penetrating investigation is into the root emptiness within disciples, the desperate hunger to relinquish personal initiative.
review3: A movie that undergoes a slow, captivating metamorphosis, scene by scene, though who's the caterpillar and who's the cocoon remains unclear until the very end.
review4: Winstead is one of the most intuitive actors of her generation, and though her impressive range is easy to spot, it's her elasticity that makes her so rewarding to watch.
review5: Mind control is a topic that should be fascinating, but it's utterly forgettable in this disappointing, low-budget indie.

title: Second Opinion: Laetrile at Sloan-Kettering
review1: Sometimes a movie featuring a man sitting on a chair talking to the camera is exactly as uncompelling as that sounds.
review2: This one's for the conspiracy-minded only.
review3: Mr. Moss's message is clear, shrewdly edited and peculiarly interesting.
review4: Though a documentary, it's dramatic enough to be reminiscent of "The Insider," the whistleblowing thriller about Big Tobacco.
review5: Like many docs with activist undertones, Second Opinion tells a potentially interesting story in a bland way - a fixed camera on its main subject, who recounts the story detail by detail.

title: Any Day
review1: A cliché-ridden, heavy-handed redemptive drama written and directed by Rustam Branaman.
review2: An earnest, utterly predictable indie that wastes a couple of decent performances in service of a hackneyed and weak script ...
review3: Everything in Any Day is portentous and presented as if it is loaded with meaning; none of it is, because everything is either so obvious or so arbitrary that nothing actually means anything.
review4: A well-intentioned disaster, only slightly redeemed by a committed performance by Sean Bean, whose talent proves nowhere near enough to make this manipulative tripe more digestible.
review5: Any Day falls into the painfully crowded trough between not-bad and seriously not-good movies.

title: Jackie & Ryan
review1: The film feels like an uncomfortable hodgepodge of styles and tones - gritty and realistic when it's following Ryan, awkwardly staged when it's following Jackie.
review2: "Jackie & Ryan" may prove too low-key and deliberately paced for less patient viewers, but distinct pleasures are to be had from this compactly shot film's easy rhythms, affecting tone and nicely modulated performances.
review3: You anticipate a cheap, sentimental ending. But it is not to be, and the movie is much the better for it.
review4: The section of the movie that should offer a climactic rush, however fleeting, feels instead more like falling action, or even a postscript.
review5: Jackie & Ryan is a sort of low-rent Nicholas Sparks romance that, for want of a better way to put it, never generates any sparks of its own.

title: The Salvation
review1: In an untamed world where hypocrisy is loud and where no one can be trusted, salvation is one's own business and actions speak louder than words.
review2: Wild West vengeance gets a terrific homage and a bloody reckoning in this oater excursion ...
review3: Lacks enough complexity to hold cliché at bay, and the CGI-heavy visuals are distracting.
review4: Writer-director Kristian Levring says there are 62 different references to classic Westerns in his own oater "The Salvation." Perhaps the greatest compliment I can pay his film is that I never looked for them. I was too busy enjoying the film.
review5: With the help of two charismatic stars, it does conjure up its share of evocative genre moments.

title: Madame Bovary
review1: Barthes feels the need to improve on Flaubert, adding and dropping scenes and inventing social metaphors - mainly spiderwebs and corsets.
review2: For a film about passion, it feels oddly flat and often passionless.
review3: With her thousand-mile frown, Mia Wasikowska was born to play Victorian heroines, though she's a little too intelligent and self-aware for Flaubert's Emma Bovary.
review4: This umpteenth adaptation of Flaubert's classic novel at least chooses its Emma wisely ...
review5: Gustave Flaubert's endlessly filmed novel Madame Bovary is hauled out yet again for another go here by director Sophie Barthes, and the result is a handsome, considerably simplified and oh-so-melodramatic costume epic.

title: Brother's Keeper
review1: Weak faith-based teen drama has violence, heavy themes.

title: Far From the Madding Crowd
review1: The current Crowd, which is a nice diversion from the summer's CGI extravaganza, should be a crowd pleaser.
review2: The film's restrained nature may ... [keep] it from being a major hit, but for all it loses in marketability it gains in being a suitably emotive experience.
review3: The story's arc is pure Harlequin -romance, but it's given a sheen of respectability by Hardy's words and Thomas Vinterberg's lush direction.
review4: The new movie version of Far From the Madding Crowd can't compete with its predecessor on any of those fronts, but it does have a trump card, and her name is Carey Mulligan.
review5: You know that your Victorian England period piece is not working when the most interesting thing on screen is the clothes-horse fashion sense of your leading lady.

title: Every Secret Thing
review1: It's described as a smart, suspenseful psychological thriller, but there's nothing smart about it, and as an alleged thriller, when the mysteries are explained in a twist finale, it could use a psychologist of its own.
review2: Diane Lane is chilling as Alice's shifty mother, and though some of the "secret things" are Law & Order predictable, other revelations will haunt you for days.
review3: Sometimes the whole is less than the sum of the parts.
review4: The film has enough twists and dark reveals to grab the viewer. But it's Macdonald's sad turn as Alice that eats away at your soul.
review5: Despite those credentials from the filmmakers and an excellent cast that includes Diane Lane, Elizabeth Banks, Nate Parker and Dakota Fanning, "Every Secret Thing" feels flat and unfocused.

title: Blackbird
review1: Despite its sense of mission, the film suffers from soapy excesses and narrative disjunctures.
review2: Director Patrik-Ian Polk makes the ending a little too pat, but he makes us root for these characters to be happy, and for their world to be a better place.
review3: Anything that can go wrong, will - often in spectacular fashion.
review4: Patrik-Ian Polk makes a huge artistic leap with this deeply affecting, funny and original peek at one confused youth's coming out process.
review5: At no point does anyone in the film even vaguely resemble an actual 21st-century teenager; when these kids text each other, it comes across like science fiction.

title: Child 44
review1: The movie hints at a riveting story but is incapable of delivering it.
review2: Given these actors and the ravishing decrepitude of the locations and costumes and the lustrous cinematography of Oliver Wood, I found it more than watchable the whole way through.
review3: Once in a while comes that star-studded film to remind that even the best assemblage of thespians isn't enough to save the most underwhelming of films.
review4: Get past some contrived plotting - and the needlessly thick Russian accents adopted by the mostly British cast - and this 1950s-set crime thriller is grimly fascinating.
review5: It's all so mushy and unclear that by the time a climactic fight takes place in a literal mire you'll feel as muddied as the participants.

title: Insurgent
review1: I appreciate the attempt to try to make this world -- an obliterated, totalitarian Chicago -- as watchable as possible. But there's too much to keep straight.
review2: Dull, monotonous, and painfully tedious.
review3: There's much more that doesn't work here than does.
review4: Instead of helping the story to move along as the middle part of a trilogy should, Insurgent ends up being nothing more than another helping of the problems that held back its predecessor.
review5: Ah, that story we ordered last year finally arrived.

title: True Story
review1: Franco and Hill's early scenes together maintains intrigue for a while, but True Story never quite indicates that it has something compelling going on beneath the surface.
review2: It's good, but it could've been amazing and falls short. [Full review in Spanish]
review3: There's a story to tell here. But in the hands of stars Jonah Hill and James Franco, it's not a great story.
review4: Perhaps True Story should have been a stage play, but this low-budget exercise is a chance to savor the abilities of its well-known stars.
review5: For all the big and intriguing themes the film subsequently pays lip service to, there's no disguising the fact that this is a fairly dull and suspense-free true crime drama.

title: A Little Chaos
review1: True French historians should simply relax and enjoy a film that takes us on a beautifully photographed cinematic romp into a past as it likely SHOULD have been.
review2: "A Little Chaos" wants us to be fascinated by a feminist who never was, then undermines her by casting an approving eye on the steamy affair she begins with her boss.
review3: It's difficult to conjure... excitement for a mess like "A Little Chaos," a lazy and off-puttingly anachronistic feminist fantasy about an 18th-century female landscape designer who finds love while creating... one of the grandest spaces in Versailles.
review4: Winslet is radiant, but limited by the fictional character written for her: a flawless woman whose lack of happiness is hampered by grief over a terrible loss.
review5: Rickman doesn't take risks and seems to have some difficulties in acting and directing at the same time. [full review in Spanish]

title: Do You Believe?
review1: A deranged melodrama where any sense of soapy, campy fun is undercut by the preachy, self-serious tone.
review2: A self-aggrandizing sermon that preaches only to the faithful.
review3: Wherever you fall on the spectrum of spirituality, the only answer to "Do You Believe?" is "No."
review4: More professionally produced and acted than the indiegelical norm, but only fitfully engaging on a dramatic level and entirely hermetic on a theological one.
review5: The cast is a motley mix of the known and unknown, all doing their best to deliver Konzelman and Solomon's awkward sermon, under Jonathan M. Gunn's equally awkward direction.

title: Match
review1: When a play is adapted for the screen, too often you can see the stitches.
review2: It's great fun to watch Patrick Stewart in "Match," seeming to chew scenery (and actually doing so from time to time) but offering something else underneath.
review3: Belber sometimes strains credulity to keep the characters together until the end, but Stewart carries the story to its conclusion with a performance ranging from the fierce to the tender.
review4: This small film (virtually all of it filmed in Tobi's New York apartment) is a real gem.
review5: Onscreen, the material seems contrived and thin. What must have been an electrifying clash of personalities onstage is over the top on film.

title: Police Story: Lockdown
review1: It makes fans of the original "Police Story" franchise wistful for the mundane locales but extraordinary daredevil stunt work of yore.
review2: This is a very poorly paced and structured movie, cutting between time periods to fill in the sort of convoluted backstory that a leaner, more propulsive piece of pulp probably wouldn't bother with in the first place.
review3: Jackie Chan makes a dull departure from his former kickass shenanigans in this rickety action-drama.
review4: This is predictable crime thriller fluff that you've come to expect from a deteriorating legend. Police Story: Lockdown isn't entirely awful, but it dilutes what was otherwise a nearly flawless and action packed franchise.
review5: 'Police Story: Lockdown' was supposed to be a star vehicle, but a vehicle that doesn't let its star shine is of no use to anyone.

title: Lost For Words
review1: Hope endures, but not for this movie.
review2: It's curious that the only conflict mined from this bicultural relationship is strictly linguistic.
review3: Perhaps only an expat like American-born, Hong Kong-based director Stanley J. Orzel could create a tribute to his adopted city as loving as Lost for Words.
review4: [Faris'] relationship with co-star Huang, while cordial, hardly reflects an emotional connection strong enough for him to conquer his character's post-romantic breakup stress syndrome.
review5: "Forget the words, follow your heart" is this film's oft-repeated Hallmark card sentiment. You may just want to forget the movie and follow the aisle to the exit.

title: Soaked In Bleach
review1: The inclination to dismiss this as fanciful conspiracy theorizing is here countered by the testimonies of various experts, certain that the Seattle police really bungled their investigation.
review2: By the time Wecht declares that this is a death that simply has to be reinvestigated, even a viewer with no special attachment to Cobain's legacy is likely to agree.
review3: Whether he's way off base or not, Tom Grant is clearly a believer, and the ideas he presents via Soaked In Bleach-as unabashedly one-sided as they are-aren't easily dismissed.
review4: The problem is, when facing down Love's and Cobain's outsize, junked-up personalities, Grant seems a total naïf.
review5: The story is still provocative, but the director has nothing new to add to it.

title: Club Life
review1: The film is undermined by choppy editing and a penchant for hoary aphorisms and forced gravitas.
review2: "Club Life" is a flat, disjointed drama that's buoyed by a couple of good performances. Your mileage may vary depending on your interest in dance montages.
review3: Don't feel bad about skipping the line for Club Life.
review4: This connect-the-dots drama [...] carries the narcissistic myopia of so many people who are told their lives would make a great movie, and who believe it.

title: The Riot Club (Posh)
review1: Although the performances are uniformly on point and the dialogue is tartly British, the film ultimately fails to earn its riotous stripes.
review2: I was drained and quivering with fury and disgust.
review3: The Riot Club is, finally, a monster movie. Which I suppose is what some become who are too rich and powerful to be bothered with inhibitions or morality.
review4: The Riot Club comes with the dubious ambition of instructing us as to the evil ways of spoiled British toffs, as if that were needed.
review5: It's all quite superficial, but never less than gripping, and is aided by an ending that at least doesn't compromise too much-the movie finishes with a smirk more than a smile.

title: Little Boy
review1: Despite boasting several important moral lessons, the period piece is more artificial than a polyester teddy bear stuffed with Splenda and Cheez Whiz - and about as appealing
review2: It's meant to be a tale of uplift for faith-based audiences, but instead wears viewers down with a heavy-handed narrative, an overbearing score and voiceover that spells out everything in cringe-inducing, folksy tones.
review3: Tolerance, World War II history and faith are served up with a sticky sentimental gloss in the family film "Little Boy."
review4: A movie that has the haranguing inspirational tone of a marathon Sunday-school lesson.
review5: I just wish the filmmakers didn't feel like they had to hit us over the head with all the moral pontificating to get their point across.

title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared
review1: It's never explained what Allan's mental state is, other than lovable geriatric rascal-itis, an irritating trope that hardly constitutes a certifiable condition.
review2: "The 100-Year-Old-Man" is wonderfully inventive, silly fun.
review3: This peripatetic farce practically propels itself.
review4: It seems destined for a Hollywood remake, which is likely to be more polished but not nearly as weirdly charming.
review5: Herngren's hyper-plotty story goes from testing credulity to utterly insulting it, as incident piles on to incident in an ever-escalating cascade of you-won't-believe-what-happens-nexts.

title: La Sapienza
review1: On the surface, writer-director Eugène Green's film "La Sapienza" is slow, strange and awkward - but stick with it and it may win you over.
review2: The Sapience juxtaposes insights on how people are emotionally connected with ruminations on the buildings and spaces through which they move, in which they live and, in Alexandre's case, which they also create.
review3: A beautiful space for people and light.
review4: This kind of formalism needs to do more than walk through classical wonders. It should want to create cinema that can stand near or beside them. This movie defensively consecrates what's already there. You don't need a film to do that.
review5: An exquisite rumination on life, love and art that tickles the heart and mind in equal measure.

title: Welp (Cub)
review1: Referencing everything from 'Suspiria' to 'The Cabin in the Woods', this is a horror movie made by and for genre fans - but that's not necessarily a good thing.
review2: This backwoods camping adventure and folk-legend fusion flies off the rails, unleashing a grotesque and vile nature in every character. "Cub" will leave you wanting to pack up your things and head home early.
review3: Similar in tone to Let The Right One In, it starts slowly and builds into a fantastical and creepy look at childhood.
review4: At a time when horror movies seem to only want to make the audience jump, it's great to find one that bothers to build a sense of dread.
review5: Feels a bit like 15 slasher movies you've already seen, but also ends up being a rather novel, unpredictable, and insane little horror flick.

title: Strangerland
review1: Strangerland runs out of gas, leaving us with a couple of final "Forget You" (shall we say) moments. Thanks. Thanks for nothing.
review2: erie and unpredictable, Strangerland holds attention, even if traditional suspense tricks are avoided like they were dingos at the daycare.
review3: Kidman's best performances have often been as grieving moms (Dead Calm, The Others, Rabbit Hole) and here she provides the flaccid movie's sole flash of daring and unpredictability.
review4: Director Kim Farrant's debut feature is beautifully shot and offers some powerful, well-acted moments from a strong cast, but it's just relentlessly dreary.
review5: It certainly provides Kidman with some meaty, twisted material. But the film abandons the viewer in the end, leaving the audience as lost as those kids.

title: Love at First Fight
review1: Director Thomas Cailley conjures up a vivid, unusual world, offering a playful reversal of usual gender roles.
review2: There's a better movie floating around the edges of the French import "Love at First Fight" than first-time feature director Thomas Cailley has allowed to surface.
review3: All in all, this film is refreshingly original, an existential, boy-meets-survivalist romantic comedy.
review4: What starts out as a promisingly unique tale of a macho woman and the meek guy who falls for her turns into something else once Madeleine leaves for training camp and Arnaud follows.
review5: This debut feature by French writer-director Thomas Cailley is the rare romantic comedy that's satisfying as genre entertainment but also inspires serious thought on pertinent social issues.

title: The Kidnapping of Michel Houellebecq
review1: A fans- and detractors-only affair. At its worst, it feels like a highbrow transgressive-celebrity-cameo skit.
review2: Hilarious, full of humor that is understated, wry and dependent on familiarity with interests as wide as Houellebecq's own.
review3: The Houellebecq we see on screen is obviously rooted as much in fiction as in fact, yet what makes his performance so fascinating is the mischievous glee he takes in sending up his own persona.
review4: A divertingly eccentric, often comically absurd movie about a novelist ... who finds something like happiness after being abducted.
review5: A playful blurring of fact and fiction.

title: The Pardon
review1: A plodding feature that makes ample use of the legal record as well as evocative Shreveport locations while leaving the well of affecting drama untapped.
review2: Jaime King lights up the screen as an empathetic femme fatale in a compelling costume drama painstakingly-recreating events surrounding a real-life murder trial unfolding in Louisiana back in 1940.
review3: Part period drama, part courtroom drama and part sermon, it's a film that never gives itself much of a chance to hit its narrative stride.

title: October Gale
review1: A rather silly, unbelievable thriller.
review2: Filmmaker Nadda's stock-in-trade is restraint, but October Gale builds up to nothing much.
review3: October Gale is a quiet thriller set in the wilds of Georgian Bay. It's an uneven movie with some odd jolts in the story, but the performances -- especially from Patricia Clarkson -- are noteworthy.
review4: Writer-director Ruba Nadda is wonderful at building up suspense for the first half of her latest film. But once she's got our attention, she has nowhere to go with it.
review5: A film that begins as a languorous study in grieving and shifts with screeching abruptness into a crime thriller.

title: Welcome To New York
review1: Few actors in the world are better suited to play a gluttonous pig than Gerard Depardieu, and I mean that in the best possible way one can make such an assertion.
review2: [The] deliberate structure demonstrates Ferrara's artfulness, as does the lush imagery.
review3: The film, a sleek and oddly moving study in the cost of debauchery, has its gleeful excesses.
review4: This frank, unruly look at sex, privilege and power unfolds so much like real life that it proves an intriguing and strangely immersive experience.
review5: In an Abel Ferrara movie, this sort of damaged, raging, unrepentant bull passes for an antihero.

title: The Color Wheel
review1: "The Color Wheel" partially recalls the scathing audacity of "The Graduate" some 45 years ago.
review2: You might not "like" Perry's movie, but it's hard to deny the forensically assured sensibility at work.
review3: Hard to swallow but impossible to ignore.
review4: Perry and co-writer/star Carlen Altman are Colin and J.R., the most loathsomely lovable brother-sister duo in the history of cinema.
review5: The most entertaining unpleasant film I've seen in years.

title: "Two Days, One Night"
review1: Consider Marion Cotillard's Oscar-nominated performance in Two Days, One Night a tour de nuance.
review2: As with their previous films, the brothers cast a discerning gaze on working-class lives, without preachiness or sentimentality.
review3: [T]he Dardennes illustrate with compelling drama the struggle to stay afloat in an unrelenting capitalist system.
review4: It is in within these acutely observed aspects of humanity, not at its best or worst but simply as it is that Two Days, One Night achieves its greatness.
review5: does not shy away from the harsh truths of life, ; but, at the same time, it seeks out and reveals hope and potential in every situation

title: Wolf at the Door
review1: In his first film Coimbra already appears to be a master of the cinematic tightrope walk, weaving flashbacks and detective work in an energetic and pleasingly sleazy manner (this is, after all, a modern noir).
review2: Though a strong director of actors, Coimbra is significantly less assured as a visual stylist.
review3: As a piece of storytelling, "A Wolf at the Door" may be a tawdry little shocker. But on a visceral level, it is a knife to the gut.
review4: Potent sexual attraction can be a wonderful thing, but it can also bring out the absolute worst in the people involved, as the bleak, disturbing Latin American noir "A Wolf at the Door" convincingly demonstrates.
review5: Coimbra's overambitious use of a complex narrative structure can feel clunky, and worst of all, the kid at the center is practically forgotten in the assemblage of flashbacks, significantly diminishing the emotional pull.

title: Where Hope Grows
review1: Director Chris Dowling should have taken another swing at his script for the sake of clarity and dimension before cameras rolled.
review2: Not to be flip, but "Where Hope Grows" has the potential to be a decent inspirational film until God shows up.
review3: Like most if not all faith-based entertainments, "Where Hope Grows" embraces the idea that God works in mysterious ways. But it also insists that God helps only those who help themselves.
review4: "Where Hope Grows" wears its heart on its sleeve, hawking its message of salvation through faith to anyone who's in the market for cheesy uplift and saccharine sentiment.
review5: Writer-director Chris Dowling handles [the] worrisome premise with a more even hand than this genre's ill-advised predecessors ...

title: Lila & Eve
review1: Davis (who was an executive producer on the film) gives a strong performance, as if she were acting in one of those many prestige projects lighting up her resume. It's a noble try, but this dreck is beyond saving.
review2: Alas, even a promising premise and a fine actress like Davis can't save an increasingly ludicrous plot. Justice may be served, but screenwriting logic? Not so much.
review3: "Lila and Eve" deteriorates into a tawdry shoot-'em-up whose screenplay takes an ill-advised surreal twist that propels the movie deep into the ozone.
review4: A mid-point twist is particularly ridiculous, and in an attempt to reconcile this turning point, the final act of the movie becomes a mess.
review5: A standard-issue female vigilante thriller that's skillfully elevated by the performances of leads Viola Davis and Jennifer Lopez.

title: Five Star
review1: The writer and director, Keith Miller, establishes engaging characters but stifles their thoughts and emotions, sets up dramatic situations but avoids their practicalities and implications.
review2: It's eye-opening to see an indie approach to this genre.
review3: Keith Miller's Five Star makes its nonactors look like trained thesps and (in a good way) vice versa.
review4: Slow and steady, and with remarkable assuredness, Keith Miller's "Five Star" plays mean-streets drama in the lowest of keys.
review5: There's just not enough meat on these bones, and what meat there is has been thoroughly chewed over.

title: Animals
review1: "Animals" is a stark, brilliant, uncompromising, beautifully acted piece of work.
review2: The couple's doomed romance feels familiar from numerous other films about addiction, and the movie is downright bad whenever it aspires to visual poetry.
review3: It's gritty and grim, but "Animals" is also a gripping portrait of young junkies in love.
review4: The trajectory of "Animals" is obvious in the opening minutes of this numbing if well-acted junkie drama.
review5: Mr. Schiffli shoots in a fluid style, tweaking colors and focus to register changes in perception and feeling.

title: Broken Horses
review1: Inside some bad movies, there's a good one, fighting to get out. Inside Broken Horses there's just another bad movie.
review2: [A] weirdly baroque modern-day Western that, while it boasts undeniably imaginative visual and plot flourishes, is far too absurd to take seriously.
review3: Mr. Yelchin's character looks somewhat at a loss about what goes on here, and who can blame him, especially when he visits the former music teacher who has lost his legs in a run-in with the bad guys and now lives in a house warmed by a flaming barrel.
review4: While Chopra attempts to crack the American market with a slice of cinematic apple pie, he holds up a mirror to how Hollywood's tried-and-true narrative of vigilantism connotes who we are, at home and overseas.
review5: There are secrets and revelations in "Broken Horses," none of them revealing.

title: The Surface
review1: This is the sort of film where you enjoy the cast even though the running time becomes a bit of a snore.
review2: "The Surface" has such fine performances in it from Mulkey and Astin that you wish the filmmakers had trusted them more, letting them bring the film back to shore on their own.
review3: The film is a true two-hander-and Astin and Mulkey are mostly up for the task-but inept storytelling sinks the picture faster than anyone can bail it out.
review4: Here's a four-word review of "The Surface": Go see "The Surface."

title: Beyond The Mask
review1: A drama of redemption by way of an American Revolution history lesson, Chad Burns' action-adventure yarn offers little in the way of subtlety or surprise.
review2: [A] stagy, overstuffed costume drama.
review3: laughable would-be epic is even more ridiculous than it sounds
review4: Full of hackneyed aphorisms and improbable history.
review5: It's just a good, fun movie.

title: Dark Was The Night
review1: A well-crafted horror pic that compensates (at least to a point) for its lack of original ideas with nice atmospherics and judicious restraint.
review2: It's quite obvious the filmmakers didn't put a lot of thought into it and went straight for the cheapest thrills.
review3: The trouble lies in Tyler Hisel's script, which teems with wheezy conventions (as its title suggests) ...
review4: As generic as its title, Jack Heller's monster-in-the-woods horror film aspires to be the stuff of nightmares but instead merely lulls the viewer into an untroubled sleep.
review5: I mean, what else is the night supposed to be?

title: Felt
review1: "Felt" is a moodily disturbing character study of a besieged woman for whom art is engagement and coping mechanism, but also conversely a source of alienation and even a weapon.
review2: Some viewers will no doubt find "Felt" maddening because it never answers seemingly crucial plot questions that a normal movie or TV show would feel compelled to clear up. That ambiguity is precisely the source of its power, and its cinematic quality.
review3: At once underwritten and overconceptualized. Reading about the filmmakers' intentions is more rewarding than watching the results.
review4: Although there are a few moments that feel a little too on the nose, Felt sneaks up on you and lingers for hours afterward.
review5: With predominantly improvised dialogue and performances, Felt gains scant narrative complexity from an over-reliance on a no-frills documentary style.

title: L'amour au temps de la guerre civile (Love in the Time of Civil War)
The Face Of An Angel
review1: Occasionally Winterbottom delivers a haunting, effective moment, giving a hint of a different, more compelling film. But then it's back to the self-righteous, self-indulgent, muddled metaphors.
review2: The film does occasionally show a pulse when it tries to re-imagine the life of the victim - when it turns the tables on the mystery and tries to become a film about love and life, instead of doom and death. But it's too little, too late, and too lame.
review3: There's a great deal of intelligent material here. Winterbottom mounts a harsh attack on our fascination with killers and our tendency to forget the victim. Yet it's overlaid with so much navel-gazing, it's hard to take.
review4: Rambling, frustrating and wholly uninvolving, "The Face of an Angel" swarms with ideas that have no place to land.
review5: Like the floundering filmmaker at its center, "The Face of an Angel" never seems sure of what story it wants to tell.

title: About Elly
