review1: Farhadi has written a first-rate script, enabling intricate plotting to intertwine with well-defined characters, and "About Elly" shows him at ease with the wide variety of situations his writing explores.
review2: "About Elly" is a stunning surprise package, profound in utterly unexpected ways.
review3: By the time the mystery is solved, it hardly seems to matter. What matters is the casual lack of honesty that almost everyone seems to depend on.
review4: It's an incisive portrait of a particular society, but it should resonate everywhere.
review5: There are no false notes anywhere in this cast of performers.

title: The Suicide Theory
review1: A contrived but weirdly compelling thriller involving a tortured hitman, his willing prey, and the inexplicable curse that keeps them both from realizing their shared goal.
review2: "Suicide Theory" does boast a couple of intriguingly complex characters, however, and some interesting points on how little satisfaction is derived from retribution, especially when what goes around reliably comes around.
review3: It sounds preposterous, and much of the movie is over the top, but the energy of the actors carries it for long stretches.
review4: Its faults aside, The Suicide Theory is a truly touching story about our need for human contact. It's strange, goofy, surreal, and deeply gratifying.
review5: the Australian neo-noir thriller The Suicide Theory is a smartly written and satisfying take on the hitman genre featuring a standout performance from Steve Mouzakis.

title: Boulevard
review1: Boulevard itself moves toward an obvious conclusion with no surprises along the way; it runs out of steam after about an hour.
review2: While it's all too clear that Nolan is unhappy - he also has an ailing dad to care for - the thoughts inside his head remain stubbornly opaque.
review3: This is certainly a believable story, but it's one we've seen before, and neither screenwriter Douglas Soesbe nor director Dito Montiel has found a way to elevate it into something that challenges or inspires.
review4: Unfortunately, the movie plods; you can always see where it's going or trying to go. It also feels incomplete.
review5: Williams delivers a performance of mannered, sometimes heart-wrenching restraint. But something closer to cautiousness tamps down the film.

title: Road to the Open
review1: The family-friendly Road to the Open is the kind of film that Hollywood rarely makes anymore: character-driven, warm, charming, human, genuinely uplifting and inspirational.

title: Safelight
review1: A bland and unremarkable tale of sad souls and dead-end circumstances from first-time feature director Tony Aloupis.
review2: Uneven would be a kind word for "Safelight."
review3: First-time filmmaker Tony Aloupis, formerly frontman of the New Jersey rock band Shadows of Dreams, serves up Americana like a stale slice of apple pie.
review4: Everything in writer-director Tony Aloupis' "Safelight" feels telegraphed.
review5: Does the world really need another indie film about lost souls living quiet lives of desperation in a heaven-forsaken one-horse town?

title: In Stereo
review1: Director/writer Mel Rodriguez III, making his feature-film debut, upends expectations with a surprisingly engrossing look at two people who stumble their way toward one another.
review2: There's no reason for the time-twisted storytelling: It serves only to leave us on unsteady ground and suspicious of our protagonist.
review3: What ensues is a dark, manic farce, as much about the destructive things we do to those we care most about as it is a cautionary tale for love-seekers in their thirties.
review4: The fun possibilities get squandered, and we are treated to a head-scratching ending that is more befitting of "All My Children" than a feature film.
review5: This is a tedious modern romance that thinks it's spouting universal truths when it's actually as myopically narcissistic as the two leads.

title: Bessie
review1: Best of all are Latifah's scenes with Mo'Nique because their energies fit and because they have the most to do with music and performance and the reasons these women are worth remembering, and re-creating.
review2: At nearly two hours, Bessie feels a lot like any other TV biopic, with unspectacular production values and a mostly chronological story structure. But it's hard not to be moved by the woman it portrays, and by the point of view it shares with her.
review3: Latifah doesn't just make us believe in Bessie Smith's claim to fame. She makes us feel for every gifted African-American singer and actor, from Smith to Latifah herself, who hasn't been given the roles and nurturing his or her talents deserve.
review4: In a cast full of strong performances, Queen Latifah stuns. Quite simply, it's the finest performance she's ever given.
review5: Viewers of Bessie will love her and want to shake her, to beg her not to squander her talent.

title: Urok (The Lesson)
review1: The kinetic yet poker-faced filmmaking renders the narrative turns especially jolting.
review2: The talented Margita Gosheva grippingly plays an assertive, hardworking, honest heroine, but that's all she'll do here. Following her static, white-knuckled strain is compelling but not exactly a delight.
review3: It's akin to watching someone get their knuckles cracked by a ruler, over and over again.
review4: The script's mordant humor only makes Nade's situation feel more bleak.
review5: A precisely paced, nightmarish thriller.

title: Backcountry
review1: Backcountry thrives in the close-quarter details: the verbal knife-pricks of a dying relationship, the jangling impact of the smallest sounds breaking silence, that dread certainty that you're completely lost and it's getting dark.
review2: MacDonald does quite well in his dramatic feature debut with solid performances from the cast. Backcountry is satisfyingly intense, although quite gory in patches.
review3: "Backcountry" inevitably brings on the bloody, but it finds atmospheric ways to depict how the bucolic hush of a nature getaway can morph into a survival nightmare for the unprepared.
review4: A couple of weekend backpackers face off against man and beast in director Adam MacDonald's accomplished, blunt-force wilderness adventure.
review5: It's beautifully tense and well-acted - the kind of modest genre picture we don't see enough of these days.

title: I'll See You in My Dreams
review1: [Danner is] clearly having a ball with this character.
review2: A touching, funny and thoughtful film that trades in honesty rather than artifice.
review3: I'll See You in My Dreams is delicate and nuanced, with writing that rejects, or at least reshapes, the cliches of movies about people facing the glare of their sunset years.
review4: The film cleverly uses the conventions more typical of romantic comedies several decades its junior ...
review5: Danner is probably the main reason to see the movie, and her screen presence is impressive; she's an actor who manages to bring gravitas to any role, and that includes her work in goofy things like Ben Stiller's Meet the Parents series.

title: Queen and Country
review1: Don't let the British pedigree and nostalgic trimmings fool you: this is no Masterpiece Theatre exercise but a broad, high-spirited, riotously funny service comedy, on par with M*A*S*H and Stripes.
review2: A wartime comedy of manners, it's a delightfully whimsical portrait of 1952 England, a time and place of class discord that's both uproarious and politically pointed.
review3: The movie is a sweet-natured, easy-going bit of storytelling, and while Bill may be the central character, Queen and Country is really a movie about England. And it's a love letter to a particular time and place
review4: The director gets all the period detail exactly right and there are plenty of historical and cultural references that evoke a sense of nostalgia.
review5: Queen and Country finds exhilarating comedy in places usually reserved for drama, violence, loss.

title: The Age of Adaline
review1: Harrison Ford's performance is the big surprise in this otherwise wonky, frequently shambling tall tale.
review2: Lively's cool, timeless poise is perfect for Adaline's melancholy reserve, the aloofness of someone from a different era, wary of letting anyone get too close.
review3: The Age of Adaline is salvaged by the performances of Lively and Ford; that is if you're brain hasn't been shutdown by fake science.
review4: Fans of more curious romantic dramas such as Benjamin Button and The Time Traveller's Wife will get the most out of The Age of Adaline, an engrossing if flawed drama.
review5: Staying 29 forever is every woman's fantasy. But, as "Gossip Girl" alum Blake Lively finds out in the predictable but endearing love story "The Age of Adaline," that blessing becomes a burden.

title: Paper Planes
review1: Kudos to this bright and breezy half-term Aussie kids flick for realising that competitive paper plane flying can unleash young imaginations.
review2: The melodrama is hokey, the family details bogus (we're supposed to believe that this modern-day 12-year-old's sprightly grandfather flew spitfires in the Second World War), and the competition element as predictable as you'd expect.
review3: Terry Norris steals the show as the irrepressible grandpa who has little intention of putting his rakish fighter-pilot past behind him.
review4: Ed Oxenbould, the talented Aussie child actor also recently seen in The Visit, gives another appealing performance in this otherwise bland and flimsy kids' movie.
review5: It's worth catching on some platform or other if you and the kids are in the mood for some pleasant Oz escapism.

title: American Heist
review1: American Heist, I want my 94 minutes back.
review2: Despite a few strong emotional beats, the crime drama "American Heist" proves as undistinguished as its generic title.
review3: American Heist has straight-to-video written all over it. Once there, I recommend you skip directly to the last act if you decide to watch it at all.
review4: Adrien Brody and Hayden Christensen work hard in crime drama American Heist but can't muscle beyond average material as yin-and-yang brothers coerced into one last bank job.
review5: Slick but derivative and forgettable on all levels.

title: Diplomacy
review1: Arestrup and Dussollier are mesmerizing as they attack and parry, argue and counterargue. They reminisce about their lives before the war and wax poetic about their families - then engage in battle again.
review2: Diplomacy will work for those who appreciate dialogue-based character films in which plot is of secondary importance.
review3: Although we know what happens, Diplomacy keeps up the suspense and pulls off surprises as Choltitz's decision reaches its inevitable ending.
review4: Its minor thrills come not from not knowing what will happen, but from watching the cagey choreography of two acrobatic minds.
review5: If you've had your fill of tony World War II dramas, this probably won't renew your interest in the genre, but the leads are fine as usual and Schlöndorff succeeds in making the stagebound material feel reasonably cinematic.

title: United Passions
review1: Even without the cloud of the recent disturbing developments, United Passions is a cringeworthy, self-aggrandizing affair that mainly benefits from its unintentional camp value.
review2: Comes across as a squirm-inducing heap of propaganda at its most self-congratulatory.
review3: One of the most unwatchable films in recent memory, a dishonest bit of corporate-suite sanitizing that's no good even for laughs.
review4: Tedious, amateurish and hilariously ill-timed ...
review5: The major players uniformly fail to bring their A-games.

title: Closer To The Moon
review1: "Closer to the Moon" draws on many of the same facts that appear in "The Great Communist Bank Robbery," but in the service of a less adventurous movie with familiar Western actors, English-language dialogue and badly strained uplift.
review2: From Romania, of all places, comes a breath of fresh air, far above the usual action film Hollywood keeps churning out with pointless abandon.
review3: Closer to the Moon is an unremarkable reenactment of a remarkable story.
review4: A provocative, darkly comedic, absurdist drama - based on a true story.
review5: Although based on a true story, 'Closer to the Moon' comes across on screen as artificial and befuddling. However, quality production values make it easy on the eyes.

title: Reality
review1: The bizarro plot threads, and dippy characters fail to connect in any rewarding way, resulting in a largely unfunny film that proves as repetitive and tedious as the 1971 Philip Glass snippet that provides its entire score.
review2: Dupieux's movie is all script twists, lacking both the naïve wonder of the films to which he pays homage and the inventive sophistication of grand Surrealist fantasy.
review3: A hilarious and increasingly disturbing series of looping, overlapping and interconnected narratives worthy of Flann O'Brien or Diderot ...
review4: Each narrative fissure further thwarts meaning. The most you can ask from a movie as nullifying as this one is that it offer wit and visual panache, which it does.
review5: A viewer can't help but take it as an artistic statement, even though nothing-not even the nods to Mulholland Dr.-suggests that Dupieux's motivated by anything more than a hankering to make something weird and funny.

title: Love & Mercy
review1: Along the way, we learn to appreciate the greatness of Wilson and discover what separated him from the rest of his group.
review2: Love & Mercy is a very well-intentioned film, attempting to explore two important times in the life of singer/songwriter Brian Wilson, but unfortunately it plays as two distinctly separate films that are on two different levels of quality.
review3: There is undoubtedly much more to be said about the intriguing, talented Brian Wilson, but "Love & Mercy" does one better than a conventional biography of the man likely ever could: it bears his soul.
review4: The parallel narratives offer an interesting contrast in persona but ultimately don't really work. Every cut to the '80s is accompanied by a desire to return to the '60s, where we are immersed in Wilson's fevered mental state.
review5: It's better than it has any right to be in virtually every capacity

title: Red Knot
review1: Stage director Scott Cohen, here making his debut as a feature filmmaker, places far too much faith in the ability of his actors to elicit and sustain audience interest while improvising their way through the tissue-thin narrative he has provided them.
review2: It's no surprise that first-time director Scott Cohen is a nature photographer by trade: he's made one of the most gorgeous movies you'll see this year.
review3: Not trusting his film's paranoid atmosphere to be sufficient, Mr. Cohen clumsily inscribes his influences.
review4: Red Knot exhibits such spot-on, heartbreaking honesty about behaviors that tear many couples apart ... that it's easy to forgive Cohen his metaphorical excesses.
review5: A beautifully-realized visual darling, Red Knot is a gorgeous metaphor for the potential trappings of marriage anchored by solid performances from its two leads.

title: Heaven Knows What
review1: Heaven Knows What feels like an authentic, sometimes painfully accurate portrait of life in New York City as experienced by the homeless, ever-hustling teenagers.
review2: Fans of the cinematic street poet Larry Clark (Kids, Bully) might go for this, though the unexpected moments of dignity and compassion that deepen his characters are in short supply here.
review3: Holmes has a face that reveals everything and nothing. Besides being strikingly photogenic, she's a natural.
review4: All this desperation and squalor reeks of authenticity.
review5: A striking portrait of addiction that doesn't say anything new - drugs are bad, kids - but it leaves a lasting and chilling impression.

title: Nightingale
review1: The careful layering of the experiences and emotions that influence Peter's choices, along with expert massaging of the tension that exists from the start, make Nightingale a sad but satisfying film.
review2: It's a performance that gets the writhing interplay of transparency and opacity in a character who has gone beyond the deep end of unhinged narcissism and self-dramatization.
review3: Nightingale is really about David Oyelowo, a magnificent actor with astonishing range who draws viewers deep down into the darkness with his character.
review4: A single-character film rests squarely on the shoulders of the actor, and Oyelowo turns in a breathtaking, visceral performance made more impressive by the strenuousness of the role.
review5: It's a gutsy piece of work, leaving the audience to contemplate the details once it's all over.

title: In the Name of My Daughter
review1: More disappointing than the film's inertia and amorphousness is its sacrifice of the real-world themes of class, money, corruption, and power. Unable to decide what story he wanted to tell, Téchiné hedges his bets and loses everything.
review2: It has its true-crime fascinations, and, until its misbegotten 30-year flash-forward to Maurice's trial, it has a silky allure of sun-kissed depravity.
review3: 'In the Name of My Daughter" is one of those French films that leave you going "huh?"
review4: It's a pleasure to take in the lush settings, to hear the delicately ominous score (by Benjamin Biolay) and to watch these actors circling each other.
review5: A fascinating, suspenseful story about obsessive love, money, the Mafia, and murder.

title: The Heart Machine
review1: A thoughtful, emotionally tricky debut benefitting from two strong lead performances.
review2: A movie that's neither ostentatious nor superficial.
review3: "The Heart Machine" neatly expresses anxieties about love in an age when technology has reshaped mating habits and urban existence.
review4: The Heart Machine rides on the low-key beauty and charm of its stars, and their easy rapport. They are believable and engaging, even as the narrative itself loses steam.
review5: Its concerns are deeper, and more richly psychological, than merely trendy probings of the zeitgeist.

title: The Only Real Game
review1: [A] clear-eyed snapshot of sports hope struggling against socioeconomic stagnation.
review2: A stirring ode to cultural bridge-building.
review3: The history lesson is fascinating, and it's nice to see an American export other than a Hollywood blockbuster engendering good will.
review4: Bank's story of the women, men, and children so passionate about their game is itself wholly absorbing.
review5: As well-intentioned, feel-good humanitarian acts go, "The Only Real Game" hits one out of the park for fanatics of America's favorite pastime or good-hearted folk with a little extra scratch in search of a new pet project.

title: Saint Laurent
review1: It captures the tense flavor of a particularly heady time in Saint Laurent's life, during which he struggled with addiction and illness and juggled relationships ...
review2: Saint Laurent was a truly mythic figure. It's a shame that Bonello's film doesn't do him justice.
review3: Repetitive, repulsive, empty while stuffed with cheap ennui and wholly lacking in either insight or inspiration, "Saint Laurent" is absolutely everything you don't want to see in a biographical film.
review4: Saint Laurent comes across as a prisoner of his own genius, at once compelling and pathetic.
review5: A flamboyant but hollow exercise in glitz and pizzazz, Saint Laurent is a riot of colors, hedonism and nonsense.

title: The Farewell Party
review1: For all its talk of death, The Farewell Party, featuring a terrific ensemble cast, is a story about life. Always honest, graceful and funny it explores with deep compassion its characters familial and romantic relationships.
review2: It's taking a strong stand on the morality of mercy killing, no doubt, but it also acknowledges the precious glory of life. It's a rare film that can smile while studying suffering.
review3: A bittersweet, wryly comic, keenly observed look at senescence from Israeli directors Sharon Maymon and Tal Granit.
review4: The gags in the movie's first half are so unapologetically mordant that I was disappointed to see them dwindle to nothing in the second, as so often happens in stories like this one.
review5: I can't recall any film ever making me laugh and cry in complete comic and dramatic balance like "The Farewell Party."

title: My American Cousin
review5: An energetic and authentic portrait of a 12-year-old girl's coming of age that reveals the mixed feelings young people have about sex, rebellion, independence, and self-esteem

title: "For Us, the Living: The Story of Medgar Evers"
Lyle
review1: With a gripping performance by Gaby Hoffmann... the first feature by its writer-director is a winningly unsettling genre exercise whose style and polish belie the constraints of its microbudgeted five-day shoot.
review2: Competently played all round and with some effective stylistic elements, this is a film that could do with a bit more ambition of its own but that still handles itself well enough, and very impressively indeed for something shot in mere days.
review3: Aided by cinematographer Grant Greenberg's visual mastery, Gaby Hoffman has you on the edge of your seat as her paranoia grows in leaps and bounds, especially as you watch her run through the streets, scamper down staircases, and Skype.
review4: The answers the movie provides aren't as satisfying as its mysteries, but it's a creepy little surprise.

title: Aloft
review1: Just when you're ready for "Aloft" to take wing, it ends.
review2: Connelly, with her signature brand of serene toughness, does tragedy very well, but she doesn't really have a character to play here; just an endless series of tight close-ups and troubled expressions.
review3: Llosa's film pushes its enigmatic and quietly brooding qualities to the point that it's inaccessible, despite some mildly intriguing spiritual story elements and skilled performances ...
review4: The majority of the film strives for ethereal lyricism but the melodrama of these lives never proves strong enough to anchor any real emotional connection.
review5: Some movies practically dare you to give up. "Aloft" is a beautifully shot, frustratingly vague and deeply ponderous mystery/spiritual journey about terminally unhappy souls.

title: Felix & Meira
review1: Delicate, warm and worried, "Felix and Meira" is a coming-of-age film about two grown people stunted by social circumstance.
review2: This is the sort of movie whose warmth toward its characters is contagious.
review3: When is an image held for too long? At what point does a shot's duration outlast its emotional information? As ardent and earnest as it is, "Felix and Meira" is a test case.
review4: There's a subtext to this love story that seems to say we're all islands, in one way or another.
review5: "Felix and Meira" raises the question: Are we happiest with a twin spirit - or with a reverse image that completes the picture?

title: 37 A Final Promise
review1: It's an awkward mix of sentiment, underdeveloped relationships and rock 'n' roll pretensions, and it never quite gels into the "Love Story" for the 21st century that it wants to be.
review2: A good deal better than any plot synopsis might make it sound.
review3: "37: A Final Promise" comes off as a paranormal and schizophrenic take on a Lifetime movie with themes of terminal illness and assisted suicide.

title: Unexpected
review1: Smulders gives one of the most natural performances of her career, and Bean's subtle, strong work announces her as a young actress to watch.
review2: A well-intentioned snooze. ... The script's high point for adrenaline is when Samantha and Jasmine make the impulsive decision to - wait for it - litter.
review3: Except for a bit of contrived conflict that arises toward the end, the connection between these two expectant mothers-who are at vastly different points in their lives-rings with a mutual kindness and compassion.
review4: Thanks to an intelligent script and the performances of Cobie Smulders, Gail Bean and Elizabeth McGovern, the minutiae of everyday life in this small, lovely film will capture your interest.
review5: Unexpected features fine performances from both women and I'd love to see more from newcomer Bean, showing grace and maturity onscreen.

title: The Ardor
review1: By the time we reached the climactic and fantastically over-the-top showdown, I realized that while the characters were indeed trying to corner the market on smoldering glances, faux-Shakespearean proclamations and in-your-face symbolism.
review2: "Ardor" lacks tension, maybe because the actors are playing archetypes: Little is said, and there are few surprises.
review3: Here is a movie that ends with a can't-miss scenario - a siege on a farmhouse in which the heroes are vastly outnumbered and outgunned - yet still fails to ever quicken your pulse.
review4: A densely atmospheric, Sergio Leone-steeped western that ultimately proves too reverential for its own good.
review5: Much of this movie is bewilderingly slow, while the big action scenes are mostly unbelievable.

title: Different Drummers
review1: There's a sense of unstructured play about "Different Drummers," a kind of ambling from one whimsical activity to the next without much regard for following rules of tidy, traditional storytelling.

title: In The Courtyard
review1: Falling back repeatedly on in-your-face symbolism - especially with regard to the specter of decline - Mr. Salvadori seems content to idle in neutral.
review2: Thoroughly nonjudgmental in its observations, Pierre Salvadori's In the Courtyard ranks as one of the funnier films about victims of depression and mental illness.
review3: I enjoyed it, and I probably won't ever think of it again five minutes after I finish this review.
review4: Salvadori explores themes and layers of the genre that are very uncommon. [Full review in Spanish]
review5: A sensitive movie that explores morality and friendship between neurotic and solitary characters. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Tio Papi
review1: [A] well-photographed, lively and lightly comic film.
review2: [a] by-the-numbers feel good story
review3: Dedio undoubtedly wrote Ray Ray as a star turn, but the character is so forcefully written to be likable - in this case, as a nebulously defined everyman - that he never feels human enough to empathize with.
review4: Doesn't try to be anything more than a soft-serve pull of treacly pandering.
review5: Bittersweet family comedy involves parental loss.

title: The One I Wrote For You
review1: In between Kauffman's repetitive platitudes about following one's dreams, the film's actors and director hit many pleasing notes.

title: 1001 Grams
review1: Gorgeous cinematography balances impeccable acting and directing for a romantic trifle that delights with design more than content.
review2: "1001 Grams" achieves a charming equipoise of levity and gravity, of formal rigor and soulful sentiment.
review3: Hamer's style is what might happen if Ulrich Seidl liked people, with immaculate balance in each shot, but the emotions in focus, as well.
review4: This portrait of an introverted soul brought out of her shell is not without its charms.
review5: Despite the weighty title, this is an extremely light, delicate art film that rarely makes a false move.

title: Fresh Dressed
review1: As rhythmic and hypnotic as the old-school hip-hop-heavy soundtrack that supports it.
review2: "Fresh Dressed" shines a light on the hip-hop fashion phenomenon, but it's not just about hip hop; it's about ambition and absorption and our need - black, white, brown, whatever - for authenticity.
review3: Much of this film is told through interviews: Mr. Kani is fascinating and also funny; Mr. Combs is cocksure; and Kanye West is appealingly hyper.
review4: Fashion is the primary focus of Sacha Jenkins' vibrant documentary on hip-hop style-and indeed, it leaves no Air Jordan or FUBU overall unturned.
review5: [An] engaging history of hip-hop fashion ...

title: Amour Fou
review1: Less than propulsive as a narrative, but provocative, instructive, consistently surprising and a kind of slow-motion thriller.
review2: Despite being inspired by actual events, it all comes off more confounding than tragic or romantic.
review3: Hausner's film feels authentically quiet and slower-paced for the time period ...
review4: It can be a strategically off-putting movie yet one that also steals under your skin scene by scene and through Ms. Schnoeink's slowly revealing performance as an ill-fated heroine turned future biographical footnote.
review5: One thing's certain: This is no swoony love story. It intoxicates all the same.

title: Manglehorn
review1: At least we get Pacino and Hunter. We may not understand why this story appealed to them, except for the fact that it gave them a chance to work together.
review2: Sure, there's an undeniable pleasure from watching Pacino and Hunter work the screen, but the syrupy, symbol-heavy script by first-time feature writer Paul Logan is weighed down further by cliches and false notes.
review3: If Manglehorn is to be remembered at all, it shall be for the excruciating first date that its title character goes on with a chirpy bank clerk he has long been chatting up.
review4: This is definitely a lonely-man-talking-to-his-cat movie.
review5: You can tell Pacino is committed to the role because he hasn't washed his hair.

title: Hidden
review1: You know how people say 'yadda yadda yadda' when telling a story, assuming that the listener can fill in certain gaps on their own? Well, Hidden is a whole movie full of 'yadda yadda yadda'.

title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl
review1: The biggest flaw in Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is right there in the title: the first word, specifically.
review2: A very ingenous prank, maybe a little too self aware, and not as good as the great films it pays homage to. [Full review in Spanish]
review3: A fresh and stimulating movie, but a little bit pretentious. [Full review in Spanish]
review4: Me, Earl and The Dying Girl is a youth tragedy, a school comedy and and exquisite movie conoseur catalogue. [Full review in Spanish]
review5: A charming and superbly made teen comedy-drama that's both laugh-out-loud funny and deeply moving.

title: Faith Of Our Fathers
review1: It's obnoxious, to say the least, to use the Vietnam War as an excuse to affirm the importance of telling all and sundry about Jesus at all times (i.e., "testifying"), under all circumstances.
review2: A clumsily told story of friendship and wartime remembrance that has a tough time serving up a halfway believable moment, let alone a moving and powerful testimony about the Lordship of Jesus Christ.
review3: This evangelical "Dear America: Letters Home From Vietnam" by way of "The Dukes of Hazzard" takes a mighty ridiculous route to righteousness.
review4: War drama has combat scenes, heavy-handed message.
review5: Message about heroics and bravery comes too late in the movie to overcome the mess that preceded it.

title: Gloria
review1: Gloria is an important film because its based on real facts, but it would've been better if it wasn't. [Full review in Spanish]
review2: A film with a mature script that never falls into the cliches of biopics or tries to be exploitative. [Full review in Spanish]
review3: Great journalistic work by Berman and an interesting directorial debut by Keller. [Full review in Spanish]
review4: For all of those who are sceptic about this movie, let me remind you its based on a serious study and it shows. [Full review in Spanish]
review5: Keller doesn't focus on Gloria's scandall and rather opts to show the real story of a woman caught up in the fame game. [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Vatican Tapes
review1: The film from director Mark Neveldine is so over the top that one can't help but imagine how the Wayans brothers might lampoon it, then embarrassingly recall them doing exactly so in "A Haunted House."
review2: In terms of characterisation and plotting, the film is utterly absurd, but taken as a fairground ride for the ghoulishly inclined, it just about passes muster.
review3: The demonic-possession subgenre isn't exactly one crammed with quality cinematic experiences, but it hits a dull, unscary new low with this inept flick.
review4: Devilish fare like The Exorcist and The Omen that rush to mind. Those classics had thrills and gore galore. This is just too tame to terrify.
review5: The Vatican Tapes has presumably been released with Hallowe'en scares in mind, but the movie only induces hilarity, with some of the daftest exorcism scenes you'll see.

title: Northern Limit Line
review1: This jingoistic war-at-sea movie, redeemed by neither narrative momentum nor fully formed characters, will test the patience of the most ardent military fanatic.
review2: For American viewers unfamiliar with the incident, watching the film by Kim Hak-soon is like being an uninvited guest at a national memorial service.
review3: An impressive, highly moving-if overlong-achievement.

title: Capital C
review1: Interviewees allude to unfunded and failed projects, as well as exploitation by scam artists, which Kundinger and Birkhofer should have investigated further.
review2: Thin but inspirational.
review3: Very effectively shows both the upside of crowdfunding and the struggles of making good on a successful campaign.

title: Hungry Hearts
review1: Rohrwacher, meanwhile, is superb as Mina, in a role that couldn't be drawn less sympathetically.
review2: A strange, harrowing, often remarkable story of love and obsession.
review3: Hungry Hearts is a troubled, troubling movie. The unrest it creates looms long after the end credits have rolled.
review4: A robust thriller with a questionable, although intriguing, commentary on motherhood and mental illness.
review5: Mr. Costanzo's attempt at rendering the fraying of minds and marital bonds draws on notions of hysteria that only shortchange his characters.

title: Paper Towns
review1: Paper Towns is particularly good at pinpointing that certain point in teenage male friendships where the guys are getting older, but they still sometimes resort to silly voices and goofy humor when the girls aren't around.
review2: After setting the scene with vivid characters and some insightful interaction, the plot of this teen comedy-drama feels like a let down.
review3: This movie's relationship to teen-romance--flirting with it, undercutting it, swooning back into its clichéd thrall--is frustrating and intriguing in spurts. By the end, it's more like it's-a-wrap than the messy, crumpled-up drafts of life.
review4: Delevingne is plain. The soundtrack is flat and bland. The film photography satisfy but does not provide. Cinematically is average with the usual voiceover that solves all kinds of problems. [Full review in Spanish]
review5: Almost in spite of itself, succeeds in saying something interesting about its teen audience before ultimately revealing itself to be entirely vacuous after all.

title: Testament Of Youth
review1: Somehow, Vikander sells it all, not with braying and big gestures, but with vulnerability, sincerity and the sort of ethereal realness that can't be quantified. More, please, more.
review2: Though the movie at times feels oddly unfinished (you wonder what Miranda Richardson, in a tiny role as an Oxford professor, is there for), it's artful and moving.
review3: As a story, it evokes a word that no battlefield nurse would ever apply to her experiences: sterile.
review4: Testament of Youth isn't a typical biopic; it's a heartfelt manual on forging ahead.
review5: Beneath all that genre eye candy, though, resides a smart and moving story that, after a somewhat slow-moving first hour, builds nicely to become an emotionally engaging drama.

title: Sunset Edge
review1: Sunset Edge has a visually poetic quality that goes a long way towards compensating for its opaquely nonlinear, barely there narrative.
review2: Full of striking images but badly overestimates the entertainment value of abandoned trailer parks for the average moviegoer.
review3: A densely atmospheric portrait of disaffected youth by artist-filmmaker Daniel Peddle that flouts preconceived notions at every unconventional turn.
review4: As uninterested in examining its chosen milieu as it is in fashioning anything approaching an engaging narrative.
review5: The one thing that's lacking? A payoff. [But] director Daniel Peddle gets great performances from his non-professional cast and expertly builds a taut and disturbing atmosphere.

title: Southpaw
review1: Southpaw has that inevitability factor .... it's tough to support a two-hour film when its course seems predetermined and it hits every familiar beat along the way.
review2: If you don't know how Southpaw is going to end, then this is the first movie you've ever seen and you should have started with a better one.
review3: Though much has been made of the physical transformation Jake Gyllenhaal put himself through to look like a real boxer, Southpaw is a fairly standard, by-the-numbers boxing melodrama that hits all those beats we're accustomed to through the Rocky films.
review4: Fuqua's film is an enjoyable enough by-the-numbers drama, with good work from Jake, Rachel and young Laurence and enough heart to keep you interested, no matter how thumpingly familiar it tends to feel.
review5: A conventional movie that stands out thanks to Gyllenhaal's performance. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Pixels
review1: Pixels is devoid of cynicism and it has a cheerfully cheesy vibe, and it's the kind of movie you'll forget about a week after seeing it.
review2: Coming up short in terms of both humour and story, Pixels runs out of lives well before the closing credits.
review3: Pixels calms down and doesn't contain a lot of internal logic, but with Monaghan and Dinklage to do the heavy lifting, it manages to stay afloat.
review4: Overlong, overcooked, overextended and over-everythinged but never amusing.
review5: Pixels' predecessors, such as Ghostbusters, had an irreverent disrespect for authority and a deadpan outlook, but few of the many elements here are developed beyond the rudimentary.

title: Tu Dors Nicole
review1: Lafleur's film is a quiet trifle that sneaks up on you, like a pleasant dream you might have and then gradually forget. Its very slightness is its greatest weapon.
review2: Martin is as desperate to grow up as Nicole is reluctant to take the next step. Both are at a crossroads that this wonderful, lighter-than-air movie depicts as a major turning point.
review3: Director Stéphane Lafleur shoots in black and white with a sure and delicate eye.
review4: The night scenes are particularly resonant, mixing humour, suspense and textured visuals. This is the kind of film dream from which you feel reluctant to wake.
review5: Tu Dors Nicole accurately recreates that feeling of youth when the summer seemed like it would last forever. As the French say, it's très drôle.

title: The Making Of A Lady
review1: The intent of the production is clear, but the execution is hopelessly mangled, leaving a picture that commences with dignity and concludes as an absolute mess.
